text: This weekend, at a few minutes past 9 a.m. EST, “CBS News Sunday Morning” will broadcast my report on this year’s Solar Decathlon. (This show’s stories often get rescheduled at the last moment, but so far it’s looking good for Sunday.)

headline: Performa 07: Scarcity Among the Riches
text: So, most of the various shows happening under the Performa umbrella don’t really get going till the end of the week; the bulk of my festival activity the last couple of days consisted of trying to figure out how to see as much as possible on this ridiculous schedule, while still going to everything else I normally see. Allan Kaprow’s “18 Happenings in Six Parts (Re-doing)” in Long Island City, Queens, was proving especially difficult to jam in. I’ve been told things that happen in Queens are easy for people who live in Queens to get to, but I remain skeptical.

headline: And the Latest Subprime Victim Is . . .

headline: Hotel Tolstoyana
text: If you haven’t been keeping up with the discussion of Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky’s new translation of “War and Peace” in the Book Review’s Reading Room, today’s a good day to check back in – if only to read Bill Keller on translation, journalism, Tolstoy … and the Eagles.

headline: Dress Codes | Pants
text: Trousers, slacks, pants: whatever men call them, they aren't saying "jeans" as often.

headline: Schreiber’s Notes: Torre’s Move Could Set Up Mattingly
text: Murray Chass pointed out yesterday that there is a danger for Joe Torre to keep managing at the age of 67 after a dozen successful years with the New York Yankees.

headline: Filling Salazar’s Running Shoes
text: “Even without a name-brand hero to inspire the masses, more than 40 million Americans did some running in 2006,” Joseph Plambeck writes in this week’s PLAY newsletter. “Gaining entry to the top marathon races, like this weekend’s New York City Marathon, has become increasingly difficult, requiring a gauntlet of qualifying runs. But many of those who do qualify in marathons don’t compete, really — they race against collapse. Would a star raise the competitive stakes, even for amateurs?”

headline: The Me in Team
text: Kobe Bryant and Alex Rodriguez, arguably the two best players in their respective sports, have made moves recently to change teams. Do you see any similarities in their situations, and would you want either one on your favorite team?Return to PLAY Newsletter

headline: Heroes: A Flooded Market?
text: Perhaps recognizing that it can only process so many applications, The Carnegie Hero Commission decided at its founding to focus on one particular kind of hero, the civilian “who knowingly risks his or her own life to an extraordinary degree while saving or attempting to save the life of another person.”

headline: Study Examines ‘Suicide Tourism’ in New York City
text: Out-of-towners traveling to New York City specifically to commit suicide have accounted for 5.3 percent of city suicides and more than 10 percent of all Manhattan suicides since 1990, according to a new research study. The two highest concentrations of such suicides took place near the George Washington Bridge, in Upper Manhattan, and in the Midtown tourism district, which includes Times Square, the Empire State Building and other skyscrapers, and most of the city’s major hotels.Nonresidents committed 21 to 40 suicides in each of those two areas from 1990 to 2004, according to the study, which is to be presented on Monday to the American Public Health Association at its annual meeting in Washington. The research paper [pdf], “Suicide Tourism in Manhattan, New York City, 1990–2004,” appears in the November/December issue of The Journal of Urban Health.

headline: Taking a Family Vacation in Christmastime Barcelona
text: We are looking to go to Barcelona between Christmas and New Year’s (two parents, a 17-year-old and a 20-year-old). Will we run into problems with restaurants, attractions and museums being closed? Where can we find nice accommodations? Thanks for any and all suggestions.

headline: Strike Deadline Passes; WGA To Hold Member Meeting Tonight
text: The Writers Guild of America has “been forging strike rules, making plans to picket and soliciting support from fellow unions,” in anticipation of a strike that could begin as early as Friday, Michael Cieply reports in today’s Times.

headline: Permanent Art, Evanescent Life
text: Isabella Kirkland, the artist I wrote about who makes intricate paintings in the style of Dutch Masters memorializing nature’s rarest plants and animals, answered a few lingering questions by e-mail this morning, and her responses are worth sharing.

headline: The Secret to Raising the Value of Eyeballs
text: Underscoring all the debates about online privacy, behavioral targeting and Internet advertising is a hard, cold reality: content costs money.

headline: The Fragility of Russian Power
text: Russia has always been a power whose ambitions exceeded its capacities. That has made for unfathomable suffering, and more than one collapse.

headline: Vince Young Is Shrinking
text: O.K., Titans quarterback Vince Young is still as big as life, but his passing numbers are falling. This isn’t a one-game reaction to his 42-yard effort Sunday, either; his passing totals have fallen five games in a row. Take a look:

headline: Interview With Barack Obama
text: The following is a transcript of an interview by Michael Gordon and Jeff Zeleny of The New York Times with Senator Barack Obama, conducted on Wednesday afternoon at his campaign headquarters in Chicago. Some of the questions have been edited for brevity and clarity, and extraneous material omitted.

headline: Clinton Beefs Up Iowa Operation
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton plans to spend roughly half of November campaigning in Iowa, according to her advisers, and her team continues to staff up there — with a key Washington-based aide heading soon to Des Moines to help run the communications operation.

headline: BofA Chief Sees No Investment-Banking Retreat
text: E. Stanley O’Neal, until recently the chief executive of Merrill Lynch, is cleaning out his desk. Charles O. Prince III of Citigroup is watching his company’s stock price fall. James E. Cayne of Bear Stearns is getting slammed in The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Joe Girardi, 32nd Manager of the Yankees
text: Joe Girardi will be introduced, in person, at a press conference that’s about to start here at Yankee Stadium. It’s pretty crowded.

headline: One Year Later, ‘It’s a Beautiful Day’
text: One year down, one to go, and the Democrats were rocking outside the Capitol this morning, with a DJ spinning the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Bruce Springsteen and, of course, U2’s “Beautiful Day.”

headline: Fright Night Scares Off Viewers
text: Halloween festivities took a chunk out of network television audiences on Wednesday, but CBS retained the most viewers overall thanks to “Criminal Minds.” That show led the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates, with 14.7 million viewers at 9 p.m.

headline: Chrysler and the Fallibility of Private Equity
text: Chrysler‘s statement Thursday that it would cut 11,000 jobs — on top of the 13,000 layoffs it announced in February — came as a surprise to many industry watchers. “The market situation has changed dramatically,” Chrysler’s chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, said.

headline: Redskins’ Campbell and Jets’ Clemens Can Relate
text: We wrote a story Sunday that looked at teams switching quarterbacks mid-season and wondered how successful those switches generally are. The research showed that teams do not necessarily improve much during the season in which they made the switch, but they do improve markedly the next season.

headline: Diller Stands by Home Shopping Network
text: HSN, the home shopping network operated by IAC/InterActiveCorp, is poised to emerge from a period of floundering, the company said yesterday as it released third quarter results.

headline: Dutch Deed Fetches More Than a Handful of Beads
text: Back in 1636, a group of Lenape Indians sold a 3,600-acre parcel of land in what is now the Flatlands section of Brooklyn to a pair of Dutch settlers.

headline: Taking Hand-Sanitizing to a New Level
text: Antibacteria mania and germ-phobia — twin phenomena in a society increasingly obsessed by cleanliness — have been in full view amid all the public hoopla over MRSA, the drug-resistant staph infection that has caused a public health scare lately.

headline: Say What? Beware of the Strawman Edition

headline: Big Brother on the Internet
text: When Internet users surf Web sites, information on where they go is often recorded and saved in ways that are personally identifiable. If you visit a site for alcoholics, or living with AIDS, or spouse abuse, that information could end up in a lot of databases — linked to you by name.

headline: The Great Facebook Team-Up?

That means developers can now write their programs only once to make them work on those sites, and others including LinkedIn, Orkut, Ning, Hi5, and the Web platforms of Oracle and Salesforce.com.

headline: How Much Was That?
text: Those of you who have been following the trail of fashion from the runways to the stores in recent seasons are probably aware that some of the most sought after pieces never make it to the sales rack. Those high-waisted pants from Givenchy and the school-boy blazers and Moroccan scarves from Balenciaga from fall, for example, were largely claimed by the house’s best customers last March — through personal shoppers or at trunk shows — before the clothes were produced. Strange to commit to a season so far in advance, but better safe than sorry.

headline: S.C. Democrats Say No to Colbert

headline: F.D.A. Is Unable to Ensure Drugs Are Safe, Panel Is Told
text: The Food and Drug Administration cannot guarantee the safety of the nation’s drug supply because it inspects few foreign drug manufacturers and the inspections it does carry out abroad are less rigorous than those performed in this country, witnesses told a Congressional subcommittee yesterday.

headline: Russia: Evidence Found in Bombing
text: The authorities said they had identified a suspect in Wednesday’s bombing of a passenger bus in the central Russian city of Togliatti that killed eight people and wounded more than 50, mostly local university students. The bomber was likely aboard the bus at the time of the explosion, said Aleksandr Bastrykin, the head of the prosecutor general’s investigative committee. Mr. Bastrykin said a search of the suspect’s apartment had turned up “elements that could have been used to build a homemade explosive device.” He refused to provide the suspect’s name or say if the suspect was killed in the blast.

headline: Giuliani Seen as Sporting Strongest Coattails
text: While members of Congress have their own 2008 elections to worry about, they are hardly disinterested spectators of the presidential race. The identity of the Democratic and Republican presidential nominees is of vast importance to Senate and House candidates facing serious challenges.

headline: Manhattan: Garden to Provide More Access
text: The owners of Madison Square Garden will modify the arena to provide greater access to people with physical disabilities, federal prosecutors said yesterday. Under the agreement announced by Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, the owners will add 50 wheelchair-accessible seats and make other changes to increase access. In a statement, a Madison Square Garden spokesman, Barry Watkins, said the owners had worked for several years to reach an agreement with the government over how best to modify the arena, which was built in 1968.

headline: Songs of Love and War From a Gamba Maestro
text: You might wonder what a viola da gamba player can do to sustain an audience year after year, but the question seems not to trouble the Spanish gambist Jordi Savall, long the instrument’s reigning star. Mr. Savall performs in New York every season, and his visits almost always include more than one concert, either on his own or with one of his three ensembles. And he rarely repeats works from a previous season’s program.

headline: Canadian Exporters Hurt by a Soaring Currency
text: OTTAWA, Nov. 1 — The morning after the Canadian dollar climbed above its postwar high against the United States dollar, Robert Hattin, the president of a company that makes custom machinery to pack products as diverse as toilet paper, cough syrup and CDs, was not celebrating.

headline: Bhutto Heads to Dubai;  Blast Kills 8
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 1 — The Pakistani opposition leader Benazir Bhutto left Pakistan today for what she said was a visit to Dubai, according to news agency reports.

headline: Art in Review
text: REVOLUTIONS

headline: Bush, Defending Justice Nominee, Sees Unfairness
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — The White House began a campaign Thursday to save the candidacy of Michael B. Mukasey for attorney general, with President Bush defending him in a speech and in an Oval Office interview, where he complained that Mr. Mukasey was “not being treated fairly” on Capitol Hill.

headline: Rules Lower Prison Terms in Sentences for Crack
text: Crack cocaine offenders will receive shorter prison sentences under more lenient federal sentencing guidelines that went into effect yesterday.

headline: M.T.A. Asks for Restoration of Automatic Dues Payment
text: After a 60-hour strike that halted subway and bus service in 2005, a state judge penalized the Transport Workers Union by taking away its most powerful money-raising tool: automatic collection of dues from members’ paychecks.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 11 about a meeting on climate change attended by Nobel Prize laureates noted for their environmental work misstated the position of the United States on the Kyoto Protocol, the international treaty aimed at fighting global warming. It was signed by the United States but not ratified by the Senate; the United States did not refuse to sign the treaty.

headline: Of Birds and Planes
text: Superman doesn’t solicit donations, but he accepts tips.

headline: Employment Report Shows Gain of 166,000 Jobs
text: A robust employment report offered investors a pleasant surprise, but an uncertain climate kept stock markets down most of the day.

headline: As Beaches Erode, So Do Solutions
text: OVER the last decade or more, federal and state funds to restore beach sand have become increasingly scarce, as government officials, taxpayers and environmentalists have argued against spending hundreds of millions of public dollars for projects that often wash away after a few strong storms.

headline: A Pacesetter in Berlin, Rop Will Try to Win New York on His Own
text: Five weeks ago, Rodgers Rop began the Berlin Marathon under strict instructions. He was to run the first 30 kilometers in precisely 1 hour 29 minutes and then drop out. His job was to set the pace for Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia to break the marathon world record.

headline: In Wild Swing, Stocks Give Up Rate-Cut Gains
text: A day that dawned bleakly on Wall Street turned even darker late yesterday as an afternoon sell-off sent the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 360 points, or 2.6 percent. Investors worried that Citigroup’s woes might be worsening and that consumers would not spend freely this holiday shopping season.

headline: Preserving Black History in the Military, at the ‘Colored Officers Club’
text: FORT HUACHUCA, Ariz. — The door to the tumbledown clapboard building, the one with the “Off Limits” sign, creaks open, and Harlan Bradford’s flashlight beam cuts through the shadows inside.

headline: Sweet, Bloody Smell of Success
text: Greatness hovers just outside “American Gangster,” knocking, angling to be let in. Based in rough outline on the flashy rise and fall of a powerful 1970s New York drug lord, Frank Lucas, the film has been built for importance, with a brand-name director, Ridley Scott, and two major stars, Denzel Washington as Lucas, and Russell Crowe as Richie Roberts, the New Jersey cop who brings him down. It’s a seductive package, crammed with all the on-screen and off-screen talent that big-studio money can buy, and filled with old soul and remixed funk that evoke the city back in the day, when heroin turned poor streets white and sometimes red.

headline: Broad Comedy
text: A plaintive portrait of a gay high school student looking for love in a small Texas town? Or a warmed-over John Waters-style farce that ridicules easy targets like evangelical Christians and petty high school bureaucrats? “Fat Girls” doesn’t know which it wants to be and ends up stranded between two concepts, either of which might have yielded a more satisfying film.

headline: The Real Climate Debate: To Cap or to Tax?
text: We interrupt our coverage of the political campaign for a few words about the cost of preventing climate change.

headline: A Fusion of Diverse Sounds and Styles, With Jokes
text: Anyone expecting straightforward bluegrass from Jerry Douglas on dobro, Edgar Meyer on bass and Sam Bush on mandolin or fiddle got just a little bit of it on Wednesday night. At the end of the trio’s concert at Zankel Hall, the musicians breezed through a banjo tune. Before then, nearly all the music they played was poised comfortably between genres: deeply rooted in bluegrass technique but toying with the parameters and options of string-band music.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Wednesday with a review of “The Leopard and the Fox,” a play about the overthrow of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan in 1977, at the TBG Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the actor playing a Washington reporter. He is Michael Crane  not Dave Cherry, the character he played.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the potential payout to E. Stanley O’Neal upon his departure as chief executive of Merrill Lynch misstated the amount of money he was paid in his five years on the job. It was more than $70 million, not “roughly $160 million.” (His payout is expected to be at least $159 million.) (Go to Article)

headline: Imus Scheduled to Returnto the Radio on Dec. 3
text: Citadel Radio and WABC-AM, one of its stations in New York City, formally announced yesterday afternoon that the station was hiring Don Imus, right, and that it would begin broadcasting his morning radio show on Dec. 3. The station said that Mr. Imus would be reunited with the cast of his former WFAN-AM show, including Charles McCord, his principal sidekick and longtime news anchor. In its news release, the station did not mention Bernard McGuirk, the producer whose on-air observation about the Rutgers women’s basketball team touched off the racially and sexually tinged exchange that got Mr. Imus fired. But the plan is for Mr. McGuirk to return in a role off microphone, said one person apprised of the station’s plans who would speak only anonymously about matters not mentioned in the release. In a telephone interview, Phil Boyce, vice president of news-talk programming for Citadel, noted Mr. Imus’s more than three decades of experience on New York City radio before adding, “The chance to get Don is something we couldn’t pass up.” Mr. Boyce said he expected other Citadel radio affiliates to carry Mr. Imus’s show, but he was not ready to say which ones. The Imus show will replace that of Curtis Sliwa and Ron Kuby. Mr. Boyce said he hoped to find another place on the WABC schedule for Mr. Sliwa but did not expect to keep Mr. Kuby, a civil rights lawyer. Asked why, he said he had no further comment.

headline: African Orphans Weren’t, U.N. Says
text: DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 1 — Virtually all of the children a French aid group tried to fly out of Chad last week had been living with family members in villages and were not orphans of the Darfur conflict, as the group claimed, the United Nations said Thursday.

headline: A Decorative Piece of Subway History Is Unearthed in a Busy Station
text: A lovely little piece of subway history on the uptown platform of the No. 1 line at 59th Street-Columbus Circle — so old it actually antedates the trains — was concealed from generations of riders by a false wall.

headline: In the Kitchen With Blobs and a Cloud
text: The writer and artist C. H. Greenblatt has “SpongeBob SquarePants” on his résumé — he shared in a 2005 Emmy nomination for that Nickelodeon series — and it looks as if he has been asked to catch Krabby Patty sauce in a bottle again with “Chowder,” his new show for Cartoon Network.

headline: Income Data Hints at Underlying Economic Strength
text: Personal income and spending continued to grow in September, a government report showed yesterday, suggesting strength in the economy even as analysts feared widespread troubles in the next few months.

headline: Guns on San Francisco Bay, and the Hiking Trails Left Behind
text: THE ballroom at the Officers’ Club is empty and silent, but it looks very much as it did when Army brass and their wives danced there in the 1950s. Gazing at the white Mission-style stucco walls, rough-hewn wooden beams, large alcove fireplaces and 100-light wrought-iron chandeliers, it’s easy to conjure up those revelers.

headline: Thomas Dawes, Musician and Jingle Writer, Dies at 64
text: Thomas W. Dawes, a rock musician and composer who wrote music for some of advertising’s best-known commercial jingles, including “Plop, Plop, Fizz, Fizz” for Alka-Seltzer and “7Up, the Uncola,” died on Oct. 13 in Manhattan. He was 64.

headline: Footnote
text: Meryl Streep will portray Julia Child in the movie “Julie & Julia,” being adapted by Nora Ephron from the Julie Powell book “Julie and Julia: 365 Days, 524 Recipes, 1 Tiny Apartment Kitchen,” Variety reported. It tells of a frustrated secretary who undertakes a yearlong endeavor to cook all 524 recipes in Julia Child’s “Mastering the Art of French Cooking.” Amy Adams is to play Julie.

headline: Girardi Will Wear Goal on His Back: No. 27
text: The mission statement is summarized in the two numerals that will follow Joe Girardi wherever he goes. The uniform number of the Yankees’ new manager is 27, and the reason is rhetorical.

headline: Musharraf Is Asked to Resist Emergency Rule
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Friday, Nov. 2 — Since Monday, American and European diplomats have been urging the embattled president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to refrain from imposing emergency rule to maintain his hold on power, a Western diplomat said today.

headline: Theater Listings
text: ‘THE USUAL FREAK SHOW’ In the mid-1980s Jeffrey Essmann was writing and performing satirical character comedy, revuelike shows that were neither theater nor exactly cabaret. “The whole East Village thing was kicking in,” he said recently, describing a scene busy with performers trying new things in joints now long gone. “It wasn’t even worth remembering the names of the clubs because they only lasted a few weekends.”

headline: Fatherhood Puts Game in Perspective
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 1 — The Jaguars’ Fred Taylor said he was dining at a Miami Beach steakhouse in the spring when a Hall of Fame running back stopped by his table to say he admired the way he runs and considered him one of the best backs in the National Football League.

headline: Drug Test Hastens Retirement for Hingis
text: A comeback that started auspiciously in 2006 for Martina Hingis shuddered to a halt yesterday, when she announced her second retirement from tennis and revealed that her decision was linked to testing positive for cocaine at this year’s Wimbledon.

headline: Gaul as a Cabinet of Curiosities and Patois
text: The Grand Canyon of the Verdon, a deep, narrow incision in the Alps of Provence, is one of the great wonders of France. The Verdon River, fast and wild, races for 13 miles between sheer limestone cliffs before emptying into the Lac de Ste. Croix, a delight for thousands of kayakers, hikers and camera-toting tourists. Yet until 1905, this natural wonder, located only 60 miles from Marseille, was known only to a few local woodcutters who descended into the canyon on ropes to cut boxwood, which they carved into high-quality balls for boules. Somehow the second-largest gorge in the world managed to hide in plain sight until the age of the automobile.

headline: Schumer and Feinstein Back Mukasey
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — The confirmation of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general seemed all but assured late this afternoon when Senators Charles E. Schumer and Dianne Feinstein, two Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee, announced that they would vote in favor of the nominee.

headline: Citing Oil Prices, Asia Starts Reducing Fuel Subsidies
text: NEW DELHI, Nov. 1 — Consumers in Asia are feeling the heat of skyrocketing oil prices — which rose above $96 a barrel Thursday for the first time — as governments start rolling back subsidies that have kept costs for gasoline and other fuel artificially low.

headline: How the Murder Case Against a Former F.B.I. Supervisor Collapsed
text: In a conference room on the 17th floor of the Brooklyn district attorney’s office, in the winter of 2005, a prosecutor and a detective investigator sat down with a woman they did not trust.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about the acquittal of a former federal prosecutor on charges that he illegally withheld evidence from defense lawyers in a major terrorism case misstated his given name. He is Richard G. Convertino, not Robert. A picture caption misspelled the surname of another lawyer and misstated his role in the case. He is Thomas Cranmer, not Crammer, and he represented Mr. Convertino’s co-defendant, Harry R. Smith III, who was also acquitted; Mr. Cranmer was not the lawyer for Mr. Convertino.

headline: Struggling Against Circumstance
text: “Love and Honor,” the final episode in Yoji Yamada’s samurai trilogy, maintains the grace and resonance of its predecessors as well as their focus on class inequality.

headline: Movies
text: MOVIES

headline: Mayor Weighs Pupil Rewards of Free Phones and Airtime
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he was considering a proposal to give some city students free cellphones and to reward high performance with free airtime, but emphasized that he had no intention of lifting the ban on cellphones in the schools.

headline: Room to Share
text: WHO Angie Wiskocil, 55, an information technology executive, and her husband, John, 55, an insurance executive, from Walnut Creek, Calif. WHAT 4-bedroom house WHERE Portola, Calif.

headline: Israel Destroys 7 Gaza Tunnels
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 1 — The Israeli military said Thursday that its forces had discovered seven tunnels running under the border between Egypt and Gaza.

headline: Job Cuts at Chrysler Go Even Deeper Than Expected
text: DETROIT, Nov. 1 — Over the last two years, the three American auto companies have vowed that their plans to slash nearly 80,000 jobs and close more than two dozen plants would be enough to transform them into leaner and nimbler competitors.

headline: Forever Drawing the World in All Its Minuscule Detail
text: He was an eccentric, disheveled, toothless and impecunious lifelong bachelor, an amateur poet and musician and an autodidact able to converse knowledgeably with experts in many different fields. And he was a genius draftsman, one of 18th-century France’s greatest. That’s Gabriel de Saint-Aubin (1724-80), the subject of a gripping exhibition at the Frick Collection.

headline: Clinton and Obama Clash on ‘Piling On’ Remarks
text: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 2 — Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama tangled today over whether women should be treated equally to men in the boxing ring of presidential politics as Mrs. Clinton backed away from her “politics of pile on” strategy portraying her as the lone woman under assault from the six male candidates at the recent Democratic debate.

headline: MySpace Joins Google Alliance to Counter Facebook
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 — MySpace and Bebo, two of the world’s largest social networking sites, on Thursday joined a Google-led alliance that is promoting a common set of standards for software developers to write programs for social networks.

headline: Girardi’s Introduction Starts the Clock Ticking
text: On his grand tour yesterday of the shell of what will be the new Yankee Stadium, Joe Girardi could peek into the future, all the way to 2009. He could smell the new concrete and see the foul poles already in their outfield places. He could envision the batting cages under the stands and where he hoped to be pressing all the right managerial buttons in the first-base dugout.

headline: Cobbling Together a Life Amid Tragedy
text: A triptych of short films set on and immediately after 9/11, “A Broken Sole” is based on a stage production by its screenwriter and co-producer, Susan Charlotte. One hopes the material played onstage, because it dies on screen.

headline: Describing American Life With Gruff Good Cheer
text: To hear the singer Steve Tyrell growl “It Had to Be You” with the aw-shucks geniality of a Texas good ole boy is to be reminded of something that can be obscured in the rarefied environment of Manhattan cabaret: The great American songbook belongs to everyone. That is what Willie Nelson demonstrated nearly three decades ago with his great album “Stardust,” in which he treated popular standards as dirt-plain nostalgic touchstones stripped of harmonic complexity and in no need of further explication.

headline: Marijuana and College Aid
text: Anything that keeps ex-offenders from attending college makes it more likely that they will be caught in the revolving door that leads to prison. Tens of thousands of people have been pushed in that direction since the 1990s when Congress passed a law that barred even minor drug offenders from receiving federal education aid. The law applies even to offenses so minor that they are normally punished by probation, a small fine or community service.

headline: Quitting Smoking: What Employers Can Do
text: To the Editor:

headline: F.T.C. Member Vows Tighter Controls of Online Ads
text: A MEMBER of the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that the agency would be exerting a tighter grip over online advertising, partly because of increased tracking by marketing companies of people’s activity on the Internet.

headline: Lundqvist Records 3rd Shutout of Season
text: After his third shutout of the season, in a game that ended with fans chanting his name, Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist ventured through the tunnel at Madison Square Garden last night and endured a few anxious moments that had nothing to do with facing shots from the Washington sharpshooters Alexander Ovechkin or Viktor Kozlov.

headline: They’re All Oldies, Dad Included
text: DISPLAYED under a padlocked cube of glass, something like the case that encloses the Rosetta Stone, were several flat, square boxes with writing scrawled on them. These were indeed much-venerated cultural artifacts. But we were not at the British Museum. We were in Cleveland, at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and the boxes contained original reel-to-reel master tapes by the Doors.

headline: A Slain Broker Is Recalled as a Loyal Friend With Nerve
text: Linda Stein, the punk-rock manager turned real estate broker who was found bludgeoned to death on Tuesday in her Fifth Avenue penthouse, was a vibrant and volatile person who aroused strong and often contradictory feelings in those who knew her, friends and colleagues said yesterday as the police struggled to find a motive in her killing.

headline: A Bitter Rift When a Boss Is the Buyer
text: “We could fire you and the entire management team,” the five directors wrote, “but that would not help our shareholders, customers or employees.”

headline: Meat Loaf Curtails Concert in England
text: The rock singer Meat Loaf, below, cut short a performance in Newcastle, England, on Wednesday night amid claims that he had told the audience it was his final appearance, the BBC reported. But Andrew Miller, promoter of the tour, said: “I’ve spoken to his doctor, and it’s clear it’s just exhaustion and stress. It’s not his last ever gig, that’s for sure.” He added that he hoped Meat Loaf, 60, would perform as scheduled tonight in Birmingham. Meat Loaf, whose real name is Marvin Lee Aday, collapsed onstage at Wembley Arena in London in 2003.

headline: Man Meets Boy, Surrenders Heart
text: Trend spotters (and actresses) take note. This season John Cusack is struggling with parenthood and worlds of sorrow: In “Martian Child” he plays a novelist widower hoping to adopt a small, broken boy, and in the forthcoming “Grace Is Gone” his working-stiff widower grapples with trying to break the bad news to his girls. In each movie the beloved is already out of the picture, which allows Mr. Cusack instantly to take possession of the screen with his trademark sensitivity. Nice guys rule, and don’t you forget it.

headline: East Coast Writers Take Their Case to the Streets
text: Members of the Writers Guild of America East took their contract dispute to the public this morning, gathering at Rockefeller Plaza to hand out fliers with their reasons for going on strike against entertainment producers. Organizers estimated more than 50 writers took part in handing out leaflets near the ice rink and a live taping of the NBC’s “Today” show.

headline: Rembrandt and Modernists at a Weekend Red-Tag Sale
text: The annual fair sponsored by the International Fine Print Dealers Association can sometimes seem like a high-class jumble sale. Dealers tend to cram their booths full of art, hanging Rembrandt etchings next to Rauschenberg silk-screens and piling excess inventory into forbidding stacks. If you are accustomed to the minimalist pretenses of most contemporary art fairs, however, the print dealers’ showcase may come as a relief.

headline: Bounty Hunter Offers Regrets for Slur
text: Duane (Dog) Chapman has apologized for his repeated use of a racial slur in a tirade addressed to his son Tucker in a private telephone conversation that was recorded and posted online, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Chapman’s statement came on the heels of the cable channel A&E’s suspension of production of “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” starring Mr. Chapman, below. In the recorded conversation posted by The National Enquirer on its Web site (nationalenquirer.com), Mr. Chapman spoke disparagingly of his son’s girlfriend, who is black, and used the slur six times in a 90-second clip. But he also said he did not care that she was black. In his apology Mr. Chapman, 54, who is based in Honolulu, said he has “utmost respect and aloha for black people who have suffered so much due to racial discrimination and acts of hatred. I did not mean to add yet another slap in the face to an entire race of people who have brought so many gifts to this world. I am ashamed of myself and pledge to do whatever I can to repair this damage I have caused.”

headline: Bloomberg Opposes Spitzer’s Latest Plan for Drivers
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came out against Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s latest driver’s license proposal during an interview on CNN last night, saying, “I still don’t think that it is where we should be.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the death of a New York City public school student who had been infected with a virulent, drug-resistant strain of bacteria misstated the given name and, because of an editing error, the title of a city official who discussed steps taken to clean Intermediate School 211, which the student attended. The official is James Lonergan, not Joel, and he is the chief executive of all school facilities, not the head of school facilities at I.S. 211.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: A War Game Supposes Scarce and Risky Oil
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — War in Iran. Gasoline rationing, at $5 a gallon. A military draft. A Chinese takeover of Taiwan. Double-digit inflation and unemployment. The draining of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

headline: Life After Securities Fraud
text: When federal marshals snapped the metal handcuffs around his wrists behind his back and led him away on a chilly December day in 2000, hedge fund manager Michael L. Smirlock wondered if his life was over.

headline: Ferndale: Fire at Foie Gras Producer
text: A fire on Tuesday killed 13,000 to 15,000 ducks at the nation’s largest producer of foie gras, the company said yesterday. The fire may have been caused by a short circuit in a boiler in the duck coop, said Michael Ginor, president of the company, Hudson Valley Foie Gras. But the loss of the ducks will not hurt the production of foie gras, he said. The ducks that died, female Pekins, had been set aside to breed with Muscovy males to produce the Moulard ducks that are used for foie gras. Mr. Ginor estimated the loss at more than $100,000.

headline: Humanity’s Ascent, in Three Dimensions
text: On Sunday, when the Museum of Modern Art’s 30-year retrospective of the sculptor Martin Puryear opens, the New York art world will find itself in what may be an unprecedented situation. For the first time in recent memory — maybe ever — two of the city’s most prominent museums will be presenting large, well-done exhibitions of living African-American artists. The Whitney Museum’s 15-year survey of Kara Walker’s work has been searing hearts, minds and eyes since it opened early last month. Now it is Mr. Puryear’s turn to weave his finely nuanced yet insistent spell.

headline: Work Starts on Minneapolis Bridge Replacement
text: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 1  Three months after the Interstate 35W bridge collapsed, construction of a replacement began here on Wednesday.

headline: New York Says Appraiser Inflated Value of Homes
text: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, accused an appraisal company yesterday of inflating the value of homes under pressure from Washington Mutual, one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders.

headline: On the Roads of China, the Buddha Was Transformed
text: What an outlandish sight Buddhist monks must have been when they first turned up more than a millennium ago in China, a land where only criminals — the disgraced and the dangerous — had shaved heads, wore patched-together clothes and begged for food.

headline: An Anthropologist Evolves With Help From Her Autistic Child
text: Are autistic children “normal” or are they better than that? It’s a question that Vivian (Lisa Emery), an accomplished anthropologist, struggles with in “Lucy,” Damien Atkins’s occasionally provocative drama about a mother who must learn how to take care of her autistic daughter.

headline: Africa’s Chance
text: Amid an AIDS epidemic, against the drumbeat of regional conflicts, overshadowed by the most abject poverty, it is easy to miss the glimmer of hope in sub-Saharan Africa. Rising prices of raw materials are helping the region achieve its best economic performance since independence.

headline: Burned Out at 14, Israeli Concert Pianist Is Back Where He ‘Really Belongs’
text: The 11-year-old pianist at Carnegie Hall 24 years ago earned high praise from a New York Times critic and a warning: “One hopes that he will be allowed his remaining years of childhood and not pushed too far too quickly.”

headline: Obama Envisions New Iran Approach
text: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 — Senator Barack Obama says he would “engage in aggressive personal diplomacy” with Iran if elected president and would offer economic inducements and a possible promise not to seek “regime change” if Iran stopped meddling in Iraq and cooperated on terrorism and nuclear issues.

headline: A Competitive Spirit Survives the Rigors of the Marathon
text: If he thought he could have been successful playing basketball or soccer or even football, Abdi Abdirahman would have poured his energy into one of those sports. He wanted to compete in something in his second year at Pima Community College, but he had never been very successful. Then he watched a track meet at the nearby University of Arizona and saw a runner finish far behind the field in a distance race.

headline: Goblins and Ghosts Spook Tv Ratings
text: Halloween festivities took a chunk out of network television audiences on Wednesday, but CBS retained the most viewers over all thanks to “Criminal Minds.” That show led the night with 14.7 million viewers at 9, Nielsen estimated. Meanwhile, ABC’s drama in that hour, “Private Practice” (11.2 million), remained No. 1 among adults 18 to 49 even as its ratings fell 15 percent from a week ago. Instead of winning the night in that demographic, as it usually does, ABC tied CBS as ABC’s “Pushing Daisies” at 8 set a new low (8.6 million) for its run. At 10, ABC’s “Dirty Sexy Money” (8.4 million) ranked second behind CBS’s “CSI: NY” (13.5 million) but ahead of NBC’s “Life” (5.8 million). NBC finished third over all, as a two-hour edition of “Phenomenon” beginning at 8 attracted just 6.4 million viewers. Fox was fourth for the night with a lineup of repeats.

headline: At the Debate: Was It Ganging Up, or Actual Debating?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Pledges ‘Aggressive’ Iran Diplomacy
text: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 — Senator Barack Obama said he would “engage in aggressive personal diplomacy” with Iran if elected president, and would offer economic inducements and a possible promise not to seek “regime change” if Iran stopped meddling in Iraq and cooperated on terrorism and nuclear issues.

headline: Feel the Love
text: BRIAN WILLIAMS: Welcome to Drexel University, the site of tonight’s Democratic presidential debate. Let’s get started with Senator Barack Obama. Senator, you’ve vowed to spend this entire debate standing on Senator Clinton’s windpipe while reducing her to a quivering mass of jelly. How do you plan on doing that?

headline: Paul W. Tibbets Jr., Pilot of Enola Gay, Dies at 92
text: Brig. Gen. Paul W. Tibbets Jr., the commander and pilot of the Enola Gay, the B-29 Superfortress that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in the final days of World War II, died yesterday at his home in Columbus, Ohio. He was 92.

headline: Gates Says Iran Gave Assurances on Explosives
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates indicated Thursday that Iran had told the Baghdad government that it would work to stem the flow of high-powered explosives into Iraq, though he also questioned the credibility of the pledge.

headline: Blame the Colts for the New-Look Patriots
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 31 — The transformation of the New England Patriots would probably have happened eventually, because Coach Bill Belichick does not need anyone else to point out the deficiencies in his team.

headline: Judges on Other Side of the Bench Plead Not Guilty
text: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 1 — At times, the proceeding seemed much like a reunion of longtime friends. But it wasn’t.

headline: New Haven: Murder Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
text: A man accused of murder in the killings of a Cheshire woman and her two daughters in July pleaded not guilty yesterday, while his lawyers accused the Cheshire Police Department of leaking details about the case to a local newspaper. The suspect, Steven Hayes, 44, of Winsted, also waived his right to a probable-cause hearing in his 10-minute appearance under heavy security in State Superior Court. A second man, Joshua Komisarjevsky, 27, of Cheshire, pleaded not guilty on Tuesday. The men are charged in the deaths of Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her daughters Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11, in a home invasion on July 23. Judge Richard A. Damiani scheduled a hearing for Tuesday to consider the defense lawyers’ request for a gag order. Lt. Jay Markella of the Cheshire police said the lawyers’ allegations were unsubstantiated.

headline: Hula Hoops, Marathon Piano, Revisited Happenings: Artists, Start Your Concepts
text: Performa 07, the second edition of New York City’s much-promoted performance art biennial, is up and running and a lot bigger than the first time around. Some of the events qualify as dance; a few as theater; most fall somewhere in between, in the vast, anarchic ocean of blarney and bliss that is contemporary art.

headline: National Archives Gets Catalogs of Looted Art
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — The National Archives announced on Thursday that it would acquire two photograph albums retrieved by an American serviceman during World War II that catalog art looted by the Nazis in France.

headline: 3 G.I.’s Die in Iraq’s North; Baghdad Civilian Toll Falls
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 1 — Three American soldiers died in attacks in northern Iraq, the military announced Thursday, while in troubled Diyala Province at least 14 Iraqis were killed in three incidents.

headline: Prostates and Prejudices
text: “My chance of surviving prostate cancer — and thank God I was cured of it — in the United States? Eighty-two percent,” says Rudy Giuliani in a new radio ad attacking Democratic plans for universal health care. “My chances of surviving prostate cancer in England? Only 44 percent, under socialized medicine.”

headline: A Russian Doctor Whose Wife Disappeared Is Charged With Insurance Fraud
text: A Russian doctor whose wife left their Upper East Side apartment to walk a dog in March 2003, and was found drowned in the East River two months later, was arrested yesterday and charged with insurance fraud.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the bequest of 18 paintings to two British museums misspelled the given name of one artist whose work is included in the bequest. He is Lucian Freud, not Lucien.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about “The Star Machine,” by Jeanine Basinger, misspelled the given name of an emerging star who appeared in the 1932 film “Three on a Match.” She was Ann Dvorak, not Anne.

headline: With Coles Likely Out, Jets Focus on Basics
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 1  Laveranues Coles joined the Jets for practice Thursday, but he wore a knit cap, a green sweatshirt and green sweat pants instead of a helmet, shoulder pads and shorts, like the other players. That was not a good sign.

headline: The Churn
text: People

headline: Senator Schumer’s Statement
text: Following is the statement issued today by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, announcing that he will vote in favor of President Bush’s nominee for attorney general, Michael B. Mukasey.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: 2 Winning Drug Tests, One Expected and One a Surprise
text: An experimental drug from Vertex Pharmaceuticals helped cure more than 60 percent of patients with a tough-to-treat form of hepatitis C, according to data to be presented at a medical meeting that starts today.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Governor, Under Inquiry, Sees Politics
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — The Democratic governor of Puerto Rico says he has been improperly made a target of Justice Department prosecutors who began by looking into campaign contributions and have since broadened their efforts with a grand jury inquiry including subpoenas of his college transcripts and even questioning about whether he has had a hair transplant.

headline: Manhattan: Workers’ Wages Recovered
text: The United States Department of Labor announced yesterday that it had recovered more than $66,000 in back wages on behalf of 46 workers at seven nail salons in New York City. The department said it had uncovered minimum-wage and overtime violations as part of an initiative to help low-wage workers. The department found violations at Classic Nails; Nails on 54th; Fifth Avenue Beauty; Hair, Nails and Tanning; and several other salons.

headline: Verizon to Put Executive Pay to Shareholder Vote
text: Directors at Verizon Communications, under fire from shareholders over executive pay practices, said yesterday that they would put the company’s compensation plans to an annual vote by investors beginning at its general meeting in 2009.

headline: Starting Over in Texas
text: Texas is reeling from the allegations of brutality, neglect and sexual abuse that have rocked its juvenile justice system. Heads have rolled and reforms signed into law this summer by Gov. Rick Perry have eased the crisis, for the moment. The only real way to remedy the situation is to raze Texas’s deeply flawed system and build a new one from the ground up.

headline: A Modern Marketplace for Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox
text: BEIT SHEMESH, Israel — When Larry Pinczower switches on his cellphone, the seal of a rabbinate council appears. Unable to send text messages, take photographs or connect to the Internet, his phone is a religiously approved adaptation to modernity by the ultra-Orthodox sector of Israeli life.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Oct. 12 about Bud Ekins, a motorcycle and auto stunt driver, referred incorrectly to two of his stunts in the 1968 crime thriller “Bullitt.” Mr. Ekins drove a Ford Mustang, not a Dodge Charger, as he doubled for Steve McQueen in part of the famous chase scene; the villains were in the Charger. In another scene, in which he laid down his motorcycle in front of a skidding truck, he played an innocent stranger who had been riding by; he was not doubling for Mr. McQueen.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Darfur’s Many Horrors, and Glimmers of Hope
text: In “Darfur Now,” Theodore Braun’s absorbing documentary about the atrocities in Darfur, the westernmost region of Sudan, Don Cheadle poses a fundamental question facing moviegoers attending a film about African strife: How do you respond to an event as difficult to understand as a government-sponsored mass murder of part of a country’s civilian population?

headline: Bronx: Man Sentenced for Child’s Death
text: A Bronx man convicted of manslaughter last month in the fatal beating of his girlfriend’s 4-year-old son was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 15 years in prison. The man, Jose Calderon, 19, left, was convicted on Oct. 17 for acting recklessly in the beating death of the boy, Quachaun Browne, in January 2006. Quachaun’s mother, Aleshia Smith, 28, pleaded guilty this year to manslaughter for failing to seek immediate medical attention for her son. She is serving 2 ½ to 7 ½ years in prison.

headline: J. K. Rowling Fights and Writes
text: J. K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series, and Warner Brothers, which makes the movies based on the books, have sued a Michigan publisher over its plans to publish a book version of a fan Web site that includes material like lists of spells found in the books and a catalog of magical creatures, according to The Associated Press. The site is edited by a middle-school librarian, Steve Vander Ark, and is known as the Harry Potter Lexicon (hp-lexicon.org). Ms. Rowling gave it a Fan Site Award in 2004 but said that plans to publish its content as a book would interfere with her own intention to compile a Harry Potter encyclopedia. In a statement released by Warner Brothers, Ms. Rowling said she could not “approve of ‘companion books’ or ‘encyclopedias’ that seek to pre-empt my definitive Potter reference book for their authors’ own personal gain.” Separately, The Associated Press reported that Ms. Rowling has completed her first book since writing the final installment in the Potter series, a collection of fairy stories titled “The Tales of Beedle the Bard.” Only seven copies are being printed, and one will be auctioned at Sotheby’s on Dec. 13 with a starting price of $62,000. Proceeds are designated for the Children’s Voice, a charity for vulnerable children in Europe.

headline: To Marine’s Father, Suit Is More Than Money
text: BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 —After a year and a half of anger, grief and legal maneuvering, the father of a marine killed in Iraq has said the success of his suit against a fundamentalist sect that picketed his son’s funeral means more than the jury’s $10.9 million damage award on Tuesday.

headline: Carelessness by London Police Cited in ’05 Killing
text: LONDON, Nov. 1 — London’s police force on Thursday was found guilty of putting the public at risk during a counterterrorism operation in 2005 that led to the killing of an innocent Brazilian electrician on a subway train.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about African-American executives misstated the employment plans of Time Warner’s chief executive, Richard D. Parsons. Mr. Parsons’s contract with Time Warner expires in May; he has not announced plans to retire in March.

headline: China Bars Exports by 750 Toy Makers
text: BEIJING, Nov. 1 — Chinese regulators said Thursday that they had suspended the export licenses of more than 750 toy companies because of quality control problems, according to the state-controlled media.

headline: An Online-Gaming Pioneer Is Back, and This Time He’s Banking on Sci-Fi
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — At the age of 46, Richard Garriott is an old man by video game standards. In fact, when it comes to games on personal computers, he could be fairly described as the old man.

headline: Manhattan: Five Wounded in Union Square
text: Four people were shot and one was stabbed in Union Square early yesterday, the police said. The shooting took place about 12:45 a.m. at Union Square West and East 14th Street. The shooting victims, young men ages 19, 18, 19 and 15, were taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where they were in stable condition, the police said. Officers who responded to a report of shots also found an 18-year-old man who had been stabbed, the police said. He was in serious condition at St. Vincent’s Hospital. The police said the matter was under investigation and could not say what led to the violence.

headline: After Charmed Season, Cavaliers Must Regroup
text: INDEPENDENCE, Ohio, Nov. 1  In his new commercial, LeBron James makes the highly counterintuitive, almost comical claim, “You don’t want to be LeBron James.” There are, it seems, some burdens to being rich, young, famous and responsible for the hoop dreams of your home state.

headline: New Canaan: State Sues Over F.A.A. Plan
text: Gov. M. Jodi Rell announced yesterday that the state had filed a lawsuit to block a new Federal Aviation Administration plan to reroute as many as 150 planes a day over southwestern Connecticut to relieve congestion. At New Canaan Town Hall, she said that the agency, contrary to federal law, had failed to consider safety and environmental issues and the effect on residents’ quality of life.

headline: Writers Say Strike to Start Monday
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2— Hollywood’s two decades of labor peace shattered Thursday night, as movie and television writers declared they would embark on an industrywide strike for the first time since 1988, when both writers and Teamsters walked out.

headline: Lobbyist With Friends of All Stripes Joins Spitzer Staff
text: After several tumultuous months of scandal, political missteps and sinking poll numbers, Gov. Eliot Spitzer is adding an affable, well-connected Albany lobbyist to his inner circle to help shape strategy as his first year in office comes to a close.

headline: Effort to Save Everglades Falters as Funds Drop
text: MIAMI, Oct. 31 — The rescue of the Florida Everglades, the largest and most expensive environmental restoration project on the planet, is faltering.

headline: Winehouse Appeals in Marijuana Case
text: The lawyer for the British pop singer Amy Winehouse, below, said yesterday that she will appeal her fine last month for marijuana possession in Norway because she did not understand that under Norwegian law, accepting a fine amounts to pleading guilty, The Associated Press reported. The lawyer, Ole Kvelstad, contended that she had been questioned without legal representation or an interpreter and had not understood the Norwegian-language charges she signed. He said that pleading guilty in a drug case could have serious consequences when Ms. Winehouse, who has spoken openly about her taste for marijuana and alcohol, seeks to enter the United States. Police Attorney Rudolf Christoffersen of Bergen said she was questioned by an English-speaking officer, who translated the charges and explained the consequences of accepting the fine. Ms. Winehouse and her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, were arrested in Bergen on Oct. 18 and held overnight on charges of illegal drug possession. They were released the next morning after paying fines of $715 each for possessing a quarter-ounce of marijuana.

headline: In Recordings From Jail, Polygamist Had Doubts
text: DENVER, Nov. 1 — The polygamist sect leader Warren S. Jeffs, in a series of jailhouse conversations recorded in January in Utah, renounced his role as a prophet of God and expressed remorse over “immoral actions with a sister and a daughter” when he was 20 years old, according to court documents.

headline: In Pledge to Voters, Edwards Reflects on His Wife’s Fight With Cancer
text: Former Senator John Edwards began running this 60-second advertisement yesterday in Iowa. It is the campaign’s first major television buy, kicking off an advertising series in the lead up to the caucuses.

headline: Friends Sitting Around a Campfire, Telling Stories About a Legend
text: When the Clash was labeled “The Only Band That Matters,” it may have been record company hype, but when I was a teenager, there was probably no band that mattered more to me. The idealism, the earnest anger, the democratic, sometimes clumsy way of mixing styles and sounds — I am almost as susceptible to it now as I was at 15. This is all by way of disclosure: It’s likely that I would have been stirred and moved by “Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten,” even if it were the straightforward, VH1-ready rock star biography it might, at first, appear to be. The film, however, is much more than a biography of the Clash’s guitarist and lead singer: It’s history, criticism, philosophy and politics, played fast and loud.

headline: Queens: Clash Investigated as Bias Crime
text: A Halloween night clash between groups of youths in Howard Beach ended with two white teenagers injured and five minority suspects arrested on charges of assault, the police said, adding that the incident is under investigation for possible bias crimes. Investigators said the dispute began with a minority youth approaching whites and glaring at them. A white youth tossed an egg toward him, but missed, the police said. Then, 30 to 40 minority youths gathered and chased the whites, two of whom ran into a McDonald’s restaurant. Some minority youths pursued them, the police said, punching one in the face and hitting the other with a stickball bat, causing a head injury requiring seven staples and an overnight hospitalization. One antiwhite epithet was reported by a restaurant worker. The attack occurred in Howard Beach, a predominantly white community where racial tension and violence have flared before. In 1986, Michael Griffiths, one of three black visitors fleeing an attack by whites, darted into a street and was hit and killed by a car.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the potential payout to E. Stanley O’Neal upon his departure as chief executive of Merrill Lynch misstated the amount of money he was paid in his five years on the job. It was more than $70 million, not “roughly $160 million.” (His payout is expected to be at least $159 million.)

headline: Japan Ends Afghan Naval Mission
text: TOKYO, Nov. 1 — Japan’s Defense Ministry ordered home its naval ships from the Indian Ocean on Thursday, ending for now a six-year mission in support of the war in Afghanistan that raised the nation’s military presence overseas but has recently drawn increasing criticism domestically.

headline: Sales at Ford Decrease for the 12th Month in a Row
text: DETROIT, Nov. 1 — The Ford Motor Company posted its 12th consecutive monthly decline yesterday, while General Motors and Toyota Motor each gained market share in the United States in October on higher truck sales.

headline: Astronaut to Make Risky Spacewalk on Saturday
text: Astronauts will take part in an unusually risky spacewalk tomorrow in an effort to mend a torn solar array on the International Space Station.

headline: Taliban Retreat Is Seen After an Advance Near Kandahar
text: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan, Nov. 1  Afghan officials said on Thursday that several hundred Taliban fighters had withdrawn from a strategic area near Kandahar, southern Afghanistan’s largest city, ending two days of clashes just outside it.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Tapped Out, but Hopeful: A Break in Texas’s Oil Decline
text: CRANE, Texas — The North McElroy oil field here in West Texas has long been a tableau of rusty tanks and worn-out pump jacks. “Not in Use” is painted across broken electrical panels affixed to an abandoned building.

headline: Cut the Scary Music: Here Sharks Are More Endangered Than Dangerous
text: The ocean is just large enough to contain the ambition of “Sharkwater.” This beautiful and horrifying debut feature by the underwater cameraman Rob Stewart of Toronto characterizes the depletion of the world’s shark population as an ecological catastrophe with dire consequences for humanity.

headline: New England Style, Little Known and Liking It
text: AT first glance, Tiverton, R.I., may seem like just another small-town window onto the past. It has the character of a bygone Cape Cod with all its seaside charm, complemented by the nostalgic smell of fried clams in the air. But it doesn’t have the Cape’s trauma of heavy traffic and the swarms of tourists.

headline: Being Kept in the Dark on Wall Street
text: It’s time for sunlight on Wall Street.

headline: Florida: Ruling on Lethal Injection
text: The Florida Supreme Court unanimously ruled that the state’s new methods for carrying out lethal injections, changes prompted by a botched execution in December, do not violate the United States Constitution’s prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. The decision could clear the way for the scheduled execution on Nov. 15 of Mark D. Schwab, who was convicted in the 1991 killing of Junny Rios-Martinez, 11, of Cocoa, Fla. The court did not specifically rule on Mr. Schwab’s request for a stay of execution. “At this time, there is nothing prohibiting Schwab’s execution from taking place as scheduled,” said Sandi Copes, spokeswoman for Attorney General Bill McCollum. But the case could still go before the United States Supreme Court, which staying the execution of a Mississippi inmate on Tuesday, signaling that it intends to block executions until it decides a lethal injection case from Kentucky next spring.

headline: Writers Set to Strike, Threatening Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 — Hollywood’s two decades of labor peace shattered Thursday night, as movie and television writers declared they would embark on an industry-wide strike for the first time since 1988, when both writers and Teamsters walked out.

headline: How Iraq’s Elections Set Back Democracy
text: Baghdad

headline: Correction: Home, Sweet ... Yikes!
text: An article last Friday about city dwellers whose weekend homes are a source of anxiety because of their fear of the darkness and unusual sounds of the countryside misspelled the surname of one homeowner. She is Lindsey Pollak, not Pollack.

headline: From Brooklyn to Los Angeles: Dodgers Hire Torre
text: Joe Torre’s departure from baseball’s managerial world lasted two weeks. Torre, the successful and longtime manager of the Yankees, was named to the same position with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday.

headline: Texas Haute Country
text: THE Hill Country, a swath of about 15 rural counties just west of Austin and San Antonio, has three things most of the rest of Texas doesn’t: trees, water and hills. That translates reliably into autumn color. But while a fall trip through the maples and red oaks and mountain cedar looks much the same as it did 10 years ago, another element is changing. The food of the Hill Country has matured to the point that you can have a barbecue sandwich for lunch and pan-seared scallops with chipotle lime hollandaise for dinner.

headline: The Blue Planet’s Lifeblood: A Finite Flow
text: It is impossible to enter “Water: H2O = Life,” the exhibition opening tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, and not feel excitement at its possibilities. You walk into darkened space where a tumbling aqua-lighted waterfall seems to descend from the ceiling; letters projected on its turbulent surface spell “water” in multiple languages.

headline: Militants Draw New Front Line Inside Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 1 — For much of the last century, the mountainous region of Swat was ruled as a princely kingdom where a benign autocrat, the wali, bestowed schools for girls, health care for everyone and the chance to get a degree abroad for the talented.

headline: Taking the Measure of the City’s Streets: Some Do It by Foot, Others by Car
text: Five years had passed since I last took up the challenge of the race now formally known as the ING New York City Marathon. It was gratifying to see that age had dulled neither the competitive spirit nor the stamina.

headline: F.T.C. Member Vows Tighter Controls of Online Ads
text: A MEMBER of the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that the agency would be exerting a tighter grip over online advertising, partly because of increased tracking by marketing companies of people’s activity on the Internet.

headline: Cabdrivers Sweat It Out Bidding on Medallions
text: “Dropped, dropped, still good, dropped, dropped.” Gary Kanterman was talking to himself as he ran his pen down his list of taxi drivers.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Expecting Presidential Veto, Senate Passes Child Health Measure
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — Talks seeking a bipartisan compromise on health insurance for low-income children were cut short on Thursday, and the Senate then swiftly passed a bill to provide coverage for 10 million youngsters, fully expecting President Bush to veto it.

headline: Why Writers Emerged From Behind Shield
text: When two reporters made a decision that unraveled a gangland murder trial in Brooklyn this week with 10-year-old tape recordings, they faced a choice that came down to one question: which of them had less to lose.

headline: Government Cannot Halt Oil Incentives, Judge Rules
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — A federal judge in Louisiana handed the oil industry a major legal victory this week, saying the government had no authority to suspend billions of dollars’ worth of drilling incentives when energy prices were high.

headline: It’s Alive! Creature Trods From Grave to the Stage
text: “I passed a night of unmingled wretchedness,” pants the tortured title character in one of many a palpitating passage in Mary Shelley’s gothic novel “Frankenstein.”

headline: Channeling the Bigger Games to the Lesser Networks
text: Under old-line television circumstances, the Wisconsin-Ohio State game would never have been carried on the Big Ten Network.

headline: Poplar Grove and the Residence Club at Fisherman’s Cove
text: Poplar Grove

headline: Second-Home Horror
text: To the Editor: Re “Home, Sweet . . . Yikes!” (Oct. 26): It’s not only relocated urbanites who have trouble with the country. Robert Frost, America’s poet laureate of snowy woods, golden maples and roads not taken, addresses the subject in three little-known, but chilling poems, “The Fear,” “The Oft-Repeated Dream,” and “House Fear,” which reads in part: “Always — I tell you this they learned — / Always at night when they returned {hellip} They learned to leave the house-door wide/ Until they had lit the lamp inside.”

headline: Amtrak Workers in Cooling-Off Period
text: Amtrak workers may be able to strike as early as Dec. 1, after rejecting mediation and entering a 30-day cooling-off period, the National Mediation Board said. Amtrak and several unions are deadlocked over health insurance costs, work rules and back pay dating to 2000, when the last contract was approved. Amtrak, the government-subsidized passenger railroad, has never had a strike in its 30-year history. About half of its 15,000 unionized employees belong to labor groups that rejected the board’s intervention in bargaining Oct. 25. Amtrak and eight unions were released from mediation Wednesday and began the waiting period yesterday, the board said.

headline: Those Uninvited Guests
text: YOU may have heard the story about the woman who waited until July to open her country home and found the living room shrouded in spider webs.

headline: Napoleonic Style, in All Its Imperial Self-Promotion
text: Napoleon is claiming a 21st-century moment.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about Superheroes Anonymous, a group of volunteers who gathered near Times Square to publicize their efforts to make their communities cleaner and safer, included an imprecise reference from one participant, Chaim Lazaros, who spoke at the event. He is a co-founder of the group, along with Ben Goldman; Mr. Lazaros is not the sole founder.

headline: Another Billionaire Who Wants to Be a Mayor
text: THOSE black plastic eyeglasses — reminiscent of the magnate Aristotle Onassis, say, with a dollop of the presidential hopeful Edmund S. Muskie circa 1972 — provide a nice retro touch, especially the dustspeckled lenses. But how the heck does their wearer, John A. Catsimatidis, the Greek-born billionaire toying with the idea of running for mayor of New York City (provided he can persuade sufficient politicos to see things his way), see a blessed thing? In focus, that is.

headline: A New Lifestyle in South Korea: First Weekends, and Now Brunch
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1 — When she returned to Seoul in 2000 after 10 years in New York City, Park Su-ji introduced her fellow South Koreans to an exotic way to socialize over food: brunch.

headline: A Greener Greenland
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Georgia: Plan on Retaining Lake Water
text: After a meeting with Bush administration officials, the Army Corps of Engineers announced a plan to hold more water in Georgia lakes, rather than sending it downstream to Florida and Alabama. Under the agreement, the corps would reduce flows by about 16 percent in the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River basin, a watershed that serves metropolitan Atlanta and parts of Alabama before flowing into Apalachicola Bay in Florida. At the same time, the plan would allow more water from another crucial river basin, the Alabama-Coosa-Tallapoosa, to flow into Alabama. Elected officials representing Florida and Alabama agreed to the plan, contingent on continuing negotiations over the water supply shared by the three states. The new operating procedure must still be reviewed and approved by the Fish and Wildlife Service.

headline: As Election Day Nears, Playing the Terror Card
text: In the waning days of New Jersey’s election season, some candidates for local and state office are reaching beyond the usual campaign accusations of corruption and overspending. They are charging their opponents with being soft on terrorism  or rather, with knowing someone who is.

headline: Britain Praises Iraqi Kurds’ Efforts to End Crisis
text: SALAHUDDIN, Iraq, Nov. 1  While Turkish and American officials have stepped up criticism of Iraqi Kurdish leaders for failing to curb the guerrilla fighters who have sanctuary in northern Iraq, a top British official lent his support to the Kurdish regional government during a visit on Thursday and indicated that he was confident of its commitment to resolving the crisis.

headline: Art in an Era of Big Gaps in Income
text: The stage glistened with curtains of what looked like icicle shards, turning it into a mysterious enclosure. But nothing very interesting happened inside that private place in John Jasperse’s new “Misuse liable to prosecution,” performed by the John Jasperse Company on Wednesday night at the Harvey Theater as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival.

headline: Rapier Wit and a Nose for Poetry
text: Sometimes a glass of moonshine is just what you need to take the sting out of life. David Leveaux’s disarming revival of “Cyrano de Bergerac,” which opened last night at the Richard Rodgers Theater, is a double shot of silvery hokum, sweet but surprisingly potent. And it goes down so easily, you’re drunk and misty-eyed before you know it.

headline: Schumer in a ‘Tough Spot’ After Supporting Mukasey
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — Senator Charles E. Schumer takes credit for exposing what he calls the politically motivated dismissals of United States attorneys. He takes credit for forcing the resignation of Alberto R. Gonzales. And he takes credit for President Bush’s nomination of Michael B. Mukasey to be the next attorney general.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Imus Scheduled to Return

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Israel and Gaza
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘There Are No Good Options in Iraq’
text: Following are excerpts from an interview by Michael R. Gordon and Jeff Zeleny of The New York Times with Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, conducted on Wednesday afternoon at his campaign headquarters in Chicago. Some questions have been edited for brevity and clarity, and extraneous material omitted. The full interview: nytimes.com/politics.

headline: Convict Charges Cover-Up of New Evidence in ’88 Death of Parents
text: A Long Island man appealing his convictions for the grisly 1988 murders of his parents sent court papers yesterday accusing prosecutors of a cover-up, alleging that they concealed two important new witnesses and suppressed their testimony about who they say are the real killers.

headline: As Kurds’ Status Improves, Support for Militants Erodes in Turkey
text: KIZILTEPE, Turkey, Oct. 31 — Ten years ago, Turkey ran the Kurdish region here in its southeast like a police state. All signs of Kurdish identity — the language, music, national dress — were strictly banned and subject to punishment. Checkpoints were everywhere. Going out after dark was forbidden.

headline: Clinton, a Wellesley Alumna, Comes Home to Stump
text: WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 1 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton reached out to the nation’s young women in an emotional return on Thursday to her alma mater, Wellesley College, where she told students who had started lining up at 6 a.m. to see her that “in so many ways this all-women’s college prepared me to compete in the all-boys’ club of presidential politics.”

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: The Issue Is Torture: Voices of Outrage
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Station Worthy of New York
text: After years of secrecy, the first inklings of a new and potentially workable plan to recreate Pennsylvania Station have finally become public. There are no lovely drawings yet, but the barest outline for the future railway terminal  a variation on the vision championed by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan  is now available at nylovesbiz.com/moynihanstation.

headline: Spending the Night Under the Lighthouse Beacon on the Hudson
text: LIGHTHOUSES capture the imagination in ways few buildings can. They hark back to an era when nautical travel reigned and time moved at a slower knot. Usually at the end of the road, or beyond the water’s edge, lighthouses are in some of the prettiest destinations you’ll find. They even save lives.

headline: A Drone No More: No Hive for Him!
text: Bees rarely fly in a straight line. They hover and zigzag, with a purpose known only to the collective brain of the hive. The most genuinely apian aspect of “Bee Movie,” DreamWorks’ new animated movie about, well, bees, is that it spends a lot of its short running time buzzing happily around, sniffing out fresh jokes wherever they may bloom. There is a plot — the usual big, elaborate story with the usual important messages about saving the planet, living together in interspecies harmony and believing in yourself — but it’s a little beside the point. The real fun is the insect shtick.

headline: Tropical Storm Blamed for More Than 100 Deaths in Caribbean
text: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Nov. 1 (AP)  Tropical Storm Noel drenched the Bahamas and Cuba on Thursday while rescue workers in the Dominican Republic headed out in boats and helicopters to reach dozens of communities isolated by floods and mudslides. The death toll in the Caribbean rose to 107.

headline: Colbert’s Presidential Bid Ends After a ‘No’ in South Carolina
text: GREENVILLE, S.C., Nov. 1 — Stephen Colbert’s nascent and satirical presidential campaign came to an abrupt end on Thursday when the Democratic Party in South Carolina decided he was not serious and turned down his application to get his name on the primary ballot.

headline: Impressionists Head South
text: Dozens of the Art Institute of Chicago’s great masterpieces — including Caillebotte’s “Paris Street; Rainy Day,” Cézanne’s “Bathers” and “The Bedroom” by van Gogh — will be exhibited at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth next year while the Art Institute undergoes a major renovation and expansion.

headline: Cashman Says Willingness to Spend Hasn’t Changed
text: Somehow, Brian Cashman managed to take his children trick-or-treating. Otherwise, he has hardly had a free moment since the Yankees’ season ended Oct. 8. Next week comes a trip to Orlando, Fla., for the annual meeting of general managers.

headline: The ‘Lucky Strike Extra’ Hits the Modern Era
text: The efforts by Madison Avenue to counter ad-skipping has revived a pervasive ploy from the early days of the medium as well as from the “golden age” of radio: integrating products into the plots of programs, a practice known as branded entertainment.

headline: Optimism in Central America
text: Meeting in a city that is quickly turning into the Miami of Central America, talk inevitably turned to bubbles during this week’s FIABCI Congress of Americas in Panama City. “Latin America is not subject to the problems in the real estate market in certain other countries,” Julio Fernando Noval Garciá, president of Spanish developer Grupo Mall, told attendees at the conference, one of the key regional events for FIABCI, the industry group.

headline: A Nose Is a Nose
text: Photos from the Broadway revival of "Cyrano de Bergerac."

headline: Highlights From SEMA
text: The Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show is an idea farm for automotive enthusiasts.

headline: Week 9 Gems and Gimps
text: Like many fantasy owners in 2007, I’ve found it hard to survive life in Bizarro World. Seriously, how can one retain one’s sanity in a season when Wes Welker trumps Marvin Harrison, Torry Holt and Roy Williams; Kenny Watson tops Shaun Alexander, Frank Gore and Steven Jackson; and virtually any skill player on the Browns — yes, the ones from Cleveland — is an uber-stud, with Derek Anderson serving as poster boy for the Fantasy Hall of Fame.

headline: Boardroom Mutiny at A.C.S.; the Cayne Memo
text: Where’s the memo? As many DealBook readers have noticed, our link to the internal memorandum from Bear Stearns chief executive James Cayne was broken in Friday morning’s e-mail newsletter. Here’s the right one — and sorry for the confusion.

headline: Petrobas to Take Exxon’s Stake in Japanese Refinery
