text: Brazil’s state-run Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, will acquire Exxon Mobil‘s majority stake in a Japan-based refinery, Nansei Sekiyu, MarketWatch reported, citing a story in Nikkei News.

headline: Blackstone Joins Bid for Nufarm, Sources Say
text: China National Chemical offered $2.96 billion Australian dollars ($2.7 billion) for farm-chemical maker Nufarm, inviting the Blackstone Group and Fox Paine & Company to join, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter. ChemChina would be the first state-owned Chinese company to team up with buyout firms for an overseas acquisition, Bloomberg wrote.

headline: Giant Interactive Has Huge Debut
text: Giant Interactive, an online gaming provider, priced its initial public offering in the United States above the initial range at $15.50 for a total deal size of $887 million. This marks the largest listing by a private sector Chinese company ever in the United States.

headline: Media Banking Head is Latest BofA Casualty
text: Stephen Ketchum, head of media investment-banking, is the latest person to leave Bank of America. Mr. Ketchum will be succeeded on an interim basis by Rick Swift, who retains his role as global head of telecommunications, The Charlotte Business Journal reported.

headline: Two Private Equity Firms Try Glove Maker On For Size
text: Two Chicago private equity firms have acquired a Nevada-based maker of disposable gloves. The Chicago Tribune reported that BarrierSafe Solutions International was bought by Linden and The Edgewater Funds for an undisclosed sum.

headline: Altria to Acquire Cigar Maker for $2.9 Billion
text: Altria Group will pay $2.9 billion to buy a cigar maker, John Middleton, from privately held Bradford Holdings in order to expand its United States business beyond cigarettes.

headline: Super Conduit Leaves Many Banks Cold
text: Two weeks after Bank of America, Citigroup, JP Morgan and Wachovia pledged their support for the Master Liquidity Enhancement Conduit, intended to take the sting out of the recent liquidity squeeze, other banks have chosen to look the other way.

headline: Verizon to Put Executive Pay to Shareholder Vote
text: Directors at Verizon Communications, under fire from shareholders over executive pay practices, said Thursday that they would put the company’s compensation plans to an annual vote by investors beginning at its general meeting in 2009.

headline: Cisco Secures a Deal for Securent
text: Cisco Systems announced a $100 million agreement on Thursday to buy venture-backed Securent. The three-year-old company makes security software that helps companies manage different tiers of application users.

headline: A Wall St. Switch: Good News May Be Good News
text: Update 8:35 a.m. Eastern: Sure enough, when the October employment report came in stronger than expected — 166,000 net new nonfarm jobs, modest growth on wages, unemployment level — the early indicators of investor sentiment all jumped in apositive direction. The next short-term question is whether that euphoric reaction will stick around all day and help reverse some of yesterday’s declines. The next longer-term question is whether the economy is out of the credit-crunch woods yet.

headline: ‘I Enjoy Bending Steel’
Specific Media Raises $100 Million in Second Round
text: In a second round of funding, Specific Media has raised $100 million from private equity firm Francisco Partners. TheDeal.com writes that the funds will be used to fuel acquisitions and an initial public offering of the online advertising agency.

headline: Barclays Shares Fall on Emergency Funding Rumors
text: Shares in Barclays fell the most in almost three months Friday morning on speculation that it approached the Bank of England for emergency funding.

headline: Peltz Files to Raise $750 Million
text: Nelson Peltz has filed with federal regulators to raise up to $750 million from stock market investors for a large shell company that will pursue acquisitions, according to a report in The Financial Times.

headline: Serious Materials Builds Up $50 Million Round
text: In a move to fund construction of as many as three large manufacturing plants to produce construction drywall materials, Serious Materials has raised $50 million in a Series B venture capital round.

headline: Bloomberg Calls for Tax on Carbon Emissions
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today his support for a national carbon tax. In what his aides called one of the most significant policy addresses of his second and final term, the mayor argued that directly taxing emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change will slow global warming, promote economic growth and stimulate technological innovation — even if it results in higher gasoline prices in the short term.

headline: Private Equity Looking to Go the Distance with Marathons
text: Private equity firms are flexing their muscles to get into the running game. BusinessWeek reported that as marathons, half-marathons, and other running events attract hundreds of thousands of people from around the country every year, private equity firms such as Falconhead Capital and Seaport Capital are beginning to take notice.

headline: Unable to Engage, MetroPCS Pulls Leap Offer
text: MetroPCS Communications on Thursday pulled its $7.5 billion offer for Leap Wireless International. MetroPCS, which made an unsolicited takeover bid in September, now says that despite “widespread investor and analyst enthusiasm” for a deal, it could not engage the target in “meaningful negotiations.”

headline: More Cuts at Cerberus-Owned Chrysler
text: Chrysler announced Thursday it would eliminate 11,000 hourly and salaried jobs in the United States and Canada and cut shifts of workers at five plants. The decision comes on top of a plan, announced in February, to eliminate 13,000 jobs and close a factory in Newark, Del. Taken together, Chrysler will be reducing its 2006 work force of about 80,000 employees by 30 percent.

headline: Whose Climate Is It, Anyway?
text: I first encountered lots of young people focused on global warming at the 2005 round of climate-treaty talks in Montreal.

headline: Life After Securities Fraud
text: When federal marshals snapped the metal handcuffs around his wrists behind his back and led him away on a chilly December day in 2000, Michael L. Smirlock, a hedge fund manager, wondered if his life was over. Hours earlier, Mr. Smirlock had received a call from his lawyer, William Brodsky, telling him that he had been indicted for securities fraud.

headline: MySpace Joins Google Alliance to Counter Facebook
text: MySpace and Bebo, two of the world’s largest social networking sites, on Thursday joined a Google-led alliance that is promoting a common set of standards for software developers to write programs for social networks.

headline: Stuff I’m Reading, Listening to, Watching
text: 1. While we’re on the subject of résumés, I stumbled onto this handy post by Pinny Cohen on Web Worker Daily on how to “keyword optimize” your résumé (that is, load it with the buzz words that will get you noticed). Clearly, I like what they are doing over at Web Worker Daily since I seem to be unable to last a week without linking to them.

headline: Boutique Banks Enjoy Being the Little Guy
text: Most of Wall Street’s big names had a rough third quarter, but not so smaller advisory firms like Lazard and Greenhill & Company. Breakingviews points out a reason for that: it’s their size and model, the very self-imposed limitations that keep them from reaching the breadth of their bigger rivals.

headline: The Early Word: Obama’s Iran Resolution
text: Barack Obama reiterated that he’s willing to reach a diplomatic hand out to Iran if elected president. In an exclusive one-hour interview with Times reporters Michael R. Gordon and Jeff Zeleny, Mr. Obama again positioned himself as the alternative to Hillary Rodham Clinton:

headline: I.R.S. to Examine Private Equity, Hedge Fund Tax Returns
text: The Internal Revenue Service is to examine the tax returns of private equity houses and hedge funds amid evidence that many partners in such firms do not file returns or may have failed to correctly account for their affairs.

headline: Merrill Hedge Fund Deals Likely to Be Examined
text: In a bid to cut its exposure to mortgage-backed securities, Merrill Lynch engaged in deals with hedge funds possibly designed to delay its heavy losses, according to a media report.

headline: The Bear Stearns Memo: Cayne Speaks
text: After The Wall Street Journal published a scathing profile Thursday of James Cayne, Bear Stearns‘ chief executive — complete with accusations that he regularly smoked pot and left the office at key moments to play golf or bridge — Mr. Cayne shot back in a memorandum to his staff.

headline: Blowback
text: It’s not often that an obituary sets off a blogstorm, but in the case of Brig. Gen. Paul Tibbets, the man who piloted the Enola Gay over Hiroshima, it was probably to be expected.

headline: Slain Real Estate Broker Stirred Strong Feelings
text: Linda Stein, the punk-rock manager turned real estate broker who was found bludgeoned to death on Tuesday in her Fifth Avenue penthouse, was a vibrant and volatile person who aroused strong and often contradictory feelings in those who knew her, Anne Barnard reports in an article examining Ms. Stein’s life and mysterious death.

headline: iRock
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Busted A.C.S. Deal Sparks Boardroom Mutiny
text: “We could fire you and the entire management team,” the five directors wrote, “but that would not help our shareholders, customers or employees.”

headline: Stray Questions for: Bill McKibben
text: Bill McKibben’s books include “The End of Nature,” “Deep Economy” and “Fight Global Warming Now.”

headline: A Reader’s Obligations
text: Thursday night, with Sam’s strongly-voiced, fair-minded support of Mr. Pevear and Ms. Volokhonsky’s translation of “War and Peace” much on my mind, I sat in an auditorium at the Morgan Library, listening to the new curator of literary and historical manuscripts, Declan Kiely, speak on some of the gems in the library’s collection. One of these was a handwritten draft of a broadcast E.M. Forster delivered on the BBC Radio’s Far Eastern Service in 1943, about Marcel Proust and “The Remembrance of Things Past.”* In the broadcast, Forster argued that “Remembrance” was the second greatest novel in European literature (“War and Peace” being the first, though he scants it in the essay); and that, as such, readers needed to understand better how to read Proust to get from him what they should. “Be patient with him,” Forster urged. “He does not go with a swing, and only gradually draws you into his mesh. And be intelligent. It is so easy to read books stupidly, not with our full powers, and Proust makes no concessions to stupidity. Some writers — and they are great writers — do make concessions. Dickens does, for instance, and even Tolstoy does. Proust doesn’t. He expects a constant awareness, both from the mind and from the senses.”

headline: Clinton Backer Goes on ‘Faith Tour’
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The Caucus came over to Greenville Thursday to catch the Rev. Marcia L. Dyson, an African-American minister from Washington, D.C., who is touring South Carolina as part of a “faith tour” on behalf of Senator Hillary Clinton. This is a new effort by the Clinton campaign to reach black women through religion.

headline: Merrill Deals Bring Back Barge-Gate Memories
text: Is that a Nigerian barge on the horizon?

headline: Giuliani Seen as Sporting Strongest Coattails
text: In his Web column today, Carl Hulse writes that publicly and privately, some senior Republicans are beginning to express the view that former New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may be the Republican candidate who provides the most help to Republican Congressional candidates who need it the most. Go to Column

headline: Friday Morning Kickoff
text: The Ohio State Buckeyes have more than their share of doubters this season. But in a season where up often turns out to be down, the Buckeyes have simply kept winning and find themselves at the top of the polls. That, writes SI.com’s Austin Murphy, is due in large part to quarterback Todd Boeckman.

headline: Heisman Contenders Are Grasping at Straws
text: Could there be a sea change in the Heisman Trophy race? One of the nation’s most prominent Heisman straw polls suggests just that.

headline: Making Up Jobs
text: Today’s employment report is mediocre at best. But to understand that, you have to look past the headline numbers.

headline: Performa 07: Beyond Boxes and Labels
text: I’m still digesting Adam Pendleton’s new piece, “The Revival,” which had only two showings, both last night. It’s one of Performa’s 10 commissions, and it’s the sort that is likely to bedevil certain people who like their work kept in easy boxes (grant panelists, marketing departments, journalists).

headline: ‘Looks Like He’s Been Riding One’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: You folks have a good Halloween last night? Boy, it was one of those nights. I don’t know what the heck happened to me last night. I woke up this morning dressed as Ugly Betty.

headline: ‘Worst Performance Since Their Honeymoon’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Well, Domino’s pizza said they delivered more than 1 million pizzas last night, nearly a 50 percent increase over a typical Wednesday. See, this is how you know Americans are getting too fat, when we can’t hand out chocolate and candy without eating pizza at the same time.

headline: E-Commerce Vids Up
text: J. Crew, long known for immaculately wholesome models and looks, has decided to push its image of Fresh-Faced Class just a little harder.

headline: Living It Up at the Hotel Pennsylvania
text: The Hotel Pennsylvania, across Seventh Avenue from Pennsylvania Station between West 32nd and 33rd Street, has been through a lot of names over the years. According to the Encyclopedia of New York City, it opened in 1919 under that name, and was successively called the Hotel Statler, the Statler-Hilton Hotel, the New York Statler Hotel, the New York Penta Hotel, the Hotel Pennsylvania (again), and the Ramada Hotel Pennsylvania.

headline: Socialized Rudy
text: Sure enough, Rudy Giuliani got his prostate treatment from a government-run insurance plan, very similar to the plans that would be available to all Americans under the Democratic health care proposals. Joe Conason has the goods.

headline: The Barry Bonds-Hall of Fame Staredown
text: Back in September, Marc Ecko certainly sounded as if he were delivering the last word on the decision to brand Barry Bonds’ record-breaking home run ball, which he owns, with an asterisk and then donate it to the Hall of Fame.

headline: Alonso leaves McLaren
text: Retrospectively, it looks like the decision for Alonso to leave McLaren might have been something on both Ron Dennis’s and Alonso’s minds for a lot longer than we may have thought. The McLaren statement said “The mutual parting of ways has not been discussed until now, since it was felt that any such discussion could have seriously disrupted the team’s and Fernando’s 2007 Formula 1 World Championship challenge. Both parties believe that this was the right decision.”

headline: ‘Made by Chimps’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Child labor activists are protesting the Gap. They’re protesting the Gap because there are clothes being sold there that are made by kids. Yeah. Even worse, the clothes at Gap Kids are made by babies, and the clothes at Baby Gap are made by chimps.Watch Conan O’Brien

headline: Arctic Warming in the Last Century, and Now
text: The Competitive Enterprise Institute, which is fighting hard against treaties or legislation limiting greenhouse gases, has pointed afresh to old media coverage pointing to “unprecedented” Arctic ice retreats and warming early in the 20th century.

headline: Merrill Denies Making ‘Inappropriate Transactions’
text: Responding to a Wall Street Journal story that said it tried to use questionable deals with hedge funds to delay potential write-downs, Merrill Lynch has denied doing anything wrong. The rebuttal did little to reverse the sharp decline in the company’s stock, however.

headline: Giuliani Weighs Veep Choice (Already!)
text: ROCK HILL, S.C. — Is Rudolph Giuliani already measuring the drapes?

headline: Writers Close To Setting Strike Date
text: The Writers Guild of America will likely begin to strike on Monday. “The WGA board was to meet Friday morning to approve the strike and set a time for the first picket lines. A strike captains’ meeting was set for Saturday morning,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Clinton’s ‘Pile-On Politics’
text: Updated Nearly three days after the Democratic debate Tuesday night, Senator Hillary Clinton’s post-forum tactics — complete with her video titled “The Politics of Pile On” and her remarks about the all-men’s club of politics — have reverberated with more buzz and backlash than her much-criticized performance in Philadelphia.

headline: Booked
text: The image at right – a somewhat defaced copy of “The Body Politic,” a 1988 novel by Lynne Cheney and Victor Gold – is taken from a gallery of photographs posted by a volunteer at a county jail at Wisconsin. All the images are from books in the prison’s library.

headline: Cellphones as Incentives for Students? Maybe, Says the Mayor
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is certain that cellphones should not be used in school. That much has not changed. And yet …

headline: When in Rome, Don’t Miss the Pope…
text: Now I am not at all religious. But I’ve always thought that one of the great experiences that most visitors to Rome overlook is the chance to see the Pope — live and in action. Of course, they visit the Colosseum, the Trevi Fountain and the Vatican Museums. So why not check out the Pope himself? It is a bit of living history and you can see the Pope without much trouble (no lines, no metal detectors!), when he delivers his weekly message to the crowds in St. Peters Square.

headline: Bond for Giuliani
text: Another day, another Senator endorses Rudolph W. Giuliani. Senator Christopher S. Bond, a Missouri Republican, announced his support for Mr. Giuliani this morning in Washington saying in a statement, “America is hungry for a President who will say what he means, and do what he says.’’

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em
text: After a two-week sojourn to Thursday, the picks return to Friday this week. Let’s hope the move will bring better luck to some of our prognosticators (especially the poor soul currently occupying third place). As always, we can expect a surprise or two this Saturday. Will our “experts” know where those shockers might be coming from? Check out the picks and see. And if you think you know better, by all means, send your choices into the comments section.

headline: New Romney Ad Uses Fox Debate Video
text: In a new television ad introduced today, Mitt Romney replays his attacks on Hillary Rodham Clinton from last week’s Republican debate, where he likens her experience to an “internship.”

headline: Obama Tries to Kick the Habit
text: Senator Barack Obama is using nicotine gum to help him quit smoking. Now the question is, can he quit the gum?

headline: According to Down Under, It’s All Over
text: Oh, Australia: Great beaches, shrimp on the barbie, Iraq War optimism … huh?

headline: Edwards Issues Video Critical of Clinton
text: The Edwards campaign is hitting both ends of the spectrum with their media releases. It followed up the “Heroes” television commercial release, replete with flags fluttering and working-class images, with a new video, emailed today to reporters, called “The Politics of Parsing” and featuring images of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Correcting a Michael Vick Profile
text: When the editors at Atlanta Magazine convened for a staff meeting on how to cover the Michael Vick saga, they knew “we were as much to blame as anyone else,” said Rebecca Burns, the magazine’s editor in chief.

headline: That Love Letter to Vick? We Take It All Back
text: Four years ago, Atlanta Magazine published a glowing profile of the Falcons’ star quarterback, Michael Vick, who is now suspended from the N.F.L. and awaiting sentencing on federal charges stemming from an illegal dogfighting ring, among other legal problems.

headline: Weekly Matchups
text: The Saban Bowl in Alabama is getting a lot of ink, but the best game of the week might again be in the Pac-10, with No. 4 Arizona State traveling to Eugene to take on No. 5 Oregon. These two games will be going on simultaneously so get your remotes and TiVos warmed up. Elsewhere Navy hopes to beat Notre Dame for the first time since 1963, while Kansas hopes to go 9-0 for the first time since the Roosevelt administration. The Teddy Roosevelt administration. Can Connecticut stay atop the Big East? Can Boston College keep it going against Florida State? Does Wisconsin have a shot at knocking off No. 1 Ohio State? Is it possible that U.S.C. could fall out of the top 25? So many questions, so few Saturdays remaining. You better pay attention and appreciate the college football while it’s still around.

headline: Sabotaging the Census
text: Withholding money is one way to make sure a project doesn’t move forward.

headline: Nostalgia About the News Is So Over

text: CHERAW, S.C. – John Edwards, it seems, missed an item from the morning newspaper.

headline: Three Ways to Bash the Buyout Tax Increase
text: The debate about taxing carried interest is a fierce one. Understandably so, considering that carried interest is the source of billions of dollars of profits for private equity fund managers. Congress is considering more than doubling the tax rate for carried interest — which, to put things in perspective, would simply make it the same as what most people pay on plain-old income.

text: Officials in Portland, Ore., are encouraging small businesses catering to cyclists.

headline: Friday’s Links: Give Rex a Break!
text: First Rex Grossman, the Bears quarterback, had to deal with losing his job to Brian Griese, a former Miami Dolphin. Then Saturday, a scarecrow dressed in his jersey lost to a scarecrow that was more fish than man in a contest among different classes of elementary school students. That just feels like piling on to me.

text: East Coast members of the writers’ guild leafleted near NBC’s headquarters at Rockefeller Plaza in New York City this morning.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Something New Under the Carnegie Sun
text: You think they are just halls? Carnegie, Avery Fisher, Alice Tully? Yes, they have the names of rich people and seats and stages. But they also have administrators — smart and ambitious folk often with music backgrounds. They like to do more than book concerts.

headline: Afghanistan's New Cash Crop
text: Farmers in Northern Afghanistan are replacing poppy fields with another illicit crop: cannabis.

headline: Family Trumps All in Staten Island Endorsement
text: It’s official now. James P. Molinaro, the Staten Island borough president, is turning his back on his one-time aide and is endorsing Michael J. Ryan, the Democratic candidate for district attorney in Tuesday’s election.

headline: Is Ridgewood the New East Bushwick?
text: There has seemed to be a bit of confusion whether or not the evicted loft tenants (“hipsters” to some) of 17-17 Troutman actually lived in Bushwick (Brooklyn) or Ridgewood (Queens).A press release apparently went out saying they were Bushwick residents, while the answer is: technically the building lies in Ridgewood.

headline: Ratings: A Super-sized ‘Anatomy’ Crowds ‘CSI’
text: The first official night of November “sweeps” was a close race between CBS and ABC for No. 1 in the ratings. Although CBS earned the most viewers on Thursday, ABC eked out a victory among adults 18 to 49 thanks to a slightly extended edition of “Grey’s Anatomy.”

headline: Hearts Versus Minds on Spitzer’s Driver’s License Plan
text: Today comes another salvo in Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s efforts to build support for his new plan to give driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants while also offering licenses that will comply with new federal security rules under the Real I.D. Act. And it illustrates the basic issue for Mr. Spitzer as he seeks to cope with what appears to be massive public resistance to the new policy.

headline: Almost Soviet
text: Amid all the debate over new surveillance legislation and telecommunications immunity, Shane Harris at National Journal drops this little bomb:

headline: Single Dad Soliloquy
text: Just yesterday, it seems, I was in the middle of an 18-month deployment. And my life back home, and my family, went through drastic changes during that time. I felt that the pieces of everything I found familiar were being shattered apart like a busy marketplace during a suicide bombing or a thousand sparrows lifting off from a single tree. I wrote this, and this, and this to describe my feelings back then.

headline: If Nothing Else, There’s Applause….
text: Well, fashion fiends, we’ve come to the end of my term as guest blogger here at OTR. I have to say thank you to all for the gracious welcome, and for not leaving me in shreds. I’m sure I’ll come back and visit from time to time. It really is addictive, isn’t it?

headline: A Myth About Growing Old
text: It amazes me that I still hear from people who doubt that white wines can age. Actually, it’s not so much that they doubt it. It simply doesn’t occur to them.

headline: Inspiration for Your 26.2 Mile Trek
text: Just in time for this weekend’s New York City Marathon, Runner’s World magazine offers an extra dose of inspiration with stories of runners who conquered disability or used running as a way to boost a charitable cause.

headline: Kitchen Options
text: Do most people who build a house spend the majority of their time thinking about the kitchen? Although I have certainly concentrated on other issues — bathrooms, decks, closets, etc. — the kitchen has been the room consuming 80 percent of my thoughts.

headline: At Slain Broker’s Funeral, Downtown Edge and Uptown Glitz
text: Women with Chanel scarves and Prada bags mingled with frizzy-haired men in leather jackets and fedoras at a memorial service today for Linda Stein, a fitting tribute to a woman who brought together New York’s downtown edge and its uptown glitz.

headline: The Three Perils of Contracts

headline: The Week in Comments: ‘Joe Torre’ Has Three (Syllables, That Is)
text: Following is a selection of reader comments from the week’s most popular posts. But we should note that one of the busiest was the Joe Torre haiku contest from last month, with more than 150 new submissions. (Follow the syllable-counting rules; we delete without mercy.)

headline: Which Advertiser Is on Your Friend List?

headline: Performa 07: The Eye of the Revivalist
text: Today I attended a student matinee of David Neumann’s fantabulous “feedforward” and stuck around for the post-performance discussion. The first question from the moderator was something along the lines of “What will stand out for you about this piece a week from now?” — a typically asinine variation of the sorts of “deep thought” questions posed to kids, who are apparently now supposed to be able to know what they will remember in the future.

headline: Jozy Altidore — We All Want to Win
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his 10th post, Altidore discusses the first-round playoff games against the New England Revolution.

text: What we are reading elsewhere…
