headline: ACS’ Ex-Directors: Fighting the Tide
text: Few tales from the buyout boom have taken as strange a turn as that of Affiliated Computer Services. Not every company can talk of its yacht-owning chairman threatening its five independent directors, in a complicated tale of buyout negotiations gone bad. (Steven Davidoff, who writes the M&A Law Prof Blog, has this to say: “Wow, wow, wow.”)

headline: Out to Sea on Law of the Sea
text: The strange campaign for the Republican presidential nomination took another weird turn this week when every major Republican candidate spoke out against the Law of the Sea Treaty, which was approved by a 17-4 committee vote and may soon come to a vote on the Senate floor.

headline: The Strange Case of the Dancing Dentist
text: For some reason, misadventures in a dental office hold a special morbid fascination for many people, and The Lede is no exception. (Otherwise, why would Laurence Olivier’s wince-provoking interrogation scene in “Marathon Man” resonate so deeply, or Steve Martin’s comic turn in “Little Shop of Horrors” make us laugh so much?)

headline: Finding Zhao Gu
text: At about 10 a.m. on June 19, 2003, in the western Chinese city of Wuwei, a man named Ma Guoxing was walking across town, intent on a pending business appointment.

headline: Late for the Sky
text: Comedy Central’s Brian Regan on how chatty pilots get during delays:

headline: The Dodd-Biden Run-In
text: Caucus readers often beg for more from the two policy wonks and longtime senators in the Democratic field, Senators Chris Dodd of Connecticut and Joe Biden of Delaware.

headline: Edwards and Danny Glover in South Carolina
text: YORK COUNTY, S.C. — John Edwards just left a dusty backwoods community called Blackmon Road, one of the poorest places in South Carolina. The road back here used to be called Trash Pile Road because everyone threw their garbage here.

headline: Who’s Predator, Who’s Prey?
text: Rob Stewart, a 27-year-old diver, photographer and now filmmaker from Toronto, desperately wants us to fall in love with sharks before we wipe them out.

headline: Strike News: Writer’s Block Starts Monday
text: Unless the writers’ guild and the studios reach a deal this weekend, writers will strike beginning at 3:01 a.m. Eastern time on Monday, the guild announced this afternoon.

headline: Strike News: Stop Me If You’ve Heard This One…
text: Next week on “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” is… this week’s “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart.”

headline: Kerry Rhodes Questionable for Sunday
text: The Jets released their latest injury report on Friday, and it contained one surprise: Kerry Rhodes, the Jets’ safety, is questionable with a knee injury. Rhodes talked and joked with reporters in the locker room after practice. He appeared to be doing fine.

headline: Hail, the Conquered Hero
text: “You take my life when you do take the means whereby I live.” — Shylock

headline: Sony Ad 2
text: Sony Ad 2

headline: Sony Ad
text: An advertisement by Sony featuring Peyton Manning.

headline: Citi Watch: The Search for a New Leader
text: Late Sunday update: The New York Times reported Sunday that former Treasury secretary Robert E. Rubin was named as Citigroup’s chairman at its board’s emergency meeting. The firm is expected to still look for a new chief executive.

headline: Bloggingheads: The Mormon Problem
text: Journalists Amy Sullivan, of Time, and Rod Dreher, of the Dallas Morning News, on how Romney can quell doubts about his faith.

headline: Putting the Reader First
text: I realize that this is always an irksome issue in translation: perfect fidelity versus greater felicity. So let me just go on record as saying that when my work is translated into other languages, I give my translators full permission to fix my mistakes, and to make my work sound more graceful and elegant, better — rather than clumsier and worse — than it is in English. Ultimately, the pleasure of the reader should trump even the brilliance of the translator.

headline: Tolstoy as Spinach
text: Hold on a second, Sam. You mean the NY Review of Books, your most formidable competitor, beat us to press with a “War and Peace” review? AND they got the author of “Natasha’s Dance” to do it? Sam, we need to talk …

headline: Frugal Chicago
text: Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, cuts down on costs, not culture, on a weekend in the Windy City.

headline: At Fort Drum, Military Families Reunite
text: Soldiers from the 10th Mountain Division's Second Brigade reunited with their families Thursday after spending 15 months in Iraq.

headline: Japan's Aging Prisoners
text: With one of the world's most rapidly aging societies, Japan is confronting a sharp increase in the number of older criminals and prisoners.

headline: North Texas Troubles
text: When the season began, Todd Dodge was best known for being a real-life Eric Taylor, the coach on the television show “Friday Night Lights.”

headline: Mike Hart: The Run
text: It didn’t take long for one of Mike Hart’s closest high school friends, Carl Runge, to come up with a favorite moment from their days at Onondaga Central High school. And in these wonderful YouTube days, Runge even told me how to look it up.

headline: Joel Zumaya and the Perils of a Damaged Shoulder
text: Reading today about Joel Zumaya, I could not help thinking of Brien Taylor.

headline: Obama, Civil Rights and South Carolina
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Barack Obama spent the day giving formal speeches about the civil rights struggle and said that civil rights pioneers had overcome fears to achieve big dreams — and he asked his listeners to overcome their own fears and support him for president.

headline: Clinton and Opponents Tangle Over Attacks on Her
text: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 2 — Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama tangled on Friday over whether women should be treated equally to men in the boxing ring of presidential politics. At the same time, Mrs. Clinton elaborated on the “pile-on politics” video her campaign prepared, which showed her under assault from the six male candidates at the Democratic debate on Tuesday.

headline: Orchestra, Muscles Flexed
text: Figuratively speaking, Yuri Temirkanov and the St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra rained death on Wednesday and Thursday evenings to end their stand at Carnegie Hall. First came pertinent excerpts from Prokofiev’s ballet score “Romeo and Juliet,” and you know what happens there. Then, on Thursday, Mussorgsky’s “Songs and Dances of Death” set up Prokofiev’s cantata “Alexander Nevsky,” with its harrowing song, “The Field of the Dead.”

headline: Welcome the Translators
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Happy Songs Are Suspect, No Cheerful Tune Is Safe
text: “What really makes us happy is when the Wicked Witch dies,” the jazz singer Tierney Sutton observed in her introduction to “Ding-Dong! The Witch Is Dead” on Thursday evening at Birdland. Musing about the guilty pleasure of schadenfreude, Ms. Sutton and her band (Ray Brinker on drums, Kevin Axt on bass and Christian Jacob on piano) made the crowing victory song from “The Wizard of Oz” the concluding chapter of a show that was a sequence of biting musical essays on happiness, or the lack thereof.

headline: Despite Gain in Jobs Data, Wall Street Is Skeptical
text: A robust employment report offered investors a pleasant surprise yesterday, but some thought it was too good to be true.

headline: With Resolution Unlikely, Writers Guild Sets Strike for Monday
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 —When the sun rises here on Monday morning, movie and television writers will be ready to head for their assigned picket lines outside Hollywood’s studios and production sites.

headline: Toxic Fumes Suspected in 4 Workers’ Deaths
text: When a worker inside a manhole at a northern Wisconsin landfill was overcome late Thursday, apparently by toxic fumes, a fellow worker went down to help. He, too, was overcome, and another colleague went to the rescue, and then another. By the time firefighters pulled the men, two of them brothers, from the hole, all four were dead, the authorities said yesterday.

headline: Rice Under Pressure in Trip to Turkey
text: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 2 — Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice came under pressure from Turkish officials upon her arrival here today to publicly blame Kurdish leaders in Iraq for the recent Kurdish rebel attacks on Turkish forces.

headline: Bush Vetoes Water Bill, Citing Cost of $23 Billion
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — President Bush on Friday vetoed a bill authorizing $23 billion in water resource projects, calling it overly expensive, and Congressional Democrats responded angrily, accusing him of insensitivity to the hurricane-damaged Gulf Coast, a big beneficiary of the legislation. They pledged to override him.

headline: Leaps and Pirouettes and 40 Nasty Whacks
text: Could there have been a time when the heart sank at the prospect of yet another performance of heavily dramatic ballets like Antony Tudor’s “Undertow” or Agnes de Mille’s “Fall River Legend”? Well, perhaps the murky “Undertow” is going too far. But in a post-Balanchine era of hectic movement for its own sake, “Fall River Legend” looked pretty good when American Ballet Theater performed it Thursday night at City Center.

headline: As Japan Ages, Prisons Adapt to Going Gray
text: ONOMICHI, Japan — In the prison’s brightly lighted workroom here, 47 inmates sat behind long tables and quietly performed their chores.

headline: Duran Duran Continues Its Revival With a Debut on a Broadway Stage
text: On Sunday Duran Duran had its first off-Broadway tryout, in Wallingford, Conn. There were the usual technical difficulties  the show started an hour late  and not all the critics were kind. (“The group tested lighting schemes, video cues and fans’ patience,” Kenneth Partridge wrote in The Hartford Courant.)

headline: The F.C.C., Cable and Competition
text: To the Editor:

headline: Magic and Memphis, Along With a Little Bit of Music
text: It’s odd to see a play about music in which music is almost an afterthought. “Hoodoo Love,” by Katori Hall, is about an aspiring blues singer in Memphis in 1933. But while there is some singing onstage, it serves more as embellishment than main event. The lead character, Toulou, gives lip service to her ambition, but it seems to be grafted onto her role. And the casting for this play, which opened on Thursday at the Cherry Lane Theater, was definitely about acting, not about voice.

headline: Pittsburgh Episcopal Diocese Votes to Leave the Church
text: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 2 — By more than a two-to-one vote, members of the Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh voted Friday in favor of separating from the national church because of a theological rift that began with the consecration of an openly gay bishop in 2003.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sitter Is Charged in Baby’s Death
text: A baby-sitter in North Plainfield, N.J., who the police say left a 6-month-old boy unattended, which resulted in his death, was charged with endangering the welfare of a child yesterday.

headline: A Few Little Pieces
text: Only 1,729 people asked to be reimbursed for buying James Frey’s largely fabricated memoir, “A Million Little Pieces,” The Associated Press reported yesterday. Larry D. Drury, a lawyer, urged Judge Richard J. Holwell of Federal District Court in Manhattan to approve the deal, which offered a refund to anyone who had bought the book before Mr. Frey’s falsehoods were acknowledged. The book earned the author more than $4 million, Mr. Drury told the judge, who approved a final settlement with disgruntled readers. In January 2006, the Web site thesmokinggun.com revealed that Mr. Frey’s memoir included numerous fabrications. Mr. Frey and his publisher then acknowledged that he had made up parts of the book. Numerous readers’ lawsuits were consolidated before Judge Holwell, and a settlement was reached that called for readers to be reimbursed. Random House set aside $2.35 million to cover their costs, but the claims for reimbursement cost just $27,348. Another $783,000 will be paid out in legal fees, along with $432,000 in costs associated with publicizing and carrying out other parts of the settlement.

headline: Farm Belt Follies
text: The Senate has one last chance to rid the country of an irrational, outdated and unfair 70-year-old program of federal farm supports that enriches the few at the expense of the many, distorts international trade and damages the environment. It has one last chance, in other words, to produce a farm program of which the country can be proud.

headline: Justice Nominee Gets 2 Key Votes From Democrats
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — The confirmation of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general appeared to be all but certain on Friday after two key Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee announced they would support the nomination despite complaints over Mr. Mukasey’s refusal to clarify his views on what amounts to torture.

headline: 12 for 26.2
text: The New York City Marathon is among the more difficult races to predict because the challenging course puts an emphasis on race strategy rather than raw speed. This was demonstrated last year, when Marilson Gomes dos Santos, a largely unproven marathoner from Brazil, surged near Mile 20 and left a pack of the world’s fastest men far behind on his way to victory.

headline: Pushing the Traditional Toward New Destinations
text: The interplay was congenial, cooperative and briskly confident at Bargemusic on Thursday night during the first of two sets by the guitarist Howard Alden and the clarinetist and tenor saxophonist Ken Peplowski. What it wasn’t, on the whole, was conservative or tired. The two musicians were covering familiar turf in one guise or another, but with a spirit of inquiry that renewed itself at every turn.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article yesterday about the N.F.L. career of Jaguars running back Fred Taylor misstated the number of players ahead of him on the career rushing list who are in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Of the 20 players ahead of him, 10 — not 18 — are in the Hall of Fame. (Several running backs ahead of him are either still active or retired too recently to be considered for the honor.)

headline: Different Situations, Same Goal, for 2 Jets
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 2  Jets left guard Jacob Bender could make his first N.F.L. start Sunday, against the team he grew up rooting for. Laveranues Coles could miss his first regular-season start in 105 games, against the team he left in 2005.

headline: Musharraf Warned Not to Impose Emergency Rule
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 2 — A senior American commander, Adm. William J. Fallon, warned Pakistan’s president on Friday not to impose emergency rule, saying that doing so would jeopardize American financial support for the military here.

headline: Rating Video Mayhem
text: The Entertainment Software Rating Board, which assigns age ratings to video games, will keep the “mature” label on Manhunt 2, despite calls from some groups to make the rating more restrictive after hackers defeated measures that blur some of the game’s violence, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Manhunt 2 went on sale in the United States on Wednesday. On Thursday the game’s publisher, Take2 Interactive Software, confirmed that hackers had managed to unblur some gruesome scenes on the PlayStation Portable version, which include killing with axes and other implements. The ratings board had originally given the game an “adults only” rating, but Take2 made modifications, including blurring some details, to gain a “mature” rating, meaning that it is intended for players 17 and older.

headline: No Second Chances in Olympic Quest
text: Among the 131 men vying for one of the top three spots at the United States Olympic trials in the men’s marathon are a former world-record holder (Khalid Khannouchi), the reigning Olympic silver medalist (Meb Keflezighi) and a runner who in April became the second-fastest American marathoner in history (Ryan Hall).

headline: Thousands Rally in Capital Against Georgia President
text: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 2  Tens of thousands of demonstrators converged on the capital of Georgia on Friday, demanding parliamentary elections for early next year and venting dissatisfaction with the country’s once enormously popular government.

headline: In Risky Spacewalk, Astronaut Repairs Damage
text: An astronaut on an unusually risky spacewalk yesterday repaired a damaged solar array on the International Space Station.

headline: An Italian Author Driven Into the Shadows by Success
text: ROME

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A dance review on Oct. 25 about the opening-night gala for American Ballet Theater’s season at City Center, where the company is performing only ballets created since 1940, omitted an American city that will see this “modern” face of American Ballet Theater. Starting Monday and running through Nov. 11, the company will perform programs from the City Center repertory at Zellerbach Hall in Berkeley, Calif., on the campus of the University of California. New York is not the only city in the United States where these works will be seen.

headline: That Promised Peace Conference
text: One month before President Bush’s Mideast peace conference  the administration’s first serious effort in six years  it’s still not clear what will be on the agenda or who, beyond the Americans, Israelis and Palestinians, will show up. Even the date is still up in the air.

headline: Footnotes
text: Ballet Hispanico will present its 20th annual New York season at the Joyce Theater from Nov. 27 to Dec. 9. For information: joyce.org. ... The Italian Cultural Institute of New York, Fondazione Aida and the Film Society of Lincoln Center are presenting “Pier Paolo Pasolini — Poet of Ashes” from Nov. 26 to Dec. 4, showcasing the work of Pasolini at locations around New York. For information: www.pasolininewyork.com.

headline: Europe Awards Rockers
text: Avril Lavigne, below, and the band Muse each won two awards at the MTV Europe Music Awards in Munich, the BBC reported yesterday. Ms. Lavigne was named best solo artist, and her composition “Girlfriend” won the award for most addictive song. Muse won for best British, best Irish and best headline act. Rihanna, the R&B singer, won the ultimate urban prize, while the British singer Amy Winehouse took the artist choice prize, chosen by her fellow musicians. Linkin Park won the award for best band of 2007.

headline: Hall Earns Olympic Berth With Commanding Win
text: Ryan Hall made a move in the United States Olympic trials marathon this morning reminiscent of his quick rise in the sport over the past year, surging away from a talented pack in the 17th mile to take a commanding victory and grab an Olympic berth. With his victory, he announced himself as a contender for a medal at next year’s Beijing Olympics.

headline: Homeless Man Killed at Shelter
text: A 46-year-old man was stabbed to death at a homeless shelter in Harlem yesterday after a dispute with another man, the police said.

headline: Tanker Collision Kills 3 and Closes I-95 in Connecticut
text: EAST LYME, Conn., Nov. 2 — A tanker truck veered out of control on Interstate 95 on Friday morning and slammed into five other vehicles, killing three people and injuring at least three others, the state police said.

headline: Bush, Mukasey and the Fairness Issue
text: To the Editor:

headline: S.I. Borough President Backs Ex-Aide’s Rival
text: The already heated race for Staten Island district attorney became even more highly charged yesterday when James P. Molinaro, the borough president, officially broke ranks with his former aide, District Attorney Daniel M. Donovan Jr., and endorsed the Democratic candidate in the race.

headline: New York’s Calorie Counter
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Halloween Adventure store in the East Village, which attracts workers with a theatrical style of dress, referred incorrectly to the operation of the store, part of a nationwide franchise. It is not in fact the only one open year-round.

headline: Officials Say Teacher Fled Country With Boy
text: OMAHA, Nov. 2 — When a 12-year-old boy from Lexington, a small city about 200 miles west of here, began acting out and his grades fell, it took his family awhile to suspect that his sixth-grade teacher, a popular young woman who had returned to teach in her hometown, might be preying on him.

headline: Proclamation of Emergency Issued by Gen. Pervez Musharraf
text: Following is the text of the Proclamation of Emergency declared by General Pervez Musharraf on Saturday, as released by The Associated Press of Pakistan, a state-run news agency.

headline: Period Music, This Time on Modern Instruments
text: “If Bach were here, he’d be rather amazed and wonder what that huge piece of furniture is,” the English violinist Andrew Manze said in genial introductory remarks before a recital he presented with the pianist Richard Egarr on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall’s Zankel Hall. Mr. Manze was referring to the impressive Steinway grand at which Mr. Egarr, his longtime musical partner, was seated at center stage.

headline: Germany’s Black Years Seen From the Inside
text: PARIS, Nov. 2  It can be argued that Impressionism killed off historical painting, and with it the tradition of portraying military victories on canvas. Yet the genre was not quite dead. Early in the 20th century history painting made another appearance in art, and this time, stripped of glory and heroism, war was finally shown in all its ugliness.

headline: Children and Cold Medicines
text: Anyone who doubts the power of drug company marketing to overcome a dearth of scientific evidence need only ponder the disturbing matter of cold medicines used to treat children and infants.

headline: From a Trash Bin, Singing Cossacks and a Bitter Dispute
text: LAKEWOOD, N.J. — Like many strange tales, the story of the antiques dealer, the scholars from Scotland and the contested archive of a Russian conductor begins in the suburbs of New Jersey.

headline: Live From New York, It’s Not Quite the News!
text: A week ago Brian Williams was in a Manhattan department store buying a gift when a woman walked up to him and introduced herself, commenting that she always watched him anchor “NBC Nightly News” but had recently read that he was going to be the host of that network’s “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Michigan’s Hart Leads on the Field and on Campus
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — When Michigan Coach Lloyd Carr made a recruiting visit to Mike Hart in Syracuse nearly four years ago, he and Hart ducked out of a frigid and windy night into a local rib joint called Dinosaur Bar-B-Que.

headline: Peace of Mind When They Ask to Borrow the Car
text: THERE is no moment where childhood and incipient adulthood collide that is more universal than the moment a teenager gets behind the wheel of a car. For the teenager, it is simple — it is the first real taste of freedom. But for the parents, that is when the worrying begins.

headline: As They Say on MySpace, Would You Chillax?
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.A.W. and Ford Reach Tentative Agreement
text: DETROIT, Nov. 3 — The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative four-year agreement with the Ford Motor Company early Saturday that follows the pattern set in new contracts at General Motors and Chrysler.

headline: The Lords Take the Lead in a Long-Running Battle
text: The 33rd annual bridge battle between the two halves of the British Parliament, the House of Lords and the House of Commons, took place at Crockford’s Club in June.

headline: 3 Top Republican Candidates Take a Hard Line on the Interrogation of Detainees
text: A central tenet of every leading Republican candidate’s campaign for president is one simple and powerful idea: I alone can best defend the United States from the threat of terrorism.

headline: A Spotlight on the Green Side of Bottled Water
text: LAST summer, environmentalists took on the bottled water industry. On their Web sites and in their press releases, many environmental groups pointed to bottled water as a prime example of an unnecessary product that uses scarce resources and adds more plastic to overtaxed landfills.

headline: My Favorite Menace
text: The Law of the Sea Treaty has become a hot-button item in the Republican presidential race.

headline: Egg-Throwing Ends in Arrests of 2 Officers
text: Two New York City police officers were arrested yesterday on charges that they drove a 14-year-old boy who had been throwing eggs at cars on Halloween to a remote area on Staten Island and left him there.

headline: The Dings and Dents of Toyota
text: DETROIT, Nov. 2 — It might seem odd to suggest that a 70-year-old company is going through growing pains, especially one with $183 billion in annual sales.

headline: Election Monitors to Head to Russia Despite Limits
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 2 — The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe announced Friday that it would send a skeleton crew of observers to cover Russia’s December parliamentary elections, after Moscow sharply reduced the number of monitors it normally allows.

headline: Medicine That Really Tastes Smooth
text: In recent years classical music has developed a subcategory of concert series devoted to presenting new music to audiences tacitly presumed not to want it. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s “New Music in the Rose” series, which opened on Thursday, joins other attempts over the years, including the Orchestra of St. Luke’s “Second Helpings” and the society’s own “Double Exposure.”

headline: Lowell Smith, 56, Dancer in Harlem Troupe, Dies
text: Lowell Smith, a principal dancer for the Dance Theater of Harlem who used precise mastery of classical ballet and exquisite expressiveness of body and face to convey emotions from tranquility to charged passion, died on Oct. 22, in Los Angeles. He was 56.

headline: Let Us Pray for Wealth
text: A GLOBAL survey recently conducted by the Pew Research Center shows that the wealthier you are, the less likely you are to be religious.

headline: Bush Sees Iraq Progress From Troop Buildup
text: FORT JACKSON, S.C., Nov. 2 — President Bush offered an upbeat assessment on Friday of progress in Iraq, saying that while corruption remained a problem and unemployment was high, the economy was growing, violence was down and, “slowly but surely, the people of Iraq are reclaiming a normal society.”

headline: Corrections
text: A television review last Saturday about “Silence of the Bees,” on PBS, misstated the cause of death of a honeybee colony’s males and also included imprecise references to other aspects of hive life. The males, called drones, die after mating or are driven out of the colony by the females and die of exposure; they are not worked to death. (The females do the work.) The life span of the males can range from two or three weeks to nearly two months or more; their life span is not always limited to 30 days. The number of males in a colony can be in the hundreds or more; a colony is not limited to 100. At the height of the nectar-gathering season, colonies can include 50,000 bees or more; thus a queen can be attended by more than 30,000 subjects, not just 30,000.

headline: Imbibers Add It All Up, and Gulp
text: SEVERAL years ago in his book “Smart Women Finish Rich,” David Bach coined the term “latte factor” to capture the way in which an innocuous expense — like a daily cup of coffee — could put a dent in your budget.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Federal Reserve’s cut in short-term interest rates misspelled the name of Standard & Poor’s housing price index. It is Case-Shiller, not Case-Schiller.

headline: Big Drop in Merrill Stock on Hint of New Troubles
text: Merrill Lynch, still operating without a permanent chief executive, saw its shares fall sharply yesterday on the possibility that it might have to write down more of its high-risk credit exposure.

headline: Missile Kills 5 in Northwest Pakistan; U.S. Denies Attack
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 2  A missile fired from an unmanned aerial drone killed five militants and wounded six other people in Pakistan’s lawless tribal areas on Friday, according to a Pakistani security official and a local resident.

headline: James Ensures Knicks Open With a Loss
text: CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 — A new season began at last for the Knicks on Friday, days after most of the N.B.A. got under way and much later than they probably preferred after a disastrous off-season.

headline: Citigroup Chief Is Set to Exit Amid Losses
text: The embattled head of Citigroup, the global banking giant, has told directors that he would resign from the bank after an emergency meeting this weekend in the wake of a $5.9 billion write-down and sharp drop in profit, people briefed on the situation said last night.

headline: Talking Point for Rodriguez? $350 Million
text: It turns out there might have been a magic number that could have gotten the Yankees the meeting they wanted with Alex Rodriguez: $350 million. That was the minimum bid the Yankees would have apparently had to make to begin negotiations with Rodriguez before he opted out of his contract during Game 4 of the World Series last Sunday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,831 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

headline: Corrections
text: A headline in some editions on Thursday with an article about efforts by Dr. Mazoltuv Borukhova, the widow of a Queens orthodontist, to compel the city to return her daughter to her left the incorrect impression that Dr. Borukhova was in court because she had shot her daughter. The shooting victim was Dr. Daniel Malakov, Dr. Borukhova’s estranged husband — not their child, Michelle Malakov, who was placed in the custody of Dr. Malakov’s relatives. Neither Dr. Borukhova nor anyone else has been charged in Dr. Malakov’s killing. (Go to Article)

headline: Storied Hotel Is Closing for a Major Face-Lift
text: Pierre New York, the venerable neo-Renaissance hotel on Fifth Avenue that has been the setting for countless society parties and served as a home away from home for famous patrons including Elizabeth Taylor and Richard M. Nixon, is set to close its doors in December for an extensive renovation, according to hotel industry executives.

headline: Texas Proceeding With Plan to Auction Preserve
text: As a Comanche moon rose one night last week over the West Texas border town of Terlingua, the Christmas Mountains Association convened over Mexican food in the Longhorn Ranch Motel.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Tuesday about Ronaldo da Costa, a former world-record marathoner, attributed an erroneous distinction to him regarding his running pace. Derek Clayton, who set a marathon record in 1969, was the first man to run the entire event at a pace of less than 5 minutes a mile — not da Costa, who was the first man to run one faster than 3 minutes per kilometer.

headline: Defense May Seek U.S. Testimony in Secrets Case
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  A federal judge on Friday ordered Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Stephen J. Hadley, the national security adviser, to be ready to testify as defense witnesses at the trial of two former pro-Israel lobbyists accused of receiving secret national security information.

headline: Maker of Lipitor Digs in to Fight Generic Rival
text: It is shaping up to be the biggest shift yet to a generic drug, potentially saving the nation $2 billion a year or more in prescription costs.

headline: Igor Moiseyev, Russian Choreographer, Dies at 101
text: Igor Moiseyev, the Russian choreographer who created a new form of theatrical folk dance and whose troupe was one of the most popular dance companies of the 20th century, died today in Moscow. He was 101.

headline: Political Leader of Sri Lanka’s Tamil Tigers Killed in an Airstrike
text: NEW DELHI, Nov. 2 — The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the Sri Lankan separatist group known for suicide attacks on political and military targets, lost their most prominent international representative on Friday when the head of their political wing was killed in an airstrike by the Sri Lankan military, according to the guerrilla group.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about tax legislation proposed by Representative Charles Rangel, a New York Democrat and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, misstated House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s position on the proposal. She supports Mr. Rangel’s plan. (When she gave a simple “no” answer to reporters on Oct. 25, she was answering their question about whether the House Democratic leadership supported the plan.)

headline: Corrections
text: A headline in some editions on Thursday with an article about efforts by Dr. Mazoltuv Borukhova, the widow of a Queens orthodontist, to compel the city to return her daughter to her left the incorrect impression that Dr. Borukhova was in court because she had shot her daughter. The shooting victim was Dr. Daniel Malakov, Dr. Borukhova’s estranged husband  not their child, Michelle Malakov, who was placed in the custody of Dr. Malakov’s relatives. Neither Dr. Borukhova nor anyone else has been charged in Dr. Malakov’s killing.

headline: Russia Temporarily Rescinds Ban on Lufthansa Overflights
text: PARIS, Nov. 2 — In an effort to defuse an escalating diplomatic dispute with Germany, the Russian authorities agreed on Friday to allow Lufthansa to temporarily resume cargo flights over Russia.

headline: For Teenage Drivers, Ever-Present Parents
text: Following are some of the companies that sell driver tracking devices:

headline: Drew Carey Stands Up for Medical Marijuana
text: Drew Carey, above, who recently replaced Bob Barker as the host of “The Price is Right,” defends the use of medical marijuana in a video posted online Thursday on Reason.tv, The Associated Press reported yesterday. “Smell that smell,” the 49-year-old comedian says as he walks into a medical marijuana dispensary. “That’s the smell of freedom.” The video is one of 20 that Mr. Carey plans to make for the Reason Foundation, a nonprofit educational group. Mr. Carey offered to produce brief documentaries on topics ranging from traffic congestion to immigration for the foundation’s Web site, said David Nott, the president of the foundation. They are to appear every two weeks through the end of the year on the site, Mr. Nott said.

headline: Blazed and Confused
text: Los Angeles

headline: Head of Class, but Not on Draft Day
text: In the N.F.L., as in Hollywood, landing the right leading man is not as simple as picking through screen tests. Sometimes it works out despite one’s best judgment, as it did when Jack Nicholson was cast to play Randle McMurphy in “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” after James Caan turned down the role.

headline: Abbas Meets West Bank Hamas Leaders
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 2  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, met Friday with a group of Hamas leaders in the West Bank, the first time he has done so since Hamas routed Fatah forces in Gaza in June.

headline: Floodwaters Devastate Mexican State of Tabasco
text: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 2 — Navy helicopters plucked people from roofs on Friday as rising floodwaters covered much of the Gulf Coast state of Tabasco, putting the state capital, Villahermosa, underwater.

headline: A Prosecution Goes Bad, and a Judge Lets Loose
text: On Thursday morning, Roy Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. agent who faced the astounding charges that he helped a mob informant kill four people, walked out of court after the prosecutors suddenly dropped the case. It turned out that their star witness had told an entirely different story a decade ago, to two of the city’s premier investigative reporters. After hearing her testify against Mr. DeVecchio, they dug out a tape of that old interview.

headline: Credit Ratings Cut to Junk for Top 3 Home Builders
text: Standard & Poor’s cut the credit ratings of the three largest American home builders  Lennar, Pulte Homes and D. R. Horton  to junk yesterday as demand for new homes deteriorated.

headline: Two Mismatched Parts Are Made Into a Whole
text: The New York Philharmonic was the ideal orchestra for two very different pieces on Thursday night. Semyon Bychkov was the visiting conductor at Avery Fisher Hall, and his choice of music  all from the 20th century but with little mutuality to share  suggested that the term 20th-century music doesn’t mean a great deal.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg to Attend U.N. Meeting on Climate Change
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is once again getting ready to pack up his plane and head overseas, this time to the island of Bali for a United Nations meeting on climate change next month, he said yesterday.

headline: Two Suspended
text: World Wrestling Entertainment Inc. suspended two performers for what it said were violations of its substance-abuse and drug-testing policy. Chris Mordetzky, known as Chris Masters, was suspended 60 days for his second violation. Harry Smith, who wrestles under the name D. H. Smith, was barred for 30 days for an initial violation. In July, traces of injected testosterone and painkilling drugs were found in the body of Chris Benoit. Benoit, 40, a performer for eight years, committed suicide in June after killing his wife and 7-year-old son in their Atlanta home, the police said.

headline: Risky Spacewalk Saturday to Mend Solar Array
text: Astronauts will take part in an unusually risky spacewalk today in an effort to mend a torn solar array on the International Space Station.

headline: A Marriage of Technology and Art
text: To the Editor:

headline: Training Through Pregnancy to Be Marathon’s Fastest Mom
text: Paula Radcliffe, the British distance runner who holds the world record in the women’s marathon, ran throughout her pregnancy last year. She even ran the day before she gave birth to a healthy baby, Isla, on Jan. 17. And 12 days after Isla’s birth, she started running again.

headline: End to a Shabby Prosecution
text: The federal government agreed this week to terminate 20-year-old deportation proceedings against two Palestinian men who were wrongly targeted for their political beliefs and activities. Better late than never, but we fear that there is little hope that the Bush administration will learn any lesson from this shockingly mishandled prosecution.

headline: To Correct an Injustice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Igor Moiseyev, 101, Choreographer, Dies
text: Igor Moiseyev, the master choreographer who created a new form of theatrical folk dance in Russia and whose troupe was one of the most popular dance companies of the 20th century, died yesterday in Moscow. He was 101.

headline: For Soldiers’ Families, Battles Are Not Far Off
text: FORT DRUM, N.Y., Nov. 2 — The last time Bobbi Plautz welcomed home her husband, Travis, from Iraq, he was a changed person. He listened to different kinds of music and craved different kinds of food. He stayed up all night and wrestled with nightmares.

headline: Nets Play Poorly Early, and Then It Gets Worse
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 2  About six months after the Nets knocked out the Raptors in the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs, Toronto played like a team with a score to settle while the Nets played like a bunch that spent the off-season in a slumber.

headline: Predators Who Fight to Control Yellowstone
text: The template for animal documentaries these days is well established: Go to the ends of the Earth to follow cute, photogenic mammals as they organize their days and lives around the primal functions of eating, mating and nurturing their young.

headline: Manning and Brady Bring to Mind Quarterbacks Past
text: Shortly before New England crushed Washington last Sunday in Foxborough, Mass., a few of us began a press-box debate over who is King of The Hill among N.F.L. quarterbacks, the Colts’ Peyton Manning or the Patriots’ Tom Brady.

headline: Myanmar Junta Orders Top U.N. Official in the Country to Leave
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 2 — Myanmar’s government on Friday ordered the expulsion of the United Nations’ top diplomat in the country after his office issued a critical statement urging the ruling generals to heed the voices of protesters.

headline: Embattled Barnard Anthropologist Is Awarded Tenure
text: An assistant professor of anthropology at Barnard College whose scholarship on the use of archaeology in Israel has attracted both fierce criticism and scholarly support has been approved for tenure, Barnard officials said in a statement released yesterday.

headline: Loyal to Kerik, Giuliani Missed Warning Signs
text: This article was reported by Russ Buettner, Michael Powell and William K. Rashbaum and was written by Mr. Powell.

headline: Neck and Neck
text: On Thursday, the first official night of November sweeps, CBS had the most viewers but ABC the most adults 18 to 49, thanks to a slightly extended edition of “Grey’s Anatomy,” which was the winner in that demographic, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That network also led the 9 p.m. hour in total viewers (18.8 million) — beating “CSI” on CBS (18.7 million). But estimates for the ABC show were rough because it ran seven minutes into the 10 p.m. time slot of the struggling “Big Shots.” ABC remained third in the 10 p.m. hour with an average of 9 million viewers, just below NBC’s “ER” (9.1 million) but significantly behind CBS’s “Without a Trace” (14.6 million). CBS finished a strong second to ABC in the 18-to-49 group, while NBC ranked third for the night in that demographic and fourth in total viewers behind Fox.

headline: Zeppelin Injury Raises Questions
text: The press agent in London was getting the same question all day: Which finger was it?

headline: Start With the Youth
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Thursday about the legal, political and public relations strategy of Blackwater Worldwide, the security contractor whose operations in Iraq are under scrutiny, misstated the middle initial of the former Whitewater independent counsel who was retained for a time to help handle suits filed by the families of slain Blackwater employees. He is Kenneth W. Starr, not Kenneth D.

headline: Baseball’s Losing Formula
text: St. Louis

headline: Bloomberg’s Pay Raises for Unions May Trouble the City After He Leaves
text: Amid the gloomy talk of subprime mortgage failures, tumbling profits on Wall Street and a cooling real estate market, one powerful force squeezing New York City’s budget has gone largely undiscussed: the sharply rising cost of municipal labor.

headline: Mayors, Looking to Cities’ Future, Are Told It Must Be Colored Green
text: SEATTLE, Nov. 2 — The mayor of Fayetteville, Ark., gushed through a slide show about how his city was in the midst of great change. Bleak roads and bland shopping strips were being redrawn to a more human scale. Downtown condominiums were going for a million dollars. Streets once silent at night now bustled.

headline: U.N. Ousts Peacekeepers in Sex Case
text: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 2  The United Nations said Friday that 108 Sri Lankan soldiers from its peacekeeping force in Haiti would be sent home Saturday “on disciplinary grounds” over accusations that they had paid for sex with local women, many of them minors.

headline: Prominent Jesuit Is Target of New Federal Charges
text: A prominent Jesuit priest accused of sexually victimizing teenage boys who were his valets as he traveled the world leading Roman Catholic spiritual retreats was taken into federal custody yesterday in Chicago.

headline: UConn ’07 Is Having a Year Like Rutgers ’06
text: Rutgers opened the season with a bowl victory under its belt, a Heisman Trophy contender in its backfield and a national ranking (No. 16). Expectations ran high for the program, which in its previous season evolved from an afterthought to a powerhouse.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about the ambivalent feelings some Boston Red Sox fans have over the team’s newfound success omitted the name of one of the authors of “Red Sox Century.” Richard A. Johnson was also a writer, along with Glenn Stout, who commented on the psyche of Red Sox fans.

headline: Bringing Musical Mercy to the Vocally Challenged
text: I STEPPED up to a music stand in the living room of Judy Blazer’s off-Broadway apartment clutching the lyric sheet of “Oh, What a Beautiful Mornin’.” It was an unseasonably warm fall afternoon. The window unit air-conditioner hummed like an off-key mechanical bird. The chintz furniture and the Sohmer piano seemed to tremble under an ensemble of spotlights and Web video equipment. Bass clef sweat stains soaked my T-shirt.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A brief report in the Memo Pad column in Business Day on Tuesday, about American Airlines’ new service between Kennedy International Airport and Stansted Airport near London, misstated Stansted’s proximity to London’s financial district in comparison to Heathrow Airport. It is farther away; it is not closer. (A direct express train from Stansted to the Liverpool Street Station in the financial district makes the trip shorter from that airport.)

headline: Al Arbour: The Man Behind the Glass
text: Uniondale, N.Y.

headline: Free to Roam Onstage Yet Captured on Camera
text: When a dancer works with one choreographer for a long time, it’s hard to escape the dynamics and coordinations that are embedded in that performer’s way of moving. Ashleigh Leite, a strong presence in the Stephen Petronio Company between 1997 and 2005, hasn’t managed that escape. But perhaps she doesn’t need to.

headline: Leaving Corporate Life at 60
text: LIFE expectancies are increasing. Phrases like “60 is the new 40” are becoming increasingly commonplace, and just about every survey shows people invariably feel younger than their chronological age.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about an earthquake in the San Francisco Bay Area on Tuesday night misstated the location of the epicenter of the large earthquake that hit the area in 1989. The epicenter was south of the San Francisco Bay, not west of it.

headline: Fair Housing and Section 8
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ford and U.A.W. in Marathon Contract Talks
text: DETROIT, Nov. 3 — Negotiators from the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union were in a marathon bargaining session Friday, a sign that a tentative labor agreement may be imminent.

headline: Chic and Punk Mingle Tearfully at Murdered Real Estate Broker’s Funeral
text: Women with Chanel scarves and Prada bags mingled with long-haired men in leather jackets and fedoras at a memorial service yesterday for Linda Stein, the punk-rock manager turned real estate broker who was found slain in her Fifth Avenue apartment this week. It was a fitting tribute to a woman who had brought together New York’s downtown grit and its uptown glamour.

headline: Plaintiffs Awarded Share of Curlin’s Sale
text: A state judge in Kentucky has given the more than 400 plaintiffs in a diet-drug lawsuit the right to 20 percent of the proceeds from the future sale of Curlin, the Preakness Stakes and the Breeders’ Cup Classic champion.

headline: Trouble at the Winfrey Academy
text: A former dormitory matron at Oprah Winfrey’s school for disadvantaged girls in South Africa has been arrested on charges of abuse and sexual assault, The Associated Press reported yesterday. A police spokesman said the 27-year-old woman, who had worked at the Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls, was arrested on Thursday. At least seven victims have submitted statements, a police spokesman said. The woman is being held by the police and is expected to appear on Monday in Sebokeng magistrate’s court, south of Johannesburg. Officials at the school announced on Oct. 17 that a dormitory matron had been suspended amid allegations of serious misconduct. The local media recently reported that Ms. Winfrey had made a tearful apology to parents and pupils in a meeting at the school. Ms. Winfrey, above, opened her school outside Johannesburg on Jan. 2 with celebrities like Tina Turner and Spike Lee in attendance, as well as former President Nelson Mandela. The $40 million school, with a first class of 152 girls, was the fulfillment of a promise that Ms. Winfrey made to Mr. Mandela six years ago. It is intended to give girls from deprived backgrounds a quality education.

headline: New Life for Initiative to Apportion Electoral Vote
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 — Republican donors are pumping new life into a proposed ballot initiative, considered all but dead by Democrats a month ago, that would alter the way electoral votes are apportioned in California to the benefit of Republican presidential candidates.

headline: A Dingy Road Glorified in Music and Cinema
text: The subject of “The BQE,” the self-described “cinematic suite” that had its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday, is an epitome of New York City grime. Sufjan Stevens, the composer, said onstage that the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is “one of the world’s ugliest expressways.” But his treatment channeled Hollywood glamour, with three screens of images, a soundtrack of lush, triumphal orchestral fanfares and a chorus line of five people twirling Hula-Hoops.

headline: Online Universities: Not Just for the Young
text: To the Editor:

headline: F.C.C. Case Is Appealed to Justices
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Dow Jones) — The Federal Communications Commission has asked the Supreme Court to review a federal appellate court decision that rejected an effort by the commission to enforce indecency standards.

headline: Ford and U.A.W. in Marathon Contract Talks
text: DETROIT, Nov. 2 — Negotiators from the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union were in a marathon bargaining session Friday, a sign that a tentative labor agreement may be imminent.

headline: Sunnis Say Baghdad Hampers Anbar Gains
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — The Bush administration has singled out Anbar Province as an example of what can be accomplished in Iraq when local citizens join forces with the American military to fight insurgents. Attacks have declined sharply in the province, and American officials have looked for ways to replicate those gains in other contested regions of Iraq.

headline: Cable Networks Help Viacom’s Profit Surge 80%
text: A day after CBS Inc. told investors that its third-quarter revenue rose 8 percent but would be down 2 to 3 percent for the full year, Viacom, which like CBS is controlled by the entrepreneur Sumner M. Redstone, said that its third-quarter revenue rose 24 percent, to $3.27 billion.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Trouble at the Winfrey Academy

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Oct. 6 about the Atlantic City mayor, Robert W. Levy, who dropped out of public view after saying he was temporarily stepping aside for medical reasons, misstated his age. He is 60, not 64. (Mr. Levy returned the following week after a stay in a rehabilitation clinic, and subsequently resigned.)

headline: Pressed by Turks, Rice Seeks to Solve Kurdish Rebel Threat While Urging Restraint
text: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 2 — Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice came under pressure Friday from Turkish leaders seeking American help to curb Kurdish guerrillas in northern Iraq. But it was not clear whether her public pronouncements at the outset of this long-awaited visit would be enough to satisfy them.

headline: Dismissal of Agent’s Murder Charges Returns Victim’s Family to Square One
text: After 17 years, the killing of Patrick Porco is a cold case. Again.

headline: Worsening the Odds
text: Lonnie Lynam, a self-employed carpenter in Pipe Creek, Tex., specialized in spiral staircases. Friends thought of him as a maestro in a toolbelt, a whiz with a hammer and nails.

headline: Lawmakers in Venezuela Approve Expanded Power for Chávez
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 2 — The National Assembly approved a constitutional overhaul on Friday that would enhance President Hugo Chávez’s authority, allowing him to be re-elected indefinitely and giving him the power to handpick rulers, to be called vice presidents, for various new regions to be created in the country.

headline: Senate Democrats Facing a ‘Pay as You Go’ Problem
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — Senate Democrats face an agonizing choice in the days ahead: find a way to raise at least $50 billion in new taxes, or undermine their most important rule for enforcing budget discipline.

headline: Auto Sector’s Role Dwindles, and Spending Suffers
text: THE automobile industry’s share of the American economy has fallen to a historic low, the government reported this week, a few days before Chrysler announced another round of layoffs.

headline: Thousands Rally Against Georgia’s Once Popular President
text: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 2 — Tens of thousands of demonstrators converged on the capital of Georgia on Friday, demanding Parliamentary elections for early next year and venting dissatisfaction with the country’s once enormously popular government.

headline: An Unlikely Megachurch Lesson
text: One Sunday morning in 1995, Ron Wolfson and Rabbi Lawrence Hoffman braked to a halt in an oddly enlightening traffic jam. The line of cars was creeping toward Saddleback Church in Southern California, whose services were drawing thousands of worshipers. As two Jews, Mr. Wolfson and Rabbi Hoffman had crossed the sectarian divide to try to figure out how and why.

headline: Personal Metal Messages From Ancient Egypt
text: In ancient Egypt, stone sculpture was the stuff of intimidation: regal, public, unyielding. A stone statue could be smashed, but it could never be reincarnated. Metal, though, is malleable, unstable. A metal statue could be melted down and re-formed as a weapon or a pair of earrings; it could slowly change color over the years.

headline: Quad Q&A: Mike Hart
text: Few players have been more prolific over the past four years than Michigan tailback Mike Hart. He’s became the university’s all-time leading rusher earlier this year. That accomplishment is all the more impressive considering that the Wolverines aren’t going to be playing teams like Hawaii or New Mexico State anytime soon. But Hart’s an even bigger deal on the Michigan campus because of his charity work and involvement in student groups. Here’s his take on good bar-b-que, his plans on being Michigan’s head coach, working in the seafood department at a grocery store and why he guaranteed a victory over Notre Dame.

headline: Tragic Day at Olympic Trials
text: A U.S. Olympic trials marathon turned tragic when Ryan Shay collapsed less than six miles into the race in Central Park and died at a hospital.

headline: Orphans of Rwanda
‘The Tenth Muse’
text: Growing Up

headline: Chinese Recycling
U.A.W. and Ford Reach Tentative Agreement
text: DETROIT, Nov. 3 – The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement with the Ford Motor Company early this morning after a 41-hour marathon bargaining session, completing a series of new contracts with the American auto companies.

headline: Uh-Oh. Hardy-Har Deficit Looms.
text: Writers’ strike set for next week, and you know what that means:

headline: Straight Arrow With Arrow in Head?
text: In a first you may care about, Brian Williams of NBC tonight becomes the first working evening-news anchor to host “Saturday Night Live,” Bill Carter reports. Here’s Williams on partaking in late-hour sessions this week in the rabbit warren of “SNL” offices at 30 Rock:

headline: We’re Having a Party
text: The Quad is doing something a little bit different this Saturday. Instead of the usual morning links, we’re starting the day off with a tailgate party. The Times’ own Melissa Hoppert is a veteran of many Ohio State tailgates and she gives us the inside scoop on the granddaddy of them all, Hineygate. Do you have a favorite tailgate? Feel free to tell us about it in the comments section.

headline: Musharraf Declares State of Emergency
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 3 — The Pakistani leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, declared a state of emergency on Saturday night, suspending the country’s Constitution, blacking out all independent television news reports and filling the streets of the capital with police officers and soldiers.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 3
text: Here is a slide show of 12 photographs that tell the story of the past week in the New York region. Subjects include a Halloween parade in the East Village, a fire that left three people dead in Queens and the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Mozart’s “Zauberflöte.”

headline: The Early Word: The Kerik Relationship, Clinton Papers
text: We have a real treat for you this morning: the latest in our “Long Run” series about the presidential candidates is a Michael Powell composition about then-Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his relationship with Bernard B. Kerik. The former police commissioner currently faces several felony charges, and Mr. Giuliani has faced questions about what he knew about Mr. Kerik and when he knew it. Here’s the crux of the issue:

headline: Obama Challenges Clinton’s ‘Textbook’
text: Updated, with audioSPARTANBURG, S.C. — Barack Obama just unleashed a corker of a speech that had students here at Converse College on their feet and cheering. He painted a bold new picture of a world in which he were president and that brought wild applause.

headline: Hey, not so big spender
text: By now, everyone knows that Bush has been a big spender, betraying the principles of small-government conservatism.

headline: Shape of the planet
text: Yesterday I complained that news reports on Rudy Giuliani’s fake facts describe his position as “in dispute,” when it’s actually just false, and describe the truth as something “Democrats say” rather than as, simply, the truth.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Ute in Weimar
text: The Café Sabarsky in the Neue Galerie is a wonderful place to hear cabaret. It’s a small, warm, wood-paneled room in which no one is very far away from the action. But “Ute in Weimar,” as one might call the opening salvo in the “Berlin in Lights” festival’s series of cabaret evenings there, bore about the same relationship to Lotte Lenya as the Café Sabarsky bears to the Weimar Republic.

headline: Doris Lessing revealed
text: My cat, that is. In the photo for Rolling Stone’s interview, p. 126

headline: Arrrggghhh!
text: The lede, from the AP report on Rudy’s prostate claims:

headline: The Real Climate Debate: To Cap or to Tax?
text: In his Web column today, Tom Redburn writes that as even the most skeptical critics have begun to accept the scientific consensus that the burning of fossil fuels cannot continue uninterrupted without risking a dangerous elevation of the Earth’s atmospheric temperature, a simmering debate among experts has erupted into the open, and the next Congress and president might have to pick a winner. Go to Column

headline: A Rout in Lawrence
text: It’s still early, but the most eye-popping score of the day will likely be Kansas’ 76-39 rout of Nebraska. It was the most points scored against the Cornhuskers in their 117-year history.

headline: Scenes From the Campaign Trail
text: On the ground in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina.

headline: Who Needs One?
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — There are no palm trees, no beach, no surf, but this is still a paradise — for scalpers.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Nov. 4
text: Be glad that you get an extra hour of sleep tonight, because you’ll want to set an alarm to catch this Sunday’s talk shows, each of which boasts a powerful lineup.

headline: Personnel File: Willis Is Excelling for Lackluster 49ers
text: There have been few positives for the 49ers during a season in which their 2-0 start had onlookers saying the team was not nearly as good as expected. But one shining light has been Patrick Willis, the rookie linebacker from Mississippi.

headline: Week 9 In Preview: Colts May Be Patriots’ Only Obstacle
text: Anyone who sees the Colts’ game against the Patriots as a dream matchup is ignoring the downside.

headline: Going Green in Eugene
text: EUGENE, Ore. — In a state that prides itself on being environmentally friendly, it was not a surprise that before today’s game between No. 4 Oregon and No. 6 Arizona State approximately 150 people had a rally outside Auzten Stadium to encourage the reduction of carbon emissions.

headline: ‘There Is No Chance They Will Nod Off’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Military experts say that companies are now very close to developing technology that can make tanks invisible. Invisible tanks? Don’t we have enough defense contractors ripping off America as it is? What’s it going to be like when they start charging us for invisible tanks? “You owe us $10 billion.” “Where are the tanks?” “Right there.”

headline: Noun + Verb + 9/11 + Iran = Democrats’ Defeat?
text: Leave a comment about the Sunday, Nov. 4 column.

headline: How Far East? Not Too Far
text: When Europeans arrived in North America around 1600, there were, it is generally believed, 30 to 60 million buffalo roaming from the Hudson Bay to Mexico except for the extreme southeast and southwest of what is now the United States.

headline: A Rate Cut, a Rally and a Plunge
text: The Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates last week, but the broad stock market fell anyway, pulled down by disappointing earnings and concern about the state of the overall economy.

headline: Two Necessary Bond Issues
text: These are not the best of times, fiscally speaking, in the great state of New Jersey. Years of irresponsible borrowing by legislators and governors of both political parties have confronted the state with billions and billions of dollars of debt. Unfunded pension costs alone are estimated to be more than $50 billion.

headline: A Satirical Sit-Com’s Memorable Music
text: SHOULD you find yourself offended by a crass punch line or a tasteless sight gag on “Family Guy,” the gleefully provocative cartoon sitcom that celebrates its 100th episode on Fox Sunday night, you should direct your displeasure to the numerous arrested adolescents who populate its writing and animation staffs.

headline: From One Asian Cuisine to Another
text: THE sign over the door of Paradise Island in Williston Park reads: “Chinese Restaurant.” Don’t you believe it. This is a Vietnamese restaurant, the only one I know of east of Queens.

headline: Remembrance of Things Cast
text: The announcement early last year that Ian Schrager was building 40 Bond, a condominium project in downtown Manhattan, with the Swiss architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron set the design world abuzz. It wasn’t the first condo to be designed by a star architecture firm, and it won’t be the last, but 40 Bond’s construction site became a destination for even jaded New Yorkers.

headline: Discovering Hartford With Florence Berkman; Can Fake Grass and Dirt Really Be Healthy?; For Unwed Mothers, a Place to Thrive (3 Letters)
text: Discovering Hartford With Florence Berkman

headline: Growing Old in New York, and Struggling to Keep Up With Ever-Increasing Rents
text: “I went to visit friends in Florida, and I was almost going to move there, but then I didn’t like it,” said Robert Murphy. He sat in his tidy new apartment in a Manhattan senior housing development. He laughed, dismissing a retirement in Florida. “I missed my New York.”

headline: Where Did the Buck Stop at Merrill?
text: ON Oct. 24, Merrill Lynch announced its biggest write-down ever, an $8.4 billion charge that also represents the biggest known loss in Wall Street history. Six days later, its chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, retired from the company he had run since 2002.

headline: Perhaps a Boor (or a Bore), but Imus Makes It Work
text: ON THE SAW MILL RIVER PARKWAY -- Forget, for a moment, the Rutgers women’s basketball team and all that. Here’s one drive-time driver’s opinion about Don Imus’s old morning show. It wasn’t very good.

headline: Correction
text: Contrary to a statement in last week’s editorial, Christopher Caruso will not be on the ballot Tuesday in Bridgeport.

headline: Chelsea’s Own P.R. Man
text: The Habitats article last Sunday about a jewelry designer who lives in Chelsea and bemoans the gentrification of the neighborhood included an incorrect comment from the designer about the number of self-service laundries on Eighth Avenue between 14th and 23rd Streets. Two remain, not just one.

headline: From Restaurant Fryers, a Petroleum Alternative
text: SINCE the Asian restaurant Pearl East opened in Manhasset 10 years ago, its owner, Cathy Huang, has been disposing of the excess cooking grease from egg rolls and fried noodles in a big trap outside that had to be pumped out monthly. She put waste vegetable oil into big barrels and paid a hauler $40 a month to take it for recycling.

headline: Safety Note: Smoke Alarms and Carbon Monoxide Detectors
text: Fire prevention authorities recommend changing batteries in smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight saving time. The time change occurred this morning.

headline: Fuel Cell Hurdle: Only the Price Tag
text: HIGH on the list of marketing challenges that automakers face in selling zero-pollution cars is convincing the public that the cars can cover sufficient driving distances between refills or recharges.

headline: Canada a Favorite Among Gays
text: Canadian cities dominated a recent list of the top 10 international destinations for gay and lesbian travelers, according to a recent survey published by Community Marketing Inc. (www.communitymarketinginc.com), a San Francisco-based gay and lesbian market research company. The 12th annual tourism survey queried 7,561 consumers, who answered 42 questions in an online survey in September. Canada, where same sex marriage is legal, was the overall country favorite with three cities in the top 10 — Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver, the latter known for its gay-themed cruises (www.cruiseyt.com). Among individual cities, London took the No. 1 spot. Other popular destinations included Paris, Rome, and Puerto Vallarta and Cancún in Mexico. New York took top honors in the domestic Top 10 list, which also included Las Vegas, San Francisco and Fort Lauderdale.

headline: Silver Polish
text: For an iconic example of postwar flatware, Georg Jensen’s Caravel is hard to beat. It was designed in 1957 by Henning Koppel, whose singular approach to organic design also produced necklaces resembling whale skeletons and a curvy pitcher that was nicknamed “the pregnant duck.” Caravel combines the primal power of sculpture with the finesse of Danish silversmithing — all the more impressive considering it was Koppel’s first attempt at cutlery. The flat surfaces of its lean, tapered handles contrast elegantly with the more rounded, sensual forms of the spoon’s bowl, the fork’s tines and the knife’s blade.

headline: Letters
text: Domestic Violence

headline: Short Leash for Knicks at Home
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 3  A year ago, it took Knicks fans less than seven minutes to start booing during the home opener. It will probably not take them that long Sunday night, regardless of how the team plays in the early going against the Minnesota Timberwolves.

headline: Put a Lid on It
text: Paris is cuckoo for cocottes.

headline: When the Sacrifice of a Queen Leads to a Checkmate Victory
text: There is no moment in chess that is more magical than the queen sacrifice, especially when it leads to checkmate.

headline: Political Art: Futile, Maybe, but Still a Noble Pursuit
text: I have always had my doubts about the ultimate purpose of political art. My skepticism stems from a feeling that there are more effective forums for the expression of outrage at social, political and humanitarian injustices than the quiet rooms of a museum.

headline: In a Former Mining Colony, a Haven for Artists
text: MINERAL DE POZOS, Mexico

headline: The Affordability Problem
text: IN New Rochelle and Mount Vernon this fall, ribbon-cutting ceremonies held to mark the opening of new affordable housing drew elected officials who hailed their own efforts to get such units built, despite the high cost of land in Westchester and public resistance in many communities. So far this year, 95 new units of below-market-rate housing have become available, and 487 are under construction.

headline: Even Cut 50 Percent, Earmarks Clog Military Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 — Even though members of Congress cut back their pork barrel spending this year, House lawmakers still tacked on to the military appropriations bill $1.8 billion to pay 580 private companies for projects the Pentagon did not request.

text: The Farther East River

headline: Questions to Answer
text: In addition to 120 legislative races, voters will decide four questions on Tuesday.

headline: New Detainee Rights Weighed in Plans to Close Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 — Administration officials are considering granting Guantánamo detainees substantially greater rights as part of an effort to close the detention center and possibly move much of its population to the United States, according to officials involved in the discussions.

headline: Two Different Policies on Subletting in a Co-op
text: Q I am a shareholder in an East Village co-op. Our proprietary lease has a provision that enables existing shareholders to buy additional apartments. The lease also has a provision that if a shareholder who lives in the building has more than one apartment, he or she has the right to sublet the other apartment without board approval. Is this legal?

headline: Ex-Treasury Chief to Fill In at Citigroup
text: Citigroup’s board is highly likely to name Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary and an influential adviser to its embattled leader, as its interim chairman at an emergency meeting today, according to a person briefed on the situation.

headline: No More Mayor Chicken Little
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who administered tough medicine and nursed the city back to fiscal health after he took office in 2002, has been warning that another economic cooling is around the corner. Few people have paid real attention, though, and it’s not hard to see why. Despite the mayor’s predictions, year after recent year — helped along in a big way by the real estate market — the city has registered billions of dollars in surpluses, $4.4 billion in the last fiscal year alone. No longer.

headline: The Imperial Presidency
text: Three years after the American invasion of Iraq, after endless searches had found no sign of weapons of mass destruction, President Bush still believed that Saddam Hussein had had them. He expressed that conviction repeatedly to his chief of staff, Andrew Card, until Card left the White House in April 2006.

headline: Larissa Brookes, Elizabeth La Blanc
text: Larissa Cheney Brookes and Elizabeth Anne La Blanc were joined in a civil union on Thursday at Town Hall in Ridgewood, N.J. Philip F. Sheridan, a municipal judge there, officiated.

headline: A Rail Station Brings London and Paris Closer
text: It will have Europe’s longest Champagne bar, a daily farmer’s market, Wi-Fi, dozens of boutiques — and some of the world’s fastest trains. It is St. Pancras International (stpancras.eurostar.com), the new London hub for Eurostar, the high-speed train service that connects England to Belgium and France through the Channel tunnel.

headline: Edwina von Gal | Landscape Designer
text: She’s dug dirt for a who’s who of international clients, from Richard Serra to Calvin Klein.

headline: Susan Moran, Peter Pangis
text: Susan Eugenie Moran was married yesterday to Peter Gus Pangis. The Rev. Ambrose Bitziadis-Bowers officiated at St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Clifton, N.J., with the Rev. Peter J. Orfanakos, another Greek Orthodox priest, taking part.

headline: Childhood for Dummies
text: Nostalgic parents who made a best seller of a faux- 1920s rough-and-tumble manual, “The Dangerous Book for Boys,” may soon do the same with its just-published companion, “The Daring Book for Girls.”

headline: The Performer in Waiting
text: MY grandfather was the president of a small Sephardic synagogue in Coney Island. My father and I would walk there from Brighton Beach for Sabbath services and the high holidays, and walk back. It was a time for conversation about the world, about growing up, about anything I wanted to ask him and vice versa.

headline: It’s a Dangerous World
text: To the Editor:

headline: Could Rodriguez Stay a Yankee? Only for Less Money
text: The only way the Yankees would bring back Alex Rodriguez is if Rodriguez became so desperate to stay that he would take a pay cut, something they do not envision. But Rodriguez has not eliminated the Yankees from consideration, and his agent, Scott Boras, said last night that he was still willing to meet with the team.

headline: Man Bites Dog, and Girls, Too
Jamie Rosen, Brian Fields
text: Jamie Beth Rosen, the daughter of Harriett and Frederic Rosen of West Bloomfield, Mich., was married last evening to Brian David Fields, the son of Cynthia and Lawrence Fields of New York. Rabbi Joseph Krakoff officiated at the Ritz-Carlton, Dearborn, in Michigan.

headline: Smoke Detectors Are Just a Start
text: SMOKE detectors were just the beginning. Now there are all manner of detectors that can alert homeowners to everything from carbon monoxide to freezing pipes.

headline: Demon Barber, Meat Pies and All, Sings on Screen
text: SOME time in 1980, during the five months that the grim and glorious musical “Sweeney Todd” played the Theater Royal Drury Lane, a California college student visiting London bought a ticket. And another and another and another.

text: This article was reported by David Rohde, Jane Perlez and Salman Masood, and was written by Mr. Rohde.

headline: Bonnie Regan, James Gerhart

The Rev. Richard Hasselbach, a priest affiliated with CITI Ministries, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Noun + Verb + 9/11 + Iran = Democrats’ Defeat?
text: WHEN President Bush started making noises about World War III, he only confirmed what has been a Democratic article of faith all year: Between now and Election Day he and Dick Cheney, cheered on by the mob of neocon dead-enders, are going to bomb Iran.

headline: Outside the Box
text: MANY colleges say their mission is to mold young minds, but a few take it to the next level. They have a particular philosophy about how life should be lived or knowledge absorbed, and they want to make sure their students are not just reading about it or dabbling in it. They want their students to live it, day in and day out, for four years. Sound intense? It is. A bit offbeat? That too. Such colleges are not for everyone, nor do they want to be.

headline: Lindsay Schmidt, Jeremy Beard
text: Lindsay Elizabeth Schmidt and Jeremy Alexander Beard were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew’s Church in New York. The Rev. Elizabeth Garnsey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rebecca Gertsmark, Ben Oren
text: Rebecca Anna Gertsmark a daughter of Edith and Aleksandr Gertsmark of West Bloomfield, Mich., was married last evening to Ben Oren, a son of Miky and David Oren of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Harold Loss officiated at the Royal Park Hotel in Rochester, Mich., with Cantor Neil Michaels taking part.

headline: Economic Growth, Clad in Military Garb
text: PAKISTAN’S recently re-elected leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has indicated that he might finally heed the calls for him to step down as head of the army. But even if the general becomes a civilian president, that will not take the uniform off Pakistan’s economy.

headline: Sara Holmes and George Flowers
text: Sara Catherine Holmes, the daughter of Linda Schwartz of Dumfries, Va., and Hannibal E. Holmes Jr. of Haverstraw, N.Y., is to be married today to George William Flowers, a son of Dr. Loma Flowers and Edgar Flowers of San Francisco. The Rev. Robert E. Slade, a United Methodist minister, is to perform the ceremony at Mount Zion United Methodist Church in Washington.

headline: ACT vs. SAT
text: FROM the moment I gave birth, I began to gird myself for the difficult questions that tiny, nosy people might one day ask. I prepared answers worthy of a White House press secretary to address such subjects as teenage sex (“never heard of it”) and drug use (“mild decongestants only”).

headline: In Local Waters, an Oyster Resurgence
text: TWO years after a failed effort to declare it an endangered species, the Eastern oyster is making a big comeback, thanks in part, experts say, to farming and habitat restoration efforts across the Northeast.

headline: Unblinking Look at Death Without Nobility
text: AT the Sundance Film Festival, where the writer-director Tamara Jenkins’s second feature, “The Savages,” had its premiere in January, dysfunctional families are, to an exhausting degree, the norm.

headline: The Global Sympathetic Audience
text: ON Aug. 1, Nick Starr, a 27-year-old computer consultant from Tampa, Fla., was tapping text messages into his cellphone, telling hundreds of his virtual friends about his day.

headline: A Tiny Child Needs More Help Than a Mother Can Deliver
text: After eight months at a homeless shelter, Rosa Zayas and her young son, Rodwin, recently moved into a one-bedroom apartment of their own. It was the 15th home for this fragile family since Ms. Zayas, 31, and her husband separated in July 2005.

headline: Prodigal Returns, Bearing Dialogue
text: THE souvenir shop in Shubert Alley, the heart of the theater district, wasn’t open the other morning as Aaron Sorkin walked by, but he stopped and squinted in the window. Frowning, he expressed disappointment that the “Wicked” T-shirts were stacked untidily on a shelf, the logos unaligned. Mr. Sorkin once worked in this very shop, in the fall of 1983, when he was fresh from studying musical theater at Syracuse University and came to New York to get work as an actor.

headline: The Riddle of Steve Levy
text: Steve Levy is a brilliant Suffolk County executive, a leader with tenacity, integrity and a lot of good ideas. He is also a maddening one, a small-bore, surprisingly ineffective mishandler of his signature issue, immigration. Solve that conundrum and you solve the riddle of Mr. Levy, which this page has not been able to do.
