headline: Iraq Postings
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Style Network
text: Ask her how she stocks Mc & Co, the under-the-radar home furnishings and accessories boutique in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and the French-born decorative painter Corinne Gilbert will blithely reply, “I just go to my friends.” Her best buds in Paris, Catherine Lévy and Sigolène Prébois, the team behind Tsé & Tsé Associées, give Gilbert access to their entire range of tableware and lighting (including their asymmetrical black goblets). Justin Giunta — the founder of Subversive Jewelry, who served as Gilbert’s assistant before becoming the current darling of costume-jewelry collectors — will unveil his foray into lamp design at Mc & Co this fall. Jagged white ceramic vases appear courtesy of Joan Bankemper. There are new discoveries, too, like Sylvain Willenz’s delicate arboreal light sculpture and Casey O’Connor’s glasses with nature-study decals à la Albertus Seba. Gilbert has also chipped in, designing the chicest tarp totes on either side of the Atlantic. What a pal! 57 North Sixth Street; (718) 388-3551.

headline: Dear Abby
text: All the nation’s founding fathers were concerned about how history would judge them, none more so than John Adams. Adams often voiced his apprehension that his contribution to American independence would be overshadowed by the attention paid to George Washington and Thomas Jefferson. Yet the survival of more than 1,100 letters exchanged by John and Abigail Adams, 289 of which are included in this welcome new edition, gives Adams an advantage over his contemporaries in the historical record.

headline: Sarah Altman, Bryan Bumsted
text: Sarah Crispin Altman, the daughter of Elizabeth S. Altman and Charles R. Altman of Pittsburgh, was married there last evening to Bryan MacLeod Bumsted, a son of Patricia P. Bumsted and Roy R. Bumsted III of Bonita Springs, Fla. The Rev. Leslie G. Reimer, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Heinz Memorial Chapel.

headline: Surrendering to the Suburbs
text: IT was a clear fall day, exactly a year ago, when we left Manhattan for our new home in Westchester. As we ambled up the Sprain Brook Parkway (upstate, in city parlance), I remember thinking how beautiful the leaves were — a brilliant array of golds, reds and browns — and that if we had stayed in the city our foliage appreciation would have been limited to what we could see on quick jaunts through Stuyvesant Town.

headline: Rally Salvages More Than Win for L.S.U.
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 3 — On his way off the field, Louisiana State center Brett Helms paused to consider what could have been an unbearable loss to Alabama. Helms had to catch his breath, not because it was a grueling four-hour game, but because it was a four-hour siege of emotion.

headline: Swann’s Hypothesis
text: Jonah Lehrer strikes me as one of those young people who turn up in articles on how life is now so competitive that children no longer have time for jump-rope or adolescents for baby-sitting. At 25, he has already been a Rhodes scholar, worked in the lab of a Nobel Prize-winning neuroscientist and been a line chef in the kitchens of Le Cirque 2000 and Le Bernardin. He writes a blog on science issues affiliated with Seed magazine, where he is an editor, and now has written “Proust Was a Neuroscientist,” a precocious and engaging book that tries to mend the century-old tear between the literary and scientific cultures.

headline: Getting Along Famously
text: Buddylube

text: Elizabeth Anne Hondl, the daughter of Constance and Roman J. Hondl of Edina, Minn., was married yesterday to Adam Maccabee Trachtenberg, a son of Francine and Stephen Joel Trachtenberg of Washington. Judge José A. Cabranes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New Haven, officiated at the Mill City Museum in Minneapolis.

headline: Correction: She’s Famous (and So Can You)
text: An article last Sunday about the model and entertainer Tila Tequila and her rise to fame on the Internet misstated the title of a recent song by Soko, which was also made famous on the Web, through MySpace. It is “I’ll Kill Her,” not “I’ll Kill Him.”

headline: Drive for Neediest Cases Fund, a Tradition Since 1912, Begins
text: Sunday begins the 96th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign. Since 1912, the fund has provided direct assistance to troubled children, families and the elderly in New York.

headline: New Jersey Man Is Killed in Midtown Poker Game
text: A mathematician and former professor was shot and killed when masked men with guns broke into a floating poker game on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan late Friday night, the police said.

headline: Yes, Minister
text: It says something about the place of Tony Blair in the contemporary British imagination that he has already faced war crimes charges at least three times — on stage, on television and now in a sharp page turner of a thriller. Even before the prime minister left office in June, London theatergoers had mulled the legal merits of a war crimes case in Richard Norton-Taylor’s “Called to Account,” focusing on Blair’s decision to join George W. Bush in the 2003 invasion of Iraq. Earlier this year, Channel 4 television minced no words with Alistair Beaton’s drama, “The Trial of Tony Blair.”

headline: Correction: Naming Names at Gitmo
text: An article on Oct. 21 about Navy Lt. Cmdr. Matthew Diaz, who was court-martialed and convicted on some charges that involved making public the names of detainees at Guantánamo Bay, misspelled the name of a city where he lived as a teenager. It is San Bernardino, Calif., not San Bernadino.

headline: What She Learned From Her Alma Mater
text: ADRIENNE KENNEDY’S mother used to enthrall her over breakfast by vividly recounting the dreams she’d had the night before. And Ms. Kennedy’s father captivated her — and audiences among Cleveland’s African-Americans of the 1930s and ’40s — with his uplifting orations on how blacks must move forward. Today, at 76, this celebrated playwright has come to recognize a melding of her parents’ narrative styles in her own work. “In spite of the fact that I’ve always thought I was influenced by ‘Antigone’ and Lorca,” she said, “it’s now clear to me that in everything I’ve ever written, I was trying to do what my parents did.”

headline: Pretty (Sometimes) in Pink
text: Works by 107 artists from New Jersey, New York and other Northeastern states make up “Pink,” a pleasant enough if muddled exhibition at the Perkins Center for the Arts. The color pink is the theme; there are also a pink catalog, a pink invitation and even free pink cookies in the galleries.

headline: The Law of Unintended Consequences?
text: THE Sarbanes-Oxley Act, enacted in mid-2002 in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom accounting scandals, aimed to improve the accuracy and reliability of corporate financial disclosures.

headline: Hot Extinguisher
text: Peter Arnell, the mastermind behind advertising and branding for Donna Karan and M&M’s, also designed Jacob the Jeweler’s Manhattan store. Now his boundary-averse company has expanded into products.

headline: Mexicans Appalled by Scenes From Flooded State
text: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3 — Mexicans were gripped Saturday by images of dramatic rescues from flooding in the southeastern state of Tabasco, where much of the state capital, Villahermosa, was underwater and the governor said that thousands of people waited on their rooftops for help to arrive.

headline: Timing of Boras’s Bluff May Prove Costly
text: The fallout from the Alex Rodriguez World Series opt-out continues to stain him and his agent, Scott Boras. Rodriguez has been publicly silent on the outrageous timing of his act, but Boras was busy the past week spinning like a whirling dervish. His words and explanations convinced nobody of his innocence in the matter. The more he talked, the more guilty he sounded.

headline: A Success Story Out of Post-Soviet Wreckage
text: RIGA, Latvia — Like the coliseums of ancient Rome, Daugava Stadium here in Latvia’s capital is a decaying monument to a fallen athletic superpower. Once a monument to Soviet sporting prowess, the bulky structure is now a crumbling reminder of past glory.

headline: Sophie Donelson, Gregory Lindsay
text: Sophie Dow Donelson, a daughter of Bettyna and Wayne Donelson of Ashburnham, Mass., was married yesterday in Hamilton, Bermuda, to Gregory Thomas Lindsay, a son of Elaine Barrie of Bourbonnais, Ill., and Thomas Lindsay of Kankakee, Ill. Marlene Christopher, the registrar general of Bermuda, officiated at the Government Administration Building.

headline: A Vote for the Adirondacks
text: It may seem like a small thing — a new well to give decent drinking water to 71 families in Raquette Lake, a small town north of Utica in the Adirondacks. But the town’s request for permission to build the well on state parkland is the only constitutional issue that voters across New York will be asked to approve next Tuesday. New Yorkers should vote yes. And lovers of the Adirondacks should be extremely relieved that even this modest request, for a structure 10 feet wide and 12 feet long, needs statewide approval before it can be built in one of the pristine areas of the park.

headline: The Perfect Match With Pig’s Tails
text: “A LOT of people don’t really like it, which I find rather strange,” Fergus Henderson said. One suspects that Mr. Henderson, the chef and owner of St. John Restaurant in London, has uttered this sentence before.

headline: Deciding Mr. DeLuca’s Fate
text: A bipartisan State Senate committee has until Nov. 11 to make recommendations on the fate of Senator Louis C. DeLuca, Republican of Woodbury. It is clear that the Senate is uncomfortable judging one of its own. But it is also clear that Mr. DeLuca brought these proceedings on himself.

headline: Mayoral Race Propels Shelter Into Limelight
text: FOR 19 years, the Jan Peek House, a homeless shelter in Peekskill, has been so unobtrusive, its supporters say, that most city residents do not even know it exists.

headline: The Prizewinning Opera Time Forgot
text: WHILE rummaging through the secondhand department of a Viennese music store many years ago I came across an unusual copy of Samuel Barber’s four-act opera “Vanessa”: one of those rough photocopies used by singers when they are learning their roles for a new work. There were light pencil marks here and there, mostly in the title character’s part. “Hmm,” I thought. “Sena Jurinac must have been cleaning out her closets.”

headline: Joanne Cosiol, Joshua Faber
text: Joanne Cosiol and Joshua Ross Faber were married last evening at Linwood Country Club in Linwood, N.J. Rabbi David Weiss officiated.

headline: 36 Hours in Ibiza, Spain
text: AS a nucleus of the electronic music scene, Ibiza attracts party people of every age and demographic, from London fashionistas and Goa-style ravers to French bobos and the prime minister of Spain. But after Oct. 1, when Ibiza's club season comes to a euphoric finale, this Spanish island eases back into its Mediterranean groove. Whether it's hibernating in yoga retreats, trekking through Unesco World Heritage sites or lounging by turquoise blue water and white-sand beaches, Ibiza offers plenty of laid-back after-party spots. Plus, there are phenomenal seafood and glamorous hippies. And if the itch to party should strike, don't worry, the island's original party palace is open year round.

headline: Pride in Architecture
text: The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about recognition conferred on various New Jersey structures by the state chapter of the American Institute of Architects misidentified the county for Margate, the home of Lucy the Elephant, a popular seaside attraction that was cited as one of state’s 150 “best places.” It is Atlantic County, not Ocean.

headline: Correction: The Future Is Drying Up
text: An article on Oct. 21 about the drought in the American West misstated the name of an organization that is a sponsor of Western Water Assessment, one of whose engineers testified before Congress about water shortages. It is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, not the National Oceanographic Atmospheric Administration.

headline: Paperback Row
text: AGAINST THE DAY, by Thomas Pynchon. (Penguin, $18.) Published nearly a decade after “Mason & Dixon,” “Against the Day” is Pynchon’s longest (at 1,085 pages) and, our reviewer, Liesl Schillinger, said, his funniest and most accessible novel. The complex plot unspools during the years from 1893 to the 1920s; one of its strands is the attempt by three brothers to avenge their father’s murder by agents of the plutocracy. Along the way there are dazzling set pieces, Dickensian characters, torrents of words and Pynchon’s signature puns. “Against the Day” proves Pynchon the heir to H. G. Wells and Joseph Conrad, Schillinger wrote, and a “matchless fantasist of the real.”

headline: Parlor Tricks
text: William P. Young and Horace J. Gardner promise, in the introduction to their 1935 party manual, “Games and Stunts for All Occasions,” that “we have been careful to eliminate anything that might offend persons of any age, creed or sex, and to avoid incorporating any game which might develop into unnecessary roughness or rowdyism.” Young and Gardner are not so tasteful that they’ve eliminated Corpse, a game in which a person lying under a sheet with galoshes on her hands must answer the question “Oh corpse, are you alive?” But in their quest for delicate, finger-sandwich fun, the authors overlook what the Victorians, who invented the parlor game, knew to be true: these games are compelling precisely because they allow people to pop their psychic corsets and indulge their rowdy inner selves.

headline: A Battle Rages in London Over a Mega-Mosque Plan
text: LONDON  Disputes over mosques have broken out across Europe. Residents from Belgium to France to Germany have expressed unease at minarets competing in the urban landscape with the spires and stones of centuries-old cathedrals.

headline: You Are What Your Name Says You Are
text: IN France, a person’s name can signify as little as a measure of what’s big on TV at any given time, or as much as an entire country’s nature.

headline: Lauren Wiener, Justin Gelman
text: Lauren Beth Wiener, the daughter of Lois Wiener and Robert Wiener of Commack, N.Y., was married last evening to Justin Adam Gelman, the son of Riva Gelman and Dr. William Gelman of Dix Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Howard Buechler performed the ceremony at Temple B’nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, N.Y., with Cantor Ralph Nussbaum participating.

headline: Correction: The Cult of Gocco
text: The Consumed column on Oct. 21 carried an incorrect art credit. The illustration was by Peter Arkle, not Leif Parsons.

headline: Turkey Skeptical of Iraqi Vows to Stop Kurdish Raids
text: ISTANBUL, Nov. 3 — Turkey said on Saturday that two days of meetings with officials from Iraq and the United States on how to stop Kurdish militants who attack Turkey from northern Iraq had produced no new proposals.

headline: Top Yanks Managers: Brains, Not Bats
text: The Yankees’ new manager was never much of a slugger. Nothing new about that. And the transition to Joe Girardi from Joe Torre stirred some commotion. Nothing new about that either.

headline: Almost a Gentleman
text: Midway through Donald McCaig’s unexpectedly diverting novel, “Rhett Butler’s People,” a black man about to be lynched in the post-bellum South asks Rhett to please shoot him dead before the mob breaks into the jail and does worse. Rhett obliges. Thus does McCaig correct the record. In Margaret Mitchell’s telling — that is, in “Gone With the Wind” — we learn that Rhett has been arrested for killing “this darky who had insulted a white woman.” A few chapters later, Rhett confesses his guilt to Scarlett O’Hara, the other half of Mitchell’s famous romantic pair. “What else could a Southern gentleman do?” he asks.

headline: Presidential Politics Have Shifted Already
text: DES MOINES, Nov. 3 — With a year to go until Election Day, the Republican and Democratic Parties are going through internal battles over their very identity, even as the races for their presidential nominations intensify. In many ways, the battles over how the parties will define themselves in the post-Bush era are nearly as significant a political fight as the presidential contest itself.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘The Almost Moon’
text: A review on Oct. 21 about “The Almost Moon,” a novel by Alice Sebold, misstated the given name of a Russian poet to whom the protagonist compares herself. It is Marina Tsvetayeva, not Maria.

headline: U.S. Sanctions Force World Bank to Halt Some Iran Aid
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 — The World Bank, newly caught up in the Bush administration’s campaign against Iran, has had to suspend payments for earthquake relief, sanitation and other projects there in response to new American sanctions on leading Iranian banks, World Bank officials say.

headline: A Modern Buddhist Uprising Strikes a Quieter Chord
text: In this country, no doubt like in others, news about demonstrating monks in Myanmar has been reduced to a trickle, though here and there word leaks out of additional protests against military rule, and these reports find their way into the back pages of the newspapers.

A Place to Find That Elusive Book; Bye-Bye, Street Fairs, Don’t Hurry Back; The Faces May Change, but the Heart Remains; We Don’t Strand Families
Who Truly Need Shelter (5 Letters)

headline: Re-Arranging the Furniture
text: For more than two decades, Tom Dixon, the renegade British designer, has put his energy not only into furniture design but also into challenging the conventions of the business. This winter, Dixon, the creator of the Mirror Ball, is bringing his show to America; and a premonition of what we can expect harks back to a London morning in September 2006, when Dixon delivered 500 injection-molded polystyrene chairs to Trafalgar Square. Every chair was gone in seven minutes, borne away by city dwellers transformed into worker ants who left behind them the lasting sense of an original event.

headline: Home-Office Politics
text: Like other businesses, politics these days is conducted less in person than on speaker phone and laptops. Campaign consultants, policy analysts, fund-raisers and bloggers do most of their work in the comfort of their own homes, or in their cars, or maybe at Starbucks. Political professionals have as a result become part of a much larger American movement. In his new book, “Microtrends,” the Democratic pollster Mark Penn notes that 4.2 million Americans now work exclusively from home (a nearly 100 percent increase from 1990), while some 20 million do it part time. Some of these workers are employees who telecommute to traditional offices, but most represent a kind of modern, untethered American work force.

headline: License Issue Figures Large in Local Races
text: BUFFALO — When she arrived at an assisted living center for a candidates’ forum here recently, Kathleen C. Hochul, the Erie County clerk, spent a few minutes explaining what county clerks do. As the audience listened sleepily, Ms. Hochul, a no-nonsense lawyer, quickly reeled through an explanation of housing permits, business registrations and her plan to shorten lines at the downtown auto bureau.

headline: Yours for the Peeping
text: JEREMY FLETCHER and Alejandra Lillo, designers at Graft, an architecture and design firm based in Berlin, Beijing and Los Angeles, were working out a dialogue between voyeurism and exhibitionism, they said, when they designed the swooping, shiny white interiors of the W Downtown, a glass-walled condominium tower to be built in 2009 in Manhattan’s financial district.

headline: Top Marathoner Collapses and Dies in Olympic Trials
text: A triumphant United States Olympic trials marathon turned somber yesterday morning when Ryan Shay, a 28-year-old veteran marathoner, collapsed during the race in Central Park and was pronounced dead at Lenox Hill Hospital.

headline: Political Tango, Women in the Lead
text: BUENOS AIRES

headline: Three Big Names Fall Behind Youngsters
text: The three grew up in Africa, migrated to the United States, became American citizens and made their mark as world-class runners on the track and the roads. All three were given strong chances to make the United States Olympic team in the marathon. None did.

headline: By Opting Out, Rodriguez Really Wants In
text: To the New York-centric sports fan, the most newsworthy event of the past week was not the Boston Red Sox’ sweep of Colorado in the World Series, but the decision of Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez to opt out of his contract to pursue the siren song of free agency. Indeed, the opt-out decision was announced during the final Series game, at virtually the earliest possible moment under the contract.

headline: Daring You to Try This at Home
text: WHAT’S hot and what’s not? That is the question the Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show strives to answer.

headline: Letters: A Man of the World
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tour de France
text: Once upon a time, an American girl in Paris went in search of the perfect French boyfriend. Her quest had all the elements of a fairy tale — handsome princes, creepy monsters and benevolent dwarfs — except for the crucial happy ending. For unlike Cinderella, whose foot found its ideal glass slipper, or Goldilocks, with her just-right porridge and lodgings, this heroine never discovered a flawless fit. Instead, her Platonic ideal of Frenchness eluded her at every turn. Étienne confessed that he spoke Catalan at home. Bernard, a native of Brittany, grumbled that construing him as a model Français was not unlike describing an Irishman as English. Ever since the Dreyfus Affair had exposed his compatriots’ anti-Semitism in the late 19th century, Léon explained, his family had viewed itself as Jewish first, French second. François, a haughty aristocrat, informed her that in the 15th century, his ancestors had fought with the Burgundians ... against the French. (“But what long memories you Frenchmen have!” she protested to both Léon and François, endearing herself to neither.) In the end, the damsel had little choice but to abort her mission, leave Paris and marry an American.

headline: College Towns Escape the Pain
text: As the inner cities, along with much of Florida and the interior of California, face the prospect of a foreclosure meltdown, American college towns appear to be islands of stability.

headline: Ready for City Life
text: IF John Berglund was going to take a job in New York, he and his family most certainly were going to live in the center of the city.

headline: TV Show Over? Obsess About It on the Web
text: The broadcast networks are clearly adopting more of an “if you can’t beat ’em, join ’em” philosophy toward the Internet. Harnessing a natural human inclination toward gossip, complaint, prediction and obsession, they are using TV show Web sites to offer clips, outtakes, interviews, games, message boards and blogs — not to mention entire episodes.

headline: ‘The Conscience of a Liberal’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Civil Discourse, Meet the Internet
text: WARNING: This column contains rude and objectionable language not normally found in the pages of this newspaper but seen surprisingly often on its Web site.

headline: In the Mother Tongue, Songs With a Wide Appeal
text: YIDDISH may seem inseparable from nostalgia, but Eleanor Reissa, a noted performer, revels in its more earthy qualities. “Yiddish is so gorgeous,” she says, “so luscious and sensual and poetic a language, that it’s funny people think of it as dead. The reality is it bursts with life.”

headline: Shock Tactics
text: Fashioned from a single metal tube bent into a sleek, low-slung frame, Marcel Breuer’s Wassily chair was a touchstone of Modernism, a manifestation of the movement’s faith in technology, convenience and the promise of a better life. In the artist Iván Navarro’s rendition of the chair, the frame is made from three neon tubes in a glowing shade of disco-era purple. Navarro’s “Red and Blue Electric Chair” is another Modernist remake, this one in the image of Gerrit Rietveld’s Red and Blue Chair from 1918. “It was kind of a building block for me,” Navarro says of the fluorescent piece, an exercise in materials and formalism. Unlike the Bauhaus approach to chairs as “machines for sitting,” Navarro’s artwork is not for sitting at all, and he would be more apt to refer to his chairs as machines for killing. “Neon is fragile,” he says, “but it can electrocute you.”

headline: Extermination States
text: Who, after all, speaks today of the annihilation of the Armenians?” Hitler supposedly said on Aug. 22, 1939, as he prepared his henchmen for the savagery of race war and the slaughter of the Jews of Europe. In many ways, this link between the genocide of the Armenians by the Ottoman Empire in 1915 and the genocide of the Jews by the Nazis from 1941 to 1945 brings together the elements of Alan Kramer’s important book, “Dynamic of Destruction: Culture and Mass Killing in the First World War.” Kramer believes that the two world wars may be regarded as a single four-decade trauma, and he argues that World War I was considerably more than simply a new industrial form of warfare that brutalized the modern world.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Film

headline: Fasten Your Seatbelts
text: The last time I saw Bette Davis, she was in her dotage, the painful ravages of cancer and a paralyzing stroke cruelly evident. We had tea in a Manhattan hotel room, and she admitted her two favorite words were “What’s next?” Her days in front of a camera were mortgaged beyond revival, but with her flaring nostrils and incendiary nicotine butts, and still walking like an anchovy, she slashed the air with one parting shot: “You have not seen the end of Bette Davis!”

headline: The Inner Scholar
text: TO hear Thomas B. Coburn, president of Naropa University, explain the theory of contemplative education is to grasp a simple concept. The Buddhist-inspired teaching that goes on at this small college, he says, is aimed at giving students "a critical perspective on their inner lives."

headline: Hey, Mr. Escalade Man
text: IF he revisits Highway 61 yet again, chances are Bob Dylan will do it in a Cadillac Escalade, just like the one he drives in a new television commercial.

headline: December Release Schedule
text: DECEMBER

headline: Rethinking How to Teach the New Teachers
text: SCHOOL enrollments are increasing year by year, but qualified teachers are leaving the classroom in droves. More than a million veteran teachers are nearing retirement, and more will follow.

headline: Rivers of Blood in a Winter Wonderland
text: THERE is blood on the snow in “Lions for Lambs,” blood on the living room carpet in “American Gangster,” blood just about everywhere in “No Country for Old Men.” The more lighthearted “Sweeney Todd” has its singing, throat-slitting barber. “There Will Be Blood” may be the title of a film opening the day after Christmas, but it could be the slogan for this entire holiday season.

headline: A Hospital’s Journey
text: THE northwest corner of Park Avenue and 70th Street has almost disappeared under construction netting. From the side street, it’s as if the big 1927 apartment house at 720 Park Avenue, designed by Rosario Candela, had never been built. In fact, it went up at the same time as everything else on the block, replacing the old Presbyterian Hospital, built in 1872, long before the Upper East Side became a desirable neighborhood.

headline: Try Giving
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Las Vegas Close-Up for Planet Hollywood
text: Movie fans visiting Las Vegas can now stay and play at the new Planet Hollywood Resort and Casino (www.planethollywood.com). Formerly the Aladdin, the property was rebranded last April and underwent a billion-dollar renovation. It will be celebrating its grand opening on Nov. 16 and 17.

headline: Correction: Lina D’Orazio, Adam Baer
text: A report on Oct. 21, about the marriage of Lina D’Orazio and Adam Baer, included outdated information on the location of the ceremony. After the article went to press, the wedding was moved from Malibu to the Mulholland Tennis Club in Los Angeles because of the California wildfires.

headline: Beyond Those Health Care Numbers
text: WITH the health care system at the center of the political debate, a lot of scary claims are being thrown around. The dangerous ones are not those that are false; watchdogs in the news media are quick to debunk them. Rather, the dangerous ones are those that are true but don’t mean what people think they mean.

headline: Now Wearing | Cuff Love
text: Handmade from reclaimed veneer, the Coffee Cuff ($68 from the Vancouver-based firm Contexture Design) is made to fit snugly around a deli coffee cup but does double duty as an eco-friendly bracelet.

headline: Willis Is Excelling for Lackluster 49ers
text: There have been few positives for the 49ers during a season in which their 2-0 start had onlookers saying the team was not nearly as good as expected. But one shining light has been Patrick Willis, the rookie linebacker from Mississippi.

headline: Golf, Wine and Sheep in New Zealand
text: A new resort, the Farm at Cape Kidnappers, is scheduled to open this month in the New Zealand wine region of Hawke’s Bay on the North Island (www.capekidnappers.com). Adjoining the Tom Doak-designed Cape Kidnappers golf course, the property, set on a 6,000-acre sheep and cattle farm, above, includes 24 suites and rooms and a four-bedroom cottage. All rooms have porches with views of the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Op-Art: Marathon Man
text: ALBERTO ARROYO calls himself the mayor of Central Park. A former boxer from Puerto Rico, Mr. Arroyo came to New York in 1935. To stay in shape, he ran in Central Park, switching to the reservoir loop after the police shooed him from the bridle path. He says he was the first man to run in Central Park.

headline: Wireless Workplaces, Touching the Sky
text: THE Hearst Tower in Midtown Manhattan is known for its environmentally friendly features, along with its stunning design by the British architect Norman Foster. A distinctive triangular structure of glass and steel, it rises from the shell of the original six-story sandstone headquarters erected by William Randolph Hearst in 1928.

headline: Incorrect and Insensitive
text: New Jersey’s Constitution, drawn up in 1947, is generally regarded as a progressive document that takes into account many of the problems and challenges of the modern era.

headline: Heather Gottlieb, Russell Freyman
text: Heather Joy Gottlieb, the daughter of Arline Gottlieb and Sheldon Gottlieb of North Massapequa, N.Y., was married yesterday to Russell Alan Freyman, a son of Andrea Hoffman of Syosset and Richard Freyman of Lakewood Ranch, Fla.

headline: Yes, You Are Old
text: For the last 10 years, Beloit College in lower Wisconsin has issued the Mindset List. The creation of Tom McBride, a humanities professor, and Ron Nief, the public affairs director, the popular list is distributed at the start of each academic year to faculty and staff (and the world at large) to remind them of the perspective of each year’s entering freshmen. Below are a few items from the decade’s lists.

headline: The Dead and the Naked
text: Last week: Detective Oakwood told Miss Skattergoods that a note (written in Latin) was found in G.G.’s wallet. Was it a threat?

headline: A Month After a Shooting, a Courtyard Has Turned Somber
text: NICK SANCHEZ, a 20-year-old musician, was fiddling with a computer in a recording studio on the top floor of a ramshackle brownstone on West 131st Street. At the touch of a key, a menacing synthesizer line emerged from the speakers, along with a gut-rattling bass beat.

headline: Krisjon Olson, Charles Bergstrom
text: Krisjon Rae Olson, a daughter of Candice and Raymond P. Olson of San Diego, was married there yesterday to Dr. Charles Peter Bergstrom, the son of Michele and Pete Bergstrom of Norwood, Mass. The ceremony was led by Stelios B. Papadopoulos, an uncle of the bride who was designated a deputy marriage commissioner by San Diego County to officiate, at the St. Francis Chapel in Balboa Park.

headline: Middle Passage
text: To the Editor:

headline: San Francisco Self Edge
text: The denim that true jeans aficionados clamor for these days is from Japan, not the United States, and nowhere is that more apparent than at Self Edge, a boutique in the Mission District of San Francisco.

headline: T-Bones — and Tea
text: Like Hell’s Kitchen, the meatpacking district has an uninviting name and increasing popularity as a place to eat well. These restaurants are the neighborhood’s latest arrivals.

headline: The Green Party
text: The scene: a convivial New York barbecue celebrating a couple’s return from Los Angeles. Margaritas were blending; the pork shoulder was falling willingly off the bone; the collard greens — straight from a guest’s garden! — were macerating with their new best friends, the minced onions. Suddenly, the hum of conversation was stopped dead by a plaintive whine from the hostess’s husband. “Honey! Do you still not want me to use paper plates? We’re running out of real dishes!”

headline: Now Flavoring | Roe v. Wasabi
text: Get out the blinis. This fall, Tsar Nicoulai, the San Francisco purveyor known for its domestic caviar, will introduce trout and whitefish roe infused with the likes of kaffir lime leaf, brandy and vanilla. The unusual collection, called Passot Roe, came about because Roland Passot, the chef who owns La Folie restaurant, began experimenting with adding flavors to trout roe, which has a firm, almost crunchy texture and is fairly inexpensive.

headline: Venting, Yes. Profiting, No.
text: WITHOUT quite having a clear plan, Gregg Rottler began contemplating his Web empire last year on his desktop computer at his home near Tampa, Fla. As many bloggers have done, Mr. Rottler, a state environmental code officer, followed an impulse to share stories about annoyances. He and his wife, Karen, an elementary school teacher, often eat out, and he realized that people liked to talk about restaurant experiences gone wrong.

headline: Productivity May Explain the Market
text: IF you have been baffled by stocks’ ability to race higher, even as the price of just about every commodity soars, some clarity may arrive this week with the Labor Department report on third-quarter productivity.

headline: 1973: Teddie’s Apple Cake
text: For reasons that elude me, cakes have come to represent long hours in the kitchen, when anyone who actually makes cakes knows that cookies are the time suck. Cookies require measuring and multiple batches. Cakes get mixed up and go into the oven all at once. The most lovable ones even cool in their pans and require no icing. Which is why if you look back in The Times archives at recipes from 30 or more years ago, when most people cooked every day, there were many more cake recipes. Cake was something you whipped up every couple of days, after the previous one vanished to crumbs.

headline: U.N. Restarts Talks to Persuade Myanmar’s Junta on Reforms
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 3  The United Nations on Saturday began its latest mission to persuade Myanmar’s military government to reconcile with its democratic dissidents. But the visit by the United Nations special envoy is already being strained by the junta’s order to expel the top United Nations official in the country.

headline: Sloe and Steady
text: If you thought sloe gin was the treacly red stuff that spawned a million beachfront bar shots with unprintable names, you may be as amazed as I was when you taste the genuine article. Real sloe gin, made with sloe berries and — shouldn’t this go without saying? — actual gin, is a homemade treat from rural England that has nothing to do with the cloying liqueur that’s usurped its name. Fortunately, some of that misinformation may soon be corrected. Early next year, Plymouth Gin in Devonshire, England, will export a limited release of its unsurpassable sloe gin, made in its Black Friars Distillery, and arguably the only commercial version that is all natural and traditionally produced.

headline: Victims’ Families Denounce Call for Time Limit on Street Memorials
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: In Land of Spitzer, a Vile Season of Frost and Fury
text: ALBANY, Nov. 2  Gov. Eliot Spitzer promised early on to spend his time “breaking some china,” proclaimed himself a “steamroller” and often invoked a favorite saying: “You can’t change the world by whispering.”

headline: Boldly, Where No Dog Had Gone Before
text: CULVER CITY, Calif.

headline: Bourbon & Bluegrass
text: ONE Friday afternoon a few weeks ago, while most people were at work, I stood in a room at Maker’s Mark distillery, in rural Kentucky, breathing in the pungent fumes of fermenting whiskey mash and feeling a kind of mild contact buzz.

headline: A Fairy-Tale Ending Eludes Separated Twins
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 1 — It had all the trappings of a Cinderella story. Carl and Clarence Aguirre, impoverished Filipino twins conjoined at the top of their heads, arrived in New York in 2003, sick and malnourished, and after a series of death-defying operations, emerged late one night on separate gurneys — fragile, sedated and bandaged, but each with his own life.

headline: Tunnel Vision
text: ONE day, when I was 12 years old, I felt a lump in my throat. It was a year of metaphorical lumps — I had just started a new junior high school and my parents were in the middle of a messy divorce — but this lump was real. A doctor diagnosed it as a cyst, benign but dangerously close to my thyroid gland, and on a December afternoon, my mother took me to see a surgeon in Manhattan.

headline: Here, the Buffalo Roam
text: AUSTIN TANNER discovered the hard way that loving buffalo, as he has since grade school, is one thing, but raising them is another.

headline: Telltale Art
text: A GIANT, gleaming blue diamond — about eight feet tall by seven feet wide — is parked on four gold-colored prongs outside Christie’s at Rockefeller Center. Just uptown Christie’s archrival, Sotheby’s, has another sight gag, an eye-catching confection of similar dimensions: a shiny, bright-red dangling heart. These playful if expensive sculptures by the artist Jeff Koons could be a metaphor for the glittered frenzy of this fall’s major auctions, which open on Tuesday with a sale of Impressionist and modern art at Christie’s.

headline: Why Google Turned Into a Social Butterfly
text: FACEBOOK is an island. A most convivial island, with one’s classmates, friends, workmates and family members close at hand. An island that since May has been enlivened with entertaining fauna and flora in the form of minisoftware applications. But it’s still an island.

headline: Plunging Into the Thicket Known as ‘Henry VI’
text: Framed by a buoyant peek at the past and a chilling, defiant look toward the future, Brian B. Crowe’s new adaptation of Shakespeare’s “Henry VI” trilogy wrestles this seldom-played, ungainly behemoth to what could best be described as a standoff. Whittling nine hours of contentious, at times horrific, English history into three is struggle enough, yet Mr. Crowe has actually chosen to add text to Shakespeare’s already swollen offering.

headline: Trying a Shuttle Bus to Make Crossing Safer
text: UNION

headline: The Diplomat
text: Q: In your new memoir, “Surrender Is Not an Option,” you recount your frustrations as ambassador to the United Nations, a position you left in December. This is the way Washington is today. It’s very personal in its politics, very bitter and very negative.

headline: A Disney Princess, Not Winking but Floating
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

headline: ‘Law & Order’ Candidate (Chung-chung)
text: WEEKS before the 2004 presidential election, former Senator Fred D. Thompson passionately defended the war in Iraq to a prime-time television audience. “Radical fundamentalists are waging a world war,” he said, calling the United States invasion a necessary response to Islamic terrorism. “They hate our way of life and our freedoms.”

headline: No, No, No, Don’t Follow Us
text: New Delhi

headline: Gift of Gall
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Space Station Is Repaired in Spacewalk
text: An astronaut on a daring spacewalk yesterday repaired a damaged solar array on the International Space Station.

headline: Drums Along the Hudson
text: While you weren’t looking, a big anniversary has been creeping into view. It is the 400th anniversary of Henry Hudson’s sail up his mighty river, an epochal event by any standard. It was in 1609 that Hudson, an Englishman hired by the Dutch East India Company, sailed on the Half Moon into New York Harbor and up the river as far as present-day Albany. He was looking for the Northwest Passage but found something better, and the history and lore that followed — New Amsterdam, New York, Wall Street, Rockefeller Center, the Macy’s Parade — flow from that date, from that ruff-collared sailor on his poky little ship.

headline: From Uzbekistan, a Single Father of 3
text: “My son, he’s coming. He speak English very well and he can be translator,” Yakov Babayev said quietly, sitting stiffly in a straight-backed chair in his overly full living room.

headline: Alexandra Piccirillo, Rosario Vaina
text: Alexandra Piccirillo, a daughter of Phyllis and Alexander Piccirillo of Nutley, N.J., was married yesterday to Rosario A. Vaina, a son of Anna and Salvatore Vaina of Brooklyn. Msgr. Joseph J. Granato performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in St. Lucy’s Church in Newark.

headline: Fall in Love for a Good Cause
text: ON the spectrum of aspiring Cupids, Pari Livermore ought to be categorized somewhere between the hundreds of professional matchmakers and the millions of meddling grannies, bubbies, nanas and nonnas.

headline: The Domino Effect
text: Most people don’t consider the other uses for sugar beyond the pleasures of the tongue. But fortunately there are the odd exceptions, who take their sweet tooth rather seriously.

headline: Wesley Werme, Brent Cartwright
text: Wesley G. Werme and Brent Alan Cartwright were married yesterday at St. James Catholic Church in Liberty, Mo. The Rev. Matthew B. Link performed the ceremony.

headline: Said That vs. Meant This, a Hot Matchup for ’08
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Dollars for Scholars, or for the Athletes? (2 Letters)
text: Dollars for Scholars, or for the Athletes?

headline: What Would Bacchus Do?
text: The rhetoric and rituals of wine appreciation are sometimes said to be the alimentary equivalent of lipstick on a pig: they are meant to give an attractive sheen to the ugly business of getting drunk. Most oenophiles, of course, take a different view: they regard wine as a uniquely complex beverage — complex in terms of its taste and also the environmental, historical and cultural factors influencing its production — that demands sober reflection (in a manner of speaking). Interestingly, a growing number of academics believe that wine is a subject fit for scholarly reflection. Three years ago, the University of London played host to a symposium on philosophy and wine. Out of that conference grew “Questions of Taste: The Philosophy of Wine,” a collection of essays examining how we think and talk about wine and how it influences us.

headline: Incentives, to Fight the Doldrums
text: DEVELOPERS in central Long Island are increasingly resorting to incentives to lure buyers. Nassau and Suffolk Counties are both affected, though new units in western Suffolk have been particularly slow to sell in the current sluggish real estate market.

headline: Reading About Eating
text: When it comes to food, the spirit of adventure would seem to be inherent, not acquired. Some people are simply more game than others, sampling tripe, silkworm pupae and a cobra’s gallbladder, not to mention small, cuddly mammals that back home might have been christened Snowball or Sparky. (Are these the same people whose idea of fun is bungee jumping?) Recent research suggests that fearlessness is ordained by a gene. I’m quite sure I don’t have it.

headline: Rebecca Walker, Benjamin Grossman
text: Rebecca Erin Walker, the daughter of Sharon and Donald R. Walker of Roxbury, N.J., was married last evening to Benjamin Isaac Grossman, a son of Barbara and Steven Grossman of Newton, Mass. Rabbi David Ross Senter officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

headline: Not All Fusion Food Blends Flavors Well
text: FUSION food, which is meant to blend tastes from different cultures, is a tricky culinary concept. It’s easy to create a confused jumble or to reduce everything to the least sophisticated common denominator.

headline: Datebook
text: MADRID

headline: Out West, a Falling Lake Lowers All Boats
text: LAKE MEAD, Nev.

headline: Sarah Willett and Jerry Chang
text: Sarah Elizabeth Willett, a daughter of Evelyn Willett and Dr. J. Michael Willett of New Haven, was married there yesterday to Dr. Jerry Weiger Chang, the son of Jennie Chang and Robert Chang of Houston. The Rev. Callista Isabelle, a minister of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, performed the ceremony at Battell Chapel at Yale.

headline: Harlem Flock Is Staying Put
text: IT’S not the greatest story ever told, but in New York, it has become familiar: Church loses parishioners; church’s land gains in value; church sells to developer, who puts up apartments.

headline: Elizabeth Hack, Richard Larach
text: Elizabeth Inez Hack and Richard Lloyd Larach are to be married today in Washington. Rabbi Leila Gal Berner is to officiate at the Park Hyatt hotel.

headline: Seeing Things
text: After blithely picking off the albatross, the title character in “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner” loses his soul to a nightmarish, dice-throwing figure called Life-in-Death. The seaman’s true life-in-death begins once his fantastically ghastly voyage ends: he’s doomed to repeat himself obsessively, buttonholing unwitting guests at social events and pouring forth his cautionary tale.

headline: Glitz? There Goes the Neighborhood
text: A little before 5 p.m. on Wednesday, as on every other weekday afternoon, the stretch of 32nd Street between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas was filled with commuters barreling westward, briefcases swinging, in a dash toward Pennsylvania Station.

headline: As Hybrids Evolve, Gains Grow Elusive
text: Toyota City, Japan

headline: The Audience as the Arbiter
text: CRITICS are sometimes asked how they prepare for premieres. In my business a new piece is a threat; it strips the writer naked. Unlike Brahms’s Fourth Symphony, it springs from nowhere and asks on the spot to be loved, hated or endured. Is prior knowledge a kind of cheating, or does a look at the score or a visit to the rehearsal hall create a cushion of experience, something that makes new music more “understandable”?

headline: Stephanie Sakoff, Rudolph Miklosvary
text: Stephanie Lyn Sakoff and Rudolph Peter Miklosvary were married last evening at Cipriani 23rd Street in New York. The Rev. P. Kimberleigh Jordan, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

headline: Grading the Law Firms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Club House
text: If William Randolph Hearst were to come back from the grave, he would surely feel vindicated for his extravagant sense of design. Hearst Castle, the 97,000-square-foot pad in San Simeon, Calif., that he built from 1919 to 1947 in a pastiche of grandiose architectural flourishes, was decorated with truckloads of European art, Italian and Spanish ceilings, enough rugs to fill a bazaar, and an original Roman temple front. Now his baronial-manorial aesthetic is having a second coming — albeit in a slightly more accessible way.

headline: Why Study Abroad Costs So Much, What to Do About It
text: In many parts of the world, college is cheap.

headline: Son of the South
text: When I was 16, my father left my mother and me for his pregnant mistress, who happened to be a jockey at the racetrack and didn’t ride sidesaddle, if you know what I mean. Well, we’re from Houston; off-color divorce is our municipal hobby. Mother’s first words after reading Daddy’s Dear Jane letter — “All that goes back tomorrow!” — referred to a cluster of shopping bags we collected earlier that day at Neiman’s and addressed the real problem for both of us: with my father gone, the gravy train was over.

headline: Runners Stunned by News of Death
text: The New York City Marathon has not experienced a runner’s death since 1994, so when the 28-year-old professional runner Ryan Shay collapsed during the Olympic marathon trials yesterday and died, the running community here was particularly stunned.

headline: Taste Maker
text: An unintended consequence of Judith Jones’s fine memoir is a wistful longing for the glory days of American publishing. Imagine how, in 1950, as a poorly paid assistant to Doubleday’s Paris editor, working through “a pile of submissions that he wanted rejected,” Jones could be drawn to a photograph on the French edition of “Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl.” She did not stop until she had read the manuscript straight through (in French) and persuaded her editor to strongly recommend its publication to Doubleday in New York.

headline: A Child From Their First Marriage
text: THE last legal barriers to Porsche’s control of Volkswagen may have fallen with a decision by the European Court of Justice. Its ruling last month struck down a German law and cleared the way for Porsche, already the largest shareholder, to obtain a majority stake in VW.

headline: Dungy Builds Coaching Tree by Going Against the Grain
text: In the early 1980s, 20-something football coaches were rare, 20-something black coaches rarer still. That was the N.F.L. landscape when the Pittsburgh Steelers made 25-year-old Tony Dungy the youngest assistant in league history.

headline: For Jews Adrift, a Port of Call
text: WITH her red lacquered nails, coiffed white hair and ever-present shopping cart, Rose Gelfand seems like a typical bubbe from Brooklyn.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Tune In, Tune Out, Move On

headline: Correction: Impresario’s Back Story of Daring
text: A column last Sunday about Florence Berkman, the art critic for The Hartford Times who befriended A. Everett Austin Jr., known as Chick, when he was the director of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, misstated the year of her death. It was 2000, not 1999.

headline: Anne Howard, Erik Fahlgren
text: Anne Katharine Howard was married in Fort Worth yesterday to Erik Victor Fahlgren. The Rev. Dr. Michael L. Marshall performed the ceremony in the Leonard Memorial Chapel at the First United Methodist Church of Fort Worth.

headline: Rice Adds to Rushing Total, but UConn Adds to Win Total
text: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 3 — In the previous two weeks, Connecticut had halted an N.F.L.-caliber quarterback (Louisville’s Brian Brohm) and turned back a surging young program (the one-time No. 2 South Florida). With their own improbable season in the balance, the No. 16 Huskies did not seem fazed by either challenge.

headline: A Man of Many Parts
text: NOTHING is as ephemeral as the theater; when the curtain falls, it’s gone. It must have been to rectify this that they invented the Broadway-memento kiosk. A “Cats” coffee mug gives you something to hold on to other than “Memories.”

headline: A Ray of Pension Sunshine
text: THE Securities and Exchange Commission’s investigation into possible conflicts of interest among advisers to pension funds has been going on so long — two years — that it’s practically fallen off the radar screen. But last week, the investigation cropped up again, big time, when Merrill Lynch advised 100 of its pension fund clients in Florida that the S.E.C. has taken issue with its practices as a consultant.

headline: A Sanitation Crisis That’s No Joke
text: The nation with the greatest lead in potty technology is, no doubt, Japan. Toilets there aren’t just self-flushing; that’s Jurassic technology by Japan’s standards. The best detect you as you enter the bathroom, lifting their lids and firing up their seat-warmers. When finished, you have a choice of warm spritzes — “bidet” or “shower” — followed, if you like, by a drying blast of hot air.

headline: Where There’s Smoke ...
text: Q I live in a New York City co-op, and cigarette smoke is having an impact on the quality of my life. I would like to know how to go about making my building smoke-free.

headline: Society’s Politics, as Seen Through a Porcelain Lens
text: “A public toilet,” Harvey Molotch was saying yesterday morning before the daylong symposium he organized on the subject, “is a window on the social and political world.”

headline: Bio Engineering
text: “I’m going to do everything I can to sabotage you,” the writer Nathan Zuckerman tells an upstart biographer in Philip Roth’s new novel, “Exit Ghost.” “I can prevent your being published, and, whatever the expense, whatever the effort, I will.” Zuckerman is incensed that the would-be biographer, a “deeply disrespectful, ardent” young man named Kliman, is trying to make a name for himself by unearthing the secrets of one of his heroes, the writer E. I. Lonoff. “The dirt-seeking snooping calling itself research is just about the lowest of literary rackets,” Zuckerman tells Kliman. “You’re going to redeem Lonoff’s reputation as a writer by ruining it as a man.”

headline: Voting? Forget the Who. It’s the How.
text: To the Editor:

headline: $1 a Square Foot! Gross
text: I live in a really big apartment. It has eight rooms, two balconies, high ceilings and a view. The best part is that it’s cheap, by New York standards, because it’s in Berlin.

headline: The Story Behind the Story Within the Story
text: THE big set piece at the heart of “Atonement” takes place on the beach at Dunkirk during the British evacuation in 1940. Dazed and exhausted, a wounded soldier named Robbie Turner stumbles onto the beach along with two sidekicks while a six-minute tracking shot establishes a montage of eerie, almost surreal images: a bandstand, abandoned cannons, a choir in rehearsal, an enormous beached boat, wandering circus horses, a Ferris wheel turning idly against a smoke-streaked sky. A little later Robbie takes refuge in a movie house where “Quai des Brumes,” a noirish Jean Gabin picture from 1938, is playing. He wanders across the screen, passing in front of a close-up of Gabin, and for a moment it looks as if he’s standing in your theater, not the one in France.

headline: A Tuna Meltdown
text: IT is tuna time in New York. I don’t mean it’s time for local bistros to put salade niçoise on their menus. I mean it’s the time when real, live tuna — some of them eight feet long — enter our waters en route to their spawning grounds in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Reader Questions
text: Keeping Score

headline: Town Without Pity
text: Someone — it’s been attributed to everyone from Dostoyevsky to John Gardner — once said there are only two possible stories: a man goes on a journey, or a stranger comes to town. To these Richard Russo has added a third: schlub stays put. In a time known in trendier circles for literary exile, Russo is the unofficial poet laureate of uneasy stasis, of fixing yourself to the place where you were born. Out the window goes the dynamism of American self-invention; in comes something almost more mysterious: a reckoning with an apparently seamless life continuity. If I didn’t invent this self, where exactly did it come from? And yet more queasily: This place that nurtured me — did it also stunt me, inhibit me, even, literally, poison me?

headline: The Turning of an Atheist
text: Unless you are a professional philosopher or a committed atheist, you probably have not heard of Antony Flew. Eighty-four years old and long retired, Flew lives with his wife in Reading, a medium-size town on the Thames an hour west of London. Over a long career he held appointments at a series of decent regional universities — Aberdeen, Keele, Reading — and earned a strong reputation writing on an unusual range of topics, from Hume to immortality to Darwin. His greatest contribution remains his first, a short paper from 1950 called “Theology and Falsification.” Flew was a precocious 27 when he delivered the paper at a meeting of the Socratic Club, the Oxford salon presided over by C. S. Lewis. Reprinted in dozens of anthologies, “Theology and Falsification” has become a heroic tract for committed atheists. In a masterfully terse thousand words, Flew argues that “God” is too vague a concept to be meaningful. For if God’s greatness entails being invisible, intangible and inscrutable, then he can’t be disproved — but nor can he be proved. Such powerful but simply stated arguments made Flew popular on the campus speaking circuit; videos from debates in the 1970s show a lanky man, his black hair professorially unkempt, vivisecting religious belief with an English public-school accent perfect for the seduction of American ears. Before the current crop of atheist crusader-authors — Richard Dawkins, Daniel Dennett, Christopher Hitchens — there was Antony Flew.

headline: Musharraf Leaves White House in Lurch
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 — For more than five months the United States has been trying to orchestrate a political transition in Pakistan that would manage to somehow keep Gen. Pervez Musharraf in power without making a mockery of President Bush’s promotion of democracy in the Muslim world.

headline: Selling America
text: Karen Hughes brought strengths to the job of public diplomacy, a critical, often overlooked tool for advancing the national interest. She was an insider’s insider, a confidante from President Bush’s Texas inner circle who could speak for him authoritatively. Yet as she prepares to leave office, polls shows the United States is hated more than ever in the Muslim world.

headline: Mary Frekko, Nicholas Kilavos
text: Dr. Mary Ilona Frekko, a daughter of Gertrude D. Frekko and Dr. Tibor E. Frekko of Darnestown, Md., was married yesterday to Nicholas George Kilavos, a son of Georgia N. Kilavos of Dearborn Heights, Mich., and the late George T. Kilavos. The Rev. Donald P. Worch performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Potomac, Md.

headline: That ’70s Show: Bella, the Blackout and the Burning Bronx
text: HOW appropriate. An oral biography of Bella Abzug.

text: East Orange

headline: Swords, Songs and Women on the Run

headline: It’s Not Whether to Kill, but How
text: WHEN the Supreme Court stayed an execution last week for the third time in October, making the month the first in nearly three years with no executions, the justices sent a clear message to the states: Don’t execute anybody until we have decided Baze v. Rees, a death penalty case scheduled to be argued in January.

headline: Double or Nothing on the Democrat
text: WILLIAM MAYER, shamed and penniless after gambling away his rural Illinois home on a bad wager, hanged himself on Nov. 9, 1904. The New York Daily Herald carried word of his demise in a one-sentence brief alongside more felicitous news of those who had picked more wisely.

headline: Next Door to a Poignant Memory
text: The “Living In” column of Oct. 21, about Battery Park City, omitted a designer of the community. The master plan for Battery Park City was created by Stanton Eckstut and Alexander Cooper, not by Mr. Eckstut alone. At the time, 1979, the men were partners in Alexander Cooper Associates.

headline: Bringing Back Breakfast
text: At Mom’s Restaurant in Ringoes, it’s easy to follow the motherly advice not to skip breakfast. Here you won’t want to miss the homestyle pancakes, waffles and omelets.

headline: Grand Switch Auto
text: ONE recent Saturday, Brian Alcazar was hanging out at RCT Performance, a modest speed shop in College Point, Queens, that specializes in squeezing the most performance out of turbocharged and supercharged cars. Through the shop window, Mr. Alcazar’s silver 2005 Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution VIII could be seen parked outside under a clear fall sky. Inside, the topic was speed and how to get it. Business as usual.

headline: Urban, Hip Place With Locally Grown Focus
text: I LIKE to give a new restaurant several months to establish itself before reviewing it, but sometimes the buzz on a place is such that it’s hard to wait. Firebox, named for the metal fuel box in the engine of a steam locomotive, opened in Hartford on June 1 and I was there shortly after, my curiosity aroused by the community-conscious entrepreneurship that the restaurant was spearheading.

headline: Power of the Press
text: After years of trying to figure out at what age one becomes grown-up, I have decided it is the age I inhabit now. Rather than do anything silly like put a number on it, let’s just say it’s the age when you’re caught up on all your tax returns, you sleep on ironed sheets and eat dinner with cloth napkins.

headline: As Cool as They Want to Be
text: Gauzy blouses and short skirts filled the junior women’s department at a Midtown H&M. I was there last fall at the request of my niece, Madeleine, then 14, who wanted better clothes for school. “I don’t like sleeveless,” she whispered about one blouse. “That’s too revealing,” she said of another.

headline: Daughter of Slain Man in Foster Care
text: A 4-year-old girl whose father was killed at a Queens playground last week was taken from her father’s relatives on Friday and placed in foster care, lawyers in the case said.

headline: A Basketball Star Assists Home Talent
text: WHEN Daisy Brand heard that the N.B.A. star Allen Iverson had bought a minor league basketball team in Virginia for his mother, she wondered aloud whether her son Elton should do the same in Westchester.

headline: Tufts Asks for 250 Words of Wisdom
text: Tufts has a problem shared by most competitive universities: After it rejects the weak and admits the geniuses, too many decent applicants remain — about three for every spot. Recommendations and polished essays “all pretty much say the same things,” says Lee Coffin, dean of undergraduate admissions.

headline: Portrait of an Ex-Dictator as an Old Man: Suharto Slips Into Irrelevance
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Nearly 10 years after the tumult of his ouster, the old dictator spends his days alone in his sitting room, one friend says, inviting few visitors, making no public statements, eating carefully to avoid hurting his stomach.

headline: Musharraf Consolidates His Control With Arrests
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 4 — The government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, making no concessions a day after seizing emergency powers, rounded up leading opposition figures and said Sunday that parliamentary elections could be delayed for as long as a year.

text: LAS VEGAS

text: DAKAR, Senegal

headline: Move Over, Orbitz
text: WITH so much of college readily accessible on the Web, families may be forgiven for relying on the Internet, too, for advice on how to pay the tuition. And loan companies and entrepreneurs are lining up to give it to them.

headline: The Girl, the Swing and a Row House in Ruins
text: EVELYN NESBIT was just 16 years old when she used to kick high into the air from the red velvet swing, aiming her toes at the great Japanese fan that hung from the ceiling of the hideaway built for seduction.

headline: Iraq, With U.S. Support, Voids a Russian Oil Contract
text: BAGHDAD, Oct. 29  Guided by American legal advisers, the Iraqi government has canceled a controversial development contract with the Russian company Lukoil for a vast oil field in Iraq’s southern desert, freeing it up for potential international investment in the future.

headline: The Day’s Best
text: PERCY HARVIN, left, became the first player in Florida history to have 100 yards receiving and rushing in a game. He ran for 113 yards and 2 touchdowns, and caught 9 passes for 110 yards.

headline: Hide and Chic
text: Designer stereotypes are easy to come by — say “Gucci girl” or “Versace babe,” and a clear picture (usually involving bikinis in St.-Tropez or fur in Gstaad) instantly emerges. Other labels, however, are harder to classify. Although Bottega Veneta has become the second-most-profitable brand in the Gucci Group stable and is one of the most recognizable luxury names on the planet, one would be hard-pressed to identify a Bottega look. That’s because its creative director, Tomas Maier, likes it that way. Whether he’s designing furniture, woven leather handbags, men’s and women’s clothes, fine jewelry or sunglasses, he always places a premium on materials, handwork and process over glitzy logos and fly-by-night trends. Unlike many of his peers, Maier believes that if you’ve truly got it, you would never dream of flaunting it.

headline: Matthew Morningstar and Alan Van Capelle
text: Matthew Edwin Morningstar and Alan Van Capelle celebrated their partnership last evening at Studio 450, an event space in New York. Mik Moore and Karen Bertulli, friends of the couple, led the commitment ceremony.

headline: Is (His) Biography (Our) Destiny?
text: “If I am the face of American foreign policy and American power,” Barack Obama mused not long ago aboard his campaign plane, “as long as we are also making prudent strategic decisions, handling emergencies, crises and opportunities in the world in an intelligent and sober way. . . .” He stopped. He wanted to make sure he got this just right, and he had got a little caught up in rebutting the claim, which Hillary Clinton has artfully advanced, that he is not prepared to handle emergencies. Obama stopped picking at his grilled salmon in order to stare out at the sky for a few moments. “I think,” he said, in that deep and measured voice of his, “that if you can tell people, ‘We have a president in the White House who still has a grandmother living in a hut on the shores of Lake Victoria and has a sister who’s half-Indonesian, married to a Chinese-Canadian,’ then they’re going to think that he may have a better sense of what’s going on in our lives and in our country. And they’d be right.”

headline: Grrridlock
text: TRAFFIC, apparently, hits a nerve.

headline: Trees Dressed in Leaves, Even This Late
text: SHARON

headline: Food-Chain Blues
text: Stewart O’Nan’s turf is the large swath of the country that lies in the dark shadow of the American dream. His fiction tends to chronicle the lives of the two classes that dwell there: the poor and, as he puts it, “the richer poor.” He is a poet of strip mall ennui, road rage, fluorescent lighting and the sparse lawns of prefabricated real estate developments. His characters strive to make their mortgage payments, hold full-time jobs and keep the refrigerator stocked, but struggle to fend off the lurking nightmares of domestic crime, alcoholism and war trauma. They buy lottery tickets, and they always lose.

headline: Consciousness Raising
text: Know-it-all career switchers don’t need to sit through that introductory psych lecture. The College-Level Examination Program, administered by the College Board, offers a chance to earn course credit at 2,900 two- and four-year colleges. The 34 subjects include educational psychology (recognized by some states, including New York, for teacher certification) and human development (for nursing degrees). The exams are taken by some 150,000 students a year, more than half of them adults. Test your psych smarts with the sample CLEP questions below. Answers at bottom.

headline: A Juicy Red to Chill
text: Unaccountably, Éric Texier’s versatile Rhône portfolio has not yet found a large audience. Thus his basic 2005 Côtes du Rhône is underpriced. It costs $13.49 at Chambers Street Wines, 160 Chambers Street (West Broadway).

headline: A Small-Town Feel in an Urban Locale
text: AFTER spending several years in the South, Darrell Wallace and Jennifer Adkins of Greensboro, N.C., decided it was time to move. “We’re both artistic and politically active, and it was really hard to find peers into the same thing in Greensboro,” said Mr. Wallace, 30.

headline: Union and Ford Reach Tentative Deal
text: DETROIT, Nov. 3  The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative four-year agreement with the Ford Motor Company early Saturday that follows the pattern set in new contracts at General Motors and Chrysler.

headline: Up Front
text: This week, the Yale legal scholar and novelist Stephen L. Carter reviews Donald McCaig’s “Rhett Butler’s People,” the latest authorized sequel to “Gone With the Wind.” Before beginning work on the review, Carter confesses, he had never read Margaret Mitchell’s classic novel. “My experience of the ‘Gone With the Wind’ universe was limited to a handful of vaguely remembered viewings of the film,” he said in an e-mail message. “My expectations for the novel might charitably be called low. I suppose I expected a poorly written racist tract.” But Carter, whose own best-selling novels “New England White” and “The Emperor of Ocean Park” suggest he knows something about combining literary entertainment and penetrating observation about race in America, found his assumptions upended. “I was staggered by the power of Margaret Mitchell’s imagination and the clean beauty of her prose,” he wrote. “Her characters are irresistible.”

headline: The Little Gold Man Made Me Do It
text: SERIOUS moviegoers tend to view the Oscars as a sideshow, and a déclassé one at that, with little relation to quality cinema. Important Films, the convention holds, do not don a revealing frock and traipse the red carpet, risking a fondling by Isaac Mizrahi.

headline: Devices Enforce Silence of Cellphones, Illegally
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 — One afternoon in early September, an architect boarded his commuter train and became a cellphone vigilante. He sat down next to a 20-something woman who he said was “blabbing away” into her phone.

headline: A Long Weekend? How About a Whole Year?
text: WHEN Peter and Jill Feuerstein sit around the dinner table with their teenage children, Betsy and Ben, it’s not unusual for them to have an animated discussion about a remote village in China, India or Zimbabwe. But unlike many people in their hometown of Larchmont, N.Y., the Feuersteins have a personal connection with these places. In June 2002, they embarked on a yearlong journey around the world with their two kids, then ages 14 and 11, in tow.

headline: Once Just a Stopover, an Australian City Grows Up
text: ONCE just a stopover for tourists en route to either the Great Barrier Reef or the beaches on the Sunshine and Gold Coasts, the eastern Australian city of Brisbane has emerged as an alluring destination in its own right.

headline: It’s Not a Popemobile but It Comes in Handy
text: It’s all white, can lift 20 tons and has custom trim and the Vatican coat of arms on the front — and it cost Pope Benedict XVI nothing. It’s the new tractor given to the pope last week by Fiat, the Italian carmaker that also owns CNH Global, the maker of Case and New Holland tractors that is based in Burr Ridge, Ill.

headline: Michelle Walton, Evin Dobson
text: Michelle Katherine Walton, the daughter of Mi Cha Han of Chicago and the late Richard K. Walton, was married Friday evening to Evin Ross Dobson, the son of M. J. Dobson and Charles Dobson, both of New York. The Rev. Joel Gibson Sr., an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

headline: Despite Malls, a Vital Culture
text: ESTABLISHED in the wake of the Great Quake a century ago, San Francisco's Japantown, or Nihonmachi, is the largest of three Japantowns in the United States. The neighborhood still bears the marks of its twin calamities: wartime internment and 1960s redevelopment. But now, with more interest in all things Japanese and still-unbridled investor enthusiasm for San Francisco real estate, Japantown is undergoing a renovation that promises to raise the area's profile considerably.

headline: Trying to Stir Up Devils, the Rangers’ Avery Settles for a Victory
text: Rangers left wing Sean Avery nuzzled up to Devils left wing Zach Parise before a face-off yesterday and started into a conversation that Parise had no interest in joining. As Avery barked, challenging Parise to a fight, Parise stared ahead.

headline: Limited Luxury
text: Anyone who has complained that the Internet is denigrating luxury hasn’t logged on to 20ltd.com. Created by the British advertising executives Jolyon Fenwick and Marcus Husselby, it showcases only 20 limited-edition products at a time, ranging from designer rings (Solange Azagury-Partridge’s) to furniture (Peter Andersson’s ebony easy chair) that Fenwick has commissioned solely for the site.
