headline: New Centers Planned for Veterans’ Services
text: MILITARY veterans from Westchester are reacting warily to pending changes in their medical care, with nursing-home and psychiatric beds poised to move out of the county while a plan to build a residential center in Yonkers moves ahead.

headline: What’s Behind the Race Gap?
text: High-cost subprime mortgages have often been framed as loans that catered to people with blemished credit records or little experience with debt.

headline: The Man I Wish Was Your Father
text: “Who’s that?” asked Katie, my 13-year-old daughter. She was pointing to a photograph I had recently found and put on my office bulletin board at home. A man and I are standing with our arms around each other on Herring Cove Beach on Cape Cod. Katie didn’t know him, which is unusual, because as a lesbian parent I make a point of having my male friends around my children as much as possible.

headline: Staying Loyal to a Killer, From His Trial to Their Arrest
text: What kind of woman would hitch her wagon to Robert E. Chambers Jr.?

headline: Eco-Education
text: As the sun goes down over the College of the Atlantic, the cafeteria gets dimmer and dimmer. But only when it is nearly impossible to see the food does a student, finally, get up and turn on the lights — prompting a collective groan at this wanton use of energy. Another adjusts the lights, bringing them down a notch.

headline: January Release Schedule
text: JANUARY

headline: Smells Like Team Spirit
text: GRADES, recommendations, SAT scores, who cares? There is another, much easier way of getting into college — if you happen to weigh 250 pounds or so, that is, and can run the 40 in under 4.5. In that happy instance, college will come to you. The football coach, or one of his assistants, will camp on your doorstep, phone you and send you text messages daily, conduct long, earnest conversations with your mom and dad, and arrange for lovely, long-legged coeds to show you around the campus. (If you were being recruited by the University of Colorado a couple of years ago, sex and alcohol were also part of the enticement package.)

headline: Metro Briefing
text: It’s easy to wake up and spend a day in New York and not notice the wonder of it all. The city offers up daily mysteries and curiosities, yet most of us are so involved in our own neighborhood-centric routines and work-and-love intrigues that what goes on outside our immediate purview is a blur. Which is why God created newspaper feature writers, who venture out to mine the magic in the seemingly mundane.

headline: Stephanie Crissy, David Rader
text: Stephanie Lauren Crissy was married yesterday evening to David Matthew Rader. The Rev. Vic Willis, a Methodist minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Republican Tricks on Children’s Health
text: Cynicism and hypocrisy were on full display in the Senate last week when Republican leaders refused to wait for a possible compromise on a bill that would provide health coverage for millions of uninsured children. Instead, they forced a vote on a bill that they know President Bush will veto, with no chance of being overridden.

headline: Mom? Lawyer? The Ambivalence Track
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

headline: Growing Up, Not Out, in Brooklyn
text: ONE way to get to the small carriage house in back is through the mansion in front.

headline: Stefanie Firtell, Jame Donath
text: Stefanie Aimee Firtell and Jame Donath were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Hirschy Zarchi officiated at the Metropolitan Club.

headline: The Trickle-Down From Pollock
text: Fifty years ago a loud, quarrelsome, hard-drinking artist from Wyoming named Jackson Pollock made himself and American art famous with his drip paintings and aberrant social behavior. Celebrating his life and influence on contemporary artists is “Jackson,” a lively, wry, suitably wacky exhibition at the Contemporary Art Galleries at the University of Connecticut in Storrs.

headline: Kathryn Godburn, Brian Schubert
text: Kathryn Ann Godburn, a daughter of Lynette Godburn and William G. Godburn of North Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Scott Schubert, the son of Ludwig Schubert Jr. of Berlin, Conn., and the late Shannon Schubert. The Rev. William Hegedusich, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Peter’s Church in Washington.

headline: Poetry, Peru, Psychedelia and Soul, With Folkie Flavors
text: SAUL WILLIAMS

headline: Clinton Rebuts Accusations of Secrecy
text: DES MOINES, Nov. 3  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s political camp struck back on Saturday against rivals who were attacking her as overly secretive, circulating legal arguments from a Clinton ally asserting that the Clintons are not blocking the release of presidential papers about their discussions in the White House in the 1990s.

headline: Foreign Buyers Take Manhattan
text: KENNY TIMMONS has spent three long weekends in New York City since 2003, catching up with friends he knew in Ireland, visiting ground zero, restocking his wardrobe at Armani and Niketown and chatting about real estate with a bartender in an Irish pub in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Attack From Beyond
text: I recently received a vitriolic diatribe from a friend who died of cancer four years ago. In her will, she ordered her diary entries transcribed and sent to each person she wrote about. Her executor was, I guess, legally bound to follow her wishes, but should he have, knowing that this would more than likely hurt the recipients? — Susan Jackson, San Francisco

headline: Another Teardown? No, an Architectural Gem
text: YONKERS

headline: Border Politician
text: God is about the only thing that evokes more reverence from the average Mexican than the concept of revolution.

headline: The Very Expensive Reality of Chasing Reality TV
text: TO say Tom Sullivan likes “Survivor” would be a gross understatement. Mr. Sullivan, a radio and television host in Atlanta, auditioned five times for this reality show, which has a $1 million prize. He spent hours shooting, editing and mailing videotapes of himself to producers and casting agents, and has traveled to four cities to compete for the honor of not being voted off the island.

headline: The Things They Carried
text: In 2003, when Gen. Colin Powell, then the secretary of state, was making the case to the United Nations Security Council that Saddam Hussein had stockpiled weapons of mass destruction, Elizabeth D. Samet, in a literature class for first-year students at West Point, was teaching Herman Melville’s story “Bartleby the Scrivener,” with its central character who stubbornly, enigmatically, declines to do as he is told. The syllabus for that week also presented the students with Ambrose Bierce’s “One Kind of Officer,” in which young Captain Ransome, with (in Samet’s words) an “aggrieved literalness,” continues firing on his own side, in stubborn, rebellious, mad, destructive and self-destructive obedience to orders he knows are wrong.

headline: Emory’s Little Tibet
text: DRESSED in a pale blue, floor-length chuba, Paige Wilson silently mouthed a paragraph-long greeting, in Tibetan, that she was about to deliver to the Dalai Lama. The members of Emory’s chapter of Students for a Free Tibet, of which Ms. Wilson is president, were among the lucky few selected to meet His Holiness in person.

headline: Breaking Through
text: Alexandra Maria Lara

headline: Does E-Mail Distract? Not if You Take Charge
text: Q. Reading and answering e-mail is taking up more and more of your time at work. How could this affect your work?

headline: James Bond in Turkey
text: To the Editor:

headline: Glass House
text: Andrew Bradbury, the sommelier behind Clo, the new wine bar and store in the Time Warner Center, follows design as closely as he follows emerging wine regions. So expect to see more than just ho-hum balloon glasses and leaded-crystal decanters. Much of the glassware at the store is culled from his travels and includes Zoe Stanton’s suite of self-filling Champagne glasses from Britain (above), Julia Leihener’s stemless Thup glass from Germany and Takahide Sano’s off-kilter Mickey decanter from Italy. There is also Extremis’s DollyPop wine cooler (it’s woolly!) and Hiroshi Tsunoda’s graphic wine rack. Even the shopping bags — bottle-shaped sleeves made of Bubble Wrap, designed by WineSkin with the cutting-edge firm 2x4 — bring some much-needed sass to vinoculture.

headline: Brews That Seek Company
text: People go to the Lazy Boy Saloon for many reasons. Some want to remember the taste of their hometown beer. Others are looking for a classic but increasingly rare bar experience, replete with hot chicken wings, shared sports enthusiasms and cold ale. Still others want to try the latest trendy microbrew.

headline: Playing Games With Toy Safety
text: With the holiday season approaching, there is more bad news about the federal agency charged with protecting children from unsafe toys. Nancy Nord, acting chairwoman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, joined industry lobbyists in opposing a Senate bill intended to strengthen her enfeebled agency. That was followed by the revelation that Ms. Nord and her predecessor took free trips from the toy industry.

headline: The Queen of Soul Takes Control
text: ON a recent Sunday afternoon the Queen of Soul’s hotel room on Central Park South looked like an executive’s pit stop. Aretha Franklin had returned to New York City late after a concert in New Jersey, and the morning had been too busy for maid service. The afternoon was no less active: an interview to promote her new collection of duets, “Jewels in the Crown” (J Records), and then a fitting for her latest designer dress. There were clothes, cotton puffs and a real-estate brochure on the floor, along with a new copy of Alan Greenspan’s book “The Age of Turbulence,” which she said she was planning to read. The television played silently; a laptop computer was open on a coffee table.

headline: Arbour Makes His Comeback, and Islanders Make It Count
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 3 — In his first stint as the coach of the Islanders, from 1973 to 1986, Al Arbour took over a struggling expansion team and won four consecutive Stanley Cup titles. He had a second stint, from 1988 to 1994, before retiring after 739 career victories and 1,499 games with the team.

headline: Colts May Be Patriots’ Only Obstacle
text: Anyone who sees the Colts’ game against the Patriots as a dream matchup is ignoring the downside.

headline: Landmark Status
text: Amid the designer new builds and gut renovations in the far West Village, Sean MacPherson’s 1840s house feels as anachronistic as a meatpacking plant — which it actually was. “No one wanted this place,” he says of the three-story structure he formed from a crumbling, roofless kosher butcher shop four years ago. “It was a grisly process,” he says, and he means it literally.

headline: Newark Arena’s Economic Impact Unclear
text: NEWARK

headline: Close to Nature, and the Airport
text: TAKE the A train to its less famous, unhurried end. Pay attention after it rises above ground and starts cutting through water. One stop before you hit Rockaway Peninsula and the Atlantic Ocean, get out.

headline: Cannabis Thrives in an Afghan Province
text: KHWAJA GHOLAK, Afghanistan — Amid the multiplying frustrations of the fight against narcotics in Afghanistan, the northern province of Balkh has been hailed as a rare and glowing success.

headline: But Can He Hum?
text: THE Brooklyn Instrument Museum is a museum only in the loosest sense: It’s the living room of a Williamsburg couple, crammed with peculiar relics they collect on eBay and dust off for jam sessions.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Comedy

headline: Heading to a Museum? Don’t Forget a Laptop
text: Purchase

headline: Mr. Geniality
text: The elements of this collection fully justify the rather modest promise offered by the title. All things are indeed considered, and they are mostly considered in a highly considerate manner. As to the “due” part, John Updike himself informs us: “Bills come due; dues must be paid. After eight years, I was due for another collection of nonfictional prose.” To which one might add that he seems determined to give everyone his or her due. Indeed, in a highly affable preface he wonders if his only fault might be a tendency to be critical — in the ordinary sense of the term — at all. Rereading his book reviews, he wonders aloud “if their customary geniality, almost effusive in the presence of a foreign writer or a factual topic, didn’t somewhat sour when faced with a novel by a fellow-countryman.” Should he perhaps have been a little kinder to E. L. Doctorow, Don DeLillo and Norman Rush or (by implication) a fraction more harsh with Ngugi wa Thiong’o and Haruki Murakami? Such scruple no doubt does its author credit, and yet “Customary Genialities” would surely have been a rather insipid title.

headline: Russian Radar Called Good, but Not Exact Enough for U.S.
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 — To block American proposals for building missile defenses in Europe, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia surprised the White House in June with a counteroffer to let the United States use one of the Kremlin’s most secret early warning radars.

headline: Steel Point: A Step Forward
text: The vacant, trash-strewn waterfront acreage of Steel Point in Bridgeport has become the symbol of that city’s potential and, at the same time, its maddening inability to prosper. But tomorrow the City Council is scheduled to vote on a land disposition agreement between Bridgeport and the proposed developer of the property, Midtown Equities. If the Council ratifies the agreement, Midtown Equities would buy the property and begin a nine-year project to build 3,500 condominiums, dozens of shops and offices.

headline: Inside the List
text: WHY I AM A RICH WRITER: Ken Follett — his new novel, “World Without End,” is No. 3 on the fiction list — is yet another popular novelist who, to his credit, makes a habit of correcting the errors that creep into his books. Follett is good-natured and witty about his mistakes, even if others sometimes are not. On his Web site, for example, he writes about the following misstep, from his novel “The Hammer of Eden”: “One of the F.B.I. agents is a Hindu called Raja Khan. Raja is a popular Hindu name, but Khan is a typical Muslim name. Some of my readers suffer a sense-of-humor lapse about this error.” Follett was the subject of a profile recently in USA Today in which he recounted this conversation with a friend, the novelist and playwright Hanif Kureishi: “We were talking about what the readers like,” Follett said. “He said, ‘I never think about the readers.’ I told him, ‘That’s why you are a great writer, and that’s why I am a rich writer.’”

headline: Luang Prabang, Laos: La Résidence Phou Vao
text: THE BASICS

headline: The Artisans of the Real Dolce Vita
text: A FEW miles from Pisa, in the tiny Tuscan hamlet of Cascina, is a small gourmet shop where gift boxes covered in cellophane line the shelves, customers scurry in to place orders and the sweet, delicate aroma of home cooking drifts in from the kitchen. The proprietor, Paul DeBondt, sets out a platter of bite-size pieces on the countertop for sampling and arranges rows and rows of artfully wrapped packages inside the display case. But you won't find dusty bottles of Super-Tuscan, aging wheels of pecorino or pungent vats of olive oil. That's because Mr. DeBondt makes only one thing — chocolate.

headline: Weed It and Reap
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Love Triangle
text: EARLY on in the crisp autumn of 1964, it became clear that geometry was not one of my academic strengths. I had already assimilated the prevailing notion that math and science were not a girl’s domain, an assumption embraced by my guidance counselor, who subtly implied that I ran the losers’ club in these subjects. Adding to this motivational atmosphere was the fact that, other than its being a school requirement, no one had ever provided a good reason for studying geometry in the first place. There was no talk of its logic, beauty or challenge.

headline: Gastrography | Mapping Meals
text: Have you been piggy at the table? Do you know which side the fork goes on? These are questions about the “landscape” of dining that Topoware, a new collection of china, linen and place mats, tries to address. Designed by Alexandra Deschamps-Sonsino and Karola Torkos, using the undulating circles and lines used in topography maps, Topoware bowls are marked “full,” “hungry” and “very hungry”; plates read “modest,” “moderate” and “greedy.” The pine place mats point to where your table setting goes.

headline: Meghan Gereghty, Casey Shanley
text: Meghan Eileen Gereghty and Casey Finnerty Shanley were married yesterday at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. The Rev. Peter M. Colapietro, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Got Headphones, Gonna Fly Now
text: At the New York City Marathon, thousands of runners will begin their 26.2-mile odyssey through the five boroughs today wearing headphones hooked up to audio players like iPods.

headline: Elections Could Shift Power in Nassau
text: THE balance of power in the Nassau County Legislature is at stake in the elections on Tuesday.

headline: Macari’s Seasonal Portfolio
text: The depth and intensity of Macari Vineyards’ autumn and winter portfolio are acutely attuned to the rich, deep flavors of the holiday dinners ahead.

headline: Shout-Out
text: “Chelsea, call me up!” That was the caption next to a picture of the cheery author Jenna Bush, lips parted in speaking, the younger daughter (by minutes) of the president described by The Washington Post as “giving a shout-out yesterday on NBC’s ‘Today.’ . . . Bush as author praised her first-daughter predecessor for her poise; said she’d love to compare notes on their common experience.”

headline: Capital Cases Stall as Costs Grow Daunting
text: ATLANTA, Nov. 3 — When Hilton M. Fuller Jr., a semiretired judge of the silver-haired, Southern-gentleman variety, agreed to preside over the trial in a notorious courthouse shooting here, he took a job no one else wanted — the legal community was still in shock over the death of a judge, a court reporter, a sheriff’s deputy and a federal agent.

headline: Maura Hogan, Scott Watson
text: Maura Gail Hogan and Scott Andrew Watson were married yesterday at Lowndes Grove, a bed and breakfast in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Dr. Mary E. Kraus, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

headline: Jane Kramer, Kenneth Kaitin
text: Jane Alison Kramer and Kenneth I. Kaitin were married last evening by Rabbi Michael Rothbaum at Doral Arrowhead, a resort in Rye Brook, N.Y.

headline: Don’t Be Shy
text: CHRISTINE STUART, a communications professor at Pennsylvania State University, stood at the chalkboard and taught her students strategies for mingling at their forthcoming class party. “Don’t monopolize,” she said cheerfully. “You need to get around the room.” She listed the three easiest forms of conversation — clichés, facts and opinions — on the board and urged students to make index cards with opening lines for starting conversations: “Gee, this sangria is great, don’t you think?” or “Sure is humid today.”

headline: ‘It’ Baggage
text: We all strive for containment,” insists the artist Toland Grinnell. “We go home to a box. We put our things in a closet. We carry a bag. Even Neanderthals must have had bags. The urge is primal, basic.”

headline: New York Schools Brace to Be Scored, A to F
text: By many measures, Intermediate School 289 is a place parents would be happy to send their children. This year, it was the only middle school in New York City to achieve “blue ribbon” status, a marker of high achievement under the federal No Child Left Behind Act. The leading public schools guidebook calls it a place where “solid academics” are combined with “attention to children’s social and emotional development.” Educators from around the country routinely descend upon the school, in Battery Park City, to shadow its teachers.

headline: Dannielle Romano, Jean-Paul Kyrillos
text: Dannielle Jenny Romano, a daughter of Patricia Romano of Harrisburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Jean-Paul Kyrillos, a son of Marguerite Kyrillos and Dr. Joseph M. Kyrillos of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Wayne Meisel, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Building, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Mei Sze Chan and Jeff Greene
text: IN 2005, Jeff Greene turned 51, the age his father died of a heart attack.

headline: The Weeklong Semester
text: WHO said education had to be meted out over 16 weeks, 40 hours a course? After all, the traditional semester was not born of some deep insight into the human learning process; it was just a logical timetable for an agrarian society ordered by harvest times and Christian holidays.

headline: Naomi Mersky, Juan Sanabria
text: Naomi Beth Mersky, the daughter of Arlene A. Mersky and Howard W. Mersky of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Juan Samuel Sanabria, a son of Victoria I. Samuel and Cruz Sanabria, both of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Leora Kaye officiated at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: Be Your Own Superhero
text: Following an unpleasant breakup, a despairing Loren Kreiss penned the dark graphic novelette “The Artifact and the Manipulated Living.” He then asked Mike Lilly, who has drawn for the “Batman” comic book, to illustrate his neo-noir story on 11 panels (one is shown left) that now sprawl across his Chelsea apartment.

headline: An Associate Makes Full Partner
text: PORTLAND, Ore.

headline: An Imitator of Chávez: He May Be Sincere, but Is It Flattering?
text: VALENCIA, Venezuela, Oct. 30  President Hugo Chávez has his own weekly television show in which he expounds on Socialist virtues. So does Luis Felipe Acosta Carlez, the governor of Carabobo, a state here in northern Venezuela that is home to a major oil-refining complex.

headline: Sarah Cornell, Travis Gorenc
text: Sarah Ashley Haviland Cornell and Travis Allen Gorenc were married last evening at the Church of the Transfiguration in New York. The Right Rev. Andrew St. John, the vicar there, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

headline: God and Man on YouTube
text: The lost art of pantomime seems to be making a comeback on the Internet. Videos of wordless spectacles — natural anomalies, freak accidents, fistfights, dances, stunts, sleights of hand, animal antics — now attract enormous polyglot audiences to sites like YouTube. A silent clowning routine, “Evolution of Dance,” is YouTube’s all-time most-viewed video. In it, a guy hams up a series of dance moves. It has been played 62 million times.

headline: Small Campus, Big Books
text: THERE is a saying at Shimer College: If there are too many people to fit around the table, the class is too big. With an undergraduate student body of 70, this is one of the smallest liberal arts colleges in the United States. It has no lecture halls, and not just because of the enrollment. There are no lectures. Books, not professors, are considered the teachers, and the path to learning relies on the Socratic method of discussion.

headline: In Stetson or Wig, He’s Hard to Pin Down
text: LONDON

headline: Lottery Numbers
A La Mode
text: Hervé Van der Straeten and Bruno Frisoni know that good parties, like good design, are all about the mix. At a recent dinner in their airy Parisian loft, the worlds of fashion and art melded in a perfect reflection of their decorating sensibility: modern chic with an edgy take on the classics.

headline: When the Long-Haul Truck Hits a Bridge
text: TRAFFIC jams are a way of life in and around New York City, but few things irritate drivers more than finding out they were delayed by a tractor-trailer that mistakenly drove onto a parkway, slammed into an overpass and had to be pulled off the road.

headline: Gridiron Girls
text: CATTYSHACK is a dark, brick-walled club carved from a former office building on Fourth Avenue near Carroll Street, on the industrial western fringe of Park Slope. The club caters to lesbians, and most nights, female revelers pack hip-wiggling dance parties featuring a well-used go-go pole.

headline: Pro Shop
text: Food nerds across Los Angeles delight in stumping the equally obsessed staff at Surfas, a 70-year-old restaurant-supply store in Culver City that’s the go-to resource for the hardest-to-find ingredients and cookware.

headline: Ottoman Intrigue
text: When you read a historical mystery by Jason Goodwin, you take a magic carpet ride to the most exotic place on earth. Like its predecessor, “The Janissary Tree,” winner of the Mystery Writers of America’s 2007 Edgar Award for best novel, THE SNAKE STONE (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25) is set in 19th-century Istanbul during the reign of Sultan Mahmut II and features the subtle sleuthing of Yashim Togalu, a eunuch with eyes and ears exquisitely attuned to the cacophony of life in his cosmopolitan world. But with the sultan on his deathbed after a 30-year reign, a deep unease has settled over the city, now poised uncertainly for a momentous historical shift.

headline: No Exit
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Merritt Friedman, Adam Pearson
text: Merritt Laurel Friedman and Adam Joseph Pearson were married last evening at the Mint Museum of Art, in Charlotte, N.C. Rabbi Barbara Thiede officiated.

headline: Youth Club Finds Windfall in Gift of Stock
text: BOSTON, Nov. 3  The Boys and Girls Club of Pittsfield, Mass., relies, in part, on financial gifts to keep running. But officials were not sure they wanted to take a donation of poorly performing stock in a small company when it was offered two years ago, worrying about potential liability and risk to the organization. And club officials figured it would not net that much money, anyway.

headline: A Latin Name, and Best Carefully Cooked
text: Technically, buffalo refers to animals of Asia and Africa — water buffalo and species like Cape buffalo. Those big shaggy symbols of the American West, revered by certain Indian tribes, driven to near extinction and often referred to as American buffalo, are in fact bison with the Latin name Bison bison.

headline: Sales Bring Business Class Within Reach
text: HUNTING for holiday bargain fares to Europe? Take a look at the front of the plane. A number of airlines are running business-class sales with discounts so deep they rival coach-class prices.

headline: Changing Coasts (and Accents, and Pay Grades)
text: SOME repaving may need to be done on the metaphoric highway between Hollywood and Broadway. Most of the traffic used to be moving west, as actors who had earned their stripes — and a modicum of fame — onstage headed to California, where greater celebrity and greater money beckoned. In the past decade or so, however, the westward traffic has slowed considerably, while the lanes heading east are filling up.

headline: Amid Architectural Glories, Piles of Cheap Fun
text: TO drive into Chicago on a sunny Friday afternoon is to experience the city the way God — or at least the holy trinity of Daniel Burnham, Louis H. Sullivan and Mies van der Rohe — intended it. Iconic skyscrapers rise from the strip-mall-strewn prairie to pierce the blue in a jumble of geometries, their glinting glass, steel, stone and concrete announcing the power and prestige of the capital of the Midwest.

headline: Dixon Makes Case for Heisman, Then Exits With an Injury
text: EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 3  Less than eight hours before No. 4 Oregon played No. 6 Arizona State on Saturday, the Ducks unveiled a nationwide television spot on ESPN that promoted the senior quarterback Dennis Dixon for the Heisman Trophy.

headline: Clemens’s Road to Starting Role With Jets Began at the End
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 2  Doubt sank in on the plane ride back from Arizona, as Kellen Clemens stole glances at the boot on his left foot and wondered if his football career was finished.

headline: Shakespeare in the Round-and-Round
text: FOR some children puppet theater is the gateway to a lifelong passion for a more grown-up kind of drama. For others, like Vit Horejs, who grew up to found the Czechoslovak-American Marionette Theater in New York, it’s home.

headline: In Local Waters, an Oyster Resurgence
text: TWO years after a failed effort to declare it an endangered species, the Eastern oyster is making a big comeback, thanks in part, experts say, to farming and habitat restoration efforts across the Northeast.

headline: The Foreign Legions
text: FOR a student at the University of Ghana in Legon, a palm-graced suburb of Accra, a dinner might involve fufu — mashed casava and plantains in a soup of peanut butter and tomatoes — from a local “chop bar.” Electricity is not a given. Nor is running water. Students might have to fetch buckets of water to flush the toilet and wash clothes. Forget sleeping in. They rise at 5 a.m., when the chaos and din begin: loud music and evangelical preaching, through megaphones. The “Challenges of Living in Ghana” handout from the University of California advises bringing earplugs.

headline: Johtje Vos, Who Saved Wartime Jews, Dies at 97
text: Johtje Vos, a Dutch woman who with her husband hid three dozen Jews in their home during World War II, shepherding them through a tunnel under the backyard and into the woods whenever the Gestapo pounded on the door, died on Oct. 10 in Saugerties, N.Y. She was 97, and had lived in Woodstock from 1951 until a year ago.

headline: Where Sales Are Buoyant
text: THINGS are always sweeter at the shore — even in real estate, as indicated by brokers and by fresh data on the market in several beach towns.

text: All dates are subject to change.

headline: The Words on the Street
text: enviro-nazi / (en vi ro\ nat se) / n. / a person who imposes his or her environmental activism on friends and family, as in, “She’s such an enviro-nazi that she won’t use paper plates, so we had to lug china for 12 to the picnic last weekend.”

headline: Witness to Wackiness on the Night Shift
text: THE human body can adjust to any type of work schedule. I have learned this over the last 12 years as a night auditor at the Hotel Diva in downtown San Francisco. My shift starts at 11 p.m. and goes until 7 a.m. During that time, most of my job is clerical. Because it is night, though, I often find myself face to face with something out of the ordinary that keeps it interesting.

headline: My Demitasse Runneth Over
text: NEW YORK is not a hard place to find coffee: street vendors, delis and your own hotel room are among the prominent sources for the not very picky. And of course, there are plenty of cafes — engineered to sell social scenes and designer sandwiches as much as coffee — where you can kill a few hours. Apologies to the French, Spanish and Portuguese, but café — their word for coffee — has become associated as much with comfy chairs and the clickety-clack of laptops as with the beverage. But that's not what you need on your vacation. You need to get your quick caffeine fix in the most civilized way possible, then be on your way. You have a city to see.

headline: You’re In. Can You Back Out?
text: The Reality

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The On Language column on Page 20 of the Magazine today, about the word “shout-out,” misstated the network of the news commentator Chris Matthews, about whom the word was used in a New York Post headline. It is MSNBC, not CNN. (Go to Article)

headline: Clemens’s 4th-Quarter Drive Not Enough to Save Jets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 4 — In another losing locker room, the Jets slumped against their lockers. They did not scream. They did not vent. When they spoke, they spoke softly, with hardly a trace of anger or frustration.

headline: Pairing Ballet With a Bachelor’s Degree
text: ON a recent Sunday evening the lobby of the Hotel Pennsylvania in Midtown Manhattan was crammed with weary tourists weighed down by shopping bags and guidebooks, porters wheeling racks of overstuffed suitcases and a sight entirely alien: slim, graceful figures gliding to the elevator bank like swans.

headline: The Pod People
text: There are some opinions you never expect to change. As humiliating as this sounds, fancying George Clooney is one. Clever, witty, politically correct and (obviously) knee-knockingly sexy — what’s not to like? But that was before I spotted Clooney in an ad for Nestlé’s Nespresso, tapping a coffee capsule as if it were a casino chip in one of his “Ocean’s Gazillion’ movies. It wasn’t the fact that he’d stooped to smirk in an ad that irked me; it was what Clooney was advertising. Now, it’s true that the espresso capsule doesn’t score high in the ever-lengthening list of contemporary evils. But those tiny aluminum pods, and the overstyled espresso machines that use them, sum up much of what goes wrong with design when marketing is dressed up as innovation.

headline: Too Much Meddling When C.E.O.’s Go a-Courtin’?
text: ASKING another corporation for its hand in marriage is always a delicate affair. But does a chief executive need to bring the directors along as chaperones? Does a merger-hungry C.E.O need his or her parents’ blessing before making a proposal?

headline: Christina Yuan, Ali Ozturk
text: Christina Yuan, the daughter of Joan Reynolds Yuan and Albert Yuan of Glenside, Pa., was married yesterday in Villanova, Pa., to Dr. Ali Kemal Ozturk, the son of Dr. Gungor Eroglu of Istanbul and Kemal Ozturk of Ankara, Turkey. The Rev. James J. McCartney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas of Villanova Church.

headline: How Smaller College Endowments Still Reap Big Returns
text: IN a world where the wealthiest investors often have access to the best-performing investment managers, it is tough for smaller college and university endowments to match the returns of deep-pocketed rivals like Harvard and Yale.

headline: Manishi Prasad and Rohit Mehrotra
text: Manishi Prasad, a daughter of Mamta Gour Prasad and Madhukar Prasad of The Woodlands, Tex., was married in a Hindu ceremony there yesterday to Rohit Mehrotra, a son of Kusum Tandon Mehrotra and Amar Mehrotra of Massapequa Park, N.Y. Kesav Shukla, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Woodlands Resort and Conference Center.

headline: Performa 07:  Performance Versus Installation
text: A series of unfortunate events caused me to miss Christian Jankowski’s “Rooftop Routine” this morning, which I’m really sad about. The idea was for people to join him on his roof to see “a unique form of morning calisthenics,” which was either a performance or a voyeuristic endeavor or something in the middle. Did anyone see it? Send me some details. I’m picturing a cross between Trisha Brown’s rooftop dances from the 1970s (which are amazing just on film, and must have been absolutely stunning live) and the morning stretches that this old guy used to do on his roof deck in San Francisco, visible from a friend’s kitchen window. Spying is grand. And, speaking of Trisha Brown, you can see short films of her and her peers’ work from the 1960s and ’70s in two Performa programs at the Anthology Film Archives on the 12th and 13th. Unless I’m overlooking something on the calendar, it will be your only chance to see New York choreographers during the festival, as was discussed in an earlier post.

headline: Berlin in Lights: ‘Symphony of a City’
text: Walther Ruttmann’s “Symphony of a City,” screened twice at Zankel Hall on Saturday, was conceived as an abstract exercise in composition: think Rodchenko turned to film (though Ruttmann does not quite have Rodchenko’s eye for a detail that is both telling and original). But though avant-garde in 1927, today it awakens primarily a voyeuristic response: what was life like then?

headline: Onward
text: About 20 percent of new college graduates go right on to grad school, especially in medicine and the arts and sciences, according to Debra W. Stewart, president of the Council of Graduate Schools. After 10 years, more than 40 percent have enrolled. (Work experience is especially valued in M.B.A. programs.) Many colleges don't keep tabs on graduates. The institutions below, culled from a Peterson's survey, are some that do poll graduates on what they're up to. Their response rates vary. The chart offers a sketch of what some freshly minted graduates are pursuing.

headline: Quit Yakking and Order Your Food
text: We published a story today about the use of cell phone jammers – gadgets that shut down cell phone signals within a several yard radius. The technology is not new, and it’s illegal, but it’s getting more popular among individual users who say they are sick of overhearing loud cell phone conversations in public settings.

headline: The Joy in Jamming
text: The cellphone jammers express great joy initially at being able to silence chatterers. They also generally seem to feel some guilt, particularly over time.

headline: Musharraf and Lincoln, in Their Own Words
text: As David Rohde reported in The Times today, Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, speaking on Pakistani television about his decision to suspend his country’s Constitution, compared himself to Abraham Lincoln.

headline: Eyewitnesses to the Marathon
text: Updated, Nov. 5 | NYTimes.com invited readers to submit photographs from their own marathon day for display on an interactive race map. We’ve received snapshots of the family and friends you cheered on, photographs of the crowds and images of the elite runners.

headline: Performa 07: Adam Pendleton, Artists and Statistics
text: My first Performa outing, to Adam Pendleton’s “The Revival,” on Thursday night, was a pretty impressive experience. The setting was the cavernous, immaculate space of the Stephan Weiss studio in Greenwich Village (what did the sculptor do with all that space?), outfitted with benches in a slight fan shape around the stage – and it was packed with fashionable Performa people, some standing near the back. The back was where Mr. Pendleton emerged from, but first his disembodied golden voice floated over the crowd, and over the choir and musicians on the stage. With a mixture of oratory, poetry, politico-speak and strident gay protest, he held sway for just on an hour, alternating his resonant, often repetitive text with the choir’s gorgeous sonorities.I had my reservations about the text – for one, the section where Mr. Pendleton quotes Aids statistics and talks about the Bush Administration’s responses to HIV infection felt like an obligatory gay rights insert rather than integral to the piece. But the man is the most charismatic performer I’ve seen on stage for a long time – and the acoustics at the studio were extraordinary – for once, the meaning of “crystal clear” seemed appropriate: you could hear everything from a whisper to the full-throated roar of the choir with utter purity.It was also an extraordinarily polished and well-paced show, from the grave processional entrance of the choir to their departure and Mr. Pendleton’s final monologue and slow exit – out back, the way he had come in. But despite that, there was a relaxed enjoyment of performance and involvement amongst the choir that was a pleasure to see. And their singing really did communicate the uplifting joyousness of that religious tradition without quite speaking directly of religion.But quite aside from the piece itself, what struck me strongly was that it was the second time in one week that a performer was up there on stage quoting statistics about life in America to an audience. In his wonderful new work, “Misuse Liable to Prosecution,” the choreographer John Jasperse offers the audience numbers about the war, the arts, the salaries of various figures, and the costs of his production. Adam Pendleton does something similar in his Aids section. Are artists feeling that things are so bad that their art forms – poetry, the dancing body in these cases – are too inchoate for what they need to say? Perhaps it was a coincidence, but I suspect not.

headline: Correction: A (Sometimes) Deadly Scourge
text: An article last Sunday about the prevalence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA, included information about treatments for infection, provided by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, that was incomplete. As the article noted, MRSA skin infections can respond to oral antibiotics like levofloxacin or moxifloxacin. But those two drugs belong to a class that the agency no longer considers optimal for treatment because MRSA is more resistant to them than to other agents. Instead, the agency recommends treatment with clindamycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, doxycycline, minocycline, rifampin or linezolid.

headline: Correction: Worrying About the Public Worrying
text: An article last Sunday about a survey of commercial pilots designed to track safety problems misidentified the federal agency that conducted the study. It was the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

headline: History, You’re Toast

text: The Jets’ inactive list contains an unfamiliar name this morning – receiver Laveranues Coles will not play because of a concussion he sustained last week against Buffalo.

text: Okay readers, how about a little praise for my last post on praise? Don’t I get a little credit? A medal? Something to make me feel good about myself?

headline: Citi Watch: A King’s Ransom for Prince’s Exit?
text: Sunday update: Charles Prince’s departure has been called “retirement,” which would entitle him to at least the $147.1 million for his time at Citigroup. We’ll update as we learn more.

headline: Recipe: Zucchini-Sausage Pizza
text: There may be more possible combinations of pizza toppings than atoms in the universe, but I’ve found that using the fewest components works best. Too many ingredients merely muddy the flavors.

text: The New York City Marathon is more than a race. For tens of thousands of runners and hundreds of thousands of spectators, it's an event.

headline: You’ve Got Questions? We’ve Got Answers.
text: Reporters and editors from The Times political desk will be answering questions about the 2008 election throughout the week. Please,E-Mail your questions to askthetimes@nytimes.com.

headline: Citi Watch: Rubin and Bischoff Are In
text: It is over. Charles O. Prince III has resigned from Citigroup, with Robert E. Rubin serving as chairman and Winfried Bischoff as interim chief executive. Read Citi’s statement here.

headline: Citi Watch: Meet the Interim C.E.O.
text: Charles O. Prince III has resigned from Citigroup, and Robert E. Rubin has taken the reins as chairman. But who’s that interim figure in the chief executive’s seat?

headline: One Collective Soul in Outer Space
text: The crews from the shuttle Discovery and the International Space Station had a farewell ceremony today and closed the hatch between the two craft. Discovery will undock tomorrow and prepare for its return to Earth on Wednesday.

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter: Pakistan
text: A talk-show menu that was top-heavy with presidential candidates took a bit of a detour from domestic politics today — to Pakistan. The newly declared state of emergency there evoked sharp expressions of concern from the candidates and a handful of lawmakers, and there was disagreement about whether America’s considerable military aid to the Pakistanis should be suspended.

headline: Citi Watch: The Goodbye Memos
text: In formalizing Charles O. Prince’s departure from Citigroup — officially deemed “retirement” — Mr. Prince and Robert E. Rubin and Winfried Bischoff sent Citi’s employees two memorandums addressing the shakeup. Mr. Prince’s sounds a remorseful note, praising Citi’s progress under his watch while accepting responsibility for its massive losses (a $5.9 billion in the third quarter, and potentially $8 billion to $11 billion to come).

headline: London Slowing ‘Rapidly’
text: Knight Frank’s report on central London released today shows price inflation for residential property slowing “rapidly” in the last three months. After a crisp growth rate of more than 3 percent a month through the summer, London’s core residential property posted a miserly 0.3 percent bump in October, the smallest increase since 2005, according to the real estate company’s research.

headline: The First Game of the Clemens Era
text: The Kellen Clemens era kicked off today, and while he showcased that powerful right arm, Clemens also showed another, more unexpected, strength: his feet.

headline: Rudy plays the race card
text: A central theme of The Conscience of a Liberal is that movement conservatives have won elections despite their economic message, not because of it, and that the most important factor in the movement’s electoral success is the exploitation of racial hostility.

headline: Bayou Closers
text: It is O.K. if you want to refer to Louisiana State’s football team as the Closers, not the Tigers.

headline: Suffering, Evil and the Existence of God
text: In Book 10 of Milton’s “Paradise Lost,” Adam asks the question so many of his descendants have asked: why should the lives of billions be blighted because of a sin he, not they, committed? (“Ah, why should all mankind / For one man’s fault… be condemned?”) He answers himself immediately: “But from me what can proceed, / But all corrupt, both Mind and Will depraved?” Adam’s Original Sin is like an inherited virus. Although those who are born with it are technically innocent of the crime – they did not eat of the forbidden tree – its effects rage in their blood and disorder their actions.

headline: Bowling in Storrs
text: Officials from the Sugar Bowl were on hand Saturday night in East Hartford to scout No. 16 Connecticut for a possible berth in the Bowl Championship Series, not the Final Four.

headline: From Portland, Oregon
text: I get second billing to President Schwarzenegger, but still . . .

headline: Carr on Hart
text: Michigan tailback Mike Hart probably won’t win the Heisman Trophy this season, after missing two full games and parts of others with injuries. But the fact that he is well known, combined with his production, will likely get him an invitation to New York as a finalist.

headline: Are the Patriots Unbeatable?
text: It may have been impossible to live up to the obscene level of hype it received, but the Patriots-Colts game certainly wasn’t a stinker. The Times’s William C. Rhoden says the game was not the Ali-Frazier type of event that Colts Coach Tony Dungy compared it to, but it proved beyond a doubt that the Patriots and the Colts are No. 1 and No. 1-A in the N.F.L.

headline: The Inheritance on Climate
Jay-Z Finds Himself at the Movies
text: Jay-Z introduced himself to the world in 1996, when he released his debut album, “Reasonable Doubt.” On the front, he wore not only an umlaut (the cover read, “Jaÿ-Z”) but also a suit with a matching hat; suffice it to say that back then Brooklyn rappers weren’t usually seen in formal wear. In the songs he played the part of the smooth criminal, delivering slick lyrics that sounded even better because he didn’t raise his voice. The idea was, he didn’t need to.

text: CHRIS BROWN “Exclusive” (Jive/Zomba)

headline: Radio Holding Off on Holidays, a Little
text: On Wednesday, the radio station KCKC in Kansas City, Mo., became the first station of the year to start playing Christmas music exclusively. Hundreds of other stations will soon follow, if previous years are any guide.

headline: We Mustn’t Turn Our Backs on the Homeless
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tracking of Web Use by Marketers Gains Favor
text: It seems that the Federal Trade Commission is not slowing down the online advertising party.

headline: Still No Answer on What Caused Runner’s Death
text: The day after Ryan Shay died during the United States Olympic trials for the marathon — a seemingly healthy 28-year-old stricken early in a race he had run many times — his family had no more answers.

headline: Gates in Beijing for Talks on Military Buildup
text: BEIJING, Nov. 4 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived Sunday in Beijing to begin two days of talks with senior leaders, and Pentagon officials said he planned to press for a more open dialogue on China’s military while discussing ways to build trust and cooperation.

headline: Burlesque Without Borders
text: The program promises “Berlin Cabaret.” But audiences at the Café Sabarsky, where the festival Berlin in Lights is presenting eight nights of cabaret this month, are getting Berlin cabaret by way of Vienna, since both the cafe and the Neue Galerie, the museum that houses it, are steeped in Viennese tradition. On Friday night this double dislocation underlined the theme of exile that permeated Ute Lemper’s opening program, which focused, as those familiar with Ms. Lemper might expect, on Brecht and Weill.

headline: Death Camp Concert Is Canceled
text: Protests by Jewish groups ended plans for a rock concert scheduled for last Saturday at the site of a Nazi death camp in Belgrade, Serbia, The Associated Press reported. On Friday, Efraim Zuroff, director of the Nazi-hunting Simon Wiesenthal Center in Jerusalem, issued a statement calling the planned performance “a heartless insult to the memory of the victims of the Nazis.” The organizers of the concert by the British band Kosheen attributed the cancellation to “pressure from foreign and domestic media.” The concert was to have been held at Staro Sajmiste, where 48,000 Jews, Serb leftists and Gypsies perished in the 1940s. The Long Play company, which organized the concert, said, “We hope that the big publicity created around the Staro Sajmiste site will be used for solving the problem of renovating the place.” Members of the dwindling Jewish population in Serbia say the camp needs to be saved from decades of neglect.

headline: Sun Reports Profit as Turnaround Continues
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5  Sun Microsystems delivered strong quarterly results today as it continued to benefit from its corporate restructuring and stronger sales of high-end computers.

headline: Drawing a Line Between Enduring Harm and Legitimate Fear
text: When Alima Traore was a young girl in Mali, parts of her genitalia were cut off, which is the custom there.

headline: Louis Vuitton Ad Shows Gorbachev Accompanied by Subversive Text
text: Even if you don’t read Russian, a recent print ad for Louis Vuitton is something of a visual joke: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the old Soviet Union, sits in a limousine as it passes a remaining part of the Berlin Wall, an open Louis Vuitton bag beside him.

headline: Kurdish Rebels Free Turkish Soldiers
text: DAHOK, Iraq, Nov. 4 — Kurdish guerrillas on Sunday released eight Turkish soldiers who were captured two weeks ago in a bloody ambush that enraged Turkey and helped stir its government to the verge of invading northern Iraq.

headline: ‘Gangster’ Swats ‘Bee’
text: Crime paid for Universal Pictures when its “American Gangster,” starring Denzel Washington as a drug lord and Russell Crowe as his law enforcement nemesis, won the battle of the buzz by outdrawing “Bee Movie” at North American box offices. According to estimates compiled by the tracking company Media by Numbers, the two heavily promoted films captured the first two rankings in weekend grosses. “Gangster” took in $46.3 million, while $39.1 million went to DreamWorks Animation’s “Bee,” distributed by Paramount and employing the voices of Jerry Seinfeld, a writer of its screenplay, and Renée Zellweger as his beloved. Having seen better days, including Halloween, last week’s No. 1 film, “Saw IV” (Lionsgate), plummeted to third place, with $11 million, followed by “Dan in Real Life” (Disney) with $8.1 million and “30 Days of Night” with $4 million.

headline: Not Quite Ali-Frazier, but It Lived Up to Hype
text: Indianapolis

headline: In Denver, a Ballot Fight Over Marijuana Arrests
text: DENVER — In 2005, voters here approved a measure making it legal for an adult to possess an ounce or less of marijuana. But arrests for misdemeanor marijuana possession have risen since then.

headline: Shhhh. Paper and Tape in Use.
text: What must Marie Cool have been like as a child? After watching her task-based collaboration with Fabio Balducci at the Clocktower Gallery in Manhattan on Friday night, an image comes to mind: a pale, solemn girl dressed entirely in black, with a long strawberry-blond braid trailing behind, padding softly through a barren house. Stopping to pick up a paper clip, she unbends it with methodical absorption. Pausing a moment to stare into space, as if framing the action, she soundlessly abandons it in search of the next ordinary object waiting to be turned into art.

headline: 26 Miles of Music: Race Is Also a Marathon of Bands
text: For 30 years, Bishop Loughlin High School’s marching band has set up at the very same spot on marathon day. For 30 years, about as long as the song has been around, they have played the theme from “Rocky.” Over. And over. And over again. Nothing else. All day long.

headline: A Roosevelt for Roosevelt Island
text: Slicing into the East River, flanked by Queens and Manhattan, Roosevelt Island should be a destination. Plenty of people take the tram from Manhattan’s East Side, but unless they live, work or go to school on the island, there is little else to do, except take the tram back.

headline: Corrections
text: The headline with an article on Saturday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign and the issue of treating women and men equally in presidential politics overstated Senator Clinton’s response to suggestions that she had been using her gender as a shield against criticism from her male opponents. Mrs. Clinton said her rivals were “picking on” her because she was winning, not because she was a woman. She then went on to say: “I anticipate it’s going to get even hotter — and if you can’t stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. And I’m very much at home in the kitchen.” Mrs. Clinton did not “retreat” on issues of men versus women. (Go to Article)

headline: A New Arena in the Fight Over Smoking: The Home
text: Jill and Joanie Shockley just want to breathe clean air in their homes. Neighboring tenants want to smoke in theirs.

headline: Chef Tell, Who Turned Kitchen Skill Into TV Fame, Dies at 63
text: The Philadelphia culinary legend known as Chef Tell, who gained nationwide fame as an early television chef in the 1970s and ’80s, died Oct. 26 at his home in Upper Black Eddy, Pa. He was 63.

headline: Dallas to Vote on Remaking City
text: DALLAS, Nov. 5 — Municipal officials here recognized decades ago that the grassy flood plain cutting a swath through the city could be transformed into a vast park.

headline: Obama Plays Convincing Obama in a Skit Mocking Clinton
text: “Saturday Night Live” has relentlessly mocked Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and this weekend allowed Senator Barack Obama, a chief rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, to join in the skewering.

headline: Parsons to Step Down as Time Warner Chief
text: Jeffrey L. Bewkes will succeed Richard D. Parsons as the chief executive of Time Warner at the end of the year, the company announced today, confirming a widely expected transition of power at one of the world’s foremost media companies.

headline: A Winning Soccer Coach Faces a Ruthless Foe
text: It is a crisp autumn day and the Martin Luther King Jr. High School soccer team is winning again. Their precision passing and stifling defense usually make for one-sided games; until a few weeks ago, the squad was ranked first in the nation.

headline: Couple Struggles to Pay Bills and Care for Sick Son
text: Like many expectant mothers, Kelly Cabrera was both nervous and eager. Her third child was due, and Ms. Cabrera had decided it would be her last. She was ready to find a job to help her husband, Edison, support their family.

headline: Guatemalan Voters Elect Businessman
text: GUATEMALA CITY, Nov. 4 — A former army general who once took on the insurgency in Guatemala’s long civil war lost his battle for the country’s presidency on Sunday night, with voters rejecting his plan to use an iron fist, as well as the country’s military, to control a sky-high murder rate.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (22, 26) CAROL BURNETT: A WOMAN OF CHARACTER Whether descending the staircase at Tara dressed in a curtain, with rod, or emitting one of her Tarzan yells, Ms. Burnett, above, made America laugh while also smashing stereotypes and showing that women could be at once feminine, empowered and funny. This “American Masters” documentary pays tribute to her life and career, using one of her signature devices: the audience question-and-answer session that opened her weekly show, which won 25 Emmys during its run from 1967 to 1978. This program includes clips of Ms. Burnett’s appearances on other television shows, in films and on the stage. It also features interviews with performers she inspired, including Tracey Ullman, Ellen DeGeneres, Kristin Chenoweth and Jenna Elfman. Alas, Ms. Burnett’s childhood wasn’t a laughing matter. But as her grandmother once told her, “Comedy is tragedy plus time.”

headline: Fixing Citigroup Will Test Rubin
text: Throughout a long, public career, Robert E. Rubin spanned the highest reaches of Wall Street and Washington, and succeeded wherever he went.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: After a Death, Time for Life and a Race
text: It was just a race — one of the best ever in the New York City Marathon, with two great athletes, two mothers, battling each other all the way, but still, only a race, in the opinion of the winner.

headline: When Playing With Food Becomes Serious Business
text: One contestant painstakingly made a model of the Starship Enterprise out of an ear of corn, a stalk of celery, an eggplant, a mushroom and other vegetables. Another turned a half-shelled peapod into the hull of a ship. Several contestants made real potatoes into Mr. Potato Head-type creations.

headline: In a Troubled World, It’s Good to Be Exceptional
text: If you have missed “Heroes,” the NBC Monday-night series about a group of people with extraordinary capabilities, then you have missed everything, which is to say, you have missed a show that exempts almost no subject of current political or social fascination from the roster of its interests. More than a quarter of the way into the second season, the ratings have slipped somewhat, but it remains the most engaged drama on television at the moment, a big hand with fingers dangling in every pot.

headline: From Paris With Love
text: The French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, arrives in Washington tomorrow on a visit to seal “the renewal of ties between France and the United States following the crisis of 2003.” Here’s how the post-Iraq Franco-American lovefest may unfold at the White House.

headline: Foster Children at Risk, and an Opportunity Lost
text: Two decades ago, New York City embarked on an experiment aimed at better assisting and protecting its most vulnerable black and Latino children. At its heart, the effort involved creating and supporting foster care agencies that would, at long last, be run by men and women of color.

headline: 2008 Already Settled? Not by a Long Shot
text: ALLISON, Iowa — With a year to go until Election Day, the Democratic Party is understandably bubbling with optimism, its spirits raised with almost every new poll, fund-raising report or overflow crowd at a rally for Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama or John Edwards.

headline: Uncle Sam on the Line
text: Washington

headline: Second Place Is Enough for a Victory
text: Smiling through her post-race news conference yesterday, Gete Wami of Ethiopia did not look like someone who had spent the entire New York City Marathon within touching distance of first place, only to fall to second in the homestretch.

headline: Serious Upscale Décor for a Wayward Lady
text: “La Traviata” returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon. When a Franco Zeffirelli production is on the boards, competition is in the air. Who will win? Verdi’s beloved music, the people who sing it, or will both be swamped under the force of opera’s premier interior decorator?

headline: Peter A. A. Berle, Lawmaker and Conservationist, Dies at 69
text: Peter A. A. Berle, who spent decades fighting for open space and clean water as a New York State assemblyman, commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation and president of the National Audubon Society, died on Thursday in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 69.

headline: Racecar Driver Is Fourth in Handcycle
text: Alex Zanardi, the Italian racecar driver who lost his legs in a crash in 2001, competed yesterday in the handcycle division of the New York City Marathon, his first marathon. Zanardi, 40, finished in 1 hour 33 minutes 17 seconds for fourth place.

headline: He Never Met a Deal He Didn’t Like
text: One of the greatest bridge players of all time, Tim Seres, died Sept. 27 at 82 in Sydney, Australia, where he lived most of his life. He was born in Hungary, lost his parents in World War II and soon thereafter, with the help of an aunt and uncle, went with his elder brother, George, to Sydney via France and Vietnam.

headline: In Portland, Cultivating a Culture of Two Wheels
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Susan Peithman did not have a job lined up when she moved here in September to pursue a career in “nonmotorized transportation.” No worries, she figured; the market here is strong.

headline: Missteps on Both Sides Led to Health Bill Veto
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 — They met almost every day in the spring and summer, a handful of powerful senators who had cleared their schedules to forge a bipartisan compromise providing health insurance to 10 million children.

headline: A Folksy Guy, in Recovery, Is About to Land Millions
text: On his daily radio talk show, Glenn Beck portrays himself as an average guy, a recovering alcoholic and a comedian who regularly injects humor into his conservative politics.

headline: Bush Offers Turkish Leader Help Against Rebels
text: WASHINGTON. Nov. 4 — President George W. Bush offered Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan additional help today in containing Iraq-based Kurdish militants, hoping to avert Turkish troops from crossing the border. Mr. Erdogan, however, did not indicate whether the White House reassurances were enough.

headline: Armstrong Comes Back for More
text: A year ago, Lance Armstrong came to New York to run his first marathon, hoping to break three hours and finishing in anguish in 2 hours 59 minutes 36 seconds. His shins hurt (he later learned he had stress fractures), and he swore he would never run another marathon.

headline: Fixing Citigroup Will Test Rubin
text: Throughout a long, public career, Robert E. Rubin spanned the highest reaches of Wall Street and Washington, and succeeded wherever he went.

headline: Tattoo Marked Hip-Hop Killer
text: Jam Master Jay’s unidentified killer had a tattooed neck, according to a witness, The Associated Press reported. Five years after Jam Master Jay, the D.J. who provided beats and scratches for the rap group Run-DMC’s groundbreaking records, was shot to death on Oct. 30, 2002, in his recording studio in Jamaica, Queens, his business partner Randy Allen told The Daily News in an interview published yesterday that he was in the control room, and his sister, Lydia High, was near the entrance at the time. Mr. Allen said she told him that after two gunmen ordered her to the floor, she saw a man with a tattooed neck approach Jay, 37, whose real name was Jason Mizell, and open fire. The first shot wounded another man. The second hit Mr. Mizell’s head at point-blank range, touching off an investigation that has been blocked by uncooperative witnesses, investigators say, despite a substantial reward. Ms. High has been reported to be in protective custody, and her lawyer said recently that he had not heard from her in more than a year. Mr. Allen said he had cooperated with investigators and was angry that others had not. Mr. Allen said, “This is a case that can be solved.”

headline: Leon Brand, 74, Who Founded New York Architecture Prize, Dies
text: Leon Brand, an architect who conceived and administered the Albert S. Bard Award, an architectural prize intended to raise the standard of excellence for building design in New York City, died on Oct. 24 in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: India, Beyond City Limits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cowboys Rough Up Reid and the Eagles
text: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4  In the opening moments of the second half, many Philadelphia fans headed for the exits of Lincoln Financial Field. Dallas quarterback Tony Romo had just staked the Cowboys to a 20-point lead, but the real insult was that he did so with a 45-yard touchdown pass to the most hated former Eagle of them all, Terrell Owens.

headline: Musical Days of Berlin (the City ... and the Irving)
text: Max Raabe, the wry, unsmiling and nonchalantly charismatic vocalist who headlines the Palast Orchester of Berlin, opened the ambitious 17-day festival Berlin in Lights on Friday night at Carnegie Hall. As is his wont, Mr. Raabe gave running commentary on the songs he and the ensemble were performing.

headline: Developer Would Include Low-Cost Units in East Side Towers
text: A developer seeking to build seven high-rise buildings on a former Con Ed property by the East River has agreed to set aside hundreds of apartments for poor and working-class tenants, as well as space for a school.

headline: Olson Takes Leave for Personal Matter
text: TUCSON, Nov. 4 (AP)  Arizona Coach Lute Olson is taking a leave of absence for unspecified personal reasons.

headline: In the End, Radcliffe and Lel Break Free to Win New York
text: Four miles into yesterday’s New York City Marathon, Paula Radcliffe of England and Gete Wami of Ethiopia were clear of the field and running into the medical unknown.

headline: Another Question? Why Was She So Funny?
text: Pardon the imitation of the thoroughly unlikable Andy Rooney, but why aren’t our joke tellers likable anymore? Margaret Cho or Sarah Silverman might make you laugh, but would you want either of them at Thanksgiving dinner with Grandma and the kids?

headline: Illness Ends Decemberists Tour
text: The indie-pop band the Decemberists have canceled the remaining dates on their fall tour, citing the illness of an unidentified member. In a statement on its Web site (decemberists.com), the five-member ensemble, based in Portland, Ore., said: “One of our band members has been ill for a while, but we thought all would be well in time for these tour dates. After a couple shows, though, it has become clear that the illness is much worse than we had initially realized. We need to return home so our friend can mend.” The cancellation of “The Long and Short of It” tour affects 28 shows, including a concert in New York that was to have taken place last Friday. According to the statement, there are no plans to reschedule.

headline: Putting an End to Abusive Lending
text: When members of the House Financial Services Committee meet this week to put the finishing touches on a bill to curb abusive mortgage lending, they need focus only on how to make a good bill better.

headline: $7,900 Valentino Gowns, a Click Away
text: ANGELENOS have Rodeo Drive. New Yorkers have Fifth Avenue. Chicagoans have the Magnificent Mile. For many other high-fashion shoppers, the nearest destination is the Web.

headline: A Singer With the South in Her Soul and Jazz in Her Heart
text: Listen to almost any recording of the Oklahoma-born 1930s jazz singer Lee Wiley, and you will hear the sultry, honey-dripping voice of a Southern-accented forerunner of the young Peggy Lee.

headline: New B.C.S. Formula: Turning Seven Into Two
text: Ten weeks have passed in this volatile college football season, and there finally seem to be some clues as to how it will end. Teams like South Florida and Boston College, which defied pedigree and expectations to rise toward the top of the poll, have settled back to reality. Others, like Florida, Louisville and California, have failed to live up to preseason expectations.

headline: Child Prodigy, Grown Up, Returns With Enthusiasm
text: The striking thing was the crowd. Elisha Abas, 35, a former child prodigy on the piano, returned to Carnegie Hall, or at least to Weill Recital Hall, on Saturday night with a program of classical standards. The program was unusual — the printed program, that is, which, in addition to the repertory, included the logos of several sponsors and announced an after-party with a D.J. at an East Village lounge, free to anyone with a ticket stub. Most in the packed auditorium appeared to be of an age to take advantage of this offer. Here was the audience that classical music presenters are continually trying to reach: hip and mostly under 40.

headline: Voice of Road Runners Knows About Endurance
text: Ian Brooks, the public-address announcer at the finish line of the New York City Marathon, stood on a platform above the action yesterday and gripped a microphone. A jumbo screen nearby showed Paula Radcliffe of Britain heading through Central Park, with Gete Wami of Ethiopia one step behind.

headline: Pakistan Rounds Up Musharraf’s Political Foes
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 4 — The government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, making no concessions a day after seizing emergency powers, rounded up leading opposition figures and said Sunday that parliamentary elections could be delayed for as long as a year.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,836 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Publishers See a Way to Track Their Content Across the Net
text: Copyrighted work like a news article or a picture can hop between Web sites as easily as a cut-and-paste command. But more than ever, as that material finds new audiences, the original sources might not get the direct financial benefit — in fact, they might have little idea where their work has spread.

headline: Culture Institutions Go After the Short-Attention-Span Crowd
text: For a certain, dwindling generation of art-loving Manhattanites, a mental map of Brooklyn resembles a variation on Saul Steinberg’s Big Apple-centric New Yorker cover, with the borough an undifferentiated lump save for that citadel of culture, the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Witness the BAMbus, which exists, much to the eye-rolling of locals, to zip Brooklyn-leery audiences to and from a show as painlessly as possible.

headline: The Day’s Best
text: Drew Brees passed for 445 yards and 3 touchdowns in the Saints’ fourth straight victory, a 41-24 win over the Jaguars. Of his 35 completions, 25 were for first downs.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about sites in Manhattan related to the Manhattan Project misidentified the location of a cyclotron that was used for physics experiments. The cyclotron shown was the one at Nevis Laboratories in Irvington, N.Y., not the one in Pupin Hall on the campus of Columbia University. (Nevis is owned and operated by Columbia.)

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Rosie O’Donnell in Talks to Join MSNBC
text: Rosie O’Donnell, who abruptly left “The View” on ABC last spring after drawing attention and ratings for her opinions on everything from the Iraq war to her co-hosts, is in serious discussions to return to television atop a new soapbox: a prime-time show on the cable news channel MSNBC, according to executives on both sides of the negotiations who have been briefed directly.

headline: As Citigroup Chief Totters, CNBC Reporter Is Having a Great Year
text: The big story on CNBC all day today will undoubtedly be the fallout from the resignation of Charles O. Prince III as chairman of Citigroup — and Maria Bartiromo, one of the best-known names in business news on television, will surely be among the reporters covering it.

headline: Statement from Citigroup on the Resignation of C.E.O. Charles O. Prince III
text: The Board of Directors of Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C) today announced that Robert E. Rubin, Chairman of the Executive Committee of Citi and a member of the Board of Directors, will serve as Chairman of the Board.

headline: Different Rules When a Rival Is a Woman?
text: DES MOINES, Nov. 4 — A critical question in this campaign — how to run against a female presidential candidate, or as one — has burst into the foreground in the aftermath of a Democratic debate last week at which Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was repeatedly challenged by her rivals and the event’s questioners.

headline: Bayer Withdraws Heart Surgery Drug
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Pressured by regulators around the world, the German pharmaceutical giant Bayer A.G. announced Monday that it had agreed to withdraw the controversial heart surgery drug Trasylol after a Canadian study suggested that it increased death rates.

headline: U.A.W. Local Chiefs Back Ford Deal
text: DETROIT, Nov. 5 — Leaders of United Automobile Workers union locals at Ford Motor unanimously approved a new contract with the automaker today, clearing the way for a vote by 54,000 workers in the United States.

headline: PetroChina Shares Triple in Debut
text: HONG KONG, Nov. 5 — PetroChina, the state oil and gas giant, became the world’s first company to pass $1 trillion in market capitalization when it debuted on the Shanghai Stock Exchange today.

headline: Bronx: Man Is Shot to Death
text: A Bronx man was fatally shot in Longwood early yesterday, the police said. An officer responding to a report of gunshots found the man, Hashim Osbourne, 28, of Gleason Avenue, lying at the corner of Kelly Street and East 163rd Street about 3:15 a.m., the police said. Mr. Osbourne had been shot multiple times in the torso and once in the head, the police said. Medical workers pronounced him dead at the scene. No arrests had been made as of yesterday evening.

headline: Olmert Backs Mideast Peace Conference
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 4 — Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel issued his strongest and most vocal support yet on Sunday for Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice’s efforts to forge a Middle East peace plan, raising the possibility of making peace with the Palestinians before the conclusion of the Bush administration.

headline: Leslie Orgel, Biochemist Who Studied Origins of Life, Dies at 80
text: Leslie E. Orgel, a biochemist whose studies of early life on primitive Earth helped lead to the formation of a now widely accepted theory about the development of DNA, died Oct. 27 in San Diego. He was 80.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A film review in Weekend on Friday about the documentary “Darfur Now” misidentified the university attended by Adam Sterling, who worked to get a bill passed to force California to divest from companies whose business benefits Sudan. It was U.C.L.A., not the University of Southern California.

headline: So-Called Show Runners Pick Sides in Looming Strike
text: Which top television writers are the least supportive of a strike? Some people in Hollywood are wondering if an unusual advertisement holds the answer.

headline: Premier Says Separatists in Kosovo Losing Patience
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Nov. 3 — Agim Ceku, Kosovo’s warrior-turned-prime minister, is used to long and treacherous journeys.

headline: Head Injury Keeps Coles on the Sideline
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 4  Last week Jerricho Cotchery called his fellow Jets receiver Laveranues Coles the toughest receiver in the N.F.L. Cotchery’s statement was backed up by Coles’s streaks: 104 regular-season starts, 107 games played, 69 games with at least one reception.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The On Education column on Wednesday about online courses included the incorrect cost, from a Pennsylvania State University professor, for the master’s program in business administration at the university. It is $49,000, not $52,000. Because of an editing error, the column also referred incorrectly to a course the writer once took that he said would not be as effective if taught online. It was a graduate-level course, not an undergraduate one.

headline: U.S. Is Likely to Continue Aid to Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 — The Bush administration signaled Sunday that it would probably keep billions of dollars flowing to Pakistan’s military, despite the detention of human rights advocates and leaders of the political opposition by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the country’s president.

headline: Plan for Nuclear Storage Is Slow to Form
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 — The Energy Department has not finished plans to consolidate storage of nuclear bomb fuel and other high-risk materials now spread among numerous sites, even though the department said in 2005 that it would do so within about a year, according to a Government Accountability Office report to be released Monday.

headline: Big Executive of the Tiny Screen
text: LOS ANGELES — When CBS Mobile introduced the Daily Delivery, a short video for cellphones highlighting fashionable shops in Los Angeles and cool gadgets, it was a disaster.

headline: U.S. Official Calls Russian Radar Good, but Not Exact Enough for Tracking Plan
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 — To block American proposals for building missile defenses in Europe, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia surprised the White House in June with a counteroffer to let the United States use one of the Kremlin’s most secret early-warning radars.

headline: Justices to Review Death Penalty Case
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 — The Supreme Court agreed today to review the case of an Idaho death row inmate who was condemned after following his lawyer’s advice to reject a plea bargain that would have spared his life.

headline: Father Charged in Death of Baby Girl in Queens
text: A Queens man was charged yesterday with the murder of his 13-month-old daughter, who died after she was found bruised and unconscious in the family’s home in South Ozone Park, the police said.

headline: Hollywood Reporter Starts an Edition for New York
text: To Eric Mika, senior vice president and publishing director of The Hollywood Reporter, the logic of setting up shop in Manhattan is obvious.

headline: Trial Near for Shiite Ex-Officials in Sunni Killings
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 3 — An Iraqi judge has ruled that there is enough evidence to try two former Health Ministry officials, both Shiites, in the killing and kidnapping of hundreds of Sunnis, many of them snatched from hospitals by militias, according to American officials who are advising the Iraqi judicial system.

headline: Things Turn Ugly in the ‘Hacks vs. Flacks’ War
text: Journalists often call publicists “flacks” and publicists call journalists “hacks,” though rarely in earshot of one another. But the gloves came off last week after Chris Anderson, the executive editor of Wired magazine, chided “lazy flacks” who deluge him with news releases “because they can’t be bothered to find out who on my staff, if anyone, might actually be interested in what they’re pitching.”

headline: With a Torrent of Lyrics, Daring the Fans to Keep Up
