text: You know that faintly disorienting feeling you get when you see a good, weird band for the first time? Happily devoid of prejudice, you listen without any guesses or opinions about what’s coming next. You make out a few snatches of lyrics and resolve to investigate them later. You realize there’s a lot you’re missing.

headline: Guy Fawkes Is Spared, and England Is Restive
text: YORK, England, Nov. 2 — Deep in the bowels of the York Dungeon, visitors were being treated to a dramatic rendition of the horrific torture and bloodcurdling screams of Guy Fawkes, the city’s most famous deceased resident. Up at the cash register, Kate Stapylton, the duty manager, was talking about the health and safety regulations governing the attraction.

headline: Google Enters the Wireless World
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 — Google took its long-awaited plunge into the wireless world today, announcing that it is leading a broad industry alliance to transform mobile phones into powerful mobile computers that could accelerate the convergence of computing and communications.

headline: Randolph’s Big Finish Gives Knicks a Reason to Celebrate
text: Zach Randolph and Knicks fans were officially introduced last night, a first date that inspired strong mutual affection, if not quite love at first sight. Deeper feelings and Hallmark cards may yet be in their future.

headline: Khun Sa, Golden Triangle Drug King, Dies at 73
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 2 — Khun Sa, the publicity-loving Golden Triangle drug lord who thrived in the region’s “kill or be killed” cauldron of ethnic rivalries and heroin-financed private armies, has died at 73 in Yangon, Myanmar, according to an officer in the militia he once led.

headline: Brokaw Explores Another Turning Point, the ’60s
text: Tom Brokaw’s “Boom!” orchestrates a baby-boom epiphany. It stages a virtual reunion of America’s Class of 1968, accompanied by a full spectrum of opinions about the impact of that pivotal year. Although he describes his role in this process as that of moderator and class president, there’s more to it than that. Mr. Brokaw serves as a latter-day Rip Van Winkle, awakening to marvel at four decades’ worth of changes in the book’s dozens of interviewees. He also takes on the perilous job of wondering what it all means.

headline: Timing of a Proposed M.T.A. Fare Increase Should Come as No Surprise
text: Officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have tried to frame their proposal for higher subway, bus and commuter rail fares as a departure from past increases. They say it should be seen as part of a long-term financial plan, with a fare increase next year to be followed by an increase in state and city subsidies down the road.

headline: The Loose Canon
text: THE New Yorker has announced plans to publish an unedited story by the late Raymond Carver. Since then, the estates of several other deceased writers have also expressed an interest in seeing manuscripts published in their original pre-edited form. Excerpts follow:

headline: Writers on the Picket Line Would Feel a Varying Pinch
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 — Unions typically consist of people with wallets of similar size. The paychecks of auto workers vary depending on seniority and job title but not so much that some drive BMWs and others rusty old Plymouths.

headline: Wobbled by Wealth?
text: At just about every stop I’ve made so far on my book tour, what I’ve come to think of as The Question comes up. I talk about the origins of the long right-wing dominance of American politics, and the reasons I believe that dominance is coming to an end. Then someone asks, “How can you be optimistic about the prospects for progressive change, when big money has so much influence on politics?”

headline: U.S. Is Likely to Continue Aid to Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  The Bush administration signaled Sunday that it would probably keep billions of dollars flowing to Pakistan’s military, despite the detention of human rights advocates and leaders of the political opposition by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the country’s president.

headline: Radcliffe Shakes Off Rival
text: Four miles into yesterday’s New York City Marathon, Paula Radcliffe of England and Gete Wami of Ethiopia were clear of the field and running into the medical unknown.

headline: Going to Prague in 1968, but Not Without His Vinyl
text: Get out your handkerchiefs, if you please, for “Rock ’n’ Roll,” the triumphantly sentimental new play by Tom Stoppard.

headline: Legal Loopholes in Iraq
text: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice refers to the lack of legal accountability that allows mercenaries working for the American government to kill Iraqis without fear of prosecution as “a lacuna” in our law.

headline: Writers Begin Strike as Talks Break Off
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 — A strike by Hollywood writers began just after midnight Monday, as last-minute negotiations between screenwriters and producers to avert a walkout failed.

headline: Fatal Beating Unnerves University in Quiet Town
text: GLASSBORO, N.J., Nov. 1 — Donald Farrell did just about everything right. As Mr. Farrell, a 19-year-old Rowan University sophomore, walked to a convenience store the night of Saturday, Oct. 27, he had followed nearly all of the precautions given to the college’s students about staying safe. He was traveling in a group. It was about 9 p.m., so he was not out particularly late. And he moved along busy roads in well-lighted areas.

headline: Linden: 2 Arrested in Officer’s Shooting
text: Two people have been arrested in connection with the shooting of a Linden police officer on Friday night, the police said yesterday. After being called to Speedy Check Cashing, on Routes 1 and 9, to investigate a report of a fraudulent check at about 6 p.m. on Friday, Officer Dave Manganiello was shot once in the chest at close range. Officer Manganiello’s bullet-resistant vest stopped the round. He was treated at University Hospital in Newark and released. A suspect, Leonardo Grullon, 34, has been charged with attempted murder in connection with the shooting. A woman who came to police headquarters to check on Mr. Grullon, Brenda Hernandez, 35, of Elizabeth, was also arrested, the police said. She has been charged with hindering apprehension and theft by deception, the police said.

headline: 50 New York Schools Fail Under New Rating System
text: Under a blunt new A through F rating system, whose results Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled today, 50 public schools across New York City, most in Manhattan and the Bronx, have been designated failures, placing them in danger of closing as early as the end of the school year and putting their principals’ jobs on the line.

headline: In Mexico, Residents Contend With a Flooded City
text: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico, Nov. 4 — Williams García paddled a kayak Sunday over the waters that covered much of Villahermosa, the flooded capital of the state of Tabasco, searching for news of his family.

headline: Accounts and People
text: Accounts

headline: A Guilty Plea in Film Skulduggery
text: A 37-year-old man has pleaded guilty to two felony charges in connection with the theft of computers and photographs with confidential material related to “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,” Steven Spielberg’s forthcoming installment of the adventures of that intrepid archaeologist, The Associated Press reported. The man, Roderick Davis, of Cerritos, Calif., will serve two years and four months in a state prison in a plea deal. He admitted to receiving stolen property and committing commercial burglary. He was arrested on Oct. 4 in West Hollywood in a sting operation by detectives, who learned that some of the stolen material connected to the film, starring Harrison Ford, Cate Blanchett and Shia LaBeouf, was being offered for sale to entertainment gossip Web sites.

headline: Treasure Hunt Begins After Runners Leave
text: They came at dawn, from far and wide, gathering at the western end of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and waiting anxiously for the start of the New York City Marathon. But when the traditional cannon blast signaled the start of one of the world’s biggest footraces, they stayed put.

headline: Egg Industry Comes Out of Its Old-Media Shell
text: A campaign is seeking to break through the clutter with the unusual sight of humans, rather than chicks, breaking out of eggs.

headline: Redskins’ Game Plan Kept Portis on His Feet
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 4  In Shaun Ellis’s eight seasons as a defensive lineman for the Jets, he has seen a lot of unfathomable things unfold on a football field. But he has never seen a team run with as much ease as the Washington Redskins did against the Jets on Sunday.

headline: Lel Defeats Goumri Again
text: When the last of their competitors had fallen away and the course tucked into Central Park, Martin Lel of Kenya and Abderrahim Goumri of Morocco turned the New York City Marathon into Part 2 of a battle they began in the London Marathon last April.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Tut Faces His Public

headline: At NBC, the Brand Becomes a Slogan
text: As a color and a concept, green will be unavoidable across NBC Universal’s media properties this week, as network logos turn green, on-screen graphics offer tips for reducing carbon emissions and television episodes emphasize environmentally friendly plot lines.

headline: Turning 50 With Wit and Youthful Vigor to Spare (So Who Needs Gimmicks?)
text: SEATTLE, Nov. 3 — The Pacific Northwest Ballet’s new quadruple bill, “Contemporary Classics,” features one ballet that relies entirely on the use of ropes (Susan Marshall’s “Kiss”). Another depends wholly on spotlights and strobe lighting (David Parsons’ “Caught”). A third work makes a greatly diminished effect if performed without billowing clouds of vapor from dry ice (Twyla Tharp’s “In the Upper Room”). Though McCaw Hall here is not the best place for dry ice, and though the last two pieces were performed to taped music, these devices all helped the pieces win big applause.

headline: The Latest in Job Cuts: Automated Poker Without Dealers
text: FOLSOM, Calif. — Most card rooms and casinos in Northern California offer live poker the old-fashioned way: with dealers doling out cards and players tossing chips into the center of a table.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC INDICATORS The main economic news will come from a report on the trade deficit for September (Friday).

headline: Lottery Numbers
2,000-Year-Old Christian Community in Iraq Gains a Spiritual First in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 4 — There is neither a cross nor a sign on the heavy metal gate to indicate that this is the official residence of one of the country’s most prominent Christians, the first in Iraq in modern times to be elevated to cardinal by the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Showing Who’s No. 1, Patriots Deal Colts Loss No. 1
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 4 — This time, the New England Patriots could not run up the score, could not embarrass the Indianapolis Colts, an opponent that was finally their equal. But that was the only unfamiliar part of the ritual for the Patriots on Sunday.

headline: A Weekly in New Brunswick Prevails Against Local Family
text: A weekly newspaper publisher who challenged the Irvings, the most powerful family in the Canadian province of New Brunswick and the province’s predominant newspaper owner, has prevailed in court.

headline: Small Plane Crashes Into a São Paulo Neighborhood, Killing Six
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 4 (Reuters) — At least six people were killed when a small plane crashed into a residential district of São Paulo just after taking off on Sunday, officials said, in the latest accident in Brazil’s crisis-ridden air system.

headline: Next Hurdle for Ford and U.A.W. Will Be Selling Contract Proposal
text: DETROIT, Nov. 4 — Over the next few weeks, Ford Motor and the United Automobile Workers union each are faced with the challenge of selling their tentative contract as the best they could get in light of Ford’s decline.

headline: Planes, No Trains, Automobiles, and Plenty of Hockey Mixed In
text: Steve Williamson, a Tampa Bay Lightning fan from Orlando, Fla., is storming through the N.H.L. He began a journey last month that will take him to a game at each of the league’s 30 arenas in 30 consecutive days.

headline: Edwards Raises Criticism of Clinton Over Iraq Plan
text: IOWA CITY, Nov. 4 — As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton collected the endorsement today from former Vice President Walter Mondale, one of her Democratic rivals intensified his criticism of her candidacy, saying she had not been forthcoming with voters who will open the nominating contest here in less than two months.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Matt Biscuiti, vice president at the New York office of the Lippin Group, was promoted to senior vice president.

headline: Tut Faces His Public
text: The face that launched a thousand trips to museums was revealed yesterday for the first time in more than 3,000 years when the blackened, leathery mummified remains of the Egyptian boy king Tutankhamen were freed from their linen burial windings, Agence France-Press reported. “The face of the golden pharaoh is amazing,” said Zahi Hawass, above center, secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities in Cairo, adding, “It has magic; it has mystery; it has beauty; and his buck teeth are similar to the rest of his family’s.” The occasion was the removal of the pharaoh’s mummy from its ornate stone sarcophagus, discovered in 1922, to a nearby climate-controlled case where experts say it will be better preserved. “Putting the mummy in this case will make the golden king live forever,” Mr. Hawass said. Each day, hundreds of visitors file through his tomb in the Valley of the Kings at Luxor, carrying with them bacteria, humidity and pollutants. “The mummy risked being reduced to dust because of the rising levels of humidity due to the visitors,” Mr. Hawass said. Rejecting a popular theory that Tut died of a blow to the neck at 19, Egyptian, Swiss and Italian experts have deduced that he did die at 19, after a 10-year reign, but that the cause was an injury to his left leg, which then turned gangrenous. When Tut’s tomb was discovered, his embalmed body was encased in three sarcophagi, one of them solid gold, and his face lay beneath a 24-pound solid-gold burial mask encrusted with lapis lazuli and other semiprecious stones. The latest in the popular King Tut exhibitions is to open in London this month and will return to the United States next year.

headline: Bankers’ Lesson From Mortgage Mess: Sell, Don’t Hold
text: Bankers on Wall Street frequently describe themselves as being in the moving and not the storage business. They make money by trading stocks and bonds, not by owning them.

headline: PetroChina May Become Top Company
text: HONG KONG, Nov. 4 — When the government-owned oil and gas giant PetroChina makes its debut Monday on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, China’s booming stock markets will be on the verge of setting another milestone. Soon after the Shanghai listing, some analysts expect PetroChina to surpass Exxon Mobil as the world’s largest company by market capitalization.

headline: Screenwriters Take to Picket Lines as Strike Begins
text: Screenwriters moved to the picket lines this morning, as last-minute negotiations between the writers’ unions and producers failed to avert a strike over payments from producers for so-called new media, among other issues.

headline: A Tongue That’s Tough to Tame
text: Ever since Michael R. Bloomberg entered politics, he has worked hard to control his impolitic tendencies.

headline: Still No Giuliani TV Ads, but He’s Ready for the Web
text: It is a question that both Democratic and Republican strategists have been asking often: When is Rudolph W. Giuliani going to start advertising his presidential candidacy on television?

headline: Protesting Demeaning Images in Media
text: Wearing white T-shirts with red stop signs and chanting “BET does not reflect me, MTV does not reflect me,” protesters have been gathering every Saturday outside the homes of Viacom executives in Washington and New York City. The orderly, mostly black crowds are protesting music videos that they say degrade women, and black and Latino men.

headline: Hunt for Cholesterol Drug Is Not Over
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 5 — Drugs to raise so-called good cholesterol may still have a future despite the widely publicized failure last year of an experimental cholesterol treatment from Pfizer, researchers said at a heart conference here.

headline: Bush Urges Pakistani Leader to Hold Elections
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 — President Bush urged President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan today to hold elections and give up his army post “as soon as possible,” but he gave no indication that General Musharraf’s decision to impose emergency rule would bring about any significant change in American policy.

headline: The Higher Value of Eyeballs
text: The Higher Value of Eyeballs

headline: Support for Replay Has Its Limits
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: Group Spotlights Jews Who Left Arab Lands
text: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 2 — With assertions of the rights of Palestinians to reclaim land in Israel expected to arise at an planned Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md., a Jewish advocacy group has scheduled a meeting in New York on Monday to call attention to people it terms “forgotten refugees.”

headline: Stocks Decline on Citigroup News
text: Stock markets declined today as financial companies stumbled in the aftermath of the shake-up at Citigroup.

headline: Chaos, Calm and Humor in Irish Composer’s Work
text: Ireland has produced a remarkable number of popular rock and pop acts in recent years, but few of the country’s classical composers have achieved such international prominence. The Web site of the Contemporary Music Center in Dublin (cmc.ie) lists an impressive number of active Irish composers, among them Gerald Barry, whose music was spotlighted at the Miller Theater on Friday.

headline: In Defense of Voting Rights
text: A House Judiciary subcommittee was the site of a sad spectacle the other day: John Tanner, who heads the Justice Department’s voting section, trying to explain offensive, bigoted comments he made about minority voters. It was a shameful moment that crystallized the need for immediate steps to fight for the rights that Mr. Tanner has been working so hard to undermine.

headline: Lies? What Else Is New?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Movies, TVs and Magazines Work Together in Web Campaign
text: THIS month, the Turner Classic Movies cable network is presenting the movie choices of 30 “guest programmers” like Alec Baldwin, Martha Stewart, Donald Trump, Gore Vidal and even Kermit the Frog.

headline: Citigroup Names Rubin as Chairman and Plans More Write-Downs
text: The board of Citigroup today accepted the resignation of its embattled chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, and appointed Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, as its chairman, according to a person briefed on the situation.

headline: A Lilly Drug Logs Success and Risks in Heart Trial
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 4 — An experimental anticlotting drug from Eli Lilly reduced heart attacks in patients with heart disease by 24 percent compared with Plavix, the current standard treatment, according to a report released Sunday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: Staten Island: Man Is Fatally Stabbed
text: A Staten Island man has been charged with fatally stabbing another man during an argument on Saturday morning, the police said. The suspect, Saverio Fabozzi, 25, of Arthur Kill Road, was charged with second-degree murder and assault, the police said. Mr. Fabozzi is accused of fatally stabbing Joseph Flagg, 26, during an argument about 3 a.m. on Excelsior Avenue, the police said. The police said Mr. Fabozzi also stabbed a 21-year-old man, whose name was not released and who was in stable condition at Staten Island University Hospital.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day last Monday, about online travel agencies, misidentified the location of LeisureLogix, a technology company that has introduced a personalized search service for travelers. It is based in Tampa, Fla., not Southlake, Tex. The column also misstated, in one reference, the name of the search service on the Travelocity Web site. As the column noted, it is the Road Trip Wizard  not the Road Trip Warrior.

headline: Never Too Young to Give, or Take,  Advice
text: At 25, Ramit Sethi seemed to have figured out what so many of my peers (pushing 40 and older) are still struggling with — how to get to the career you want without first putting in a whole lot of time doing something you don’t enjoy.

headline: Crashes and Traffic Jams in Military Test of Robotic Vehicles
text: VICTORVILLE, Calif., Nov. 4 — A Pentagon-sponsored robot race at a former Air Force base here on Saturday revealed that computer-controlled vehicles, at least to date, have failings that are all too human.

headline: Let’s Heal Our Ailing Health System
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Media, New Value, Old Troubles
text: In the hierarchy of things the American public seems not to care about — the national debt, Paris Hilton’s charitable works, Fred D. Thompson’s campaign for president — the Hollywood screenwriters’ strike probably wins hands down.

headline: ‘What’s More, He Has Hog Warts’
text: Excerpts from “Weekend Update” on NBC’s “Saturday Night Live”:

headline: Obama Night Live
text: “Saturday Night Live.” which has relentlessly mocked Hillary Clinton, let her rival Senator Barack Obama join the skewering in a sketch portraying her as a witch. Read more here and here. And watch the video:

headline: Office Challenge
text: A time-waster that’s all over the web — for example, here, here and here.

headline: Look Ma, No Hands!
text: Calling all funny caption writers: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above. It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’ve been posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines here. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: AOL to Buy Israeli Start-Up, Report Says
text: Time Warner‘s AOL unit plans to pay $300 million for an Israeli advertising start-up, Quigo, in a move to compete better with Google and Yahoo, an Israeli newspaper report said.

headline: Qatari Fund Withdraws Sainsbury Offer
text: The British supermarkets group J Sainsbury will remain independent after the Qatari-based investment fund Delta Two on Monday abandoned its 10.6 billion pound bid ($22.1 billion).

headline: Deal for Canadian Shoe Retailer Collapses
text: The sole remaining Canadian retail business in the Bata shoe empire has quietly slipped into bankruptcy protection after a deal with a would-be buyer, Michael Gold, fell apart over a tax dispute.

headline: W2 Scores $30 Million, With More to Come
text: W2 Group, a three-year-old holding company that’s been building a business in digital marketing, said on Friday it had received a $30 million cash infusion from Monitor Clipper Partners with a total commitment of more than $100 million.

headline: MedQuist Mulls Sale Amid Investor Discontent
text: MedQuist, a provider of medical transcription services, is considering a sale of the company after a majority stockholder, Royal Philips Electronics, said Friday that it wanted to sell its 70 percent stake in the company.

headline: The Law of Unintended Consequences?
text: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act, enacted in mid-2002 in the wake of the accounting scandals at Enron and WorldComwas intended to improve the accuracy and reliability of corporate financial disclosures.

headline: An Overhyped Role in Overheated Art Markets?
text: When the credit bubble popped this summer, many believed that the art bubble would burst as well. It was feared that as hedge fund managers felt the pain, so too would the auction houses.

headline: Blackstone Teams With ChemChina in Nufarm Bid
text: The Blackstone Group has teamed up with China National Chemical and the private equity firm Fox Paine to bid up to $3 billion Australian dollars ($2.75 billion) on Monday for Australia’s Nufarm, a deal that would create the world’s largest generic farm chemicals firm.

headline: PetroChina Skyrockets in Debut
text: PetroChina, the state oil and gas giant, became the world’s first company to pass $1 trillion in market capitalization when it debuted on the Shanghai Stock Exchange on Monday.

headline: Is Bad News for Merrill Good News for Investors?
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s investigation into possible conflicts of interest among advisers to pension funds has been going on so long – two years – that it’s practically fallen off the radar screen. But last week, the investigation cropped up again, big time, when Merrill Lynch advised 100 of its pension fund clients in Florida that the S.E.C. has taken issue with its practices as a consultant.

headline: CIBC Sells Part of U.S. Capital Markets Business
text: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said on Sunday it would sell a major part of its capital markets business in the United States to Oppenheimer Holdings as it focuses on its core operations. The businesses to be acquired by Oppenheimer employ more than people, or about half of CIBC’s employees in the United States, and had annualized revenue of about $400 million, Oppenheimer said.

headline: Filing Is Seen as Signal of Buyout Plan for A.I.G.
text: Is Maurice R. Greenberg planning to make a run on his former firm?

headline: Black’s Warhols Go on the Block
text: Conrad Black, the former media mogul convicted this summer of corporate fraud and obstruction of justice, is back in the news. That is because two Warhol paintings he owns will be auctioned by Christie’s, each with a selling price estimated at $150,000 to $200,000. The first auction is Nov. 14.

headline: Singapore Sets Out to Lure Hedge Funds
text: Singapore, striving to become the Switzerland of Asia, is gung-ho on hedge funds, The Deal.com reports. Leading the charge is the Singapore government, which has crafted regulations that both streamline the process for establishing funds and give fund managers some juicy tax breaks when they’re up and running. It’s now possible to open a fund in just weeks.

headline: SAC May Balk at ITT’s Edo Bid
text: The activist hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors served notice late Thursday that it might be dissatisfied with ITT‘s deal to acquire the defense contractor Edo for $1.5 billion.

headline: Yucaipa Plans Bid for Twinkies Bakery
text: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters on Friday joined forces with Ronald Burkle’s Yucaipa and Bimbo Bakeries USA and have a plan for Yucaipa to buy the bankrupt Interstate Bakeries, which makes Wonder Bread and Twinkies.

headline: Neutral Tandem Raises $78.6 Million Despite Choppy Market
text: Executives at Neutral Tandem may have been having some second thoughts on Thursday, when the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 362 points. The last thing that a company going public wants is a down market.

headline: The Young and the Not So Restless
text: This week, my column, “Never Too Young to Give, or Take, Advice,” focuses on some career mavericks — a cadre of 20-somethings (and one not even 20), who have just entered the work force yet have found a way to lead others.

headline: Congress Set to Override Water Bill Veto
text: Congress is poised to enact legislation over the objections of President Bush for the first time in his tenure.

headline: Kraft Close to $2.8 Billion Deal to Sell Post Cereals, Report Says
text: Kraft Foods is a few weeks away from announcing to a deal to sell its Post cereals business to store-brand food maker, Ralcorp Holdings, for about $2.8 billion, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Why are Oil Majors so Keen on Renewable Energy?
text: Just when will oil run out, creating economic and social panic, and putting an end to decades of prosperity based on the plentifulness of petroleum? The answer seems to be “soon,” according to a documentary called “A Crude Awakening,” which I saw this weekend in London before it officially opens in cinemas in London Nov. 9. (The film has already been released in Canada, Switzerland, Australia and New Zealand, and is showing on cable television in the U.S. It will be playing at the Guangzhou International Documentary Film Festival, China, at the beginning of December, according to a Web site promoting the film.)

headline: As Citi Chief Totters, Bartiromo Is Having a Great Year
text: The big story on CNBC all day Monday will undoubtedly be the fallout from the resignation of Charles O. Prince III as chairman of Citigroup – and Maria Bartiromo, one of the best-known names in business news on television, will surely be among the reporters covering it.

headline: Foster Children at Risk, and a Breach of Faith
text: Twenty years ago, New York City embarked on an experiment aimed at better protecting its most vulnerable black and Latino children. At its heart, the effort involved creating and supporting foster care agencies that would, at long last, be run by men and women of color. The Times spent months examining this ambitious, billion-dollar investment in minority-run agencies – what once seemed a bold and overdue shift in one of the most challenging areas of social policy. It found a trail of scandals and disappointments, as well as a new commitment to better caring for the city’s vulnerable black and Latino children. “Breach of Faith,” by Leslie Kaufman, the first in a series of three articles, appears today on the front page. Readers are invited to post their comments here. (See an and a at one foster care provider.)

headline: The Early Word: The X Factor
text: Here’s a theme that has lasted for nearly a week:

headline: Skadden: The Law Firm Behind Private Equity I.P.O.’s
text: Much has been made of the private equity and hedge fund industry’s move to tap public markets while maintaining their relatively low-level tax structures. Bills in Congress to increase taxes on the industries have pitted Democrats against Republicans, while buyout shops and hedge fund managers have been coughing up cash to lobby against any such efforts.

headline: As Icahn Looms, BEA In Race to Restate
text: BEA Systems is under the gun to get its financial restatements in order before its largest shareholder, Carl C. Icahn, calls an annual shareholders meeting.

headline: Where Did the Buck Stop at Merrill?
text: On Oct. 24, Merrill Lynch announced its biggest write-down ever, an $8.4 billion charge that also represents the biggest known loss in Wall Street history. Six days later, its chief executive, E. Stanley O’Neal, retired from the company he had run since 2002.

headline: Bankers’ Lesson From Mortgage Mess: Sell, Don’t Hold
text: Bankers on Wall Street frequently describe themselves as being in the moving and not the storage business. They make money by trading stocks and bonds, not by owning them.

headline: Too Much Meddling When C.E.O.’s Go a-Courtin’?
text: Asking another corporation for its hand in marriage is always a delicate affair. But does a chief executive need to bring the directors along as chaperones? Does a merger-hungry C.E.O need his or her parents’ blessing before making a proposal?

headline: Rubin’s Big Test: Fixing Citigroup
text: Throughout a long, public career, Robert E. Rubin spanned the highest reaches of Wall Street and Washington, and succeeded wherever he went. Now he may be facing his most difficult challenge – helping to revive Citigroup, which said yesterday that it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down related to subprime mortgages, on top of the $5.9 billion reported in early October.

headline: Hostile Reactions to CIBC’s Citi Report
text: CIBC’s Meredith Whitney is a $15 billion woman, after her negative report on Citigroup last week drove the firm’s shares down 7 percent and perhaps hastened Charles Prince’s departure. But not everyone was happy with her report (which she discussed with The New York Times here).

headline: The Case for Real Food
text: Is there more to a carrot than beta carotene? Is lycopene the best we get from tomatoes? And when we heap our plates with salmon, are we serving up something other than omega-3s?

headline: Merrill Is Said to Favor Fink as New C.E.O.
text: Laurence D. Fink may be closer to taking the reins at Merrill Lynch. The securities firm’s board of directors has told Mr. Fink, the chairman of BlackRock, that the top spot is his should he want it, CNBC reported citing unnamed sources.

headline: Pooh-poohing health care problems
text: People have asked me what I think of Greg Mankiw’s piece in The Times. I’ll outsource the criticism to Mark Thoma, Brad DeLong and Dean Baker.

headline: The Thin Red Line
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Greening of the Gridiron
text: Well, we all thought the big news in pro football would be yestereday’s much anticipated Colts-Patriots tilt or rookie running back Adrian Peterson’s record-setting day, but it seems the gridiron is taking on a new shade of green. Chris Mottram, the irreverant Mr. Irrelevant comments on the news: “The massive market of hippie football fans is about to get their heads blown: NBC is going “green” all week. And it kicks off with Sunday Night Football.”

headline: Barry Diller’s Big Breakup
text: IAC/InterActiveCorp, the media-and-Internet conglomerate cobbled together by Barry Diller, said Monday that it plans to carve itself up into five companies. The spinoffs seemed to signal a retreat for Mr. Diller, a media magnate who was the Unites States’s most highly paid chief executive in 2005.

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.The Independent

headline: Nouvelle Chimie
text: Chefs are learning from the lab how to fry mayonnaise, congeal coconut milk and perform other culinary chemistry experiments

headline: Morning Papers: Strike Update, Maria Bartiromo, ‘Family Guy’ Composers
text: — “Under the eye of a federal mediator, Hollywood’s writers and producers resumed talks toward a new contract Sunday as a midnight strike deadline drew near,” Michael Cieply reports from Los Angeles. “As of late afternoon here, there was no sign of a breakthrough.”

headline: Egg Spot 2
text: Spots by the American Egg Board's longtime agency, Grey in New York, play up the benefits of eating eggs, primarily their protein content.

headline: Egg Spot 1
text: Spots by the American Egg Board's longtime agency, Grey in New York, play up the benefits of eating eggs, primarily their protein content.

headline: Money, Fats and Science
text: During the trans-fat debate here, readers criticized me for quoting the American Council on Science and Health, arguing that it wasn’t a credible source and that I should have pointed out it receives donations from corporations. Some accused it of not doing peer-reviewed research and getting most of its money from corporations, and said they’d trust the Harvard School of Public Health over ACSH any day.

headline: Newsweek on Bloomberg, the ‘Billion Dollar Wild Card’
text: In a 6,962-word cover article in the issue of Newsweek that hits the newsstands today, the magazine’s editor, Jon Meacham, takes an in-depth look at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and assesses the chances that he might run for president. Mr. Meacham was given considerable access to the mayor, in interviews at Gracie Mansion, in Seattle and aboard the mayor’s personal jet.

headline: Monday Morning Kickoff
text: After Saturday’s debacle against Kansas, John Henderson of the Denver Post writes that Nebraska “must fire head coach Bill Callahan and defensive coordinator Kevin Cosgrove, like, five minutes ago.” Meanwhile, Steven M. Sipple of the Lincoln Journal Star lists four reasons why he thinks Callahan will be out of a job soon.

headline: Thompson in New Hampshire
text: BEDFORD, N.H., — Fred Thompson has heard the grumbling from New Hampshire voters that he hasn’t spent enough time in the state, and he has responded with promises to visit the state “early and often.”

headline: A ‘Hidden Oasis’ in Las Vegas’s Water Waste
text: There’s a back to the land movement of sorts around Las Vegas these days, driven by the desert city’s growing realization that the only reason it can exist — the sapphire, but shrinking, expanse of Lake Mead 30 miles away — is not as durable as the Hoover Dam that created the reservoir 70 years ago.

headline: Who’s Watching Over Citi?
text: The turmoil at Citigroup has left the banking giant without a permanent leader. It has also put all eyes on the company’s board of directors, a group that includes some of corporate America’s heaviest hitters.

headline: ‘No Money, No Funny!’
text: The above was one of the chants at Rockefeller Center today as Hollywood writers went on strike — a reminder that many on the picket line on New York work in late-night comedy. But even the quality of the chants left some disenchanted. Still, nothing could be done. The writers, after all, are on strike. Said one half of a pair of married scribes: “I was telling my husband that we need some new and better chants, but he reminded me: ‘No writing. None.’ ” Read more …

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: Formula One: After months of speculation that Fernando Alonso would leave McLaren before his three-year contract was up, the team made it official.

headline: In Pakistan, a Fight to Stay Connected on the Web
text: Considering the signals and rumors that have swirled for months, including a particularly intense day in August, it would seem that both the Pakistani government and the political opposition have had time to anticipate and prepare for the emergency-rule decree issued on Saturday by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of the country.

headline: Then We Came to the End
text: Hello, one and all. So we have come to the end of this great novel — this huge vision of life. A brief review of Volume IV: The Russian army withstands Napoleon’s onslaught and does not so much defeat him as outlast him. The French army decomposes, soldiers flee en mass or limp away, taunted by the ragged people who collectively “saved Europe.”

headline: The Debate Over Cellphone Jamming
text: In October, Bruce Schneier, a prominent computer security expert, made note on his blog about the growing use of jammers. He received nearly a hundred comments on the debate, many encouraging jamming.

headline: Barry Diller and the Fallacy of IAC
text: Barry Diller’s decision, announced today, to split IAC/InterActiveCorp into five parts says a lot about Mr. Diller’s restlessness. But it also shows the flaws in the strategy that he has been trying to pursue for a decade: building an Internet conglomerate.

headline: 2008 Already Settled? Not by a Long Shot
text: In his Web column today, Adam Nagourney writes that “For all the indisputable Democratic advantages, strategists in both parties say it is too early to hand the White House keys over to the Democratic Party.”

headline: The Feast After the Finish
text: I only half noticed the first person who walked stiffly, with something of a limp, by my friends and me at Primehouse New York last night.

headline: Images From the Picket Lines
As IAC Splits, Who Gets the Gehry?
text: In breaking up IAC/InterActiveCorp, Barry Diller is taking a step many thought he should have taken a long time ago. Many analysts and investors have derided the 12-year-old conglomerate as a jumble of companies, jerry-built by Mr. Diller’s voracious wheeling and dealing.

headline: Writers’ Strike Begins; Negotiations Break Down; Silver Lining For Networks?
text: “A strike by Hollywood writers began just after midnight Monday, as last-minute negotiations between screenwriters and producers to avert a walkout failed,” Michael Cieply writes in The New York Times.

headline: Why Economists Don't Vote
text: Why you should vote, if you really feel like it.

headline: Waterboarding the Wiseguys?
text: “The Republican debate over torture has become a debate over resumes, as John McCain warns from personal experience about the dangers of harsh questioning and Rudy Giuliani takes credit for his skill with it as a prosecutor,” reports Boston Globe:

headline: Bush’s Niece Endorses Plastic Bag Recycling
text: A City Council bill that would require supermarkets and other large retail stores to collect, transport and recycle the plastic carryout bags they give to customers received an endorsement today from an unusual source: Lauren Bush, a fashion model and a niece of President Bush.

headline: Bracing for Citi’s Next Surprise
text: Just how many shoes does Citi have?

headline: ‘Today’ at the Ends of the Earth
text: Ann Curry, the news anchor for NBC’s “Today” show, donned a red parka and sunglasses early this morning and prepared for a highly unusual live shot.

headline:
Memo to Self:
Don’t Throw Novel in Fire
text: Here’s a short film from David Wain, made in 1997, that stars himself and Amanda Peet.

headline: At Real Hospitals, Less Trauma…and Drama
text: Medical shows have long been a staple of prime time television. But how well do they reflect what really happens at the hospital?

headline: Do the New School Ratings Match Your Experience?
text: Under a blunt new A through F rating system, whose results Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled today, 50 public schools across New York City, most in Manhattan and the Bronx, have been designated failures, placing them in danger of closing as early as the end of the school year and putting their principals’ jobs on the line. Elissa Gootman and Jennifer Medina of The Times explain how the new rating system works and what it means for students, parents and educators. To find the data for your school, consult this graphic, which lists, for each school, the letter grade, the overall score and scores for school environment, student performance, student progress and additional variables.

headline: Eric Schmidt’s GPhone Dance
text: “Where’s my Gphone?”

headline: Oprah Winfrey Addresses Abuse Charges at School
text: Oprah Winfrey is blamed for a lot of things, from ruining the marathon to expanding the popular lexicon. It’s mostly light-hearted stuff that comes with the biggest paycheck in television. But today she addressed the world on a much more serious matter.

headline: Arena Is Out as Red Bulls Coach
text: Bruce Arena’s tenure with the New York Red Bulls ended today, almost 16 months after his appointment as coach and sporting director began with much fanfare and expectation.

headline: Colbert Ends White House Bid
text: It’s over. So says Stephen Colbert, who has just issued his first formal statement in response to the decision by South Carolina Democrats last week to deny him a spot on the presidential primary ballot.

headline: Citi Rewrites Recent History on Earnings
text: Citigroup‘s chief executive isn’t the only thing that changed over the weekend. The bank’s third-quarter earnings, which it reported in the middle of last month, suddenly shifted as well. Downshifted, that is.

headline: Rhode Island Juveniles, Caught in Limbo
text: Rhode Island attracted a national spotlight recently when it repealed a disastrous, four-month-old law under which 17 year-old offenders were automatically tried as adults.

headline: The Quiet Hedge Fund I.P.O.
text: Scanning the headlines on Monday reveals a blizzard of articles on Citigroup, IAC/InterActiveCorp and PetroChina. Decidedly less obvious is the fact that another hedge fund has gone public in the United States — even though it rang the opening bell Monday morning.

headline: Who Cares About Terrorists Attacking Chemical Plants?
text: Terrorism experts agree that one of the most serious terrorist threats is an attack on a chemical plant. A chemical cloud released from such an attack could put hundreds of thousands of lives at risk.

headline: Election Day Finds Few Hotly Contested Races
text: Tuesday is Election Day, but there are very few contested races around the city. Most of the elections are for various judgeships: Civil Court, State Supreme Court and — in Brooklyn and Staten Island — the Surrogate Court.

headline: 'Vanessa'
text: A video excerpt from the new production of Samuel Barber's opera at New York City Opera.

headline: One Other Little Dance
text: On the Google conference call, a reporter asked about another potential reason that Google may want to soft-pedal a possible GPhone: Eric Schmidt serves on Apple’s board of directors.

headline: Romney Lands Big Endorsement
text: Mitt Romney has landed a much-coveted endorsement from the social conservative world: Paul Weyrich, chairman of the Free Congress Foundation and one of the founders back in the day of the Moral Majority.

headline: Zen and the Art of Dumpster Diving
text: The middle word in the environmental mantra “reduce, reuse, recycle” may have a deeper and more ancient root than some realize.

headline: Giuliani Praises Former Police Commissioner
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani offered praise on Monday for his disgraced former police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik. Mr. Giuliani told The Associated Press that Mr. Kerik’s achievements outweigh his mistakes, and added that “if I have the same degree of success and failure as president of the United States, this country will be in great shape.”

headline: Yolk of the Day
text: It’s a live-or-fry situation for these eggs (vegans, discretion advised):Eggs – Funny bloopers R us

headline: It Came From Chicago, and It’s Not Puffy
text: CB2, Crate and Barrel’s sprightlier Gen Y offspring, is scheduled to open its 8,000-square foot SoHo store on Tuesday (next to the Muji Store!), as part of the gentretail-ification of the Broadway stretch north of Canal. The eagerly anticipated store, located at 451 Broadway, is the first CB2 outside of the Chicago area (and third over all). For years, this City Room reporter has been obsessed with CB2, once even making a trip to Chicago, in part to see the two CB2 stores there.

headline: Parsons to Step Down as Time Warner C.E.O. Next January
text: Richard D. Parsons is about to have a lot of time on his hands.

headline: Obama Questions Petraeus
text: Barack Obama was one of five presidential candidates that questioned Gen. David E. Petraeus. (Video From MSNBC)

headline: Obama on the Trail
text: Senator Barack Obama delivered his proposal on Iraq to a crowd in Clinton, Iowa, on Wednesday.

headline: More Images From The Picket Lines
text: The New York Times reports: “The real-life version of picketing in Hollywood, it turns out, bears little resemblance to the rowdy, angry way the industry typically depicts it.”

headline: A Truffle Heist in Northern Italy
text: Those who covet white truffles — the elusive treasure that has grown rarer still this year — seem to have few choices these days. Either shell out more cash, with an extreme case being the purchase of a single truffle for $7,000 last month. Or downgrade to lesser quality truffles, or worse, truffle oil.

headline: Pimp Your Ride? Drain Your Checkbook
text: LAS VEGAS — Mounting an iPod in the center of your steering wheel may seem like a convenient place to put it. But in the event of a hard frontal impact, one of two things is likely to happen: 1. Your air bag might not work anymore; 2. Your air bag will go ahead and deploy, but the front of your skull will thereafter have an iPod embedded in it, instead of a face. In either scenario, the outcome would not be pretty.

headline: Edwards on Iran, Pakistan
text: IOWA CITY, Iowa – In a speech today, John Edwards proposed a five-point plan for how to deal with Iran, saying the United States needs to avoid a “preventive” war strategy and instead employ diplomatic and economic measures to capitalize on what he calls the Iranian people’s readiness for change.

headline: Brian Williams Draws a Crowd to ‘SNL’
text: What was potentially the last new “Saturday Night Live” for a while was also the highest-rated “Saturday Night Live” in a while, NBC said yesterday.

headline: Curing Insomnia Without the Pills
text: Better sleep doesn’t have to come in a pill.

headline: CBS Captures Sunday Night
text: The twelfth edition of “The Amazing Race” got underway to solid ratings on Sunday as CBS garnered the night’s most viewers overall. The network led its competitors by a significant margin going into prime time thanks to an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. A highly anticipated match-up of undefeated teams, the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts, delivered more than 32 million viewers in its final half-hour, according to Nielsen’s preliminary estimates.

headline: Clinton Invokes Gore on the Trail
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa – Al Gore wasn’t by Hillary Rodham Clinton’s side as she delivered a speech on energy efficiency here this morning, but he was here in spirit: Mrs. Clinton mentioned her old rival a few times in her remarks, hailing his Nobel Peace Prize victory and embracing some of his ideas on the environment.

headline: Modeling the falling dollar
text: Some models of a plunging dollar look like this.

headline: Grim Days for Talk Show Guests
text: Writers, producers and viewers aren’t the only groups to be affected by the Writers Guild of America’s strike. The authors, musicians and entertainers who rely on television talk shows to promote their products and projects are also feeling the strike’s effects, as their guest spots get postponed or canceled.

headline: Analysis: BEA’s Comedy of Deal Errors
text: BEA Systems may have rebuffed Oracle‘s $17 a share bid. But through a series of negotiating mistakes, it may have unwittingly put itself in a box.

headline: The GPhone: So Open It Could Be Closed
text: Eric Schmidt’s conference call about Google’s new cell phone operating system was exactly the opposite of a showy Steve Jobs keynote.

headline: The Marathoner Wore Heels
text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: Sophia’s Bathroom
text: Having decided — as we did last week — that we would have only two bathrooms upstairs instead of the three, as our builder Johnny (strongly) suggested, we still had to figure out a couple of things about the second bathroom:

headline: Conserved Woods and Wetlands, Where Orphans Once Romped
text: For about a century, Mount Loretto, on the southeast coast of Staten Island overlooking the Raritan Bay, was a haven for homeless and disabled orphans. The Rev. John Christopher Drumgoole, himself an Irish immigrant, founded the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin in 1871 to help care for Irish children who had lived on Manhattan’s streets after the Irish potato famine and the Civil War. The mission moved to Staten Island in 1883 and continued, for decades, to provide vocational training and religious instruction for its charges.

headline: Who Trusts This Dividend?
text: Why pay a dividend if investors think you can’t afford it?

headline: A Plea to Open Up Campus Campaign Stops
text: A 2004 Bush-Cheney campaign stop at Allegheny College left some students and faculty peeved at the college’s event policy. Dick Cheney spoke at a ticketed on-campus event that was open to only G.O.P. supporters and 40 Allegheny students who gained entry through the student organization, College Republicans.

headline: Guy Fawkes Day Helps Raise Millions for Paul
text: Updated | 11:58 p.m. Historians and British schoolchildren remember Guy Fawkes as the Roman Catholic, anti-Protestant rebel who on Nov. 5, 1605, tried to assassinate King James I by blowing up the Parliament. Supporters of the Republican primary campaign of the libertarian Representative Ron Paul may remember Fawkes as a wildly successful fund-raising gimmick.

headline: Romney Gets a Conservative Blessing
text: While his name might not rank up there with Novak and Nagourney, or Broder and Brownstein, David Brody of the Christian news outfit CBN continues to bring in big stories about campaign ‘08, or at least from the far-right side of campaign ’08. “We’ve found out that Paul Weyrich, the former co-founder of The Moral Majority has endorsed Mitt Romney for President,” Brody informs us. “If you know anything about the conservative movement in this country in the last 30 years or so, you know how big a deal this is … His claim to fame is that he was one of the co-founders of the Moral Majority.”

headline: Daniel Cassidy on Slang
text: Mr. Cassidy, a native New Yorker, discusses the similarities between English slang and elements of Gaelic, which his family spoke.

headline: Checking In on Radiohead’s Experiment
text: “Way to go Radiohead!” was the first of many excited comments on news last month that Radiohead was letting its customers set the price of its new album. Industry observers were just as excited, heralding a game-changing moment. But what happened afterwards?

headline: Rising Up in New Orleans, the Post-Storm House
text: New Orleans has always been known for its eclectic housing styles. Now emerging is what could be called a posthurricane vernacular.

headline: Award Winning Design
text: The Salt House (Photo: Cristobal Palma)

headline: Generals Agree: Waterboarding Is Torture
text: President Bush’s nominee for Attorney General, Michael Mukasey, has had trouble deciding that waterboarding — a method of interrogation that is designed to make a prisoner believe that he is drowning — is torture.

headline: Q&A: Home Fires
text: The five writers of Home Fires are inviting questions from readers this week. If you’d like to submit a question, please leave it as a comment on this post. A selection of questions and answers will be published online next week.

headline: She’ll Be Comin’ Round the Mountain
text: When Oprah Winfrey comes to Digital Town, you’d better believe the big-name Shriners come out with a welcome wagon — and a marching band and some giant weird pumpkins.

headline: Barry Diller Asks and Google Answers With Cash
text: Barry Diller does have a nose for deals. He’s usually not real early on a trend, but he’s not that late either. Take Ask Jeeves, which his company, IAC/InterActiveCorp bought in 2005 for $1.85 billion.

headline: Human, All Too Human
text: This weekend, as I wrapped up my rereading of “War and Peace,” I moved on to the book that will be discussed tonight in my book club — a group I formed 7 years ago, to help ensure that, what with all the editing, research, and reviewing I did in my working life, I did not lose the habit of reading for pleasure. (The same sentiment applies to all the women in my group, though some of us are not editors or writers.) A handful of books made me love reading: “Jane Eyre,” “David Copperfield,” “Pride and Prejudice,” “The Red and the Black,” “A House for Mr. Biswas,” “The Brothers Karamazov,” “The Heart of the Matter,” “Père Goriot,” everything by P.G. Wodehouse, and yes, “War and Peace.” We have read several of those in book club, not “War and Peace” however. (We’ve noticed that books longer than 400 pages tend to defeat our best intentions.)

headline: Picketing Writer Struck By Car Outside Paramount
text: The mood was somber outside the stately wrought-iron gates of Paramount in Los Angeles on the first day of the Writers’ Guild of America strike, where a driver entering the gates struck and slightly injured a picketing writer, according to Bernard Lechowick, who works on the CBS soap opera “The Young and the Restless.”

headline: Fans Still Line Up For Non-Scripted Shows
text: The tension at Television City, a Los Angeles complex that houses CBS headquarters and soundstages for “Dancing with the Stars” and “American Idol,” was palpable on Monday as about 120 striking writers marched next to people lining up to get tickets to the afternoon taping of “Dancing with the Stars,” whose writers are not covered under the Writers’ Guild of America.

headline: Pencils Down, Picket Signs Up
text: The Times's David Carr interviews members of the Writers Guild of America East who are on strike and picketing in front of New York's Rockefeller Center.

headline: Tools for the Chronically Obnoxious
text: Matt Richtel got quite a debate going over the use of cell phone jammers.

headline: Economy Catching Up as an Issue
text: The Iraq war looms large, but a recent ABC News/Washington Post poll finds increasing concern about the economy.

headline: Le Mars, Iowa? Perhaps It’s the Ice Cream
text: Ever been to Le Mars, Iowa? Senators Joseph R. Biden Jr., John McCain and Barack Obama have, as have John Edwards, Mike Huckabee and Mitt Romney.

headline: The ‘Saturday Night Live’ Primary
text: Senator Barack Obama’s cameo on “Saturday Night Live,” jesting at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s expense, raised the question of who is winning the Lorne Michaels primary. Neither Democrat, finance reports show.

headline: No, It’s Not Déjà Vu; It’s Real
text: The television writers’ strike could affect the presidential campaign in one way. It promises to wipe out the part of the echo chamber that is late night comedy.

headline: Bred in the Bone
text: A new coffee-table-format book, "Evolution," demonstrates that skeletons provide evidence for the history of life both hard and beautiful.

headline: Iowa Dinner for 9,000
text: The Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner is a Democratic tradition throughout the nation. But rarely is it as celebrated as it is in Iowa in the year before a presidential election. The dinner honors Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson and helps raise money for state and local Democratic Parties. In Iowa, it showcases the candidates in advance of the first caucuses, on Jan. 3.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Mideast Peace
text:
Heather Hurlburt, of Democracy Arsenal, and David Frum, of the National Review, on whether the Annapolis conference has a chance of success.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Happy Returns for the Jets
text: Jets fans have at least one thing to be happy about.

headline: The Mystery of Buyer’s Remorse — Or, Should You Look for a Money-Back Guarantee?
text: At a gathering of social psychologists earlier this year in Memphis, I was surprised to hear one of them say mournfully, “You know, we haven’t really come up with a solid concept since cognitive dissonance.” What made this surprising was that it’s been a half century since cognitive dissonance was identified.

headline: Neglected Samuel Barber Opera Sees the Light Again
text: Once in a while an opera company presents a new production that prompts a re-evaluation of a misunderstood work. That’s what happened on Sunday when New York City Opera unveiled its staging of Samuel Barber’s “Vanessa.”

headline: As Floods Ebb in South, Mexico Tends to Displaced
text: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico, Nov. 5 — Residents of the state of Tabasco woke up Monday to find that the swollen rivers that had flooded much of the state had begun to subside. But there were plentiful signs that the worst may not be over.

headline: The Pakistan Mess
text: By imposing martial law, Gen. Pervez Musharraf has pushed nuclear-armed Pakistan further along a perilous course and underscored the failure of President Bush’s policy toward a key ally in the war on terrorism. The events should not have come as a surprise to administration officials. This is what you get when policy is centered slavishly on a single, autocratic ruler rather than more broadly on his country.

headline: No More Bench Strength
text: In corporate America, it may be time to retire the phrase “heir apparent.”

headline: Rethinking What Caused the Last Mass Extinction
text: FREEHOLD, N.J. — Splashing through a shallow creek in suburban New Jersey, the paleontologists stepped back 65 million years to the time of the last mass extinction, the one notable for the demise of the dinosaurs.

headline: With Brothel Plans Delayed, a Madam Does Laundry
text: PAHRUMP, Nev. — Sex is the commodity that Heidi Fleiss says she knows best, but for now she is settling for fabric softener.

headline: Nomination of Mukasey Sent to Full Senate
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — The Senate Judiciary Committee this morning endorsed the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey to be attorney general, virtually assuring his confirmation by the full Senate.

headline: Rebuilding New Orleans, Post-Katrina Style
text: NEW ORLEANS — This city has always been known for its eclectic housing styles — Greek Revival, Italianate, Creole. Now emerging is what could be called a posthurricane vernacular, wide-ranging architectural responses to what everyone here refers to simply as the Storm.

headline: Britain: Bid for Sainsbury Ends
text: A Qatari investment fund, Delta Two, withdrew its £10.6 billion ($22 billion) bid to take control of the British supermarket chain J Sainsbury as a result of escalating borrowing costs, Delta Two said. The fund will still have a 25 percent stake in the British retailer, and the fund manager, Three Delta, expressed confidence in Sainsbury’s management, a sign it apparently intended to hold onto its stake. “The transaction would not be in the best interest of stakeholders,” Paul Taylor, a principal of Three Delta, said in a statement.

headline: Now They Know: Jimmy Slagle Played Here
text: WORTHVILLE, Pa. — In his day, Jimmy Slagle, a native of this speck of a town in northwestern Pennsylvania, was one of the best players on the most dominant team in major league baseball.

headline: Screenwriters on Strike Over Stake in New Media
text: This article was reported by Michael Cieply, David Carr and Brooks Barnes, and was written by Mr. Cieply.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,837 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Zelda Fitzgerald Novel Wins Goncourt Prize
text: A fictional autobiography of Zelda Fitzgerald, wife of F. Scott Fitzgerald, has won France’s highest literary award, the Prix Goncourt, Agence France-Presse reported. Written by a former journalist, Gilles Leroy, above left, the novel, “Alabama Song,” tells a tale of wild parties in the Roaring Twenties, Zelda’s relationship with her husband and her decades of struggle with mental illness. Another of France’s leading literary accolades, the Prix Renaudot, was awarded to Daniel Pennac, above right, for “Chagrin d’École” (“School Blues”), about his experiences as a self-professed class dunce. The prizes ushered in the season of French literary awards.

headline: House Votes to Override Bush’s Veto of Water Projects
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — The House voted 361 to 54 this evening to override President Bush’s veto of a $23 billion water projects bill, apparently sealing Mr. Bush’s first defeat in a veto showdown with Congress.

headline: Memo Pad
text: THE WORST YEAR Domestic airline performance through September of this year ranked as the worst for any comparable period in at least 12 years, the Transportation Department’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics reported yesterday. Through September, 73.18 percent of flights arrived on time this year, compared with 76.14 percent in the same period last year and the 12-year high, 82.82 percent in 2003. The worst 3 of the top 32 major airports through September of this year were all in the New York area: Newark Liberty (59.60 percent on time) LaGuardia (59.85 percent) and Kennedy (60.86 percent). The best three were Salt Lake City (80.31 percent), and Oakland (80.22 percent) and San Diego (78.95 percent) in California.

headline: More Acidic Seas Can Change Behavior of Anxious Sea Snails
text: Climate change may get the most publicity, but it’s not the only global phenomenon linked to rising levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Another is the gradual acidification of the oceans, as more of CO2 dissolves in seawater, creating carbonic acid and lowering the pH.

headline: Protector of Lake Loses Appeal in Chinese Court
text: BEIJING, Nov. 5 — A prominent Chinese environmental leader has lost his appeal of a three-year conviction on blackmail and fraud charges, according to his wife and his lawyer, even as the authorities promised to invest billions to clean up the lake he fought for years to protect.

headline: A Planetary System That Looks Familiar
text: They say there is no place like home, but it is beginning to look as if there is a place sort of like home 41 light-years from here in the constellation Cancer.

headline: A Little Mopey, a Tiny Bit Lah-Di-Dah and Always Earnestly Melodic
text: Band of Horses wasn’t far into its show at Terminal 5 on Sunday night when Benjamin Bridwell, the lead singer, made an observation about New York audiences: They aren’t as scary as they’re made out to be. Backhanded praise, to be sure, but Mr. Bridwell sounded appreciative and even a bit relieved, and got an encouraging cheer.

headline: Big Marathon Payday Becomes More Than a Dream
text: Gete Wami remembered the first time she earned prize money for running.

headline: Bond Buyers Are Losing Confidence
text: After a recuperative October, investors in the credit markets are starting to feel a familiar sense of dread.

headline: Sun Reports Modest Profit, but Revenue Disappoints Investors
text: Sun Microsystems posted a meager profit yesterday as it continued to benefit from its corporate restructuring and improved gross margins, but revenue disappointed investors who were hoping for a bigger start to the fiscal year.

headline: Lundqvist and Rangers Silence the Flyers
text: Until last night, the dynamics of a Henrik Lundqvist shutout had usually looked the same. The Rangers would not muster much offense and Lundqvist had to play every shot as if the game depended on it, because often, it did.

headline: Healing Hearts and, Possibly, Divisions in Guatemala
text: GUATEMALA CITY, Nov. 5 — Heart surgery might not appear to have much in common with politics, especially the bare-knuckle brand practiced in Guatemala. But this country’s newly elected vice president, a prominent cardiologist here and in Houston, has long dabbled in both worlds.

headline: To Coles, Sideline Is More Painful Than Any Hit
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 5 — An old friend phoned Jets receiver Laveranues Coles last week, and when he recognized the name and number, he let it pass to voice mail. He already knew what Wayne Chrebet was going to say.

headline: Athens Rally Defends Art Deco Building
text: Thousands of protesters demonstrated yesterday in Athens to prevent the demolition of an Art Deco building near a new museum on the Acropolis, Agence France-Presse reported. Neighborhood residents, supported by an international petition carrying 8,000 signatures, are appealing plans authorizing the destruction of the building that were approved this year by the Archaeology High Council and endorsed by the minister of culture. Officials of the new museum, scheduled to open next year at the foot of the Acropolis, say the Art Deco structure and another building, owned by the Greek composer Vangelis, obstruct the view from the museum’s restaurant. The neighborhood residents are also waiting for a ruling from the Ministry of Environment and Public Works. They are supported by the modern Greek architecture specialist François Loyer of the National Center for Scientific Research in France, who said in a letter to the Greek culture minister, Michalis Liapis, that the demolitions would be a major “error.” The 1930 Art Deco building was designed by Vassilis Kouremenos, who trained at the Beaux-Arts academy in Paris.

headline: A Detour From a Battle Against Terror
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 5 — While Gen. Pervez Musharraf justified his emergency rule decree as helping him combat terrorism, it could end up weakening his ability to rein in the Qaeda militants who ultimately threaten American interests.

headline: At Hearing on Child Neglect Petition, Doctor Testifies That Slain Husband Beat Her
text: A woman whose estranged husband was shot dead on a Queens playground last month cried in Queens Family Court yesterday as she testified about her broken marriage and the custody battle she and her spouse were waging over their 4-year-old daughter.

headline: Black Sea Republic Displays Traditions Fierce and Gentle
text: The Georgian State Dance Company belongs at Radio City Music Hall. But you can’t be too finicky when it comes to this group of dancers and musicians — even if that means traveling a bit off the dance world’s beaten path, to the Bronx. The company, formed in 1945, performed there on Sunday afternoon at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts.

headline: Bush Urges Musharraf to Reverse Course but Signals No Penalty if He Doesn’t
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 — President Bush on Monday urged Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, to hold elections and give up his army post “as soon as possible,” but gave no indication that the general’s imposition of emergency rule would bring about any significant change in American policy.

headline: Odes to an Ax Murderer From New England and a Singer From Hoboken
text: Gillian Murphy and Michele Wiles may be American Ballet Theater’s pre-eminent female technicians, the kind of dancers who shine particularly brightly in abstract works that are all about brilliant movement in space. Both were cast in the frazzling ballerina role in Balanchine’s pure-dance “Ballo Della Regina,” new to Ballet Theater this season. And both were less predictably cast as the Accused in Agnes de Mille’s “Fall River Legend,” the 1948 ballet based on the story of Lizzie Borden, tried in 1893 on charges of murdering her father and stepmother with an ax.

headline: Richard Tucker Night Is Opera’s All-Star Game
text: Big opera galas have much in common with sporting events: Fans gather to watch, and compare, feats of physical prowess. This parallel is always particularly clear at the annual gala of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, held this year on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Venezuelan General Likens Chávez’s Proposals for Constitution to a Coup
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 5 — In a sharp indictment of President Hugo Chávez’s proposed changes to the Constitution, the former top army commander here described the proposed charter on Monday as “in effect a coup d’état” intended to abolish checks on Mr. Chávez’s expanding power.

headline: Tuesday: Election Day
text: NEW YORK Polls in New York City and throughout the state are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. The New York Public Interest Research Group and Common Cause New York are running a nonpartisan voter help line. Voters can call (212) 868-3692 to locate a polling site, get advice on voting rights or report problems at the polls. Voters can also call the New York City Board of Elections toll-free at 1-866-VOTENYC (1-866-868-3692).

headline: In the Lab: Device Could Help Doctors and Smokers
text: If doctors want to know if their patients smoke, they can always just ask. But researchers say there may be a better way to determine a patient’s smoking status — and at the same time provide a powerful incentive to quit.

headline: IAC/InterActive to Split Into 5 Companies
text: Barry Diller finally decided yesterday to see if the parts of IAC/InterActiveCorp, his grab bag of Internet companies and services, are greater than the whole.

headline: Giuliani Says Successes Surpass Kerik’s Mistakes
text: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the crime-fighting successes of the disgraced former police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, outweighed his legal problems, and added that “if I have the same degree of success and failure as president of the United States, this country will be in great shape.”

headline: Giants Get Back to Work With Goal of Getting Back on Schedule
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 5  The Giants are one of the hottest teams in the N.F.L., having won six consecutive games. They are also one of the most rested, having not played since defeating the Miami Dolphins in London eight days ago.

headline: Faults Seen at Agency That Patrols U.S. Borders
text: Thousands of travelers who should have been barred from entering the country last year were allowed in by lax procedures of United States Customs and Border Protection officers, the Government Accountability Office reported yesterday.

headline: The Lowly Parking Garage With the Colorful Identity
text: I USUALLY take a commercial car service to and from the airport. I have been using the same service for 20 years, and it has never failed. Ask for a 4:30 a.m. pickup, and the driver is out front at 4:25 a.m.

headline: Girardi Will Be Filling Torre’s Shoes With a Bit of Showalter’s Style
text: Buck Showalter was watching television with some friends when he learned that Joe Girardi would succeed Joe Torre as manager of the Yankees. The reporter on the broadcast said that the intense Girardi might be more of a control freak than the focused Showalter, who preceded the laid-back Torre in the Bronx. Showalter was not flattered.

headline: The Garden and the Trains
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mary Lillian Ellison, 84, the  Fabulous Moolah, Is Dead
text: Mary Lillian Ellison, whose flying drop kicks, flying head scissors and hair-pulling “flying mare” body slams brought her renown as the professional wrestler the Fabulous Moolah, died Friday in Lexington, S.C., near her home in Columbia. She was 84.

headline: Flying and Blood Clots: A Deadly Risk
text: Life-threatening blood clots and flying have been linked for more than 50 years, but a new study of business travelers confirms the risk, particularly for those who take long flights or fly frequently.

headline: In Iowa Field, Edwards Sees Only Senator Clinton
text: IOWA CITY, Nov. 5  A few minutes before John Edwards delivered a forceful closing argument to the voters who will help determine the fate of his presidential ambitions, he called upon a gentleman seated near a window in the library in downtown Charles City.

headline: The Claim: Zinc Can Help You Beat a Cold
text: THE FACTS

headline: Sweden: Getinge Buys 2 Units
text: Getinge, the world’s largest maker of surgical workstations, agreed to buy two Boston Scientific Corporation units for $750 million to expand its tools for heart operations. The two divisions are a heart unit, which employs about 450 people at its headquarters in San Jose, Calif., and a factory in Dorado, Puerto Rico, and a vascular surgery unit, which employs 250 people in Wayne, N.J. Getinge, based in Stockholm, said it was cutting expenses and making purchases to become more profitable. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., said it was selling the units to reduce debt and focus on businesses with more growth potential.

headline: On Fur and Feather, Crittercams Turn 20 Seeking New Vistas
text: WASHINGTON — For photographers lacking training, experience and even the ability to click a shutter button, they produce remarkable pictures. Under the sea, deep in the woods and high in the sky, furry, feathery and leathery-skinned creatures are opening up vistas by taking cameras where no human can go.

headline: More Readers Trading Newspapers for Web Sites
text: THE circulation declines of American newspapers continued over the spring and summer, as sales across the industry fell almost 3 percent compared with the year before, according to figures released yesterday.

headline: Heart Surgery Drug Pulled From Market
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 — Pressured by regulators, the German pharmaceutical giant Bayer AG announced Monday that it had agreed to withdraw the controversial heart surgery drug Trasylol after a Canadian study suggested that it increased death rates.

headline: Before the Court: Are Munis Like Milk, or Garbage?
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  A case with the potential to unsettle the municipal bond market produced a lively Supreme Court argument on Monday, with no clear indication of whether justices would permit states to continue the widespread practice of exempting the interest on their bonds from state taxation while taxing the interest on bonds issued by other states.

headline: Pettitte Is Electing to Pause
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 5 — Brian Cashman received a call from Andy Pettitte on Monday, and the message Pettitte delivered was not the worst news Cashman had ever heard. But it was not what Cashman wanted to hear.

headline: Torre Gets a Sunny Welcome to Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5  Joe Torre, the Brooklyn boy who rooted for the Giants, smiled atop a blue-draped platform Monday in center field at Dodger Stadium, where he was extolled as the manager needed by a team that next season will celebrate its 50th anniversary of playing in Los Angeles.

headline: Food 2.0: Chefs as Chemists
text: In September, talking to an audience of chefs from around the world, Wylie Dufresne of WD-50 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan waxed enthusiastic about a type of ingredient he has been adding to his restaurant’s dishes.

headline: Google Enters the Wireless World
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 — What Apple began with its iPhone, Google is hoping to accelerate, with an ambitious plan to transform the software at the heart of cellphones.

headline: Citi Names Executive to Repair Mortgage Problems
text: Citigroup, reeling from its exposure to billions in assets backed by volatile home loans, has appointed a triage team led by one of Wall Street’s best-known fix-it men.

headline: Matisse Painting Auctioned for $33.6 Million
text: A Matisse painting depicting one of the artist’s favorite models fetched $33.6 million tonight at Christie’s, breaking the previous auction record for the artist in a lively kickoff to the fall auction season.

headline: At Time Warner, Successor to Parsons Emerges
text: After months of speculation, Time Warner announced yesterday that Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief operating officer, will succeed Richard D. Parsons as chief executive at the end of the year.

headline: New Jersey Ballot Asks Voters to Allow More Debt
text: TRENTON, Nov. 2 — At a groundbreaking for the Stem Cell Institute of New Jersey recently, Gov. Jon S. Corzine drove a spade into the dirt and declared the site the “nexus of cutting-edge scientific breakthroughs.”

headline: ‘Bad’ Legal Advice and the Death Penalty
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Eighteen years have passed since an Idaho murder defendant took his lawyer’s advice to reject the state’s offer of a guilty plea that would have resulted in a life sentence. The defendant, Maxwell Hoffman, went to trial instead, and was sentenced to death for participating in the murder of a government informer.

headline: Waning Support Led to Ouster of Citigroup Chief
text: As recently as last month, Charles O. Prince III could count on the support of Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, the biggest shareholder of Citigroup, the financial behemoth that Mr. Prince had run for four years.

headline: Spending Trumps Social Issues on Ballots This Time
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 — When it comes to the state and local ballot measures before voters across the country on Tuesday, it is mostly about the money.

headline: Shining Light on Diseases Often in the Shadows
text: When is a neglected disease no longer “neglected”?

headline: Portrait of the Broadway Theatergoer
text: The League of American Theaters and Producers released its 2006-7 demographic report yesterday, and the standout fact about Broadway theatergoers was that most are not from around these parts.
