Tourists accounted for 65 percent of Broadway ticket buyers, up from 57 percent last year. Almost 2 million of the 12 million Broadway ticket buyers were foreigners, up more than 44 percent from last year and an all-time high. At the same time, there has been a decline in local theatergoers. The number of ticket buyers from New York was at its lowest in seven seasons; the number of those from the New York suburbs declined for the eighth season. Thanks to shows like “The Color Purple,” “Chicago” and “The Lion King,” Broadway audiences are becoming a little less white — 26 percent of theatergoers were not white, a 56 percent increase from five years ago. Otherwise, much was the same as last season: the average age of the Broadway theatergoer was 41, and average household income was $98,900, both slight decreases from last year’s report.

headline: A Top Sicilian Mafia Boss Is Held, Italy Says
text: MILAN, Nov. 5 — One of the most powerful bosses in the Sicilian Mafia was arrested Monday, according to the Italian authorities.

headline: Bronx: Man Dies After Robbery
text: Six to eight men forced their way into a basement apartment on Glover Street early yesterday, attacked the two occupants and left them tied up after stealing an undetermined amount of cash, the police said. One occupant, 18, managed to free himself and called the police. When officers arrived, they found the other occupant, Antonio Castillo, 44, unconscious. He was taken to Westchester Square Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Living With Pain That Just Won't Go Away
text: Pain, especially pain that doesn’t quit, changes a person. And rarely for the better. The initial reaction to serious pain is usually fear (what is wrong with me, and is it curable?), but pain that fails to respond to treatment leads to anxiety, depression, anger and irritability.

headline: Watered-Down Mortgage Reform
text: What a difference a day makes. Just yesterday, this page praised the House Financial Services Committee for producing an exemplary bill, the Mortgage Reform and Antipredatory Lending Act of 2007, and urged its members to make only a few improvements before passing the measure. When they meet today, the committee chairman, Barney Frank, is prepared to offer an amendment that will make the weakest part of the bill even weaker.

headline: The Price of Sugar
text: To the Editor:

headline: Skeletons Flesh Out Life’s Past
text: About half a billion years ago, our ancestors were slender, jawless, fishlike creatures. Their backs were stiffened by a rod of cartilage, along which grew bony prongs. That smattering of bone was the forerunner of our vertebrae, and it gave us and all the other descendants of those ancient animals our name: the vertebrates. Vertebrates have evolved into tens of thousands of species dominating the ocean, land and sky. Much of their success is due to the many new forms their skeletons have taken. A new coffee-table-format book, “Evolution” (Seven Stories Press), offers hundreds of gorgeous photographs of those forms, as diverse as bats with fingers thinner than pipe cleaners and rhinos with skulls as stubborn as boulders.

headline: Water on Mars May Have Piled Up as Ice Near Equator
text: There is plenty of evidence that water once flowed on the surface of Mars, and other evidence that points to where some of that water is now: in layers of dirty ice deposits at the poles.

headline: The Power of Light
text: Q. Does reflected light also help plants grow, or does it have to be direct sunlight?

headline: New DVDs
text: ANIMATION

headline: 50 New York Schools Fail Under Rating System
text: Under a blunt new A through F rating system that judges schools not just on performance but also on progress, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg designated 50 New York City public schools as failures yesterday, saying they were so dismal that their 29,000 students would be allowed to transfer elsewhere.

headline: Facebook to Turn Users Into Endorsers
text: Facebook wants to turn every member into a spokesman for its advertisers. Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and chief executive of the superhot social network, today announced what the company calls “social ads.”

headline: Week's Notables
text: PLAYER In Asia, Aleksandar Duric, a 37-year-old striker born in Bosnia, has been called to Singapore’s national team for its World Cup qualifying match against Tajikistan on Friday. Duric, a naturalized citizen, is the leading scorer in Singapore’s top league with 37 goals this season.

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Say They Want Accord Soon
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Nov. 5 — Israeli and Palestinian officials hope to reach a comprehensive peace agreement before the end of President Bush’s term, Israeli, Palestinian and American officials said Monday.

headline: Critics Cite Red Tape in Rebuilding of Louisiana
text: NEW ORLEANS — If rebuilding anything in this storm-scarred place could possibly qualify as simple, surely it would be the administration building in City Park.

headline: Adding Color Untangles the Brain’s Gray Secrets
text: For an organ that has been scanned millions of times by experts using high-end imaging technology, the brain remains in large part a shrouded landscape, as lost in darkness as the ocean floor.

headline: Shares of Alibaba.com Climb on First Day of Trading
text: SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Nov. 6 — Shares of Alibaba.com, one of China’s biggest Internet companies, soared in early trading on Tuesday in this country’s latest hot initial public stock offering.

headline: Hope After Failure of New Cholesterol Drug
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 5 — Drugs to raise so-called good cholesterol may still have a future despite the widely publicized failure last year of an experimental cholesterol treatment from Pfizer, researchers said Monday at a heart conference here.

headline: Part of Door Frame Dismantled in Search for Clues to Slaying
text: Investigators removed part of a door frame yesterday from the Fifth Avenue apartment where a celebrity real estate broker was bludgeoned to death last week, a law enforcement official said.

headline: Clinton Energy Plan Includes Push for Higher Gas Mileage
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 5 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday released her plan to combat climate change and to increase energy efficiency, which includes raising fuel standards to 55 miles per gallon by 2030 and creating five million jobs through renewable energy advancements.

headline: How Long to Wait for Salmon Before Casting Again? Sometimes, It’s All Winter
text: McNAMEE, New Brunswick  To the list of life’s great mysteries  the primacy of the chicken or the egg, who shot J.F.K., why there is an s in the word “lisp”  I would add one more: how long should an angler wait to cast again to an Atlantic salmon that has come up for, but not taken, a fly?

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Oct. 14 about Angola’s persistent poverty despite its financial windfall from rising oil prices misstated, in some editions, the country’s daily oil production. It is 1.5 million barrels, not 2 billion. (Go to Article)

headline: Army’s Aggressive Surgeon Is Too Aggressive for Some
text: SAN ANTONIO — Since the war in Iraq began, Col. John Holcomb has been working to change the way the military takes care of its wounded.

headline: Mayor Calls Detective Hero but Adds to the Confusion
text: After a week of intense criticism, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg retreated yesterday from previous remarks and said a retired police detective who died at age 34 after working hundreds of hours at ground zero was indeed a hero.

headline: More on the Career of the Genius Who Boldly Compared Himself to God
text: Talking about his own highly eclectic, highly protean style, Picasso once said to his mistress Françoise Gilot: “Of course if you note all the different shapes, sizes and colors of models he works from, you can understand his confusion. He doesn’t know what he wants. No wonder his style is so ambiguous. It’s like God’s. God is really only another artist. He invented the giraffe, the elephant and the cat. He has no real style. He just keeps on trying other things. The same with this sculptor. First he works from nature; then he tries abstraction. Finally he winds up lying around caressing his models.”

headline: It’s Fall in New York, and Cabs Are in Bloom
text: In the early-morning darkness, parked yellow taxis lined West 29th Street. Pungent curries scented the chilly air. For the drivers, it was a chance to grab some chicken korma, use a bathroom, relax for a few minutes or pray. For members of Garden in Transit, it was a ripe opportunity to apply decal sheets of whimsical flowers on the hoods, tops and trunks of the cabs.

headline: Democrats Reject G.O.P. Bid for More Iraq Spending
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — House and Senate negotiators approved a $459 billion military spending bill today, but rejected a Republican bid to provide $70 billion more to continue fighting the war in Iraq without any restrictions.

headline: Dell to Acquire Storage Company for $1.4 Billion
text: Dell said yesterday that it would acquire EqualLogic for $1.4 billion in a move to claim a larger share of the data storage market.

headline: A Few Words of Thanks for a Support System
text: Gratitude first: Thank God for answered prayer.

headline: Morocco Angry at Royal Visit to Enclaves
text: MADRID, Nov. 5 — Spain moved to soothe diplomatic tensions with Morocco on Monday as the Spanish king and queen began a visit to two territories on the coast of North Africa that both countries claim.

headline: Competitively Priced Electricity Costs More, Studies Show
text: Retail electricity prices have risen much more in states that adopted competitive pricing than in those that have retained traditional rates set by the government, new studies based on years of price reports show.

headline: A Pointless Slap at Transit Workers
text: For three days at the height of the December 2005 holiday season, New York City transit workers engaged in an illegal strike that stranded everyone who was dependent on subways and buses. It was maddening, dangerous and bad for the economy, and the union was punished for it. Now the city wants to keep the bad feelings alive by denying the union the right to collect dues through an automatic checkoff. Rather than continue the acrimony, the city should try to help usher in more peaceful labor-management relations.

headline: Texas: Options Considered in Land Sale
text: The Texas land commissioner, Jerry Patterson, said he hoped to award a state-owned wildlife preserve near Big Bend National Park to one of two private bidders today, but give the National Park Service 90 days to meet or exceed the winning bid. The ideas of selling the preserve, the Christmas Mountains Ranch, to a private buyer and allowing hunting on it have drawn controversy. Both bids would allow hunting, and the National Park Service can seek Congressional authority to allow guns on the land, Mr. Patterson said. The 9,270-acre tract was given to the state in 1991.

headline: Last Defendant Is Guilty in Attack on a Gay Man
text: In a case that has drawn intense scrutiny to the legal meaning of hatred, the last of four young men charged with selecting a gay man as a robbery target and chasing him to his death in traffic pleaded guilty yesterday to manslaughter and attempted robbery as hate crimes.

headline: Russia: Nursing Home Fire Kills 31
text: At least 31 people died Sunday in a fire at a nursing home in the Tula region south of Moscow. The center did not have an alarm that could notify firefighters. The fire was the latest in a string of blazes in Russia that have caused many deaths and underscored patterns of negligence and poor governance. Fire officials told official Russian news agencies that the nursing home had failed a fire inspection but managed to remain open, and that once the fire broke out the firefighters were not notified for at least 30 minutes.

headline: Doing Away With Far and Away
text: I REMEMBER standing in line at the post office in Florence in 1982, waiting with my parents to get into a phone booth to call the United States.

headline: Obama and Iran
text: To the Editors:

headline: Dog Eats Humble Pie
text: Duane Chapman, the embattled star of the hit A&E series “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” will appear on the Fox News Channel program “Hannity and Colmes” tonight to talk about the racially charged comments he made in a private phone conversation. Mr. Chapman, who is also scheduled to appear on Larry King’s CNN program tomorrow night, has been apologizing publicly for the comments, which include extensive use of racial epithets. A&E removed the show as soon as a tape of the conversation was made public by The National Enquirer, which paid Mr. Chapman’s son for it. Several advertisers had said they would pull commercials from the show. A&E also announced that it was shutting down “for the foreseeable future” production on the start of 13 new episodes of the series, scheduled to broadcast in January. But Michael Feeney, a spokesman, said that the show, the most successful series on the cable channel over the past five years, had not been canceled. He added: “We are taking a very proactive approach. This is a serious matter.”

headline: Mental Abilities: Gene Found to Play Role in Benefits of Breast Milk
text: For decades, experts have debated why children raised on breast milk tend to score higher on I.Q. tests. Was it something in the milk?

headline: Present at the Creation
text: Amman, Jordan

headline: Court-Martial to Open in Killings of 3 Iraqis
text: An Army sniper team leader charged with murdering three men south of Baghdad will go on trial today in Baghdad in a court-martial that is likely to highlight a classified Pentagon program in which snipers placed fake weapons as “bait” to attract and kill enemy fighters.

headline: Aging: Flip Side to Education Is Seen in Dementia
text: People with more years of schooling appear to suffer the symptoms of dementia later than others who have it — but once it does come, it proceeds more quickly, researchers say.

headline: A Switch From Beer to Holiday Cheer
text: AT 10:45 p.m. on Saturday, Justin Olsen stood behind the bar at the Gowanus Yacht Club, a seasonal outdoor beer garden on Smith Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and made an announcement. “The last keg of the year has been tapped,” he said. And with that, the countdown began to the finale of one of the last remnants of summer in New York — even though the calendar says it is fall.

headline: Manhattan: Education Campaign for Workers
text: The New York City Central Labor Council plans to begin a campaign today to educate construction workers, truck drivers and other workers in the city to make sure they are not classified as independent contractors instead of as employees. Misclassification often saves employers money while depriving workers of unemployment insurance and workers’ compensation protections, the labor council said. The council plans to have dozens of union members distribute leaflets. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has asked state agencies to crack down on misclassification.

headline: Spending Is Focus of Nation’s Ballot Measures
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 — When it comes to the state and local ballot measures before voters across the country on Tuesday, it is mostly about the money.

headline: Iraqi Police Academy Remains Largely Unusable
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 5 — More than a year after the Parsons Corporation, the American contracting giant, promised Congress that it would fix the disastrous plumbing and shoddy construction in barracks the company built at the Baghdad police academy, the ceilings are still stained with excrement, parts of the structures are crumbling and sections of the buildings are unusable because the toilets are filthy and nonfunctioning.

headline: For Clues on Teenage Sex, Experts Look to Hip-Hop
text: Hip-hop, with its suggestive lyrics, videos and dance moves, has long been criticized by public health experts and parents, who fear that it leads to risky sexual behavior among teenagers.

headline: Pakistan Attempts to Crush Protests by Lawyers
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 5 — Angry protests by thousands of lawyers in Lahore and other cities on Monday demonstrated the first organized resistance to the emergency rule imposed by the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. But the abrupt arrests of many of them threatened to weaken their challenge.

headline: Ford Warns of New Steps if Sales Decline
text: DEARBORN, Mich., Nov. 5 — Even as the Ford Motor Company’s 54,000 hourly workers prepare to vote on their new contract, the automaker is warning that it may have to adjust its corporate restructuring plan if industry sales continue to slide.

headline: Nor Can British Imperial Customs, Caesar, Stale Her Infinite Variety
text: CHICAGO, Nov. 3 — We live in an especially fertile time for inventive reimaginings of operas by Handel, the greatest stage composer of the Baroque era. Even so, a production of “Giulio Cesare” that was given its American premiere by the Lyric Opera of Chicago on Friday night stands out for sheer audacity.

headline: They Look Like Shoes, but Give Her Wings
text: Roxie Stamps, 58, is accustomed to toil. It is idleness that is harder to endure.

headline: PetroChina Shares Triple in Debut
text: HONG KONG, Nov. 5 — Superheated markets in China drove the value of PetroChina, the state oil and gas company, above $1 trillion today, giving it the highest market capitalization in corporate history and underscoring worries about a fast-growing stock bubble on the mainland.

headline: Hillary’s Tough Sell
text: The U.S. is in the midst of the most important presidential election campaign since World War II, and if there has ever been a time when women voters had the opportunity to decisively affect the nation’s future, it’s now.

headline: Footnotes
text: Daniel Radcliffe, the star of the Harry Potter films, confirmed that he would make his Broadway debut next year in Peter Shaffer’s “Equus,” the critically acclaimed revival in which he starred in London this year. The show is expected to open in September.

headline: Perceptions: Conductors’ Ears and Eyes Seem to Stay Equally Alert
text: To concentrate on a difficult task that involves listening, people tend to unconsciously divert their attention from what they are seeing. But music conductors, a new study reports, are not as apt to be distracted in this way.

headline: When Your Cellphone Is in My Space
text: To the Editor:

headline: Queens: Man Denies Killing Daughter
text: A Queens man accused of killing his 13-month-old daughter pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday in Queens Criminal Court. The man, Peter O’Keeffe, 35, who is charged with second-degree murder, was ordered held without bail. Judge Alex J. Zigman also ordered that Mr. O’Keeffe be placed in protective custody and on suicide watch. Prosecutors said that Mr. O’Keeffe beat the girl, Jessica, while baby-sitting on Saturday afternoon because she would not stop crying, and then ran from his house on 117th Street in South Ozone Park and fled to Philadelphia. The baby’s mother found her when she returned home, prosecutors said. Mr. O’Keeffe returned and surrendered to the authorities. His lawyer, Michael V. Cibella, said Mr. O’Keeffe worked as an accountant and bookkeeper for a printing company.

headline: Led by Troubled Banks, Shares Slide
text: Shares of financial companies stumbled yesterday in the aftermath of the shake-up at Citigroup, sending the stock markets down and leaving investors on edge about further troubles in the credit market.

headline: Trading Arcana for Haydn
text: Marc-André Hamelin has built a devoted audience by performing difficult piano music, both recent and arcane, demonstrating a solid, often dazzling technique, as well as a thoughtful musicality that reveals the poetry within the virtuosic glare. At his recital on Sunday afternoon at the Rose Theater, he did something different. Leaving his more peculiar specialties aside, he played a program of familiar works, starting with a crisply articulated, if slightly puzzling, account of Haydn’s Sonata in B minor (Hob. XVI: 32).

headline: Publication to Cease for House & Garden
text: House & Garden, one of the nation’s oldest magazines, will close after the abrupt departure of its publisher and years of losses for its parent, Condé Nast Publications, the company said yesterday.

headline: Alibaba Shares Nearly Triple in Debut
text: SHANGHAI, Nov. 6 — Shares of Alibaba.com, China’s biggest electronic commerce company, nearly tripled today in a spectacular opening day of trading, creating an Internet giant and one of the world’s wealthiest technology companies.

headline: In Such a Rich Land, a Health Care Disgrace
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Corona, Please, and Don’t Hold the Lime
text: Moonshine is the kind of cozy, lived-in Brooklyn bar that allowed customers to bring dogs inside and meat for the grill outside, both of which, it would come to learn, are against New York City health department regulations. But no one foresaw one violation uncovered during a recent surprise inspection of the Red Hook tavern.

headline: Bail for Dorm Matron at Winfrey Academy
text: A former dormitory matron accused of abusing students at Oprah Winfrey’s Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa was freed on $458 bail yesterday and left the Sebokeng magistrate court, south of Johannesburg, with a blanket over her head, Reuters reported. The court postponed the case involving the woman, Virginia Mokgobo, 27, to allow further investigation of charges, including assault, indecent assault and soliciting under-age girls to perform indecent acts. When the charges were read, Ms. Mokgobo, who was not asked to enter a formal plea, said she was innocent, The Associated Press reported. The court postponed the case until Dec. 13 to allow time for additional investigations. At a video news conference from Chicago yesterday, Ms. Winfrey, above, said she was “cleaning house” at the $40 million academy, which opened in January. Calling the scandal one of the most devastating experiences in her life, she said she had not renewed the contract of the headmistress and was removing the dormitory supervisors.

headline: It’s Familiar but Just a Little Different
text: It was déjà vu all over again, but with a subtle shift. When the pianist Murray Perahia performed at Avery Fisher Hall seven months ago, his program included Bach’s Partita No. 3 (BWV 827), Beethoven’s two Opus 14 Sonatas, Chopin’s Ballade No. 4 and works by Schumann. When he returned to New York on Saturday evening, this time for a recital at Carnegie Hall, he played Bach’s Partita No. 4 (BWV 828), Beethoven’s Opus 15 Sonata, Chopin’s Ballade No. 3 and works by Schumann’s protégé Brahms. It seemed almost as if Mr. Perahia were making his way through a few repertory cycles in slow motion.

headline: Telling the Stories Behind the Abortions
text: Dr. Susan Wicklund took her first step toward the front line of the abortion wars when she was in her early 20s, a high school graduate with a few community college credits, working dead-end jobs.

headline: Gates Questions China on Military Growth
text: BEIJING, Nov. 5 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates looked directly on Monday into two of the most striking facets of modern China.

headline: A Mentor Turns on His Protégé at Citigroup
text: As recently as last month, Charles O. Prince III could count on the support of Prince Alwaleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, who is the biggest shareholder of Citigroup, the financial behemoth that Mr. Prince had run for four years.

headline: Australia: Bid for Chemical Maker
text: The China National Chemical Corporation, backed by the Blackstone Group, agreed to pay 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) in cash for Nufarm of Australia to form the world’s largest supplier of generic farm chemicals. The offer by China National values Nufarm at 17.55 Australian dollars a share, 27 percent higher than its closing price on Oct. 30, Nufarm said. The price includes the payment of a 30-cents-a-share dividend by Nufarm, it said. Buying Nufarm gives China National entry to the $36 billion global market for herbicides and pesticides as a worldwide agricultural boom spurs acquisitions.

headline: Palestinians Clash in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 5 — Palestinian security forces clashed with militiamen affiliated with the party of the Palestinian president in the West Bank city of Nablus on Monday, days after the Palestinian Authority sent in a reinforcement of 300 police officers by agreement with Israel.

headline: British Intelligence Chief Sharpens Terrorism Warning
text: LONDON, Nov. 5 — Britain’s chief domestic intelligence official said Monday that at least 2,000 people in Britain posed a “direct threat to national security and public safety” because of their support for terrorism, an increase of 400 in the last year.

headline: The Red Bulls and Arena Part Ways
text: Bruce Arena, the man the Red Bulls were desperate to hire as coach but who failed to take the club beyond the first round of the M.L.S. playoffs, is leaving the team after 15 months in charge.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about the professional successes of Maria Bartiromo, a business journalist for CNBC, misstated the surname of Citigroup’s senior vice chairman, with whom she recently conducted a prominent interview. He is William R. Rhodes  not Rose. The article also misspelled the name of a sovereign investment fund that Ms. Bartiromo said she found exciting. It is Qatar Associates  not Cutter.

headline: Romney Gets Major Backer on the Right
text: Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign announced yesterday an endorsement from the man whom some consider the father of the religious right, Paul M. Weyrich, chairman of the Free Congress Foundation and a founder of the Moral Majority.

headline: EADS Warns It Will Take a Hit From Delayed Military Plane
text: PARIS, Nov. 5 — The parent of Airbus, European Aeronautic Defense and Space, warned Monday that delays of up to a year for its latest multibillion-dollar military transport aircraft program would reduce third-quarter earnings by as much as $2 billion.

headline: Honoring the Hands of a Pianist and a Survivor
text: Neither index finger works anymore, not a good thing for a woman whose life is devoted to the piano. Then again, those fingers are more than 103 years old. At that age, some parts are bound to give out.

headline: City Slow to Act as Hope for Foster Children Fails
text: Taken as a young child from her drug-abusing mother, the girl had lived in one foster home after another. Now, at 16, she saw the day approaching when she would become an adult and be sent off to make a life on her own.

headline: Candidate’s Pleased to Remember This Fifth of November
text: Historians and British schoolchildren remember Guy Fawkes as the Roman Catholic, anti-Protestant rebel who on Nov. 5, 1605, tried to assassinate King James I by blowing up the Parliament. Supporters of the Republican primary campaign of the libertarian Representative Ron Paul may remember Fawkes as a wildly successful fund-raising gimmick.

headline: A Midseason Injection of Star Power and Momentum
text: The Chicago Fire is the hottest team in Major League Soccer, Coach Juan Carlos Osorio is the maestro of the month, and the provocative Cuauhtémoc Blanco is the spider spinning an unavoidable web.

headline: White House to Offer Own Plan on Product Safety
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 — The Bush administration on Tuesday will propose a significant expansion of the authority of the federal drug and consumer product safety agencies to inspect and certify imports, White House and other administration officials said Monday.

headline: Gaza’s Reflection in a Foul Threat
text: UMM AL NASSER, Gaza, Oct. 30 — Fahmi al-Abrak, 70, was at home on March 27 when a lagoon of human waste broke through its sand embankment and hurtled downhill, inundating this poor village of Bedouins in northern Gaza. “It rose to here in 15 seconds,” he said, pointing to a discolored line on the walls, four feet above ground.

headline: General Managers Can Have Short Shelf Life
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: The Land of the Big Sky and the Deep Inner Void
text: The man who is about to die would like you to know that even though he is being portrayed by an actor, his feelings are real. Normally, people in plays do not feel it’s necessary to assert this.

headline: Sarkozy Whirling Into Washington
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — The French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, arrived in Washington today for his first official visit to the White House since becoming president.

headline: A Role Thomas Relishes and Needs
text: While evaluating his prize acquisition Zach Randolph and, by extension, the Knicks in their narrow victory over Minnesota on Sunday night, Isiah Thomas seemed to have a new pet phrase.

headline: Those Smutty, Nutty Kids With Heart, Treading the Boards in Merry Olde Italy
text: A jolly group of itinerant actors sing of themselves in “The Glorious Ones,” a new musical about the roistering life of the clowns who paved the streets of 16th-century Italy with sight gags and sex jokes. With buoyant music by Stephen Flaherty and a bawdy book and lyrics by Lynn Ahrens, the show mixes the lowdown pratfalls of commedia dell’arte with the rosy sentimentality of classic American musical comedy. It encourages sniggers in one scene, as we watch the players perform classic comic sketches on a scrappy wooden stage, and sympathy in the next, when we sneak behind the scenes to lend an ear to their hopes, fears and heartaches.

headline: Macao: Ex-Official Goes on Trial
text: Ao Man-long, the former transport and public works minister, went on trial, accused of taking $100 million in kickbacks from developers. Macao, a former Portuguese colony that is now a special administrative region of China, has overtaken Las Vegas in gambling revenues after a frenzy of casino construction.

headline: 500 Million Years Ago, Jellyfish Left Their Mark in Fine Sea Sediments
text: Your average jellyfish washed up on a beach is hardly recognizable — just an amorphous blob, fast decomposing in the sun. (They don’t call them jellyfish for nothing.)

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Portrait of the Broadway Theatergoer

headline: Dubious Fees Hit Borrowers in Foreclosures
text: As record numbers of homeowners default on their mortgages, questionable practices among lenders are coming to light in bankruptcy courts, leading some legal specialists to contend that companies instigating foreclosures may be taking advantage of imperiled borrowers.

headline: Staten Island: 16 Sickened by Chemical Fumes
text: Firefighters removed residents from a section of the Richmond Terrace Houses yesterday after three City Housing Authority workers were overcome by fumes from a cleaning chemical just after 1 p.m., the police said. The Fire Department said that 16 people, including five firefighters, were treated at Richmond University Medical Center in the afternoon. One person was in critical condition, two were in serious condition and the rest were treated for minor injuries. The Fire Department said the workers had used hydrated lime, a cleaning chemical, in an enclosed space.

headline: Knicks and Nuggets Say the Melee Has Been Forgotten
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 5 — The competency gap between the Knicks and the Denver Nuggets last year was so great that a mid-December game begot a rout, and the rout begot a brawl. Suspensions, fines and name-calling followed in short order.

headline: A Vote for Justice
text: Washington

headline: Peter Viertel, 86, Author and Screenwriter, Is Dead
text: Peter Viertel, a noted author and screenwriter who plumbed his relationships with the aristocracy of Hollywood — starting with Greta Garbo, his mother’s best friend — and literary lions like Hemingway to produce provocative works of fiction and memoir, died on Sunday in Marbella, Spain. He was 86.

headline: Yazoo Pumps: They’re Back!
text: Like an indestructible ghoul in a low-grade horror flick, the Yazoo Pumps are rising again from the bureaucratic crypt.

headline: Newspaper Circulation Falls 3%, Audit Bureau Says
text: The circulation declines of American newspapers continued to accelerate over the spring and summer, as sales across the industry fell almost 3 percent compared with the year before, according to figures released today.

headline: Retired Principal Rekindles Competitive Fire for Archery
text: Phyllis Shipman did not look like the other athletes attending the United States Olympic Assembly last month in Houston. Neither buff nor sinewy and, at 64, several decades older, Shipman represented the sport of archery at the annual gathering of Olympic stakeholders.

headline: Pope Meets King of Saudi Arabia
text: ROME, Nov. 6 — Pope Benedict XVI and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia clasped hands at the Vatican on Tuesday in the first meeting ever between a pope and the Saudi monarch, who is entrusted to protect Mecca, the birthplace of Mohammad and the center of the Islamic world.

headline: Bush Pledges to Help Turkey on Intelligence
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 — President Bush pledged Monday to increase intelligence cooperation with Turkey in its fight against Kurdish rebels, hoping to head off any significant Turkish military operation in Iraq.

headline: Letters
text: A Borough and the A-Bomb

headline: Bradford Kelleher, Creator of Met’s Store, Dies at 87
text: Bradford Kelleher, a pioneer of museum merchandising who founded the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s first full-fledged gift shop and oversaw the creation of countless artful and educational tchotchkes, including the museum’s unofficial mascot, the Egyptian hippopotamus nicknamed William, died on Wednesday in Riverhead, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan and Cutchogue, N.Y.

headline: Canada: Encana Buys Gas Partner
text: The EnCana Corporation, a Canadian natural gas producer, agreed to buy out its partner in an East Texas gas field for $2.55 billion, its largest acquisition in three years, to increase its presence in one of the fastest-growing sources of the fuel in the United States. EnCana said it had acquired the stake in the field, located about 80 miles northwest of Houston, from Leor Energy, which is privately held. EnCana, which is based in Calgary, said it planned to accelerate drilling there next year by adding three rigs to the seven now in service.

headline: The View From Roosevelt I.
text: To the Editor:

headline: For a Key Education Law, Reauthorization Stalls
text: The leaders of the Senate and House education committees are signaling that time has run out for reauthorizing the No Child Left Behind Act this year, leaving prospects for rewriting it uncertain during the presidential campaign in 2008.

headline: Ex-Contractor Is Convicted in Bribery Case
text: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 5  After almost four days of deliberation, a federal jury here on Monday convicted a former military contractor of 13 felonies related to the bribery of former Representative Randy Cunningham.

headline: A Blossoming Cathedral Tower Sheds Its Scaffolding
text: Fifteen years have passed since the stonemasons put down their chisels and mallets for the last time. Now, they can finally see what their carving wrought: the uppermost 55 feet 2 inches of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

headline: Despite Strike, Prime-Time TV Marches On
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 — Worry not, prime-time television fans. Despite a Hollywood writers’ strike, Meredith will continue to pout on “Grey’s Anatomy,” Scofield will continue to scowl his way through “Prison Break,” House will limp and the Housewives will bicker. And all of those crime-solving, clue-unearthing, cold-case-cracking law enforcers will keep on digging — at least for another month or two, thanks to a backlog of about half a dozen episodes already filmed.

headline: Amazing Race Is Off to a Flying Start
text: The 12th edition of “The Amazing Race” got under way to solid ratings on Sunday, as CBS attracted the night’s most viewers over all. The network led its competitors by a significant margin going into prime time, thanks to an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. That highly anticipated match-up of undefeated teams, the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts, delivered more than 32 million viewers in its final half-hour, according to Nielsen’s preliminary estimates. Although that audience largely dissipated once the game ended around 7:30 p.m., 18.8 million viewers stuck around for CBS’s “60 Minutes,” and 13.8 million tuned in for CBS’s “Amazing Race” after that, the most ever for a first episode of the contest. For the night, NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” edged past CBS for first place among adults 18 to 49, while ABC had a rare third-place finish, despite leading the 9 p.m. hour with “Desperate Housewives” (18.5 million). Fox ranked fourth over all. The 100th episode of Fox’s “Family Guy” drew 10.5 million viewers at 9, while the annual Halloween episode of “The Simpsons” (11.7 million) led its 8 o’clock slot in the 18-to-49 set.

headline: Loud and Cleared: N.F.L. Says Colts Didn’t Pump in Noise
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 5 — In case the New England Patriots’ fourth-quarter comeback to beat the Indianapolis Colts did not do enough to stoke the N.F.L.’s best rivalry, what came afterward surely will.

headline: Massachusetts Looks at Using Biofuel in Home Heating Oil
text: BOSTON, Nov. 5  Gov. Deval L. Patrick and legislative leaders proposed a bill on Monday to require all home heating oil and diesel fuel to contain at least 5 percent biofuel by 2013.

headline: Legal Think Tanks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Art Dealer Files for Bankruptcy, Delaying Suits Against Him
text: Lawrence B. Salander, the embattled Manhattan art dealer whose gallery was ordered locked by a State Supreme Court justice last month, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Friday.

headline: Go Ahead, Rationalize. Monkeys Do It, Too.
text: For half a century, social psychologists have been trying to figure out the human gift for rationalizing irrational behavior. Why did we evolve with brains that salute our shrewdness for buying the neon yellow car with bad gas mileage? The brain keeps sending one message — Yesss! Genius! — while

headline: Cable Channel Nods to Ratings and Leans Left
text: Riding a ratings wave from “Countdown With Keith Olbermann,” a program that takes strong issue with the Bush administration, MSNBC is increasingly seeking to showcase its nighttime lineup as a welcome haven for viewers of a similar mind.

headline: A Map of the Oil World
text: In 2006, Saudi Arabia was by far the largest producer of oil, followed by Russia and United States. On average, the United States consumed 20.6 million barrels per day, which made it the largest oil consumer in the world.

headline: Injury Roundup
text: * Stop me if you’ve heard this before: a Carolina Panthers quarterback got hurt Sunday. It was David Carr, again. Carr, who has been battling a bad back for weeks, sustained a concussion Sunday against Tennessee. This is not entirely surprising because he was sacked seven times. UPDATE: The Charlotte Observer reports that Drew Olson is likely to sign with Carolina so there is someone to take reps in practice.

headline: $500,000 Homes
text: Properties on the market in South Carolina, Missouri and California.

headline: When Corona Beer and Lime Are a Crime
text: A Brooklyn bar has been busted for illicit lime insertion into bottles of Corona. Quoting from the rap sheet against the bar, Michael Wilson describes the crime as:

headline: Psychological Tests at Work: Can You Study?
text: A friend (who asked me not to use her name for reasons that will soon become obvious) recently told me that she had interviewed for a job but didn’t get it. She said she thought it might have to do with the psychological evaluation she had to undergo as part of the interview process. Of course, she’ll never know. But it was gnawing at her. It was the first time she had to submit to that kind of test for an interview, and she couldn’t help wondering if she made a misstep somewhere.

headline: Ex-Executive of Wal-Mart Drops Suit on Severance
text: A former advertising executive for Wal-Mart Stores has decided to drop her breach-of-contract lawsuit against the retailer, saying that the lawsuit had become financially draining and more complex than she had expected.

headline: HarbourVest to List Fund on Euronext
text: A Boston private equity house, HarbourVest Partners, said Monday it plans to raise up to $400 million in a listing of one of its funds on the NYSE Euronext exchange in Amsterdam.

headline: Grammercy Capital Scoops Up American Financial Realty
text: American Financial Realty Trust, which aimed to become the preferred landlord of leading banks and other financial institutions, announced Monday that it was being bought for $1.1 billion in cash and stock by Gramercy Capital, a New York commercial real estate finance company.

headline: A Park Grows in Brooklyn
text: The new South Oxford Park with its whimsical central fountain was quickly converted from a derelict facility into a magnificent public space.

headline: Black Loses Bid for New Trial
text: The former press baron Conrad Black and three of his associates, convicted in July of fraud at their company, Hollinger International, lost their request Monday for a new trial.

headline: Boston Scientific Unloads Cardiac Surgery Unit
text: Boston Scientific said Monday it would sell its cardiac and vascular surgery businesses to Sweden-based Gettinge Group for $750 million.

headline: Bank Write-Downs Unnerve Bond Buyers
text: After a recuperative October, investors in the credit markets are starting to feel a familiar sense of dread.

headline: Hedge Fund Group Discloses New Guidelines
text: A leading hedge fund trade group unveiled new recommendations Monday aimed at improving practices in the lightly regulated, $2 trillion hedge fund industry.

headline: Investors Eschew Hedge-Fund Start-Ups
text: The hedge fund industry is grappling with its first shakeout in a decade as investors increasingly avoid hedge-fund start-ups considered susceptible to the turmoil in credit markets.

headline: Led by Troubled Banks, Shares Slide
text: Shares of financial companies stumbled Monday in the aftermath of the shake-up at Citigroup, sending the stock markets down and leaving investors on edge about further troubles in the credit market.

headline: Rewriting Rap to Empower Teens
text: A group of high school girls in Atlanta got tired of taunts and catcalls from men in the street. So they decided to rap about it:

headline: Behringer Harvard Signs for Chicago Office Towers
text: Behringer Harvard closed on its $832.5 million purchase of four downtown Chicago office towers from affiliates of Beacon Capital Partners, Behringer announced Monday.

headline: V.C.’s Turn On to LED Lighting Fixtures
text: LED Lighting Fixtures said Monday the company had raised $16.5 million in a second round of financing to bring energy-efficient lighting to businesses and homes. The funding, led by Digital Power Capital, brings the company’s total capital to $23 million.

headline: How a Prince Lost His Citi Crown
text: As recently as last month, Charles O. Prince III could count on the support of Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, the biggest shareholder of Citigroup, the financial behemoth that Mr. Prince had run for four years.

headline: Shares of Alibaba.com Climb on First Day of Trading
text: Shares of Alibaba.com, one of China’s biggest Internet companies, soared in early trading on Tuesday in China’s latest hot initial public stock offering.

headline: No Coke — Politics!
text: The presidential field is full of connections to “Saturday Night Live,” and not just guest-host and cameo appearances. As Michael Cooper reports on our political blog The Caucus :

headline: Dell to Acquire Storage Company for $1.4 Billion
text: Dell said Monday that it would acquire EqualLogic for $1.4 billion in a move to claim a larger share of the data storage market. The deal, Dell’s largest acquisition to date and its fourth this year, comes as the company is trying to stage a corporate turnaround and reclaim ground lost to more nimble competitors.

headline: Buyout Chatter Surrounds ITV
text: The British broadcaster ITV got an initial lift Monday on weekend reports that a British private equity group, Apax could return to bid for the company.

headline: Citigroup Names Executive to Oversee Subprime Assets
text: Citigroup named Richard Stuckey to manage most of its $43 billion of subprime mortgage assets, choosing the same executive who nine years ago helped unwind Long-Term Capital Management‘s bad bets.

headline: A Boom Time for Islamic Finance
text: Even as banking segments like those that securitize subprime mortgages and finance leveraged buyouts suffer from the current crisis, Islamic finance is seeing spectacular growth.

headline: EnCana to Pay $2.5 Billion in Texas Gas Deal
text: EnCana is paying $2.5 billion to buy out its partner in the Amoruso natural gas field in Texas. The play could become the most important in its North American portfolio.

headline: Judge Sets Date in Sallie Mae Trial
text: A Delaware judge on Monday set a tentative trial date in July in the dispute between Sallie Mae and an investor group led by the private-equity firm J.C. Flowers seeking to terminate its proposed $25 billion buyout of the student lender.

headline: Northern Rock Falls on Fears That Bidders Will Vanish
text: Shares in the stricken British mortgage bank Northern Rock tumbled more than 6 percent on Monday amid concerns that potential bidders will steer clear as the turmoil in global financial markets deepens.

headline: Saving the Heritage Turkey
text: A breeder in Kansas is on a mission to save the rare birds and the culture of raising them.

headline: When There’s No Chief on Deck
text: In corporate America, it may be time to retire the phrase “heir apparent.” For years, the idea of grooming a successor was a job requirement of a chief executive and a priority for a company’s board, who both wanted a smooth transition.

headline: Banks Are Said to Resume Sale of Chrysler Debt
text: A group of Wall Street banks plan to make another attempt to start selling $10 billion of Chrysler loans this week, according to news reports. The move follows the banks’ decision in July to shelve the debt offering amid woes in the credit markets.

headline: Time Warner May Be in for a New Era of Dealmaking
text: The news that Jeffrey L. Bewkes, Time Warner‘s the chief operating officer, will succeed Richard D. Parsons as chief executive at the end of the year had industry watchers wondering if a spate of dealmaking may be in the offing at world’s largest media company.

headline: Comedian Falls Short of Pat Paulsen
text: Stephen Colbert went from running last month, to not running last week, to reruns this week — reruns because of the writers’ strike. On Monday, here’s how the comedian announced his withdrawal from the presidential race:

headline: Schlumberger Offers $679 Million for Eastern Echo
text: Schlumberger, the oil-field services company, bid up to $679 million for a Norwegian-listed company, Eastern Echo, on Tuesday to expand its seismic operations at a time when record oil prices are driving demand.

headline: ING to Buy Sharebuilder’s Online Unit
text: The Dutch financial services group ING has agreed to buy ShareBuilder‘s online brokerage business for $220 million to extend its reach in the United States, ING said on Tuesday.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Is There Pop After Weimar?
text: Carnegie Hall is pitching Berlin in Lights as a celebration of Berlin’s Culture With a Capital C: not just its music but its art, architecture and film. And although plenty of the programming is overtly historical, you get the sense that this is all meant to add up to a contemporary portrait of a reborn city.

headline: Time (and Paint) on His Hands
text: Could this guy be a Republican? But wait — isn’t that his left hand? More hand art found here.

headline: In DreamWorks Fight, It’s Mogul vs. Mogul
text: All of Hollywood was shaken up this year over reports of a deepening feud between Paramount and DreamWorks, the movie studio that is the home of Steven Spielberg. Press reports were atwitter with word that Mr. Spielberg wasn’t happy with the lack of recognition due DreamWorks — and a response in September from the head of Paramount’s parent, Viacom, that the studio’s walking away would be “completely immaterial.”

headline: What’s Next for Zell and Tribune?
text: The real estate magnate Sam Zell is famous for his bluntness and for his history of taking daring business risks — many of which have paid off.

headline: Will IAC Breakup Bring Peace Between Moguls?
text: Barry Diller is splitting IAC/InterActiveCorp into five parts, but will that be enough to end the tensions between Mr. Diller and his old partner, John C. Malone?

headline: A Different Take on I.P.O. Lawsuits
text: Plaintiffs are counting on a largely overlooked legal theory in their latest lawsuits against Goldman Sachs and other top investment banks that underwrote initial public offerings during the dot-com boom, The Seattle Times reports.

headline: The Early Word: Climate Crusaders
text: Climate change is a big talking point for Democratic presidential candidates, and their plans for reversing it come with an even bigger price tag. The Washington Post reports today that the Democrats are counting on voters to get on board with their risky, expensive strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions because they believe it will ultimately save Americans money and save the earth.

headline: “Motionless in London” on Congestion Charging in Manhattan
text: This comment excerpt (from this post) made me stop and think a bit:

headline: Greece and Quiet
text: A look at a two-story residential-commercial property on the edge of a small Greek island.

headline: Making Sense of the New School Rankings
text: The new school ranking system unveiled by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday has begun to stir vigorous discussion among parents and guardians.

headline: Bloomberg Calls Report of Run Against Spitzer ‘Fictitious’
text: In a cover article today, The New York Post reports that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg‘s top political strategist, Deputy Mayor Kevin Sheekey, met late last month with a former state Republican chairman, William J. Powers, to discuss the possibility that Mr. Bloomberg might run against Gov. Eliot Spitzer in 2010. According to The Post, Mr. Sheekey told Mr. Powers that Mr. Bloomberg is “open” to the idea.

headline: M.L.B. Takes First Step to Add Instant Replay
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 6 — With a 25-5 vote, general managers took the first step Tuesday to add instant replay to baseball games. The vote marked a significant departure from previous votes at general managers meetings, where the issue had the support of, at best, half of those present.

headline: Mukasey Gets a Hearing
text: Well, for once the other senator from New York has set off the big blog debate. “I am voting today to support Michael B. Mukasey for attorney general for one critical reason: the Department of Justice — once the crown jewel among our government institutions — is a shambles and is in desperate need of a strong leader, committed to depoliticizing the agency’s operations,” writes Charles Schumer on this morning’s Times Op-Ed Page.

headline: Red Sox Retain Schilling
text: The Boston Red Sox took care of their veteran right-hander Curt Schilling by signing him to a one-year, $8 million contract.

headline: Food Stuff
text: For New Yorkers, Never Too Much Chocolate

headline: PayPal is Rude in the Lunch Line
text: It’s not easy competing with Google. But a few minutes trying to buy my daughters their school lunches showed me why I think eBay’s PayPal will lose ground to Google Checkout.

headline: If You Don’t Buy This Magazine …
text: The estimable Texas Monthly magazine, based in Austin, hasn’t always been kind to the Bush administration – witness the issue at left, which recently won a 2007 American Society of Magazine Editors award for best cover line. (“If You Don’t Buy This Magazine, Dick Cheney Will Shoot You in the Face.”)

headline: Heads Turn Over Model’s Disputed Dollar Diss
text: There are headlines about supermodels, and there are headlines about currency markets, and rarely the twain shall meet. So it’s no wonder that the following headline from Bloomberg News on Monday turned heads and raised catcalls on Wall Street:

headline: The Mysterious Assault on Fortress
text: Fortress Investment Group appears to have a hole in its castle walls. At least, that is the sense you get from its tumbling stock price.

headline: Making More Room in Queens for Visiting Fans of Satchmo
text: Louis Armstrong, the acclaimed jazz trumpeter and vocalist, bought a house in Corona, Queens, with his wife, Lucille, in 1943. He lived there until his death in 1971. The house was designated a national historic landmark in 1977 and a city landmark in 1983, the year Lucille Armstrong died. In 1986, the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, which she created, donated the house to New York City and made arrangements for Queens College to maintain it.

headline: Q&A: Chicago Coach Juan Carlos Osorio
text: Juan Carlos Osorio is no stranger to Major League Soccer. The 46-year-old native of Colombia was an assistant coach with the MetroStars for two years (2000-1) before taking a job as Manchester City’s strength and conditioning coach (2001-6). He returned to Colombia last season as the coach of Millonairos of Bogotá before becoming the third coach in the history of the Chicago Fire on July 9.

headline: Sullivan & Cromwell Names New Partners
text: How important are overseas markets in the deal-making business these days? Just look at the list of newly elected partners at Sullivan & Cromwell, the New York-based firm that is a perennial front-runner in the league tables that track merger advisory work.

headline: Beyond Beyoncé
text: Posters on Siraselviler Caddesi tout the eclectic mix of live music in Istanbul.

headline: Fossil Hunters!
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Tuesday Morning Kickoff
text: When you combine an e-mail newsletter controversy with a disappointing performance on the field, this becomes almost inevitable: Dennis Franchione is on the verge of accepting a buyout from Texas A&M, according to CBSSportsline’s Dennis Dodd. Ray Melick of the Birmingham News writes that the former Alabama coach Gene Stallings, now a member of the Texas A&M’s Board of Regents, could have a major say in who the Aggies’ next coach will be. And Steve Campbell of the Houston Chronicle says that the next coach had better be a big name.

headline: Pitching Is Mets’ Priority
text: Mets General Manager Omar Minaya said his priority this off-season was to acquire a top starting pitcher. But with a thin free-agent market, making a trade could be challenging.

headline: The Longest Season?
text: This strike could take a while.

headline: Tuesday’s Links: Those Other A.F.C. Teams
text: Let’s make a deal: How about I promise not to mention the Colts or the Patriots?

headline: At M.T.A. Hearing, Universal Opposition to Fare Increase
text: The process of raising the fares and tolls collected by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has often been described as a kind of ritual dance, with politicians, transit officials and straphangers all spinning around one another.

headline: Import a Good Idea
text: The hat that helps kids in one part of the world turns out to help kids everywhere.

headline: Pay Attention to Spot Opportunity
text: Owner Debra St. Claire turned desire for a vegetarian mint into a popular product.

headline: Sell Your Unique Talent
text: Talent honed at Disney and Warner Brothers is this company's competitive edge.

headline: Be Your Market
text: Brothers who love to surf in Baja brought their favorite Mexican flavors to California.

headline: Visiting Venice in the Off-Season
text: I travel a lot but have never to been to Venice, mainly because I am fearful, as I have heard, that it is always so crowded with tourists. I can travel whenever I want and the weather doesn’t concern me at all. I was thinking of late November and early December as those seem to be times when the travel season is the lowest and you can get the best fares.

headline: Umberto Eco, Not a Cellphone Exhibitionist
text: For most of last weekend, one of the most e-mailed stories on the Times’s website was about a device that enables you to silence the cell phones of annoying users. (Sign me up, please.)

headline: Taking Leave of an Old Friend
text: There’s a beautiful passage in Edward Gibbon’s memoirs in which he describes completing “The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire” after so many years of work and being overcome by melancholy, as if he had “taken everlasting leave of an old and agreeable friend.” Reading “War and Peace,” I had been so happily and so fully immersed in the novel that, when I finished the last sentence, I felt a little disoriented and bereft, almost as if I had lost all of my old, agreeable friends at once.

headline: Citi’s New Subprime Manager: The Memo
text: With concerns growing over Citigroup‘s exposure to subprime mortgage-related securities, the firm said Tuesday that it had appointed Richard Stuckey as its point person to manage the business. Mr. Stuckey is no newcomer to helping Citi out of a jam: In 1998, he helped pull the bank out of Long-Term Capital Management.

headline: Marmalade or Marmite? 2 shops serve British cravings
text: A small, well stocked store for anglophiles.

headline: F1 season snaps back into life
text: Next week Michael Schumacher will be testing in Spain at the same time as some other teams. At almost 39 years old, Schumacher has suddenly become a valuable asset for Ferrari, as the team prepares for the new season without traction control. I imagine Schumacher is also still capable of giving the team technical input worth Felipe Massa and Kimi Raikkonen combined.

headline: It’s Time to Play ‘Name That Gargoyle’
text: End of Quiz: Answer Revealed

headline: Brennan and the Dread Heads
text: Hawaii quarterback Colt Brennan is two touchdown passes away from breaking Ty Detmer’s career college football record of 121. In this essay for The Quad, Brennan reflects on his career, and tips his helmet to his four dreadlocked receivers, who are affectionately known as The Dread Heads.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: A look at this week's news events with Alison Smale of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

headline: The Bubble in Tom Perkins’s Sails
text: There’s a lot of chatter these days about whether the current state of Silicon Valley qualifies as a bona fide bubble. The tone of this discussion implies that being in a bubble ushers in some sort of dark and dangerous age.

headline: Governor Commences Wildfire Aftermath
text: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger played cheerleader-in-chief as the wildfires raged in Southern California last month, lauding the efforts of emergency workers and steadfastly dismissing criticism of any kind. “I think it’s not the right time now to point fingers or anything like this,” he said on Oct. 30. “Those that do are opportunists.”

headline: New Bus Shelter Is Vandalized by Acid
text: Updated, Nov. 7 | The city’s new glass-walled bus shelters have received their baptism by acid.

headline: A Good Day’s Work for Ron Paul
text: “Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul, aided by an extraordinary outpouring of Internet support Monday, hauled in more than $4.2 million in nearly 24 hours,” reports the Associated Press.

headline: Book Review: Meat Market
text: Author Bruce Feldman will be signing copies of “Meat Market” in Manhattan at Borders on 32nd and 2nd on Nov. 6 at 7 p.m.

headline: Thompson Joins Air Wars With New Ads
text: If his “Meet the Press” and “Law & Order” reruns aren’t enough for you, Fred D. Thompson is hitting the airwaves even harder starting tomorrow with ads in Iowa and on Fox News Channel.

headline: How Will Schumer’s Mukasey Vote Play in New York?
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, is normally one of the most visible public officials, known for frequent press conferences, a steady stream of news releases and general availability for interviews. But over the past two weeks, he has largely avoided comment on one of the most significant votes of his time in the Senate — his decision today to buck his Democratic colleagues on sending the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general  to the full Senate.

headline: Easton, Conn.
text: A rural town in Fairfield County, Easton has well-kept antique homes, high-performing schools and areas with close-knit neighbors.

headline: Bloomberg Holds Forth on Corn Subsidies
text: The government may have shut down for Election Day, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg isn’t taking the day off from holding forth on presidential issues while denying that he is a candidate (for either governor or president). In an interview on MSNBC this morning about whether declared candidates like Hillary Rodham Clinton and John Edwards were pandering to Iowa voters by supporting subsidies for corn-based ethanol, Mr. Bloomberg sounded very much like a man who wants to be in that mix.

headline: Whistling Past the Credit Crunch
text: Small can be beautiful too.

headline: The Animated Life: Yours
text: A 1945 film and song transformed by the art of animation.

headline: Images From The Picket Lines, Day Two
text: As the strike entered day two, Writers Guild of America, East members moved from Rockefeller Center in Manhattan to Silvercup Studios in Queens.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Cabaret Fare to Go
text: Audience members at Carnegie Hall who attended the concert by Max Raabe and the Palast Orchester, which kicked off the Berlin in Lights Festival on Friday night, scooped up all the CDs of the ensemble that were being sold in the lobby and the gift shop. Clearly, Mr. Raabe, the dapper and stylishly nonchalant vocalist who headlines this 12-piece band, is not just a compelling performer but a savvy promoter.

headline: Half-Hour Comedies Take A Hit
text: Most of the television shows immediately affected by the strike “are half-hour comedies that are taped in front of a studio audience,” Edward Wyatt reports. Yesterday production was shut down on the CBS comedies “Two and a Half Men,” “The Big Bang Theory” and “Rules of Engagement,” and the Fox sitcom “‘Til Death.” Why?

headline: Any Way You Can Vote I Can Vote Better
text: It used to be that the road to the Presidency wound its circuitous route from Iowa to New Hampshire to South Carolina. Well, that road has been getting a lot circuitouser. Florida, Michigan and even Wyoming have all moved their primaries into January, sacred ground for the Big 3 states.

headline: A Love, Fortified
text: Sometimes the process of reporting a story reawakens feelings that have been dormant for too long. For example, I know I love Madeira, but I really haven’t gone out of my way to drink any recently. Then I spent some time with Joseph DeLissio, the wine director at the River Cafe, who has put together an astounding collection of vintage Madeiras, which I’ve written about in Wednesday’s newspaper, and I remembered what I loved about them in the first place.

headline: Is Burning Coal a Patriotic Duty?
text: Coal companies and utilities have tried a new approach in defending black combustible rock as the fuel of the future, at least in Kansas.

headline: Jets’ Ben Graham, Daddy Dearest
text: Jets punter Ben Graham welcomed his third child into the world Monday at 7:15 p.m., and the birth just happened to coincide with the Jets bye week. Another example of how, for punters, timing is everything.

headline: Separation Anxiety as IAC Plans Spinoffs
text: Life won’t necessarily be easy for IAC/InterActiveCorp‘s corporate offspring.

headline: The Beatle and the M.T.A. Board Member
text: It would seem improbable for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to be fodder for the British tabloids. But the London newspapers — and now The Daily News and The New York Post — are in a tizzy today with reports that Paul McCartney is having a romantic relationship with Nancy Shevell, who was appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki to the M.T.A. board in 2001.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: A look at this week's news events with Alison Smale of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

headline: Strikers: Not Writing, But Still Blogging
text: Even when they’re on strike, Writers Guild of America members are still writers at heart. Perhaps for that reason, several television screenwriters and show-runners have been busy blogging about the situation.

headline: Satellite Dishes and Pakistan’s Media Blackout
text: When the president of Pakistan declared emergency rule over the weekend and the government halted private television broadcasts, several networks there turned to the Internet to stream news coverage of the political crisis. One network chief explained the situation this way:

headline: New Ads Aim at Single Women
text: Sometimes referred to as the “Sex and the City” vote, single women get stereotyped out there as more into their clothes, their shoes or their work, (not necessarily in that order), rather than their voting rights.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Deutsche Grammophon Serves Up an Appetizer
text: Nov. 13, the official release date of a new recording from the Berlin Philharmonic, comes right in the middle of Berlin in Lights. Did the savvy folks at Deutsche Grammophon purposefully link the recording to Carnegie Hall’s festival, in which the Berlin Philharmonic plays a major part? Or is this a potentially profitable coincidence?

headline: Approaching Panic
text: The financial guarantors are the latest object of fear and loathing on Wall Street. They have guaranteed zillions of dollars of obligations, and some of them are not going to work out well.

headline: A Look at the Third Base Market
text: At long last, the Yankees had their meeting with Scott Boras today. It was outside the bank of elevators at the Hyatt Grand Cypress here at the general managers’ meetings in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Leaping from FR.OG
text: Didier Virot, the Jean-Georges-trained chef who landed at FR.OG in SoHo this spring, has already hopped away, Florence Fabricant reports in tomorrow’s Off The Menu.

headline: Winter of our discontent
text: Oil at $97!

headline: An Election Day Thought: Time to Change How Judges are Selected
text: Today is election day, and in Pennsylvania, a nasty, high-spending race for two seats on the state Supreme Court is coming to a close. No matter who wins, judicial integrity, independence, and impartiality are already the losers.

headline: Cell Phones — Here Come the Jammers
text: One of the Times news stories that has generated the most buzz this week has been this one, reporting on the increasing use of cell phone jammers to cut off conversations of annoying people blabbing on the cell phones in public places.

headline: Giuliani on Biden
text: Brian Williams asked Mr. Giuliani about his feud with Senator Joseph Biden.

text: Rudolph W. Giuliani discussed the troop surge in Iraq.

headline: Giuliani on Kerik
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani answered questions about Bernard Kerik, his former police commissioner.

headline: Video: NBC Interview With Giuliani
text: Brian Williams interviewed Rudolph W. Giuliani today for a segment that will air at 6:30 p.m. Eastern on tonight’s NBC Nightly News. The former New York mayor talked about Hillary Rodham Clinton, Joseph Biden’s comments about him during the recent Democratic debate, the situation in Iraq and his former police commissioner. Watch excerpts of the interview from NBC:

headline: U.N. Panel Says Mercenary Ranks Growing
text: “A lot of people call us mercenaries,” complained Erik D. Prince, chief of Blackwater USA, at a House committee hearing last month.

headline: The Good Doctor
text: Congressman Ron Paul, still trading at 8.7 on InTrade since raising more than $4.07 million yesterday, may already be our Internet president.

headline: The Politics of Coal
text: We just thought it would be worthwhile to cross-post to another sib-blog, DotEarth, where politics has entered into the realm of coal.

text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: CBGB to Become Men’s Fashion Boutique
text: The men’s fashion designer John Varvatos  confirmed today that he is building a 3,200-square-foot boutique in the Bowery storefront that housed CBGB, the legendary punk-rock nightclub that closed in October 2006.

headline: Baby, It’s Cold Inside
text: AMANA, Iowa — The temperature is 41 degrees here this afternoon. The wind has been blowing for a few days now. No, winter hasn’t technically arrived, but a 33 degree wind chill makes it seem as though that season is not far away.

headline: ‘Nightline’ May Be a Strike Beneficiary
text: With Jay Leno of NBC and David Letterman of CBS sidelined by a writers’ strike, ABC’s 11:35 p.m. alternative — the half-hour newscast “Nightline” — may stand to benefit.

headline: Kucinich Pushes Cheney Impeachment
text: It’s hard to know which effort has longer odds, the bid by Representative Dennis Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio, to become president of the United States, or his bid to unseat Vice President Dick Cheney by trying to get him impeached.

headline: Judith Giuliani in New Hampshire
text: Judith Giuliani spoke Nov. 6 at the Vermont-New Hampshire chapter of Susan G. Komen for the Cure group.

headline: Schreiber’s Notes: Will Boras Blink?
text: Everybody is making fun of Alex Rodriguez (calling him Me-Rod) for intruding on the last game World Series when his agent, Scott Boras, announced he would opt out of his contract with the Yankees.

headline: Clandestine Dining
text: Scenes from "One Pot," a series of underground, movable dinners run by Michael Hebberoy in Seattle.

headline: Ask About New York Foster Care
text: In a series called “A History of Neglect” [Part 1 | Part 2 | Part 3], Leslie Kaufman and Benjamin Weiser of The Times reported this week on how New York City began an experiment in foster care two decades ago that was aimed at better protecting the city’s most vulnerable black and Latino children.

headline: Colbert vs. Obama vs. S.C.
text: Stephen Colbert’s presidential candidacy may have been a joke to many, but apparently some in South Carolina took it seriously enough to lobby Democratic officials in the early primary state to deny him a spot on the state’s ballot.

headline: Bye Bye Independence
text: Accounting rules set by the International Accounting Standards Board are on the verge of taking over the world. Chris Cox, the chairman of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, is pushing through American acceptance of them before it is clear if they are being applied on a consistent basis.

headline: Edwards Revises Ad for New Hampshire
text: DES MOINES – The Edwards campaign retooled parts of the television commercial that was released in Iowa last week and broadcast it today in New Hampshire. The 60-second commercial is based on the same themes: support for American workers and the story of the decision Mr. Edwards and his wife made to continue with the race for the Democratic nomination despite the return of her cancer.

headline: ‘Yours’
text: “Yours” began with a soundie, a film made for projection in a “film jukebox” in 1945.

headline: Islamabad's Lawyers Defiant
text: The ousted Supreme Court chief justice urged lawyers to defy Gen. Pervez Musharraf's state of emergency in Pakistan.

headline: Red Bulls Players React to Arena’s Exit
text: It was somber Tuesday at the Red Bulls training facility of the campus of Montclair State University in Little Falls, N.J., less than 24 hours after it was announced that Bruce Arena, the club’s coach and sporting director, had left the club.

headline: Tracing My Roots Back to Korea
text: Returning to Korea for the first time since my adoption was a defining moment in my life. It took 20 years to muster the courage to confront the most basic of questions: Who am I? Where did I come from?

headline: The Politics of Punctuality
text: Updated | 12:37 a.m.

headline: Islamabad's Lawyers Defiant
text: The ousted Supreme Court chief justice urged lawyers to defy Gen. Pervez Musharraf's state of emergency in Pakistan.

headline: Project to Capture CO2 With Plankton Puts to Sea
text: The WeatherBird II, a 115-foot private research vessel, has put to sea from Florida as part of a novel and contentious effort to commercialize the removal of heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by triggering blooms of plankton.

headline: Port Authority Sets Its Sights on Robust List of Projects
text: For decades, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was a bastion of patronage and a hulking bureaucracy living on its past success in building much of the region’s transportation network.

headline: A Second Chance for Ex-Offenders
text: If past patterns hold true, more than half of the 650,000 prisoners released this year will be back behind bars by 2010. With the prison population exploding and the price of incarceration now topping $60 billion a year, states are rightly focusing on ways to reduce recidivism. Congress can give these efforts a boost by passing the Second Chance Act, which would provide crucial help to people who have paid their debts to society.

headline: Sarkozy Is Greeted Warmly by Congress
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 —President Nicolas Sarkozy of France was greeted with cheers and standing ovations in the United States Congress today, a sign that France was forgiven for opposing the American-led war in Iraq.

headline: A High-Five for Roethlisberger
text: It was clear as the Pittsburgh Steelers dismantled the vaunted Baltimore Ravens pass defense Monday night that Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, below right, was having a special game, but it was not obvious just how unusual it was.

headline: Pass the Peruvian F.T.A.
text: Congressional Democrats took their time, but more than a year after it was originally signed, the free trade agreement between the United States and Peru is finally due for a vote in the House of Representatives today.

headline: Correction: Pork With Beans, Smoke and Spice to Match the Red
text: Because of an editing error, the Pairing column last Wednesday, about a Portuguese dish that inspired a recipe for a pork stew, referred incorrectly to Mealhada, the town that specializes in the dish. It is not at the mouth of the Douro River.

headline: New York Public Library’s Donnell Branch to Share Space With Hotel
text: Shhh, this is a hotel.

headline: 2007 Is Deadliest Year for U.S. Troops in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 6 — Six American soldiers were killed in three separate attacks in Iraq on Monday, the military said Tuesday, taking the number of deaths this year to 852. The toll makes 2007 the deadliest year of the war for United States troops.

headline: Rediscovering a Hidden Island
text: Our kayaks were beached above high tide. The sun had set. We looked out over one of the most beautiful shorelines in the Caribbean. I had just fired up a cigar when we spotted it: a boat’s searchlight scanning the shore beyond the next point.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A map with a sports article on Monday about a hockey fan’s 30-day journey to attend a game at every National Hockey League arena misidentified the hometown of the Minnesota Wild. It is St. Paul, not Minneapolis.

headline: Overweight People Found Less Likely to Die From Some Diseases
text: About two years ago, a group of federal researchers reported that overweight people have a lower death rate than people who are normal weight, underweight or obese. Now, investigating further, they found out which diseases are more likely to lead to death in each weight group.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,838 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: More Met Opera Transmissions in More Sites
text: The second season of “Metropolitan Opera: Live in High Definition” will begin on Dec. 15 with a presentation of Gounod’s “Roméo et Juliette,” starring Anna Netrebko and Roberto Alagna (right)  and conducted by Plácido Domingo. It will be the first of eight live opera transmissions to be seen in more than 600 movie theaters, arts center and universities in North America, Australia, Europe and Japan — triple the number of last year’s sites, the Met said. Ticket sales in North America begin on Friday. The 2007-8 series will include a New Year’s Day presentation of Humperdinck’s “Hansel and Gretel,” as well as Verdi’s “Macbeth,” Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut,” Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde,” Britten’s “Peter Grimes,” Donizetti’s “Fille du Régiment” and Puccini’s “Bohème.” Among the participating movie houses is the Walter Reade Theater in Lincoln Center. The “Live in High Definition” program will expand in New York into public schools in all five boroughs.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture in the Today in Business column in Business Day yesterday with a brief report about an executive change at Time Warner was published in error. The picture was of Charles O. Prince III, the departing chief executive of Citigroup — not Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the newly chosen chief executive of Time Warner.

headline: The Carbon Calculus
text: A CHANGE is in the works that could go a long way toward making alternative energy less alternative, and more attractive to consumers and businesses.

headline: Kentucky Governor Loses to Democrat
text: Dogged by political scandal in his first term, Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, a Republican, lost his bid for re-election yesterday to Steve Beshear.

headline: G.M. Takes $39 Billion Charge on Tax Offset
text: DETROIT, Nov. 6  General Motors said Tuesday that it would take a $39 billion noncash charge in the third quarter to remove net deferred tax assets from its books.

headline: Seagoing Climate Experiment Begins
text: The Weatherbird II, a 115-foot private research vessel, has put to sea from Florida as part of a novel  and contentious  effort to commercialize the removal of heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the atmosphere using blooms of plankton.

headline: For Suppliers, the Pressure Is On
text: HOME DEPOT did not sell organic roses this past Mother’s Day. Why? There were no cheap local ones available. And the amount of carbon that would have been emitted by shipping cheap ones from Venezuela seemed to eclipse any environmental benefit of avoiding pesticides and such.

headline: Conservative Authors Sue Publisher
text: Five authors have sued the parent company of Regnery Publishing, a Washington-based imprint of conservative books, alleging that the company deprives its writers of royalties by selling their books at a steep discount to book clubs and other organizations owned by the same parent company.

headline: Foreign Firms Envision Wind Farms Dotting the U.S.
