text: THE European Union has taken the lead on many climate change issues — from ratifying the Kyoto Protocol to passing laws to require and encourage the development of renewable sources of energy. Why, then, are so many European energy companies looking to the United States for investment opportunities?

headline: Aiding the Environment, a Nanostep at a Time
text: SOME of the grandest ideas about how to preserve the environment involve molecular-scale engineering known as nanotechnology. Such visions might inspire more confidence, though, if there were real products available to achieve them.

headline: Bonuses Likely to Shrink for Many on Wall Street
text: Wall Street bonuses may be the latest victim of the subprime mortgage collapse and the tight credit market. Over all, bonuses are expected to be flat to down 15 percent, according to compensation experts and Wall Street executives.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: NEW PLACES

headline: Uzbekistan: Leader Nominated Again
text: Delegates at a congress of the Liberal Democratic Party voted unanimously to nominate President Islam A. Karimov to run in the Dec. 23 presidential election, the Interfax news agency reported. He is constitutionally barred from seeking a third seven-year term, and election officials have not yet explained the legal mechanism justifying his nomination.

headline: Private Efforts to Preserve the Coast
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Bus Shelter in Chelsea Is Defaced With Acid
text: The city’s new glass-walled bus shelters have received their baptism by acid.

headline: Brooklyn: Teenager Shot to Death
text: A 14-year-old boy was fatally shot shortly before 7 o’clock last night in the lobby of a public housing complex in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim, Sunny Carter, was shot several times at 85 Tompkins Avenue, part of Tompkins Houses, where he lived in another building. He was taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center and was pronounced dead on arrival. Investigators said it was too soon to comment on a motive or possible suspects.

headline: Voters Are Split on Spending Measures
text: In Texas, voters were in a spending mood on Tuesday. In New Jersey and Oregon, they were not.

headline: Soon, at a Nearby Theater, Opera From La Scala
text: In a new venture, opera from Teatro alla Scala in Milan and two other renowned Italian houses will be shown at more than 60 theaters from coast to coast, beginning next month with Franco Zeffirelli’s production of Verdi’s “Aida.” The full lineup of high-definition broadcasts, through June, includes Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde,” Donizetti’s “Maria Stuarda,” Verdi’s “Traviata” and Puccini’s “Trittico,” all from La Scala, as well as Verdi’s “Forza del Destino” from Maggio Musicale in Florence, and Puccini’s “Rondine” from La Fenice in Venice. In Manhattan “Aida” will be seen at Symphony Space on Dec. 2. Tickets for the presentations will be $20. These screenings will be offered at different times in each theater, rather than being live broadcasts on a specific day at a specific time.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Trade Deal With Peru Likely to Pass House Vote
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  In a rare show of bipartisan cooperation, President Bush and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi appealed Tuesday for passage of a free-trade agreement with Peru in a vote scheduled for Wednesday in the House of Representatives.

headline: Musharraf’s Martial Plan
text: Islamabad, Pakistan

headline: After Completing Marathon, a Runner Dies in His Home
text: Shortly after completing the New York City Marathon on Sunday, Dr. Matthew P. Hardy, a research scientist, returned to his Manhattan apartment and died. He was 50.

headline: Bidding War for Rodriguez Needs 2 Teams
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: Correction: Recipe: Pork Grillades and Grits
text: A recipe for pork grillades and grits with an article last Wednesday about the New Orleans chef John Besh omitted the amount of butter that should be folded into the grits. One pound of butter should be used.

headline: Turkish-Bred Prosperity Makes War Less Likely in Iraqi Kurdistan
text: DOHUK, Iraq, Nov. 6 — Viewed from the outside, Iraqi Kurdistan looks close to war. Tens of thousands of Turkish troops are amassed on the border. And thousands of Iraqi Kurdish pesh merga fighters have taken up positions in the Mateen Mountains, ready for a counterattack, their local commanders say, should any Turkish operation hit civilians.

headline: Germany’s Soccer Power Echoes a League in Transition
text: MUNICH, Nov. 4 — In Germany’s top soccer league, the empire struck back with a vengeance. The question is whether F.C. Bayern Munich, the country’s most decorated club, can somehow manage to lead the entire league back to greatness.

headline: Mushy: Handsome in Uniform
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Thompson’s Down-Home Pitch
text: This advertisement, the first for Fred D. Thompson since he announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, is to begin running today in Iowa and nationally on the Fox News Channel.

headline: Living the Wild Life at College
text: ADIRONDACK PARK, N.Y.  On a recent afternoon, Katie Powers, 21, swam in the still water of Lake Massawepie, though the lake’s temperature was somewhere in the 50s.

headline: Financial Ground Has Shifted Under a Record Deal
text: The record price paid in January for the 41-story aluminum-clad office tower at 666 Fifth Avenue — $1.8 billion — was breathtaking, even by the standards of the heady Midtown Manhattan commercial real estate market.

headline: Bush’s Import-Safety Plan Is Detailed
text: A new Bush administration proposal to give the federal government sweeping authority over imports won plaudits yesterday as a step toward restoring public confidence in product safety. But some advocacy groups warned that unless the plan was backed by significant funds, it would prove meaningless.

headline: The Not-Google Phone
text: Two of the biggest technology stories of 2007 have been stories about phones — the solid achievement of Apple’s iPhone, released during the summer, and the news, announced on Monday, that Google will help orchestrate, develop and fund a new open software standard for mobile phones. Some people were disappointed by Google’s announcement, if only because there was no actual gadget to hold in their hands. But it was possibly as groundbreaking in its own way as the iPhone itself.

headline: New York Democrats Say License Issue Had Little Effect
text: Democrats declared yesterday that Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to give driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants had not proved to be the electoral boon Republicans had hoped for in local elections, despite the Republicans’ aggressive efforts to exploit overwhelming public opposition to the proposal.

headline: Salt Lake City Is Finding a Payoff in Conservation
text: SALT LAKE CITY

headline: Democratic Rival Defeats Mayor in Mount Vernon
text: In a three-way race for mayor in Mount Vernon, N.Y., the Democratic challenger, Clinton I. Young Jr., defeated the incumbent, Ernest D. Davis, last night.

headline: Vintage Madeira’s Enduring Charms
text: AS the wine director of the River Café in Brooklyn for almost 30 years, Joseph DeLissio has gladly sold vintage Champagnes and old Bordeaux, California cult wines and rare Burgundies. But about five years ago a terrible thing happened: he put some rare old Madeiras on the wine list — and sold them, too.

headline: Fix-It Expert Will Lead a New Team at Citigroup
text: Citigroup, reeling from its exposure to billions in assets backed by subprime mortgages, has appointed a triage team led by one of Wall Street’s best-known fix-it men.

headline: Bush Brother’s Firm Faces Inquiry Over Purchases
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — The inspector general of the Department of Education has said he will examine whether federal money was inappropriately used by three states to buy educational products from a company owned by Neil Bush, the president’s brother.

headline: Paper Mill’s New Chief
text: The Paper Mill Playhouse, which has steadily regained its footing after a financial crisis in the spring almost shut it down, announced yesterday that it has appointed a new executive director, Mark W. Jones. For the last four years Mr. Jones has been the executive director of Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, Mass. He has his work cut out for him in Millburn, N.J., Paper Mill’s home, where the financial crunch has been addressed in the short term by a $3.5 million bank loan. The theater has been without an executive director since Michael Gennaro unexpectedly announced his resignation last November. Although Mr. Gennaro’s position at Paper Mill combined the duties of executive director and artistic director, the theater is moving back to the dual structure it once had. A permanent artistic director has not yet been named. Mr. Jones started on Monday.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 26 in Northern Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 6 — A suicide bomber threw himself at a delegation of lawmakers visiting a town in northern Afghanistan Tuesday, killing at least 26 people, including a leading opposition figure, and wounding scores more, many of them schoolchildren forming a welcome parade, local and regional Afghan officials said.

headline: F. Maynard Sundman, Stamp Dealer, Dies at 92
text: F. Maynard Sundman, a stamp and coin dealer whose innovative mail-order marketing, using everything from comic books to matchbook covers, introduced millions to the once exclusive worlds of philately and numismatics, died Oct. 31 in Littleton, N.H. He was 92.

headline: Corruption Scandal Spreads at Samsung
text: SEOUL, Nov. 6 — A corruption scandal at the Samsung Group, the South Korean conglomerate, widened Tuesday as prosecutors opened a formal investigation into charges that its chairman masterminded a broad scheme of bribery and illegal transactions.

headline: House Steps Up Confrontation With Bush Over Spending
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — A majority of House Republicans joined Democrats this evening in escalating a confrontation with President Bush over federal spending as the House overrode Mr. Bush’s veto of a popular water projects measure.

headline: Staten Island District Attorney Is Re-elected in One of City’s Few Contested Races
text: Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, was overwhelmingly re-elected yesterday following a contentious campaign in which he lost the support of his former boss and political benefactor, James P. Molinaro, the borough president.

headline: Manhattan: Man Sought in 17 Bank Robberies
text: The police are seeking a man suspected of 17 bank robberies in Manhattan and the Bronx since May 2006. On Monday, the man entered the Sovereign Bank at 169 Seventh Avenue in Manhattan about 5:20 p.m. and gave a note to a teller demanding cash. He is described as black, with a mustache and goatee, 40 to 45 years old, about 5-foot-3 to 5-foot-5. The police ask anyone with information to call 800-577-TIPS (800-577-8477).

headline: Bill Clinton and 2 Democrats Spar Over Comment on Debate
text: Bill Clinton’s suggestion that his wife faced a Republican-style “Swift boat” attack during and after the last Democratic debate drew a rebuke yesterday from Senator Barack Obama, who said, “I was pretty stunned by that statement.”

headline: A Guitar-Rock Sandwich With a Soft Acoustic Center
text: Eclecticism can be a curse as well as a blessing for any record label, just as it can for any artist. For Recall Records, a Paris independent that celebrated its 10th anniversary at the Blender Theater at Gramercy on Monday, the philosophy of difference has mostly been a good thing.

headline: The Day After School Grades Come In, Parents Are Buzzing
text: It came up over lunch at a Middle Eastern cafe in Brooklyn Heights, where Todd Glass broke the news to Davide Cantoni that Public School 8, where their sons attend kindergarten, had received a C on the city’s new report card for its schools. He urged his friend not to panic.

headline: Despite Investigations, Perez Is Re-elected in Hartford
text: HARTFORD, Nov. 6 — Mayor Eddie A. Perez was able to fight off a field of challengers to win re-election on Tuesday, despite a state investigation into his hiring of a city contractor that had raised questions of conflict of interest during the campaign.

headline: Muscles Weakening, 11-Year-Old Speaks Through Painting
text: “That’s me and him. He draw for me,” Almaz Kelib says.

headline: For Citigroup’s New Head, Focus Is Subprime Tangle
text: Until Sunday, Robert E. Rubin collected over $18 million a year as Wall Street’s ultimate hands-off executive. On Monday, he had to roll up his sleeves.

headline: Plugging In to Make a Joyful Noise Unto the Lord
text: VICTORVILLE, Calif. — Mike Day, singer and guitarist, gathered his rock band around him.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Robert J. Armband, chief executive and publisher at La Raza Newspaper, Chicago, part of ImpreMedia, is stepping down to spend more time with his family, he said, and pursue “new projects and challenges.” Mike Cano, marketing director at La Opinión, Los Angeles, a newspaper also owned by ImpreMedia, will succeed Mr. Armband for the time being.

headline: Glitch at Start Muddles Times
text: Some of the 38,676 people who completed the New York City Marathon on Sunday were given incorrect finishing times, possibly affecting their attempts to qualify for the Boston Marathon.

headline: TV Writer-Producers Show Solidarity
text: BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 7 — They face off against each other each week in prime time: “Desperate Housewives” vs. “Family Guy,” “Ugly Betty vs. “My Name is Earl” and “Private Practice” vs. “Bionic Woman.”

headline: Kentucky Governor Loses to Democrat
text: Dogged by political scandal in his first term, Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, a Republican, lost his bid for re-election yesterday to Steve Beshear.

headline: Manhattan: Minor Injuries in Subway Crash
text: A subway operator received minor injuries yesterday when his train hit a wooden barrier at the end of a track, transit officials said. The southbound M train had just made its final stop and was not carrying any passengers, the officials said. The train crashed shortly before 11 a.m. in a tunnel just south of the Chambers Street station. The driver, who was not identified, was able to walk unassisted, and was taken to St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan, fire officials said.

headline: Warning on Impact of China and India Oil Demand
text: LONDON, Nov. 7 — A leading international energy agency today urged oil-producing countries to replenish crude oil inventories in light of a record oil price.

headline: Republicans Join Vote to Override Water Bill Veto
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — Congressional Democrats escalated a confrontation with President Bush over federal spending on Tuesday as the House overrode Mr. Bush’s veto of a popular water projects measure and approved a $215 billion bill to pay for health, education, labor and veterans programs despite a veto threat.

headline: Letters
text: Ancient Traditions

headline: The Mystery Finger
text: The finger has been identified. The digit that the guitarist Jimmy Page fractured, forcing a two-week postponement of Led Zeppelin’s reunion concert, was his left pinky. He broke it in a fall after tripping on a stone slab in his garden, he told the BBC. “It’s a nuisance because it’s really needed,” he said, adding that the damage was “not permanent.” Which finger was not specified in the vague news release the band issued on Thursday announcing the delay. But the splint was noticeable when Mr. Page accepted a Living Legend honor at the Classic Rock awards in London on Monday night.

headline: Shuttle Discovery Lands Safely
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. Nov. 7 — The shuttle Discovery glided to a safe landing here Wednesday, bringing to a close an eventful mission that combined challenging space station construction and emergency repairs.

headline: On Mukasey: Saying No to Schumer’s Yes
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Meatloaf Conundrum, Solved
text: MEATLOAF is as firmly ensconced in the pantheon of American comfort foods as mashed potatoes and macaroni and cheese. It’s also the hardest to get just right. That Betty Crocker archetype — moist and juicy ground meat seasoned barely sweet and spicy with onions, ketchup and Worcestershire sauce — is too often darkened by the school-lunch reality of dense, dry meat that needs more ketchup on the side to make it palatable.

headline: Afghan Struggle to Change Poppy Fields Into Roads
text: Joel Hafvenstein returned to Afghanistan in late 2004 armed with nothing but good intentions. Employed by Chemonics, a private company with a contract from the United States Agency for International Development, he was part of a team trying to discourage cultivation of the opium poppy by providing an alternative income for poor farmers.

headline: Texas: No Bid Chosen for Wildlife Preserve
text: The Texas School Land Board did not choose to award a state-owned wildlife preserve in West Texas to a private bidder or require that a winning bid allow public hunting, as the state’s land commissioner, Jerry Patterson, had insisted. Instead, the three-member board, which includes Mr. Patterson, chose to keep the two current bids open while giving the National Park Service 90 days to present an acquisition proposal on the 9,270-acre tract, the Christmas Mountains Ranch.

headline: Facebook Is Marketing Your Brand Preferences (With Your Permission)
text: FACEBOOK wants to put your face on advertisements for products that you like.

headline: Bronx: Standoff With Police Officers
text: A search for a suspected killer in the Bronx early yesterday turned into a six-hour hostage situation and ended with the arrest of Marlon Sanders, 31, of Queens, on charges of second-degree murder, the police said. Shortly after 3 a.m., detectives went to a home at 4445 Williamsbridge Road in Morris Park in search of Mr. Sanders, who was suspected of fatally shooting Jamal Leavy, 37, of Queens, on Monday, the police said. When they arrived at the home, Mr. Sanders had a woman and her two children captive, but they were removed unharmed about 9 a.m., the police said.

headline: Forced to Run Straight, a River Must Now Twist
text: KUSHIRO, Japan — In the early 1980s, engineers straightened out stretches of the Kushiro River, which had meandered some 100 miles under Hokkaido’s big sky here in northern Japan, flowing through green hill country and rural towns, winding through the nation’s largest wetland and this port city’s downtown before emptying into the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Sarkozy Throws Open His Arms to Bush, and U.S.
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — France’s president, Nicolas Sarkozy, burst onto the Washington scene on Tuesday, clearly reveling in his first official visit to the White House and asking the United States to embrace him as a friend.

headline: The Knicks Win a Good, Clean Fight
text: There was blood on the baseline and tension along the sidelines, as anyone might have expected when two teams that brawled ferociously 11 months ago reunited last night. But the blood came without violence and the tension was purely organic, produced by a tight, highly entertaining game on the Madison Square Garden court.

headline: Nets Build a Lead, Then Hold Off Hawks
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 6 — The Nets play their home games at a renamed, repainted arena that squats in the middle of a huge construction zone and is ringed by what seems like miles of temporary chain-link fence.

headline: Telling a Tale of Torment, Wordlessly
text: The poor stepchild of the movie industry, what we loosely call experimental film, tends to be banished to the fringes of festivals and out-of-the-way art houses. As a result, the opportunities for mainstream audiences to experience the unconventional are tragically few.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bush Urges Musharraf to Return Pakistan to Civilian Rule
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  President Bush telephoned President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan today to urge him to return his country to civilian rule as soon as possible.

headline: Former Beatle Linked to Member of M.T.A. Unit
text: It would seem improbable for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to be fodder for the British tabloids. But the London newspapers were in a tizzy yesterday with reports that Paul McCartney was having a romantic relationship with Nancy Shevell, who was appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki to the authority’s board in 2001.

headline: Within the Fed, Resistance to Further Rate Cuts
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — Even if the economy slows sharply in the final quarter of this year, some policy makers at the Federal Reserve are opposed to cutting rates again at their next meeting, in December.

headline: From a Palette of Rubble, a Misty Grove, With Room to Run
text: The first time he walked through the broken lot on South Oxford Street in Brooklyn, Emmanuel Thingue, a landscape architect for the Parks and Recreation Department, took the measure of the ground he had to work with. It added up to a bit more than an acre of rubble and weeds, a palette of 52,230 square feet that crunched beneath his shoes.

headline: Mum’s the Word: We Found a Greener Gas
text: PSYCHOLOGISTS and Wall Street traders have long known it: people and markets act on perception, whether it clashes with reality or not.

headline: Tonight, Patronizing Language. Enjoy.
text: DINING out nightly has taught me many things, including this: Nothing kills enjoyment like too many mentions of it.

headline: A Little Composition and a Little Archaeology
text: The ability to read the score of a complex orchestral composition is by no means a common skill. But even to the untrained eye, the manuscript of the Russian composer Alfred Schnittke’s Symphony No. 9 would speak volumes.

headline: Outrageous? He’s Heard That Before
text: Seattle

headline: Chemical Industry 1, Public Safety 0
text: Air travelers are asking for trouble if they show up for a flight with 3.5 ounces of shampoo in their carry-on bags. But the Department of Homeland Security has decided that the government should not even trouble chemical plants to account for the storage of anything under 2,500 pounds of deadly chlorine. The department’s new rules on reporting stockpiles of toxic chemicals, issued last week, have certainly made the industry happy. They should make the public worried.

headline: In Long Writers’ Strike, New York Would Fare Better Than Los Angeles, a Study Says
text: When television and movie writers started walking picket lines in Manhattan and Los Angeles on Monday, their bicoastal protest highlighted the role the two cities play as the hubs of America’s arts and entertainment economy.

headline: Report Links 3 Players to the Use of Steroids
text: Three more current or former major league baseball players have been connected in a published report to shipments of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: U.S. Prosecutors to Seek Indictment of Kerik
text: Federal prosecutors are scheduled to seek a grand jury indictment on Thursday of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, on a list of charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy counts, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the intentions of Prime Minister Agim Ceku of Kosovo to declare the country’s independence if agreement on its future is not reached with Serbia misstated Mr. Ceku’s age. He is 47, not 57.

headline: Hartford Senators Seek Subpoena Power in Inquiry
text: HARTFORD, Nov. 6  A six-member bipartisan Senate committee investigating the conduct of the former Republican minority leader voted on Tuesday to ask the full Senate for subpoena power in considering whether to expel him for asking a trash hauler with alleged mob ties to threaten his granddaughter’s husband.

headline: The Road to the White House Is Paved With Parodies
text: Trolling the Internet, Laura Bush stumbles across a Democratic candidate’s Web site and bursts into an exquisite song about the passion between members of rival factions. Tweaking the words to “Maria” from “West Side Story,” she sings: “The most beautiful name I ever heard — Obama! Obama, Obama, Obama!”

headline: Rosanne Cash to Have Brain Surgery
text: The singer Rosanne Cash, 52, the daughter of Johnny Cash, announced yesterday that she is to undergo brain surgery at New York Presbyterian Hospital for a “rare but benign” condition and must cancel the final four concerts of her current tour, The Associated Press reported. Manhattan Records, her label, said Ms. Cash, who lives in New York, is expected to make a full recovery and resume recording and touring in the spring to promote her Grammy-nominated album, “Black Cadillac.” Earlier her singing career was interrupted for more than two years by polyps on her vocal cords. ... The rocker Meat Loaf has canceled his European tour after developing a cyst on his vocal cords, Reuters reported. In a statement Meat Loaf, whose real name is Marvin Lee Aday, said: “It really breaks my heart not to be able to perform these shows. But I have to do what the doctors tell me so I can look forward to healing and coming back strong in 2008. Let me dispel any rumors before they start — I will be back.” The statement said most such cysts require surgery, but voice therapy is normally conducted to decide if it is necessary. Four to six weeks are needed to make a determination.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Soon, at a Nearby Theater, Opera From La Scala

headline: Dealer Repatriates Art
text: Italian officials, trumpeting another victory in their drive against the illegal traffic in antiquities, yesterday displayed eight Etruscan or Roman statues, bronze figurines and vases, above, they said were looted but had been returned by a New York art dealer, The Associated Press reported. The artifacts, valued at more than $500,000, were bought at auction by the dealer, Jerome Eisenberg of Royal Athena Gallery. Gen. Giovanni Nistri, who leads the art theft squad of the Italian national military police, said Mr. Eisenberg was unaware that the pieces had been looted, and when the Italian authorities showed him evidence, “he saw it was right to return them.”

headline: Cuts Urged in China’s and India’s Energy Growth
text: China’s and India’s surging fuel consumption poses a growing challenge to the world’s energy systems and, unless curbed, will strain global oil trade, push up prices and lead to substantially higher carbon dioxide emissions in coming decades, according to a report by an influential energy organization scheduled for release today.

headline: Stage’s Second Serving of Louisiana Gumbo
text: “The Brothers Size,” which opened at the Public Theater in January as part of its Under the Radar Festival, has reopened at the Public,  425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village; (212) 967-7555. It is running through Dec. 23. Following are excerpts from Jason Zinoman’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 20.

headline: Pakistani Lawyers Angered as Hope for Change Faded
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 6 — Behind the public rage of Pakistan’s lawyers, who protested for a second day on Tuesday, lies a long-smoldering resentment toward the country’s military president, who at first held out promise for educated, politically moderate Pakistanis, but steadily squandered their support.

headline: Correction: Industry Money Fans Debate on Fish
text: An article on Oct. 17, about a public health group that received money from the fishing industry and then recommended that women of childbearing age eat more fish despite fears of mercury contamination, referred imprecisely to the position of a Web site, realmercuryfacts.com, that also received money from the fishing industry. Although the Web site raises questions about studies that focus on the dangers of mercury in seafood, it does not directly dispute government warnings about mercury in seafood.

headline: Students Call Protest Punishment Too Harsh
text: CHICAGO, Nov. 6 — A school superintendent’s decision to suspend, and perhaps expel, about two dozen students who took part in a protest against the Iraq war at a suburban high school drew criticism Tuesday from the students and their parents, who demanded that their children be allowed to return to classes.

headline: A 1-Yard Catch, a 50-Yard Receiving Line for Jets’ Kowalewski
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 6 — Joe Kowalewski scored more style points than actual points with his first N.F.L. touchdown and the ensuing celebration.

headline: A Daughter Discovers Branches of the Family Tree Pruned by Her Father
text: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 6 — In a white-box living room in an apartment on lower St. Charles Avenue here, the dining table was set for a family party: plastic bowls of chips, dip and salsa; a plastic bag of sepia-toned family photographs waiting to be opened; and a copy of Bliss Broyard’s new book, “One Drop: My Father’s Hidden Life — A Story of Race and Family Secrets.”

headline: Military Bill Approved, but Without Iraq Increase
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  House and Senate negotiators approved a $459 billion military spending bill on Tuesday, but rejected a Republican bid to provide $70 billion more to continue fighting the war in Iraq without any restrictions.

headline: Senate Committee Approves Mukasey Nomination
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — The Senate Judiciary Committee voted on Tuesday to approve the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general despite opposition from most of the committee’s Democrats over Mr. Mukasey’s refusal to label a harsh interrogation technique used on terrorist suspects as torture.

headline: Causes of Death Are Linked to a Person’s Weight
text: About two years ago, a group of federal researchers reported that overweight people have a lower death rate than people who are normal weight, underweight or obese. Now, investigating further, they found out which diseases are more likely to lead to death in each weight group.

headline: CSX Lawyers Says They Cannot Find Key Witness in Asbestos Case
text: Lawyers for the CSX Transportation Corporation, which is fighting costly asbestos claims, say they have been unable to find a crucial witness in a case, a doctor whom they accuse of fabricating scores of medical evaluations.

headline: Life After Rodriguez May Include Cabrera
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 6 — The Yankees finally had their long-awaited summit with Scott Boras at the general managers meetings Tuesday. Boras was returning from a workout, drenched in sweat, and he shook hands with General Manager Brian Cashman near a bank of elevators. Then they went their separate ways.

headline: Ousted Chief Justice in Pakistan Urges Defiance
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 6 — As lawyers protested for a second day in Pakistan on Tuesday, the ousted chief justice of the country’s Supreme Court urged them to continue to defy de facto martial law imposed by the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Frank Viola, Leader in Sport of Racing Pigeons, Dies at 87
text: Frank Viola, one of the grand old men of a grand old New York sport — pigeon racing — died on Oct. 3 at his home in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn. He was 87.

headline: At 90, Biaggi Offers Reminders of Survival as Well as Service
text: When Mario Biaggi, the revered Bronx congressman, was about to be sentenced in a racketeering case in 1988, he declared in court that the hostile testimony and unflattering publicity were punishment enough.

headline: Fears Over Aftermath of Mexico Floods
text: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico, Nov. 6 — Many parts of this city remained underwater on Tuesday, more than a week after torrential rain swelled rivers that then burst their banks, as the authorities and residents expressed concern about the potential for looting and for outbreaks of disease.

headline: Conservation at the Touch of a Button
text: TALK about remote control.

headline: In Foster Care Review, Vows of Help and Vigilance
text: John B. Mattingly became New York City’s child welfare commissioner aiming to bring accountability to the dozens of private agencies the city paid hundreds of millions of dollars each year to care for foster children.

headline: Some Television Writer-Producers Side With Guild
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 — Hollywood writers and the studios that produce the most popular programs on television began tightening the screws on each other Tuesday, the second day of the first industrywide strike in nearly two decades.

headline: Taming the Guzzlers That Power the World Wide Web
text: BEHIND every Google search, direct deposit, MapQuest request and rant on a blog is a data center crammed with machines called servers and, behind them, a power plant.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about a lawsuit alleging that a former lawyer for the New York State court system was fired for accusing her superiors of unethical conduct misstated the jurisdiction of the First Department of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court. It covers the Bronx and Manhattan, not “most of New York City and Westchester.”

headline: Wiretapping and the Telecoms
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Trust in an Expert Is Unwise
text: A few years ago, an economics graduate student named Henry Schneider drove his dad’s old Subaru station wagon up to Montreal. He had heard about a Canadian consumer interest group that had done undercover investigations of auto-repair shops, and he wanted to try a more academic version of its experiment.

headline: Little-Known Entrepreneurs Putting China Near Top of Billionaires’ List
text: SHANGHAI, Nov. 6 — The United States has more billionaires than any other country: 415 by the last count of Forbes magazine.

headline: Conservative Authors Sue Publisher
text: Five authors have sued the parent company of Regnery Publishing, a Washington imprint of conservative books, charging that the company deprives its writers of royalties by selling their books at a steep discount to book clubs and other organizations owned by the same parent company.

headline: On a Greek Isle, Preserving Tradition
text: POROS, Greece

headline: Islanders Come Alive in Third and Rangers Falter on Road
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 6 — By the third period Tuesday night, Rangers Coach Tom Renney was starting to feel edgy about how his team was playing against the Islanders. Yes, the Rangers were nursing their familiar one-goal lead, and even when they gave it up, they took another one-goal lead.

headline: The Spirits of TV Past, Present and Future
text: No, Virginia, there may not be any new Christmas specials starring Eva Longoria as Slutty Santa and Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen as elves. And while many viewers may consider that potential consequence of the writers’ strike a cause for seasonal celebration, it’s not as merry a prospect as one might think.

headline: For Fiji Water, a Big List of Green Goals
text: Fiji Water, with annual sales of about $150 million, is but a drop in the bucket of the $15 billion domestic bottled-water industry. But little Fiji could make a big splash on the sustainability front.

headline: Deadly Fires Expose Disorder in Putin’s Russia
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 6 — Sergei Babayan was trapped. Minutes before, wisps of smoke had begun flowing through cracks in his classroom door at the private Moscow Institute of Government and Corporate Management.

headline: Toy With Date-Rape Drug Recalled
text: HONG KONG, Wednesday, Nov. 7 — A bead toy that just won an Australian Toy of the Year award was recalled by its manufacturer on Tuesday after media reports that a chemical in it turns into a powerful date-rape drug, GHB, when eaten.

headline: Ex-Worker at AT&T Fights Immunity Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  When Mark Klein, then an AT&T technician in San Francisco, stumbled on a secret room apparently reserved for the National Security Agency inside an AT&T switching center, he hardly expected to be caught up in a national debate over the proper balance between American civil liberties and national security.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about circulation declines in the newspaper industry misstated the overall decline in Sunday circulation. The decline was 3.5 percent, not 4.6 percent. (Sunday circulation dropped 4.6 percent for the top 25 newspapers by circulation; the 3.5 percent figure was for more than 600 newspapers for which numbers were available.)

headline: Death Toll in Afghan Bombing at 52
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 7 — The death toll from a suicide bombing in northern Afghanistan rose to 52 on Wednesday, making it the worst single suicide bombing in the country since 2001, government officials said.

headline: Pope Benedict Meets Saudi King at Vatican
text: ROME, Nov. 6 — Pope Benedict XVI and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia clasped hands at the Vatican on Tuesday in the first official meeting between a pope and a Saudi monarch, who is entrusted to protect Mecca, the birthplace of Muhammad and the center of the Islamic world.

headline: ‘Fidelio’: From Opera House to Parlor to Concert Hall
text: The year 1902 had no CDs or DVDs, but it did have arrangers. Into them music publishers poured symphonies, operas, string quartets and oratorios, all to be ground to a consistency suitable for parlor piano. Monday night’s parlor was the tiny performing space at the Austrian Cultural Forum, where Dennis Russell Davies and Maki Namekawa played Alexander Zemlinsky’s four-hand version of Beethoven’s “Fidelio.”

headline: High-Priced Oil Adds Volatility to Power Scramble
text: As the price of oil surges toward a symbolic milestone of $100 a barrel — hitting $96.70 yesterday — it is creating new winners and losers across the globe.

headline: What You Get for ...$500,000
text: Aiken, S.C.

headline: Enzo Biagi, 87, Journalist Fired in Italian Political Fight, Is Dead
text: MILAN, Nov. 6 (Bloomberg News) — Enzo Biagi, the enduringly popular Italian journalist whose criticism of Silvio Berlusconi during the 2001 election campaign got him ousted from state television when Mr. Berlusconi became prime minister, died Tuesday in Milan. He was 87.

headline: A More Direct Route to Spain
text: THE publicity pitch and chatter that attended the transformation of the not-so-old restaurant Ureña into the not-exactly-new restaurant Pamplona boiled down to something like this: the chef Alex Ureña gets real.

headline: Getting a Lower Price, for Repairs You Don’t Need
text: In his study of auto-repair shops, Henry Schneider varied what he told the mechanics in one important way. At half of the 40 Connecticut garages where he brought a Subaru station wagon for an inspection, he said that he and his (fictional) wife had just moved to town. At the other half, he said they were about to move to Chicago.

headline: New Delhi Air Quality Is Worsening, Group Says
text: NEW DELHI, Nov. 6 — Air quality in New Delhi has deteriorated significantly in the past two years, exposing the capital’s residents to heightened risk of a range of respiratory diseases, a leading environmental research group warned Tuesday.

headline: New Jersey Voters Defeat Stem Cell Measure
text: TRENTON, Nov. 6 — In a stunning defeat for Gov. Jon S. Corzine, New Jersey voters on Tuesday rejected a ballot measure that would have permitted the state to borrow $450 million for stem cell research.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A profile in Science Times yesterday about Col. John Holcomb, a trauma surgeon who heads the Army’s Institute of Surgical Research, misspelled the surname of a former military physician who is the associate director of critical care medicine at Washington Hospital Center. He is Dr. Andrew F. Shorr, not Schorr.

headline: Mrs. Giuliani, in Rare Solo Appearance, Campaigns Again
text: LEBANON, N.H., Nov. 6  Judith Giuliani returned to the campaign spotlight Tuesday to make a speech, one of the few without her husband at her side. At a breast cancer forum here, she pledged that a Giuliani administration would provide resources and support for people with cancer.

headline: G.M. Posts Its Biggest Quarterly Loss
text: DETROIT, Nov. 7 — General Motors reported a nearly $39 billion third-quarter loss today, its largest ever, after it took a huge noncash charge to write down deferred tax credits.

headline: Morgan Stanley May Be Next to Write Down Assets
text: Now it is Morgan Stanley’s turn.

headline: Job Bias Case Turns on Filing Right Form
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The age discrimination case that was argued before the Supreme Court on Tuesday turned on a hyper-technical issue that only an employment lawyer could love.

headline: Proposal Gives More Power to F.D.A.
text: Regulators would get more authority over drugs sold without a prescription under a bill by three Democrats. The proposal would give the Food and Drug Administration power to quickly ban marketing of over-the-counter products linked to potential safety risks, said the lawmakers, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Representatives Henry A. Waxman of California and Tom Allen of Maine.

headline: Pakistan’s General Anarchy
text: London

headline: 1937 Matisse Sells for $33.6 Million
text: Countering speculation that foreigners would emerge as the dominant buyers, Americans took home nearly half the art at Christie’s last night in the start to the fall auction season.

headline: Pat Robertson Endorses Giuliani for President
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani scored a coup today by winning the support of Pat Robertson, who, as one of the nation’s best-known televangelists, could help Mr. Giuliani reassure Republicans who are wary of his support for abortion rights and gay rights.

headline: Concert in North Korea
text: To the Editor:

headline: Your Ad Here: Web Surprise Hits ’08 Race
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — Visitors to Gay.com can sign up to find the perfect dating partner, advice on sex and how-to articles on same-sex marriage and parenting.

headline: Abolish Electoral College
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Printed Collection of Heroes Comics
text: The first 34 chapters of the continuing online comic book devoted to NBC’s “Heroes,” a series about ordinary people dealing with extraordinary abilities, will be released today as a hardcover collection. The stories provide additional details about the characters’ backgrounds. The collection, published by DC Comics, includes an introduction by Masi Oka, the actor who plays the time-traveling Hiro. The book, which sells for $29.99, is available with a cover by Alex Ross or Jim Lee, two of the comic-book industry’s most popular artists. The latest chapter of the online “Heroes” saga can be found at nbc.com/heroes/novels.

headline: A Gallery’s Money Crisis, and Shaken Trust
text: The artist Paul Resika remembers what someone who is well connected in the art world told him one day last spring as rumors were beginning to swirl about financial trouble at the Salander-O’Reilly Galleries. He also remembers his reaction.

headline: Senator Questioning Ministries on Spending
text: Senator Charles E. Grassley, the ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, is investigating six prominent evangelistic ministries to determine whether they have illegally used donations to finance opulent lifestyles.

headline: A College Is Stalked by an Attitude
text: Like all truly scary horror stories, the tale told in Adrienne Kennedy’s “Ohio State Murders” leaves a lasting chill in the bones. Hours after seeing this short, sharp, quietly hypnotic play about an infanticide that ruptures a Midwestern winter in the 1950s, you might find yourself looking anxiously over your shoulder or starting awake with an unsettling thought or image in your head.

headline: Gay Muslims Find Freedom, of a Sort, in the U.S.
text: SAN FRANCISCO — About 15 people marched alongside the Muslim float in this city’s notoriously fleshy Gay Pride Parade earlier this year, with various men carrying the flags of Egypt, Lebanon, Palestine and Turkey and even Iran’s old imperial banner.

headline: Preservation’s Progress
text: Lindsborg, Kan.

headline: BlackRock Chief Is Said to Be Meeting Over Merrill
text: Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of BlackRock and the leading candidate to take over the job as head of Merrill Lynch, has met with the executive search firm responsible for filling the brokerage firm’s top seat, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

headline: Toyota Reports Strong Profits
text: TOKYO, Nov. 7 — Another quarter of higher profits at Toyota, Japan’s largest automaker, shows the company’s growth remains in high gear despite soaring global fuel prices and signs of an economic slowdown in its biggest market, the United States.

headline: House Approves Ban on Anti-Gay Discrimination
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 — The House approved a bill this evening granting broad protections against discrimination in the workplace for gay men, lesbians and bisexuals, a measure that supporters praised as the most important civil rights legislation since the adoption of the Americans with Disabilities Act in 1990 but that opponents said would result in unnecessary lawsuits.

headline: M.L.B. Takes First Step to Add Instant Replay
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 6  With a 25-5 vote, general managers took the first step Tuesday to add instant replay to baseball games. The vote was a significant departure from previous votes at general managers meetings, where the issue had the support of, at best, half of those present.

headline: Terrorism Raids Net 20 Suspects
text: Twenty suspected Islamic militants were arrested around Europe in an operation led by the Italian police to break up what it said was a cell recruiting suicide bombers for Iraq and Afghanistan. Among arrests in Britain, France and Portugal, the Italian authorities said they had arrested 11 men in northern Italy, most of them Tunisians. While the authorities said the group did not appear to be planning attacks inside Italy, they said they confiscated Al Qaeda manuals for making explosives, remote detonators, poisons and instructions on guerrilla techniques. Last month, Spain arrested six North Africans suspected of recruiting bombers to go to Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Sidewalks of New York Become Premium Space
text: If you think New York’s sidewalks seem more crowded than ever, you may be right: in some areas, there is less sidewalk square footage to go around.

headline: Test to Guide Heart Treatment Inconclusive
text: A diagnostic test intended to identify patients who should receive heart defibrillators did not produce conclusive data, according to initial results from a clinical trial presented yesterday at the meeting of the American Heart Association.

headline: Belgium: New No-Government Record
text: Belgium broke its own record for the longest period without a government as tensions continued among the country’s leaders, divided by language. Almost five months since national elections on June 10, Belgium marked 149 days without a government, beating a previous record set in 1988. As the deadlock continues, speculation is mounting that political divisions between the Flemish, who speak a form of Dutch and make up two-thirds of the population, and the Walloons, who speak French, could lead to Belgium’s splitting up.

headline: A Firsthand Experience Before Decision on Torture
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — The debate over torture here can get heated, as it did this month when a dispute over the legal status of waterboarding threatened to sink the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general. Still, it usually remains a matter of strictly abstract legal analysis.

headline: Protecting a Wild Patch of City Marshland
text: “Simply the last best unprotected New York City coastal wetland,” raved a coalition of 20 environmental groups.

headline: Brooklyn: Man Charged After Fatal Crash
text: A Queens man was arrested yesterday after having struck and killed a pedestrian in Brooklyn about 5 a.m., the police said. The man, David Aldarondo, 59, of Ozone Park, was charged with criminally negligent homicide, speeding and running a red light, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney said. The police said that Mr. Aldarondo, westbound on Atlantic Avenue, struck a pedestrian, Lillian Mustapha, 63, of East New York, at the Crescent Street intersection. She was pronounced dead at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said.

headline: What’s Black and White and Made in Queens?
text: “Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037” follows the painstaking yearlong process of building and fine-tuning a handmade nine-foot concert grand piano in the Steinway company’s factory in Astoria, Queens. A paean to the rewards of old-fashioned craftsmanship in an age of mechanization, the film, directed by Ben Niles, amounts to a de facto infomercial for Steinway & Sons, the 150-year-old company that is the biggest name in the high-end piano business. Steinway produces about 2,000 pianos a year, compared with the approximately 100 a day by other companies, none of whose names are mentioned.

headline: Job Opening: State Treasurer. Pay: Not Much for an Executive. Burdens: Huge.
text: TRENTON, Nov. 6  Gov. Jon S. Corzine may soon need to hang a help-wanted sign outside the treasurer’s office.

headline: New Class(room) War: Teacher vs. Technology
text: Halfway through the semester in his market research course at Roanoke College last fall, only moments after announcing a policy of zero tolerance for cellphone use in the classroom, Prof. Ali Nazemi heard a telltale ring. Then he spotted a young man named Neil Noland fumbling with his phone, trying to turn it off before being caught.

headline: The Dawn of E2K in India
text: New Delhi

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article and picture caption in some editions on Saturday about a deadly collision on Interstate 95 in Connecticut involving a tanker truck and five other vehicles misidentified the location of the accident. It was near Exit 75, not Exit 47.

headline: A Basic Pie: No Oven Required
text: NOT long ago, toppings for pizza were becoming unbearably fancy — hoisin-slathered duck, or fontina and truffles — or just ridiculous (you’ve seen the ones with pasta?). Pizza threatened to become something other than pizza. Fortunately, that trend has reversed.

headline: Correction: Off the Menu
text: A listing in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about Elementi, a restaurant in Brooklyn, misidentified the owner and the restaurant where the chef previously worked, and misspelled the chef’s given name. Elementi is owned by Roy and Mallory Rutledge — not by the chef, Camillo (not Camilo) Bassani. Mr. Bassani previously worked at the restaurant Esca, not Cipriani.

headline: A Model for Health Care That Pays for Quality
text: Seeing low fees for family doctors as a weak link in the nation’s health care system, some big employers and health insurers are seeking new ways to pay doctors to reward high-quality medical care.

headline: Radioactive Nimby: No One Wants Nuclear Waste
text: WÜRENLINGEN, Switzerland

headline: Kucinich Offers Bill to Impeach Cheney
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — It is hard to know which effort has longer odds, the bid by Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, Democrat of Ohio, to become president of the United States, or his bid to unseat Vice President Dick Cheney by impeaching him.

headline: M.I.T. Sues Frank Gehry, Citing Flaws in Center He Designed
text: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has sued the architect Frank Gehry and a construction company, claiming that “design and construction failures” in the institute’s $300 million Stata Center resulted in pervasive leaks, cracks and drainage problems that have required costly repairs.

headline: Calendar
text: Long Island Celebration

headline: A Chance to Meet (Four-Footed) Cheesemakers
text: TO explain why she climbed on to a charter bus on Essex Street at 8:30 a.m. on a recent Sunday morning, when the Lower East Side was virtually deserted, Kristina Angelozzi, a clothing designer for the Gap, said, “We don’t get field trips as adults.”

headline: $3 Billion More Set for Hurricane Rebuilding
text: Congressional appropriations committees agreed to add $3 billion to the $7.5 billion federally financed program to rebuild hurricane-damaged houses in Louisiana. State officials said that without increased aid, the program, known as the Road Home, would run out of money in January, before an expected 163,000 applicants had all received grants of up to $150,000.

headline: Weekly Wrap: Ripping Up the Ravens
text: The Fifth Down’s contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

headline: Facebook’s Next Privacy Problem
text: I think Facebook’s new Social Ad system could be brilliant, but the company may well be in for a storm of user protest. And I’m perplexed about why, after all the trouble they had last year, they aren’t being more sensitive.

headline: Facebook Everywhere
text: The most important bit of news at Facebook’s press conference yesterday was what they didn’t say out loud: Once the company gets the bugs out of its system for social ads on its own site, it will likely create a network to use its data to display advertising on other sites.

headline: British Choose Most Absurd Laws
text: A poll ranks Britain’s most absurd laws, as reported by the BBC:

headline: All Six ‘Rocky’ Films in 10 Seconds
text: Yo, Rocky’s been doin’ some speed woik on YouTube.

headline: For European Firms, the U.S. Is The Promised Land of Wind Power
text: Desire to tap the United States market for wind energy has sparked a round of dealmaking by European firms. While setting up shop in the United States may seem counterintuitive, given that the European Union has taken the lead on many climate change issues, the reasoning is fairly straightforward.

headline: Financial Ground Has Shifted Under a Record Deal
text: The record price paid in January for the 41-story aluminum-clad office tower at 666 Fifth Avenue – $1.8 billion – was breathtaking, even by the standards of the heady Midtown Manhattan commercial real estate market.

headline: As Chinese Companies Float I.P.O.’s, Billionaires Emerge
text: The United States has more billionaires than any other country: 415 by the last count of Forbes magazine. No. 2, and closing fast? China, with more than 100, according to the widely watched Hurun Report.

headline: Commerzbank Names New C.E.O.
text: Commerzbank named a new chief executive Tuesday and said its total write-downs related to the subprime crisis in the United States were 337 million euros ($494 million) during the second and third quarters, more than expected.

headline: Nasdaq Said to Be in Deal for Philadelphia Exchange
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market has entered into a preliminary agreement to buy the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for $650 million, according to news reports.

headline: Wall St. Bonuses Likely to Shrink
text: Wall Street bonuses may be the latest victim of the subprime mortgage collapse and the tight credit market. Over all, bonuses are expected to be flat to down 15 percent, according to compensation experts and Wall Street executives.

headline: Brazil Raids Banks in Money Laundering Probe
text: Police detained 19 people Tuesday for allegedly taking part in a scheme to help large Brazilian companies evade taxes by laundering money through UBS, Credit Suisse and the American International Group.

headline: Republicans Raise Privacy Concerns Over Google Deal
text: Representative Joe Barton, the senior Republican on the House Commerce Committee, and other GOP lawmakers are apparently having second thoughts about Google‘s $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick and are calling for a hearing into the privacy aspects of the proposed merger.

headline: TCV Raises $3 Billion Fund
text: Technology Crossover Ventures, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm, said Tuesday it closed this year’s largest tech-focused investment fund at $3 billion.

headline: Time Warner Is Said to Tie Bewkes’ Pay to Stock Price
text: Time Warner is planning to tie a large portion of the compensation it plans to pay its next chief executive to its share price performance, The New York Post reported.

headline: SMG to Raise $200 Million in Rights Issue
text: SMG, a Scottish broadcasting company, will raise 95.1 million pounds ($200 million) in an attempt to lower its debt load and avert a fire sale of Virgin Radio.

headline: Cox Says S.E.C. Is Examining Banks’ Subprime Disclosures
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking at whether banks made proper disclosures when announcing their investments in subprime-mortgage products, the agency’s chairman, Christopher Cox, said on Wednesday.

headline: Carlyle Raises First Infrastructure Fund
text: The Carlyle Group said it had raised its first fund to invest in infrastructure projects and received equity commitments totaling $1.15 billion.

headline: Swiss Life Sells Private Bank for $1.65 Billion
text: The long awaited next step in consolidating Switzerland’s private banks came Wednesday morning as Swiss Life announced the 1.87 billion Swiss franc ($1.65 billion) sale of Banca del Gottardo to BSI.

headline: Freddie Mac Ex-C.E.O. to Pay $16.4 Million in Settlement
text: The government on Tuesday reached a $16.4 million settlement with Freddie Mac‘s former chief executive for his role in the mortgage finance company’s multibillion-dollar accounting scandal.

headline: TomTom Sweetens Offer for Tele Atlas
text: A navigation device maker, TomTom, raised its bid for Tele Atlas, the last remaining independent maker of maps for navigation devices, on Wednesday to $4.2 billion (2.9 billion euros), topping a rival offer from Garmin.

headline: BNP Hires New Hedge Fund Executives
text: The French bank BNP Paribas is expanding its hedge fund services divisions in New York, Hong Kong and London.

headline: Yahoo Gets Lift from Alibaba
text: Yahoo has been hit hard lately from assorted pundits for everything from falling behind Google, to not getting a stake in Facebook, to colluding with Chinese authorities in the arrest of a journalist.

headline: Sullivan & Cromwell Matches Cravath Bonuses
text: Sullivan & Cromwell on Monday became the latest firm to match the bonus range announced last week by Cravath, Swaine & Moore, which said it would pay both year-end and one-time “special” bonuses to associates totalling $45,000 for first-years and going up to $110,000 for senior associates.

headline: Jabre Capital Looks to Raise $728 Million for New Fund
text: Jabre Capital, the hedge fund group founded by a former trader at GLG Partners, is raising a new 500 million euro ($728 million) fund.

headline: Hillary Clinton on Immigration
text: At a town hall in Iowa, Hillary Clinton was queried on the issue of drivers licenses for illegal immigrants and border security.

headline: ‘War and Peace’ on the Campaign Trail
text: I reached the final page Tuesday morning on a plane home from Des Moines, after a few days of chasing presidential candidates. Squeezing chapters of Volume IV between campaign events, I found the novel bleeding into my observations of the politicians who would be president. John McCain, with his military breeding and his distaste for sugar-coating unpleasant news, reminded me of a voluble Kutuzov. John Edwards, who has lately amped up his populist fervor (as my colleague Jeff Zeleny recounted in Tuesday’s paper) displays definite Denisov tendencies.

headline: Armani Welcomes Investors, but Not Private Equity
text: The Italian designer Giorgio Armani told Reuters on Tuesday that he was open to a tie-up with a wealthy “fashion lover” or another investor. He also told the newswire that he had received an offer from Beiersdorf, the German maker of Nivea cosmetics, two years ago, adding to current talk of a merger amid a flurry of deals in the fashion world.

headline: Citigroup Role Will Be Test, Even for Mr. Fix-It
text: Citigroup, reeling from its exposure to billions in assets backed by subprime mortgages, has appointed a triage team led by one of Wall Street’s best-known fix-it men.

headline: For Citigroup’s New Head, Focus Is Subprime Tangle
text: Until Sunday, Robert E. Rubin collected over $18 million a year as Wall Street’s ultimate hands-off executive. On Monday, he had to roll up his sleeves.

headline: Minority Female Associates’ Early Exits
text: It’s no secret that nowadays most associates don’t plan on spending their entire legal career at one law firm. But of all associates, minority females are the most likely to head for the exits, according to a study by The Minority Law Journal.

headline: The Early Word: Democrats Gain Seats at State Level
text: Election Day 2007 saw a few traditionally red states turn a bit purple. Republican incumbent Ernie Fletcher lost the Kentucky governorship to Steve Beshear, and Democrats won a slim majority of seats in the state Senate of Virginia, which is expected to be up for grabs in 2008. Republicans still control the Virginia House, says the Washington Post:

headline: BlackRock Chief Is Said to Be Meeting Over Merrill
text: Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of BlackRock and the leading candidate to take over the job as head of Merrill Lynch, has met with the executive search firm responsible for filling the brokerage firm’s top seat, The New York Times reported.

headline: Morgan Stanley May Be Next to Write Down Assets
text: Now it is Morgan Stanley‘s turn.

headline: Ousted Citi Executive Todd Thomson Fires Back
text: Todd S. Thomson, the former Citigroup executive whose January ouster was the talk of Wall Street and the tabloids, says that Charles Prince, until recently Citi’s chief executive, may have been part of a campaign to smear his reputation.

headline: Dashed Hopes for Ticket Holders
text: Imagine waiting to see “Saturday Night Live” for two years — only to find out that a writers’ strike has put the program on hold.

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Peter Robinson
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

headline: Filling in the Leadership Gaps at Merrill and Citi
text: Citigroup and Merrill Lynch are in uneviable positions right now, scrambling to find new leaders at the same time.

headline: In Local Elections, No Great Backlash Against Democrats
text: Democrats declared that Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to give driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants had not proved to be the electoral boon Republicans had hoped it would be in local elections. Though Democrats appeared to expand their majority in the Legislature in Suffolk County, Republicans were not ready to concede a pivotal Nassau County legislative race, and pointed to significant victories in several county races upstate as evidence of a Republican resurgence in the state.

headline: Chris Anderson Is My Hero
text: Chris Anderson, editor of Wired Magazine and author of “The Long Tail,” sent the public relations community into a tizzy last week when he published a list of e-mail addresses of publicists he never wants to hear from again.

headline: Purging the rottenness
text: Robert Samuelson, now:

headline: Let’s Not Even Talk About It
text: “The House voted Tuesday to stop Rep. Dennis Kucinich’s, D-Ohio, effort to bring up a debate on impeaching Vice President Dick Cheney,” CNN reports, in a manner apparently dedicated to taking all the fun out of one of the more amusing Capitol dustups in recent memory.

headline: Denver Voters Set ‘Lowest Priority’ for Cops: Pot
text: Voters were in a cost-conscious mood this Election Day, rejecting several ballot measures to spend more taxpayer money in new areas, like stem-cell research in New Jersey.

headline: For Pay, It’s Still Good to Be Goldman
text: When speculation about a buyer for Bear Stearns cropped up a few months ago, several possibilities were mentioned, including a Chinese bank, Wachovia and even Warren E. Buffett. (The struggling investment bank has since unveiled a joint partnership with China’s Citic Securities.)

headline: The Ad Network Campaign
text: Advertising networks hit the front page of the Times today, and not for all the money they are making. Jim Rutenberg reports that political campaigns are increasingly using ad networks in the current campaign.

headline: Pat Robertson Endorses Giuliani; Brownback Goes for McCain
text: The televangelist Pat Robertson endorsed Rudolph W. Giuliani today at the National Press Club in Washington, providing the former New York City Mayor with a big symbolic boost as he tries to allay the concerns of Christian conservatives about his candidacy.

headline: In Trouble in Islamabad
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Hunting down the Berlin Wall
text: A remaining piece at Bernauer Strasse

headline: Wednesday’s Links: A Viking Conquerer
text: Adrian Peterson’s single-game record 296 yards in the Vikings’ win against the Chargers has to be the story of the week; the Minnesota rookie is on a feverish pace. …ESPN.com’s Tuesday Morning Quarterback praises the singular concentration displayed by the Vikings’ rookie. …MSNBC.com’s Mike Cimini says Peterson is without a doubt the best back in the league. …And, just for some perspective, the yards are adding up for Peterson, and so are the dollars.

headline: AOL’s New Plan: It’s Not Working
text: Randy Falco, AOL’s chief executive, is betting the entire AOL franchise on building up its advertising network. The Time Warner results released this morning show his horse is slowing down.

headline: Is Robertson for Rudy?
text: Mitt Romney got the nod from Moral Majority co-founder Paul Weyrich the other day, but Rudy Giuliani seems to have one-upped him: NBC News reports “that religious conservative leader Pat Robertson will endorse Republican presidential hopeful Rudy Giuliani at a news conference this morning in Washington, D.C.”

headline: Serving in Tongues
text: My Critic’s Notebook today about the stilted language used by servers (and others) in restaurants is one of those stories that arose from countless conversations with friends, many of which the friends themselves began, about the little locutions that pop up repeatedly and become annoying.

headline: With Investigation Winding Down, Mitchell Sets Deadline
text: George J. Mitchell, who is leading Major League Baseball's investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs, has set Saturday as the final day he will accept documentary evidence and conduct interviews, according to a lawyer familiar with the investigation. The deadline was first reported by cbsnews.com.

headline: Log Off and Get to Work
text: Turns out your bosses don’t want you updating your social networking page at the office.

headline: A Deadly School Shooting, This Time in Finland
text: UPDATED, 4:34 p.m.

headline: Wednesday Morning Kickoff
text: SI.com’s Stewart Mandel says style points were not a factor when he put L.S.U. at the top of his latest power rankings.

headline: In Big Map Deals, Google Can’t Be Found
text: Google, where are you?

headline: Bloomberg-Backed Candidate Is Unseated in Virginia
text: Democrats seized control of the State Senate in Virginia on Tuesday. Why might a New Yorker care? As we reported last week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg flew to northern Virginia to endorse State Senator Jeannemarie Devolites Davis, a moderate Republican who represents Fairfax County. Ms. Davis — whose moderate, pro-gun-control positions were lauded by Mr. Bloomberg — lost to a Democratic challenger, J. Chapman Petersen. As Ian Urbina reports today, the Democratic gains in Virginia could signal that the state is becoming a battleground in next year’s presidential election.

headline: Falafel!
text: Amazing.

headline: Tunic Video
text: A video from "Sympathy for the Devil," a show which traces the intersection between images and sounds from the Velvet Underground and beyond.

headline: A Note on the Translation
text: Without translation (linguistic and cultural), there would be no intellectual life as we know it. Surely the important point to make about the new translation of Tolstoy is that it has inspired a lot of people to read or re-read “War and Peace,” as evidenced by this very forum.

headline: Too Easy on the Aristocracy
text: Well before you get to the twilight of “War and Peace,” it dawns on you: what is often acclaimed (rightly in my view) as one of the greatest novels ever written is really about which of two previously married male aristocrats will get the young aristocratic girl. In the end, Count Bezukhov, otherwise known as Pierre, a bastard, obese, weak, wins the hand of Natasha, the self-centered “little princess,” while Prince Andrei Bolkonsky, her other suitor, perishes from war wounds.

headline: Some Advice for the Ladies
text: Online video is excellent for how-to’s and demos. Not only is it useful to SEE — in moving images — what exactly hands should do when they bone a chicken or rewire a lamp; it’s also invaluable to witness the attitude and style of a competent person pulling off this stuff.

headline: Iraq War: The Heartland Speaks
text: How does middle America feel about the Iraq War? Yesterday’s election gave a good indication, in the results of two referendums in Montana.

headline: The Lost World Series Baseballs
text: When Red Sox closer Jonathan Papelbon struck out Colorado’s Seth Smith to end the 2007 World Series last month, catcher Jason Varitek immediately stuck the ball in his back pocket. Then he gave the ball to Papelbon sometime during the celebration, and now it is gone.

headline: Behind Brownback’s McCain Endorsement
text: Senator Sam Brownback, who met with both Mr. Romney and Mr. Giuliani before deciding the endorse Mr. McCain, said that it was the Arizona Senator’s long record of consistent support of issues important toChristian voters ­ – particularly on abortion ­- that ultimately led to his decision.

headline: The (Warming) World Is Not Flat
text: The world may be flat in some respects, as my colleague Tom Friedman has pointed out.

headline: When Doctors Take Their Own Advice
text: For years, when Minnesota physician Dr. Chris Balgobin saw patients with diabetes and high blood pressure, he found it difficult to counsel them about losing weight and exercise.

headline: A Cure for Buyer’s Remorse
text: We have further proof of your superior wisdom. I asked if getting a 30-day money-back guarantee would diminish buyer’s remorse, and Lab readersnot only guessed the answer from personal experience but found the research to back up their hunches.

headline: In Hollywood, Shows of Solidarity
text: Some prominent show runners — “the writer-producers who fill multiple roles at the helm of television programs” — are siding with the Writers Guild of America.

headline: Lampert’s Wrong-Way Bet on Citi
text: In August, a hedge fund controlled by Edward S. Lampert, the value-oriented billionaire investor, disclosed that it had built up a $1.3 billion stake in Citigroup, the beleaguered financial giant. At the time, Mr. Lampert’s quickly growing stake, backed by his reputation for finding bargains, prompted some to wonder whether Citi’s battered stock was ready for a rebound.

headline: 'No Country for Old Men'
text: A. O. Scott reviews "No Country for Old Men," the new thriller from Joel and Ethan Coen.

headline: Gentrification as ‘Benign Ethnic Cleansing’
text: If there is a leitmotif this year among scholars and writers who study New York, it is the reshaping of Manhattan by the forces of wealth and gentrification — and the angst accompanying those forces. There have been books on the “suburbanization” of New York, panel discussions on whether the city has lost its soul and reports about the flurry of bank branch construction.

headline: Fried Mayonnaise
text: Life isn’t fair. Frozen deep-fried Twinkies are ridiculed as the confection of county-fair waddle-butts, while fried mayonnaise — fried mayonnaise! — is extolled as haute cuisine and a melding of high science and art to boot, as The Times reports this week. So anyway, inquiring real or potential waddle-butts wanna know, how can we whip some up? It’s tricky, as Esquire notes on a visit to Wylie Dufresne’s New York restaurant WD-50:

headline: The God Couples
text: Obviously, commentary on Pat Robertson’s endorsement of Rudy Giuliani is not confined to conservative head scratching. Joe Sudbay of AmericaBlog typifies the disgusted amusement to be found on the left: “One of the pillars of the anti-gay, anti-abortion theocratic community, Pat Robertson, is supporting the thrice married mayor who supports a woman’s right to have an abortion. … Apparently, Robertson and his ilk only challenge Democrats on social issues. Robertson is nothing more than a political hack. Let’s stop pretending there are any morals behind anything he does.”

headline: Send Us Your Late-Night Monologue Jokes!
text: Sure, the TV writers are on strike, but the human comedy isn’t. Send us your newsy jokes &#224 la Leno, Letterman or O’Brien (via the comment link below) and we’ll post the best here if they’re any good. We may even publish some in the paper. Include your name, town and email address. Morally conflicted? Not to worry about crossing picket lines: We won’t actually put your jokes on TV. You won’t even get paid!

headline: Obama Talks About Working Families
text: BETTENDORF, Iowa – As Senator Barack Obama sets off on a two-day Iowa bus tour here today, one goal sits near the top of his agenda: Reminding voters that he understands the daily struggles of working families.

headline: On YouTube, Creative Venting
text: As the writers’ strike enters day three, some writers and producers are taking to the video sharing site YouTube to express their frustrations.

headline: Federal Prosecutors Plan to Seek Charges Against Kerik
text: Federal prosecutors are scheduled to seek a grand jury indictment on Thursday of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on a list of charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

headline: Pakistani Unrest: The Internet Edition
text: General Pervez Musharraf’s ruthless repression in Pakistan may have silenced TV and radio stations in his nation, but the Internet is buzzing.

headline: Why Mack Isn’t Going Anywhere
text: Wednesday P.M.: Morgan Stanley said that it would take an additional $3.7 billion write-down related to its exposure to subprime mortgages for the two months ended Oct. 31. The results would apply to the fourth quarter, the bank said in a statement.

headline: Mayor Grapples With How to Memorialize Post-9/11 Deaths
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has already reached at least one conclusion about how to memorialize people like James Zadroga, whose death has been linked to 9/11, although he did not die on that day. Their names, the mayor said, do not belong with those around the voids at the memorial.

headline: Federal Prosecutors Plan to Seek Charges Against Kerik
text: Federal prosecutors are scheduled to seek a grand jury indictment on Thursday of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on a list of charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy, according to people who have been briefed on the case. William K. Rashbaum has the details in City Room.

headline: Jets Wave Bye
text: The Jets waved goodbye to their season a few losses ago, but still received a break from the schedule gods this week. After six straight losses, the Jets will not lose again this weekend. Of course, they don’t play, either, during their bye week.

headline: Formula One’s Next Star
text: It’s Adrian Sutil. Really. People have been talking about the reckless German driver since Lewis Hamilton dropped his name in a recent interview with Autosport. In case you missed it, this is what he said:

headline: No Disrespect Intended
text: Sheryl Gay Stolberg, who covers the White House for The Times, gets a steady stream of complaints from readers about a curious issue.

headline: Ron Paul Wins Straw Vote in New York
text: Ron Paul Wins! That’s the headline today after the first New York State Republican Straw Poll. Clearly, after raking in a record amount of money the other day, Mr. Paul is on a roll. He seems to have out-organized his fellow Republicans — on Rudolph W. Giuliani’s home turf.

headline: $25,000 for a Hot Chocolate?
text: What would you do with $25,000? Buy a new Toyota Camry? Pay for six months at Harvard?

headline: Rubin to Back Clinton
text: Aside from Al Gore, the biggest presidential endorsement prize that is still up for grabs from the Clinton administration is Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary and deficit hawk who remains one of the most admired economic stewards in Democratic politics.

headline: Monday Ratings Update
text: Nielsen delayed the release yesterday of its overnight ratings for Monday due to processing problems. Final numbers issued this morning indicate that ABC came in first for the night, followed by CBS in second place and then NBC and Fox, which tied for third.

headline: ‘NCIS’ Beats ‘Dancing’ and ‘House’
text: CBS’s five-year-old series “NCIS” earned its largest audience ever on Tuesday, surpassing even the night’s usual leaders including ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” and Fox’s “House.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the Navy-themed crime drama delivered 18.3 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour, just more than the 18.1 million who tuned in at 9 p.m. for “House.”

headline: Probation Recommended for Oklahoma State Player Guilty of Sexual Assault
text: Updated: A jury recommended Wednesday that the Oklahoma State sophomore linebacker Chris Collins receive probation for the aggravated sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl three years ago, Bowie County District Attorney Bobby Lockhart said. Collins will be sentenced on Dec. 10.

headline: Pakistan Protest Drama Unfolds Online
text: As emergency rule was declared in Pakistan on Saturday, Awab Alvi handed over his blog, Teeth Maestro, to an outsider, and he urged fellow Pakistani bloggers to do the same. “We cannot risk it here,” he wrote, referring to the government’s curbs on the media.

headline: Robertson Endorses Giuliani
text: Pat Robertson said he believed "the overriding issue before the American people is the defense of our population from the blood lust of Islamic terrorists."

headline: Answers About New York Foster Care, Part 1
text: Following is a first set of answers from Benjamin Weiser and Leslie Kaufman of The Times, who, along with a panel of experts, answered readers’ questions about foster care from Nov. 7-12. In a series called “A History of Neglect” [Part 1 | Part 2 | Part 3], Ms. Kaufman and Mr. Weiser reported this week on New York City’s foster care system.

headline: Green Car Award: None of the Above
text: LOS ANGELES — One of the highlights of the Los Angeles Auto Show is the presentation of the Green Car of the Year Award. The 2008 winner is scheduled to be announced Nov. 16 during press previews at the 2007 show. After looking over the field of candidates for this year’s award, I’m shifting my rating of the event from highlight to lowlight.
