headline: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly of the Champions League
text: The European Champions League should, in theory, feature some of the most exciting and competitive soccer games on the continent. And often it does. Each team is top of its domestic league (or near it) and fields some of the most exciting players in the world.

headline: A Winning Bathroom Configuration
text: The plumbers started yesterday, so we’re under pressure to resolve how the guest bathroom will be configured. They need to know where to put water lines and drains. (They also need us to tell them where the sink, dishwasher and ice maker will be located in the kitchen. We’ll give you an update on Friday.)

headline: Obama’s Travel Travails
text: WAPELLO, Iowa — When Senator Barack Obama stopped for an ice cream cone and a little lunch in this eastern Iowa town this afternoon, he stopped for a moment to discuss the weighty topic of his travel travails Tuesday, when his private jet mistakenly landed in the wrong Iowa city.

headline: Con Edison Is Ordered to Return $18 Million to Customers
text: The New York State Public Service Commission ordered Consolidated Edison today to return $18 million to its customers for failing to provide safe and reliable service in 2006, a year that included a nine-day blackout that began in Long Island City, Queens, and affected 170,000 people. The highly critical decision could affect Con Edison’s request for a substantial increase in electric rates.

headline: Darth Gore to Senator Obama: I Am Your Father
text: Barack Obama is Luke Skywalker, Hillary Clinton is Princess Leia, Rudolph Giuliani is Han Solo and Mitt Romney looks like the PackBot from iRobot, but is probably R2D2. I don’t know what it all means, but Israeli humor site AniBoom’s new animated series, Race for the White House, is worth a look – particularly if you are starved for laughs during the ongoing Hollywood writer’s strike.

headline: 1830s Warehouse in Lower Manhattan Is Demolished
text: History is disappearing by the inch today on Pearl Street.

headline: Right! That’s Why the Kids Had No School
text: Oh, yeah, there was an election yesterday. Or so I’m told. The Times’s Ian Urbina runs down the results here highlighting the fact that “dogged by political scandal in his first term, Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, a Republican, lost his bid for re-election yesterday to Steve Beshear.”

headline: Only Mama Knows This Is the No. 3 ‘Least Caffeinated City’
text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: Tallying the Votes in Tuesday’s Election
text: Following are the preliminary vote tallies, by borough, of Tuesday’s general election in New York City, as provided today by the City Board of Elections. The official election results will not be certified for several weeks. In each race below, the names of the winner or winners are in bold; in races where the same candidate ran on multiple party lines, the party line on which the candidate won the most votes is the one noted in bold. Where voters could select more than one candidate, the number of vacancies is indicated.Citywide: Proposal One

headline: For Some Shows, The Strike Offers a Silver Lining
text: For a few new television series, the writers’ strike may actually be a good thing.

headline: New York Lawyers Take Stand on Pakistan Crisis
text: New York City has some of the most hard-charging, influential and learned lawyers anywhere. But even with their collective clout, it is not clear whether they can do much to exert influence on the political crisis in Pakistan. Today, the New York City Bar presented a letter to Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, urging him to reverse his decision to fire justices of the Supreme Court, impose emergency rule, crack down on protesters and detain lawyers and other activists without charges.

headline: Ad Networks Are the New Dot-Coms
text: It’s no longer enough to have a Web site. Blog software let absolutely everyone into that club. Now the way to fame and riches seems to be starting an advertising network.

headline: Can Gadgets and Humor Mix?
text: An encore presentation by David Pogue.

headline: Leaving Vietnam
text: [The following entry, written by the author at 13 years old, recalls the day of her adoption at age 6.]

headline: Pat Robertson Endorses Giuliani
text: The Times's David D. Kirkpatrick discusses Pat Robertson's announcement endorsing Rudolph W. Giuliani for president.

headline: Sarkozy Visits Washington
text: International Herald Tribune reporter Katrin Bennhold on President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, who made his first official visit to Washington.

headline: Sarkozy Visits Washington
text: International Herald Tribune reporter Katrin Bennhold on President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, who made his first official visit to Washington.

headline: Memorable Moments
text: In his latest column, George Vecsey calls Shalrie Joseph’s pass to Steve Ralston that led to New England’s goal last Saturday night to oust the Red Bulls one of the best plays he has seen in Major League Soccer.

headline: Auctioning Americana
text: The contents of the Elvis Is Alive Museum, offered in a single lot on eBay, support its owner's theory that Elvis is alive.

headline: Bloggingheads: School Vouchers
text:
Mark Schmitt, of the New America Foundation, and Megan McArdle, of the Atlantic, on whether vouchers are the answer to public education's problems.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Dubai: Working Class Investment?
text: Rendering of the Burj Dubai, projected as the tallest building in the world

headline: Protests in Georgia Become Violent
text: Four years after the "Rose revolution," demonstrators were once again on the streets in Georgia last week.

headline: Revisiting Psychological Tests: Can They Really Do That?
text: Tuesday’s post about psychological testing in job interviews and other work-related settings caused a mild tempest in the comments section. I’m going to address just a few of the many issues that came up, beginning with this one (which I’ve abbreviated):

headline: Strike Postpones ’24’ Premiere; Fox Revises Schedule
text: Three days into the writers’ strike, Fox has become the first broadcast network to announce revisions to its prime time schedule.

headline: Coping With the Mexican Floods
text: Residents of Villahermosa, Mexico, were living on their rooftops last week while waiting for the flood waters to recede.

headline: Early Victim of Strike: ‘Office’ Originals End Next Week
text: Television viewers are beginning to get a better sense of how the writers’ strike will affect their favorite shows. Original half-hour episodes of NBC’s hit half-hour comedy “The Office” will stop being shown after next week.

headline: Con Edison Is Penalized for Blackout
text: State utilities regulators hit Con Edison with an $18 million penalty yesterday for its service disruptions last year, which included a nine-day blackout in western Queens and other power failures in Westchester County.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Stock Market Continues Downhill
text: Stock markets ended flat for the day as investors showed a spot of optimism in the final hour of trading. But technology stocks swooned as investors faced a grim fourth-quarter forecast from the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke.

headline: Mexican Floods Push Families to Last Islands of Home
text: VILLAHERMOSA, Mexico, Nov. 7 — Javier Hernández and Ángel Pérez killed a pig on Wednesday morning on their rooftop. That is where they are living.

headline: Tax Proposal From Rangel Could Benefit His Donors
text: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee has proposed legislation that would effectively halt some current tax audits of people who get a tax break for living and operating a business in the United States Virgin Islands.

headline: Fed Chairman Says Economy Likely to Slow
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 — Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress today that the economy is going to get worse before it gets better, a message that got a chilly reception from both Wall Street and politicians.

headline: Corrections
text: Editors' Note

headline: It Takes a Big Man to Seek Help on Weight Loss
text: NASHUA, N.H.

headline: Selected Studies: Heartburn
text: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Southwest Ends Open-Boarding Policy
text: Southwest Airlines abandoned its longstanding first-come-first-served approach to seating yesterday, giving business travelers, who pay the highest fares, first choice in boarding.

headline: What Economic Slowdown? Small Businesses Grow Stronger
text: EVEN as oil prices surge, the housing market contracts, Wall Street reels and multibillion-dollar deals falter, small businesses are flourishing and, in fact, are helping to buoy the economy, experts say.

headline: Rubin Is Reported Set to Back Clinton
text: Robert E. Rubin, Treasury secretary in the Clinton administration and new chairman of Citigroup, has overcome early misgivings about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential candidacy and will support her publicly in the fight for the Democratic nomination, people close to both of them said yesterday.

headline: Fire Dept. Changes Way Demolition Is Supervised
text: The Fire Department announced yesterday that it was changing the way it inspects buildings under construction or being torn down, to avoid the confusion that contributed to the deaths of two firefighters in a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building at ground zero last summer.

headline: Hank Thompson Is Dead; Country Singer Was 82
text: Hank Thompson, a sequined singer and songwriter who fused jazz-inflected Western swing and hard-edged honky-tonk to produce seven decades of musical musings, seasoned with sly humor, on loving, drinking and dying, died on Tuesday at his home in Keller, Tex. He was 82.

headline: Escalation of Tactics in Writers’ Strike
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 — At least two major television studios, 20th Century Fox and CBS Paramount, have sent breach-of-contract letters to the show runners on their current series who have stopped performing their production duties once they went on strike with other television writers.

headline: European Bank Leaves Rate Unchanged
text: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8  The European Central Bank held interest rates steady today but also signaled its displeasure with the euro’s rushed rise against the dollar.

headline: For Miller, One Not Loneliest Number
text: At this point, Bode Miller’s motor home is more of a symbol than a means of transportation.

headline: A Departure Adds Colors to the Palette
text: Garth Fagan has sometimes seemed a limited modern-dance choreographer, with jagged moves and cross-stage patterns as his too familiar trademarks. There was some of that when Garth Fagan Dance opened at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. But this first of two programs for once suggested range and invention.

headline: Eventful 15-Day Mission for Shuttle Discovery Ends
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 7 — The shuttle Discovery glided to a safe landing here Wednesday, bringing to a close an eventful mission that combined challenging space station construction and emergency repairs.

headline: A Sigh of Relief for Heartburn Sufferers
text: Over the last decade, a tide of powerful heartburn medications, many once available only by prescription, has washed over store shelves, helping to introduce gastroesophageal reflux disease -- or GERD, the medical name for persistent heartburn -- into the vocabulary of consumers everywhere. But along with relief has come worry. Many patients fear they are afflicted with an incurable chronic condition that, if left untreated, eventually leads to more serious problems like inflammation or even cancer of the esophagus.

headline: Pat Loves Rudy
text: Back in mid-2001, when Mayor Rudy Giuliani was busy committing adultery, lurching into his divorce and third marriage and rooming with a gay couple he promised to marry as soon as the law allowed, who among us would have imagined that one day he would be endorsed for president by Pat Robertson?

headline: India’s Solution for Oil Prices: Ban Speculation by Banning Trading
text: NEW DELHI, Nov. 7 — As oil approaches the $100-a-barrel milestone, M. S. Srinivasan, India’s petroleum secretary, has an unorthodox recommendation for cooling overheated prices: halt trading of crude oil on commodity exchanges.

headline: Bending Ears on Economics as ’08 Nears
text: On the campaign trail, Barack Obama and John Edwards are aggressively pitting themselves against Hillary Rodham Clinton in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But when it comes to something as fundamental as economic policy, the lineup quietly shifts: It is Senators Obama and Clinton against Mr. Edwards.

headline: Need a Life? She’ll Arrange One
text: ON a warm autumn afternoon, Allison Storr was giving Brad Peik, a San Francisco real estate investor, a crash course on the Chelsea art world. “The gallery scene can be a little intimidating,” Ms. Storr said as she took him on a tour of galleries that was intended as a primer for cocktail party chatter, not collecting.

headline: Another Step for a Remade AOL
text: AOL has scooped up yet another online advertising company  this time, one that has faced off with Google and Yahoo in selling contextual text ads, those small, sponsored links that run next to articles.

headline: Toll Rises to 41 in Afghan Bombing
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 7 — The death toll from a suicide bombing in northern Afghanistan rose to 52 on Wednesday, making it the worst single suicide bombing in the country since 2001, government officials said.

headline: Radioactive Dumping Is Reported in Congo
text: KINSHASA, Congo, Nov. 7 (Reuters) — Officials in Congo said Wednesday that they were investigating reports that 18 tons of highly radioactive minerals had been dumped into a river in Katanga Province, in the southeastern part of the country.

headline: Life Sentence in Killing of Police Officer
text: A Brooklyn man who was convicted of fatally shooting a police officer in a wild car chase through Flatbush two years ago was sentenced today to life in prison without the chance of parole.

headline: In a Surprise, Pat Robertson Backs Giuliani
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  They could compete for strangest bedfellows of 2008.

headline: These Naughty Gifts Don’t Clutter a Closet
text: LAST week, I stumbled across a short item at a site called Mashable.com, which described how one of Facebook’s most popular programs allows users to give each other virtual Naughty Gifts.

headline: Militant Group Is Out of Baghdad, U.S. Says
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 7 — American forces have routed Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the Iraqi militant network, from every neighborhood of Baghdad, a top American general said today, allowing American troops involved in the “surge” to depart as planned.

headline: For the Young of Heart and Hair
text: AN hour before walking past squealing kids wobbling cutely around the Bryant Park skating rink, on my way to the BCBG Max Azria flagship, I had been struggling in my bathroom, trying to take my own passport photo.

headline: Timing Glitch Affected Thousands in Marathon
text: A technical problem with the timing system at the New York City Marathon on Sunday affected thousands of runners, forcing race directors to resort to the honor system in determining runners’ precise times and whether some met the qualifying standards for the Boston Marathon, one of the world’s most prestigious races.

headline: Stranger Posts Bail for Chambers’s Friend
text: When Robert E. Chambers Jr. was arrested on Oct. 22 on charges of selling cocaine out of an Upper East Side apartment, many people saw it as the denouement of a morality tale, the final fall of “the preppy killer” who pleaded guilty to strangling Jennifer Levin during rough sex in Central Park two decades ago.

headline: Fred W. McDarrah, Photographer, Dies at 81
text: Fred W. McDarrah, a self-described square who as a longtime photographer for The Village Voice documented the unwashed exploits of the Beat generation, and as an enterprising freelance talent agent rented out members of that generation (washed or unwashed) to wide-eyed suburban society gatherings, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 81.

headline: Digital Camera for the PlayStation 3 Is Watching, and Listening, While You Play
text: The idea of watching a video game is not new. But what about when the games start watching back? Last week, Sony released its long-awaited PlayStation Eye, a digital camera that lets players interact with some games using body motions.

headline: O’Brien Performs Live, but Charity Benefits
text: NBC ran a rerun of “Late Night with Conan O’Brien” on Wednesday night during the ongoing writers’ strike, but it was still possible for a select few to see the host do an original monologue.

headline: Bet on Citigroup Hurts a Prominent Investor
text: In August, a hedge fund controlled by Edward S. Lampert, the value-oriented investor, disclosed that it had built a $1.3 billion stake in Citigroup, the beleaguered financial giant.

headline: Free-Jazz Pioneer, Aware of His Legacy
text: The Ohio-born tenor saxophonist Albert Ayler probably would have gotten a kick out of Kasper Collin’s documentary about his life, “My Name Is Albert Ayler,” which opens today at the Anthology Film Archives. Named after one of his albums and built around snippets of audio interviews with Mr. Ayler, it attempts and often achieves a fresh, playful style that’s equally informed by jazz traditions and Mr. Ayler’s urge to shatter them.

headline: Honors Pile Up for Former Ranger Leetch
text: For the former Rangers defenseman Brian Leetch, being honored yesterday with the Lester Patrick Award for contributions to American hockey was one of a series of events that followed his retirement this year. He dropped the first puck at the Rangers’ home opener to a thunderous ovation. He will have his number retired at Madison Square Garden in January.

headline: Cast Aside Underarm Protection, if You Dare
text: IN Kurt Vonnegut’s “God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater,” there is an imaginary country that is in search of a common enemy, but every disease has already been cured and all wars have stopped. So, the country wages a battle against odor. It is a story that feels prescient, minus the disease and war part.

headline: Priest Jailed in Stalking of Conan O’Brien
text: A priest from Boston has been charged with stalking and harassing the talk show host Conan O’Brien, law enforcement officials said last night.

headline: MSNBC and O’Donnell Can’t Make a Deal
text: Two days after NBC acknowledged that it was talking to Rosie O’Donnell about a possible show on MSNBC, those conversations have stalled, with no immediate prospect of being revived, an executive of the network said last night.

headline: Computer Servers for Home Use Can Help Get a Grip on All Those Photo, Music and Video Files in the PC Attic
text: It may not be the sexiest part of computing, but storage is becoming increasingly critical as masses of photo, music and video files accumulate. Microsoft thinks it’s time families had help storing it all with computer servers intended for the home.

headline: On Campaign Stump, Romney Preaches the Importance of Optimism
text: The question put to Mitt Romney at the Republican presidential debate in Michigan several weeks ago seemed to be a golden opportunity for him to show off his vaunted analytical side. Maria Bartiromo, a CNBC commentator, asked the candidate what he thought posed “the greatest long-term threat” to the American economy.

headline: On the Trading Block: Endless Kobe Rumors
text: Over the last two weeks, we have crowned a new World Series champion, the New York Yankees have been turned upside down, the N.F.L. played a game in London and the New England Patriots won the league’s latest Game Of The Century. All the while, Kobe Bryant has been on the front page of ESPN.com six times. Which is fascinating, considering that absolutely nothing has happened with him for the last two weeks.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,846 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Russia: Parliament Suspends Arms Treaty Compliance
text: Parliament’s lower house voted 418 to 0 to back a Kremlin decision to suspend participation in a treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe. In July, a Kremlin statement said that NATO expansion into Eastern Europe had increased the alliance’s military capacity, in violation of the original treaty adopted in 1990 by NATO and the Soviet Union. Officials in Russia also suggested Russia would stop observing the treaty because of the Bush administration’s decision to abrogate another, the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, and move ahead with a missile-defense system in Central Europe. Russian officials have threatened to direct their missiles toward Europe if the United States proceeds with the system. The vote to suspend the conventional forces treaty must be approved by the upper house and signed by President Vladimir V. Putin. Both are expected to do so.

headline: China Remarks Drive Dollar Lower
text: Currency traders gave the dollar a thorough pounding today after a Chinese official suggested that the country could begin to diversify its huge foreign-exchange reserves.

headline: Homeowners Feel the Pinch of Lost Equity
text: RENO, Nev., Nov. 5 — As his wedding day approached last spring, Marshall Whittey found that his money could not keep pace with the grandiosity of his plans. But rather than scale back, he chose instead, like millions of homeowners across the country, to borrow against the soaring value of his home.

headline: ‘I Won’t Dance’? Just Try and Stop Her
text: Chita Rivera has a gleam in her eye, a smirk on her lips and a bounce in her step. That description could, of course, be applied to scads of other entertainers purveying resilience and optimism. But Ms. Rivera’s brand of vivacity is qualitatively different from almost everyone else’s, because it emanates from deep within her.

headline: New York Widens Inquiry on Mortgages
text: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has subpoenaed Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as he expands his investigation into what he calls “widespread” collusion between real estate appraisers and lenders, including Washington Mutual, to inflate home values.

headline: Thailand Race Begins
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 7 (AP)  Official campaigning for Thailand’s first general elections since last year’s military coup began Wednesday as 18 parties registered for the Dec. 23 balloting.

headline: Romanian Premier Tries to Calm Italy After a Killing
text: ROME, Nov. 7 — Romania’s prime minister visited Italy on Wednesday to try to defuse a week of anger here, after the arrest of a Romanian in the killing of an Italian woman exploded into a national debate on immigration and crime. Some three dozen immigrants have been expelled since then, with calls from the center-right opposition for many more expulsions.

headline: A.I.G. Takes a Hit of $1.95 Billion on Housing Investments
text: The American International Group, the world’s largest insurance company, said yesterday that it wrote down nearly $2 billion in investments related to mortgages in the third quarter and expected to write down an additional $550 million in the next quarter.

headline: U.N. Objects to Expulsion of Aid Official From Darfur
text: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 7 — The United Nations on Wednesday deplored the expulsion of its chief aid official from Darfur, and Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Sudan was delaying the arrival of peacekeeping troops in Darfur by withholding approval of the force’s composition.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Polanski to Film ‘The Ghost’

headline: Duran Duran Is Still Big, Just the Stage Got Small
text: When a name-brand band settles in for a residency at a small Broadway theater  as Duran Duran is through next Tuesday at the Ethel Barrymore Theater21;151; the selling point is a chance to get closer to the musicians and the songs. On Tuesday night some fans took full advantage of their proximity, like the woman who repeatedly grabbed the singer Simon Le Bon’s leg whenever he walked too close to the edge of the stage.

headline: Civics, Without Passion, From HBO
text: The deal with “The Deal” isn’t that this 2003 British film traces former Prime Minister Tony Blair’s early rise to power.

headline: Iraq Plans to Confront Security Firms on Guns
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 7 — The Iraqi interior minister said Wednesday that he would authorize raids by his security forces on Western security firms to ensure that they were complying with tightened licensing requirements on guns and other weaponry, setting up the possibility of violent confrontations between the Iraqis and heavily armed Western guards.

headline: Perfect for Prowling
text: THIS season, the call of the wild sounds more like a primal scream. From top to toe, pith helmet to platform shoe, animal prints are back with a vengeance. Not that they ever went away. A perennial favorite, they emerge in some degree every autumn, as reliable as the Thanksgiving turkey, and for some, just as enticing.

headline: After Further Review?
text: Earlier this week, baseball’s general managers recommended for the first time that the league allow instant replay. The proposal is limited to instant replay on possible home run balls -- whether they are fair or foul, for instance -- and faces several more layers of approval. Is this a move in the right direction for baseball, or a bad precedent?

headline: Recording Video on the Go
text: Q. Can the iPod record video? Are there any portable media players that let you record directly onto the device, instead of having to copy prerecorded files onto the player from the computer?

headline: New Ticket to Lady Liberty
text: The company that will replace the Circle Line, which has provided ferry service to the Statue of Liberty for more than half a century, has begun selling tickets online for trips in January.

headline: As They Say in France: What’s This?
text: INVITING the public to a fashion show, by plopping one onto the plaza of Lincoln Center, as did “Project Runway” on Tuesday, or inside Grand Central Terminal, as did Target on Tuesday and Wednesday, would seem to be a fine way to grab attention.

headline: Florida Sun Doesn’t Shine on Baseball
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: A Boys’ Guide to Narcotizing the Pain
text: The boys, overgrown tykes all, seem endearingly happy in their squalid playpen of an apartment. Oh, not the three potentially suicidal brothers who share a home in “Things We Want,” Jonathan Marc Sherman’s thickly whimsical comedy of despair, which opened last night at the Acorn Theater. They’re pretty miserable.

headline: From Streets of China to Family Life in Queens
text: The wisps of smoke were sweet and pungent, seductive and soothing, lazy tentacles unfurling from bamboo pipes. Opium humbled a great empire, creating an addiction that rotted China from within. But in the crevices of the history books, which diligently record the epic battles and the humiliating treaties, lie the families that crumbled and the children who were orphaned, including Tai Run Chen, now 65.

headline: State’s Oldest Inmate Is Granted His Freedom by Parole Board
text: A panel of the State Parole Board voted 2 to 1 yesterday to release Charles E. Friedgood, a wealthy Long Island surgeon who was convicted in 1976 of murdering his ailing wife and who is now, at 89, the oldest state prison inmate in New York. He is expected to be freed in mid-December and admitted to a veterans’ hospital.

headline: Serb Nationalist’s Trial Begins in The Hague
text: THE HAGUE, Nov. 7 — The man considered the main propagandist of the Serbian nationalism that led to four disastrous wars went on trial on Wednesday at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. He is accused of inflammatory speech and of numerous crimes committed by his own militia.

headline: Caution Signs
text: THE American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists makes exercise recommendations for pregnant women. In general, the group suggests that those without medical or obstetric complications should get 30 minutes or more of moderate activity daily. The association made this point in a 2002 committee opinion, the most recent available. The benefits of exercising while pregnant include reduction of backaches, better sleep, and treating or preventing gestational diabetes.

headline: Posada and Rivera at Top of Yanks’ List
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 7 — The Yankees are preparing new offers to their top free agents, Jorge Posada and Mariano Rivera, in an effort to sign them before other teams can negotiate with them.

headline: Dog and Rabbit Sleuths vs. a Demonic Santa
text: “The snow will turn red with the blood of the naughty,” screams Santa as he fires a pistol at one of his elves.

headline: Unseasonably Higher, Gas Prices Add to Strain on U.S. Consumers
text: HOUSTON, Nov. 7 — Most years, the shorter days and lower temperatures of autumn mean falling gasoline prices, as demand eases from the busy summer travel season.

headline: Toward Afghan Success
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn: Navy Yard Development
text: The Brooklyn Navy Yard will become home to a historic center as part of its expansion and redevelopment, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said yesterday. The center, scheduled to open in early 2010 in the Marine Corps commandant’s residence, is to use multimedia exhibits, including oral history projects, to tell the story of the Navy Yard and provide meeting space and offices for the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. The City Council has promised $10 million of the $15 million needed to renovate and expand the building, which was erected in 1857.

headline: Giving Up the Memorabilia, but Not the Belief: Elvis Lives
text: WRIGHT CITY, Mo., Nov. 6 — The 16-foot-tall likeness of Elvis Presley that stands sentry here at the Elvis Is Alive Museum, a fading outpost of Americana, has seen better days.

headline: Poet Wins $200,000
text: The American lyric poet Anne Stevenson, 74, who has lived in Britain for more than 40 years, was named the winner yesterday of the $200,000 lifetime achievement award of the Lannan Foundation of Santa Fe, N.M. Awards of $150,000 each were made in fiction to A. L. Kennedy of Scotland and Susan Straight of Riverside, Calif., and in nonfiction to Mike Davis of San Diego. Writing fellowships totaling $550,000 went to Paula Gunn Allen of Fort Bragg, Calif.; Daniel Alarcón of Oakland, Calif.; Edie Meidav of Rhinebeck, N.Y.; Dinaw Mengestu and Jeremy Scahill of Brooklyn and Sinead Morrissey of Belfast, Northern Ireland. The Lannan Literary Awards and Fellowships were established in 1989 to honor established and emerging writers of work of exceptional quality. ... “Late Nights on Air,” the third novel by Elizabeth Hay, 56, a former radio broadcaster in Canada, won the $43,000 Scotiabank Giller Prize, the most lucrative Canadian prize for fiction, Reuters reported. The novel, about loves and rivalries at a small radio station in Yellowknife, in the Northwest Territories of Canada near the Arctic, beat shortlist competition that included “Divisadero,” by Michael Ondaatje.

headline: Right State, Wrong Town for Obama
text: WAPELLO, Iowa, Nov. 7 — As presidential hopefuls go, Senator Barack Obama is generally one of the more punctual politicians of the election season.

headline: Paul Soloway, 66, World Bridge Champion, Dies
text: Paul Soloway, five times a world bridge champion and the holder of the largest collection of master points, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 66.

headline: Humdinger of a Project: Tracing Slang to Ireland
text: Growing up Irish in Queens and on Long Island, Daniel Cassidy was nicknamed Glom.

headline: Global Markets Down After U.S. Sell-Off
text: Stocks in Europe and Asia declined today on worries about rising oil prices and the prospect of an economic slowdown in the United States. But American shares were poised to move upward today, after a heavy sell-off on Wednesday spurred by fears that the problems in housing were likely to persist into next year.

headline: Journeys That Leave the Traveler Changed
text: Isaac Julien’s beguiling, heady film, “Fantôme Afrique,” demonstrates the wonders of collaboration. A second film, “True North,” underlines the dangers of accommodation.

headline: A Norwegian Orchestra and Its Aural Thumbprint
text: The Bergen Philharmonic has been in business since 1765 and lists Edvard Grieg among its former artistic directors. It is overshadowed these days by the Oslo Philharmonic, but the Bergen musicians seem ready to challenge their Oslo compatriots for a piece of the international spotlight. At Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, led by Andrew Litton, its conductor since 2003, the Bergen Philharmonic played with an unusual solidity and warmth, and produced a breadth of color that gave it a distinctive sonic thumbprint.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: On Aug. 7, we published a letter from Zachary Townsend, a student at Brown University and a columnist for the student newspaper, about Japan’s role in sex slavery in World War II, and slavery in the world today. We have now learned that the letter included material taken without attribution from an article in the November/December 2006 issue of Foreign Affairs, “The New Global Slave Trade,” by Ethan B. Kapstein.

headline: G.M.’s Attempt  at 2 Steps Forward Is Taken One Back
text: DETROIT, Nov. 7  Nearly two years ago, amid speculation of a potential bankruptcy filing, General Motors unveiled details of its reorganization plan and vowed to end the crisis that had enveloped the company.

headline: Georgian Leader Imposes a State of Emergency
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 7 — The president of the republic of Georgia declared a state of emergency Wednesday night, after riot police officers used tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannon to clear thousands of demonstrators from the streets. The order immediately closed two television stations and banned public assembly in the capital, and would be in effect for at least 48 hours, a senior government official said by telephone.

headline: Don’t Throw Out Your Broken iPod; Fix It via the Web
text: A FEW months ago, Stephen Ironside, a student at the University of Arkansas in Fayetteville, confronted a minor but modern tragedy: the iPod that filled his life with song stopped working.

headline: Pregnant Exercisers Test Limits
text: JAMES PIVARNIK, the director of the Human Energy Research Laboratory at Michigan State University, is all in favor of a woman exercising when she is pregnant. But some of the athletes he studied seemed to know no bounds.

headline: Pete Doherty Apologizes
text: The British rocker Pete Doherty acts “stupid.” Says who? Mr. Doherty himself, Reuters reported. Mr. Doherty, the Babyshambles frontman, apologized yesterday for using heroin last week, after saying he was conquering his well-publicized drug addiction. Mr. Doherty called his relapse “a stupid, stupid action for which I feel only shame.” He plans to re-enter a rehabilitation clinic. In a statement, his record label, EMI, said, “Doherty would like to apologize to the medical staff, fans and well-wishers who have helped and encouraged his progress in fighting his addiction to heroin.” A spokesman said an arena tour planned for this month would proceed.

headline: For CBS, Crime Pays
text: CBS’s five-year-old series “NCIS” attracted its largest audience ever on Tuesday, surpassing even that night’s usual leaders, including ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” and Fox’s “House.” Nielsen estimated that “NCIS,” a Navy-themed crime procedural, delivered 18.3 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour, slightly more than the 18.1 million who tuned in at 9 for “House.” But “House” remained far and away the night’s leader among adults 18 to 49, lifting Fox into first place in Tuesday’s ratings. CBS ranked second in total viewers, but third in the 18-to-49 demographic behind NBC, which led the 10 p.m. hour with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (11.8 million). The results episode of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” at 9 drew 17 million viewers, fewer than the 20.5 million the show attracted on Monday with an extended edition from 8 to 9:45. Although ABC finished first in the ratings for that night, on Tuesday it suffered a rare fourth-place finish in the 18-to-49 set, partly because of lackluster ratings for “Cavemen” at 8 (4.9 million) and “Carpoolers” at 8:30 (5.5 million).

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Stitchery

headline: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Musharraf
text: When Zalmay Khalilzad was the U.S. ambassador to Afghanistan, he would clash with Colin Powell, then the secretary of state, over whether Gen. Pervez Musharraf’s Pakistan was friend or foe.

headline: Alternative Tax Showdown
text: The House and Senate are poised to vote on a vitally important tax bill that poses a test for each chamber of Congress. In the House, the vote on a short-term fix for the alternative minimum tax will test whether Democratic representatives have the courage of their convictions. In the Senate, the vote will test whether Democratic senators have any convictions at all, or just a belief in keeping the world safe for campaign contributors.

headline: At Sotheby’s Art Auction, Buyers Were Not Impressed
text: The combination of estimates that were too high and material that was too familiar made last night’s sale of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby’s a rocky evening, as second-rate paintings by Picasso, van Gogh and Miró failed to sell.

headline: What to Ask About Heartburn
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening -- and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: A Bit Older, No Reason to Fret
text: TORRINGTON, Conn.

headline: What You Said
text: “At the point where both players represent the ultimate offensive weapons of their sport and both command huge salaries, the fact that Kobe plays to win clearly makes him more desirable than A-Rod.”

headline: Do Not Go Gentle Into Pakistan’s Night
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dubai: Court Hears French Boy’s Rape Testimony
text: A 15-year-old French boy, Alexandre Robert, testified for two and a half hours in the trial of two Emirati men accused of raping him at knife point in July. The court session was closed to the public, but the boy’s mother, Véronique Robert, said that he identified the men as two of his three assailants. The third suspect is being tried in a juvenile court. Alexandre returned to Dubai from Switzerland, where his mother lives, despite a risk of being prosecuted himself for homosexual activity after pressing the charges against the three suspects.

headline: Big Tobacco Defeats Sick Kids
text: One of the biggest disappointments in Tuesday’s election was the defeat of an Oregon ballot initiative that would have raised the state’s cigarette tax by 85 cents a pack to help pay for health care for uninsured children.

headline: For TV Executives, It’s Time to Juggle
text: Jack Bauer will return to save the world on “24” — again — but somewhat later than expected. And Michael Scott, the comically obtuse regional manager on “The Office,” will not be serving up any original cringe-inducing comments after next week.

headline: Marching After Goldwater in the Opposite Direction
text: In 1960 a brash young conservative writer named L. Brent Bozell Jr. ghost-wrote a book for a brash Republican senator from Arizona named Barry Goldwater. That book, “The Conscience of a Conservative,” argued for a radically different relationship between government and the individual than the one to which Americans had become accustomed.

headline: A Trade Publication Alters a Rule, Lifting an Eagles Album to No. 1
text: In the latest indication of the clout of mass retailers, the Eagles, the longtime rock group that is selling its new studio album exclusively through Wal-Mart, seized the top spot on the sales charts this week thanks to an 11th-hour change by a music trade magazine that has stirred up a ruckus in the music industry.

headline: Putting the Shower to the Test (and the Nose on Alert)
text: WE asked three adults who have used a deodorant-antiperspirant combination every day since puberty to see how long they could go au naturel. Only one was still abstaining after 12 days.

headline: Falcons’ Babineaux Is Cleared of Charges
text: The Atlanta Falcons finally got some good news about a player accused of killing a pit bull.

headline: How to Load a Digital Frame
text: Q. I want to buy one of those digital photo frames. I’ll insert a memory card containing the photos, but how do I get the photos on my computer onto that memory card? The computer has no slot for the card.

headline: Superdelegates for Clinton (Undecided’s No. 1)
text: In an early indication of where Democratic Party leaders are leaning, a survey of the party’s superdelegates — elected officials and other leaders who vote at the party’s convention but are not selected in primaries — found they are favoring Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York.

headline: House Approves  Broad Protections for Gay Workers
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 — The House on Wednesday approved a bill granting broad protections against discrimination in the workplace for gay men, lesbians and bisexuals, a measure that supporters praised as the most important civil rights legislation since the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 but that opponents said would result in unnecessary lawsuits.

headline: French Architect Picked for Film Museum
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 — An architect who helped raise a bustling new quarter from the industrial mess of southeast Paris will now get his shot at a section of this city best known for its automotive repair shops, tumbledown cottages and slapdash sidewalk posters.

headline: Senate Confirms Mukasey as Attorney General
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 — The Senate confirmed Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general Thursday night, approving him despite Democratic criticism that he had failed to take an unequivocal stance against the torture of terror detainees.

headline: Oklahoma State Player Sentenced in Sex Assault
text: The Oklahoma State sophomore linebacker Chris Collins received a five-year prison sentence yesterday for aggravated sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl three years ago. But the jury, in New Boston, Tex., recommended that his punishment be served through probation.

headline: A Mishmash Reflective of Country Music
text: Long before the 41st annual Country Music Awards were over last night, the winner for best speech seemed clear. Let’s give that award — a meta-award, perhaps — to Jamey Johnson, who helped write the break-up song “Give It Away” for George Strait, which won song of the year. Mr. Johnson dedicated his award to his ex-wife, inspiring a chuckle from the audience. “She certainly deserves half of this award,” he added dryly. “And half of this song, too.”

headline: On the Road to Spread the Word of Good, Old-Fashioned Evil
text: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 7 — On Tuesday night, in a plush tour bus parked in this city’s scruffy downtown, a couple of Norwegians were talking about world music. They were talking about the competing musical traditions of Norway and Sweden. They were talking about Icelandic linguistics and Viking mythology. They were talking about indigenous scenes in Canada, India and lots of places in between. In other words, they were talking about heavy metal.

headline: Batmans Energy Crisis
text: The Caped Crusader is in hot water in Hong Kong. When producers of his latest adventure, “The Dark Knight,” starring Christian Bale, asked tenants on the waterfront to leave their lights on all night, the better to show off that city’s glass-and-steel skyline, environmentalists saw red. Gabrielle Ho, a project manager for the conservation organization Green Sense, told The Associated Press, “We believe producers are able to create the same effects via postproduction works, but instead they are asking us to turn on so many lights, wasting so much energy.” October Pictures, the Hong Kong company handling the production, did not respond to a request for comment.

headline: Morgan Stanley Takes a Hit on Mortgages
text: Morgan Stanley, its stock buffeted in recent days by speculation of high credit losses, said yesterday that it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages.

headline: Surge Seen in Number of Homeless Veterans
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 — More than 400 veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars have turned up homeless, and the Veterans Affairs Department and aid groups say they are bracing for a new surge in homeless veterans in the years ahead.

headline: In First Bush Veto Override, Senate Enacts Water Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 — The Senate voted overwhelmingly today for a popular $23 billion water projects measure affecting locales across the country, thereby handing President Bush his first defeat in a veto showdown with Congress.

headline: Birth Control Pills May Clog Arteries
text: Birth control pills taken by about 100 million women worldwide may clog arteries when taken more than 10 years, according to a study. Women on oral contraceptives were 20 percent to 30 percent more likely to have buildup of fat and cholesterol in their arteries, reducing blood flow, according to a study of 1,301 Belgian women ages 35 to 55. Most used birth control now made by companies like Johnson & Johnson and Barr Pharmaceuticals Inc. for more than 10 years. Fatty clogs can lead to heart disease and stroke. The pills in the study were older forms that combined estrogen and progestin, two sex hormones. The finding differs from advice given by doctors based on previous research, said Sharonne Hayes of the Mayo Clinic. The research was reported at the American Heart Association meeting in Orlando.

headline: In Tests, AIDS Vaccine Seemed to Increase Risk
text: In a puzzling and potentially troubling development, an AIDS vaccine tested in a closely watched trial might have increased the risk among vaccine recipients of becoming infected with H.I.V., researchers reported yesterday at a scientific meeting in Seattle.

headline: The Artist’s Fall Collection
text: KERI EVILSIZOR trained a covetous eye on the handbags pristinely arrayed on white-lacquered shelves. She was not quite sure what to make of the display, housed in a 1,000-square-foot island of commerce inside the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. No matter. She was there to shop.

headline: New Jersey Democrats Grapple With Rebuke of Stem Cell Initiative
text: TRENTON, Nov. 7  Stung and puzzled by the defeat of a ballot initiative to borrow $450 million for stem cell research, leading Democrats in New Jersey struggled on Wednesday to explain why they were repudiated by voters and how they planned to finance the biomedical research for a center already under construction.

headline: Exercise on the Brain
text: FEELING a little less mentally quick than you did a few years ago? Maybe you are among the many people who do “brain exercises” like sudoku to slow the cognitive decline associated with aging. We’ve got a better suggestion.

headline: If Rodriguez Price Falls, Mets Might Be Interested
text: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 7  The Mets had a meeting Wednesday with Scott Boras, the agent for third baseman Alex Rodriguez, staying on the fringes of negotiations for the marquee free agent of the off-season.

headline: After Coin Flip, Pennington Takes On New Role
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 7  The former franchise quarterback walked from the sideline to midfield, the same as dozens of times before. He stood next to the other captains as the coin tumbled toward the ground.

headline: U.S. Prods Musharraf to End Emergency Rule
text: This article was reported by David Rohde, Jane Perlez, Helene Cooper and Steven Lee Myers, and written by Mr. Rohde.

headline: Democrats Divided as House Passes Peru Trade Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 — Defying appeals from labor leaders, environmentalists and foes of free-trade, nearly half the Democrats in the House joined today with the Bush administration’s backers to support a trade liberalization agreement with Peru that the White House hopes will lead to the approval of future trade deals.

headline: Wanted in Germany, Terrorism Suspect Arrested in Turkey
text: BERLIN, Nov. 7 — The Turkish police have arrested a suspect in what the German authorities said in September was a plot to conduct a series of deadly bombings against German and American targets.

headline: Security Study Urged for Atlantic Yards
text: Of the many criticisms leveled against the planned Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, two of the major ones are that it would worsen traffic in an already congested area and that its 18,000-seat basketball arena might provide a tempting target for terrorists.

headline: Ex-Gov. Ryan of Illinois Reports to Prison
text: CHICAGO, Nov. 7 — Former Gov. George Ryan, who drew international attention for halting the death penalty in this state, reported to a federal prison in Wisconsin on Wednesday to begin his six-and-a-half-year sentence for racketeering and fraud.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.  How do I clean a fabric lampshade?

headline: North Korea Still a Threat, South Korean Tells Gates
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 7 — The military threat presented by North Korea has not diminished despite its early steps to dismantle its nuclear weapons program, the South Korean defense minister said Wednesday.

headline: Small Town Mourns a Running Marvel
text: CENTRAL LAKE, Mich., Nov. 7 — It snowed the night they brought Ryan Shay home to bury him. Three hundred candles in paper bags lined the inner lane of the high school track. The wind extinguished some candles and ignited several bags into balls of flame.

headline: Polanski to Film the Ghost
text: Roman Polanski has signed on to direct a film adaptation of “The Ghost,” a political thriller written by Robert Harris and published last month in the United States by Simon & Schuster. The novel is narrated by a ghostwriter for a former British prime minister, Adam Lang, who is writing his memoirs. Lang recently stepped down after a sharp slide in popularity because of his support for an American-led war, and his first collaborator has mysteriously died. In an interview, Mr. Polanski, who lives in France and had been working with Mr. Harris on a film adaptation of Mr. Harris’s novel “Pompeii,” said he read “The Ghost” and knew right away that he wanted to turn it into a film. “A political thriller is exactly what I wanted,” said Mr. Polanski, the director of “Chinatown” and “Rosemary’s Baby,” who won an Oscar for “The Pianist” in 2003. “I like books that I can’t put down, and at the same time it’s a kind of satire on certain political situations with which we are only too well acquainted.” A large portion of “The Ghost” takes place on Martha’s Vineyard; Mr. Polanski won’t be able to film there because he has remained a fugitive since fleeing the United States in 1978 to avoid prison after pleading guilty to statutory rape. “It doesn’t really matter where you do it,” Mr. Polanski said, referring to filming “The Ghost,” which he hopes to begin next fall. “It just has to be somewhere on the Atlantic off season where you have dunes and empty roads and unlived-in holiday houses.”

headline: Just Forget All the Muss, Your Photos Will Now Upload Themselves
text: If you’ve ever looked at a digital camera full of photos and thought, “Best get to it, those pictures aren’t going to upload themselves,” you can think again.

headline: Giants Keep Running to Delight of Linemen
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 7 — The wind swirled around Giants Stadium, and it blew cold across the adjacent practice field. It carried the first icy hint of winter.

headline: Blanket Statements
text: WHEN it comes to making a bed, there are two kinds of people: those who like comforters and those who prefer blankets. Bill Sofield, the New York interior designer, counts himself among the latter. On his bed, Mr. Sofield uses a top sheet and a blanket without a bedspread to create “a casual but tailored look,” he said. “It’s very satisfying to go to sleep under the weight of a wool blanket,” he added. “Comforters are too fluffy.”

headline: Gathering Storm
text: What does it say when a leader tells his people he must suspend their civil rights in order to combat extremism, then locks up judges, lawyers and human rights activists — society’s most moderate forces — while Osama bin Laden and the Taliban run free? And what are those oppressed people supposed to conclude when the reaction of the world and even some of their own leaders is grudging?

headline: Staten Island: Expanded Train Service
text: New York City Transit will expand the express service on the Staten Island Railway next week. On Wednesday, the railway will add five express trains for the evening rush, for a total of 13. The expanded service will be timed to serve passengers on the Staten Island Ferry leaving Manhattan between 4 p.m. and 7:20 p.m. Morning service will expand on Dec. 5 with the addition of three express trains, for a total of nine. The trains will arrive at the Staten Island terminal in time for riders to board ferries from 7 a.m. to 9 a.m. The evening express trains run nonstop from St. George to Great Kills and then make local stops to Tottenville. The morning express trains make all stops between Tottenville and New Dorp and then run nonstop to St. George.

headline: Tell the Man Who Plays Gotcha: ‘Gotcha!’
text: Every writer knows that he can peruse his own prose for days and not spot a mistake. But if he casts his eyes over someone else’s writing, the errors leap off the page.

headline: South Korean Says North Still a Threat
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 7 — The military threat presented by North Korea has not diminished despite early steps by Pyongyang to dismantle its nuclear weapons program, the South Korean defense minister said today.

headline: Manhattan: Sentence in Terror Case
text: A jazz bassist and martial arts expert from the Bronx who pleaded guilty this year to terrorism charges was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 15 years in prison. In April, the defendant, Tarik Shah, 44, admitted taking part in a plot to teach would-be Qaeda operatives to wage jihad with hand-to-hand combat. An undercover F.B.I. informant recorded Mr. Shah making incriminating statements.

headline: Oprah Winfrey Spurns Racists Book
text: Oprah Winfrey banished from her list of recommended books a prize-winning best seller written by a white supremacist under a pseudonym, The Associated Press reported. The book, “The Education of Little Tree,” was supposedly the true story of an orphaned boy raised by his Cherokee grandfather. It was first published in 1976 as the work of Forrest Carter, who was later identified as Asa Earl Carter, a member of the Ku Klux Klan. Mr. Carter was also a speechwriter for George Wallace, the former governor of Alabama, and wrote Wallace’s slogan: “Segregation today, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever.” Ms. Winfrey said the book had been posted in “error” among recommended titles like “The Color Purple” and “The Grapes of Wrath.” She said she did not know how long it had been on the her Web site (oprah.com). In 1994 she discussed “Little Tree” on her television show, saying she had once been a fan, but when she learned the truth about it, felt she “had to take the book off my shelf.”

headline: A Crowded Family Enters the Space Age
text: ERIC ALAN and his wife, Rhonda Voo, had long wanted to enlarge the 1,100-square-foot bungalow that they shared with their three daughters in the Palms district on the west side of Los Angeles. But it wasn’t until they went shopping at the new L.A. Eyeworks store on Beverly Boulevard that they found the right person to do it.

headline: M.L.S. Playoffs Ride a Cultured Left Foot
text: Michelangelo, da Vinci, Beethoven and Benjamin Franklin — all ambidextrous. Soccer players are taught to emulate those geniuses with their feet, because you never know when opportunity will come skittering.
Manhattan

headline: Personalizing the Management of Heartburn
text: Dr. Joel E. Richter is chairman of the department of medicine at Temple University in Philadelphia and a leading research scientist in the field of gastroenterology. He has published more than 500 articles on gastroesophageal reflux disease.

headline: Retailers Report Weak October Sales
text: The holiday shopping outlook just got even grimmer.

headline: Recent Dings Don’t Dent Toyota Profit
text: TOKYO, Nov. 7 — Another quarter of higher profit at Toyota, Japan’s largest automaker, showed Wednesday that the company’s growth remained strong despite soaring global fuel prices and hints of an economic slowdown in its biggest market, the United States.

headline: Yes, Tune In Tomorrow: No Soap Reruns for Now
text: While the sidelining of “The Colbert Report” until further notice is one of the more prominent repercussions of the film and television writers’ strike, there are other uncertainties: Will that passionate kiss shared this week by Marina and Cyrus after Cyrus nearly died signal a permanent reconciliation?

headline: Markets Jolted by Oil Surge and Worries Over Slowdown
text: Stock markets plummeted and the dollar sank to a record low against the euro today as investors worldwide grew skittish over rising oil prices and the prospect of a substantial economic slowdown in the United States.

headline: Congratulations on the Book Award, and Welcome to the Scrutiny
text: BRAY, Ireland — The Man Booker Prize carries with it a check for £50,000 (about $105,000), a guaranteed increase in book sales and, for little-known authors, instant popular recognition. But the spotlight sometimes falls in unexpected places.

headline: A Painter’s Painter, Working With a Cast of Big Heads
text: It is instructive to imagine the D C Moore Gallery’s 10-year survey of Mark Greenwold’s small, fraught Realist paintings in one of New York’s major museums. Such a fantasy points up how narrowly even the best art institutions tend to define contemporary art, and how easily and rewardingly those strictures might be stretched.

headline: Channeling Mother Earth
text: Take one part adventure sports, mix with one part geology class, and you’ll get “Fearless Planet,” a new six-part series hosted by Will Gadd, an adventure sports veteran. In the series, which starts Sunday evening on the Discovery Channel, Gadd takes what he describes as “a literal jump into the wildest, most beautiful places on Earth,” and also talks with some geologists and experts who, with the help of some fancy computer graphics, help explain the area’s geological processes.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Encouraging Blooms

headline: E.U. Offers Serbia a Deal Towards Eventual Membership
text: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, Nov. 7 — With a deadline for negotiations over the disputed province of Kosovo just a month away, the European Union gave pro-Western forces in Serbia a boost today, initialing with Serbia a deal that could lead to Serbia joining the 27-nation group.

headline: Sleuthing for a Danger in Toy Beads
text: HONG KONG, Thursday, Nov. 8 — The story started with a 2-year-old boy who was taken to a suburban Sydney hospital on Oct. 5 in a shallow coma and suffering from seizurelike spasms. It ended with the latest recall of a Chinese-made toy, as the Consumer Product Safety Commission ordered the recall of 4.2 million Aqua Dots in the United States on Wednesday evening.

headline: Ohio Goes After Charter Schools That Are Failing
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Ohio became a test tube for the nation’s charter school movement during a decade of Republican rule here, when a wide-open authorization system and plenty of government seed money led to the schools’ explosive proliferation.

headline: U.S. Will Ask a Grand Jury to Indict Kerik
text: Federal prosecutors will ask a grand jury today to indict Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy counts, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

headline: Really Thinking About Things
text: Boston

headline: Tip of the Week: Viewing Gmail From Anywhere
text: If you’re a Gmail user, you can now set up your account to use Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) with your favorite e-mail program. Unlike the older POP mail system, which typically confines message downloads to the computer or the device you are working on, IMAP is server-based so your mailbox has all the current messages no matter where you use it — on a computer, Web browser or mobile device. Using IMAP with Gmail is free, and instructions on setting it up with different mail programs are at preview.tinyurl.com/yofbl9.

headline: Visa Agrees to Pay Amex $2.1 Billion to Settle Suit
text: Visa has agreed to pay $2.1 billion to its credit card rival American Express to settle damages relating to a 2004 antitrust lawsuit.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Georgia Leader Declares Emergency Over Protest
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 7 — The president of Georgia declared a state of emergency Wednesday night after riot police officers used tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannon to clear thousands of demonstrators from the streets of Tbilisi, the capital. The order immediately closed two television stations and banned public assembly in the capital, a senior government official said by telephone.

headline: Reaching for Apple, Falling Short
text: The iPhone’s biggest achievement isn’t any particular feature; it’s the way Apple took veto power away from the cellphone carriers.

headline: Deputy Is Killed While Transporting Inmate
text: MIAMI, Nov. 7 — A 76-year-old Broward County sheriff’s deputy was shot to death on Wednesday by an inmate he was transporting to court, the police said. The inmate overpowered the deputy, shot him with his own gun and dumped him in a parking lot before driving away, investigators said.

headline: Nigeria: Charges Against American Dropped
text: Prosecutors dropped charges against Judith Asuni, a 60-year-old American activist arrested along with a Nigerian colleague and two German filmmakers in September while doing research for a documentary film about the troubled, oil-rich Niger Delta. Ms. Asuni, left, and her colleague faced charges tantamount to espionage that could have brought a seven-year prison term. She has lived in Nigeria for more than 30 years and is a controversial fixture in the violent and chaotic delta, well known for her links to the power elite. A prosecutor told reporters that the charges had been dropped “in the public interest.”

headline: With Patience, a Family of 6 Builds Up
text: AFTER they had their fourth child, Lucy Musgrave and Zad Rogers realized they had outgrown their four-bedroom, 1,100-square-foot apartment in a central London high-rise. But they found few choices nearby for a family of their size.

headline: The Antisuburbanites
text: AS hard as it is to find enough space for a family in New York City, the Census Bureau reports that the number of young children living in Manhattan increased by more than 30 percent between 2000 and 2006. And stroller-clogged sidewalks, child-friendly cafes and busy online message boards for parents in cities around the world confirm that it’s possible to raise children without moving to the suburbs.

headline: Germany: Industrial Output Rises
text: German industrial output unexpectedly increased in September, led by the construction and energy sectors. Production rose a seasonally adjusted 0.3 percent from August, when it advanced 1.9 percent, the Economy and Technology Ministry said. Economists expected a 0.5 percent decline. Output rose 6 percent from the period a year earlier, when adjusted for the number of working days. Construction rose 0.7 percent in September from a month earlier and energy output gained 1 percent, the report said. Production of consumer durables was down 4.4 percent.

headline: Ford Narrows Quarterly Loss
text: DETROIT, Nov. 8  The Ford Motor Company said today that it lost $380 million in the third quarter, flipping back to a loss after a surprise profit in the second quarter.

headline: New Autopsy of Prisoner Fails to Resolve Mystery
text: A new autopsy report has added to the mystery surrounding the possible beating of an Alabama inmate who died shortly after being imprisoned for killing two police officers.

headline: Voters Split on Spending Initiatives on States’ Ballots
text: In Texas, voters were in a spending mood on Tuesday. In New Jersey and Oregon, they were not.

headline: Trump Steps In as Partner for Troubled Meadowlands Project
text: The developer Donald J. Trump pledged yesterday to rescue the troubled EnCap golf and housing development in the New Jersey Meadowlands, saying he would come up with a new design, a world-class golf course and more upscale housing.

headline: Renovating for a Flexible Future
text: THERE is a fairly predictable real estate trajectory for the growing family in New York, from single-life studio to one bedroom, from one bedroom to two. A dining alcove becomes the nursery, you annex the apartment next door, and then the outer boroughs and finally the suburbs beckon.

headline: Congress Warms to France’s New President
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 — The United States Congress welcomed Nicolas Sarkozy, the French president, with loud cheers and standing ovations on Wednesday, a sign that France had been forgiven for opposing the American-led war in Iraq.

headline: ‘Spelling Bee’ Ends Run
text: After three years in New York, two and a half of them on Broadway at the Circle in the Square Theater, “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee” is closing. The musical, which opened on Broadway on May 2, 2005, after a sold-out engagement Off Broadway at Second Stage Theater, will end its run on Jan. 20. It won two Tony Awards and will have played 121 previews and 1,136 regular performances. . ... Second Stage has announced that Alice Ripley (“Side Show”) and Brian d’Arcy James (“The Apple Tree”) will play the lead roles in “Next to Normal,” a new musical by Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey starting performances there on Jan. 16.

headline: Hearing Begins in O.J. Simpson Case
text: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 8 — The man who contends that O. J. Simpson stole $100,000 in sports memorabilia from him told a judge on Thursday that the former football star led a six-minute “military-invasion-fashion” raid in September in a Las Vegas hotel room.

headline: Immigration Status of Newark Shooting Suspect in Question
text: Rodolfo Godinez, one of six suspects in the Aug. 4 shooting deaths of three young people in a Newark schoolyard, will be detained by immigration authorities even if he is able to post $3 million bail, Essex County prosecutors said yesterday.

headline: Congressional Democrats Grow Wary of Spitzer License Plan
text: Democratic members of Congress, having watched Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton stumble on the question of whether states should give driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, are growing increasingly agitated over Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to do so and are calling for him to shelve the idea.

headline: Ways to Fix the Health Care System
text: To the Editor:

headline: Germany: Suspect in Bomb Plot Arrested in Turkey
text: Atilla Selek, a 22-year-old German with Turkish parents sought in connection with a reported plot to bomb German and American facilities in Germany, has been arrested in Turkey. Turkish officials said he was detained Tuesday in Konya, his family’s hometown. Three other men, two Germans and a Turkish resident of Germany, are already in custody. German authorities said the plot was in an advanced stage when they uncovered it in September and seized large quantities of potentially explosive chemicals. German officials said Mr. Selek may have helped obtain detonators. In an interview in September, he denied having any links to the plot or to terrorism.

headline: Gunmen Attack Opponents of Chávez’s Bid to Extend Power
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 7  Masked gunmen shot into a group of students on Wednesday at this country’s most prestigious university. The students were returning from a march here protesting changes to the Constitution proposed by President Hugo Chávez that could allow him to remain in power indefinitely.

headline: For All You Smartphone Users With Big Thumbs: Motorola’s New Q Global Aims to Encourage You to Type
text: Motorola’s Moto Q line of smartphones has a new entry, the Q Global, also called the Q9h. This one has been redesigned to make services easy to activate with dedicated keys, so it takes one click to get to e-mail, the calendar, music, the Internet, the camera (both still and video) and the phone.

headline: Markets and Dollar Sink as Slowdown Worry Increases
text: Stock markets plummeted and the dollar sank to a record low against the euro yesterday as investors worldwide grew skittish over rising oil prices and the prospect of a substantial economic slowdown in the United States.

headline: Ingenuity in Space
text: The astronauts and their support team on the ground performed admirably under difficult conditions on an unusually busy and lengthy mission that ended with a smooth landing yesterday. Their accomplishments were a testimonial to the ingenuity of NASA — and a warning of how precarious the nation’s space ventures can become when unexpected glitches develop far from the nearest repair shop.

headline: Country Music Awards
text: The 41st annual Country Music Awards took place in Nashville.

headline: Footnote
text: Footnote

headline: In Paris? Try inventive British or American fusion fare
text: By Katrin Bennhold

headline: Scenes From Performa 07
Finicky Foodies
text: We’re far from reader averse, so here’s some reader verse. “Eat, Drink & Make Crazy,” sent in by Leon Freilich of Park Slope, Brooklyn:

headline: Feeling ‘Blank Inside’
text: Brian Regan of Comedy Central on greeting cards:

headline: Build Up That Wall
text: Hallie Stephens and Holly Pakfar made a one-bedroom apartment in Stuyvesant Town more livable by dividing the living room.

headline: Nasdaq to Add Philly Exchange to Its Stable
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market confirmed Wednesday that it would acquire the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for $652 million to expand its presence in the fast-growing equity options business.

headline: Kirin Swallows Australia’s National Foods
text: The Japanese brewer Kirin Holdings will buy an Australian dairy and juice producer, National Foods for $1 billion from a Philippine partner San Miguel as it seeks growth away from stagnating beer sales.

headline: KRG Capital Closes $1.96 Billion Fund
text: Midmarket buyout firm KRG Capital Partners said it closed its fourth private equity fund at $1.96 billion, beating its $1.25 billion target by 57 percent.

headline: K.K.R. Affiliate Stung by Subprime
text: KKR Financial Holdings, a specialty finance unit of the buyout shop Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, shed its mortgage business and closed a series of collateralized loan obligations as the firm swung to a third-quarter loss after taking an expected hit from the credit crunch.

headline: Kraft Adds 2 Directors Allied With Peltz
text: Kraft Foods on Wednesday struck a deal with the activist investor Nelson Peltz, adding two board members nominated by his Trian Partners and avoiding a potential proxy battle.

headline: Cheyne Pays $6.7 Million in Tax Settlement in Britain
text: Cheyne Capital, the British hedge fund manager whose $6.7 billion structured investment vehicle Cheyne Finance went into bankruptcy last month, has paid a 3.2 million pound ($6.7 million) tax settlement to British authorities.

headline: Delphi Gets Exit Financing From Citigroup and JPMorgan
text: Bankrupt Delphi has revealed the lending group that has agreed to provide close to $7 billion to help the insolvent auto parts maker emerge from court protection.

headline: American Public Boosts I.P.O. Price
text: American Public Education increased the expected price range of its initial public offering to $18 to $19 a share, setting up the company’s two venture capital owners for a richer-than-expected payday.

headline: MerchantCircle Rounds Up New Funding
text: MerchantCircle, a pioneer in online local advertising, raised $10 million in a Series B financing round, sticking with its faithful early-stage investors and adding a pair of key strategic partners.

headline: Close Brothers Spurns $2.9 Billion Buyout Offer
text: The Close Brothers Group, a 129-year-old British investment bank, rejected a 1.4 billion pound ($2.9 billion) cash offer from Cenkos Securities and a partner, Landsbanki Islands.

headline: Morgan Stanley Takes a Hit on Mortgages
text: Morgan Stanley said it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages, underscoring how much the tight credit market was affecting even peripheral players in the mortgage market.

headline: Digg Said to Be Close to Sale
text: Digg, a popular news site where readers rank stories, was the subject of renewed takeover rumors on Wednesday, as the Valleywag blog, citing anonymous sources, said a “major media player” was close to acquiring it for $300 million to $400 million. Digg’s chief executive declined to comment to CNET News.com on the rumor.

headline: After Alibaba, Baidu Considers I.P.O. of Its Own
text: The Chinese Internet search firm Baidu.com is pondering acquisitions and possibly a Hong Kong share listing to fuel an expansion into the country’s consumer Internet market, taking on Alibaba.com in the world’s second-largest Web market.

headline: Wall Street’s Minnows Make Big Calls on Banks
text: A few hitherto unknown analysts have made names for themselves recently with their headline-grabbing calls on investment banking writedowns, Breakingviews says.

headline: Buyout Shops Cash in Lenovo Shares
text: Shares of the Lenovo Group, the computer maker, fell 6.4 percent Wednesday in Hong Kong as three private equity firms sold part of their holdings to cash in 2.9 billion Hong Kong dollars ($372 million) after the stock hit a seven-year high.

headline: Another Advertising Deal for AOL
text: AOL said it would buy Quigo, a seller of small, sponsored links that run next to articles, marking its fourth advertising acquisition this year. The price was reported to be about $340 million.

headline: A New Four-Letter Word on Wall Street: ‘Retirement’
text: The Financial Times’ John Gapper has a bone to pick with Merrill Lynch and Citigroup over the semantics used to describe the departures of the banks’ chief executives.

headline: Will Mergers Ease Investment Banks’ Pain?
text: With all the misery surrounding investment banks of late, is a spate of industry mergers on the horizon? The answer, one analyst told Reuters, is a resounding yes.

headline: Tailor-Made in Hong Kong
text: By Matthew Driskill

headline: AQR Capital Said to Shelve I.P.O. Plans
text: AQR Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm run by a former trader at Goldman Sachs, Cliff Asness, has been forced to shelve plans for an initial public offering after poor performance caused several large investors to pull their cash from the firm’s $38 billion fund, The New York Post reported.

headline: Rubin Is Set to Back Clinton
text: Robert E. Rubin, Treasury secretary in the Clinton administration and new chairman of Citigroup, has overcome early misgivings about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential candidacy and will support her publicly in the fight for the Democratic nomination, The New York Times reported.

headline: Kansas Governor Gets No Apology From Big Coal
text: [UPDATE 11/11: See below for Republican lawmakers’ point of view on this fight.]

headline: How Will Kerik’s Indictment Affect Giuliani?
text: Federal prosecutors will ask a grand jury today to indict Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy counts, William K. Rashbaum and Russ Buettner explain in a front-page article.

headline: Start of a Trend?
text: From The Onion:

headline: S.E.C. Looks Into Merrill’s Subprime Holdings
text: Merrill Lynch disclosed on Wednesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an inquiry into its mortgage-related holdings. It also said that its total exposure to mortgage-related securities is $27.2 billion, or $6.3 billion more than what it said last month.

headline: Rio Tinto Rejects $140 Billion Takeover Bid
text: BHP Billiton said Thursday that it had approached Rio Tinto about a potential takeover that would create a global mining giant worth about $360 billion. Rio rejected its offer, but BHP added that it would continue to press for a deal, which would rank among the largest mergers in history.

headline: The Early Word: Giuliani Backers
text: The unlikely alliance of Rudolph W. Giuliani and evangelical broadcaster Pat Robertson yesterday brought mixed reaction from Republicans. Some conservative Christians worry whether the thrice-married Giuliani shares their values, and other G.O.P. members wonder if Mr. Giuliani’s alliance with a controversial televangelist will turn off moderate voters.

headline: Russians Accused of Poisoning Tennis Star
text: Tommy Haas’s severe case of food poisoning at the Davis Cup would be a rather tame addition to the annals of Russian poisoning accusations.

headline: America Feels L’Amour
text: O.K., quick quiz: Which world leader said the following?

headline: Honoring Tom Cruise
text: The Museum of the Moving Image Gala Honoring Tom Cruise Melena Ryzik attends, makes a flip book.

headline: Painfully Funny
text: The British writers and booksellers Russell Ash and Brian Lake have compiled a small but toothsome anthology called “Bizarre Books: A Compendium of Classic Oddities.”

headline: Smells Like Reader Spirit
text: From a reader comment on an article today questioning the need for regular deodorant use:

headline: Jim Cramer in Middle of Spitzer-Cuomo Niceties
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo appeared together for their first joint news conference in some time to announce a number of steps to bolster Mr. Cuomo’s investigation of corporate practices that contributed to the home mortgage crisis.

headline: Mining for a Blockbuster Merger
text: It’s hardly a done deal, but if BHP Billiton succeeds in acquiring its rival mining giant Rio Tinto, it would be a tie-up for the record books. Deal price tags have not been this high since 2000, a banner year for megamergers that brought us the union of America Online and Time Warner.

headline: Mayor Offers Best Wishes (but No Haiku) to Torre
