text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave a live interview this morning with Rich Masters of the Bill Press Show, on Sirius Satellite Radio, to discuss his call for a carbon tax and his often-repeated complaints about inaction in Washington.

headline: Slowing the Sharks’ Vanishing Act
text: Two environmental groups have put out a fresh call to the United States to strengthen the Shark Finning Prohibition Act, a 2000 law aimed at blunting the illegal trade in shark fins that biologists say has devastated shark populations worldwide in the last decade or so.

headline: Thursday Morning Kickoff
text: Well, well, well. The same place that may have hosted the best college football game of the year also hosted the first huge college basketball upset of the season. We interrupt this football blog for a basketball shocker: The 20th-ranked Kentucky hoops team lost to Gardner-Webb last night. Andy Katz does a nice job here with the late wrap up.

headline: Schreiber’s Notes: Three Lefties to Trade For
text: The Red Sox signing Curt Schilling the other day is a signal that, for a relatively reasonable amount of money ($8 million plus incentives), the team didn’t see anybody out there on the free agent market that was very attractive. Boston could have explored trades, but instead they locked up Schilling before he could get away.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Weill and a Less Celebrated Name
text: Tonight the Austrian composer H.K. Gruber, also known as a conductor and a most unconventional chansonnier, comes to Zankel Hall to lead a pick-up ensemble in works by Kurt Weill and Hanns Eisler. Though you never know, the program should be fascinating.

headline: Genetic ‘Elvis’ for Sale
text: Bill Beeny, who has run the Elvis Is Alive Museum in Wright City, Mo., for 17 years, is selling the museum’s contents on eBay. Along with books, newspapers clippings and a Cadillac is, he says, convincing evidence that Elvis Presley did not die in 1977:

headline: Online Socializing: Safer Than You Think?
text: To many parents, Web sites like My Space and Facebook are a threat, a door open to the outside world that lets strangers into homes. But the benefits of online interaction may far outweigh the risks.

headline: Orange Bowl Memories
text: When Miami plays hosts to Virginia on Saturday it will be the Hurricanes’ last game in the Orange Bowl before moving to Dolphin Stadium next season. The cost to renovate the stadium was too high and the appeal of more modern facilities was too great. As a result, the Hurricanes’ 70th season in the Orange Bowl will be their last.

headline: After Further Review?
text: Earlier this week, baseball’s general managers recommended for the first time that the league allow instant replay. The proposal is limited to instant replay on possible home run balls — whether they are fair or foul, for instance — and faces several more layers of approval. Is this a move in the right direction for baseball, or a bad precedent?

headline: Goodbye, You Dirty Old Charmer
text: There were many glorious highlights at the Orange Bowl, but these made our short list:

headline: On the Trading Block: Kobe Trade Rumors
text: “Kobe Bryant might be traded, and he might not,” writes Will Leitch in this week’s Play newsletter. “He’ll tell reporters he wants to be traded, then he’ll back off, then he’ll post a message to his Web site, then he’ll recant it hours later. None of it means anything. Currently in Google, ‘Kobe Bryant Championship’ brings up 702,000 hits; ‘Kobe Bryant trade’ brings up 926,000. This will be his legacy, and ours.”

headline: Say, What?: The White House on Pakistan
text: From today’s press briefing by White House press secretary Dana Perino, after the Pakistani military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, announced that elections scheduled for Jan. 15 will be delayed for no more than a month, which means they might now be held by Feb. 15:

headline: The Economics of Information
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: NaturalSelector89
text: In the orderly manifesto of Pekka-Eric Auvinen, the Finnish teenager who killed seven people yesterday before killing himself, there’s a section called Collective Deindividualization: Totalitarianism & Delusions Of Democracy.

headline: Readers Answer Some of Pogue’s Imponderables
text: I'm speaking on a Geek Cruise to the Panama Canal—tough job, but somebody's got to do it—so I'll be taking two weeks off from my column, blog and videos.

headline: Town & Country
text: The most exciting thing that happened on vacation was the mouse that came back to life. This happens to a lot of designers we know. A bad season, and then, presto, born again. I tried to do as little as possible during my holiday, which essentially entailed the odd flirtatious dance with the vacuum cleaner. Everything was too much and nothing was too little, if you know what I mean. My son brought home Terry Richardson’s book of his father Bob Richardson’s photographs and we especially liked Bob’s stories and his straight-forward opinions about other photographers, mainly Avedon and Meisel. I think Terry did a great job with the book; it’s a valuable resource for young photographers, and a week or so later, when I saw Terry’s recent pictures in Vogue Hommes International, particularly of James Franco, I sensed again the son’s desire to be contemporary. Like his dad. (Vogue Hommes also has a pretty good interview with Calvin Klein; especially interesting was what he had to say about Mark Wahlberg, then and now.)

headline: Readers Answer Some of Pogue’s Imponderables
text: I’m speaking on a Geek Cruise to the Panama Canal—tough job, but somebody’s got to do it—so I’ll be taking two weeks off from my column, blog and videos.

headline: A Day Trip From Paris to Luxembourg
text: My husband and I will be spending time in Paris, and we’d like to take a day trip to Luxembourg. Can this be done, and if so, can you recommend an itinerary?

headline: Put the Lime in the Bomber and …
text: Add it to the list of remedies to widespread health scares: leeches, penicillin, the polio vaccine, the iron lung, and now, the Lime Bomber.

headline: Morgan’s Bad News Is Good, or Maybe Not
text: Welcome to the upside-down world of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Old Enough for Wine?
text: I got an e-mail yesterday that alerted me to a hugely interesting column in the Detroit Free Press, where I once worked for five years. headline: Fiscal Policy, 30 Years After the Crisis
text: If you ask most New Yorkers about GAAP-balanced budgets, four-year financial plans and the city’s emergency financial control board, you are likely to get only a blank stare. But any city resident who lived through the pain and tumult of the mid-1970s can attest to the anxiety caused by tens of thousands of layoffs, the disruption of city services and the looming fear of municipal bankruptcy.The city’s Independent Budget Office and the Center for New York City Affairs at the New School organized a gathering of the city’s leading experts in municipal finance — including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s budget director, Mark Page — this morning for a discussion, moderated by Joyce Purnick of The Times. The issue is not a theoretical one, because next year will bring a major change — the first since 1975 — in how the city’s budget works.

headline: Understand?
Blind Date in Addis

A dear friend who had adopted a child from Ethiopia wanted me to consider an adoption from that country and told me that I could see some nice waiting children on a video if I contacted the agency she used. I had no intention of doing such a thing and that was that. I did not call the agency.

headline: Riverhead: Nine Arrested in Gambling Raids

The raids, at eight locations, followed a robbery at an illegal poker game in Lindenhurst in September, said Thomas J. Spota, the Suffolk County district attorney. In a statement, Mr. Spota said the robbery, by two men carrying shotguns, demonstrated the potential danger of high-stakes poker games. He said that the games attracted violence, and that “law enforcement is concerned about the safety of the innocent people in the neighborhoods.”

headline: Master Carver of Old Salem

Despite never leaving home, he was an enlightened 18th-century American: self-educated, talented, determined and energetic.

headline: Goodbye, You Dirty Old Charmer
text: Rickety. For at least the past 40 years, that’s been the default modifier for the Orange Bowl Stadium, a Miami landmark since 1937. Electric is more fitting. Start with the shock upon arriving in the neighborhood, when the guy told you “treinta” — $30 — to park on his lawn. When the stands shook and swayed, it felt like it would register on the Richter Scale. A big-play roar for the home team was like Niagara Falls from the Maid of the Mist. Home-field advantage? Huge. The Dolphins played there from 1966 to 1988, went unbeaten in 1972, and made it to four Super Bowls. None since. The University of Miami, which played its home games there, has won five National Championships since 1985, the most in college football. Now the Hurricanes are turning out the lights at the Orange Bowl for the last time after their game against Virginia on Saturday and will move to Dolphins Stadium in North Miami in 2008. Less rickety, less electricity.

headline: Italy: Big Bank Acquisition

Monte Paschi, based in Siena, is under pressure to grow after its bigger rivals, UniCredit and Intesa Sanpaolo, expanded through takeovers. Based in Padua, Antonveneta has 1,000 branches concentrated in Italy’s northwest.

headline: Art Is Brief. You Just Have to Be There.

headline: Uncorking One Family’s Secret
text: Graham Swift’s lugubrious new novel, “Tomorrow,” is told in the voice of an Englishwoman named Paula Hook silently addressing her children. Unable to sleep, Paula worries about what is going to happen the next morning: She and her husband, Mike, have decided that tomorrow is “Doomsday” or “Bombshell Day,” the day they are going to tell their 16-year-old twins, Kate and Nick, a family secret that “will change all our lives.” Mike and Paula have dreaded this moment for years: Earlier this evening they planned a “terminal supper,” and “made love in a special, a poignant, a farewell way.” As the narrator sees it, the ordeal to come is her husband’s “real moment of judgment,” and she tells her children that they will be in a position to “decide in his favor” or not. She says she has no idea how Nick and Kate will react to his news: “I picture a bomb going off and this house falling to bits. I picture everything remaining oddly, precariously, ominously the same. An unexploded bomb. It still might go off — next week, the week after, any time.” The big secret, which seems pretty obvious to the attentive reader early on, is revealed about halfway through the novel — and this is fair warning to readers who would prefer not to know: that Mike is not the twins’ biological father, that they were conceived by artificial insemination, using an anonymous donor’s sperm.

Lauder for $135 million. The portrait, “Adele Bloch-Bauer I,” was sold to him after the Austrian government returned to the family five Klimt paintings looted by the Nazis.

headline: A Former Dutch Enclave Charms a New Generation

And starting in the 18th century, Dutch settlers built their homes with gray, squarish chunks of it, giving their walls a marbled cast. On more than three-dozen vintage structures today, that look endures, so perhaps the misnomer can be forgiven.
