text: To the Editor:

headline: College Art Sale Halted
text: A Virginia judge has granted a temporary injunction preventing the sale of four paintings owned by Randolph College’s Maier Museum of Art until litigation against the school is settled, The Associated Press reported. The ruling on Thursday was in response to motions filed by a group seeking to stop this financially troubled school from selling the works to increase its endowment. The paintings, including “Men of the Docks” (1912), below, by George Bellows, were to be sold through Christie’s this month in New York, for an estimated $25 million to $35 million. Judge J. Leyburn Mosby Jr. of the Lynchburg Circuit Court found that “the harm if the art is sold is greater than the harm if the art is not sold.” The injunction is to take effect once the opponents to the sale post a $10 million bond. The college, in Lynchburg, will appeal to the Virginia Supreme Court and hopes to have the decision reversed before the first auction on Nov. 19, a college spokeswoman said. Another motion previously filed by Randolph College asks the circuit court to determine whether the school can legally sell or share 36 pieces of art bought from a trust bequeathed by a former professor.

headline: Tough Guy Kerik Often Lived on the Edge
text: In late 2001, at the end of his 16-month term as New York police commissioner, the reckless side of Bernard B. Kerik played out on three stages.

headline: Ford Workers Voting as Contract Opponents Step Up Their Efforts
text: DETROIT, Nov. 9  Workers at major Ford Motor Company plants are voting this weekend on a new contract whose approval looks likely, even though dissidents are stepping up efforts to defeat it.

Eliot Spitzer made statements to investigators about an effort to discredit Senator Joseph L. Bruno that differed from the account he later provided under oath to the state’s public integrity commission.

headline: Hope for the Everglades
text: Seven years ago, Congress and the Clinton administration set in motion the most ambitious environmental initiative on the planet: an $8 billion, 40-year project to restore South Florida’s ecosystem and, in particular, the Everglades, which had been punished by a half-century of uncontrolled development and starved of fresh water.

headline: Green Cities Solve Ills
text: To the Editor:

headline: Students Emerge as a Leading Force Against Chávez
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 9 — Finding Yon Goicoechea, a leader of the nascent student movement protesting the expanding power of President Hugo Chávez, is not easy. He changes cellphones every few days. After receiving dozens of death threats, he moves among the apartments of friends here each day in search of a safe place to sleep.

headline: U.S. Strategy for Pakistan Looks More Fragile
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — In pushing for the deal that took Benazir Bhutto back to Pakistan, the Bush administration hoped to build a broader base of support that might help Gen. Pervez Musharraf stay in power.

headline: Bush and Relatives of Fallen Lean on Each Other
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — Late one night last year, while her husband was an Army scout in Iraq, Melissa Storey sat in the quiet of her bedroom to write President Bush a letter. She wanted him to know “we believed in him.” And after Staff Sgt. Clint Storey, 30, was killed by a roadside bomb, his widow put pen to paper again.

headline: It’s Asian Work, but Abandon the Stereotypes Before Entering the Booths
text: Two young, bald Asian women in Western-style clothes are horsing around. One points her finger at the head of the other, who scrunches up her face as if bracing for a bullet.

headline: As Oil Soars, Natural Gas Is a Bargain
text: As oil prices surged over the last few months, natural gas prices in the United States did something that could help to cushion the economic shock. They fell.

headline: 3 Big Banks See Troubles; Barclays Falls on Rumors
text: Three big banks warned yesterday about continuing losses in the credit markets, while Barclays of London denied speculation that it was facing a huge write-down of assets.

headline: Pakistani Leader Blocks Protests, Creating Impasse
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 9 — The sweeping security crackdown by Gen. Pervez Musharraf that thwarted a protest rally against his emergency decree by the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto left the two adversaries locked in a standoff on Friday.

headline: Cotto-Mosley Could Offer More Action Than Hype
text: Oscar De La Hoya is no stranger to boxing’s hype machine. Six months ago, for his fight against Floyd Mayweather, he was part of one of the most intense promotions the sport had seen.

headline: Bail Offer for Friend of Killer Is Opposed
text: He was grilled with all the vehemence of a witness in a mob case, but he was a comedian trying to put up bail for a small-time drug addict who is the companion of a notorious symbol of overprivileged and amoral youth.

headline: Analysts See Merck Victory in Vioxx Settlement
text: For the drug maker Merck to pay almost $5 billion to settle lawsuits from people who contended that the painkiller Vioxx caused their heart attacks and strokes may not seem like a corporate victory.

headline: New Jersey’s Verdict on Stem Cells
text: Tuesday’s decision by New Jersey voters to reject a measure that would have let the state borrow $450 million for stem cell research represented a victory for conservative groups that mustered a full-throated campaign against it, a painful defeat for Gov. Jon Corzine and a disheartening setback for medical research.

headline: Exports Help Shrink the Trade Deficit to Lowest Level in Two Years
text: A surge in export sales, fueled by the dollar’s record-low value against the euro, sent the United States trade deficit to its lowest level in more than two years, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday about the former world bridge champion Paul Soloway misspelled the given name of his surviving sister. She is Alison Greenberg, not Allison.

headline: The Orchestra Plays Hard, the Audience Is Warned
text: Assistant and associate conductors at major orchestras can often be heard grumbling that whatever the benefits of the job — a great résumé line, a close-up view of how a big musical organization works and the chance to lead educational and community concerts — they get little quality time in the spotlight. Xian Zhang, the New York Philharmonic’s associate conductor, may have it better than most, making a few high-profile appearances every season, both in subscription programs and in goodwill appearances like the orchestra’s free concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

headline: The Knicks Lose James to Injuries
text: Jerome James, a backup center for the Knicks, will have surgery on his right foot Monday, the team said yesterday. He is expected to be out indefinitely.

headline: Near Hometown of the Gipper, Protests Over an Exhumation
text: Even larger in death than he was during his astonishing and all-too-brief life, the Notre Dame football legend George Gipp is once again stirring passions, 87 years after he died.

headline: Personal Assistant Is Charged in Broker’s Killing
text: A personal assistant was charged yesterday with using a piece of exercise equipment to fatally bludgeon her boss, Linda Stein, the former punk-rock manager turned real estate broker, in her Fifth Avenue penthouse, the authorities said.

headline: Paying More for Power
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some editions on Thursday about a crackdown on charter schools in Ohio by the state’s attorney general referred incorrectly to Bill Richardson, a Democratic presidential candidate who supports quality charters. He is the current governor of New Mexico, not a former one.

headline: Where the Rats Come Out to Play
text: The rat that was circling André Thomas’s feet was big and brazen, measuring more than a foot from the tip of its tail to a pointed snout that arched upward to the aroma of Mr. Thomas’s ham and cheese sandwich.

headline: Canadian Inquiry to Review Payments to Ex-Prime Minister
text: OTTAWA, Nov. 9  Allegations surrounding substantial cash payments by a German-Canadian businessman to Brian Mulroney, a former prime minister, will be reviewed by an independent investigator, Prime Minister Stephen Harper said Friday.

headline: George Ratterman, Football Star and Sheriff, Dies at 80
text: George Ratterman, a quarterback for Notre Dame’s 1946 national champions and the Cleveland Browns who later drew national attention when he was drugged and set up for an arrest while leading an anticorruption drive in a notorious Kentucky river town, died last Saturday in Centennial, Colo. He was 80.

headline: Oil Spill Spreads in San Francisco Bay
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 — Challenged by strong winds and tides, cleanup crews struggled Friday to contain an oil spill spreading in the San Francisco Bay as Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger declared a state of emergency for the area.

headline: Finding Thrills With the King of ‘Blueberry Hill’
text: Fats Domino offered just a taste of music during the all-star benefit concert held in his honor on Thursday at the Chelsea nightclub Pink Elephant. Taking his place at a grand piano, he laid into the familiar triplet vamp of “Blueberry Hill.” In short order he was singing that landmark hit, in his agreeable and remarkably ageless New Orleans drawl.

headline: In Battery Buying, Enough Decisions to Exhaust That Bunny
text: DAYLIGHT saving time ended this week, and we were all told that it would be the perfect time to change the batteries on our smoke alarms.

headline: Broadway Strike Will Halt All but Eight Shows
text: Broadway’s stagehands will go on strike today, capping more than three months of unsuccessful negotiations with theater owners and producers, the producers said in a posting on their Web site this morning. Local One, the stagehands’ union, was told last night by its parent union to walk out, according to two people who have been briefed on the decision.

headline: Georgian Parliament Confirms Emergency Rule
text: MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 10 — The Georgian Parliament approved a state of emergency decree on Friday issued by President Mikheil Saakashvili on Wednesday, allowing emergency rule for as long as 15 days despite calls from inside and outside the country for the restoration of personal and political rights.

headline: Florida Ends Shuttling of Refugees to Canada
text: A Florida organization that assisted hundreds of illegal immigrants in fleeing to Canada must close and return thousands of dollars it collected from the immigrants, who believed they would be given legal status in that country, Florida’s attorney general said yesterday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Q. Do You Believe in God? A. Yes, No and Well . . .
text: Do you believe in God? What will happen to you at death? Do you pray? Do you think religious believers are deluded?

headline: A Series of Composers Add Up to a Symphony
text: For composers since Beethoven, writing a ninth symphony has become something like attaining the biblical threescore and 10; for the more superstitious among them, it means the end is nigh. Beethoven died with his 10th on the drawing board. So did Mahler. Bruckner wrote 11, if you count two symphonies he repudiated, one performed as the Symphony No. 0.

headline: 2 Students Die in Fire on Day a University Inaugurates a President
text: ROCHESTER, Nov. 9 — It was to have been a day of celebration at the Rochester Institute of Technology. Instead it was a day of mourning for two seniors who died in an early morning fire on Friday after flames engulfed their off-campus house.

headline: NBC Chief Puts On His Own Angry Show
text: Ben Silverman, who runs NBC’s entertainment operation, and Kevin Reilly, who used to, were once close enough friends that they went on a ski trip together last winter. It is not likely that either will be on the other’s holiday card list this year.

headline: Corrections
text: An article yesterday about the anger on the streets of Pakistan over President Pervez Musharraf’s declaration of emergency rule misstated the circumstances of Pakistan’s independence 60 years ago. It was created when the British partitioned colonial India into the states of India and Pakistan. It was not granted independence by India.

headline: F.C.C. Planning Rules to Open Cable Market
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — The Federal Communications Commission is preparing to impose significant new regulations to open the cable television market to independent programmers and rival video services after determining that cable companies have become too dominant in the industry, senior commission officials said.

headline: Mailer Made America His Subject
text: Norman Mailer was nothing if not ambitious. He once declared he wanted to write “a novel which Dostoyevsky and Marx; Joyce and Freud; Stendhal, Tolstoy, Proust and Spengler; Faulkner, and even old moldering Hemingway might come to read.” He wanted to “alter the nerves and marrow” of the nation with his work, to “change the consciousness” of his times. He wanted to write the Big Book, the Great American Novel. He wanted to hit the longest long ball of them all.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on Nov. 2 about the accusation that a French boy was raped in Dubai referred incorrectly, using information from a police report, to the American School in Dubai and a 17-year-old suspect in the case. The suspect is not a student at the American School, and the school says it has no Emiratis enrolled.

headline: TV Writers’ Strike Leaves Jilted Authors Looking for a Bully Pulpit
text: David Levy’s publisher had built his entire book tour around a scheduled appearance on “The Colbert Report” last Monday.

headline: China Juggles Tombs, Dragon Boats and Marx
text: HONG KONG, Nov. 9 — A Chinese government panel announced plans on Friday to revamp the holiday schedule to re-emphasize traditional festivals at the expense of the Marxist May Day celebration.

headline: Gaza’s Isolation Takes Toll on Students and Prices
text: GAZA — Miriam Ashour will turn 18 in November and speaks English with only the slightest of accents. She has a scholarship to study for a college degree in business administration at Columbia College, affiliated with the United Methodist Church, in Columbia, S.C.

headline: From Center Court to Off Court (and Maybe in Court)
text: The women’s year-end championships are in full swing in Madrid, with Justine Henin still in fine form and Maria Sharapova showing signs of resurgence. In Shanghai, the men’s year-end championships are set to start tomorrow with the top eight men in the world, led by Roger Federer.

headline: Mother Denied Custody of Girl
text: A woman whose estranged husband was killed in an unexplained shooting on a Queens playground last month was denied temporary custody of the couple’s 4-year-old daughter yesterday.

headline: Recession? What Recession?
text: If it looks like a recession and feels like a recession ...

headline: Federal Judge Calls Rendition Process ‘Outsourcing’
text: Calling the process of rendition “outsourcing,” a federal appeals court judge in New York sharply questioned government lawyers yesterday at a hearing involving a Syrian-born Canadian detained at Kennedy Airport in 2002 and sent to Syria, where he was held for 10 months.

headline: Singing of Weimar Era, Subversively
text: Carnegie Hall’s ambitious Berlin in Lights Festival went back to the Weimar era during a sold-out concert on Thursday night at Zankel Hall. The Austrian composer, sometime actor and idiosyncratic chansonnier H K Gruber led a dynamic pick-up ensemble, the Zankel Band, in songs and instrumental works by Kurt Weill and Hanns Eisler, the greatest music theater composers of the 1920s and early ’30s in Berlin.

headline: Illusion of Success Gives Way to Suits and Suicide
text: MURFREESBORO, Tenn. — Robert W. McLean cut a larger-than-life figure in this small mid-Tennessee city. An investment manager and arts patron, he traveled by limousine, flashed a wide grin as he presented oversize checks to advance his favorite causes and promised huge returns to those who invested with him.

headline: Third-Quarter Loss at Fannie Mae More Than Doubled
text: Fannie Mae, the home mortgage company, said yesterday that its third-quarter loss more than doubled, to $1.39 billion, as a deepening housing slump increased mortgage delinquencies.

headline: An Operatic Voice Retuned for Cabaret
text: Listening to Patricia Racette sing popular songs at the Neue Galerie on Thursday and recollecting her “Madama Butterfly” this season at the Metropolitan Opera posed the interesting question of where her natural voice lies, or if “natural voice” means anything.

headline: Some Help for One Whose Life Means Loss
text: Ana Melendez is a woman in mourning, though you wouldn’t immediately know it from her warm, gravelly laugh and sparkling eyes. But each day is a reminder that some of the most important people in her life are gone.

headline: Guest, Entertain Us. Now.
text: Many of the 200 or so guests who arrived at The Atlantic Monthly’s 150th-anniversary party on Thursday night didn’t realize they were going to end up as part of the advertised performance.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary yesterday about Abram Lerner, the first director of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, misstated the reason the government established the Works Progress Administration, which employed Mr. Lerner in the 1930s as an apprentice muralist. Its primary purpose was to provide employment during the Depression, not to support artists and writers. (Three of its divisions, the Federal Art Project, the Federal Writers’ Project and the Federal Theater Project, did support artists and writers.)

headline: Attracting Valuable Coaches to the Priciest College Town
text: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 5 — When Scott Shafer came to Stanford to interview for the defensive coordinator’s job last winter, he became more excited as the day went on. He enjoyed Coach Jim Harbaugh’s energy, meeting his potential co-workers and seeing the vision for the program.

headline: Experts Discuss Engineering Feats, Like Space Mirrors, to Slow Climate Change
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 — There is now “no doubt” that some of the effects of human-induced climate change could be offset with engineering fixes, according to David Keith, an expert on climate and energy at the University of Calgary.

headline: Another Steep Plunge Ends Harsh Week for Stocks
text: Stocks came tantalizingly close to a flat close yesterday before plunging in the final minutes, ending a painful week in the markets on a low note.

headline: Footnotes
text: The National Arts Center in Ottawa and the Toronto Symphony Orchestra are teaming to create a major summer arts festival in Niagara, Ontario, The Toronto Star reported. “We are aiming for something first class with the clout and international reputation of Tanglewood,” said Peter Herrndorf, chief executive of the National Arts Center. “We are still working on feasibility studies, but if all goes well we would aim for opening in 2011 or 2012.” ...“The Starry Messenger,” the Kenneth Lonergan play which was to star Matthew Broderick, has been dropped from the Manhattan Theater Club season because of scheduling conflicts. The play, which Mr. Lonergan was to direct, was to open in February at City Center. A replacement production has not been announced. ... A British judge ordered a rival group to stop using the name of the Four Tops, The Associated Press reported. Judge Nicholas Warren of the High Court in London ruled that the singer Viscount Oliver Miller must stop performing and recording under the name Viscount Oliver’s Legendary Four Tops. The Four Tops were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1990.

headline: Rudy and Bernie: B.F.F.’s
text: The past seven years have given us some helpful hints on what we want to avoid in the next president. I’m starting to make a list.

headline: Denmark’s Unabashed Lightning Rod on Immigration
text: COPENHAGEN

headline: Telling Mattress Users a Lot Has Changed Since 1871
text: NO one would be happier than H. Thomas Bryant, 60, chief executive of Tempur-Pedic International, based in Lexington, Ky., to hear the last squeak of an innerspring mattress. But while his company, which makes and sells mattresses and pillows from its proprietary Tempur pressure-relieving material, is making inroads against Sealy, Serta, Simmons and others, it has a long way to go. Tempur-Pedic has a 10 percent share of the mattress market in the United States, based on dollars, but only a 2.2 percent share of units sold.

headline: House Backs Tax Relief Bill, but Fate in Senate Is Unsure
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — The House passed a $78.3 billion tax bill on Friday that would shield about 21 million people from the alternative minimum tax next year, and pay for it in part by ending tax breaks for private equity funds, hedge funds and other partnerships.

headline: Rev. Chad Varah, Anglican Priest Who Helped the Suicidal, Dies at 95
text: The Rev. Chad Varah, an outspoken, publicity-sly, sometimes cantankerous Anglican priest who started a telephone hot line for the suicidal after concluding that loneliness is the most heart-rending anguish, died Thursday in Basingstoke, England. He was 95.

headline: Obama Fights Foes, Seen or Otherwise
text: JOHNSTON, Iowa, Nov. 9 — Senator Barack Obama’s political appeal has always stemmed in part from his biography. For nine months, he has been telling his story in dozens of visits across Iowa, amplified by a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign and a robust network of admirers.

headline: There Comes a Time to Sell
text: FEW investments go up forever, so as tempting as it may be to stick with a big winner, fund managers sometimes conclude that enough is enough.

headline: Citing Health, Lawmaker Announces Plan to Retire
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — Representative Jim Saxton of New Jersey, a Republican who has served in Congress since 1984, said Friday that he would not seek re-election next year because he had prostate cancer.

headline: Welsh Bass-Baritone Hears the Call of Home
text: During a recent rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera for Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro” the marvelous Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel exuded charisma, pretending to answer his cellphone mid-aria. Mr. Terfel’s Met performances as Figaro, a signature role and the one with which he made his Met debut in 1994, start this afternoon, and this will be his swan song in the part.

headline: Bookkeeper Is Stabbed to Death in a Store
text: A 52-year-old bookkeeper from the Bronx who was apparently working after hours at a boutique jeweler on the Upper East Side was found stabbed to death at the back of the store early yesterday, the police said.

headline: Autopsy Finds That Death of Gotbaum Was Accident
text: Carol A. Gotbaum, who died in a police holding cell at a Phoenix airport in September, was accidentally strangled, according to an autopsy released yesterday, which also said intoxication from alcohol and prescription medication played a role in her death.

headline: E*Trade Cuts Profit Forecast, Citing Write-Downs on Mortgage Securities
text: The E*Trade Financial Corporation, the discount brokerage and banking firm, said yesterday that it would not be able to meet its previously announced profit targets because it expected to report “significant write-downs” in the value of mortgage-backed securities it holds.

headline: Roosevelt Island Plan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stopping the Presses on a Potter Book
text: After being sued by J. K. Rowling, a publisher said he would halt typesetting on the “Harry Potter Lexicon,” by Steve Vander Ark, until a federal judge rules on whether it violates Ms. Rowling’s intellectual property rights or the copyright on her novels held by Warner Brothers, the maker of the Harry Potter films, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The book, drawn on material from the fan-created Harry Potter Lexicon Web site (hp-lexicon.org), founded by Mr. Vander Ark, had been set for a Nov. 28 release. Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr., of the Southern District of New York, barred publication to allow him to assess the suit’s merits; Roger Rapoport, publisher of RDR Books of Muskegon, Mich., said the typesetting would stop. The suit seeks to block publication on the grounds that the book is likely to borrow too heavily from Ms. Rowling’s work, and interfere with her plans to publish her own encyclopedia on the wizarding world. Ms. Rowling said on her Web site that she took “no pleasure” in the prevention of the Lexicon’s publication.

headline: Larry Johnson Out
text: Although his injured left foot “has made significant improvement,” Kansas City Chiefs running back Larry Johnson will not play tomorrow against Denver, the team said.

headline: Myanmar Dissident Meets With Party
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 9 — The pro-democracy leader in Myanmar, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, met on Friday with members of her party, the National League for Democracy, for the first time in three years as well as with Aung Kyi, the general appointed as a liaison by Myanmar’s military government, news agencies reported from Yangon.

headline: Roses and Reality in Georgia
text: These are critical days in the former Soviet republic of Georgia. The survival of its hard-won democracy, its aspirations to join NATO and the European Union and the once-glowing international reputation of its president, Mikheil Saakashvili, are all suddenly on the line.

headline: Speed and Stillness, With Strokes of Humor
text: It’s a treat when a small downtown theater shines a spotlight on an artist like Douglas Dunn, who once performed with Merce Cunningham and Yvonne Rainer, was a member of the collective Grand Union and began presenting his own work in 1971.

headline: Two Growing Markets That Start at Your Tap
text: Municipal water systems are aging. Environmentalists are castigating the makers of bottled water  and the people who buy it  for defiling the environment with plastic.

headline: Thompson Seeks to Alter Entitlement for Retirees
text: Fred D. Thompson, venturing into the treacherous political territory of changing Social Security, called yesterday for slowing the growth of benefits for future retirees by using a different yardstick on which to calculate the monthly payouts.

headline: Rhode Island to Reclassify 17-Year-Olds
text: Rhode Island criminal courts will again treat 17-year-olds as juveniles after Gov. Donald L. Carcieri let a bill repealing a four-month-old law become law without his signature.

headline: C.E.O. Evolution Phase 3
text: Has the time come for C.E.O. Version 3.0?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A map with the Outdoors article in sports on Wednesday about kayaking on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques misidentified a site on the north coast that is popular for its views and water activities. It is Mosquito Pier — not Mosquito Bay, which is on the south coast and is famous for its bioluminescence.

headline: Housing Program on Track Amid Financing Concerns
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is on track toward achieving his plan of creating or preserving 165,000 units of housing for low- and moderate-income New Yorkers by 2013, but financing is likely to pose a challenge in the coming years, according to a report released yesterday by the city’s Independent Budget Office.

headline: As Stagehands Strike, Shows Don’t Go On
text: After a morning of confusion and anxiety during which members of Local One, the stagehands union, met and the producers waited to see what would happen, the stagehands strike has officially begun. Union members are holding picket signs in front of theaters and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, the parent union of Local One, issued a statement confirming the walkout.

headline: Swimming, Biking, Running and Flying Under Radar
text: CLEARWATER, Fla., Nov. 8  When 1,500 elite-level triathletes compete in the second annual Ironman 70.3 world championship here Saturday, they will be greeted mostly with ambivalence by residents of the Tampa Bay area.

headline: Imagine There’s No Heaven, Just Flamenco
text: At the core of flamenco is the notion of duende — those dark forces contesting within the artist’s soul, forcing their way out through the dance to evoke the battle with life, with death, with the birth of art itself.

headline: The New Penn Station
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rendering Services Beyond the Call of Duty
text: When Gil Parkin was the personal assistant to a real estate broker, his duties included cooking her lunch and dinner, picking out gifts that went to her clients, and once, doing what amounted to emergency dental work.

headline: In Search of Sex, Money and the Meaning of Life
text: The ideas and sometimes the actors ricochet around the stage with such energy and scattershot purpose in Adam Rapp’s “Bingo With the Indians” that they might be in a pinball machine. A dark comedy that starts with a sitcom premise and finally invokes questions about the meaning of life, the play spins out of control, but that forgivable chaos comes from a writer who hasn’t reined in his overabundance of ideas.

headline: A Defiant Kerik Vows to Battle U.S. Indictment
text: A defiant Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, vowed yesterday to fight a 16-count federal indictment, setting the stage for legal proceedings that could cast a shadow over the presidential campaign of his friend and one-time mentor, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, deep into the 2008 election season.

headline: Veterans Day Events in Westchester County
text: Here is a partial list of Veterans Day events in Westchester County.

headline: UConn Is Right on Time
text: STORRS, Conn., Nov. 7 — In every room at the University of Connecticut’s new football complex, embedded in nearly every wall, are the red digits of synchronized clocks.

headline: Indicting Mr. Kerik
text: Bernard Kerik’s indictment on fraud and corruption charges is disturbing on its own, but it also raises broader issues. It is sobering to think how close Mr. Kerik came to becoming secretary of the Homeland Security Department, and it is also troubling that Rudolph Giuliani, a leading candidate for president, has been so close to him for so long, as a friend, boss and business partner.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Oct. 31 about efforts by law schools to overhaul their curriculum misidentified a report that Catherine Carpenter, a law professor at Southwestern Law School in Los Angeles, co-authored and on which she commented. It was a report on a survey for the American Bar Association about the teaching of law; she was not co-author of a Carnegie Foundation report on legal education. When Ms. Carpenter said she would like to do “this survey again in 2010 and really see what has changed,” she was referring to the bar association report, not the Carnegie report.

headline: Norman Mailer, Towering Writer With Matching Ego, Dies at 84
text: Norman Mailer, the combative, controversial and often outspoken novelist who loomed over American letters longer and larger than any writer of his generation, died today in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: John E. Grenier, 77, a Leader of Goldwater’s ’64 Bid, Is Dead
text: John E. Grenier, a former executive director of the Republican National Committee and one of the architects of Senator Barry M. Goldwater’s Southern strategy in his failed bid for the presidency in 1964, died Tuesday in Houston. He was 77 and lived in Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about Mitt Romney’s emphasis during campaign appearances on the need for Americans to be optimistic referred incorrectly to President Jimmy Carter’s description of the mood of the United States in 1979. In a speech that year, Mr. Carter discussed a “crisis of the American spirit,” but he did not use the word “malaise.”

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on Nov. 2 about the accusation that a French boy was raped in Dubai referred incorrectly, using information from a police report, to the American School in Dubai and a 17-year-old suspect in the case. The suspect is not a student at the American School, and the school says it has no Emiratis enrolled. (Go to Article)

headline: Lessons in Shakespeare, From Stage to Boardroom
text: James Dimon rediscovered Shakespeare shortly after he was fired from his job as president of Citigroup by the man who had been almost like a father to him, Sanford I. Weill.

headline: A Mountain’s Molten Heart Keeps a Village on Edge
text: KALI BLADAR, Indonesia, Nov. 9 — For about a month, Ibu Suwarni’s life has been interrupted by Mount Kelud, one of Indonesia’s most dangerous volcanoes. The mountain was giving every indication that a major eruption was imminent, with clouds of white smoke billowing as the temperature of its crater lake spiked as high as 169 degrees.

headline: Seeing Progress in Iraq, McCain Hopes for Credit
text: CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 9 — Now that President Bush’s decision early this year to send more troops to Iraq is showing signs of reducing the violence in Baghdad, Senator John McCain, who had long called for beefing up the American military presence there, is betting that the politics of the war are changing as well.

headline: In Mine Bid, BHP Again Takes the Long View
text: SINGAPORE, Nov. 9 — As chief executive of BHP Billiton, Charles W. Goodyear was fond of showing investors and journalists a chart of commodities prices dating back to the War of 1812 — the “200-year view,” it was entitled.

headline: Dance in Review
text: MONICA BILL BARNES

headline: Afghan Bombing Tally Rises to 72
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 9 — New reports pushed the death toll in Tuesday’s suicide attack on a parliamentary delegation in northern Afghanistan to at least 72 on Friday, according to the Education Ministry, driven by an agonizing increase in the number of schoolchildren killed to 59.

headline: Face of Giants Now a Cog in the Wheel
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 9 — Behind the chuckle, the smirk and the wink is the old Jeremy Shockey. No matter which disguise he uses, he cannot fully hide some measure of discontent over his role with the Giants.

headline: Fordham Believes, and Then Starts Winning
text: It was halftime of the fifth game of the season, and Fordham had been playing like a team going nowhere — not necessarily a surprise for a program having not only a bad year but also a bad decade. The Rams trailed Colgate, 24-13, and seemed headed to a loss and a 2-3 record.

headline: Crime Pays for CBS
text: CBS linked “CSI” and “Without a Trace” Thursday and garnered a ratings windfall. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 21.9 million viewers tuned in to “CSI” at 9 p.m., the most since the show’s September season premiere. “Without a Trace” at 10 p.m. (21.4 million) delivered CBS’s best ratings in that slot in almost two years. CBS easily won the night, taking the 8 p.m. hour as well with “Survivor: China” (14.9 million), which beat the runner up, “Ugly Betty” on ABC (10.9 million). ABC’s 9 p.m. drama, “Grey’s Anatomy” (19.3 million), was the top-rated show among adults 18 to 49, but ABC ranked second for the night. NBC, buoyed by “The Office” at 9 (8.3 million), earned third place. Fox tied NBC in total viewers but finished fourth in the 18-to-49 set.

headline: The Sex Pistols Return
text: The Sex Pistols snarled through their greatest hits late on Thursday at the start of a reunion tour, Reuters reported. “Half a century young!” the lead singer, John Lydon, below, shouted to thousands of fans at Brixton Academy in south London. Sporting spiky orange hair, Mr. Lydon, known as Johnny Rotten, wore a pheasant shooting outfit, whose trousers kept slipping down. “There’ll Always Be an England” blasted over the speakers before the set began. The Times of London described Mr. Lydon’s performance as “a splenetic, spitting drizzle of gurning invective.” Mr. Lydon, 51, performed with the guitarist Steve Jones, 52, the bassist Glen Matlock and the drummer Paul Cook, both 51. After Brixton, the band is scheduled to play Manchester and Glasgow.

headline: Latin Mass Draws Interest After Easing of Restrictions
text: MERCHANTVILLE, N.J. — Kelly Rein, 16, used to spend most Thursday nights doing homework. These days, Kelly wears a lace mantilla over her striped T-shirt and stovepipe jeans and attends a class on the traditional Latin Mass.

headline: Perp Nation: ‘Cops’ and Its Steady Run of Bad Boys
text: As “Cops” presents its 700th episode this evening, Saturday nights on the networks are resembling an abandoned neighborhood. Once upon a time, American families gathered there to see Carol Burnett gamely sing along with Julie Andrews, or Mary Tyler Moore throw a calamitous cocktail party, or even Charo make her umpteenth “Love Boat” appearance.

headline: The Politics of Taxes
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Sea Activity Draws Concern
text: Countries bound by a treaty governing dumping at sea agreed on a statement of “concern” about a nascent business in which companies are preparing to add iron or other substances to the ocean to absorb climate-warming carbon dioxide from the air. There are only a handful of such enterprises so far. The businesses are hoping to sell credits for absorbed carbon dioxide to businesses or individuals seeking to offset unavoidable emissions from other activities. The goal is to cause blooms of plankton by adding nutrients missing from seawater in some places. “Given the present state of knowledge regarding ocean fertilization, such large-scale operations are currently not justified,” said part of a statement agreed to by parties to the treaty, called the London Convention.

headline: U.S. Releases 9 Iranians in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 9 — Nine Iranians held on suspicion of aiding insurgents were released from American custody in Baghdad early on Friday, according to the United States military.

headline: Big Fees for Little Credit
text: SOME issuers of credit cards are “quietly collecting hundreds of millions of dollars in profits selling nearly worthless, predatory credit cards targeting vulnerable consumers, including those with bad credit,” according to a report published this week by the National Consumer Law Center (consumerlaw.org).

headline: Note to N.F.L.: High Prices Cut Demand
text: “Cable runs the risk of making this an issue with the regulators.” — Jerry Jones, owner

headline: Britain: Guilty Plea in Bomb Plot
text: Only days before he was due to face trial for a second time for attempted murder in an abortive plot to bomb London’s transport system, a 34-year-old immigrant from Ghana pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of conspiracy to cause explosions. The man, Manfo Kwaku Asiedo, was one of six people indicted in the failed bomb plot of July 21, 2005. Two weeks earlier, suicide bombers killed 56 people, including themselves, on London subway trains and a bus. In July, four men involved in the second transit system plot were convicted of attempted murder and sentenced to minimum terms of 40 years; earlier this week, a fifth man, Adel Yahya, was sentenced to six years and nine months after he, too, pleaded guilty to a lesser offense. The failure of the jury in the July trial to reach verdicts on Mr. Asiedo and Mr. Yahya led to plans for a second trial this month, now pre-empted by their plea-bargaining agreements.

headline: France: More Security Cameras
text: France wants to triple the number of closed-circuit television cameras in public places within two years, the interior minister, Michèle Alliot-Marie, said. Although the French have long been suspicious of such surveillance, a new government-commissioned survey showed that 78 percent were in favor of their use in public places.

headline: The Search Party
text: "The Searchers" was shot in 1955, a strange year in the movies, and perhaps only someone with John Ford's reputation could have made it. The cold war was thriving and the blacklist survived, but censorship was giving way, at least for directors with prestige.

headline: Daniel Day-Lewis’s All-Time Top Westerns
text: I don't particularly like westerns as a genre, but I do love certain westerns. ''High Noon'' means a lot to me - I love the purity and the honesty, I love Gary Cooper in that film, the idea of the last man standing. I do not like John Wayne: I find it hard to watch him. I just never took to him. And I don't like Jimmy Stewart as a cowboy. I love him, but just not as a cowboy; ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington'' is one of my favorite films. I love Capra. I love Preston Sturges. But we're talking about westerns. ... I have always admired Clint Eastwood's westerns. The spaghetti westerns were a great discovery. And ''Pale Rider.'' As a child, the John Ford film ''Cheyenne Autumn'' made a big impression on me. And ''Five Easy Pieces.'' It's not really a western, but it is about the possibilities that can be found in the West. Jack Nicholson is sublime in that film, just sublime. It's the most stultifying portrait of middle-class life. You want to flee from that world and head anywhere less civilized. Which is, of course, the appeal of the West: It's not tamed yet.

headline: Separated at Mirth?
text: First came Stephen Colbert’s largely unfunny book (a best seller, of course). Then the fizzling of his presidential “candidacy” (an old gag). Now this.

headline: Cowboy Business
text: In a culture industry fueled by formula, no genre has been more important to Hollywood than the western. From the birth of "the movies" through the classical Hollywood era (1920-1960), the western played not only a vital role as a popular narrative form — and one that would comprise nearly a fifth of all feature films from the silent era through the 1950s — but also in shaping the business of filmmaking itself.

headline: Trojan Course
text: The Book Review notes that once again, a lengthy treatise has been published about a subject that not long ago would have been considered unfit for polite conversation. It’s “The Humble Little Condom: A History,” and animal intestines aren’t the half of it:

headline: Bialystock und Doom?
text: Could Mel Brooks’s life be imitating his show “The Producers,” in which hucksters intend for a musical to bomb so as to abscond with investors’ money? That’s maybe a charitable explanation for the new high-budget production of “Young Frankenstein.” From Ben Brantley’s review (he laughed “exactly three times”):

headline: Benazir Bhutto Is Permitted to Leave Home
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 10 -- The Pakistani police allowed the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto to leave her home on Saturday, but then blocked her from visiting the home of the ousted chief justice, who has been detained.

headline: Nine Soldiers Die in Ambush in Afghanistan
text: Six American soldiers and three Afghan soldiers were killed Friday when insurgents ambushed them in eastern Afghanistan, NATO officials said Saturday.

headline: American Character and the Western
text: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott analyzes what  westerns tell us about America.

headline: Men, Women and Who’s to Blame for Global Warming
text: It seems we are measuring the carbon footprint of everything these days, so why shouldn’t men and women apply the same rigorous analysis to each other’s lifestyles? That’s what Gerd Johansson-Latham seems to suggest we should do in a study published by the Swedish Ministry of the Environment and publicized this week by the New Scientist.

headline: End of an era
text: In my chapter on the Great Compression, the equalization of American incomes that took place in the 30s and 40s, I use the transformation of Long Island’s image as a metaphor — in the 20s it was the land of great mansions, but by the 50s it was epitomized by Levittown, the land of middle class homes. Here’s how Levitt and Sons describes itself:

headline: Jozy Altidore: South Africa Here I Come
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his lates post, Altidore discusses his first call-up to the United States senior national team, the first-round playoff loss to the New England Revolution and the departure of the club’s sporting director and manager, Bruce Arena.

headline: The Early Word: Romney Confronts Religion, Privately
text: John F. Kennedy’s 1960 speech to Houston ministers is often heralded as one of the best articulations of the proper role of faith in American public life. Mitt Romney, a Latter-day Saint, has not given such a sweeping address although it has been suggested that he do so.

headline: The Old Warrior
text: For American children in the '50s, westerns were the default entertainment option. If it wasn't Roy Rogers then it was Hopalong Cassidy or the Lone Ranger. In the evening, with the parents, "Have Gun — Will Travel." Every kid had a fringed vest, a pair of toy six-shooters and a cowboy hat. We played cowboys and Indians and, if we were girls, imagined ourselves in bonnets and long dresses, with names like Miss Kitty. It was numbing.

headline: Author of Some Pretty Big Babies
text: “Writing books is the closest men ever come to childbearing.”— Norman Mailer, who died Saturday at 84. (Columbia World of Quotations)

headline: The Greatest Death Scene
text: A screenwriter friend and I duck into Video Free Brooklyn to rent Altman's "McCabe and Mrs. Miller." "Great death scene!" my friend exclaims. I instantly agree, but it turns out we mean two different things. He's thinking of McCabe — Warren Beatty, that is — succumbing from his bullet wounds after going to ground in a snowstorm, then being enveloped by swirling flakes and the elegiac tones of Leonard Cohen's "Winter Lady." Yes, this is one of the western's great death scenes. It completes one of the slowest and most heart-rending descents in all cinema; the shattering of McCabe's dreams comes to stand for a farewell to both the western tradition and to the sublimely fragile idealisms of the glamorous hippies both Beatty and McCabe really were beneath gruff western garb.

headline: Jim Harbaugh Q&A
text: Need a sign that things are different this season at Stanford? Look no further than the tin of Skoal tobacco on the desk of Coach Jim Harbuagh. Harbaugh is the Cardinal’s fiery first-year coach and a longtime N.F.L. quarterback. He replaced the bookish Walt Harris. (Harris always made it a point to say that he bought The New York Times on Tuesdays to read the Science Times section.) Harbaugh often tells his players to “approach this day with an enthusiasm unknown to mankind.” He won them over, in part, by running wind sprints with them and jumping in to quarterback some two-minute drills in practice. He won over the country by beating top-ranked U.S.C. as a 41-point underdog. Now can he win over recruits? Here’s the always free-spirited Harbaugh talking about growing up in a football family, Stanford’s limited recruiting pool and why his coordinators get free houses.

headline: Cost of Living
text: Thanks to a tip from Stanford Athletic Director Bob Bowlsby, I found this list of the most expensive and least expensive college towns in the United States to live in. Bowlsby knows this, of course, because Palo Alto is the most expensive, with the average price of a 4-bedroom, 2,200 square-foot house being $1.67 million. This led to Stanford beginning an innovative new program where they actually buy houses for their football team coordinators to live in and give the assistant coaches a $3,000 per month housing stipend. That would buy a mansion in Muncie, Ind., the home of Ball State and the least expensive university town. A 4-bedroom house there costs an average of $150,000. The list was compiled by Coldwell Banker and is available to see here. Definitely some surprising numbers scattered throughout.

headline: Bayern Munich’s First Bundesliga Loss of the Season
text: An update on this week’s article about then-undefeated FC Bayern Munich: The club suffered its first defeat of the Bundesliga season Saturday, falling to VfB Stuttgart, 3-1, after trailing, 3-0, at halftime. The chances of a miracle season are over, and it could quickly turn into a crisis for the team from Bavaria.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Youth Movement
text: Advance contingents of the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela, which plays at Carnegie Hall on Sunday and Monday, took the stage this morning at the Queens Museum. (You have to love a museum where, to get to the proper gallery, you’re directed to turn right at the parrot: a huge puppet, “The Parrot Who Had a Way With Words,” to you.)

text: The Democratic presidential candidates have a big night tonight at the Iowa Democratic Party’s Jefferson Jackson Dinner, but that’s not stopping four of them from appearing tomorrow morning on the Sunday talk shows. On top of that, three G.O.P. contenders are also booked.

headline: ‘Button Bob’ Draws a Crowd in Des Moines
text: DES MOINES – Trade was brisk around Button Bob’s table outside of the auditorium where John Edwards was holding a rally for his supporters.

headline: Innocent mistakes
text: So there’s a campaign on to exonerate Ronald Reagan from the charge that he deliberately made use of Nixon’s Southern strategy. When he went to Philadelphia, Mississippi, in 1980, the town where the civil rights workers had been murdered, and declared that “I believe in states’ rights,” he didn’t mean to signal support for white racists. It was all just an innocent mistake.

headline: Navy Keeps Rolling
text: There was no hangover from the Notre Dame victory for Navy.

headline: Leko Takes Early Lead at Tal Memorial
Oklahoma State Debate
text: STILLWATER, Okla. — Even with Oklahoma State suspending the sophomore linebacker Chris Collins after he pleaded guilty this week to a felony charge of aggravated sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl three years ago, his future with the Cowboys remains a controversial topic.

headline: Outside the Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner
text: DES MOINES – Outside of the auditorium where the Jefferson Jackson Day dinner is being held tonight, there are massive placards bearing the names and slogans of the Democratic candidates, attached to buildings and posted around grassy squares.

headline: Scenes From the Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner
text: DES MOINES – Jefferson and Jackson might not have imagined a dinner like this.

headline: The Coup at Home
text: Leave a comment about the Sunday, Nov. 11 column.

headline: Strong Words in Columbus
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The Buckeyes’ undefeated season and national title chances may have been dashed, but they weren’t going to be shown up on their home field. So when the Illinois sideline spilled out onto the middle of the field and players began dancing on the logo, Ohio State players took umbrage. A scuffle, including punches and pushing, ensued.

headline: Ponomariov in Firm Control in Spain
With Paul Westhead
text: Paul Westhead, who guided the Phoenix Mercury to the W.N.B.A. championship in September, accepted a job as an assistant with the Seattle SuperSonics two weeks later. He was previously the head coach of three N.B.A. teams and three college teams, including Loyola Marymount. Westhead, 68, won the N.B.A. title in 1980 as coach of the Los Angeles Lakers.

headline: Escapes
text: The illustrator Guy Billout works the narrow but fertile territory where clarity intersects with mystery. It’s a place where the graffiti might read “René Magritte Was Here (de Chirico, Too),” but Billout’s concerns are his own: his drawings (or are they paintings? or both?) often employ tricks of scale and perspective, along with large expanses of deceptively flat color, compositions that resolve in witty visual jokes while tapping deeper currents of unease. They’re bright, figuratively and literally, like dreams dreamt under a noonday desert sun rather than in the usual shape-shifting murk.

headline: Sari Laufer, Benjamin Cutter
text: Rabbi Sari Rebecca Laufer, the daughter of Karen Laufer and Martin Laufer of Manhattan, is to be married there this evening to Benjamin Joseph Cutter, the son of Georgianne Cutter and Rabbi William Cutter of Los Angeles. Rabbi Lennard R. Thal is to officiate at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers, with Rabbi Robert N. Levine, the senior rabbi of Congregation Rodeph Sholom in Manhattan, participating in the ceremony.

headline: Full Circle
text: The best moment in this tour de force of paper engineering arrives just as the front cover opens, when a graceful swirl of slim white strips — a sinuous fan, playing delicately with its own shadows — springs up. The accompanying text reads, “White grasses tip tap and 90 Black Spots,” though the square-topped lengths of paper don’t resemble waving grass so much as elongated piano keys. Diligent counters will indeed find 45 of them, and the black dots on both sides of each tip.

headline: Norman Mailer, Towering Writer With a Matching Ego, Dies at 84
text: Norman Mailer, the combative, controversial and often outspoken novelist who loomed over American letters longer and larger than any other writer of his generation, died early yesterday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Alexis Luongo, Scott Litman
text: Alexis Louise Luongo and Scott David Litman were married last evening at Pier Sixty at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Marci Bellows officiated.

headline: At Home in Infamous Surroundings
text: The National Perspectives article on Oct. 14 about residential developments in buildings once used for different purposes referred imprecisely to a former factory in Hartford that is being transformed into rental apartments. While the plant was known for producing firearms in great numbers in the 19th century, it was not “the birthplace” of the Colt revolver. Samuel Colt earlier produced revolvers in Paterson, N.J.

headline: Tories and Radicals
text: Earlier this year, the Atlantic Monthly Press began to publish a series of books on “books that changed the world.” Now comes “Thomas Paine’s ‘Rights of Man’: A Biography,” an examination by the journalist and polemicist Christopher Hitchens.

headline: Kansas Inches Further Into Title Picture
text: STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 10  Overlooked by N.C.A.A. Division I teams coming out of Eisenhower High School in Lawton, Okla., four years ago, Marcus Henry was headed to play football at an Oklahoma junior college.

headline: Washington’s Name Slept Here. And Here.
text: WHEN the people of Washington Township in Mercer County voted by nearly three-to-one on Tuesday to change its name to Robbinsville, they dropped Washington into a tie with Franklin as the most often-used municipality name in the state.

headline: Correction: A Range of Disorders Tamed by the Beat
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about music therapy programs misstated the affiliation of the music therapist Angeline Brown, who was shown holding a drum for children to play. As the article noted, she is on the faculty of the Music Therapy Institute — not Stepping Stones, one of the many off-site locations where she and other members of the institute conduct music therapy sessions.

headline: Lauretta Ansah and Michael Joseph
text: Lauretta Adwoa Larbi Ansah and Michael Anthony Joseph were married on Friday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Clive E. Neil performed the ceremony at the Bedford Central Presbyterian Church, where the bride and the bridegroom together lead the H.I.V./AIDS ministry.

headline: House of Blues
text: LET me take you where classic jazz was made back in the day. We’ll meet not in some dark smoky Greenwich Village bar but on a quiet lane in Dix Hills. Indeed, important jazz landmarks lie well beyond the five boroughs and past big-city limits. The roots of a musical genre and a culture identified as a quintessentially urban American experience are nonetheless planted in suburban soil.

headline: The Mother of All Rhymes
text: Praising nursery rhymes, Vita Sackville-West observed, “The direct statement can seldom compare in aesthetic value with the oblique statement — which is probably the ultimate meaning that man sets on that strange devisement he calls art.” Nonetheless, some have been eager to wring sense from nonsense. Chief among these were William and Ceil Baring-Gould, who in “The Annotated Mother Goose” (1962), asserted connections between famous people and such characters as Jack Horner and Miss Muffet; the spider who sat down beside her, incidentally, was said to be the Protestant reformer John Knox. Equally quotidian was Geoffrey Handley-Taylor, whose humorless disapproval of Mother Goose in 1952 appears in his census of crimes to be found therein: under “means of murder,” for example, two cases of choking and one each of devouring, being cut in half, decapitation, squeezing, shriveling, starvation, boiling, hanging and drowning.

headline: Front Office Changes, but Will the Pirates?
text: The Pittsburgh Pirates have endured 15 consecutive losing seasons, one season short of the record for futility, and this is how they decided to reverse their fortunes:

headline: Extreme Politics
text: Few people would dispute that the politics of Washington are as polarized today as they have been in decades. The question Ronald Brownstein poses in this provocative book is whether what he calls “extreme partisanship” is simply a result of the tactics of recent party leaders, or whether it is an enduring product of a systemic change in the structure and behavior of the political world. Brownstein, formerly the chief political correspondent for The Los Angeles Times and now the political director of the Atlantic Media Company, gives considerable credence to both explanations. But the most important part of “The Second Civil War” — and the most debatable — is his claim that the current political climate is the logical, perhaps even inevitable, result of a structural change that stretched over a generation.

headline: Battlefield Report From the Evolution War
text: WHEN Paula Apsell first heard about the case of Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District, she did not consider it a good subject for “Nova,” the science series she produces for public television.

headline: The Colossus
text: John Richardson’s writing is tremendously satisfying, at once easygoing and magisterial. In the third, penultimate installment of his life of Picasso, Richardson is juggling so many people and themes and events with such aplomb that readers may not quite realize what literary pyrotechnics are involved. This powerhouse of a book spans a dauntingly complicated time in Picasso’s life and in European history as well, taking us from World War I and Picasso’s adventures with Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes to the riotously erotic images of Picasso’s youthful mistress, Marie-Thérèse Walter, and the darkening situation of the early 1930s. Richardson obviously delights in a life that in this account takes on some of the bewildering complexity of a three-ring circus. And why not? Picasso himself often chose to refract his experiences through the world of clowns and jugglers and gymnasts, whether in the melancholy portraits of saltimbanques that absorbed him in the first years of the 20th century or in the long series of etchings, with their densely plotted, sometimes wildly comic dream-narratives, that are a commanding achievement of the years leading up to his death in 1973 at the age of 91.

headline: Kristin Brown, Udai Puramsetti
text: Kristin Michelle Brown, a daughter of Sheila A. Brown of Gloucester, R.I., and the late Michael H. Brown, was married yesterday to Udai Kumar Puramsetti, a son of Vara Puramsetti and Veer Puramsetti of Austin, Tex. The Rev. John W. Lolio, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, officiated at Banchet Flowers, a flower shop in New York, with the Rev. Steven R. Fogel, a nondenominational minister, taking part.

headline: Lost Women
text: When Judith Thurman was a child, her mother, Alice, did something extraordinary, provoking and ultimately mystifying. Having recopied “in her schoolmarm’s penmanship” a set of poems Thurman composed at the age of 8, Alice “wrote half a dozen poems of her own and, like a crooked cardsharp, shuffled them into the pack.” Upon discovery of her mother’s “perverse act of inverted plagiarism” Thurman challenged Alice, who denied her peculiar trespass with results that proved more lasting than even the most ambitiously meddlesome mother could have hoped.

headline: Kansas Team’s Streak Is at 52
text: The Smith Center Redmen ran their winning streak to 52 games Friday night with a 56-0 victory over previously unbeaten Oakley in a Kansas state high school playoff game.

headline: Correction: The Special Relationship Tries to Swim the Channel
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 28 about changes in French and British attitudes about the United States carried an incorrect dateline. The article was written in Brussels, not Madrid.

headline: Obama and Clinton Duel for Iowa Democrats
text: DES MOINES, Nov. 11 — In back-to-back speeches Saturday before thousands of Iowa Democrats, Senator Barack Obama pointedly suggested that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was running a “poll-driven campaign” out of fear of what Republicans might say about her in a general election.

headline: Oil Spills From Russian Tanker
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 11 — A fierce storm in the Black Sea split a small tanker on Sunday, causing an oil spill that could lead to significant environmental damage, officials said. At least four other cargo ships also sank in the storm, and several of their sailors were missing.

headline: Closely Watched, Bhutto Is Allowed to Move
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 10 — The Pakistani police allowed the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto to leave her house on Saturday, but blocked her from visiting the home of the ousted chief justice, who has been detained.

headline: Werner Kleeman’s Private War
text: FOR 56 years, Werner Kleeman’s corner of the world has been a small house on a quiet street in Flushing, Queens, a brick, Cape Cod-style two-family house that is one of a row of similar homes built on a former potato farm during the Depression. Mr. Kleeman and his wife, Lore, raised their two daughters in the house, on 196th Place, and he made his living under the same roof.

headline: Two Become First-Time Council Members
text: HARTFORD

headline: Aloysee Heredia, Nicholas Jarmoszuk Jr.
text: Aloysee Heredia and Nicholas Jarmoszuk Jr. were married yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Manhattan. Msgr. William J. Toohy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Megan Barrett, James Quinn
text: Megan Elizabeth Barrett and James Francis Quinn were married yesterday by Msgr. Blase M. Gintoli at Our Lady of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn.

headline: Cool It on the Hudson
text: THE health of the Hudson River is improving, or so it would seem. Yet many populations of fish that have been the mainstay of the river’s ecology are in decline.

headline: Veterans’ Rolls Decline Here as Fewer Enlist and More Move
text: For much of the 20th century, New York sent its share of residents off to war, and today, in many of the state’s working-class neighborhoods and towns, the armed forces are as revered as ever.

headline: Countrywide’s Chief Salesman and Defender
text: AS the credit crisis sent financial markets into a tailspin in August, Countrywide Financial, the nation’s biggest mortgage lender, was in dire need of cash. In a move that fueled anxiety among investors, it decided to tap an $11.5 billion credit line it held with a number of other banks.

headline: ‘Rite of Spring’ as Rite of Passage
text: THE composer Camille Saint-Saëns is said to have stormed out of the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in Paris at the world premiere of Igor Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” in 1913, angered by the apparent misuse of a bassoon. He wasn’t the only person to lose his cool that night. Scandalized by the sensuality of Vaslav Nijinsky’s choreography and the raciness of Stravinsky’s score, the audience hooted and fairly rebelled. Sergei Diaghilev, whose Ballets Russes presented the performance, was elated. Better publicity could not be bought.

headline: Tracy Bloom, David Lerner
text: Tracy Marissa Bloom, a daughter of Marilyn Bloom and Robert Bloom of East Meadow, N.Y., was married last evening to David Brown Lerner, a son of Emily Lerner and Dr. Marc Lerner of Middletown, N.J. Rabbi Albert J. Lowenberg officiated at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, N.Y.

headline: Power Hangs in Balance in Nassau Legislature
text: ABOUT 200 votes in Tuesday’s election will make the difference in the balance of power in the Nassau County Legislature.

headline: Gay Paree
text: What a charming and peculiar bulletin from the past is this little book from 1927, supposedly written by a man famous in his day as a cultural impresario and libertine but now remembered as the husband of Colette. Ostensibly a quasi-scientific tour of the male homosexual world in France, Italy and Germany in the 1920s, “The Third Sex” is by turns leering, sympathetic, philosophical, patronizing, exuberant, impenetrable, tender and hilarious, often all on the same page. As the translator, Lawrence R. Schehr, points out, Henri Gauthier-

headline: Lambrusco, Thankfully
text: Lambrusco, a fizzy Emilia-Romagna red that resembles sweet soda pop, has long been déclassé. Now some producers have gone upscale.

headline: What Market Slump?
text: ALTHOUGH there are many questions about the direction of the Manhattan real estate market, the evidence to date shows that the market remained strong last month, continuing right through the last closings.

headline: Sarah Evans and Eric Thelen
text: Sarah Allison Evans and Eric Scott Thelen were married on Friday at the Lido Beach Resort in Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Christopher N. Gray, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Whitney Rice, Edward Childs
text: Whitney Elizabeth Rice, the daughter of Amy Hamilton Rice and Mark Rice of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Edward Caulkins Childs, a son of Elsie Caulkins Childs and Samuel W. Childs of Niantic, Conn. The Rev. Oswald E. Pinder, an Anglican priest, officiated at Pink Sands Resort in Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

headline: Celtics Show Nets That New Really Is Better
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 10 — At least the Nets had an excuse Saturday. They had to play the final 13 minutes against the Boston Celtics without Vince Carter, who sprained his right ankle late in the third quarter. Not that Carter necessarily could have made a difference. By the time he left, the new, improved and undefeated Celtics (5-0) had already put away their latest victim.

headline: When an Election Becomes a Forum on Immigration
text: BREWSTER, N.Y.

headline: Back to Basics
text: A FEW years ago, developers created amenities to make their buildings stand out from the pack. Buyers returned the favor, rushing to the newest building with the latest gimmick and snapping up apartments as fast as they became available.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in the special Education Life section last Sunday about Shimer College in Chicago, one of the smallest liberal arts colleges in the United States, misidentified the site of classes. They are held in a building on South State Street — not in S. R. Crown Hall, Mies van der Rohe’s glass-and-steel legacy on Chicago’s South Side. (Go to Article)

headline: Small Tarts Pack a Big Punch
text: Like eating just one potato chip, having just one of the creamy little tarts called pastis de nata won’t be enough for most people. I know of only one place in the county where this delicate, cup-shaped dessert — Lisbon’s favorite — is made. That’s Caravela in Tarrytown. No surprise, Fernando Cabral, a fine baker and the owner of this restaurant, comes from Portugal.

headline: Laura Barrow, Philip Geiger
text: Laura Jan Barrow, a daughter of Amy and Peter H. Barrow of Wilmette, Ill., was married yesterday to Philip Charles Geiger, the son of Marilyn and James E. Geiger of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Asher Knight officiated at the InterContinental hotel in Chicago, with Ana Bonnheim, a rabbinical student, taking part.

headline: A New Look to the Sky as  Oil Prices Rise
text: Suddenly, the sun is back. In the 1970s, during the energy crisis, its popularity as an energy source was on the rise. But then oil prices dropped, consumers no longer felt shock at the gas pump, and the sun lost its sheen as a power-harnesser. Solar panels across the nation fell into disuse and started to seem quaint.

headline: Ellen Zajac and Teddy Schwarzman
text: Ellen Marie Zajac, a daughter of Ellen Zajac and John Zajac of Berlin, Md., was married last night at the Round Hill Hotel and Villas near Montego Bay, Jamaica, to Edward Frank Schwarzman, the son of Ellen Katz and Stephen A. Schwarzman, both of New York. The Rev. Arthur Becker, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, and Michael Matalon, the president of the Shaare Shalom Synagogue in Kingston, Jamaica, led the ceremony; Stephen Henriques, a marriage officer in Jamaica, served as the legal officiant.

headline: A History of Violence
text: HAPPY families are all alike. Every happy family touched by murder is shattered in its own distinctive way. For me, the news last summer of the savage killings of Jennifer Hawke-Petit and her two daughters in Cheshire, hurled me back to the infamous murder that has haunted my own Connecticut family for more than 50 years.

headline: Calendar of Events
Freedom Train
text: In the early ’60s, James Baldwin spent a year at the home of his friend William Styron. Through the fall and winter they talked and wrote, the Harlem-born grandson of a slave and the Virginia-born grandson of a slave owner. Baldwin encouraged Styron in his latest project, “The Confessions of Nat Turner.” When the novel was published in 1967, it met with acclaim from mostly white mainstream critics. But many blacks were outraged. They accused Styron of distorting history, of appropriating a black man’s voice and using it to perpetuate racist stereotypes. They organized a boycott of the book. Virtually alone in his support for his friend, Baldwin said only, “He has begun the common history — ours.”
