text: Dalton Dorm Saga Over

headline: Songs of Devotion
text: To the Editor:

headline: Builders Return to Class for Lessons in ‘Green’
text: WHEN Rick Ryan and his team were planning the Withers Preserve, a 3,690-acre community of plantation-style houses and condominiums in Myrtle Beach, S.C., they decided to build “green.”

headline: A Presentation Practically ‘in Your Living Room’
text: INSIDE the intimate theater of the Rosenthal J.C.C. of Northern Westchester, the veteran Shakespearean actor Michael Cumpsty is reciting the famous opening line of “Richard III”: “Now is the winter of our discontent.” No sooner has Mr. Cumpsty finished his first soliloquy than he is interrupted by Brian Kulick, the artistic director, who wants to point out to the 145-member audience the way in which this scene depicts the inner workings of the evil protagonist’s mind.

headline: Giants' Defense vs. Cowboys' Defense
text: GIANTS’ DEFENSE

headline: Abdicate and Capitulate
text: It is extraordinary how President Bush has streamlined the Senate confirmation process. As we have seen most recently with the vote to confirm Michael Mukasey as attorney general, about all that is left of “advice and consent” is the “consent” part.

headline: Masters Cup to Close Year of Strange Events
text: It has been a weird year for tennis and a rotten year for round robin, which was introduced in regular men’s Tour events, then quickly jettisoned after problems with the math and the meaning.

headline: Knocked Up
text: The good news about Nick Hornby’s first young adult novel, “Slam,” is that it’s not so different from — indeed, it can be read right alongside — the rest of his sly and laid-back oeuvre. Hornby’s novels tend to be about men who are essentially boys. “Slam” is a portrait of a prickly and interesting boy who is forced to become, very quickly, a man.

headline: Web Surfers Can Take the Internet Along for the Ride
text: WHILE riding in the back of a Cadillac Escalade recently, I made a video call to a friend (“Hey, guess where I’m calling from!”). Then I checked my ranking in an online football pool. And then I sent e-mail messages to my editors, explaining my tardiness in filing this article. I was still testing mobile high-speed Internet access to show how to get the Web on wheels.

headline: Condos Above Classrooms Strike Some as an Odd Mix
text: HASKEL LOOKSTEIN, the rabbi of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and the principal of the Ramaz Lower School next door, faces a problem of overcrowding that did not exist when he was one of the school’s six inaugural pupils in 1937. Ramaz, on 85th Street near Lexington Avenue, today serves 450 students, and its space is also shared by the synagogue for various purposes. What results, members say, is a space squeeze.

headline: The Wanderer
text: WHILE packing my family’s belongings for our move from Manhattan across the water to Brooklyn — dishes carefully, books tenderly, clothes haphazardly — I sit back, pour myself a cup of tea and wonder how Brooklyn will change me.

headline: As Stagehands Strike, Broadway Shows Don’t Go On
text: Most of Broadway was dark yesterday as stagehands went on strike over new work rules that producers have imposed or have been pushing during months of contentious negotiations.

headline: Kari Evans, Mark Kelly
text: Kari Melissa Evans, a daughter of Jane L. Evans and David R. Evans of Eldersburg, Md., was married last evening to Mark Thomas Kelly, a son of Cindy Kelly and Dr. Thomas J. Kelly of New York. Judge John P. Miller of the circuit court Baltimore, officiated there at the Evergreen Museum & Library at Johns Hopkins University.

headline: Who Are These People?
text: High school might seem a little early for a top-to-bottom re-evaluation of one’s entire life, but Gabrielle Zevin’s heroines cut straight to the important stuff. For both Liz, the protagonist of “Elsewhere” (2005), Zevin’s first novel for teenagers, and Naomi, the narrator of “Memoirs of a Teenage Amnesiac,” there’s really nothing else to do.

headline: Peterson Stealing Lynch’s Thunder
text: A rookie running back on a pace for 1,380 yards and 10 touchdowns would usually be a big story at the midpoint of the season, but Buffalo’s Marshawn Lynch is not. Instead of receiving attention as a rookie of the year contender, he is playing in the shadow of Minnesota’s Adrian Peterson.

headline: If You Need a Passport, Now Is a Good Time to Apply
text: If you’re planning to travel to foreign countries for the holiday season — or at any point next year — now is the right time to apply for passports, according to a State Department official, who said that fall is traditionally a low-volume period for applications, and that January typically gets much busier, which could mean longer processing times. Contributing to the busy season this winter will be the land and sea phase of the Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative, which currently requires passports or other accepted documents for all United States citizens traveling by air within the Western Hemisphere, including Mexico and the Caribbean. The first transition of this phase is scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 31, which will require all citizens of the United States traveling by land and sea to present a government-issued photo identification card, like a driver’s license, along with proof of citizenship, like a birth certificate, at the border. It is expected that passports or alternative secure documents will be required for all sea and land travel by next summer (www.travel.state.gov).

headline: From the Greeks to Eminem
text: Marc Aronson begins his complex, unusual history of race with a confession. Standing in line at a snack bar, he watches as several boys are accused of stealing money from the tip jar. He believes them guilty, he admits, because they are black.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: The Garage Guy Dons a Lab Coat
text: THE days when car mechanics were considered grease monkeys have gone the way of the Oldsmobile.

headline: Two Short Fables That Revel in Freedom
text: ALBERT LAMORISSE’S “White Mane” (1953) and “The Red Balloon” (1956) are among the world’s most famous and most honored films for children. Both were prizewinners at Cannes, and “The Red Balloon,” which is 34 minutes long and contains about half a dozen lines of dialogue, improbably received an Oscar for its screenplay. But kids’ stuff they are not.

headline: The Hollywood Diet
text: Nothing over the course of many years of having dinner parties prepared me for the list, provided without request, by the couple I invited to my new Los Angeles home. It contained the items they would not consume: no red meat; no dairy; fish only if grilled, but no salmon; and please, no button mushrooms. Once at my table to eat their prenegotiated meal of grilled tuna and dry couscous, the husband spotted flecks of garlic in the mango salsa and recoiled, demanding to know if he had indeed spied a mote of cheese.

headline: Seven Sketches, From a Skewed Eye
text: Advertised as “seven madcap comedies” for the price of one, “Mere Mortals” delivers far fewer laughs than that billing might suggest.

headline: Stephanie Alperin, Eric Biderman
text: Stephanie Lynn Alperin, a daughter of Lisa and Stuart Alperin of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Eric Adam Biderman, the son of Wendy and Mark Biderman of New York. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated at the Pierre in New York, with Rabbi Robert Levine participating.

headline: Nancy Becker, Scott Margolin
text: Nancy Ilana Becker, the daughter of Lucy Becker and Robert Becker of Manhattan, was married last evening to Scott Howard Margolin, the son of Sandra Roberts of Tinton Falls, N.J., and Howard Margolin of Deal, N.J. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated at the Essex House in Manhattan, with Cantor Dov Keren participating.

headline: Correction: Under 21 and Running for Mayor
text: An article last week about Raul De Jesus, a 20-year-old Hartford resident who is running for mayor, misstated the number and length of terms that the incumbent, Eddie A. Perez, has been in office. Mr. Perez was elected to a two-year term in 2001; the next year, the City Charter was changed to make the mayor’s term four years, and Mr. Perez was re-elected in 2003. On Tuesday, he was re-elected to another four-year term.

headline: There’s No Superhero in the Wings
text: LAST week’s ugly action in the stock market was caused in large part by fear about how badly banks will be hit by loan and securities losses. Uncertainty is ever the investor’s foe, and until we get some clarity on what banks’ holdings are truly worth, market gyrations will be a fact of life.

headline: Hobbled by Injuries, Heat Limps to Slow Start
text: MIAMI, Nov. 10 — Shaquille O’Neal still has a huge tattoo on his left arm declaring himself a man of steel, with a Superman S to accent the assertion. It is the only Superman-like thing about him right now.

headline: Veterans Day Events on Long Island
text: Here’s a partial listing of Veterans Day events scheduled for Nov. 11 on Long Island.

headline: First-Rate Performances Convey a Tortured Family
text: In one of the juiciest entrances ever written for an actor, Arthur Miller’s Gregory Solomon arrives huffing and puffing and wheezing after climbing the stairs to the furniture-choked attic apartment of an old Manhattan brownstone. Almost as old as the building — and it is about to be demolished — he has come to assess the contents, the abandoned furnishings of the family who had occupied the house before it was broken up into apartments.

headline: Serfs of the Turf
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: A Principal Who Makes It Happen
text: Mount Vernon

headline: Strike Dampens the Moods of Many Tourists
text: As if the Grinch really had stolen Christmas, children cried and parents were crestfallen. Confusion, surprise and anger played at box offices, and dispossessed theatergoers shared the sidewalks with grim pickets yesterday as the stagehands’ strike shut down most of Broadway’s plays and musicals.

headline: Faking It
text: Carrying this book around recently I’ve caught more than a little flak, not least from my kids, who once thought of me as a literary intellectual, or at the very least as a guy who espoused the virtues of reading. Hey, really, I told them — as well as my wife and the guy sitting next to me on the subway — no kidding, it’s a serious book, written by a professor of literature who’s also a psychoanalyst. A French professor/shrink, no less, who’s written books on Proust, Maupassant, Balzac, Laclos and Stendhal, among other canonical heavyweights. So lay off.

headline: In a Father’s Honor, One Perfect Macoun
text: WHEN my father became critically ill in 1991, he asked for a favor. He was a practical man, so I thought he might say, “Take care of your mother — she gets so emotional,” or “Don’t forget — the important papers are in that black box in the bedroom closet. Take them to the lawyer.” Instead, he said, “Plant a fruit tree for me.”

headline: A Novelist’s Nonfiction Captured the American Spirit
text: Norman Mailer was nothing if not ambitious. He once declared he wanted to write “a novel which Dostoyevsky and Marx; Joyce and Freud; Stendhal, Tolstoy, Proust and Spengler; Faulkner, and even old moldering Hemingway might come to read.” He wanted to “alter the nerves and marrow” of the nation with his work, to “change the consciousness” of his times. He wanted to write the Big Book, the Great American Novel. He wanted to hit the longest long ball of them all.

headline: Special Teams
text: About 15 years ago, pro football lost me, and therefore I am out of step with millions of Americans, if one believes the weekly TV ratings. Maybe it was the four-hour games that ran the same two commercials on every change of possession. Maybe it was expansion to Jacksonville (the Jaguars) and Charlotte (the Panthers), whose teams seem to have the same teal turbo-cat logos on their helmets and so appeared to be more marketing strategies than football teams. Maybe it was the lack of a sonorous voice like that of Ray Scott — a minimalist announcer, unlike today’s bombastic entertainers — who could ennoble a late-afternoon game from the Los Angeles Coliseum by describing an arching touchdown pass from the Rams’ John Hadl to Harold Jackson with the simple “This is Jackson,” followed only by the roar of the crowd.

headline: Time to Move on a Hudson Tunnel
text: It sounds absurd, but the only passenger rail tunnel that crosses under the Hudson River to New York was built a century ago. It has two tracks, one coming and one going, shared by two very busy railroads, Amtrak and New Jersey Transit. Capacity is limited, delays are frequent. Something clearly must be done to supplement what is, after all, an essential lifeline to the nation’s largest city.

headline: Banks Said to Agree on Credit Backup Fund
text: The country’s three biggest banks have reached agreement on the structure of a backup fund of at least $75 billion to help stabilize credit markets, a person involved in the discussions said yesterday, ending nearly two months of complicated negotiations against a worsening economic backdrop.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE BACK LIST: Thirty-five years ago this week, on the Nov. 12, 1972, New York Times best-seller lists — at that time, descriptions of each title were not provided — things looked like this:

headline: Far Out: Studios Imagine Smart Cars for a World Transformed by Robots
text: FIFTY years ago, tail fins were at their most extreme: cars seemed to want to be rockets. But 50 years from now, cars will want to be robots, at least according to the design challenge at the Los Angeles auto show this year.

headline: Wild West: The Prequel
text: Buffalo Bill

headline: A Body of Work Spanning 59 Years
text: Norman Mailer published more than 30 books in his career. These are among his most notable:

headline: A Muddle Over Middle School
text: ON weekday mornings, Llunorkys Veras dresses her four children, takes them by the hand and walks them two blocks from their apartment to Public School 11 on Ogden Avenue in the Highbridge section of the Bronx. But Ms. Veras is dreading what school mornings will be like next year, when her oldest child, Richard, now a fourth grader, will have to travel on two buses to attend Junior High School 166.

headline: Bitten by the C.E.O. Bug
text: MY father, a naturalized British citizen, was an important figure in my life. My grandfather, who was the western correspondent of The Times of London, died fairly young, and my father had to skip college and go to work to support the family. He went into underwriting and invested in the Maricopa Land and Cattle Company, whose purpose was to make the desert fertile.

headline: Grading the Grades
text: Brilliant proposals are often undermined through less-than brilliant execution. That is clearly the case in New York, where Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s new system for rating the city’s public schools has come under withering fire from across the political spectrum.

headline: Charities Trying Mergers to Improve Bottom Line
text: Charities have long been reluctant to merge, fearful of alienating both loyal donors and longtime employees. But with the number of nonprofits increasing rapidly and donors growing weary of the rise in solicitations, charities are experimenting with mergers as a way to cut costs, reduce duplication of services and increase their reach.

headline: Balkans’ Idolatry Delights Movie Fans and Pigeons
text: ZITISTE, Serbia — In this sleepy farming village, residents talk of a new spirit of exaltation ever since a towering bronze and concrete statue of Rocky Balboa was erected in the village square, his boxing gloves raised in a heroic gesture of triumph.

headline: The City That Never Shuts Up
text: Lullaby? What lullaby? This droll counting rhyme begins with an explosion of color and energy that will pop your eyes wide open. At a busy intersection, traffic is snarled. Horns blare. A truck driver sticks his head out the window. So does a dog, one car over. Everywhere, heavy black letters spell out sound effects: toot, honk, beep, toooooooot!

headline: Week 10 in Preview
text: JAGUARS at TITANS

headline: This Is Your Brain on Politics
text: This article was written by Marco Iacoboni, Joshua Freedman and Jonas Kaplan of the University of California, Los Angeles, Semel Institute for Neuroscience; Kathleen Hall Jamieson of the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania; and Tom Freedman, Bill Knapp and Kathryn Fitzgerald of FKF Applied Research.

headline: More Than Just a Pretty Face From History
text: The first public showing of the face of the boy pharaoh Tutankhamun, last week, exposed more than cracked, leathery skin and his buckteeth. (Gene Tierney’s overbite was much more fetching.) Archaeologists also detected a new feature, the hint of a Tut smile, transfiguring a regal mummy from antiquity into a human being with emotions perhaps like those of people today. The first reaction of Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s head of antiquities, was unscientific. The face, he said, “has magic; it has mystery; it has beauty.”

headline: With Victory, Volunteers and Their Coach Silence the Critics, for Now
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 10  Tennessee Coach Phillip Fulmer leaned into the microphone. His voice boomed throughout the interview room Saturday, but he insisted that what made his voice fervent was excitement over a 34-13 victory against Arkansas, not defiance in the face of critics who want him fired.

headline: Alanna Stack, Byrd Leavell III
text: Alanna McCaffrey Stack and Byrd Stuart Leavell III were married yesterday by the Rev. Carleton P. Jones at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan.

headline: Recruiting’s High-Tech Game of Cat and Mouse
text: On Feb. 7, when football recruits signed official letters of intent to attend their chosen colleges, the recruiting Web site Rivals.com claimed a whopping 74.5 million page views, almost five times the number that MSNBC.com drew on its election night coverage a few months earlier. ESPN and Fox Sports Net show high school games weekly to a national audience.

headline: Week 10 in Preview
text: BEARS

headline: Shock and Awww
text: I remember reading “Edie,” the oral history of Edie Sedgwick, and thinking that having a story told by a chorus of voices, each with its own point of view and agenda, could make for an interesting novel. And for a while that’s what seems to be happening in “Maynard & Jennica.”

headline: An Artistic Neighborhood, Right Down to the Firehouse
text: LAST winter, a firefighter in Ladder Company 104 named Dave Herman called a meeting in his firehouse on South Second Street in Williamsburg.

headline: Katherine Davidson, Patrick Hudson
text: Katherine Loretta Davidson, a daughter of Katherine M. Davidson and Kevin D. Davidson of Newtown, Pa., was married yesterday to Patrick Alexander Hudson, a son of Edith Hudson and Robert F. Hudson of Miami. The Rev. Patrick Hollywood officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, with the Rev. Iain MacLellan, a cousin of the bride who is also a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: That Special Something: Kick Returners Running Wild
text: The N.F.L. is in the middle of what will most likely be a record-breaking season for kickoff and punt returns for touchdowns, and it is doing nothing for Steve Tasker’s mood. Viewed through the critical goggles of a renowned special-teams player, one of football’s most thrilling plays looks more like a series of breakdowns, a reflection of the devaluation of special teams.

headline: Bhutto’s Persona Raises Distrust, as Well as Hope
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 10 — A day after she was barricaded in her home, surrounded by police officers and barbed wire, the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto was quickly back to a world to which she is more accustomed on Saturday.

headline: Can-Do Creatures
text: As far back as Aesop, storytellers have projected human traits onto creatures great and small. We know the most popular pairings by heart. Owls are wise. Mice are timid. Bees and beavers? Both busy.

headline: Mourning TV
text: Los Angeles

headline: Consumers Won’t Know What They’re Missing
text: THE Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture has decided that consumers are too dim to make their own shopping decisions. Agriculture officials in Ohio are contemplating a similar decision.

headline: Judy Matz, Ryan Martin
text: Judy Matz and Ryan Joseph Martin were married last evening at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the restaurant on the Rockefeller family’s Pocantico Hills estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Dr. Robert Berson, the leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Northern Westchester, officiated.

headline: Little Girl Sold, and Other Tales of the Sex Trade
text: ONE of the bigger hurdles in producing “Holly,” a drama about sex trafficking, was finding a Vietnamese girl to play the title character, a 12-year-old sold into the notorious Cambodian brothel town known as K11.

headline: Backup Helps Rangers Win on Road
text: TORONTO, Nov. 10  For the Rangers, the beginning of Saturday night’s game against the Toronto Maple Leafs was all about Mark Messier, who came through their locker room to encourage them before the game, two days before he will be inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame here.

headline: Skateboarding Rolls Out of the Suburbs
text: IT was late afternoon when the young skaters gathered in front of the Brooklyn Museum on Eastern Parkway. Weaving among the commuters who trudged from a nearby subway station, the skaters hurdled steps, slid along curbs and kick-flipped their boards into the air. With a few exceptions, their performances fell somewhere between outright beginner and advanced novice. But it wasn’t their ability or the lack of it that made this group notable, it was the composition: most of the skaters were black.

headline: A Flawed Law
text: It is hardly a surprise that New Jersey’s civil union law is not working very well. During the past several weeks, dozens of same-sex couples have testified that the law has not provided the equal benefits that were promised when it passed.

headline: Forgetting Everything
text: 1. Symptoms

headline: A Bad Mood May Turn Worse
text: WHEN traders are nervous, danger lurks in every economic report. Two potentially perilous pieces of data this week are snapshots of October inflation.

headline: Ears of a Clown
text: In hot pursuit of cold-blooded kidnappers, the Danish clown Kasper Krone — the hero of Peter Hoeg’s new novel — is shot in the stomach, has his head split open and breaks a wrist and several teeth. Yet as he lies in his hospital cot, slurping soup and leering at an African nun (how could he resist, since her sensuality projects “the energy of an Olatunji drum solo, of a gnu trampling through the rain forest”), he’s able to transcend his physical pain and ponder the transmigration of bouillon: “It was beef soup; it tasted of eternal life and of the fact that all living beings consume one another.” There hasn’t been a day in 20 years when Kasper hasn’t longed to “give up,” to leave Copenhagen for good — to “withdraw his savings. Take off for the Fiji Islands. Develop an opium habit. Listen to cello sonatas on the stereo and fade out on the beach.” You have to wonder what stopped him. An ordinary person hesitates to leave everyday life and run off to join the circus. But if you’re already in the circus, what’s holding you back?

headline: Albee the Enigma, Now the Inescapable
text: THE small, disintegrating painting — delicate flowers flaking off silk — is the work of a French master, but the story about it is pure Edward Albee. Hanging in his TriBeCa loft, almost unnoticeable amid a forest of African sculpture and walls of bold abstractions, it is, Mr. Albee said during a conversation there recently, a puzzle, or rather the key to one. He bought it ages ago, thinking it some kind of sketch or study, only to discover much later the existence of a larger painting with a hole in its middle, of which his flowers were clearly the missing, central piece.

headline: Stars, Stripes, Burgers
text: If you’re seeking American food on Veterans Day, consider Williamsburg. Its thriving restaurant scene, while diverse, has a good selection of American places old and new.

headline: Killing Sends Tremors Through City’s Illegal Poker Scene
text: For years, they have operated in the shadows of Manhattan. With names like Straddle, the Fairview, Playstation and the New York Players Club, they are remarkably well organized, but nonetheless illegal: poker clubs that attract thousands of players at all hours of the day and night.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Comedy

headline: Two New Leaders Take Over Power Authority’s Direction
text: WITH little fanfare, the public-private partnership that supplies electricity to Long Island has been overhauled and put in the hands of different leadership.

headline: Magical Mysteries
text: Back in the 1960s, when I was a teenager, I was always melancholic after hearing the last verse of Peter, Paul and Mary’s “Puff, the Magic Dragon,” released in 1963. I still feel a gnawing pit in my stomach when Peter Yarrow sings, “A dragon lives forever, but not so little boys,” and reaches a crescendo with “One gray night it happened, Jackie Paper came no more / And Puff, that mighty dragon, he ceased his fearless roar.”

headline: Insiders Bail, Stockholders Suffer
text: AT first glance, Crocs and Coach might not appear to have much in common. One is known for its plastic clogs that, while comfortable, will never be beloved by the arbiters of style. The other is famous for deluxe leather handbags that command both high prices and respect from tony consumers.

headline: Georgian Leader Says Emergency Rule to Last as Needed
text: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 10  Anticipating demands from a senior American diplomat that he immediately lift a state of emergency, President Mikheil Saakashvili said Saturday that the emergency decree would remain in effect as long as the Georgian government deemed it necessary.

headline: If the Shoe Fits
text: Whom would you invite to a dinner party if it could be anyone in the history of the world? Forget Copernicus and Karl Marx. Think of people who would actually be fun: the storytellers. They had their fingers on the pulse — the desires, customs and gossip — of their day and could spin a great yarn to boot.

headline: Arianna Zukerman, Peter Sekulow
text: Arianna Zukerman, a daughter of Eugenia Zukerman of New York and the violinist Pinchas Zukerman of Ottawa, was married last evening to Peter Louis Sekulow, a son of Susan F. Sekulow and Eugene A. Sekulow of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk officiated at the Columbus Club, an event space at Union Station in Washington.

headline: The 25-Cent Revolution
text: Quick! What is the best-selling children’s picture book of all time? You might be surprised to learn it’s “The Poky Little Puppy,” by Janette Sebring Lowrey, originally published in 1942. One of the first 12 Little Golden Books, it has sold more than 15 million copies and is still in print. For her efforts, Lowrey was paid a fee of $75. This and many other delightfully entertaining nuggets of information are included in Leonard S. Marcus’s enthusiastic history of Golden Books.

headline: Speak English Like the English
text: IN the Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of “Pygmalion,” Prof. Henry Higgins (Jefferson Mays) vows to teach Eliza Doolittle (Claire Danes) to speak properly. “I shall make a duchess of this draggle-tailed guttersnipe,” he says, and he does, transforming a Cockney flower girl into a refined socialite.

headline: Anatomy of a Director
text: Otto Preminger (1905-86) had, for many of those who worked for him, some of the aspects of an angry eggplant — his bald head and stern face turning purple as he loomed over quaking actors or technicians on a movie set, snarling or screaming outrage at some generally imaginary defect in their work. In fact, he was rather more complicated — a civilized, upper-class Jewish émigré from Vienna, son of Emperor Franz Josef’s chief legal defender; a political liberal; a man capable of courtly kindness and generosity to favored colleagues; a shrewd showman with a genius for manipulating the press; a producer who in the 1950s became one of the first great masters of independent (as opposed to studio system) production; and, finally, a cinematic stylist with a unique, if sometimes limiting, manner.

headline: A Sampler From Mailer
text: Their uniforms were twice blackened, by the water and the dark slime of the trail. And for the instant the light shone on them their faces stood out, white and contorted. Even the guns had a slender articulated beauty like an insect reared back on its wire haunches. Then darkness swirled about them again, and they ground the guns forward blindly, a line of ants dragging their burden back to their hole.

headline: Consumers Have Taste for Local Birds
text: MARK MILOSKI’S turkeys make a racket, surrounding him as he enters their 25 acres at his farm in Calverton.

headline: Antonietta Miniero, Greg Mansfield
text: Antonietta Miniero, the daughter of Concetta and Catello Miniero of Manhasset, N.Y., is to be married today to Greg Brian Mansfield, a son of Stephen Mansfield of New Orleans and the late Kathleen E. Mansfield. The Rev. Damian O’Connell, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Fordham University Church in the Bronx.

headline: In Colombia, a War Zone Reclaims Its Past
text: CANTERING down a muddy path through Tayrona National Park in Colombia, we pulled our horses to a stop and listened as a high-pitched chant in an unfamiliar tongue filtered through the jungle. “That’s Lorenzo,” our guide told us, turning his horse off the trail and up a steep hill toward a solitary mud hut perched on the summit.

headline: The System Flunked, We Didn’t
text: OUR public elementary school in East Harlem, Central Park East I, got a D from Mayor Michael Bloomberg last week.

headline: Very Magic Bullet Theory
text: Some authors are diffident about their thesis, burying it in a blizzard of qualifications and footnotes. James Piereson is not one of them. In “Camelot and the Cultural Revolution,” Piereson, formerly the executive director of the John M. Olin Foundation and currently a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, offers a starkly revisionist account, from the right, of American liberalism and the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

headline: Muslims on TV, No Terror in Sight
text: RAJA MUSHARAFF is not the foreign exchange student the Tolchuck family of fictional Medora, Wis., was expecting. Tall and gangly with gentle brown eyes, Raja comes from a village in Pakistan. He is a practicing Muslim. He is dark skinned. He is anything but the blue-eyed Euro-teen the family envisioned from the brochure.

Miranda of Spring, Tex. Ryan Dowell Baum, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated at the Westin Diplomat, a hotel in Hollywood, Fla.

headline: Rachel Payne, Matthew Snyder
text: Rachel Godwin Payne and Matthew Filip Snyder were married yesterday by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel at the Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan. The Rev. Teresa Payne Gocha, an Episcopal priest and cousin of the bride, participated.

text: In Florida, Loria Must Go

headline: Gizmos to Smooth a Driver’s Bumpy Road
text: “I think you sent me the wrong model,” I told the national sales manager of Petersen Brands of Arlington Heights, Ill. “This one is for professionals. I need the consumer model, the one any idiot can use.”

headline: Trust and Caution
text: A few years ago, impressed by the popular success of David McCullough’s “John Adams” and of Joseph J. Ellis’s “Founding Brothers,” I asked my Newsweek colleague Evan Thomas (himself then at work on a biography of John Paul Jones) to write an article for the magazine on what we called “Founders’ Chic.” Why, we wondered, were so many millennial Americans so intrigued by the stories of dead white men — heroic and fascinating dead white men, to be sure, but still dead white men — from the late 18th century? The answers we came up with were not particularly surprising. Dissatisfied with contemporary political leaders, many looked back with longing to a time when giants seemed to walk the earth; in those pre-9/11, pre-Iraq days, too, the stakes of the Revolutionary generation’s struggles seemed epic compared with the squabbles of our own time. They were fighting for the rights of man while we quarreled over a lockbox for Social Security.

headline: Comic Genius?
text: It has been a while since Hollywood discovered comics. The film industry learned long ago that a great deal of money could be made producing big-budget action films inspired by cheaply printed little books about men in tights and capes. But it’s only recently that the comics world really learned what it could get out of Hollywood. Or at least that Scott Mitchell Rosenberg learned an interesting lesson: actual ink, paper and staple comics might just be the least important part of the comic-book industry.

headline: Adverse Possession: Mind Your Property
text: EARLIER this year, the New York State Legislature passed a bill that would bar a claim of adverse possession, a centuries-old doctrine that allows a person to claim title to property that he or she has used for a specific period of years, if the person making the claim had “actual knowledge” that the property was owned by someone else.

headline: For Cabbies, Due Process With Dread
text: JUST off Queens Boulevard in Sunnyside, on the third floor of a converted factory building where guards check drivers’ licenses at the door, a roomful of rumpled men sat slouched on plastic chairs. They napped, stared into space, or flipped through the yellow violation notices that had brought them to this room this weekday morning, at the threshold of the City Taxi and Limousine Commission’s administrative tribunals.

headline: The Cold War Kid
text: In the spring of 1957, a Hungarian girl appeared one day in my second-grade class in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Our teacher urged us to welcome the new arrival, who spoke no English and would be staying in our class temporarily. Her family, we were told, had just come to America to escape the Russians.

headline: Chasing Dreams, Amputee Inspires Others
text: Hicksville

headline: Getting Beyond the Ferry
text: CONSIDER yourself a savvy regular visitor to the city, but plagued with guilt about that utterly unknown land mass off the southern tip of Manhattan? Perhaps you've even been there and made a brief toe touch at the ferry terminal before turning around and coming back, or taken the drive-through on I-278 on your way from the Goethals Bridge to the Verrazano-Narrows. Much as you might have been wowed by the accurately painted lane dividers, you know that doesn't count as tourism.

headline: Paying a Premium Not to Mingle at Sea
text: BY nature, cruise lovers tend to be egalitarian types. That’s because embarking on a cruise requires a certain willingness to mingle with the masses at the buffet line, pile into the pool with hundreds of other passengers and go onshore with complete strangers — and like it.

headline: In Portugal, a New Stop on the Global Wine Trail
text: ON a crisp fall evening a clutch of bigwig museum directors were barefoot and treading grapes in an old stone vat in the Douro, Portugal’s port wine region. They included João Fernandes, the director of the prestigious Serralves Museum in Oporto, and Vicente Todoli, the director of Tate Modern.

text: SOUTHPORT

text: IT'S so tempting to call it Stalinland.

headline: Jordan, Fearing Islamists, Tightens Grip on Elections
text: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 9  This month’s legislative elections were supposed to be a watershed in this pro-American kingdom’s slow but committed march to democratic change.

headline: Elizabeth Essner, Nils d’Aulaire
text: Elizabeth Maxine Essner, a daughter of Rosalind Essner of Huntington Beach, Calif., and Robert A. Essner of Morristown, N.J., was married last evening to Nils Parin d’Aulaire, the son of Emily d’Aulaire and Per Ola d’Aulaire of Redding, Conn. Jon Bulette, a friend of the couple who was ordained as a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated at Eleven Madison Park, a restaurant in New York.

headline: Daughters of Rival Drug Kings Unite
text: Francine Lucas says she thought her father was in the candy business. Nicole and Ebony Barnes remember a lot of cash around their house, but were not sure exactly what their father did.

headline: A One-Woman Vanguard
text: THE conductor Marin Alsop has strong artistic convictions that she puts into practice and expounds on readily. But there is one aspect of her career that she has been ambivalent about discussing: Ms. Alsop is a notable woman in a field that for whatever reasons continues to be dominated by men.

headline: How the Western Was Won
text: LIKE A GUNSLINGER standing on a dusty street in a one-horse town, facing down a posse or, if he’s wearing a tin star, a gang of outlaws, the western has proved hard to kill. Officially, of course, its death has been documented again and again, with regret and, sometimes, with satisfaction. But as soon as the obsequies have been pronounced and the coffin lowered into the sandy earth, the rumble of hoofbeats sounds on the horizon, and the western rides again. In 1991, for example, the critic J. Hoberman published a thorough and persuasive essay called “How the Western Was Lost,” documenting the waning of a once-vigorous form. That same year, however, Kevin Costner’s “Dances With Wolves” won the Oscars for Best Picture and Best Director, a feat Clint Eastwood’s “Unforgiven” would match two years later. But Hoberman surely had a point. The movie western had retreated from its position as a quintessential and vital form of American storytelling, undone by the same cultural tumult that had put paid to other manifestations of midcentury consensus. The newer westerns, the ones made since Vietnam, were either revivalist or revisionist, seeking to bury the old myths or to exhume them.

headline: The Unraveling
text: Who is Craig Venter? One answer is that he is the scientist who instigated the celebrated race between the government and his former company, Celera, to produce the first complete transcription of a human genome. By 2000, when the two parties declared their contest a tie, Venter was a media darling, a brash, entrepreneurial scientist with a taste for sailing and adventure: the Larry Ellison of the lab, the Richard Branson of biology.

headline: Ellen Stein, Marc Mellinger
text: Dr. Ellen Meredith Stein, a daughter of Jeanne Stein and Dr. Peter J. Stein of Guilford, Conn., is to be married today to Marc Joseph Mellinger, the son of Janet S. Mellinger and Martin B. Mellinger of Belleville, N.J. Rabbi Jill Hausman is to officiate at the New Haven Lawn Club in Connecticut.

headline: A Resource for the ‘Other Westchester’
text: Valhalla

headline: Getting There Almost as Mom and Dad Did
text: IN a world where portable G.P.S. navigation devices cost less than $200 and free mapping software from Google, Microsoft and AOL is available online, is there any reason to buy a trip-planning program for your computer?

headline: Frayed Judicial Robes
text: Imagine a courtroom scene, maybe something out of “Law & Order.” Then ask yourself which official earns the least of all those important people sitting in front of the jury. If you guessed the judge, chances are you’re right.

headline: 36 Hours in Marrakesh, Morocco
text: EVERY generation, Westerners find new reasons to go gaga for Marrakesh. For Edith Wharton and Winston Churchill, the draw was medieval Islamic architecture and rugged mountainous landscapes. For the globetrotting hippies of the woozy “Marrakesh Express” days, the appeal lay in “charming cobras” and “blowing smoke rings,” to quote Crosby, Stills and Nash. These days, with Marrakesh emerging as the center of North Africa’s style and night life, everyone from Julia Roberts to Naomi Campbell has threaded through its labyrinthine old lanes in search of celebrity chefs, opulent spas and designer boutiques. Indeed, for many of Europe’s jet set playgrounds — Ibiza discos, Riviera beach clubs, Paris hotels — a Marrakesh outpost is now de rigueur.

headline: The Devil Went Down to Broadway
text: FLAME licks the upper corner of a playing card, and the suit is spades. If the graphic in the publicity for Conor McPherson’s “Seafarer” spells deviltry and hellfire to you, you’re getting the message. Set in a coastal town north of Dublin, the play makes no mystery of the identity of one Mr. Lockhart, a new acquaintance who joins a quartet of raffish, hard-drinking Irishmen one Christmas Eve for a high-stakes game of poker.

headline: Correction: Yours for the Peeping
text: An article last Sunday about the recent de-emphasis of privacy in architectural design misidentified the program headed by Sherry Turkle, a psychologist who commented on the significance of glass towers. She is the director of the M.I.T. Initiative on Technology and Self; she is not the director of the Program in Science, Technology and Society, though she is a member.

headline: There Are No Easy Answers for Reid and His Family
text: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9  Sounding less like a coach than a counselor of a 12-step program, Andy Reid talked about how to get his Philadelphia Eagles back on track. He said he had encouraged his players to take one game at a time, to keep it simple, to be accountable. In his experience, those are the guiding principles for overcoming a 3-5 start.

headline: Not Everyone Has to Be a Turkey Hunter
text: BOB ERIKSEN knows turkeys. He knows they’re easily startled and will fly up in a jumble if they are. He knows they’re social birds that gobble and yelp and cluck. But he also knows that they’re not easily fooled.

headline: Ambush by Insurgents Kills 6 U.S. and 3 Afghan Soldiers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 10  Six American soldiers and three Afghan soldiers were killed Friday when insurgents ambushed them in eastern Afghanistan, NATO officials said Saturday.

headline: Guns, Germs and Latex
text: Once again, a lengthy treatise has been published about a subject that not long ago would have been considered unfit for polite conversation. “What?” you’re saying. “Michael Pollan has written another exposé about where hamburger comes from?”

headline: Diane Nabatoff and Robert Machinist
text: SEASONED daters will tell you that in-person chemistry is infinitely more significant than the virtual or pen-and-ink kind. After all, you can jibe with someone via e-mail messages, you can wax poetic (apologies to Shelley, Byron, Keats) over their text appeal, but none of that really counts until you meet face to face.

headline: If You Really Want to Hear About It
text: I grew up reading Peter Cameron; he made me want to write. For readers who want to be writers, books are N.F.L. game tapes: they demonstrate what types of plays can be successfully run. What Cameron showed in the mid-1980s, his work appearing regularly in The New Yorker, was that stories could be assembled from moods. The odd sadness his young characters were prone to was something I’d never seen before. (Here’s the conclusion to one story, “Homework”: “Find the value of n such that n plus everything else in your life makes you feel all right. What would n equal? Solve for n.”)

headline: Rediscovering New York as It Used to Be
text: MICHAEL ANDALORO lived in Alphabet City for nearly 25 years before moving to Brooklyn last year, and he doesn’t long for Manhattan. “I didn’t miss it for the past 10 years,” Mr. Andaloro said facetiously. The bohemian East Village of his younger days had become so bourgeois that he could barely recognize it. “On Thursday nights, it was like spring break in Orlando,” he said.

headline: The Day’s Best
text: JOE GANZ, left, set Nebraska records by throwing for 510 yards and 7 touchdowns, helping the Cornhuskers stop a five-game losing streak with a 73-31 victory over Kansas State.

headline: Doctors With Instruments (Not the Surgical Kind)
text: IF a beeper goes off when the Albert Einstein Symphony Orchestra performs, it might be from the stage. Many members of the orchestra — which opens its new season on Nov. 18 at 3 p.m. in Robbins Auditorium of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx — are doctors. Among them is its founder, conductor and music director, Dr. Stephen Moshman, an associate professor of medicine at New York Medical College in Valhalla and a visiting associate professor at Einstein.

headline: Disappearing Into the Desert
text: It took a German to capture on film the seduction of American space, and how it would look to vanish into it. I first saw Wim Wenders’s “Paris, Texas” in 1994, 10 years after it was made. Not long before I drove through the American desert for the first time. I exercised the freedom it offered by driving at very high speeds. When I stopped the car on the side of the road and got out, especially at night, the idea of my own disappearance into such enormousness terrified me. I grew up on Long Island, and whenever my family traveled, we went east, across the Atlantic, back toward the crowded cities of Europe from which we’d come. When I left for college, the farthest west I’d been was New Jersey.

headline: Odd Man In
text: WHEN you have a reputation as Hollywood’s reigning deviant, the weirdest thing you can do is act traditional. This is perhaps why Crispin Glover — an actor who counts a century-old ophthalmologist’s wax model of diseased eyes as a prized possession — seemed eager to discuss his stodgy enthusiasms for Tchaikovsky and antique furniture en route to dinner at Jean Georges on a recent evening out with his girlfriend, Mara LaFontaine.

headline: And Your Point Is ... ?
text: When a children’s book sends a message — or when an adult book does, for that matter — it is usually strongest when the moral is conveyed with delicacy and complexity. Openly didactic stories rarely make for child or parent favorites, because beloved picture books are read repeatedly. To sustain such repetition, they need to operate on multiple levels: to inspire conversations, laughter, identification, emotion.

headline: Where Cider Gets a French Kick
text: ASK for a glass of “cidre” in Quebec and you will get not the unfermented, unfiltered juice of the apple that cider drinkers in the United States expect, but an alcoholic, sometimes sparkling beverage that can range from sweet to dry. Ask for cider in the Eastern Townships — a sprawling area east of Montreal and south of Quebec City — and you are likely to be served a flute of cidre de glace, or ice cider, an alcoholic beverage made by fermenting the juice of apples that have been left to freeze in the frigid Quebec winter. In local restaurants, it is offered, well chilled, with the cheese or dessert course.

headline: Is Private Equity Giving Hertz a Boost?
text: An article on Sept. 23 about the performance of Hertz, the rental car company, since its buyout by private equity firms in 2005 referred imprecisely to some of its past practices. At times, Hertz indeed used outside printers and other outsourcing for some work and used financial yardsticks like Ebitda and cash flow; those practices did not start after the buyout, though they have been expanded broadly. And before 2000, Hertz’s chief executive reported directly to senior managers such as the chief financial officer and vice chairman of Ford, a previous owner of Hertz; the chief executive did not report to lower-level managers. A letter dated Oct. 2 from Frank A. Olson, chief executive of Hertz from 1977 to 1999, clarifying certain past practices, was misdirected within The Times. This correction was further delayed for research.

Just as we had an upsurge in difficult westerns when we were struggling with Vietnam, now we’re struggling with Iraq, and so we are having the same upsurge.

headline: Reaching for It
text: It looks as if the western has chosen this historical juncture to make its reappearance, after a long absence. A glimpse of the reason can perhaps be obtained from Neil Jordan’s “Brave One,” an honorary western of sorts. Jodie Foster’s character, a whimsical public-radio chatterer, becomes an urban vigilante after falling victim to street violence. In the midst of her spree of bloodletting, she obliquely alludes to her activities on the air, and quotes from D. H. Lawrence’s “Studies in Classic American Literature”: “The essential American soul is hard, isolate, stoic and a killer.” Whatever Lawrence’s own political predilections, that line (he was thinking of James Fenimore Cooper’s “Deerslayer”) has the oddest of fan bases, making bedfellows of two gangs who, you might think, wouldn’t otherwise be caught dead in the same room: European romantics and American right-wing ideologues. The former crowd enjoys the frisson imparted by that remote and menacing Other; the latter imagines seeing it in the mirror. Everyone else may be caught between wonder and suspicion — just whose American soul are we talking about?

headline: Go on, Bold Couch Potatoes, Click Into the Unknown
text: “Fifty-seven channels and nothin’ on,” Bruce Springsteen sang back in 1992, but nowadays that number is laughably low. If you still live on the mainstream end of the remote, the writers’ strike that has paralyzed some of television’s most popular shows may be the incentive you need to go searching in the triple-digit reaches of the cable- and satellite-dish world. It is a realm of the odd and the obscure and the low budget. But hey, at least it’s something different to stare at mindlessly while your favorite show is in reruns. Here’s a guide:

headline: Athens: Mastihashops
text: The aromatic resin from the mastiha, or lentisk, tree on the Greek island of Chios has flavored potions, sweets and cosmetics in the eastern Mediterranean for thousands of years. In more recent times, entrepreneurs have been transforming the fresh burst-of-sweet, hint-of-bitter sap known in Greece as mastiha into a boutique brand for these healthy-chic times.

headline: Up Front
text: This week we present our twice-yearly Children’s Books special issue, a 32-page review within the Review, edited once again by the children’s books editor, Julie Just. It was a massive one-person job; this year Julie selected 37 children’s and young adult books, commissioned reviews of each and then edited the reviews as they came in. She also recruited the three judges who sifted through hundreds of illustrated books in search of the 10 Best (the winners appear here). As was the case last year, a strong selection of young adult novels shares the stage with the season’s outstanding picture books — including first ventures into the field by writers like Peter Cameron, Nick Hornby and Sherman Alexie, whose autobiographical novel is a finalist for the National Book Award for young people’s literature.

headline: See How They Ran
text: I remember exactly where I was sitting when I started reading “What It Takes,” Richard Ben Cramer’s 1,000-page, tiny-print history of the 1988 presidential campaign. It’s not a hard thing to remember, because I couldn’t sit anywhere else: I had mangled my knee in a touch football game, and all I could do was sit on the couch with my leg strapped into a motion machine. Like a lot of young journalism school graduates then and now, I had come to see political journalism as a lesser form of the craft, populated mostly by the effete and the unindustrious, while the real reporters were out there braving crack corners and foreign wars. “What It Takes” showed me something else entirely.

headline: Picketing but Still Punchy
text: THE writers of “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” are some of the newest members of the Writers Guild of America — just over a year old. Developmentally, we’re babies — still in the oral stage. When we finally get a new contract, the first thing we’re doing is sticking it in our mouths.

headline: Hey, Candidate, I’m All Yours, Your Very Own Pied Piper
text: SO the most unlikely pairing of the presidential campaign is unveiled, with the Rev. Pat Robertson flashing a television-practiced smile at Rudolph W. Giuliani, the thrice-married, pro-abortion-rights former mayor of New York.

headline: Subcontinental Drift
text: Paul Theroux is the thinking person’s James Michener, a globe-hopping chronicler of distant lands whose stories, some reported, some invented, aim to inform and broaden, not merely engage, and permit the armchair voyager to stamp new visas in his intellectual passport. Theroux delivers richer prose than Michener, subtler insights and slyer dilemmas, but he resembles the late mass-market master of narrative geography by treating societies as his true protagonists while giving his characters (in his novels, at least) the auxiliary role of inciting, observing or acting out the conflicts latent in their surrounding cultures. Art for art’s sake isn’t Theroux’s bag, and it needn’t be, of course. He likes to lecture a little between the lines, to show off the artifacts gathered during his travels and speculate on their significance.

headline: The Terrorism Card
text: Sometimes victory comes at too high an ethical cost. headline: The New Frontier’s Man
text: IN 1976, WHEN HE WAS 19, Daniel Day-Lewis, who is British and was trained in the grand theatrical tradition of Shakespeare and the classics, saw “Taxi Driver” and, despite the considerable weight and seeming obligation of his heritage, realized that what he longed to be was an American actor. “It was a real illumination,” Day-Lewis told me late in August as he sat at the rough wood dining table of a duplex apartment in downtown Manhattan, where he and his wife, Rebecca Miller, and their two boys stay when in New York. “I saw ‘Taxi Driver’ five or six times in the first week, and I was astonished by its sheer visceral beauty. I just kept going back — I didn’t know America, but that was a glimpse of what America might be, and I realized that, contrary to expectation, I wanted to tell American stories.” It was raining hard outside, and Day-Lewis, who has the look of an elegant vagabond, was wearing clothes seemingly chosen many years ago for their utility and subtle details. His loose denim jeans were worn soft and white by use and the once-vibrant red plaid of his shirt had aged into a warm maroon. Day-Lewis is tall and lean and has tattoos circling his lower arms and the permanently inked handprints of his and Miller’s two sons climbing up his body to his shoulders. There were gold loops in each earlobe, and although he had left his sturdy, beat-up leather work boots outside the front door and was padding around in his socks, Day-Lewis still had a kind-of-jaunty porkpie hat on his head. The hat covered his long black hair and set off the contours of his face, which is dominated by his noble, bashed nose.

headline: Paperback Row
text: NIXON AND KISSINGER: Partners in Power, by Robert Dallek. (HarperCollins, $18.95.) Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger, his national security adviser and, later, secretary of state, were simultaneously visionaries and cynics, according to the historian Robert Dallek (pictured below). Both were ruthless pragmatists and insecure loners who distrusted and abused those around them, including each other. Their partnership produced bold foreign policy advances like the opening of relations with China in 1971-72, but also prolonged and expanded the Vietnam War and overthrew the democratically elected government of Chile. Relying on recently declassified material, including thousands of pages of transcriptions of Kissinger’s phone calls, Dallek argues that the careers of both men “reflect the extent to which great accomplishments and public wrongdoing can spring from inner lives.” Another secretary of state with a complicated relationship to his president is the subject of SOLDIER: The Life of Colin Powell (Vintage, $17.95), by the Washington Post editor Karen DeYoung. Her presentation of Powell’s early career draws heavily on his 1995 memoir; six long interviews with Powell inform DeYoung’s sympathetic account of his contribution to the Bush administration’s case for war. DeYoung sees Powell’s willingness to promote a policy he questioned as rooted in his habitual caution and his view of his duty: “His job was to serve the president, not to undermine him,” Michael Lewis explained in the Book Review.

headline: Ayurveda and Ice at New Resort Spas
text: The Leela Kempinski Kovalam Beach Hotel, a clifftop resort in Kerala, India, has just opened an 8,000-square-foot ayurvedic wellness center called Divya. The center has 15 therapists and 4 physicians trained in ayurvedic medicine, an ancient healing practice, and an open-air meditation hall, above. The resort itself has 181 rooms and suites on 44 acres, including two infinity pools. To celebrate the opening of the center, the resort is offering several packages that start at $1,490 for five days and include beach-view rooms, consultations with ayurvedic doctors, herbal medicines, and a daily ayurvedic massage (www.theleela.com).

headline: The Clink of Glasses, the Crash of Pins

I’ve been here at least five times already.”

headline: A Fresh Bird Raised Just for a Feast
text: WHETHER it’s brined, broiled, baked or served up smoked from the barbecue grill, come the fourth Thursday of November, turkey will be the centerpiece of most Americans’ Thanksgiving feast. Yet the thousands of birds available at grocery stores have drifted ever further from the fresh fowl of our forefathers. Continuous breeding cycles, forced feeding, reliance on hormones and antibiotics, and a lengthy period on ice during transport have taken their toll, which is where Connecticut farmers come in.

headline: McGovern Redux
text: It’s an article of faith among many centrist Democrats (and nearly all Republicans) that the Democratic Party blundered badly in 1972 when it nominated George McGovern for president. Bruce Miroff’s wise and informative book “The Liberals’ Moment” invites a peek through the telescope’s opposite end. Miroff, a political science professor at the State University of New York at Albany, reminds us gently that the real blunder was committed by the 47 million voters who re-elected Richard Nixon in a 49-state landslide.

headline: In the Bond Market, a Bleak Prognosis for Iraq
