headline: Hollywords
text: Eggheaded showbiz types who seriously insist on calling movies films are hung up on (or as they would say, “obsessed with”) the word genre. It’s French, pronounced only the French way — zhahn-ruh — and means “class, kind, category, species.” You don’t have to be French to understand “noir is my favorite genre”; any film critic who used the synonym “type” would be drummed out of the corpse.

headline: Rachel Dinkes, Jason Hoffman
text: Rachel Beth Dinkes, a daughter of Ellen Dinkes and Dr. Lawrence Dinkes of Trumbull, Conn., was married last evening to Jason Foster Hoffman, the son of Sheryl Staren of Bethesda, Md., and Jack Hoffman of San Clemente, Calif. Rabbi James Prosnit performed the ceremony at Temple Sholom in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Datebook
text: PARIS

headline: The Real, the Mortal, the Inspirational
text: K T TUNSTALL, the Scottish singer-songwriter who was nominated for a Grammy for “Black Horse and the Cherry Tree” (better known as the “woo-hoo” song), is back with her second album, “Drastic Fantastic” (Virgin). In addition to accolades Ms. Tunstall’s soulful twang over syncopated guitar riffs has evidently inspired feats of athleticism. “I had a lot of trim middle-aged women coming up to me at signings saying they listened to my music in Jazzercise class,” she said. Ms. Tunstall, 32, was recently spending a day at her home in London before continuing on a tour that includes Los Angeles, Chicago and New York City, where she’ll play Nov. 21. She spoke by phone with Winter Miller about what she’s listening to and watching.

headline: Reluctantly Embracing the Upper East Side
Much Loved, Now Much Used
text: WHEN residents of Darien, Conn., walk into their new library sometime in 2009, they will be able to read a book or magazine while sipping coffee in a cafe that spills out to the sidewalk. They will find books grouped by subject, as they are in bookstores, instead of according to the Dewey Decimal System. They will lounge in overstuffed chairs, peruse DVDs in a Blockbuster-style video section, write a report on a wireless computer or print one on a color copier, and bind a proposal in the building’s small business center.

headline: Turkish Newspapers Vie for Fluency in Two Societies
text: MÖRFELDEN-WALLDORF, Germany  Kerem Caliskan has what sounds like an impossible job. He is working to persuade people born in Germany, educated in Germany and living in Germany  many of them German citizens  to read Turkish newspapers.

headline: Hershey Shakes Up Its Board
text: The chocolate maker Hershey, which replaced its chief executive last month, announced a reshuffling of its board of directors late this afternoon as the charitable trust that controls the company stepped up efforts to lift Hershey’s languishing stock.

headline: Lauren Tabak, Jason Fass
text: Lauren Brooke Tabak, a daughter of Judy W. Tabak and Mark H. Tabak of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Jason Frederic Fass, the son of Robin E. Fass and Stephen H. Fass of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi Irwin Kula officiated at Capitale, an event space in New York, with Rabbi Bernard S. Lipnick taking part.

headline: Royalton Shake-Up, From Top to Lobby
text: AS tourists slipped past the tall mahogany doors into the lobby of the Royalton Hotel the other evening, many appeared taken aback. The hotel’s interior since 1988 — a bold confection by the designer Philippe Starck — had been torn out. Gone were the chair legs shaped like ram’s horns. Gone was the Champagne bar that conjured up the inside of a genie’s bottle.

headline: Garden of Vandals
text: Some local fifth graders vandalized our town’s voluntarily financed, old and prestigious organic garden. They were caught and did community service, but there is still several thousand dollars’ worth of damage. Do their wealthy parents have an obligation to pay for these repairs? — R.S., California

headline: Coen Brothers Country
text: Joel and Ethan Coen, who write, direct, produce and edit their films, do not agree that their latest movie, “No Country for Old Men,” adapted from the Cormac McCarthy novel, is a western. “When we think about westerns,” Joel explained, “we think about horses and six-guns, saloons and hitching posts.” Ethan, who was sitting next to his older brother on the couch in their cluttered college-dorm-like production office in downtown Manhattan, continued the thought. “ ‘No Country for Old Men’ is sort of a western,” he said, “and sort of not.”

headline: Squaring Off on Global Warming
text: Five Connecticut environmental groups recently called on the state to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 80 percent by 2050. They promise a proposal in time for the next legislative session that would, if passed, impose mandatory caps on fossil fuel emissions to combat global warming.

headline: From Oaxaca, With Echoes of European Art
text: A cradle for early Mesoamerican civilizations, the fertile state of Oaxaca in southwestern Mexico was home to a long list of settlers and conquerors: the Zapotec people, the Mixtecs, the Aztecs and finally the Spanish. Today it is home to Mexico’s largest concentration of speakers of indigenous languages.

headline: Driving School Students Wait Out the Governor
text: The M-Punctual driving school, a gray-carpeted shoe box of an office on a side street in Kensington, Brooklyn, has been a bit livelier in recent weeks. More immigrants with questionable documents, or no documents, every one of them a potential customer, have been inquiring about the governor’s driver’s license proposal.

headline: Illinois Is the Team That Spoils Ohio State’s Season
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10 — For the second consecutive season, undefeated Ohio State flopped spectacularly in a big game. Only this season, the loss came a few weeks earlier for the top-ranked Buckeyes.

headline: Please, Translator, Can I Have Some More?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Roots
text: In his children’s novel “What-the-Dickens,” Gregory Maguire does for the dark and stormy night what he did for witches in “Wicked” and for the vaguely malevolent kingdom of Snow White in “Mirror Mirror”: he brings a literary commonplace to booming, three-dimensional life.

headline: 2 Die and 2 Are Wounded in Pair of Weekend Shootings
text: Two men were shot, one of them fatally, outside a Brooklyn bakery early yesterday, moments after the men had finished their meal, according to the police and the bakery manager.

headline: Me and My Alien
text: Somewhere around age 10, the excitement of reading — of just knowing what those words say on the page — is over. Many readers have plowed through everything they wanted to, meaning they’ve read all the series books. They’ve read and reread “Warriors,” the Alex Rider books, “Artemis Fowl,” the Percy Jackson books and “The Edge Chronicles.” Harry Potter is over. Sigh.

headline: In Search of Savers: 401(k) Rules Are Changing
text: NEW 401(k) regulations that take effect next month will sharply alter the rules of the game — at least for some employees.

headline: Real Retirees, in a ‘Virtual Village’
text: NEW CANAAN

headline: The Audience’s Role; Aretha Franklin; War on Film
text: THE AUDIENCE’S ROLE

headline: Old Walls, New Spirit
text: HALF a thousand years ago, in 1508, Juan Ponce de León arrived on the island of Puerto Rico and set up an outpost near the back of the great harbor on the island's northeast coast. He had with him a company of soldiers, a famously vicious red dog named Becerillo, and permission to use whatever means necessary to convince the local Taino people that they would rather look for gold in the rivers and salvation in heaven than carry on enjoying their little tropical paradise.

headline: Rebecca Spielfogel, Daniel Polivy
text: Rebecca Ivy Spielfogel, a daughter of Roni A. Spielfogel and Joel L. Spielfogel of Jericho, N.Y., was married last evening to Daniel Jacob Polivy, a son of Linda G. Polivy and Dr. Kenneth D. Polivy of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Michael Katz officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y., with Cantor Kalman Fliegelman taking part.

headline: Stranger in a Strange Land
text: Some of the most accomplished graphic novels in existence are never identified as such. Maurice Sendak’s “In the Night Kitchen” comes to mind, as does Peggy Rathmann’s “Good Night, Gorilla” and David Wiesner’s recent Caldecott winner “Flotsam.” Sendak, Rathmann and Wiesner are best known as children’s book illustrators, but these particular works are pure comics in the way they construct their narratives.

headline: O Frabjous Day!
text: Christopher Myers’s take on the greatest nonsense verse in the English-speaking world — a basketball face-off — combines brio and whimsy with more energy than a power forward. But doesn’t shooting hoops with the Jubjub Bird and the Bandersnatch require an incredible leap of the imagination?

headline: Sara Kippur, Joshua Lambert
text: Sara Dania Kippur, a daughter of Susan and Stephen Kippur of New York, is to be married today to Joshua Nathaniel Lambert, a son of Elaine and Robert Lambert of Toronto. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon is to officiate at the Metropolitan Pavilion, an events space in New York, with Cantor Ari Priven participating.

headline: Too Much Meddling When C.E.O.’s Go a-Courtin’?
text: The DealBook column last Sunday, about chief executives who seek merger deals for their companies, misstated the status of a buyout that Richard D. Kinder, the chairman of Kinder Morgan Inc., led to acquire that company. It was completed in May; it is not pending.

headline: When One of Me Suddenly Became Three
text: BECAUSE of a twist of fate, I became a grandmother nearly concurrently with becoming a mother, not long after I was reunited with the daughter I had given up for adoption decades before. By the time I found her — I was 42 and she 25 — my daughter, who would soon have a child herself, had been with several mothers, but none who had stayed. And I had never had another child. In this way we needed each other; our wounds were clean and deep.

headline: For a Hard-Luck Motel, Hard Feelings Down the Street
text: DESPITE its humble appearance, the three-story beige box in East Elmhurst, Queens, known as the Westway Motel is the kind of place that could have inspired an Emma Lazarus sonnet.

headline: Deconstruction Zone
text: Young artists enjoying success don’t usually move to Shelter Island. But that is what Alan Shields did in 1972, when he was 28 and atop the heap in the New York scene. He simply packed up and opted out for a life on a seaside farm where he grew his own vegetables and fished from a handmade boat.

headline: Taint by Association
text: HENRY BLODGET, an author and former stock analyst, is a gifted writer whose work has appeared in The Times four times in the past two and a half years, most recently last month in a special business news section, DealBook.

headline: Alkistis Meimaris, Vassilios Papageorgiou
text: Alkistis Georgie Meimaris, a daughter of Helen Callaizakis Meimaris and Alkiviades Meimaris of Fort Lee, N.J., was married on Thursday to Vassilios Papageorgiou, a son of Glykeria Papageorgiou and Panagiotis Papageorgiou of Katerini, Greece. The couple had a civil ceremony at the South County Courthouse of Palm Beach County in Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. Nicholas Samaras is to lead a religious ceremony next Sunday at Sts. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church in West Nyack, N.Y., with assistance from the Rev. Alex Karloutsos, another Greek Orthodox priest.

headline: What Is the Measure of a Successful Mom?; Those Artificial Fields: a Question of Safety (4 Letters)
text: What Is the Measure of a Successful Mom?

headline: Correction: Telltale Art
text: Two picture captions with an article last Sunday about fall art auctions were reversed. The Mark Rothko painting on the right, “Untitled (Black and Gray),” is being sold at Christie’s on Tuesday, and the other Rothko painting, “Untitled,” is being sold at Sotheby’s on Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption last Sunday in T: Design & Living magazine, with an article about the return of the baronial-manorial aesthetic in interior design, included an incorrect location from the Corbis photography agency for a library once owned by William Randolph Hearst. The library was in the Clarendon on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, not in the Hearst Castle in San Simeon, Calif.

headline: Doctor, Doctor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Full Shelves, Empty Awnings
text: LYDIG AVENUE, a long, curvy street with a bustling seven-block retail corridor in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx, seems to have everything a shopping strip might need. Bulbous loaves of crusty bread cool on a wire rack in the bakery window. Snapper fillets and salmon steaks are piled on ice in the fish market. The pharmacy offers sales on paper towels and allergy medicine.

headline: Family Secrets
text: Young adult literature has been doing some growing up. It’s not that it is getting better (although in a lot of ways it is) but rather that more and more of it is being aimed at older teenagers. “Twelve and up” used to be the standard reading-level designation for young adult novels; now “14 and up” or even “16 and up” have become common.

headline: Major Changes for Magnet Schools
text: When it comes to desegregating public schools, voluntary measures are best, Connecticut says. State officials have created incentives over the years by offering generous financial support for both the construction of regional magnet schools and the education of the students who attend them. These subsidies have led to the construction of many more magnet schools — from just a few in the early 1990s to 54 statewide today.

headline: Rabbit in a Hot Rich Sauce
text: TESTED: 2008 Volkswagen R32

headline: Ever Backward Into the Royal Future
text: LONDON

headline: Dana Hork, Brad Weckstein
text: Dana Elizabeth Hork and Brad Stephen Weckstein were married last evening at the Kiawah Island Club on Kiawah Island, S.C. Rabbi Arnold Belzer officiated.

headline: High-Def at High Noon
text: Today’s film fanatics, the ones who buy DVDs of high-definition directors’ cuts and study all the extras, are sticklers for vividness, crisp borders and high color. In this way, these aesthetes may have something in common with the rugged heroes of Hollywood’s great westerns, those austere individualists who also prize clarity. This shouldn’t be surprising. Film and frontier have always gone together. Formally, they’re kin.

headline: Pieds Can Be à Terre Here, Too
text: FOREIGN and out-of-state buyers and renters seeking high-end pieds-à-terre so they can take advantage of New York City seem to be figuring out what permanent suburb dwellers already know: Access to Manhattan is a good deal cheaper if your real estate investment occurs just next door.

headline: John Lithgow Sings of the Sewer, and Other Funny Stuff
text: MOVIE, television and theater audiences have gotten to know him as a transgendered football player, a kindly alien professor and an evil gossip columnist. But John Lithgow is eager to familiarize people with a new side of him. Actually, a few new sides.

headline: Giving to Charity, Through Real Estate
text: SIDNEY AND ELISABETH GARVAIS had a lifetime of memories tied up in their second home, a small cottage on 4 ½ acres on Block Island, R.I. They paid around $20,000 for it in 1965, and used it for summer vacations and to entertain guests on weekends. Of course, it also turned out to be one of their best investments.

headline: America’s Team, Right or Wrong
text: Anthony Wright remembers his Dallas Cowboys pajamas. He was 6 or 7, living in Vanceboro, N.C., and rooting for the organization known as America’s Team, sometimes to the tooth-gnashing fury of those who did not fall under the spell.

headline: City’s Newest Food Co-op Gains a Foothold in the South Bronx
text: The newest food cooperative in New York City opened for another day of operations yesterday, right underneath the stairwell of a community center in the Bronx.

headline: Out of the Fire
text: When Dante wrote the poem we call “The Divine Comedy,” he called it simply the “Commedia”: a story, beginning in sorrow and ending in joy, of one man’s journey from hell, through purgatory, to paradise. It’s a good story. But while many of us are eager to harrow the halls of hell, with its gossipy tales of human suffering, few of us make it to heaven, where we are instructed in the theological intricacies of free will, gravity and the soul. No one said the journey was going to be easy.

headline: Correction: The Artisans of the Real Dolce Vita
text: A picture caption last Sunday with the Journeys column, about the growing number of chocolatiers in Tuscany, misidentified the shop where a display of small chocolates with designs was shown. It is La Bottega del Cioccolato, not Slitti Cioccolato e Caffè.

headline: Letters
text: Jessica Seinfeld, Take 3

headline: No Drivers, but a Lot of Drive
text: ON Nov. 3, when robot vehicles raced through Darpatown, a simulated suburbia created in an abandoned Air Force Base in Victorville, Calif., each machine appeared to show its own distinct personality.

headline: The Tables Turn for Dilbert’s Creator
text: THIS is yet another story about a clueless but obtrusive boss — the kind of meddlesome manager you might laugh at in the panels of “Dilbert,” the daily comic strip.

headline: The Subtler Shades of Racism
text: It’s hard to imagine, in 2007, a white actor who would avoid going to lunch with the African-Americans in the cast of his Broadway play. But most of the other slights, indignities and just plain idiocies besetting the black performers rehearsing an anti-lynching play in Alice Childress’s 1955 backstage comedy-drama, “Trouble in Mind,” seem as plausible in today’s world as they were back when the play opened Off Broadway.

headline: Whose Flawed Family Is This, Anyway?
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Your Home Can Be the Star of an Online Show
text: IF you’re shopping for a new home, it’s easy to take a virtual stroll through the ranch house at 640 Hobart Avenue, San Mateo, Calif., asking price $1,049,000. The house has its own Web site, complete with a soundtrack (www.640hobart.com). Click on it and a real estate agent welcomes you in the voiceover, as crisp digital photographs of the sunny rooms flow past on the screen, with each photo neatly dovetailed to the narration.

headline: County Seeks to Imitate Water-Quality Plan
text: SINCE 2002, Connecticut has reduced the amount of nitrogen being released into the Long Island Sound by allowing its 79 sewage-treatment plants to trade pollution credits.

headline: Notes for a Theory of the Road Movie
text: What is the origin of road movies? A year ago, I interviewed Wim Wenders on this topic for a documentary about “On the Road,” Jack Kerouac and the legacy of the Beat generation.

headline: Hatched
text: In the 1940s, children’s books with holes or windows, as well as those with flaps, tabs, bumps and berms, were likened to “toys,” introducing new dimensionality to the growing picture-book genre. Today’s “die cuts” (a publisher’s term for books with holes of various shapes) range from intricate playthings to simple tools for learning.

headline: Recognizing the Honor of a Son
text: RIVERHEAD

headline: Low-Tech, Perhaps, but They Still Work
text: THERE are more old-fashioned emergency call boxes on eBay than in Linden, Elizabeth, Perth Amboy and dozens of other New Jersey cities combined. But while many towns around the state are deactivating street-corner alarms that have survived 150 years, others continue to rely heavily on them.

headline: How Large a Fine Can the Board Impose?
text: Q A controversy has arisen in my co-op about whether the board of directors can levy a fine in excess of the amount provided for in our proprietary lease and without a prior written warning as the lease requires. Or can the board impose a fine it deems “reasonable” after what it deems “reasonable” notice?

headline: Palestinian Calls Off Meeting With Israelis
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 11 — The leader of the Palestinian team working with Israelis to prepare for an international meeting on Middle East peace called off a meeting with his Israeli counterparts on Sunday evening after being stuck at an Israeli checkpoint for 20 minutes, an aide said.

headline: Looks Aren’t Everything
text: Dystopian fantasies are uniquely suited to the young adult reader, mainly because the usual story line — the hero realizes that his or her “perfect world” isn’t perfect after all — mirrors the experience of venturing from the relative safety of childhood into the harsher realities of adult life. Whatever the author’s intent, which is usually gloomily political, the story’s psychological underpinning is the adolescent’s shock at learning that some of what you’re taught isn’t true, your parents are flawed human beings and the world isn’t constructed for your benefit. Perhaps that explains why even dystopian novels written for adults, like “1984,” are most powerfully experienced in early adolescence, when Winston Smith’s realization that Big Brother wants to crush him kind of feels like the reader’s real life.

headline: Off the Rez
text: Arnold Spirit Jr. is the geekiest Indian on the Spokane Reservation. He wears chunky, lopsided glasses. His head and body look like Sputnik on a toothpick. When he doesn’t stutter, he lisps. Arnold is a 14-year-old high school freshman. When he goes outside he gets teased and beaten, so he spends a lot of time in his room drawing cartoons. “I think the world is a series of broken dams and floods,” he says, “and my cartoons are tiny little lifeboats.”

headline: Norwegian Opera Will Perform at Sea
text: Hurtigruten (www.hurtigruten.us), formerly Norwegian Coastal Voyage Inc., has invited the Norwegian National Opera aboard its 674-passenger Trollfjord ship for several opera-themed cruises in late January. The program, “Opera Beneath the Polar Sky,” will have three-, four- and eight-night versions, which will all feature performances onboard as well as concerts held in sites close to select ports, including the Arctic and Lofoten Cathedrals. Selections include works by Dvorak, Strauss, Sondheim and Mozart, like “The Magic Flute,” left. The three-night cruise, which starts at $1,399, sails north with calls at Hammerfest, Honningsvag, Vadso and Murmansk (Russia); the four-night cruise, starting at $1,599, sails south with calls at Murmansk, Honningsvag, Harstad and Svolvaer; and the eight-night cruise combines the two itineraries and starts at $2,499. Prices are per person, double occupancy, and include accommodations, all meals and all concerts.

headline: Once Again, Johnson Finds Higher Gear in the Chase
text: If ever there was a driver who could run with Jimmie Johnson in the Chase for the Nextel Cup, his Hendrick Motorsports teammate Jeff Gordon should have been the one to do it. But even Gordon, the winner of four championships in his career and the points leader through most of the playoff, is beginning to fade against Johnson, who has become the master of the Chase.

headline: A Homeland Beckons
text: IN a soundproof glass booth in the back of a travel agency on Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, Alex Polanco was murmuring into his microphone in Spanish. “We want to know your thoughts, your opinions,” said Mr. Polanco, a host of Grupo Radial Delgado, a tiny radio station aimed at New York’s Ecuadorean immigrants. “The Plan of Return, is it good? Is it bad? The lines are open.”

headline: The Dead and the Naked
text: Chapter 10: Terrible Things Happen There

headline: Isles Foil Brodeur’s Shot at 500th Win
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 10 — Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur has fattened up his impressive victory total by repeatedly foiling the Islanders over the years, beating them 38 times.

headline: Correction: Essay About “The Toothpick”
text: An essay on Oct. 28 about “The Toothpick: Technology and Culture,” by Henry Petroski, misstated one of the author’s academic fields. It is civil engineering, not civic.

headline: High Anxiety at a Popular Preschool
text: AMONG the many posts about the Riverside Church Weekday School that appeared on the Urban Baby online message board this fall, one from a parent interested in learning about the school prompted this response: “Currently in turmoil.”

headline: Of Human Bondage
text: The stories told in a pair of trials in federal courtrooms in Lower Manhattan and Central Islip have been heartbreaking. At the first trial, witnesses told of abuses they suffered in what federal agents say was an international prostitution ring — a sophisticated enterprise that smuggled Asian women into the country and forced them to work at massage parlors and spas up and down the East Coast.

headline: Democracy’s Root: Diversity
text: Last Tuesday, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia met Pope Benedict XVI at the Vatican — the first audience ever by the head of the Catholic Church with a Saudi monarch. The Saudi king gave the pope two gifts: a golden sword studded with jewels, and a gold and silver statue depicting a palm tree and a man riding a camel.

headline: A Bite of the Bagel
text: Hillary Clinton had the bad luck to fumble a debate before the writers’ strike knocked late-night comics off the air.

headline: Asian Confusion
text: Miko Hayashi and her colleagues have worked hard to organize the Asian-American Digi-Fest, a little film festival in Berkeley, Calif., and now it’s time to screen the prizewinner, “Fortune Cookie Rookie.” The movie is just another piece of high-minded, low-budget hokum, but the Asian-American audience smiles and applauds at the fade-out — except for Miko’s boyfriend, Ben Tanaka, a grumpy, 30-year-old Japanese-American, who’s having none of it. After refusing to go to the after-party, he starts spewing his usual venom.

headline: The Cloistral Hush Revisited
text: “Ten more days left to punting season,” a longtime Oxfordshire resident mulled as he led a group of us on a nature walk, complete with dogs and muddied Wellington boots, through University Parks. We were blessed with warm, clear weather on a Saturday in early October as we tramped past duck ponds, through pastures and over rickety bridges. But, with a touch of typical English pessimism, we were also told it would not last.

headline: Parents Fault School for Delay Over Mold
text: WESTPORT

headline: A Big Box of Eagles
text: The new Eagles album — “Long Road Out of Eden”— came out recently, but only at Wal-Mart. One of the points the Eagles may be making is that you have to consider your allegiances in the world of the present, not the past. A few years ago, any link between Wal-Mart and Don Henley, an ardent environmentalist, would have seemed puzzling at best. But there is a simple equation here. This new album was released without the participation of a major record label. This isn’t just a case of selling exclusively in the Big Box. It’s a case of giving up Big Vinyl and its distribution.

headline: The War to End All Wars? If Only...
text: Rutherford

headline: Climbing Some Steps on the Pay Ladder
text: THE New York City government is helping Andre Franks and Makida Hall rise from the bottom rungs of the job ladder. And Mr. Franks and Ms. Hall are helping the city become more sure-footed in providing such aid.

headline: A New York Refrain: ‘I’m Stuck in Traffic!’; The Captive Audience of the Transit Preacher; Living Room Couches Are Not Homes (5 Letters)
text: A New York Refrain:

headline: Taming the Daily Chaos of Ailments Left and Right
text: For Cheryl and Jose Carmona, daily life is a marathon of obligations. But they do not seem to mind.

headline: No Lesbian Bishop for Chicago Diocese
text: WHEELING, Ill., Nov. 10  The Rev. Tracey Lind lost her bid Saturday to be the second openly gay bishop of the Episcopal Church and the first female bishop of its Chicago diocese.

headline: Romo Angles for Stardom; Manning Ambles on His Own
text: Unlike Tony Romo, Eli Manning started out famous. Before he was chosen with the first pick of the 2004 N.F.L. draft, Manning was well known as the son of one quarterback and the brother of another. He was flung to the hot lights of New York, a premade star and a savior for the Giants, christened before his first professional snap.

headline: Kids Don’t Need Protection From Every Little Risk
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sewage Plant Trading Program Reducing Pollution
text: SINCE 2002, Connecticut has reduced the amount of nitrogen being released into the Long Island Sound by allowing its 79 sewage-treatment plants to trade pollution credits.

headline: Broken Supply Channel Sent Arms for Iraq Astray
text: This article was reported by Eric Schmitt, Ginger Thompson, Margot Williams and James Glanz, and was written by Mr. Schmitt and Ms. Thompson.

headline: Rock ’n’ Revolution
text: COUNTLESS rock bands have sung about rebellion. One of the few that can claim it spurred a revolution is the Plastic People of the Universe, who — starting with no political agenda — catalyzed democracy in Czechoslovakia.

headline: The Homintern
text: Last September in Washington, Larry Craig’s risible self-defense was still quaintly competing with his colleagues’ apparent consensus that if any mere misdemeanor could get you kicked out of the United States Senate, it would be the one he had committed in a Minneapolis airport men’s room. Going largely unobserved amid the din was a small ceremony a mile or so away, at which the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of American History unveiled the glass-encased display of two picket signs that had been carried by homosexual-rights protestors outside the White House in 1965, four years before the Stonewall riot. That these signs are now considered national treasures, worthy of exhibition a few feet from the hat that Lincoln wore to Ford’s Theater, may tell us more about the long run of historical progress than the Craig mess says about enduring denial and hypocrisy.

headline: In Kilter
text: The fashion world is having another fling with Scottish tartan, presently seen as sneakers or a vintage tam-o’-shanter. The couple above, seen in Paris last month, were slipcovered in tartan, including their luggage. The man at right is wearing a trompe l’oeil kilt that was actually a bath towel bought at a Woolworth’s in Edinburgh. He was at a Scottish dance at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York last week, where many of the guests, bottom row, were wearing tartan clothes. The same week, there was a party for the book “Tartan: Romancing the Plaid” at Saks Fifth Avenue with the authors, left, Doria de La Chapelle, seated, and Jeffrey Banks.

headline: How a Grant Travels From Foundation to Field
text: One challenge that foundations face in giving away large amounts of money is finding organizations that are equipped to handle it. The GAVI Alliance — formerly the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization — has received a commitment of $1.5 billion over 15 years from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Here is a look at how the money flows.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: THE DISCOVERY OF FRANCE: A Historical Geography From the Revolution to the First World War, by Graham Robb. (Norton, $27.95.) Robb presents France as a group of diverse regions, each with its own long history, intricate belief systems and singular customs.

headline: Best Illustrated Children's Books 2007
text: The Book Review chooses the year's 10 best illustrated children’s books.

headline: No Country
text:
The strivers, weirdos, beauties, believers and
would-be prophets from the films of the Coen Brothers.

headline: ‘How to Talk About Books You Haven’t Read’
text: Books You Don't Know

headline: ‘The Third Sex’
text: Introduction Louis Estève

headline: Musharraf Sets Elections, but Will Maintain Rule by Decree
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 11 — General Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, appeared to yield to intense American pressure on Sunday by restoring parliamentary elections in early January, but he said his emergency decree would last at least through then, immediately raising new questions about the vote’s legitimacy.

text: Wow. We’re all over the Hollywood writers’ strike today. Global warming could get an inferiority complex. No fewer than four articles, from Maureen Dowd’s late-night comedy withdrawal pangs, to intimations of the death of TV in Op-Ed, to a writer’s first-person account from the pickets …

headline: ‘The Quiet Girl’

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: Formula One: Ross Brawn, who was Ferrari’s technical director during Michael Schumacher’s spectacular run, was named team principal for Honda. After finishing second in the constructor’s championship in 2004, Honda has fallen far behind the top teams, scoring only 6 points last season. Brawn, who has never been a team principal, had also been courted by his former team. And Autosport reports that shortly after Brawn’s hire at Honda, Ferrari announced it will move to Stefano Domenical to Director of the Gestione Sportiva, a position held by Jean Todt on an interim basis.

text: JOAN TATE, tipsy after another revelatory lunch with her son, illustrates her point (early August 2000):

text: Undone by a pair of long touchdown passes from Tony Romo to Terrell Owens in the second half, the Giants fell to the Cowboys, ending their six-game winning streak.

text: Film

text: Researchers watched the brains of a group of swing voters as they responded to presidential candidates. Here are the results.

headline: The Joys of Underachievement
text: Has your get-up-and-go gotten up and gone? Say, “Hallelujah!” Sunday’s Times is rife with reasons why that’s a good thing. Why strive to be well-read (“How to Talk About Books You Haven’t Read”); well-informed (“Too Much Information? Ignore it”); or even thin? The hell with it, we say!

headline: More Heat on Ways to Lower the Thermostat
text: The latest reports from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change make clear some very inconvenient realities about the growing human influence on climate.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Youth Orchestra’s First Generation
text: They were uniformly dressed in blue jeans. Leather jackets and hoodies were draped on chair backs. Many were warming up in the auditorium. The musicians of the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela took the Carnegie Hall stage on Saturday evening to rehearse Sunday’s program: Berlioz’s “Carnaval Romain”; Chopin’s Piano Concerto No 2, with Emanuel Ax; Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony; and unnamed Latin American goodies.

headline: Blast From the Past
text: An odd event took place in Moscow on Nov. 8 and 9: A “U.S.S.R.” team played a 10-board match against a team from “Yugoslavia.” Of course, neither of these countries exists anymore, having split up after the end of the cold war. But the match was held to commemorate an annual series of “friends and rivals” matches between the two countries from the 1950’s through the 1980’s. In keeping with the spirit of the idea, the participants in the current match were players who had competed in those earlier encounters. The official Web site, which is in Russian and English, has all the games as well as pictures of the event.

headline: Berlin in Lights: And, oh Yes … She Also Sang
text: Cabaret can often be a disappointingly sedate experience. But from the moment the glamorous singer Meow Meow came rushing through the door of the Neue Galerie’s Café Sabarsky in a blur of shopping bags and spiky red heels and glittery makeup, I knew I wouldn’t have to stifle any yawns.

headline: Sunday Kickoff
text: Ohio State’s loss wasn’t only good for teams like Oregon and Kansas, it was good for the country, writes Stewart Mandel of SI.com. But John McGrath of the News-Tribune in Tacoma, Wash., isn’t exactly excited about the prospect of seeing Louisiana State in the B.C.S. title game, either.

headline: Edwards Outlines Policies in Des Moines
text: Updated | 6:10 p.m.DES MOINES – Following last night’s speech at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner, John Edwards released a booklet today summarizing his policies for caucus-goers and reinforcing many of the central issues of his campaign at a speech this morning.

headline: Live From Giants Stadium, It’s a Blog!
text: It is not often that a team asks its fans to show their support by wearing a color generally not associated with the team. But that is what the Giants have done. Since the players will wear the team’s alternative jersey, the ones that are bright red, the Giants asked fans coming to today’s game to do the same.

headline: Why, Barack, why?
text: The great Social Security debate of 2005 was a seminal moment for American progressives. Conventional fiscal wisdom in the Beltway was that the aging population is THE big problem — when the truth is that grim long-run fiscal projections mainly reflect projected health care costs. And conventional political wisdom was that the Bush administration’s fear-mongering on the issue would work.

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter, Nov. 11
text: As the presidential campaign progresses, the talk-show hosts seem to be pressing their candidate-guests a bit harder – and the candidates seem quicker to turn on one another. It all makes for good television and, let’s say it, entertaining politics, too.

headline: Bourdais finishes with another victory
text: Sébastien Bourdais is all set to test with Toro Rosso this week, complete with an eighth victory in his final race of his final year in Champ Car. That was a record number of wins for Bourdais in a single season in Champ Car, and brings his total to 31 victories in five seasons.

headline: It Depends What the Meaning of ‘Makes Sense’ Is
text: Well, it finally arrived, the long-anticipated bump in Hillary Clinton’s road to the nomination, the bump that many predicted would slow her down and give her competitors a chance to catch up.

headline: Tennessee Pulls Itself Together
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — Just when it looked like all the excitement here would be for basketball, not football (gasp!), Tennessee played another home game and its defense found its groove.

headline: A Shining Beacon
text: Retirees are gobbling up old lighthouses in the U.S., according to this article from Barron’s Online. Abandoned facilities, many on deserted islands, can be purchased for as low as $30,000 (€20,400) and there are reportedly dozens available.

headline: Reclaiming Ownership of My History
text: My dad had been serving his tour of duty in Vietnam when he’d decided to adopt. He and my mother had already had two boys and wanted a girl. In 1970, toward the last six months of his tour, he’d come across me in an orphanage and taken me home.

text: The “death of manmade global warming theory” lasted 70 minutes last week, showing the amazing power of the Web to amplify, and then dismantle, fictions at light speed.

headline: Bailing Out a Money Market Fund
text: Wachovia, it its 10-Q filed Friday, became the first money market fund sponsor that I have noticed to have to dip into its own assets to bail out its money market fund.

headline: Mississippi Statement
text: When Mississippi State defeated Alabama on Saturday, the Bulldogs became bowl eligible for the first time since 2000. After the victory, Sylvester Croom, the fourth-year Bulldogs coach, emphasized its importance.

headline: Bias in Texas?
text: After his team’s 59-43 loss Saturday at Texas, Texas Tech Coach Mike Leach blasted the game’s officials and insinuated that they favored the Longhorns.

headline: Murray’s Peterson Act
text: When the former Oklahoma tailback Adrian Peterson finished as the runner-up in the Heisman Trophy voting three years ago, the Sooners freshman records he set then seemed unlikely to be challenged anytime soon.

headline: Sunday Talking Points
text: There have been plenty of marquee games this season, but for my money, Week 10 figured to be the most exciting week of the season so far. Rematches and rivalries and divisional battles abound. And I am not afraid to admit that almost nothing went the way I thought it would today. Now that the 1 p.m. 4 p.m. all the games are over, here are a few things to discuss:

headline: Chinese Novel Wins Prize
text: A Chinese novelist has won the inaugural Man Asian Literary Prize. The author, Jiang Rong, 61, beat four other Asian writers on the short list to capture the $10,000 award established to honor the region’s best literature that has yet to be published in English. Mr. Jiang’s book, “Wolf Totem,” above, first published in Chinese, draws on the author’s personal experience in the Mongolian grasslands to depict life among the rural poor during the Cultural Revolution of 1966 to ’76. Adrienne Clarkson, a former governor general of Canada who was chairwoman of the panel of three judges, said, “This masterly work is also a passionate argument about the complex interrelationship between nomads and settlers, animals and human beings, nature and culture.” “Wolf Totem” is to be published in English by Penguin next year. Its translator, Howard Goldblatt, received a prize of $3,000. Because of ill health Mr. Jiang, from Beijing, was unable to travel to Hong Kong to accept his prize.

headline: My Network, My Cause
text: IN 2003, as Howard Dean’s presidential bid surged, the Internet was hailed as a decisive new factor in electoral politics. In 2007, the explosive growth of online social networks seems poised to drive a similar upheaval in the world of philanthropy.

headline: Not From Here: An Opera for Houston’s Immigrants
text: HOUSTON, Nov. 11 — With brickbats flying over border issues, the Houston Grand Opera put immigration center stage this weekend in a dramatic outreach to the more than 1 million foreign-born residents here in the nation’s fourth largest city.

headline: First One Orphan, Then Many More
text: THE United States has plenty of affluent do-gooders who are taken with the idea that with their experience and creativity they could harness expertise and money to better the lives of people in the developing world.

headline: A Big Salary With a Big Stipulation: Share It
text: LATE last year, a Bear Stearns employee panicked: had she donated enough money?

headline: For a Memorial With Cracks, Fix or Replace?
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 — The fate of the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery is uncertain this Veterans Day weekend, as the Army has yet to decide whether to replace or repair the 75-year-old monument, which is marred by several large cracks.

headline: Screenwriters Seek Bigger Slice of Half-Eaten Pie
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 — As Hollywood digs in for a second week of a strike, the screenwriters might want to send a few angry picketers over to Will Smith’s place. Or Steven Spielberg’s.

headline: ‘Bee’ Bumps ‘Gangster’
text: In the second weekend of combat between two of the season’s most heavily promoted films, the DreamWorks Animation “Bee Movie” (distributed by Paramount) ousted “American Gangster” (Universal) from the No. 1 spot at North American box offices. “Bee Movie,” with the voices of Jerry Seinfeld (for Barry B. Benson, right) and Renée Zellweger, took in $26 million, while “American Gangster,” starring Denzel Washington as a drug lord and Russell Crowe as his law enforcement nemesis, grossed $24.3 million, according to estimates from the tracking company Media by Numbers. “We don’t often see a movie start out in the No. 2 position then move up to No. 1,” Paul Dergarabedian, the president of Media by Numbers, told The Associated Press. “It just shows how strong the word of mouth is on this movie and that families are really enjoying it.” Third and fourth places went to two newcomers. “Fred Claus” (Warner Brothers), the comedy starring Vince Vaughn as the disgruntled elder brother of Santa Claus (Paul Giamatti), took in $19.2 million. Robert Redford’s current-affairs drama, “Lions for Lambs” (MGM), with Tom Cruise and Meryl Streep, gathered $6.7 million. Finishing fifth was the comedy “Dan in Real Life” (Disney), with $5.8 million in its third week. The weekend’s top per-screen average went to Joel and Ethan Coen’s latter-day western, “No Country for Old Men” (Miramax), with Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem and Josh Brolin, which took in $42,929 per screen at 28 theaters, compared with $7,950 for “American Gangster” at 3,059 theaters.

headline: The Real Margo Channing’s Fasten-Your-Seatbelts Life
text: The legendary film star Bette Davis was what might charitably be called “a real piece of work.” According to Ed Sikov, author of “Dark Victory: The Life of Bette Davis,” many who knew her often put it more bluntly. Barbara Stanwyck, no slouch herself in the legends category, described Davis’s “creative ruthlessness,” and her co-star Brian Aherne said “nobody but a mother” could have loved her.

headline: To Tax or Not to Tax Nonprofits? Cities Ask the Billion-Dollar Question
text: DESPITE a long tradition of waiving taxes for charitable nonprofit groups, communities are feeling more pressure to eliminate property-tax exemptions.

headline: D-League Team Could Bring Rens Back to Harlem
text: Commissioner David Stern wants to put an N.B.A. Development League team in Harlem, U.S.A. The idea was jolting at first. Now it’s intriguing.

headline: In the Fund-Raising Game, Blogs Cut Both Ways
text: IN the world of animal rights’ charities, a certain phrase has been fund-raising gold lately — “Michael Vick’s dogs.”

headline: Sharp Sell-Off Sweeps Asian Markets
text: TOKYO, Nov. 12 — Rising fears of a slowdown in the United States economy sparked a sharp sell-off in Asian stock markets today, driving a leading Japanese index to a two-year low.

headline: Whatever the Challenge, Shy Is Not as Shy Does
text: Petite, baby-faced and outwardly diffident, the young French pianist Lise de la Salle presents a shy eye to her audience, but one that turns fierce when the music starts. Her recital at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday, indifferently attended, was a split-screen advertisement for an impressive talent.

headline: Seeking More Aid, Gulf Coast Looks to Foundations
text: AFTER Hurricane Katrina wrecked the Gulf Coast, Kathy Laborde started a nonprofit group in New Orleans to build inexpensive replacement housing. She has one block of apartments nearly finished and a dozen other projects ready to start.

headline: Borders Adds TV Watching to Its Bookstores’ Entertainment
text: Borders bookstores — with their cafes, toys and games and large displays of movies and music — have never exactly been confused with, say, university libraries.

headline: Greeks Save Ship With 275 Migrants
text: ATHENS, Nov. 11 — The Greek coast guard on Sunday rescued 275 people believed to be illegal migrants crammed on a Turkish cargo ship that nearly capsized in rough seas southwest of the Greek coast, a Greek coast guard spokeswoman said.

headline: Musharraf Sets No Date to End Emergency Rule
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 11 — Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, appeared to yield to intense American pressure on Sunday by restoring parliamentary elections in early January, but he said his emergency decree would last at least through then, immediately raising new questions about the vote’s legitimacy.

headline: A Museum Rises, but Not the Usual Way
text: PEOPLE in Denver like to say that while New York may be an experiment that is over, their town is one in the making. That’s the sort of spirit that moved Karl Kister, a philanthropist and entrepreneur, to become involved with the Museum of Contemporary Art/Denver.

headline: A New York Honor, Centuries Old and Gold-Plated
text: Keep your eye out. Fats Domino could show up anywhere in New York at any moment. He now has the “freedom of the city.” And an official, five-and-three-quarters-inch-long gold-plated pewter key to prove it.

headline: Study: Foreign Students Added to Economy
text: While foreign students at American colleges and universities are most often singled out for their scientific and cultural contributions, their growing numbers help make them an increasingly important economic force as well, according to a new report from the Institute of International Education.

headline: Beyond the Gift of Cold, Hard Cash
text: AMONG the items that Tom Bird gave to charity last year was what he considered a “lingering asset” on his personal balance sheet: the domain name, farm.com, which he retained when he and his business partner sold their Silicon Valley record storage company, First American Record Management (FARM) in 1999.

headline: Some Japanese Tonal Colors for Tales Dressed in Kimonos
text: Opera is supposedly a grand form, yet many people devoted enough to present it can realize their passion only on a small scale. New York is rife with small opera companies, ranging from highly professional troupes offering lesser-known works to groups that function essentially as community theater.

text: Sabrina Conney twisted her hand into a C chord and smiled toward the polished surface of her guitar.

headline: Iraq Premier Sees Families Returning to Safer Capital
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 11 — The Iraqi prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, said in a news conference on Sunday that increased security in Baghdad had allowed thousands of families to return to their homes in the capital and outlying areas.

headline: Clarity Lacking in Discipline for Hits to Head
text: On the same day the N.F.L. instructed its officials to eject players who delivered flagrant helmet-to-helmet hits, three high-profile college football players sustained injuries from vicious hits involving the helmet. None of the plays drew penalties.

headline: Absinthe Returns in a Glass Half Full of Mystique and Misery
text: Dear reader! Should this column impress you as being more than usually lyrical, recalling perhaps the imagery and elegance of poetry by Baudelaire or Verlaine; should it seem a bit decadent, redolent of Oscar Wilde’s withering hauteur; should it have a touch of madness or perversity, combining, say, the tastes of Toulouse-Lautrec with the passions of van Gogh; should it simply sound direct and forceful and knowing like one of Ernest Hemingway’s characters; should it do any or all of that, let me credit something that each of these figures fervently paid tribute to: the green fairy, the green goddess, the green muse, the glaucous witch, the queen of poisons.

headline: European Tabloids Still Agog Months After Child Vanishes
text: LONDON, Nov. 8 — “Gerry McCann Back at Work,” the tabloid Evening Standard screamed out to London commuters on a recent afternoon.

headline: Restoring Confidence in the Balloting Process
text: Since the election fiasco in Florida in 2000, how much progress have the states made in overhauling their election systems?

headline: Life After Wartime
text: MY mother, who is 88, told me last month that it had been a long time since she’d seen Paul Tibbets in the Bob Evans restaurant on the east side of Columbus, Ohio. She thought this was odd; she ate lunch there so often, and he ate lunch there so often, that his absence worried her.

headline: Profile Rises at School Where Going Against the Grain Is the Norm
text: GREAT NECK, N.Y. — A high school social studies class was studying the federal government’s response to Hurricane Katrina on a recent afternoon, without any readings, lessons or even desks. Only one student was taking notes.

headline: Clinton Aides Prompted Queries at Events
text: At two campaign events in Iowa this year, aides to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton encouraged audience members to ask her specific questions, a tactic that drew criticism from an opponent for the Democratic presidential nomination and led her yesterday to promise that it would not happen again.

headline: Cellphone Straitjacket Is Inspiring a Rebellion
text: First come the grumblings, then the torches and pitchforks.

headline: Attention Shoppers: Philanthropy in Aisle 5
text: THE lime-green box of chocolate truffles looks like yet another elegant designer package. Round cut-outs reveal rows of confections intricately decorated with everything from a striped candy cane to a snowman donning a bright blue top hat.

headline: A Heart Stent Gets a Reprieve From Doctors
text: A year after safety questions about drug-coated heart stents prompted doctors to change treatment for hundreds of thousands of cardiac patients, many physicians say the medical community overreacted and should now reverse course.

headline: All They Are Saying Is Give Happiness a Chance
text: The framers of the Declaration of Independence evidently believed that happiness could be achieved, putting its pursuit up there alongside the unalienable rights to life and liberty. Though governments since then have seen life and liberty as deserving of vigorous protection, for all the public policies aimed at increasing economic growth, people have been left to sort out their happiness.

headline: Outrage, Bile, Hardcore Punk ... and a Sensible Lost-and-Found
text: “This next song is about the people who want to control our bodies,” said the singer known as Pink Eyes, adding, “This next song is about the police.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Day 2 of Stagehands’ Strike, and a Chill Sets In
text: Just after what would have been curtain time on Saturday night, Day 1 of the stagehands’ strike on Broadway, things seemed, if not normal, at least bearable. Some theater-district restaurants lost business, but others were buzzing with people who simply turned their pre-theater reservations into 8 p.m. dinners. Chorus folks hit the bars for a rare Saturday night off. There was even some singing in the streets.

headline: Giving Away Money, Getting an Education
text: Natick, Mass.

headline: SquarePants RoundTrip: SpongeBob’s Yearlong Ride to Atlantis, via Korea

headline: Bring the Real World Home
text: In the gym at the NATO base in Kabul, U.S. soldiers hit the treadmills every morning and gaze at TV screens broadcasting Al Jazeera’s English news channel. When Osama bin Laden makes news, as he did recently with a statement about Iraq, America’s finest work out beneath the solemn gaze of their most wanted enemy.

headline: Giving Goes Global: Three Stories
text: IN the upper stratum of wealth, people are increasingly taking a global view, devoting considerable effort and money to help victims of poverty, war and natural disasters and work for causes like social justice, the environment and peace.
