text: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Envoy in Myanmar to Try to Tally Dead
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 11  A United Nations envoy arrived in Myanmar on Sunday to begin the first independent investigation into the military government’s crackdown in September on protests led by Buddhist monks and students.

headline: Supreme Court May Take Gun Case
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 — Both sides in a closely watched legal battle over the District of Columbia’s strict gun-control law are urging the Supreme Court to hear the case. If the justices agree — a step they may announce as early as Tuesday — the Roberts court is likely to find itself back on the front lines of the culture wars with an intensity unmatched even by the cases on abortion and race that defined the court’s last term.

headline: Dollar Policy: Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell
text: When asked about the administration’s policy on the dollar, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson Jr. dutifully says a strong dollar is in the nation’s interest and that markets should determine currency exchange rates.

headline: Music for Use: Dance, Sing Along or Examine It Closely
text: It must be odd for those outside Western European culture to find their music presented on brightly lighted stages in front of listeners sitting quietly in the dark. Friday night at Zankel Hall, the Nevzat Akpinar Ensemble — eight musicians performing folk and ritual music of Turks and Kurds — wrestled good-naturedly with a printed program seemingly created to be undermined.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart in Business Day last Monday with an article about collateralized debt obligations, a complex investment instrument backed by assets like mortgages, described incorectly a ranking of investment banks. The ranking was of top book runners of collateralized debt obligations, not issuers. (Book runners manage the offerings of new securities.) (Go to Article)

headline: Play That Funky Spinning Bike Wheel, Berlin Boy
text: As anyone who frequents New York’s downtown lofts and Brooklyn’s nightclubs can attest, cutting-edge music flourishes where rents are relatively low and patrons are unburdened by the rigorous customs of conventional concert life. The model works just as well in Berlin, as the KNM Berlin, an 11-member ensemble founded in the late 1980s by students from the Hanns Eisler College of Music there, proves.

headline: Opening Loss Is More Bad News for Rutgers
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 11 — With the Don Imus imbroglio and a defeat in last season’s national championship game behind it, Rutgers was hoping to begin a new chapter and a new season on a positive note Sunday night. Instead, the Scarlet Knights were left to deal with a different kind of painful experience: a last-second loss.

headline: Sale of Wendy’s May Be Delayed
text: The auction of Wendy’s International may be in jeopardy because of continued turmoil in the credit markets, potentially forcing the company to delay its sale, people close to the situation said yesterday.

headline: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?
text: Only a couple of years ago, Firefox was the little browser that could — an open-source program created by thousands of contributors around the world without the benefit of a giant company like Microsoft to finance it.

headline: Footnotes
text: Bon Jovi will headline the 2007 Royal Variety Performance gala next month, with Queen Elizabeth II in the audience at the Empire Theater in Liverpool, Agence France-Presse reported. By royal command, other performers will include Kiri Te Kanawa, Enrique Iglesias, James Blunt and Katherine Jenkins. The performance benefits the Entertainment Artistes’ Benevolent Fund. The queen is a patron. ... Beijing will ring in the New Year with New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day performances at its new National Center for the Performing Arts. The event will feature the China National Symphony Orchestra, led by the Japanese conductor Seiji Ozawa, the Chinese pianist Lang Lang, the Russian violinist Vadim Repin and the American soprano Kathleen Battle. ... American Ballet Theater has changed the name of the ABT Studio Company. This small classical company of 13 young dancers of high potential will now be called ABT II, Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of American Ballet Theater, announced. Wes Chapman, artistic director of ABT II, said the idea was to improve the troupe’s visibility to the public. ... A new song by the composer and cabaret singing star Michael Feinstein will open the 81st annual Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade on Nov. 22. The number, “Making Magic,” choreographed by John Dietrich of the Radio City Rockettes and featuring lyrics by Bill Schermerhorn, the parade’s creative director, was written for 600 dancing children trained by Camp Broadway, which offers summer programs taught by theater professionals.

headline: Beware, Conniving Count, This Rugged Figaro Will Have You Dancing to His Tune
text: Cast changes are inevitable during the run of a production at a repertory opera company. But when Jonathan Miller’s staging of Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro” returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon after a break of more than three weeks, the company fielded an entirely different cast from the one introduced in early October.

headline: Israeli Police Raid Offices for Evidence on Olmert
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 11 — About 100 police investigators from Israel’s National Fraud Unit conducted unannounced searches in more than 20 locations around the country on Sunday, seeking materials connected with criminal investigations under way against Prime Minister Ehud Olmert.

headline: With Health Costs Rising, a Tougher Sell for Hospitals
text: AFTER charging tens of thousands of dollars for a knee replacement, the hospital wants a donation?

headline: Film Festival in Baghdad
text: An international film festival is planned for Baghdad next month, an Iraqi director told Agence France-Presse yesterday. The filmmaker,  Abdul Basit Salman, who now lives in Cairo, said the festival, presented by the Association of Iraqi Filmmakers Without Borders Dec. 16 to 19 at a site to be decided, would consist mainly of submissions from Egypt, Jordan and Iran. If the event goes off as planned, it will be the first major cinematic event in Baghdad since a popular festival of short films was held in 2005 in the Al-Mansour Hotel, which this June was the target of a suicide bomber who killed 12 people. Only a few movie theaters in Baghdad still keep their doors open.

headline: Redirecting Heartache Into Donor Funds
text: AFTER nine operations for cancer, what Leslie Ries wanted most was to help other people facing treatment by directing money to groups that provide services that large charities do not address.

headline: For U.S. Exporters in Cuba, Business Trumps Politics
text: HAVANA, Nov. 11 — A trade fair in Communist Cuba is perhaps the last place you would expect to find a Republican governor from the American heartland. Yet last week, Gov. Dave Heineman of Nebraska was here to sign a deal to export $11 million worth of his state’s wheat to the island.

headline: Ray S. Smith, Arkansas Lawmaker, Dies at 83
text: Ray S. Smith, a former Arkansas legislator who during the turmoil after the integration of Central High School in Little Rock in 1957 cast the only vote against a bill giving Gov. Orval E. Faubus the power to close public schools, died on Nov. 1. He was 83.

headline: A Canyon Refuge for Animals in Need of Some T.L.C.
text: BECAUSE the pink dunes and sandstone walls of Angel Canyon in southern Utah served as a backdrop for 1950s Westerns, the area had been known as Little Hollywood. Today, Angel Canyon serves a less glamorous if more heartfelt role, as a sanctuary for the thousands of animals that the Best Friends Animal Society saves each year.

headline: Congregation Writes Torah, With Help From a Scribe
text: Thousands of years old though it may be, the Torah began anew on a recent Sunday with Helen Margalith, 92 years old. She faced the congregation, then stared at the seeming immensity of a blank white sheet of unblemished parchment. A sofer, or scribe, sat by her side, holding a feather quill. She tentatively grasped it an inch above his hand.

headline: Over There — and Gone Forever
text: BY any conceivable measure, Frank Buckles has led an extraordinary life. Born on a farm in Missouri in February 1901, he saw his first automobile in his hometown in 1905, and his first airplane at the Illinois State Fair in 1907. At 15 he moved on his own to Oklahoma and went to work in a bank; in the 1940s, he spent more than three years as a Japanese prisoner of war. When he returned to the United States, he married, had a daughter and bought a farm near Charles Town, W. Va., where he lives to this day. He drove a tractor until he was 104.

headline: Editor of More Replaces One at Reader’s Digest
text: The domestic edition of Reader’s Digest has replaced its editor in chief, Jacqueline Leo, hiring Peggy Northrop away from the Meredith Corporation’s More magazine, the magazine announced Friday.

headline: Virtual Lures for Holiday Shoppers
text: ONLINE retailers take solace in knowing that no matter how painful it may be to click around endlessly searching for products, it still often beats the mall.

headline: An Evening’s Serenade Harks Back to Summer
text: One advantage chamber musicians often have over orchestral players is the luxury of ample rehearsal time. At the annual Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont, run by the esteemed pianists Richard Goode and Mitsuko Uchida, veteran and emerging artists collaborate on substantive study and performances of the chamber music repertory. Some of those musicians then tour with works prepared during the summer.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Bee’ Bumps ‘Gangster’

headline: For Ousted Citigroup Chief, a Bonus of $12.5 Million
text: This year, thousands of Citigroup employees can expect bonuses based on their work in 2007, when the bank’s results have been less than stellar. One, however, will get a bonus based largely on his performance in 2006, which was a better year: Charles O. Prince III, who resigned under pressure as chairman and chief executive last week.

headline: 3 Dead in Storm That Caused Oil Spill
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 — A fierce storm in the Black Sea sank at least five ships on Sunday, killing at least three sailors and causing a massive oil spill that could lead to severe environmental damage, officials said. About 20 sailors were missing.

headline: Italy’s Best Battle It Out for Club Title
text: The 96-board final of the Italian Club Championship, which ended Oct. 28, brought together that country’s top four pairs. Representing Torino-Allegra were regulars on the Italian team, Norberto Bocchi and Giorgio Duboin, playing with Agustin Madala and Antonio Sementa. The other team, Tennis Club Parioli, included Italy’s other two world champion pairs, Fulvio Fantoni-Claudio Nunes and Lorenzo Lauria-Alfredo Versace. Francesco Angelini played the first and fourth sessions with Versace.

headline: Westchester Post for Itzhak Perlman
text: Itzhak Perlman has been appointed artistic director of the Westchester Philharmonic, beginning with the 2008-9 season. He is to conduct the orchestra at three of its five programs for three seasons, beginning on Oct. 11, 2008. He will succeed Paul Lustig Dunkel, who helped found the Westchester Philharmonic 25 years ago and has since been its music director and conductor. Mr. Dunkel announced last year that he would step down in May 2008.

headline: The Plight of American Veterans
text: As an unpopular, ill-planned war in Iraq grinds on inconclusively, it can be a bleak time to be a veteran.

headline: Some Wonder if the Banks’ Stabilization Fund Will Work
text: When the country’s three largest banks reached agreement on Friday on how to structure a $75 billion fund to prop up distressed securities, an exhausted group of its top planners gathered in a Bank of America conference room to toast their success with 12-packs of Bud Light.

headline: Queens: Man Killed in Three-Car Crash
text: A 66-year-old man was killed late Saturday night when the car he was driving was struck by an out-of-control Honda Accord, the police said. The driver of the Accord, Christopher Rivera, 25, of Howard Beach, was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter. The collision occurred shortly after 10:45 p.m. on Woodhaven Boulevard near 101st Avenue in Woodhaven, when Mr. Rivera’s car crossed the median into northbound traffic, striking the victim’s 1999 Nissan Maxima, the police said. The Maxima then struck a third vehicle, a 2006 BMW. The driver of the Maxima, whose name was not released yesterday, was pronounced dead at the scene. His passenger, a 60-year-old woman, was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. Mr. Rivera and his passenger were also in stable condition, as were the two occupants of the BMW, the police said.

headline: Again and Again in the Balkans
text: The Balkans have a dismal way of living up to their stereotype as a region of ancient, intertwined and irreconcilable feuds. This month was supposed to be the one in which the Kosovo issue was finally put to rest. Now, with Russia’s active meddling, not only does that look unlikely, but the Serbs are threatening to stir new troubles in Bosnia if Kosovo declares independence. This is a time for urgent, creative diplomacy by the major powers.

headline: Giants Saddle Up but Don’t Measure Up
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 11 — For six consecutive games, all of them victories, the Giants set out to prove that the start of their season was an aberration. Yet all those Sundays removed from a humiliating opening-day defeat to the Cowboys in Texas, the Giants squandered a second chance to make a strong impression and recast themselves as true title contenders.

headline: With Ponies, Unicorns and Secret Codes, an Effort to Unleash a Craze for Girls
text: He has already introduced America to a boy-oriented trading card game (Magic: The Gathering) and one with unisex appeal (Pokémon). Now, Peter D. Adkison is hoping to find new success with a line of collectible cards aimed at girls.

headline: Brooklyn: Woman Charged in Fatal Stabbing
text: A Brooklyn woman was arrested yesterday on accusations that she fatally stabbed a man during a domestic dispute on Saturday evening, the police said. The woman, Shenequa DeFreitas, 27, of Ocean Avenue, was charged with manslaughter, the police said. Ms. DeFreitas stabbed the man, Thomas Adonis, 25, of East 57th Street, in the torso during a dispute in her home about 6:20 p.m., the police said. Mr. Adonis was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead.

headline: Cowboys Serve Big Helping of Reality
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Browns Show Life, but Steelers Survive
text: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11  The Browns are improving but are not good enough to beat the Steelers  not yet. Pittsburgh proved that Sunday by coming from behind twice for a 31-28 victory in a battle for first place in the American Football Conference North.

headline: Win Fabulous Prizes, All in the Name of Innovation
text: THE quests are monumental: end global warming; build a private spaceship; cure diseases; develop a car that can go 100 miles on a gallon of gas.

headline: California Zeros in on the Intractable
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Imagine There’s No Heaven, Just Flamenco
text: At the core of flamenco is the notion of duende: those dark forces contesting within the artist’s soul, forcing their way out through the dance to evoke the battle with life, with death, with the birth of art itself.

headline: A Place to Leave the Wars Behind
text: AS a Vietnam veteran, Michael Howk likes nothing better than fielding questions from newcomers to Stand Down House, a residential program in Lake Worth, Fla., that helps homeless male veterans who are battling mental health and substance abuse problems.

headline: Living Paycheck to Paycheck Was Already a Way of Life
text: Bradford Winters, a screenwriter who lives and works in New York, came home very animated after walking the picket line last Monday, the first day of the Writers Guild of America’s strike against the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers.

headline: Making a Difference From an Early Age
text: TEACHING by example remains the best way for parents to inspire charitable values, but experts — and some former children — say there are other methods to help young people develop the habit of giving, even in families of modest means.

headline: Without Randolph, Knicks Collapse at the End
text: Stephon Marbury heard boos last night, not for anything that happened during his curious, sometimes scandalous off-season, but for everything that happened in the final seconds of a tight game against the Miami Heat.

headline: For Chinese-Americans, Schools Earn the Prize
text: LAST February, Jerry Yang and his wife, Akiko Yamazaki, pledged $75 million to Stanford University for a variety of programs. Two-thirds of their gift will go to build a new environment and energy site. The balance will go to the medical school.

headline: Heavy Storm Splits Tanker, Spilling Oil Off Russia
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 11 — A fierce storm in the Black Sea split a small tanker on Sunday, causing an oil spill that could lead to significant environmental damage, officials said.

headline: Striking Writers Peddle Words, for Outlets Off the Picket Line
text: Sometimes it seems that every time the striking television and movie writers put down their picket signs, they pick up their pencils.

headline: I.R.S. Moves to Weed Out Deadwood Charities
text: DONORS should get a much clearer picture of how secular charities handle their money, and which charities are legitimate, thanks to new rules imposed by Congress.

headline: With Theaters Dark, Finding Their Fun Elsewhere
text: Broadway has gone dark, but a family’s vacation must go on.

headline: A Young Orchestra Led by a Youthful Major Player
text: When Gustavo Dudamel walked on the stage at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to conduct the first of two programs with the Simón Bolívar Youth Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela, it looked for a moment as if his much-touted unflappability were going to desert him. With his unkempt mane of curly hair and slight build, he looked a little ashen-faced and shy.

headline: Veterans Day: Parking
text: Because of Veterans Day, which is observed today, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Decoding the Markets 101, for the Soon-to-Retire
text: IT has famous Wall Street parents and an alphabet-soup abbreviation known only to investment professionals. Now Finra, the new private regulator for securities firms, mutual fund houses and stockbrokers, has a bold plan: to be a best friend to America’s ordinary investors.

headline: Back-Office Support for Busy Microfinanciers
text: THE microfinance industry — bankers to the poor — faces a paradox of scale, growing large in some ways but remaining small in others.

headline: A Not-So-Simple Plan to Keep African Girls in School
text: THEY call it the Map of Africa.

headline: When Reagan Spoke of States’ Rights
text: To the Editor:

headline: More Than Cinema: A Campaign to End Child Sex
text: THE movie “Holly” has a pedigree that any independent filmmaker would envy: a critically acclaimed run through the international festival circuit, a recognizable but not-yet-famous actor from “Sex and the City,” a red-carpet screening at the United Nations with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on the host committee.

headline: Security Guard Fires From Convoy, Killing Iraqi Driver
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 11 — An Iraqi taxi driver was shot and killed on Saturday by a guard with DynCorp International, a private security company hired to protect American diplomats here, when a DynCorp convoy rolled past a knot of traffic on an exit ramp in Baghdad, the Iraqi Interior Ministry said Sunday.

headline: Pigs Fly! Philadelphia Papers’ Circulation Holds
text: Newspapers in Philadelphia have chosen the image of airborne pigs to illustrate their unlikely achievement: circulation holding steady at a time when the industry’s is dropping.

headline: Forging Ahead With Life’s Tests, One Day at a Time
text: San Francisco

headline: Fighting a Disease of Logistics, He Means Business
text: WHEN Lance Laifer, a hedge fund manager in New Jersey and former Internet entrepreneur, started researching malaria two and a half years ago, a prominent professor with a medical background told him that doctors were not drawn to malaria research because it was a disease of logistics. “Doctors don’t do logistics,” Mr. Laifer recalls that he said. “Business does logistics.”

headline: Contemplating the Meaning of ‘Life’
text: In 1977, when Gerald L. Hessell was sentenced to life in prison for second-degree murder, a gallon of gas cost 62 cents and a life term in Michigan meant about 15 years.

headline: A Cookbook of One’s Own From the Internet
text: As a founder of the online photography service Ofoto, Kamran Mohsenin took note of the pleasure and pride his customers derived from making personalized calendars and books. “The perceived value and the sense of accomplishment in creating your own photo book was high,” he said.

headline: A Weekend of Skirmishing for Obama and Clinton
text: DES MOINES, Nov. 11  Senator Barack Obama kept on the attack against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, accusing her of running a “poll-driven campaign” that avoided tough questions. He said on Sunday that he would increase the amount of income subject to Social Security taxes.

headline: A Family Legacy, Built to Withstand Dynamite
text: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 11 — With less than 48 hours until one of this city’s favorite but rarest of spectacles, the principal players stood around a long table on Sunday morning readying their props and showing no traces of stage fright.

headline: The Young and the Restless Try, Too
text: IN many ways, 27-year-old Jonathan Holmes is the picture-perfect next-generation philanthropist. In 2004, he was teaching art at a Maryland boarding school — “because I wanted to affect the greater good,” he said — when his aunt asked him to return to New Jersey and inject new life into a limping family foundation. He agreed, on the condition that she allow him to find a mission “based on what I felt was really needed in these communities.”

headline: The Day’s Best
text: Brett Favre passed for 351 yards and 3 touchdowns as the Packers improved to 8-1 by beating the Vikings, 34-0. Favre is 1,105 yards from breaking Dan Marino’s N.F.L. career record.

headline: Taking It Game by Game Minus Wade, the Heat Looks at Itself as 1-0
text: A Miami Heat losing streak that stretched back to April came to an abrupt halt last night against the Knicks in a defensive struggle at Madison Square Garden.

headline: A New Channel for Soft Money Appears in Race
text: The so-called Wounded Warriors Act, legislation intended to improve health care for veterans, has attracted nearly unanimous, bipartisan support in Congress. So why would the newly formed Foundation for a Secure and Prosperous America begin running a television commercial urging the citizens of South Carolina to tell Congress to pass it?

headline: A Spy’s Path: Iowa to A-Bomb to Kremlin Honor
text: He had all-American cover: born in Iowa, college in Manhattan, Army buddies with whom he played baseball.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Grants for Gay Services Grow and Go Mainstream
text: IT’S not easy being a teenager and gay in a deeply conservative community like Colorado Springs. This is the headquarters of many Christian groups that strongly disapprove of homosexuality, including Focus on the Family.

headline: Google Options Make Masseuse a Multimillionaire
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 — Bonnie Brown was fresh from a nasty divorce in 1999, living with her sister and uncertain of her future. On a lark, she answered an ad for an in-house masseuse at Google, then a Silicon Valley start-up with 40 employees. She was offered the part-time job, which started out at $450 a week but included a pile of Google stock options that she figured might never be worth a penny.

headline: Intel to Unveil Chips for Improving Video Quality on the Web
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 — Intel plans to announce a family of microprocessor chips on Monday that it says will speed the availability of high-definition video via the Internet.

headline: A Stark Reminder of War, 25 Years On
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 — Throngs of veterans gathered on Sunday under a clear sky on the Mall to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, a stark symbol of a war that bitterly divided the nation.

headline: With Sudden Wealth, the Desire for Sudden Impact
text: SILICON VALLEY is percolating again, with venture capital flowing, Google’s stock in the stratosphere and companies like Facebook valued in the billions. And in increasing numbers, the rich are cultivating a sense of noblesse oblige.

headline: They Channel Intentions to the Right Places
text: BILL DONNELL is a philanthropist with many charitable interests, among them gay and lesbian rights, the environment, the arts and, above all, the well-being of the city where he lives. “Ultimately,” he said, “it’s New York City I would like to benefit. I have a genuine love for it.”

headline: Treasury Auction Set for This Week
text: This week, the Treasury has an auction of four-week bills scheduled on Wednesday.

headline: Dogged Cotto Surprised Everyone but Himself
text: Miguel Cotto did some uncharacteristic ducking and dancing in the ring at Madison Square Garden against Shane Mosley on Saturday night. He used an effective jab, which was as surprising as his speed.

headline: Romo Solves a Defensive Puzzle
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 11  The T-shirt that Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo had worn under his jersey was so threadbare that it looked as if it would shred if a defensive tackle even glanced at him. But nine games into the season, the shirt is still intact, and so is the Cowboys’ control of the N.F.C., saved by Romo’s improvisational skills that assured that the Giants got an eyeful of him, but not much more.

headline: Helping Time Warner Give Away Some of Its Millions
text: THOSE who saw this year’s Fall for Dance Festival at New York City Center or the August Wilson series at Signature Theater in New York in 2004 might have noticed Time Warner’s name on posters or in programs. But they probably had no idea how Time Warner came to support such events. A large company with a philanthropic arm must review hundreds of requests for help.

headline: A Windfall Illuminates the Poetry Field, and Its Fights
text: IN November 2002, news of a $100 million grant from the pharmaceutical company heiress Ruth Lilly to the Modern Poetry Association, publisher of Poetry magazine, electrified the arts and philanthropic communities.

headline: How Long Should Gifts Just Grow?
text: AS nonprofit institutions have seen donations and investments grow spectacularly in recent years, the urge to keep the money rolling in is being supplemented by a new pressure: make it flow out faster.

headline: Tut’s Tomb to Close
text: Egypt plans to limit the number of visitors to King Tut’s tomb and to close it to visitors indefinitely next year to carry out restoration, Agence France-Presse reported. In a statement yesterday Zahi Hawass, secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities, said the number of daily visitors would be restricted to 400 beginning next month, and restoration work on the tomb, discovered in 1922 in the Valley of the Kings, would begin in May.

headline: Gilberto Gil to Resign
text: The Grammy Award-winning singer, composer and guitarist Gilberto Gil, above, plans to resign his post as Brazil’s culture minister next year to treat a polyp on his vocal cords, The Associated Press reported. Citing local news media, the agency said Mr. Gil, 65, had not set a date for his resignation. Since his surprise appointment as culture minister in 2003 he has divided his time between politics and music. He said that at a performance in July, he realized he had a recurring vocal problem. “For the first time in many years I had to make a tour under pressure of losing my voice,” he said. “That really tormented me.” Mr. Gil and his friend Caetano Veloso are credited with founding the Tropicalism movement, a blend of rock and bossa nova that influenced David Byrne, Paul Simon and Beck. The political content of its lyrics offended Brazil’s military dictatorship. Mr. Gil and Mr. Veloso were jailed in 1968 and lived in London from 1969 to 1972.

headline: Two-Wheeled Neglect
text: To the Editor:

headline: Posada Likely to Return to Yankees
text: Jorge Posada acknowledged last night that he was likely to return to the Yankees next season.

headline: City Power Wins Title in Shootout
text: The Martin Luther King Jr. High School boys soccer team defeated Francis Lewis in a penalty-kick shootout yesterday to win the Public Schools Athletic League championship at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island.

headline: Jaguars Bulldoze Titans’ Ground Defense
text: NASHVILLE, Nov. 11  On game days, Jacksonville tailback Fred Taylor showers in the dark so he does not have to close his eyes to visualize a great performance. He sits down in front of his locker and studies a montage of his highlight runs on his iPod, the better to put himself in the right frame of mind to add to the compilation.

headline: Monday’s Matchup
text: A changing of the guard was predicted in the N.F.C. West. But San Francisco and Arizona have not put up much of a fight, even though Seattle, the three-time defending champion, has left the door wide open. With Shaun Alexander injured and ineffective, Seahawks Coach Mike Holmgren has renewed focus on the passing game, which is ranked 10th in the league. The 49ers, losers of six in a row, wish they had only one facet of their 32nd-ranked offense to be concerned about. The Seahawks, who won in San Francisco in Week 4, are hungry for payback after a season sweep by the 49ers last year. San Francisco Coach Mike Nolan’s father, Dick Nolan, a former Giants player and 49ers coach, died yesterday, but Mike Nolan is expected to be with his team tonight. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

headline: Mystique Follows Messier Wherever He Goes
text: Three years after he last played and 13 since his transcendent moment as a Ranger, Mark Messier can still light up Madison Square Garden with only one smile.

headline: The Film Was Fine, Now That It’s Over
text: A study in The Journal of Consumer Research explores people’s faulty memories of how much they liked an experience, showing that they look for cues in their own subsequent behavior.

headline: Child Studies May Ease Fears on Misbehavior
text: Educators and psychologists have long feared that children entering school with behavior problems were doomed to fall behind in the upper grades. But two new studies suggest that those fears are exaggerated.

headline: Lifestyle Magazine for Jewish Women to Appear
text: More often than not, when Martha Stewart gets out her glue gun to make a holiday decoration, it is a Christmas tree ornament or an Easter display. And when Family Circle reaches out to readers, it may ask them to submit Christmas cookie recipes.

headline: Carrie Rozelle, 69, Child Advocate, Dies; Started a Center for Learning Disabilities
text: Carrie Rozelle, whose struggles with the daily “hurricane” of a son with learning disabilities prompted her to start the National Center for Learning Disabilities, died on Oct. 29 at her home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. She was 69.

headline: John Firor, 80, Early Voice on Environment, Is Dead
text: John Firor, an environmental scholar and former director of the National Center of Atmospheric Research who was an early voice linking climate change and human activity, died last Monday in Pullman, Wash. He was 80.

headline: Who’s Afraid of the Menace Within? Not Edward Albee
text: The beast is still scratching at the door, howling, demanding to be let in. And Edward Albee is never going to let us forget its existence, not as long as his plays are being read and produced.

headline: U.N. Examining Myanmar Crackdown
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 11 — A United Nations envoy arrived in Myanmar on Sunday to begin the first independent investigation into the military government’s September crackdown on protests led by Buddhist monks and students.

headline: For Children, a Scary World Out There (in There, Too)
text: Fears of crawling insects, the dark and all types of vegetables are common among young children, as any child-rearing expert will attest.

headline: U.S. and Israel Play Down Hopes for Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 — The American-sponsored Middle East peace conference expected by the end of the month looks to be thin on content, mostly serving as a stage to begin formal negotiations on a peace treaty between Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas.

headline: Irish Sheep Hoof-to-Toe With Hip-Hop
text: No article about the Irish tap dancer James Devine has failed to mention that he is the fastest tapper in the world, so let’s just get that over with: He can do 38 taps a second. Yes, a second. But from an artistic point of view that’s not much more interesting than learning that someone can eat 38 hard-boiled eggs in a minute.

headline: New Way of Counting Radio Listeners May Cut Ad Income
text: The test of a new method for measuring radio audience in New York showed big ratings declines for stations appealing to blacks and Hispanics last week, causing considerable consternation among station owners and programmers.

headline: Auctioning the Old West to Help a City in the East
text: DALLAS, Nov. 11 — Prospective bidders looking to buy a piece of the Old West here over the weekend were greeted by an intimidating view straight down the barrel of a Model 1883 Gatling gun. Behind the weapon, an exhibit hall at a hotel was filled with rows of exquisitely beaded moccasins, revolvers and well-oiled Western saddles.

headline: Increased Compensation Puts More College Presidents in the Million-Dollar Club
text: Soaring compensation of university presidents, once limited to a few wealthy institutions, is becoming increasingly common, with the number of million-dollar pay packages at private institutions nearly doubling last year, and compensation at many public universities not far behind.

headline: Sharp Sell-Off Sweeps Asian Markets
text: TOKYO, Nov. 12 — Rising fears of a slowdown in the United States economy sparked a sharp sell-off in Asian stock markets today, driving a leading Japanese index to a two-year low.

headline: Yue Minjun and the Symbolic Smile
text: Images from the exhibition at the Queens Museum.

headline: All the Trimmings
text: Images and recipes from the Dining section, past and present.

headline: Troy Meets Gabriella, This Time on Skates
text: It’s girls’ night out at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum from now through Sunday. And at the Izod Center (formerly the Continental Airlines Arena) in the New Jersey Meadowlands from Nov. 20 through 25.

headline: Too, Too Solid Flesh
text: “Hamlet,” of course, involves a fair amount of emotional turmoil and transformation. So you may not be the right performer for it if you have a particularly wooden countenance. If you are, for instance, a marionette.

headline: Today’s Productivity Tip
text: How to spin a pencil:

headline: Flushophobia
text: While nearly half the world suffers the horrors of not having toilets, many of the haves are scared to death of them:

headline: Murder and Hymns
text: Images of metal bars, white on black like Wedgwood patterning, run around the shallow stage where the Actors Company Theater revival of “The Runner Stumbles” is set. The bars sometimes denote a prison, sometimes a church confessional; often the sense of constraint that fetters the lead characters, a priest and a nun; and always the eye to detail that makes this production, directed by Scott Alan Evans, so compelling.

headline: Laughter and Tears, One Sketch at a Time
text: It can seem as if there’s been a confessional solo show about every kind of tragedy (AIDS, cancer, Jewish mothers), but Jeffrey Essmann, a fixture on the fertile downtown scene of the late 1980s and ’90s before decamping for Chicago, says he has a new calamity to wax poetic about: My Journey With Type A Glaucoma.

headline: Oak Hill Flies Off With Firth Rixson
text: The private equity firm Oak Hill Capital Partners said Sunday it would buy Firth Rixson, a provider of specialized metal products primarily to aerospace engine manufacturers, in a deal valued at about $2 billion.

headline: V.C. Funds Kept Flowing in 3rd Quarter
text: Silicon Valley companies received more than $2.48 billion in venture capital in the third quarter of 2007, which the Mercury News takes as a sign that the region’s “entrepreneurial culture” is thriving even amid the recent market turmoil

headline: Start-Ups Trace a Dog’s Life
text: The concept behind SNIF Labs verges on the nutty: The Boston-based start-up is developing intelligent tags for dogs to wear, so that their owners can monitor their daily activity and track the friends they’ve made at the park.

headline: Lessons in Shakespeare, From Stage to Boardroom
text: Shakespeare’s ability to delve deep into the moralities and consequences of power have fascinated audiences and readers since the reign of Queen Elizabeth. Now, The New York Times takes a look at the sway he holds over a different court: that of corporate America.

headline: Countrywide’s Chief Salesman and Defender
text: In a lengthy profile of Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide Financial‘s embattled chief executive, The New York Times takes a look at the man made a fortune shaking up the staid home mortgage business only to see the company he built become the quintessential proxy for the mortgage meltdown that now surrounds it.

headline: The End of Childbirth 101?
text: Pregnant women are cutting childbirth class.

headline: Sour Grapes in Philadelphia Exchange Deal
text: The proposed $625 million sale of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to the Nasdaq Stock Market has some stockholders and former members feeling bitter, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

headline: Canadian Banks Feel Their Share of Pain
text: The credit crunch, which has been hammering the largest U.S. financial institutions, is increasingly taking its toll on Canadian banks.

headline: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?
text: Only a couple of years ago, Firefox was the little browser that could – an open-source program created by thousands of contributors around the world without the benefit of a giant company like Microsoft to finance it.

headline: C.E.O. Evolution Phase 3
text: Has the time come for C.E.O. Version 3.0?

headline: Some Wonder if Banks’ Stabilization Fund Will Work
text: When the country’s three largest banks reached agreement on Friday on how to structure a $75 billion fund to prop up distressed securities, an exhausted group of its top planners reportedly gathered in a Bank of America conference room to toast their success with 12-packs of Bud Light.

headline: Advice from a Silicon Valley Guru: Pull the Plug
text: As one of Silicon Valley’s most respected entrepreneurs, Marc Andreessen is something of a connoisseur of what he calls “productivity porn,” or techniques to maximize personal productivity.

headline: How to Stop a Buyout: Think Like Private Equity
text: The specter of private equity – and the prospect of being snapped up, stripped down, and sold at a colossal profit, all in the name of maximizing value – has shaken traditional managers to the core.

headline: Following MasterCard, Visa Schedules an I.P.O.
text: Visa, the biggest credit card network in the nation, said in a regulatory filing Friday that it hoped to raise $10 billion in an initial public stock offering. Visa said it planned to deposit a portion of the company’s proceeds from the offering into an escrow account to pay settlements or judgments related to litigation.

headline: Harvard Endowment Picks a Steward
text: A former Goldman Sachs vice chairman was selected by Harvard University to temporarily manage its $35 billion endowment, the university said Friday.

headline: For Masseuse, Google Options Made Millions
text: Bonnie Brown was fresh from a nasty divorce in 1999, living with her sister and uncertain of her future. On a lark, she answered an ad for an in-house masseuse at Google, then a Silicon Valley start-up with 40 employees. She was offered the part-time job, which started out at $450 a week but included a pile of Google stock options that she figured might never be worth a penny.

headline: Time Warner Unveils Details of Bewkes Deal
text: Time Warner has signed a five-year employment deal with its incoming chief executive, Jeff Bewkes, for $1.75 million a year in salary and an annual target bonus of $8.5 million.

headline: A Very Bad Day for Big Banks
text: Friday proved a dismal day for three major banks in the United States, who announced continued losses related to mortgages. Meanwhile, Barclays of Britain denied that it would announce major write-downs of its own.

headline: BHP Outlines Details of Rio Tinto Bid

headline: Hellman and Silver Lake Cash Out of Nasdaq

text: The auction of Wendy’s International may be in jeopardy because of continued turmoil in the credit markets, potentially forcing the company to delay its sale, The New York Times reported.

headline: Silly season movements not only for drivers
text: While we wait in the winter season to find out which drivers will race at which teams next year, and we watch as the pieces fall into place in the way we normally do in the middle of the summer, the so-called silly season is also affecting the team directors market. Today as Honda announced that Ross Brawn – Nigel Stepney’s former close associate – would move to Honda – where Stepney had apparently wanted to go with a group of people (remember the early stages of the spy scandal) – Ferrari also made the following interesting announcement:

headline: A Focus on the Weirdness of Wall Street C.E.O.’s

text: A bill that would more than double the tax that private investment firms pay on their profits passed the U.S. House of Representatives Friday.

headline: Facing Looming Threats, From Space or From Us
text: After I wrote my post examining what makes it worthwhile for a current generation to work to limit future risks, I sent an e-mail to a few contacts exploring risks and responses, inviting them to weigh in. A note came back from the Apollo 9 astronaut Rusty Schweickart, who has lately been pressing for the United States to intensify efforts to limit a danger both far more concretely understood than global warming and far less in vogue as a serious threat — the reality that a very large rock will inevitably head on a collision course for Earth.

headline: Mum’s the Word
text: Calling all witty caption writers: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above. It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’ve been posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines here. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Goldman’s Level 3 Problem
text: Goldman Sachs reported a blowout third quarter, even as its peers’ earnings sank. But as some have warned, its profits may stem from accounting maneuvers, a suspicion that may be backed up by a recent regulatory filing.

headline: For Prince, Exit Pay Is a Blast From the Past
text: This year, thousands of Citigroup employees can expect bonuses based on their work in 2007, when the bank’s results have been less than stellar. One, however, will get a bonus based largely on his performance in 2006, which was a better year: Charles O. Prince III, who resigned under pressure as chairman and chief executive last week.

headline: The Early Word: Pointed Attacks
text: With the Democrats headed to Nevada for a debate later this week on Thursday, the top three candidates’ criticisms of one another keep piling up in another version of “piling on.”

headline: Veterans Are on Congressional Minds
text: Congress takes a Veterans Day break today but both Republicans and Democrats sought to use the holiday to demonstrate their gratitude to the nation’s veterans who, as it turns out, figure into the spending fight that will resume when Congress returns Tuesday.

headline: Anxiety Rises as Broadway Shutdown Continues
text: Today is Day 3 of the stagehands’ strike on Broadway, and anxieties are mounting, as reflected in accusations leveled on both sides, lost restaurant and hotel revenue and worry among workers all along the Great White Way. Campbell Robertson reports that the two sides — the producers’ league and the stagehands’ union — do not appear to be near a settlement.

headline: Psychological Testing: Still Talking About It
text: People were really up in arms after reading my post about the use of psychological tests at work. And not just readers. National Public Radio asked me to come on their program, “The Bryant Park Project,” on Friday to discuss these tests.

headline: Berlin in Lights: Flamboyance Jostles Solemnity Aside
text: With my colleague Tony Tommasini having handled the critical end of things, here are some random observations about last night’s concert by Gustavo Dudamel and the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Dudamel’s many musical gifts aside, he manages to project a good-natured sincerity, an earnestness that seems entirely genuine. When Emanuel Ax, the soloist, played an encore, Mr. Dudamel sat down right in the string section and listened. When he took his bows, he did so off the podium, shoulder to shoulder with the string players, his arm draped over a cellist.***The orchestra players did their signature act, donning jackets with the Venezuelan colors (red, yellow and blue) after a solemn and grandiose Beethoven Fifth Symphony and generally turning into the definition of flamboyance — spinning instruments, standing up and jiving, shimmying, pointing their horns into the air — for the Latin-inflected part of the program. But the same kind of physical enthusiasm, not choreographed and not premeditated, was evident in the Beethoven, where the first violins rocked back and forth together, almost synchronized. For those who missed the concert, the unbridled Latin act – totally infectious – can be seen in several previous versions on YouTube, most prominently from a London Proms concert.***Venezuelan pride was not just on the stage. Several audience members hung the nation’s flag over the rail of the first balcony and waved it during applause.***On the group’s big night at Carnegie, a mishap hit the viola section. A string appeared to break on a first-stand instrument during the first movement of the Beethoven. The players passed it back to the tail end of the section. A last-stand violist passed a replacement instrument forward and changed strings on the viola that had come down the line. Ah, the unexpected nature of live acoustical performance.

headline: Special Olympics in China
Mailer and the Murderer
text: A tidbit from Charles McGrath’s lengthy obituary of Norman Mailer, who died on Saturday, intrigued us: Mailer’s role in helping to win parole for Jack Henry Abbott, a felon, in 1981. Mailer championed Mr. Abbott’s release, citing the quality of the prisoner’s writings, and he agreed to hire Mr. Abbott as a research assistant. But Mr. Abbott went on to commit another murder within weeks of his parole.

headline: Mark Twain and Web Hoaxes
text: From the Great Poodle Scam of 2007 to a sensational claim about chocolate toothpaste to the United Nations’ Windex of Mass Destruction, The Lede loves to keep track of the latest deflated news on the Web.

To his credit, he writes that the No. 1 thing we learned this weekend is that the pollsters have “no idea who’s No. 1 this year.”

headline: Seeding the Google Phone With Apps
text: One of the big challenges for Google’s ambitious phone project is persuading software developers to write interesting applications. Already, developers of mobile phone programs complain about having to write for too many different software platforms, like Windows Mobile, Symbian, Palm, RIM, and soon, Apple’s iPhone. And while those software platforms are already powering millions of phones, there are no phones out there running Google’s “Android” system — and there won’t be any until the second half of next year.

Bottom line: the US does lead the world in medical innovation, but the high prices we pay for insurance, drugs, etc. have little to do with it. Instead, it’s about the National Institutes of Health — it’s the government, not the private sector.

It’s a promotion for a book by Scott Kenemore, “The Zen of Zombie: Better Living Through the Undead,” a parody of a self-help book. From inception, work on “Atlantis SquarePantis,” about SpongeBob’s quest to the lost city of Atlantis (featuring David Bowie), spanned more than a year and multiple continents — none of them submerged. text: Following is a fourth and final set of answers from Benjamin Weiser and Leslie Kaufman of The Times, who, along with a panel of experts, answered readers’ questions about The Times’s series on foster care [“A History of Neglect,” Part 1 | Part 2 | Part 3] during the past week. Previous sets of questions and answers were posted last week.

headline: Big Oil Says There is No Energy Problem?!
text: I’m here at the World Energy Congress in Rome, a conference of leaders in the energy field that occurs once every five years. I just heard Rex Tillerson, chairman of ExxonMobil say that: “The world has plenty of oil resources … Twice the total of oil consumed in human history is still available.” OK, so why is oil hitting $100 a barrel? Mr. Tillerson seemed to place much of the blame on oil-rich countries that were not giving oil companies like his adequate access to their riches, nationalizing their oil resources.

headline: Investors Flee E*Trade; Will Depositors Follow?
text: E*Trade Financial is a leader in the new generation of Internet-only lenders. But its stock got crushed Monday amid fears about a distinctly old-fashioned problem: a run on the bank.

headline: Restoring Confidence in the Voting Process

headline: Monarchs, Presidents and Athletes Are Among Recipients of a Symbolic Key
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave the jazz musician Fats Domino the key to the city last week, it got us wondering: What is the key made of, what does it represent and who has received this honor? In researching the answers to these questions, we received a list of recipients since 1978. The mayor’s press office, which furnished the list, cautioned that it would be incomplete before the 1990s, when record keeping was computerized. Additionally, some older names and titles on the list were misspelled or rendered incorrectly, some beyond recognition. Where there was a question that we at City Room could not resolve, we omitted the name, so this roster is not comprehensive.

headline: A Superjumbo Jet That Airbus Better Deliver on Time

headline: Proposal to Control Pigeons: Fine the Hands That Feed Them

Well, one can kill them (not advisable on grounds of ethics or taste), starve them (well, not really starve them, but stop feeding them) or scare them away. At least those are the methods that most have tried in the past.

headline: Performa 07: Restaging Brings Mixed Emotions

Instead, the company has teamed up with others in the wireless industry to create an open-source operating system, as well as other services, for mobile phones. Other companies, including Motorola, LG and Samsung, are expected to build phones based on this software.

headline: Graphic: Campaigns on the Nightly News
text: Evening news programs on the three major networks have devoted significantly more time to the 2008 presidential campaign so far this year than any of the pre-election years since 1991, according to Andrew Tyndall, a television news analyst. NBC spent the most time covering the campaign with 228 minutes, followed by CBS with 191 minutes and ABC with 180 minutes. Individual candidates and the horse race were covered the most; only 18 minutes has been spent on issues on the trail.

headline: Interview: Michael Shellenberger

headline: The World of ‘Black Money’
text: Despite government crackdowns, the use of so-called “black money” is still rife in Spain and could be skewing officially reported prices by as much as 30 percent, says Martin Dell of Kyero.com, the property portal.

headline: Redesigning a Condom So Women Will Use It
text: The female condom has never caught on in the United States. But in the third world, where it was introduced in the late 1990s, public health workers hoped it would overthrow the politics of the bedroom, empower women and stop the AIDS epidemic in its tracks.

headline: With Carter on Bench, Nets Lose to Hornets

headline: Born With a Hole in His Heart, a Child Best Known as Magic
