headline: U.S. to Send Special Envoy to Confront Musharraf
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 — The Bush administration is dispatching a high-level envoy to Pakistan to tell the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, face to face that the United States will not be satisfied with his plan to hold elections unless he first lifts emergency law, administration officials said Monday.

headline: Macao: MGM Venture to Open Dec. 18
text: MGM Mirage and Pansy Ho, daughter of the billionaire Stanley Ho, will open their joint venture’s first casino in Macao on Dec. 18. The casino, the MGM Grand Macau, will have 600 rooms, suites and villas and 375 gambling tables and cost about $1.25 billion, said MGM, the gambling company based in Las Vegas.

headline: Wal-Mart Profit Is Up; Home Depot Takes a Hit
text: Economic unease, from the credit markets to the gas pump, is proving a boon to the nation’s largest discount retailer, Wal-Mart, but a bust for the biggest home improvement chain, Home Depot.

headline: Four Transplant Recipients Contract H.I.V.
text: Four transplant recipients in Chicago have contracted H.I.V. from an organ donor, the first known cases in more than a decade of the virus being spread by organ transplants.

headline: Your Bird for the Holiday Will Be Costly and Stuffed
text: AS a major holiday travel season approaches and airlines scramble to cover soaring fuel bills, air fares are going up. And this time, they’re likely to stay up.

headline: Top Rhythmic Gymnast Sees Dreams of Beijing Fade Away
text: When the rhythmic gymnast Lisa Wang stood atop the podium at the Pan American Games in July, a gold medal draped around her neck, an exciting thought filled her head, she said: the 2008 Olympics.

headline: In Westchester, Cleaning Up After One Flood While Planning for the Next
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — At the First Unitarian Society of Westchester, at the foot of a dead-end road here, there are signs that the congregation is finally patching itself up after a devastating flood in April, one that ravaged parts of the East Coast and was one of the worst in the county’s history.

headline: Screenings: Colonoscopy Suggestion May Be Made Too Often
text: Colonoscopies are a proven means of detecting small growths and removing them before they become deadly, but a new study suggests that many doctors are recommending them too often.

headline: More Than One Way to Help a Business Grow
text: If you Google the phrase “grow or die,” you get more than 11 million hits. So clearly there is something to the idea that if a business is not expanding it is withering away.

headline: Ex-Devil Stevens Considers Next Step After Hall
text: TORONTO, Nov. 12 — When the time came for Scott Stevens to put on his Hall of Fame ring, he struggled to slip it over his knuckle. He laughed as he wrenched it on and joked about never being able to take it off.

headline: Radiohead to Sell an in Rainbows CD
text: After distributing digital downloads of its new album, “In Rainbows,” last month, in many cases free, the British rock band Radiohead said yesterday it would begin to sell a version on compact disc through an independent label on Jan. 1. As previously reported, the band will sell the album in an arrangement with ATO Records and a related spinoff label, TBD Records. Representatives of the band, which is fronted by Thom Yorke, above, said yesterday that ATO planned to seek radio airplay for two of the album’s songs, “Bodysnatchers” and “Jigsaw Falling Into Place.” Questions about the prospects for selling a CD version of “In Rainbows” have lingered since the band let fans name their own price — even nothing — for downloading the album from a Radiohead Web site, inrainbows.com. So far, the band has declined to detail how many copies were distributed, or for what price, and has disputed a recent outside study suggesting that more than a million copies were downloaded. (The price of the CD has not yet been set.) The shift to an independent label comes after Radiohead fulfilled its long-term contract with the music giant EMI Group. EMI said last week that it planned to package Radiohead’s six previous studio albums and a live album in a CD box set, and in other formats, for sale on Dec. 10.

headline: Strange, Green and Pak Inducted
text: Curtis Strange and Hubert Green, each winners of 2 majors and 17 tournaments on the PGA Tour, were among six golfers inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame last night.Se Ri Pak of South Korea was inducted based on the L.P.G.A. Tour’s points system, which she surpassed three years ago, combined with 10 years on the women’s Tour.Strange, elected on the PGA Tour ballot with 70 percent of the vote, was the last golfer to win consecutive United States Opens, in 1988-89. Green, 60, captured the 1977 United States Open and the 1985 P.G.A. Championship. Joe Carr, the first Irishman to be inducted; Kel Nagle of Australia, who won the 1960 British Open; and Charles Blair Macdonald, who designed the National Golf Links in Southampton, N.Y., were the other inductees.

headline: Division of the U.S. Didn’t Occur Overnight
text: During President George W. Bush’s first term, one of his senior political advisers summed up the prevailing philosophy at the White House like this: “This is not designed to be a 55 percent presidency,” he said. “This is designed to be a presidency that moves as much as possible of what we believe into law while holding 50 plus one of the country and the Congress.” Bold ideas that could mobilize his conservative Republican base were prized over efforts to convince independent voters in the center; sharp divisions over the administration’s policies were regarded as proof of Mr. Bush’s decisiveness and willingness to challenge conventional thinking.

headline: Muslim Singer With a Country Twang
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Ask Kareem Salama, billed as the first Muslim country-western singer, what makes his music “country,” and he grins for about half a beat before answering, “Probably my accent.”

headline: In Hollywood Hives, the Males Rule
text: In his new animated film, Jerry Seinfeld plays Barry B. Benson, a wisecracking, moony-eyed, charmingly petulant New York honeybee who doesn’t want to spend his days as a worker bee stuck on the honeymaking assembly line. “You know, Dad, the more I think about it,” Barry says, “maybe the honey field just isn’t right for me.” To which his father, a proud, lifelong “honey stirrer,” snaps: “And you were thinking of, what, making balloon animals? That’s a bad job for a guy with a stinger!”

headline: Rage and Revival in Italy’s Sports Opera
text: The drama of Italian soccer, the success and the squalor, the skill and the sleaze, has again been laid bare for the world to see.

headline: Some Restrictions to Be Lifted in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 12  Iraqi military commanders signaled Monday that they would soon remove some roadblocks and other restrictions that had been imposed over the past nine months as part of the effort to reduce violence here in the capital.

headline: Go East, Young Writers, for Theater!
text: Here’s a trivia question — category: theater — for all those writers lying on the couch in Hollywood perfecting their video-game scores, or weeding the backyards of their Laurel Canyon haciendas, or doing whatever it is television and movie writers do when they are not cooking up dialogue for detectives, superheroes or nerdy, horny teenagers.

headline: Brushing Innovations, Built on Titanium
text: Titanium, the multitalented metal used in everything from jet engines to eyeglass frames, has taken on yet another role as the crucial component of two toothbrushes that aim to shake up the staid world of dental hygiene.

headline: Weight Around the Waist
text: Q. If added weight in the midsection raises the risk of health problems like diabetes and heart trouble, does a tummy tuck or liposuction lower the risk?

headline: Slowing Economy Posing Test for Disney
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 — Since becoming chief executive of the Walt Disney Company two years ago, Robert A. Iger has dazzled Wall Street by delivering soaring profits and moving aggressively to fix trouble spots.

headline: Speculation on E*Trade Hurts Stock
text: Shares of E*Trade Financial tumbled yesterday after an analyst suggested that the company might have to seek bankruptcy protection if panicked customers withdrew deposits because of the brokerage firm’s faltering mortgage investments.

headline: The Public Face of Wal-Mart’s Health Care Program
text: Linda M. Dillman, who oversees the employee health care program at Wal-Mart, did not ask for the job. Indeed, when the chief executive of the company, the world’s largest retailer, told her of the appointment, she wondered, “Did I make somebody mad? Are they trying to tell me something?”

headline: In Farm Belt, Ethanol Plants Hit Resistance
text: SPARTA, Wis. — When plans were announced for a new ethanol distillery on the outskirts of this city of 9,000, residents complained that it would mar the view from the municipal golf course. They worried that its emissions would taint the milk-based products made at nearby Century Foods International, one of the community’s biggest employers. They even argued over whether the plant would reek like burned molasses or blackened popcorn or fermenting beer.

headline: From Ants to People, an Instinct to Swarm
text: If you have ever observed ants marching in and out of a nest, you might have been reminded of a highway buzzing with traffic. To Iain D. Couzin, such a comparison is a cruel insult — to the ants.

headline: Chronic Pain: A Burden Often Shared
text: Chronic pain is a family problem. When people experience unrelenting pain, everyone they live with and love is likely to suffer. The frustration, anxiety, stress and depression that often go with chronic pain can also afflict family members and friends who feel helpless to provide relief.

headline: On Their Own Stage, Protégés Channel Choreographic Mentors
text: The literary critic Harold Bloom put a catchy phrase into circulation when he published “The Anxiety of Influence” in 1973, and it could have been the subtitle for the Rolex Arts Weekend presentation at Dance Theater Workshop on Sunday night.

headline: Knicks Hope to Leave Bad Habits Behind When They Hit the Road
text: A visit to the back right corner of the Knicks’ locker room usually provides a glimpse into the team’s state of affairs. Quentin Richardson, one of the most seasoned and secure veterans, resides there, dispensing brutal honesty when it is needed most.

headline: I.B.M. Offers $4.9 Billion for Cognos
text: OTTAWA, Nov. 12 — I.B.M. offered about $4.9 billion in cash today to acquire Cognos, a Canadian producer of software used by corporations to analyze their operations.

headline: Exercise Advice Often Ignores Jiggle Factor
text: Exercise is all about moving your body. But some body parts move more than you want them to.

headline: Levittown: Woman Killed in Crash
text: An Albertson woman who is the daughter of a renowned Kentucky Derby-winning jockey has been charged with vehicular manslaughter and driving while intoxicated after a crash Sunday morning in which one person was killed and four people were injured, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The accused woman, Sophia Santos, 20, the daughter of the jockey José Santos, was in Nassau University Medical Center yesterday, the police said. They said that Nancy Tumminello of Elmont was turning left onto Hempstead Turnpike from Wantagh Avenue about 2:30 a.m. on Sunday when her car was hit by Ms. Santos’s, which was westbound on Hempstead Turnpike. One passenger in Ms. Tumminello’s car, Virginia Casazza Urgo, 62, of Valley Stream, who was out celebrating her birthday with the group, was pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. Two other passengers were taken to the hospital in critical condition, while Ms. Tumminello and a fourth passenger were treated and released, the police said.

headline: France: Strike to Challenge Sarkozy
text: As France braced for a fresh wave of transportation strikes, a union leader said walkouts set to start tonight were not only about plans to roll back the retirement benefits of about 500,000 public sector workers. “At stake is whether unions in France will retain their say in economic reform,” said the official, Bernard Thibault, secretary general of the Confédération Générale du Travail. The protest has become a major test of President Nicolas Sarkozy’s ambition to bolster the economy by making it easier to hire and lay off public sector employees.

headline: Spanning the Blue Globe, for Little White Ones
text: AS a former flight attendant and now as president and founder of my company, PearlParadise.com, I’m a lover of both the friendly skies and some of the world’s finest pearls.

headline: Abortion Foes Throw Support to Thompson
text: A prominent anti-abortion group has decided to endorse Fred D. Thompson’s presidential bid, giving the candidate a boost in his efforts to court conservative voters.

headline: N.Y.U. Student Commits Suicide
text: A sophomore at New York University committed suicide in a dormitory room on Friday, university officials said yesterday. The university declined to identify the student or to provide other details, citing requests for privacy from the student’s family. The suicide was the second at N.Y.U. this semester; a freshman from California jumped from a dormitory roof in September. In 2003 and 2004, five students jumped to their deaths.

headline: Stocks Make a Comeback After 4 Days of Declines
text: Stock markets moved into the black after four days of declines, as investors cheered reassuring reports on two recent trouble spots, consumer spending and the credit market.

headline: Regimens: Weight Found to Affect Prostate Cancer Outcome
text: A new study reports that overweight men with advanced prostate cancer seem not to live as long as those with normal body mass.

headline: Couple Who Helped Lead Khmer Rouge Are Arrested
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 12  Ieng Sary and Ieng Thirith, a husband-and-wife team of French-educated Communist revolutionaries who held senior positions in the Khmer Rouge government in Cambodia in the 1970s, were arrested in Phnom Penh on Monday and charged with crimes against humanity.

headline: Righting Reagan’s Wrongs?
text: Let’s set the record straight on Ronald Reagan’s campaign kickoff in 1980.

headline: Don’t Rush to a Fare Hike
text: Since the summer, New York’s Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been trying earnestly to make its case for increasing fares. The needs of the system are overwhelming and, even though the M.T.A. is looking at a $1 billion surplus, substantial deficits are projected starting in 2009. The authority’s chief executive, Lee Sander, has no choice but to find a way to fill the hole.

headline: Laraine Day, ‘B+ Movie’ Star, Dies at 87
text: Laraine Day, a popular actress who appeared in almost two dozen MGM movies during Hollywood’s Golden Age, notably as the nurse Mary Lamont in a series of Dr. Kildare movies, died Saturday in Ivins, Utah. She was 87.

headline: Containers Wall Off a Newark Housing Project
text: NEWARK, Nov. 7 — Tasha Solomon opened the grimy plastic blinds of her first floor-apartment in the Millard E. Terrell Homes, a housing project hard by the Passaic River.

headline: Celebrities Chat With Athletes, in Reebok Gear
text: REEBOK will segue next month from shoe business to show business, teaming with the IFC cable network for a celebrity interview series that is being produced by a new entertainment arm of Reebok.

headline: Yankees Persuade Posada to Stay
text: The Yankees added a fourth year to Jorge Posada’s contract offer late last night, and as soon as Posada completes the formality of taking a physical, he will officially return to the team. Posada has agreed to the terms of the deal, which would make him the highest-paid catcher in the majors.

headline: Paranoia Strikes Deep, Into Your Headset It Will Creep
text: The windows near the elevators on the 21st floor of the Sheraton Meadowlands Hotel are fit for football espionage. The Giants’ practice field sits about a mile in the distance, past the maze of highway lanes and off-ramps, past the massive parking lots.

headline: Man, 18, Is Fatally Shot by Police in Brooklyn
text: A young man was fatally shot last night in a hail of 20 bullets fired by five police officers who responded to his mother’s 911 call for help in a domestic dispute in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

headline: In Mixed Slice of Baghdad, Old Bonds Defy War
text: BAGHDAD — At its oldest spot, a small dusty strip of dirt road near a mosque, the neighborhood of Bab al Sheik — a maze of snaking streets too narrow for cars — dates from a time, more than a thousand years ago, when Baghdad ruled the Islamic world.

headline: New DVDs
text: BERLIN ALEXANDERPLATZ

headline: Italy Moves to Tighten Soccer Security and Control Fans After Riots
text: ROME, Nov. 12  The Italian authorities moved Monday to ban large groups of soccer fans from traveling to out-of-town matches and imposed stricter security measures in stadiums, in response to rioting that took place in several cities on Sunday after the accidental police shooting of a soccer fan.

headline: Letters
text: Recipes and Experiments

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Sunday about the writer Norman Mailer misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the secretary of state whom Mr. Mailer invited to a literary conference, an invitation that prompted criticism of Mr. Mailer from leftists. He is George P. Shultz, not Schultz.

headline: Prosecutor Examines Spitzer Aide’s Statement
text: ALBANY, Nov. 12  The Albany County district attorney’s office, which has opened an inquiry into the possibility of perjury by Darren Dopp, a former top aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer, is examining Mr. Dopp’s sworn statement denying having ordered surveillance of Senator Joseph L. Bruno’s travels, according to a person who has been briefed on the investigation.

headline: Pakistani Officials Order Detention of Bhutto and Block a March
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, Tuesday, Nov. 13 — Hundreds of riot policemen today blocked the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto and her supporters from making a planned long march from this eastern city 160 miles through Punjab Province to the capital, Islamabad.

headline: Software for Rent
text: Marc Benioff has never been modest in his dreams for Salesforce.com, the business software company he founded in 1999.

headline: For Newsweek, a Political Web Venture
text: Newsweek is to announce today that it is starting the equivalent of a weekly political television show on its Web site, newsweek.com, and that it has hired a producer from MSNBC to oversee it. Tammy Haddad, who was executive producer of “Hardball With Chris Matthews” until this summer, when she became a vice president of political coverage at MSNBC, will have the title of consulting executive producer at Newsweek. In a statement, Jon Meacham, executive editor of Newsweek, a unit of the Washington Post Company, described Web video as “one of the great new storytelling tools of the time” and Ms. Haddad’s charge as devising “a fresh way of reaching more readers with our signature coverage of politics.” Ms. Haddad is also creating a production company, Haddad Media, which will do similar work with the National Journal Group.

headline: Marvel Puts Superheroes Online
text: Marvel Comics, the publisher of Spider-Man, Wolverine and the Fantastic Four, is introducing an online subscription service. For $9.99 a month or $59.88 a year, subscribers will get Web access to a library of 2,500 comic books, as well as 20 new titles each week. For the introduction of the site, marvel.com/digitalcomics, Marvel will offer a free sampling of 250 titles. The service will make it easier and more affordable for people to read the first copy of “Captain America,” from 1941, which in its print form is valued from $7,433 to $160,000. Though comic books have been available digitally for some time, the paid subscription model is relatively new. For Marvel, a chief concern is to avoid cannibalizing demand for print copies. “This is a big step,” said Dan Buckley, the president and publisher of Marvel Entertainment, the parent company of Marvel Comics. He added that there would be “a timing lag between our print products and going online.”

headline: Kazakhstan: China Gets a Share in Uranium Mine
text: China will get a stake in a 2,000-ton-a-year uranium mine in Kazakhstan in exchange for its share in a uranium-processing business, the state-owned company Kazatomprom said. The company’s president, Moukhtar Dzhakishev, said in Almaty that the company would gain access to Chinese assets, without elaborating. Kazatomprom said on Oct. 12 it signed agreements in Beijing with the China Guangdong Nuclear Power Group and the China National Nuclear Corporation, China’s largest producers of atomic energy.

headline: Google Hits European Hurdle on DoubleClick Deal
text: PARIS, Nov. 13 — European Commission competition authorities refused today to approve Google’s $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick, the Internet advertising company, and ordered an in-depth review amid opposition from rivals, publishers and consumer groups.

headline: Reaching Out to Students When They Talk and Text
text: Can the Bloomberg administration convince thousands of low-achieving students that succeeding in school is actually, well, cool?

headline: U.S. Prosecutors Start Investigating Oil Spill
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 — The United States Attorney’s Office has begun investigating an oil spill last week in San Francisco Bay. The move signals that criminal charges may be filed against the crew of the vessel that lost 58,000 gallons of fuel after hitting the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge.

headline: Opera’s Newest Gimmick: The 90-Minute ‘Tosca’
text: ROME — For months the Piccola Lirica company has been staging “Tosca” here, as its slogan says, “in miniatura.” The other night I stopped by to see it. It lasted about as long as some Italian governments: in just 90 minutes Scarpia was dead, Tosca had hurled herself off the parapet, and the audience was back strolling the streets, hunting for the perfect linguine alle vongole.

headline: Grisly Murder Case Intrigues Italian University City
text: PERUGIA, Italy, Nov. 12  “Who is Amanda?” the newspaper Voice of Perugia asked Monday. “From brilliant student to cold maneater.”

headline: That Clinton Boy Defends His Wife and Raises Eyebrows
text: It’s a Southern thing, not a gender thing.

headline: Ex-Publisher’s Suit Plays a Giuliani-Kerik Angle
text: Judith Regan, the former book publisher, says in a lawsuit filed today protesting her dismissal by the News Corporation, the media conglomerate, that a senior executive there encouraged her to lie to federal investigators about her past affair with Bernard B. Kerik after he had been nominated to become homeland security secretary in late 2004.

headline: Magnanimity Becomes One of Rap’s Moguls
text: Dynastic succession, cutthroat competition, brand reinforcement: these were a few of the items on Jay-Z’s agenda at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Sunday night. Of course he covered this ground with exultant style, surrounding himself with constituents, protégés and even a notable rival. Fittingly for any hip-hop mogul, and especially for this one, the show felt scrappy as well as spectacular.

headline: Public Works: When ‘Big Government’ Plays Its Role
text: At the dedication of the Triborough Bridge in 1936, Franklin Roosevelt made an impassioned case for public works. There was a time when no one complained, he said, “that our schoolhouses were badly ventilated and lighted” or that “there were no playgrounds for children in crowded tenement areas.” But times had changed. “People are demanding up-to-date government in place of antiquated government,” he declared, “just as they are requiring and demanding Triborough Bridges in place of ancient ferries.”

headline: Bands to March on Atlanta
text: Ten marching bands, with their strutting drum majors, vibrant dance teams and synchronized drumlines, have been chosen from the nation’s historically black colleges and universities as the finalists in the sixth annual Honda Battle of the Bands, scheduled for the Georgia Dome in Atlanta on Jan. 26. Nominated from 42 colleges were Virginia State University and Shaw University, representing the Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association; Bethune-Cookman College and Norfolk State University, representing the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference; Tuskegee University, in Alabama, and Albany State University, in Georgia, representing the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference; Texas Southern University and the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, representing the Southwestern Athletic Conference; and North Carolina Central University and Winston-Salem State University, both independents. As sponsor of the event, the American Honda Motor Company will award $142,000 in grants to the bands.

headline: Study Indicates Benefit of Vaccines
text: Death rates for 13 diseases that can be prevented by childhood vaccinations are at all-time lows in the United States, according to a study released yesterday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,848 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last week:

headline: Luis Herrera Campíns, Venezuela Leader, Dies at 82
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 11 — Luis Herrera Campíns, a former president whose years in office were marked by bountiful oil riches and a painful economic bust when oil prices plunged in the early 1980s, died here on Friday. He was 82.

headline: Bad Behavior Does Not Doom Pupils, Studies Say
text: Educators and psychologists have long feared that children entering school with behavior problems were doomed to fall behind in the upper grades. But two new studies suggest that those fears are exaggerated.

headline: Monitoring Rodriguez, Mets Look for Trades
text: David Wright is one of the few Mets who spend the off-season in New York. Naturally, that makes it easier for him to attend the team’s promotional events, oversee his charitable foundations and embrace the community endeavors that have helped cement his status as the team’s most visible player.

headline: Mayor’s Offer of Mediator in Theater Strike Goes Nowhere
text: As the stagehands’ strike on Broadway entered its third day yesterday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and senior members of his administration continued to reach out privately to the producers and stagehands, urging them to negotiate and offering the use of Gracie Mansion and a mediator.

headline: 2 States’ Voters Still Not Settled on Favorite Candidates
text: This article was reported by Adam Nagourney, Marjorie Connelly and Dalia Sussman and written by Mr. Nagourney.

headline: Kelly Says Man Provoked Officers
text: New York City Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly said today that the shooting death of an unarmed Brooklyn man by five police officers last night fell within departmental guidelines because the man, an 18-year-old with a history of mental illness, pointed a black object at the officers and claimed it was a gun.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Oct. 29 about the lobbyist Robert D. Blackwill, a former White House aide who works on behalf of the former Iraqi prime minister Ayad Allawi for the Washington firm of Barbour Griffith & Rogers, misstated, in two references, the surname of another former aide who met with one or more of the firm’s lobbyists to discuss Iraq, according to disclosure reports. She is Meghan O’Sullivan, not Sullivan. (Go to Article)

headline: East Haven: Second Recount Ordered
text: Secretary of the State Susan Bysiewicz ordered a second recount of ballots in East Haven’s mayoral election yesterday after discrepancies turned up in the first recount. April Capone-Almon, a Democrat, defeated Mayor Joseph Maturo, a Republican, by 21 votes in last week’s election, according to Election Day counts. Local officials who counted the paper ballots on Sunday found that Ms. Capone-Almon had an even bigger lead. Lori Jaffe, an election moderator, declined to reveal the exact discrepancy, but said the victory margin was now about 50 to 60 votes.

headline: For Edwards, a Man on the Run, Time Is No Ally
text: DES MOINES, Nov. 12 — Night was falling, and John Edwards was an hour late for a campaign event at a recreation center in Williamsburg, Iowa.

headline: During War, Tough Mother Sets Out to Shield Her Son
text: Kathleen Chalfant can perform such miracles onstage that she has even found the lifeblood in Howard Barker’s bloodless essay question of a play, “A Hard Heart.”

headline: Smoking, the Environment and an Epidemic of Lung Disease
text: Dr. Barry Make is co-director of the C.O.P.D. program at National Jewish Medical and Research Center in Denver.

headline: Next Project for eProject: A New Name
text: Not that long ago, when it came to corporate branding the “I’s” had it, and so, too, did the “E’s,” as marketers sought to signal they were part of the Internet boom by starting their names with those vowels.

headline: McCain Disavows Group Trying to Help His Campaign
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Senator John McCain asked his donors on Monday not to send money to independent groups that circumvent campaign finance regulations as they seek to assist his presidential campaign.

headline: Challenger Named in Georgian Election
text: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 12  Georgia’s opposition nominated the owner of a winemaking company on Monday to face President Mikheil Saakashvili in early presidential elections, scheduled for Jan. 5.

headline: Poisonous Mushrooms Forge Their Own Path, Genetically Speaking
text: It’s a thin line between love of wild mushrooms and death. Some species in the genus Amanita are edible, but others are among the most lethal foods known. That’s why all but the most expert mushroom hunters are wise to stay away from Amanita species. Unless you really know what you’re doing, your next sauté may be your last.

headline: Pope Benedict to Visit in April
text: Pope Benedict XVI is scheduled to come to the United States in April, his first visit as the pope, and plans to make stops in Washington and New York, the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops announced yesterday.

headline: Oil Drops on Lower Demand Forecast
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 13  The price of crude oil extended its slide today after a prominent energy group lowered its estimate for worldwide oil demand, saying high prices were harming consumption.

headline: Selected Studies: C.O.P.D.
text: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Jawbone Sheds Light on Divergence of Humans and Apes
text: Scientists who study the divergence of humans from the other great apes have been stymied by a lack of evidence. It is thought that humans and chimpanzees split 6 million to 7 million years ago, and humans and gorillas a couple of million years before that. But almost no ape fossils from this period — the Late Miocene — have been found in Africa.

headline: Challenges to Both Left and Right on Global Warming
text: For many years, the battle over what to think and do about human-caused climate change and fossil fuels has been waged mostly as a yelling match between the political and environmental left and the right.

headline: The Character Factor
text: Rochester, N.H.

headline: Barricaded in Home, Bhutto Says President Should Resign
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, Tuesday, Nov. 13 — Hundreds of riot police early today blocked the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto and her supporters from making a planned long march from this eastern city 160 miles through Punjab Province to the capital, Islamabad. Ms. Bhutto, barricaded in her home here, called for the resignation of Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, in a phone interview with CNN this morning.

headline: Japan: Operating Profit Falls at Isuzu
text: Isuzu Motors, Japan’s biggest maker of light trucks, had a 26 percent drop in second-quarter operating profit after rising overseas vehicle sales failed to make up for a slump in domestic demand. Operating profit, or sales minus the cost of goods sold and selling, general and administrative expenses, fell to 25 billion yen ($227 million) in the three months that ended Sept. 30, from 33.7 billion yen a year earlier. Sales rose 10 percent, to 472.4 billion yen.

headline: Lawyer’s Long Fight for Democracy Puts Him in Familiar Place: Jail
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 12 — Twenty-five years ago, when President Reagan treated Pakistan’s dictator, Muhammad Zia ul-Haq, to a White House state dinner, a promising young lawyer out of Cambridge University languished in jail. He had protested too loudly, and too often, about the lack of democracy in his country.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Open Book, See Red

headline: The Claim: Some Red Lipstick Brands Contain High Lead Levels
text: THE FACTS

headline: Warmth Is Found in a Heated Rivalry
text: Choosing which sports rivalry is the fiercest, looniest or nastiest is a timeless, if fruitless, exercise. How do you compare Red Sox-Yankees with Auburn-Alabama, North Carolina-Duke with Real Madrid-Barcelona or Glasgow Celtic-Glasgow Rangers?

headline: Germany: Bank to Post a Huge Loss
text: WestLB, the German state-owned bank based in Düsseldorf, said it would report a full-year loss of more than 100 million euros ($145 million) because of “persistently difficult market developments.” The lender will post a pretax “low three-digit million euro loss,” in contrast to an original forecast of a profit, according to a statement. The company, which is scheduled to publish nine-month earnings on Dec. 6, blamed “the substantial price losses of structured securities in the past weeks.”

headline: Networking at the Spa
text: The golf course is not the only place to do business in a casual setting. The new spot to network with colleagues and clients is the hotel spa.

headline: Addenda
text: Accounts

headline: Delbert Mann, Director, Is Dead at 87
text: Delbert Mann, a director from the heyday of live television who won an Oscar for his first big-screen effort, “Marty,” in 1955, died Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 87 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: One Lawmaker’s Waste Is Another’s Namesake
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 — Buried deep in the largest domestic spending bill of the year is money for a library and museum honoring first ladies. The $130,000 was requested by the local congressman, Representative Ralph Regula, Republican of Ohio. The library was founded by his wife, Mary A. Regula. The director of the library is his daughter, Martha A. Regula.

headline: Europe Advances Plan to Cut Jet Emissions
text: PARIS, Nov. 13  A bold effort by the European Union to impose caps on aircraft emissions received a lift today when legislators voted to raise the costs for airlines and to include international flights sooner than expected.

headline: Old Story, Updated: Better Living Through Pills
text: Athletes taking performance-enhancing drugs. Growing concern about a reliance on pills for relief from pain, stress and anxiety. Medical leaders alarmed about drug fads, calling on doctors to exercise restraint when prescribing.

headline: Britain Takes Tougher Stance on Sanctions Against Iran
text: LONDON, Nov. 12  Britain will push for a worldwide ban on foreign investment in Iran’s oil and gas industry and other financial sanctions unless two reports due this month show that the Tehran government is ready to abandon efforts to acquire nuclear weapons, Prime Minister Gordon Brown said Monday.

headline: French Literary Honors
text: France’s literary awards season continued yesterday with the Prix Medicis and the Prix Femina, Agence France-Presse reported. The Prix Medicis went to “La Stratégie des Antilopes” (“The Strategy of Antelopes”), by Jean Hatzfeld, an account of what happened after the Rwandan authorities allowed 40,000 of those who carried out the 1994 genocide to return to their homes. The Prix Femina, awarded by an all-female jury, went to Eric Fittorino for his novel “Baisers de Cinéma” (“Cinema Kisses”). The committee awarded its prize for a foreign novel to the British writer Edward St. Aubyn for “Mother’s Milk,” and the Prix Medicis for foreign work went to an American, Daniel Mendelsohn, for “The Lost,” about a search for family members who died in the Holocaust.

headline: Palestinian Refugees
text: To the Editor:

headline: I.B.M. Acquires Cognos, Maker of Business Software, for $4.9 Billion
text: OTTAWA, Nov. 12 — Cognos, the last major independent producer of software that companies use to analyze mountains of data, agreed on Monday to be acquired by I.B.M. for $4.9 billion in cash.

headline: Australian Judge Dismisses Terrorism Case
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 12 — A judge in Australia dismissed a case against a terrorism suspect, Izhar ul-Haque, on Monday, and accused the Australian Security Intelligence Organization of false imprisonment and kidnapping.

headline: Dressing Up Those Bleak Downtown Construction Sites
text: Yes, those are orange zebra stripes on the traffic barriers along lower Broadway. Yes, the 14-foot-tall plywood lightning bolts on John Street take the place of common sidewalk scaffolding. And yes, that tartan pattern on the construction fence along Fulton Street is made of security netting.

headline: The Daily Show
text: Washington

headline: Police Transcript of 911 Call
text: NEW YORK (AP) — The police transcript of the 911 call prior to the police shooting of an 18-year-old in New York:

headline: Looks Deceive: This Destination Drew Too Well
text: HOLLIS, N.H., Nov. 10 — The town dump here is a kind of unofficial social club, the place to buy Girl Scout cookies, meet political candidates and catch up with friends while unloading a week’s worth of trash.

headline: Gumbel Gives His First Year a Low Grade
text: It is rare to hear network announcers say their work is substandard, but Bryant Gumbel said yesterday that he was not very good last season. It was his first as the play-by-play announcer for the NFL Network’s eight-game schedule.

headline: In a Loss, Dungy Says He Learned a Lesson
text: Few things in football are more unexpected than seeing Indianapolis place-kicker Adam Vinatieri, one of the great clutch performers in football history, blow an easy kick: he missed a chip-shot field-goal attempt Sunday night with a chance to eek out a victory against the San Diego Chargers.

headline: Another Impeachment Complaint Filed Against Philippine President
text: MANILA, Nov. 12 — Opponents of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo filed a new impeachment complaint against her today, accusing her of corruption and illegal policies that they said have resulted in the death, torture and disappearance of hundreds of government critics.

headline: For the Record: In Tests of Inhalers, Results May Depend on Who Pays
text: Inhalers are an effective treatment for asthma and other respiratory diseases, but they can have adverse side effects. The conclusions of studies on these effects apparently depend in part on who pays for the study.

headline: BHP Takes Buyout Plan to Shareholders of Rival
text: BHP Billiton, whose $153 billion takeover offer for a rival mining company, Rio Tinto, was rejected by the target’s board, took its case to shareholders yesterday, detailing what it said would eventually be $3.7 billion in annual savings and holding out the promise of $30 billion in payouts if the deal goes ahead.

headline: Open Book, See Red
text: Book rage has now been added to the list of neurotic human behaviors. So far confined to Canada, it is characterized by angry outbursts in bookstores and, more specifically, by the hurling of books, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. The causes: the declining United States dollar, the rising Canadian dollar and dust jackets imprinted with prices making books more costly for Canadians. For more than 30 years the value of the Canadian dollar has lagged that of its American cousin; five years ago it was worth 62 American cents. As a result, book jackets customarily show a United States price and a higher Canadian price. But last week the Canadian dollar hit $1.10 against the United States dollar; yesterday it stood at $1.03. Thus book rage and widespread reports of unhappiness among buyers expected to pay the higher price. Some Canadian booksellers, including Wal-Mart Canada, have begun to offer their wares at United States prices; others are giving discounts on the Canadian price, rebates or simply marking down the books.

headline: Pennsylvania: Boy Talked to Youth in Finland School Shooting
text: A teenager who plotted an attack on a suburban Philadelphia high school discussed the 1999 Columbine massacre with the Finnish student who killed eight people and then himself at a school near Helsinki last week, the teenager’s lawyer said. The American, who is 14 years old, contacted the Finnish youth, Pekka-Eric Auvinen, 18, online last summer, and they exchanged views about Web sites and videos, including one that glorified the Columbine attack, said the American’s lawyer, J. David Farrell. Although that video was among “common interests” the two boys discussed, there was no talk of any plan that Mr. Auvinen had to attack the Finnish school, Mr. Farrell said, adding that his client was “shocked” by the attack in Finland.

headline: Case Touches a 2nd Amendment Nerve
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 — Both sides in a closely watched legal battle over the District of Columbia’s strict gun-control law are urging the Supreme Court to hear the case. If the justices agree — a step they may announce as early as Tuesday — the Roberts court is likely to find itself back on the front lines of the culture wars with an intensity unmatched even by the cases on abortion and race that defined the court’s last term.

headline: Korean Officials Accused in Widening Bribery Scandal
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 12  A widening corruption scandal at the Korean electronics giant Samsung engulfed the government of South Korea on Monday when President Roh Moo-hyun’s next chief prosecutor and his top anticorruption agent faced accusations of accepting bribes from the conglomerate.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Investment Firm Names Gore as a Partner
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 — Deepening his ties to Silicon Valley, former Vice President Al Gore said on Monday that he had become a partner in the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

headline: Childhood: Too Little Sleep May Pose Obesity Risk
text: Children who do not get enough sleep may increase their risk for obesity, a new study has found.

headline: Voter Anger May Free Up Energy Bills
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 — Congress saw it coming. Earlier this year, lawmakers warned of an impending energy crisis as they debated wide-ranging legislation to improve automotive efficiency, reward energy conservation and spur development of alternative power sources.

headline: Football Beaten by Housewives
text: Despite tough competition from NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” and Fox’s animated comedy lineup, ABC eked out a victory on Sunday as the night’s most watched network. “Desperate Housewives,” the night’s top-rated show, gave ABC its usual lift, drawing 18.5 million viewers at 9, Nielsen estimated. The network also earned solid ratings from “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (15.1 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 (12.5 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC finished in a three-way tie with Fox and NBC, which both benefited from live football coverage. Although Fox’s comedies, in particular “The Simpsons” at 8 (10.6 million) and “Family Guy” at 9 (10.4 million), remained competitive in that demographic, the network began the night with more than 18 million viewers tuning in at 7 for an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. NBC’s prime-time Sunday coverage of the Indianapolis Colts at the San Diego Chargers delivered approximately 14.4 million viewers from 8 to 11. CBS ranked a distant fourth for the night in the 18-to-49 set. It earned its best ratings at 8 and 9 with “The Amazing Race” (10.5 million), followed by “Cold Case” (13 million).

headline: For the Record
text: A letter from Rochester yesterday about Ronald Reagan and states’ rights misspelled the name of the German city where he spoke at an SS burial ground. It is Bitburg, not Bitberg.

headline: Symantec Planning to Cut Some Jobs
text: The Symantec Corporation, the maker of security software, said yesterday that it would cut jobs in some business units, less than a month after its forecast of sales fell short of analysts’ estimates.

headline: Giants May Have Been Close, but Now They Have Far to Go
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 12 — When Giants Coach Tom Coughlin addressed reporters minutes after Sunday’s 31-20 loss to the Cowboys, he stepped away from the podium after answering two questions. Frustration was written on his face and spelled out in his words. He did not like a question about whether the loss represented a squandered chance in a statement game.

headline: Warnings of Long-Term Damage After Russian Oil Spill
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 — An environmental disaster began to unfold in southern Russia on Monday as tens of thousands of oil-slicked seabirds and globules of heavy oil dotted the shoreline, a day after at least 11 ships, including a small oil tanker, sank or broke apart in a fierce storm, Russian officials said.

headline: Focus on Names Misses the Steroids Story
text: The feeding frenzy is on. As George Mitchell gets closer to writing and issuing his report on the use of performance-enhancing substances in baseball, the prospect of seeing names in the report has people in Major League Baseball nervous and the news media tingling with anticipation.

headline: An Artist’s Famous Smile: What Lies Behind It?
text: Your first reaction upon meeting Yue Minjun might be, yes, it is indeed he! The face with the enigmatic, jaw-breaking grin, perhaps the most recognizable image in contemporary Chinese painting, is a self-portrait.

headline: What to Ask About C.O.P.D.
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening -- and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: 6 Palestinians Killed in Gaza at Fatah Rally
text: GAZA, Nov. 12  At least six Palestinians were killed and more than 100 wounded here on Monday when a rally by the relatively pro-Western Fatah movement to mark the third anniversary of the death of its founder, Yasir Arafat, ended in armed clashes with its rival, Hamas.

headline: An Ailing Health System: Feel Better!
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Injury to Vilma, Jets Give an Inch
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 12 — Most N.F.L. teams are secretive about injuries, and the Jets are more secretive than most. So it was startling Monday when the Jets disclosed which injured knee had ended the season of Jonathan Vilma, the inside linebacker, defensive captain and backbone of their defense.

headline: Picking Up City’s Vibes to Predict Quake Effects
text: The boxy white postal truck bounced along West 28th Street in Manhattan, hit a pothole, shimmied some, then lumbered on.

headline: Blackstone, Deal Maker, Posts Drop in Earnings
text: The Blackstone Group yesterday reported third-quarter earnings that were lower than in the period a year earlier, as troubles in the credit market shook up its real estate business.

headline: Ministers Want Stronger Chinese Currency
text: European finance ministers meeting in Brussels urged China to let its currency strengthen so Europe’s economy no longer bears the brunt of the slide in the United States dollar.

headline: Nun Pleads No Contest in Sex Abuse
text: A Roman Catholic nun pleaded no contest yesterday to two counts of indecent behavior with a child in connection with accusations from the 1960s when she was a principal and teacher at a Catholic school in Milwaukee.

headline: Off Endangered List, but What Animal Is It Now?
Some Help in a New Life
text: In the former Soviet Union, Mikhail Fayner was a physicist and his wife, Aleksandra, an engineer. They are intelligent people, warm and playful. They are also Jewish, and in the Soviet Union, carrying that stamp on your passport meant a lifetime of trouble. By the time the Soviet Union fell, they had long since had enough and were finally free to start a life somewhere new. The United States granted them refugee status, and in 1997 they moved to New York City.

headline: A Soldier Home From War, and a Mother Fighting Hard
text: On Veterans Day, all that Cathy

headline: A Painless Execution
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shooting Kills a Boy, 13, and Wounds Another
text: ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 12 — Jacqueline Purdie clutched herself against the cold, stared at the monitor showing the blurry surveillance tape, and watched her 13-year-old son die.

headline: Love of Chocolate May Have Begun With Cacao Beer
text: The ancient peoples of Mexico and Central America loved to drink chocolate. But their beverage was nothing like the modern one — it was a frothy, bitter brew of fermented, roasted and ground cacao seeds, often spiced with chile peppers, more like mole poblano than Swiss Miss.

headline: The on Wings of Song Series Shows a Fledgling’s Flights
text: At 19, the soprano Nadine Sierra is a seasoned performer. A native of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., she entered the Palm Beach Opera’s young artist program at 14 and made her stage debut there two years later. Her 2004 performance of Puccini’s “O mio babbino caro” on the National Public Radio series “From the Top” generated a buzz. A video clip of Ms. Sierra singing that aria, posted on YouTube last year, has been viewed more than 11,700 times.

headline: Justice Dept. Chief Faces a Test in Minnesota
C.I.A. Officer Pleads Guilty to Illegal Searches
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — A Lebanese-born C.I.A. officer who had previously worked as an F.B.I. agent pleaded guilty today to charges that she illegally sought classified information from government computers about the radical Islamic group Hezbollah.

headline: The Prince and His Palace: A 6,400-Square-Foot Getaway That Flies
text: PARIS, Nov. 12 — He may be only the world’s 13th-richest man, but Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia will soon be able to claim the bragging rights to the world’s largest private jet.

headline: A Lineman in My Bed: Notes on Teeth Grinding
text: I grind my teeth at night. Have for years. It’s my secret shame. But now I have the comfort of knowing that at least 8 to 10 percent of the adult population shares my malady.

headline: Dick Nolan, 75, N.F.L. Coach and Player, Is Dead
text: Dick Nolan, who played nine seasons as a National Football League defensive back and was later a head coach for 11 years, twice guiding the San Francisco 49ers to conference championship games, died Sunday in Grapevine, Tex. He was 75.

headline: Listening to the Fragile, Ethereal Beat of Butterflies’ Wings
text: At a time when many composers wrote works of gargantuan size and scope, Gabriel Fauré produced just one prominent, large-scale masterpiece: the ethereal Requiem. Instead he concentrated on songs and chamber music, the focus of a concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Sunday at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, its temporary home while Alice Tully Hall is being renovated.

headline: A Health Plan for Wal-Mart: Less Stinginess
text: For much of the last decade, the retailing behemoth Wal-Mart Stores has been associated with stingy health care as much as low prices.

headline: Memo Pad
text: BUSINESS-CLASS SALES The trans-Atlantic business-class fare war for holiday travel that Continental started recently is escalating as American, Lufthansa and eight other carriers have joined in. Round-trip business-class fares on trans-Atlantic routes, which can cost $10,000 at regular walk-up prices, are being offered at $1,200 and less by some carriers for limited periods over the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. Matthew Bennett, publisher of the online premium air travel newsletter Flightbliss.com, suggests that the discounts are a good way for elite-status frequent fliers to take holiday trips in comfort while padding their year-end totals of miles needed to requalify for elite status next year. Business-class fares, he points out, often yield extra qualifying mileage credit.

headline: A Toast to Tuscany, With a Staten Island Red
text: CRESPINA, Italy, Nov. 7 — The visit to this picturesque corner of Tuscany probably will not spawn a best-selling sequel with a title like “Under the Staten Island Sun.” But in the not-too-distant future, Staten Island will bring a little bit of Tuscany to New York, in the form of a vineyard being developed at the Staten Island Botanical Garden.

headline: Bush Vetoes Major Domestic Spending Measure
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — President Bush on Tuesday vetoed a major spending measure that would have funded education, health care and job training programs, saying it contained money for too many of the special projects known as earmarks. But he signed a $459 billion bill to increase the Pentagon’s nonwar funding.

headline: Structural Failures
text: The recent crash of an Air Force F-15 fighter jet — and the grounding of the entire 700-plane fleet as a precautionary measure — is the latest reminder of the tough military budget choices this country will face for the foreseeable future. Even if American troops were withdrawn from Iraq tomorrow, billions of dollars would still be needed to replenish military equipment, swap aging weapons systems for new ones and rebuild and expand ground forces strained to the breaking point by this misguided war.

headline: Dealer’s Trove Draws Loyal Collectors and Strong Bids at Christie’s
text: The quirky eye of the legendary Manhattan dealer Allan Stone drew a loyal following of collectors and dealers last night to Christie’s, where a selection of the art and objects he collected so obsessively opened this season’s auctions of postwar and contemporary art.

headline: M Is for the Many Things We Sell Her …
text: The television folks who brought you tmz.com are back online again, this time not with the inside dope on celebrity misbehavior but with a community Web site for mothers.

headline: Berlin in Lights: With Two Interlopers, a Doughty Dozen
text: A long day of following the Berlin Philharmonic’s component parts ended at Zankel Hall on Monday night with a concert by its cello section. “The 12,” as they are called, have a specific origin.

headline: Injury Roundup
text: Adrian Peterson’s torn knee ligament was the injury news of the day, but the status of several other top players is up in the air.

headline: ‘Bee’ Sting
text: In Science Times, Natalie Anger lays into Hollywood cartoons, in which the overwhelming majority of animal characters are male, despite nature’s preferred sex ratio of roughly 50-50:

text: Constellation Brands, the winemaker, said Monday that it planned to buy the American wine business of a rival, Fortune Brands, for $885 million, in a move to expand its portfolio of higher-end California wines.

headline: Officials Accused in Samsung Bribery Scandal
text: A widening corruption scandal at the Korean electronics giant Samsung engulfed the government of South Korea on Monday when President Roh Moo-hyun’s next chief prosecutor and his top anticorruption agent faced accusations of accepting bribes from the conglomerate.

headline: BHP Takes Buyout Plan to Shareholders of Rival
text: BHP Billiton, whose $153 billion takeover offer for a rival mining company, Rio Tinto, was rejected by the target’s board, took its case to shareholders Monday, detailing what it said would eventually be $3.7 billion in annual savings and holding out the promise of $30 billion in payouts if the deal goes ahead.

headline: Borse Dubai Gets Approval in Joint Bid For OMX
text: Sweden’s financial regulator has given Gulf-based Borse Dubai approval to own OMX, the Nordic stock market operator, bringing Nasdaq‘s joint $4.9 billion bid to acquire OMX with Borse Dubai a significant step closer.

headline: The Unwanted Bounce of Exercise
text: At a recent school function, a mother started talking to me about her exercise routine, but I interrupted with a more pressing question. “What sports bra do you use?”

headline: Gazprom Eyes 2 London-Listed Oil Concerns
text: Gazprom, Russia’s state-owned energy company, is considering taking equity stakes in two London-listed oil companies that had hitherto faced problems with Russian regulators.

headline: Kleiner’s New Political Rainmaker
text: While Al Gore’s new role as partner in the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers will give the Nobel laureate an opportunity to use his expertise in environmental causes to identify investments, it is the former vice-president’s political ties that may come in even handier in nurturing green businesses.

headline: Countrywide Warns Against a Junk-Bond Rating
text: Countrywide Financial, the mortgage lender, said Monday that its ability to raise money and increase deposits in its banking subsidiary could be hampered if its credit ratings were reduced below investment grade.

headline: The Buyout Boom Is Alive and Well. In China.
text: Private equity dealmaking may be slowing in the United States, but according to The Washington Post, some of the biggest and most powerful dealmakers here have found a way to keep the buyout boom going: by aggressively pushing into China.

headline: In Defense of Predatory Lending?
text: There is a new Web site today, which I’ll get to in a moment. But first you should check out the site it is parodying, from the Community Financial Services Association of America — otherwise known as the Payday Lenders.

headline: Lampert Said to Lose $4.47 Billion in 3rd Quarter
text: The hedge fund controlled by Edward S. Lampert, the value-oriented billionaire investor, may be out $4.47 billion in the third quarter, according to press reports’ back-of-the-envelope calculations.

headline: Hedge Fund Targeted By Overstock Countersues
text: The hedge fund at the center of Overstock.com’s controversial short-selling lawsuit has filed a counterclaim against the online retailer, arguing it is trying to cover up questionable accounting and poor business decisions.

headline: Death By a Thousand Write-Downs
text: What’s really killing investors’ confidence in Wall Street firms is the uncertainty and unpredictability of the recent write-downs, David Weidner wrote in a commentary on MarketWatch. The solution may be for more firms to take a tough line on marking to market.

headline: Terra Firma Said to Unveil EMI Plans
text: British investor Guy Hands’ Terra Firma, on the hunt for additional equity investors in EMI, is telling prospective partners they can nearly quadruple their money in the struggling major label and cash out within five years, The New York Post reported.

headline: A Prince and His Palace in the Sky
text: It’s been a busy month for Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia. After helping to push Charles O. Prince III out of the top job at Citigroup, the bank’s largest shareholder is now claiming bragging rights to the world’s largest private jet.

headline: Villa With a View
text: A look at Villa San Giorgio, a renovated two-story farmhouse in Italy.

headline: Food Stuff
text: A Smoked Fish Spot in TriBeCa Cultivates a Last-Century Vibe

headline: 12 Wall Street Firms Unite for Trading Platform
text: Twelve Wall Street firms that had started competing platforms for trading unregistered securities known as 144a issues have agreed to cooperate on a single platform operated by the Nasdaq Stock Market, the exchange said Monday.

headline: Formula One’s Lewis Said to Eye I.P.O. — Of Himself
text: Lewis Hamilton, the 22-year old Formula One racing sensation who came within inches of winning the Grand Prix championship in his debut season, is now reportedly mulling another bold maneuver — listing himself on the London stock market.

headline: Accel Closes $520 Million Investment Fund
text: Early-stage venture capital firm Accel Partners announced the final closing of its 10th investment fund with $520 million on Monday.

headline: Private Equity-Backed CDM Resource Plans $140 Million I.P.O.
text: CDM Resource Partners, a company that provides natural gas contract compression services, aims to raise as much as $140 million in an initial public offering.

headline: What ‘Should’ You Do in Your Career?
text: When I decided to become a lawyer 20 years ago, it was a decision laden with shoulds, mostly from my father, who was projecting his wishes onto me. (His “Marci should be a lawyer” became “I should please my father and become a lawyer.”) If I had listened better to my own vision for a career, I might have found a career that fit me better the first time around.

headline: Vodafone Considers Selling Vodacom Shares in I.P.O.
text: The Vodafone Group , the world’s biggest provider of mobile-phone services, said it may sell shares in Vodacom Group in an initial public offering as part of Vodafone’s plan to raise its 50 percent stake in South Africa’s largest wireless provider.

headline: Sun Capital Said to Threaten Hostile Bid for Kellwood
text: Investment firm Sun Capital Partners is threatening to take its $544 million buyout offer for Kellwood to the company’s shareholders unless the apparel maker’s board reconsiders its rejection of the bid, the Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday in its online edition.

headline: Macquarie Profits Rise in 1st Half, but Outlook Is Glum
text: Macquarie Group, Australia’s biggest securities firm, said a rally in equity markets may falter in the second half, making it harder to repeat its record 45 percent profit growth of the first six months.

headline: $900,000 Homes
text: Properties on the market in Florida, Montana and Washington.

headline: Words on Warming: Which Message Works?
text: The books that tend to catch people’s attention are those at the edges of the span of thought on an issue of the day, whether it is the existence of God, the way out of Iraq or the best way to avoid global warming.

headline: Cisco Launches Eastern European Venture Fund
text: Cisco Systems said Monday that it will launch a program to make venture capital investments in technology companies in Central and Eastern Europe, a first step into a region where the networking giant hopes to fund startups and potentially make acquisitions.

headline: For Barclays’ Diamond, Succesion Is a No-Brainer
text: Some industry observers cried foul over the lack of succession planning at Citigroup and Merrill Lynch, which became apparent this month after the two banks ousted their chieftains. Financial News now helpfully suggests that the Merrill and Citigroup could get a lesson in succession from Robert Diamond, the head of Barclays‘ investment banking unit.

headline: What’s Next for E*Trade?
text: E*Trade Financial lost more than half its market value Monday, after an analyst suggested that the company might have to seek bankruptcy protection if panicked customers withdraw deposits because of its faltering mortgage investments.

headline: The Early Word: Thompson’s Campaign
text: Fred Thompson picks up a major endorsement today, in the form of support from the National Right to Life Committee, whose backing Mitt Romney and Mike Huckabee had also sought.

headline: Brats Rule!
text: Don’t tell your child, the class cut-up, about the lead story of today’s paper:

headline: For Crack Offenders, Reduced Circumstances?
Citi Reorganizes Its Capital Markets Group
text: Citigroup‘s embattled capital markets unit is regrouping under its new leader.

headline: Questions Over Police Shooting of Man, 18
text: A police shooting of an unarmed young man drew an angry crowd in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, on Monday night and focused attention anew on the use of force by the police. Khiel Coppin, 18, died in a hail of 20 bullets fired by five police officers who had responded to his mother’s 911 call for help in a domestic dispute. The police said officers believed Mr. Coppin had a gun, but it turned out that he had been holding a hairbrush.

headline: McCain Ad: ‘Outrageous’ Spending
text: As if to signal that Senator John McCain’s campaign doesn’t need any help from outside groups, it has released a new advertisement in which he promises to “stop wasteful spending in Washington.’’

headline: Glam Lets Rivals Copy Its Ad Network Plan, and Takes a Cut
text: A deal announced Monday in which Glam will run an advertising network for the Lifetime cable network is a textbook example of how to co-opt potential competition.

headline: Oxford’s Word of the Year, and Runners-Up
text: Not everyone has joined the local food movement, but it has won over Google’s cafeteria, Barbara Kingsolver’s kitchen, writers at The New York Times, and now, leading wordsmiths at the Oxford American Dictionary, who are adding their lexicographic seal of approval:

headline: My Dirty Book Collection
text: Some people won’t lend their books because they don’t like to. I sometimes won’t lend mine because I’m embarrassed about them. Some are seriously dirty.

headline: Avoiding Climate Change: Why Americans Prevaricate and Delay on Taking Action
The WSJ goes green
text: Let it not be said that the editors of the Wall Street Journal lack ecological awareness. Today they save energy, both theirs and mine, by repeating exactly the same bogus arguments about income inequality that they made — and I refuted — fifteen years ago.

headline: Spitzer Gives Up Driver’s License Fight
text: Updated, Nov. 14 | Meeting with members of Congress in Washington, Gov. Eliot Spitzer acknowledged this morning that he had misjudged public sentiment in proposing to grant driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, but he vowed to press Washington for comprehensive immigration legislation and said his critics had stoked partisan and irresponsible fears of immigrants. (See this new post for full updates, including the text of the governor’s remarks.)

headline: Tuesday Links: Different Seahawks, Same 49ers
text: For the second week in a row, the Monday night game was a stinker. The Seahawks won, 24-0, to push the 49ers’ losing streak to seven games. Watch the highlights at your own risk. As a follow-up to the discussion Sunday about division races, add the N.F.C. West to the list of divisions that have an uninspiring race. Jerry Brewer of The Seattle Times says the good Seahawks are back, while his colleague Steve Kelly welcomes the return of the pass-happy offense. Ted Miller of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer writes that a victory over the 49ers isn’t something to build an opinion on. Perhaps that’s because, as Ray Ratto of The San Francisco Chronicle points out, the 49ers are actually getting worse, as if that’s possible. Mark Purdy of The San Jose Mercury News says that Mike Nolan’s return to the sidelines the day after his father’s death was not the stuff of TV movies.

headline: City Drivers Caught Smoking, Eating, Gabbing — and Putting on Makeup
text: Student researchers at Hunter College spent much of October observing 3,120 New York City drivers at 50 intersections and, according to their study, 1 in 3 were using cellphones, smoking, eating, drinking or grooming while operating their vehicles.The study, overseen by Peter S. Tuckel, a professor of sociology, found that more than 1 in 5 of the drivers were observed talking on their cellphones — half of them on hand-held phones, which has been illegal in New York State since 2001. In addition, about 1 in 10 drivers were engaged in other distractions like eating hamburgers and French fries, drinking coffee or soda, applying makeup, and smoking cigarettes.

headline: Fortress Posts Loss for 3rd Quarter
text: The hedge fund and private equity company Fortress Investment Group reported a third-quarter loss on Tuesday, hurt by a special charge.

headline: FX President: DVR’s Will Hurt Quality

headline: NBC Squeaks Out An Evening News Win Over ABC
text: For the first time in almost three months, “NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams” has attracted more total viewers and 25- to 54-year-old viewers than ABC’s “World News with Charles Gibson.”

headline: At CW, Overbearing Mothers Share the Stage
text: The CW will use the finale of its top-rated show, “America’s Next Top Model,” to launch a new reality show about a mother/daughter beauty pageant competition next month, the network announced on Monday.

headline: Welcome
text: With the debut of this blog, I’m happy to say that I now have the capacity to receive comments. Unfortunately, I don’t have the time to respond to every message, but if all goes well, I will be able to read them. My researcher, Amanda Millner-Fairbanks, will be posting some representative comments after every column appears, and I’ll try to blog as often as I can.

headline: Name This Solar Twin and Win a Prize
text: The Greeks believed that the Helios, the sun god who drove a chariot across the sky, had two siblings: Eos, the goddess of the dawn, and Selene, the goddess of the moon. But now astronomers have expanded the family by identifying a “solar twin.”

Instead, he chose to focus almost solely on calling for strengthening America’s military by increasing its size, something all the Republican candidates agree on.

If you can’t get rid of them, the theory goes, at least make them look better.

headline: Are Ethnic Shopping Strips Luring Suburban Customers?

The neighborhood’s central corridor, 74th Street, has become renowned as a Main Street for South Asian Americans, even though few Indians, Bangladeshis and Pakistanis actually live there, according to Madhulika S. Khandelwal, a professor of urban studies at Queens College who directs the Asian American Center there.

headline: Ratings: Boost For ‘Samantha’ and ‘Big Bang’
text: ABC remained No. 1 in the ratings on Monday thanks to consistently solid audiences for “Dancing With the Stars” and “Samantha Who.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the celebrity dancing competition earned the night’s top ratings as usual with an average of 21.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. Following it, ABC’s “Samantha Who,” with Christina Applegate, drew 14.3 million, just shy of that series’ largest audience to date.

headline: Michael Biondi, Lazard Banker, Dies at 50
text: Michael J. Biondi, a Lazard partner and a heavyweight among mergers and acquisitions bankers, died Monday evening at his home in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Biondi worked as Lazard’s co-chairman of investment banking, a role he held since 2003. The cause of death was unknown, pending an autopsy.

headline: Sundhage to Coach U.S. Women
text: According to the Associated Press, Pia Sundhage will become the coach of the U.S. women’s national team. The former Swedish star will replace Greg Ryan whose contract was not renewed after his controversial and ultimately unsuccessful stewardship during the Women’s World Cup in China.

But I just wanted to mention something that a contemporary choreographer, Trajal Harrell, said after the screenings, which pertains to this whole discussion about why there is so little back-and-forth (or at least the perception of that lack) between the dance and visual art worlds today.

headline: Press Is Invited, Then Ejected, From Jeb Bush Lunch

Bloomberg. At the very least, Mr. Bush might have something to say about the city’s new A to F grading system for schools. And maybe he’d even float a couple of ideas about the presidential politics.
