headline: Who Are You Also Known As?
text: Like many adopted people I never had a simple answer to the question, "Where did I come from?" For most people raised by their biological parents, this question can be answered by simply gazing at their parent's face. There in the turn of a nose and the curve of the eye they are reminded of where they came from. bounded by blood, a part of a human continuum passed from mother to daughter, from father to son.   (Photo: The author, the day she arrived in the United States, walking off the plane at J.F.K. airport. (Photographs courtesy of Hollee McGinnis.)) I, on the other hand, seemingly dropped out of the sky on a Boeing 747, walking, talking and potty trained. I was adopted in May 1975 at the age of 3 ½ with just the clothes on my back: a little red pant suit and vest, and white sweater trimmed in red. I have no memories of that day I arrived in America – but I have been told stories so many times that I feel like I remember: running up and down the escalators of John F. Kennedy airport after being cooped up in an airplane for 28 hours; my parents giving me lollipops because I was too big for a pacifier to quiet me on the ride to my new home in the suburbs of New York City; and pushing the Uncle Ben's white rice on the floor the first morning and eating the Entenmanns's coffee cakes instead.  My parents told me that summer of my arrival I would sing and talk in Korean. Of course they never knew what I was saying. They also told me that in those first weeks I would run up to the front door, throw my body up against it and cry and cry and say in Korean, "Jip e ka le!" My sister, born to my parents and age 9 at the time, thought it might be some strange Korean game. So she would run up to the door, throw her body against it and say, "Jip e ka le!" I can imagine my sister doing this over and over – and turning my tears into laughter. Years later my parents learned what my Korean words meant: I want to go home.   (Photo: The author, front row lower left in the red outfit at the orphanage on Tok Chok Island founded by the Maryknoll priest, Ben Zweber (center).)   This illustrates two things: first, that no matter how old a child is when adopted – whether as an infant, a toddler, or young child – they come with a history, a past that is real. Secondly, it illustrates that when we adopt, there is movement. There is a movement from one place to another, from one culture to another, from one family to another, and in these movements there are both losses and gains. The only way a child gains a family through adoption is by losing another family in some way. This paradoxical nature of adoption raises serious questions that need to be resolved: What are adoption gains and losses? And do the gains outweigh the losses?   Growing up, I was not aware of the losses in adoption, just the gains: parents and siblings and friends who loved me. Like many adopted people who have the fortune of being raised in a supportive home, I did not think much about the fact of my adoption. I thought of my adoption as one thinks about breathing – it was simply part of who I was. I was not necessarily conscious of it as a child growing up unless someone pointed it out to me. And I certainly did not feel like there was anything "wrong" because I was adopted. I grew up knowing very clearly who I was: I was Hollee.   My personal awakening to the losses of adoption began in my late adolescence when I became aware that strangers assumed I was not an American because I did not have blond hair and blue eyes or assumed I spoke Korean (or Chinese or Japanese) or complimented me on my English. I, on the other hand, did not think of myself as Korean – although I felt pride that I was — because I was raised by a non-Korean family. I felt like an imposter because people assumed I knew Korean culture based on my race, but I only knew American culture.   Thus, in my first year of college I sought to fulfill the stereotypes and assumptions people had of me based on my race. I studied Mandarin – because my college did not offer Korean at that time – and took classes in Asian art and history. But it angered me that people would make assumptions about who I was based on things I could not change: my gender, my race, my adoption status – and judge me not for the individual I was. And so in my sophomore year I changed my major to American studies because I wanted to understand how I, as an Asian woman with an Irish last name and blond-haired mother, could be an American too.   Ultimately I realized this conflict about my identity arose because I felt I had only two choices: Korean or American. The reality was that I was both. I felt to identify simply as being Asian would be to deny the love and nurture of my adoptive parents; and to identify solely as American, I would be denying my Korean ancestry and heritage. When I began to embrace both identities rather than trying to "fit in" I realized the gains in my life that came from this duality. I realized, "Well, hey, not everyone gets to be adopted internationally and have two countries and two families."   Learning about the history of intercountry adoptions, I knew I was not the only person who might feel caught between these two worlds. In fact, I was inspired by the fact that there was such a large community of adult international adoptees – an estimated quarter million in the United States — who could share their experiences, especially with the younger generation of families being formed through intercountry adoption. I felt that as a community we could truly create a space in which we could explore, and come to embrace and celebrate our dual heritages given to us by birth and adoption.   Thus, two years after college at the age of 24 I started a non-profit organization for adult intercountry adoptees in New York City — Also-Known-As. The goal of the organization was and is to share the unique experiences and identity of intercountry adoptees and their families and to celebrate the broader transcultural community. The organization works to empower those who have been adopted internationally by providing mentorship to adopted youth, building cultural bridges through awareness and appreciation of one's birth culture, and transforming racial stereotypes.   In accepting my identity as an international transracial adoptee, and rejecting the identities imposed upon me, I realized the question, "Who am I?" can only be answered by my declaration "Who I am."   Who I am is a transcultural, multicultural, interracial, hybrid, bridging worlds, being. I am Hollee McGinnis also-known-as Lee Hwa Yeong. I have an Asian face, an Irish last name, a blond-haired mother.   But who I am is not just about who I know myself to be, but who I want to also be known as in this world. At its best, intercountry adoption demonstrates to me the greatness of our human spirits to love across race, nationality and culture. But I also know that it takes a lot more than just love to make a success; – it requires courage, honesty, and commitment.   This means we must be willing to talk about the hard stuff – the discrimination, inequalities, and prejudices that exist in the world. We must also be willing to change and challenge our societies so that the gift we give our children – adopted or not – besides the love and security of a permanent family is a world that values them for who they are and who they will be – regardless of race, nationality, culture or circumstance.

headline: Marbury Leaves Knicks in Dispute
text: PHOENIX, Nov. 13 — Stephon Marbury was not the Knicks’ starting point guard Tuesday, and it was not clear when, or if, he would be again. That his future was even in question was a startling sign of how badly his once-promising career has eroded.

headline: Volatile City Tests Palestinian Police, and Peace Hopes
text: NABLUS, West Bank, Nov. 8 — This lawless city in the northern West Bank is ruled by rival militias and criminal gangs, an especially gritty illustration of why a full withdrawal of Israeli forces from the West Bank, as expected under a future peace deal, gives Israelis pause.

headline: Mets Set to Make Torrealba an Offer He Can’t Refuse
text: The last time the Mets needed a starting catcher, after the 2005 season, they went hard after the top two free agents, Ramón Hernández and Bengie Molina. General Manager Omar Minaya visited both players the first day he could and soon offered what the team believed were generous three-year contracts. Almost attached, however, was this caveat: If they took too long to decide, the Mets would move on.

headline: Looted Art Returned to Iran
text: The Italian Culture Ministry yesterday returned 41 archaeological artifacts of Middle Eastern origin to the Iranian ambassador in Italy. The pieces date between the 8th and 14th centuries and were part of a larger haul of 309 objects found by the ministry’s art-theft police in September 2005 at an antiquities fair near Milan. Experts at the National Museum of Oriental Art in Rome studied the artifacts and determined which countries they belonged to. Culture Minister Francesco Rutelli told reporters at a news conference that the Italian government had always repatriated objects it believed had been looted. “It is our moral, political and scientific obligation to do so,” he said. Italy has been waging its own successful campaign for the return of what it claimed to be plundered artifacts from American museums. The 41 objects include colorfully painted terra-cotta vases and several coins, as well a 10th-century bowl, above, from the Samanid dynasty. They had arrived in Italy via Thailand, a clandestine trade route now under investigation by the art-theft police, said its chief, General Giovanni Nistri.

headline: Spitzer Dropping His Driver’s License Plan
text: ALBANY, Nov. 13 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer is abandoning his plan to issue driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, saying that opposition is just too overwhelming to move forward with such a policy.

headline: For Olympics, China’s Marketers Are Showing Their Pride
text: THERE are those who consider the Summer Olympics a quadrennial exercise in hyperbolic marketing, a five-ring circus of commercialism interrupted occasionally for televised glimpses of muscular youth doing something with batons or volleyballs.

headline: Olean: Parents Accused of Cover-Up
text: The parents of a Long Island teenager involved in a hit-and-run crash in January that killed a freshman at the University of Connecticut were charged yesterday with helping him cover up the crime. The teenager, Anthony Alvino, 19, of Lindenhurst, was charged in February with fleeing after fatally hitting the freshman, Carlee Wines, 19, of Manalapan, N.J., with his Nissan Armada in a crosswalk at the university’s campus in Storrs on Jan. 20. Mr. Alvino pleaded no contest to felony charges and is awaiting sentencing in Connecticut. Yesterday, his parents, Donna and Anthony Alvino, were charged in Olean City Court with traveling to St. Bonaventure University in upstate New York, where their son is a student, after the accident and bringing his truck back to Long Island for repairs. They faced charges of tampering with physical evidence, hindering prosecution and conspiracy.

headline: Awaiting Its Star Turn, Nevada Fights for Respect
text: LAS VEGAS — The idea was a simple one. The presidential primary calendar lacked an early Western state, and so with an ample dose of lobbying by Senator Harry Reid last year, the Nevada caucus was moved to Jan. 19, right between the Iowa caucus and the New Hampshire primary.

headline: Sex Diseases Still Rising; Chlamydia Is Leader
text: The incidence of gonorrhea, which had declined sharply, has risen in the last two years in this country while the number of chlamydia and syphilis cases continue to rise, federal health officials said yesterday.

headline: Sharp Drop Seen in Deaths From Ills Fought by Vaccine
text: Death rates for 13 diseases that can be prevented by childhood vaccinations are at all-time lows in the United States, according to a study released yesterday.

headline: Before Shooting in Brooklyn, a History of Mental Illness and Family Discord
text: It was a familiar exchange of pleasantries. Denise Owens would wheel her cart into the C-Town Supermarket across the street from her grim apartment complex on Gates Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant. Alan Dorsette, 15, a cashier at the store who lived down the hall from her, would ask, “How’s your son?”

headline: As Home Depot Fights a Weak Economy, Wal-Mart Sees a Ray of Holiday Hope
text: Economic unease, from the credit markets to the gas pump, is proving a boon to the nation’s largest discount retailer, Wal-Mart Stores, but a bust for the biggest home improvement chain, Home Depot, as consumers start to make choices about spending this holiday season.

headline: New Chief Prosecutor at the Hague
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has nominated the Belgian criminologist Serge Brammertz to succeed Carla Del Ponte early next year as the chief prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Mr. Brammertz’s candidacy became known informally this summer, but he had to complete his mandate as the head of the United Nations inquiry into the killing in 2005 of Rafik Hariri, the former prime minister of Lebanon. Mr. Ban also nominated Daniel Bellemare, a Canadian prosecutor, to take over the Lebanon investigation. Both appointments require the approval of the Security Council, which is likely.

headline: Washington Post Critic Apologizes to Ex-Mayor
text: The Washington Post said its music critic, Tim Page, had apologized to the former mayor of Washington, Marion Barry, for calling him a “crack addict” in an e-mail message. Mr. Page sent the message to an aide to Mr. Barry, who is a city council member, in response to a press release. The message asked that his name be taken off a mailing list. “It’s the stupidest thing I’ve done in 30 years of journalism,” Mr. Page said, according to an article in The Post yesterday. “I am deeply ashamed for what I did and I know how hurtful my words could be.” The newspaper said “appropriate” action had been taken against Mr. Page, who is scheduled to go on a four-month leave on Jan. 1.

headline: Chinese Minister Visits Iran for Talks
text: TEHRAN, Nov. 13 — The Chinese foreign minister, Yang Jiechi, arrived here on Tuesday to urge Iran to comply with the international demands to halt its uranium-enrichment program, in advance of two reports on the country’s nuclear program.

headline: 3 Dead in Blast at Philippine Congress
text: MANILA, Nov. 13 — An explosion on Tuesday evening in the Philippine House of Representatives killed three people, one of them a lawmaker, and wounded several others.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Study Compares States’ Math and Science Scores With Other Countries’
text: American students even in low-performing states like Alabama do better on math and science tests than students in most foreign countries, including Italy and Norway, according to a new study released yesterday. That’s the good news.

headline: Taking a Whack at Making a Car
text: Los Angeles

headline: Students of Arabic Learn at a Syrian Crossroads
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — This sleepy capital has long been a popular destination for foreigners who want to learn Arabic. Drawn by the charmingly well-preserved old city, an easily understood Arabic dialect and dirt cheap tuition prices subsidized by the government, thousands of foreign students enroll in language institutes here every year.

headline: Gaza: Fatah Members Arrested
text: Hamas security forces arrested supporters of the rival Fatah movement in the Gaza Strip, a day after a mass rally in honor of Yasir Arafat, the late Palestinian leader and founder of Fatah, ended with six dead and more than a hundred wounded. Hamas, which rules Gaza, also threatened a political crackdown, saying in a statement that its leaders would “take measures” to ensure the “protection of internal security.” Ehab al-Ghsein, a spokesman for the Hamas-run Interior Ministry in Gaza, said that “tens” of Fatah supporters had been arrested; Fatah officials put the number in the hundreds.

headline: Barrels of Crude Imported From Canada
text: When I first read about “Kenny vs. Spenny,” I thought that the Canadians were finally getting their revenge. They were tired of being nothing but a “South Park” punch line and, in a diabolically clever move, were sending us their grossest television show as a way of lowering the general tone of our culture even further.

headline: When Packaging Radical Art, Be Careful Not to Damage the Contents
text: These days two Butoh festivals have something in common with Performa 07, the performance art festival that’s trying with all its might to capture New York in the 1970s (with less grime). They show that the framing of choreography can present even more challenges than the choreography itself. Packaging a radical artistic movement  extending its life through artificial means  is a good way to sap its spirit.

headline: A Little Planning Can Mean More for Heirs Later
text: MANY business owners are so consumed with day-to-day operations that they don’t think about estate planning. But the federal estate tax, with a top rate of 45 percent, can have a big effect on the business you leave behind, and planning while you are hearty is the best way to manage that.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An Agence France-Presse report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about French literary awards misspelled the surname of the winner of the Prix Femina. He is Eric Fottorino, not Fittorino.

headline: Oil Price Drops Sharply as Global Agency Sees Demand Easing
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 13 — The price of crude oil dropped sharply on Tuesday after a prominent energy group lowered its estimate for worldwide oil demand, saying high prices were harming consumption.

headline: In Complaint, a Portrait of a Company Marked by Rivalry
text: The lengthy defamation complaint filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by Judith Regan creates a picture of rivalry and retaliation within the HarperCollins publishing house.

headline: Plan to Cut Jet Pollution Is Approved in Europe
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — The European Parliament voted Tuesday to impose quotas on the emission of carbon dioxide by airlines, setting up a fight with the United States, which argues against unilateral actions on aviation, a relatively small but rapidly growing source of global warming gases.

headline: Bear Stearns Takes a $1.2 Billion Write-Down
text: The brokerage firm, Bear Stearns, its shares suffering in the wake of the credit crunch, said today that it would take a $1.2 billion write-down on its exposure to securities tied to subprime mortgages.

headline: Disgraced Rider and New U.S. Team Take the Lead Against Doping
text: Sitting in a jail cell in Biarritz, France, David Millar realized he had lost everything: the contract with his professional cycling team, the new home he was building, the reputation he had developed as one of the world’s top riders.

headline: Your Computers Are Down? No Problema
text: SUDDENLY, all 50 computers at a Yonkers car dealer lose their Internet access.

headline: Recipe: Bourbon Barbecue Sauce
text: Time: 20 minutes

headline: Health of Economy Is Top Concern (Emphasis on Health)
text: Americans say they’re not going to spend as much money on holiday gifts this year as they did last year. No wonder. Many of the elements of bad economic times are coalescing — rising gas prices, a devalued housing market and stagnating wages. Depending on the depth of the economic downturn forecast last week by Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, financial worries could eclipse the war in Iraq as the driving issue in the presidential campaign.

headline: Manhattan: Helping the Council Track Complaints
text: Following Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s lead, City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, left, announced a new case-tracking tool yesterday, similar to the city’s 311 system, to help manage and resolve constituent complaints. The system, called CouncilStat, will be fully installed in January and is intended to help council members track the exasperating everyday problems, big and small, that affect their constituents, from nightclub noise to dwindling supplies of affordable housing. Ms. Quinn said it would also allow members to share data and problem-solving ideas, identify local and citywide trends, and focus city resources where they are most needed. “One of the most important things we do as council members and council staff is serve New Yorkers, deal and help the constituents who call, or now e-mail, our offices asking for help,” Ms. Quinn said at a news conference at City Hall.

headline: Broadway’s Showdown: The Lowdown
text: The main attraction on Broadway this week continues to be the street theater of picketing stagehands. And from the way things look, it could be a long run.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Co-Host Quits New NPR Show

headline: Recipe: Parsley Purée
text: Time: 10 minutes

headline: More Gravy? It’s Nice to Have Options
text: THOUGH there is pleasure in the ritual of Thanksgiving, its culinary choices are limited by the near absolute necessity of the turkey. Almost as inexorable is the gravy, perhaps the most hair-raising aspect of the meal, since it is made at the last minute and requires two burners on a crowded stove.

headline: A Troubled Man and 20 Police Bullets in Brooklyn
text: A troubled 18-year-old man. A furious family argument inside a first-floor Brooklyn apartment. A 911 call. Then, in the darkness, 20 bullets fired by five police officers. The 18-year-old is fatally wounded. The police say he was holding a hairbrush.

headline: Rangers’ Avery Is Fined for Pregame Altercation
text: The National Hockey League fined the Rangers and the Maple Leafs yesterday as a result of an incident before their game Saturday night in Toronto. Rangers forward Sean Avery was also fined, but he challenged a report that he made derogatory comments about the recent cancer diagnosis of Maple Leafs forward Jason Blake.

headline: Building a Nation of Polyglots, Starting With the Very Young
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

headline: Spitzer Drops Bid to Offer Licenses More Widely
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer formally announced today that he would abandon his plan to give driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, conceding that his best efforts to sell New Yorkers on the merits of his proposal had clearly failed.

headline: Following the Tacos South for the Winter
text: AND so the migration of the taco eaters begins. The sun has set on the Red Hook ball fields’ food vendors for the season, so south and east the pilgrims go, to Fifth Avenue in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, winter feeding ground of the displaced soccer taco enthusiast.

headline: Ford Workers Ratify Contract
text: DETROIT, Nov. 14  United Automobile Workers members at Ford Motor approved a new four-year contract by the widest margin of any auto company, the union said today.

headline: Bush, Confident on Economy, Vetoes Domestic Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — Even in the darkest times, President Bush has been able to draw hope from the almost uncanny ability of the American economy to endure shock after shock with surprisingly limited damage.

headline: Good News: Housing’s Down, Market’s Off, Oil’s Up
text: Until yesterday’s rally on Wall Street, the news on the business pages has sounded pretty grim lately. Stocks are still down 6 percent from their peak this year, and oil is near a record high. The dollar, incredibly, is worth only 96 Canadian cents. And house prices will be falling for a long time to come.

headline: An Infamous Explosion, and the Smoldering Memory of Radicalism
text: On a brisk November morning, Cathy Wilkerson strides down one of the city’s finest streets, 11th between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, her glance sweeping across the row of handsome town houses, alighting nowhere in particular. “The street I remember,” Ms. Wilkerson says, “was a lot less polished.”

headline: Manhattan: Suing to Get Police Data
text: The New York Civil Liberties Union filed suit yesterday to have the police make public a database of information that officers have recorded on more than 800,000 stops of civilians since the beginning of 2006. The lawsuit, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, comes after requests for the database by both the civil rights group and the City Council were denied. Christopher Dunn, associate legal director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said the group expected the data to confirm its contention that stop-and-frisk operations have been improperly used and that they employ racial profiling. The police have turned over the database to the Rand Corporation, a private nonprofit research group, to determine if there are flaws in police procedures. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, at a news conference yesterday, said that the results of the Rand analysis were expected soon, but that he did not believe the data contained evidence of racial profiling.

headline: As She Awaits Broadway Debut, Her Opening-Night Dress Is on Standby
text: Alexandra Wilson, who was supposed to make her Broadway debut tonight, imagined many things surrounding her big break. Pre-curtain jitters? Check. Looking glam at the opening-night party? Check. Thrilling applause and rave reviews? Absolutely. A stagehands’ strike that would cripple Broadway and keep the curtain from going up as scheduled?

headline: For the Finale, a Perfect Pie (or Two)
text: THE three pillars of the Thanksgiving dinner are turkey, cranberry sauce and pie. Pie baking, happily, allows more room for variation than the other tried, true and perennially required dishes do. Pies and tarts also represent a great contribution to the dinner for a guest who, when asking, “can I bring anything?” receives a resounding “Yes!”

headline: A. F. Hawkins, Civil Rights Lawmaker, Dies at 100
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — Augustus F. Hawkins, who was California’s first black representative in Congress, serving 14 terms in the House, and who had a hand in important civil rights legislation, including the Civil Rights Act of 1964, died on Saturday in Bethesda, Md. He was 100 and had lived in Washington since retiring from Congress in January 1991.

headline: The Prince and the Plane
text: On Monday, a Saudi billionaire, Prince Walid bin Talal, placed an order with Airbus for his new private plane, the A380. That superjumbo will be the largest private jet on the planet. No hard figures were mentioned, but the asking price for an A380, which weighs 200 tons more than a Boeing 747 and has a floor space of about 6,000 square feet, is around $300 million. That is for the raw plane itself, hull, wings, engines, etc. — nothing to distinguish its interior from the hold of a cargo plane. But even unfurnished, the purchase of this Airbus offers some interesting numbers to think about.

headline: Pointed Question Puts McCain in a Tight Spot
text: When presidential candidates appear at public forums, passions about the field are often on vivid display. Monday, Senator John McCain received a question from a woman in Hilton Head Island, S.C., that was blunt and harsh.

headline: Hamas Arrests Fatah Supporters
text: GAZA, Nov. 13 — Hamas police officers rounded up scores of supporters of the rival Fatah movement here today, a day after a mass rally in honor of Yasir Arafat, the late Palestinian leader and founder of the Fatah, ended in violence.

headline: Winemaking That Doesn’t Require a Mortgage
text: San Francisco

headline: Monkeys in the Parks, Monkeys in the Palace
text: NEW DELHI, Nov. 13 — The authorities here managed to do very little about the city’s soaring wild monkey population — until the deputy mayor toppled from his terrace to his death as he tried to fend off a gang of the animals.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A film review in Weekend on Friday about “No Country for Old Men,” in which Tommy Lee Jones is one of the stars, misidentified the role Mr. Jones played in “The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada” in comparing his part in the new film to two previous roles. He played a ranch hand  not the sheriff, a role played by Dwight Yoakam.

headline: Brooklyn: Two Men Accused in Mob Killing
text: Prosecutors opened their murder case yesterday against two men accused of hiring assassins to kill an associate of the Genovese crime family in 1994. The defendants, Carmine Polito and Mario Fortunato, had been found guilty of similar charges in federal court, but that conviction was overturned. A federal appeals court ruled that prosecutors had failed to prove the men had committed the crime to increase their underworld status. In June, a state appeals court ruled that the men could stand trial again in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Two of the confessed assassins are expected to testify, but the star witness is a man who was also shot in the attack. That witness, Michael D’Urso, has confessed to his own violent and diverse range of crimes, committed before he became a government informer.

headline: Producer Prices Steady in October
text: Spending is slowing  but so is inflation, offering the Federal Reserve more room to stimulate the economy by lowering interest rates next month, if it wants.

headline: Powerful Quake Hits Northern Chile
text: A powerful earthquake measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale ripped through northern Chile today, causing panic, power outages and some structural damage, and closing down, at least temporarily, some of the country’s copper mines, according to news reports.

headline: U.N. Envoy to Myanmar Calls Junta Responsive
text: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 13 — The United Nations special envoy to Myanmar said Tuesday that the situation there was “qualitatively different” from the way it was in the aftermath of September’s brutal crackdown on protesters, but that the authorities had still showed no willingness to free the pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

headline: Calendar
text: Porcelain Diplomacy

headline: In First Ads for Giuliani, a Wild City Is Made Over
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York will begin advertising this week in New Hampshire with a commercial that dramatically presents him as the man who tamed a crime-ridden and unmanageable city in spite of typical human foibles.

headline: German Official Resigns in Blow to Coalition
text: BERLIN, Nov. 13 — Germany’s second most powerful politician, Vice Chancellor Franz Müntefering, announced Tuesday that he would resign from office. His departure is likely to destabilize the already shaky power-sharing coalition between the country’s two biggest parties.

headline: New Coach for Women’s U.S. Soccer Team
text: Pia Sundhage, who coached in the United States in the Women’s United Soccer Association, has been named coach of the women’s national team through the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

headline: F.B.I. Says Guards Killed 14 Iraqis Without Cause
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — Federal agents investigating the Sept. 16 episode in which Blackwater security personnel shot and killed 17 Iraqi civilians have found that at least 14 of the shootings were unjustified and violated deadly-force rules in effect for security contractors in Iraq, according to civilian and military officials briefed on the case.

headline: Keeping Up With Customers: A Phone List Is So Yesterday
text: EVERY small business needs some way to share and keep track of its customers and prospects. But finding the right collection of software tools and techniques is not easy, and the choices can be confounding. There are three major decisions to make.

headline: C.I.A. Officer Admits Guilt Over Hezbollah Files
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — A Lebanese-born C.I.A. officer who had previously worked as an F.B.I. agent pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges that she illegally sought classified information from government computers about the radical Islamic group Hezbollah.

headline: Trying to Escape Attackers, Teenager Is Shot to Death
text: A 16-year-old boy running from attackers in Newark yesterday afternoon was fatally shot in the back just as he was climbing over a fence, the police said.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,850 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: After 5 Decades, Still Igniting the Screen
text: In August 1952 the director of “Monika” began shooting this wistful story of young passion and the autumn that inevitably follows in its wake. It had been a busy year. He had directed one of his own plays and been hired as the director of a theater company. He had shot and finished another film, the 11th in an already complicated career, though it had yet to open. He was supporting two ex-wives and five children from those unions, as well as a third wife and an infant son. Ingmar Bergman had just turned 34.

headline: News Writers Weigh Step Toward Strike Against CBS
text: With one writers’ strike already under way, CBS will face the prospect of a second one when news writers, producers, editors and artists take a strike authorization vote tomorrow and Friday.

headline: Lawyers Rally in Support of Colleagues in Pakistan
text: They stood outside the county courthouse in Lower Manhattan, a crowd of lawyers and judges in suits and ties, and listened to other lawyers behind a lectern quote Mandela, Cromwell, Shakespeare and President Bush.

headline: When Hillary Clinton Faced Down Sexism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Home Is Where the Heart Is, but Then the Heart Moves
text: In “I for India” Sandhya Suri offers her family’s immigrant experience as a springboard for questions of nationality, filial responsibility and what we mean by home.

headline: Where’s That Energy Bill?
text: Two months ago, Washington was filled with hope that Congress would produce an energy bill that would begin to address the two great challenges of oil dependency and climate change. Each chamber had approved respectable if incomplete measures that could be combined in one outstanding bill. Then the bills disappeared into the back rooms as Democratic leaders tried to negotiate a final product.

headline: Digging a Hole
text: With five words in an interview with reporters for The Times yesterday, Gen. Pervez Musharraf showed how far removed he is from understanding what democracy is, nevermind fulfilling his oft-broken promise to lead Pakistan back toward a stable and prosperous future.

headline: Fed to Reveal More About Its Forecasts
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 — The Federal Reserve announced plans today to take some of the mystery out of its policy-making, saying it will disclose more information about its economic forecasts — and also, implicitly, about its objectives for growth and inflation.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Nov. 4 about the state of the presidential campaign a year before the election misstated, in some editions, the surname of a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee who said the Democrats’ desire to win had eased some of their traditional internal divisions. He is Joe Andrew, not Andrews. (Go to Article)

headline: Recipe: Pumpkin, White Bean and Kale Ragout
text: Time: 1 1/4 hours

headline: Ira Levin, of ‘Rosemary’s Baby,’ Dies at 78
text: Ira Levin, a mild-mannered playwright and novelist who liked nothing better than to give people the creeps — and who did so repeatedly, with best-selling novels like “Rosemary’s Baby,” “The Stepford Wives” and “The Boys From Brazil” — died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Few Friends for Proposal on Media
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The head of the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday announced the details of his plan to relax the longstanding rule that had prevented a company from owning both a newspaper and a radio or television station in the same city.

headline: 4th Woman Joins U.S. Bias Suit Against Bloomberg L.P.
text: Another woman has joined the federal government’s lawsuit against Bloomberg L.P., the financial services and media company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, accusing the company of discriminating against pregnant employees.

headline: Ex-Publisher’s Suit Plays a Giuliani-Kerik Angle
text: Judith Regan, the former book publisher, says in a lawsuit filed yesterday protesting her dismissal by the News Corporation, the media conglomerate, that a senior executive there encouraged her to lie to federal investigators about her past affair with Bernard B. Kerik after he had been nominated to become homeland security secretary in late 2004.

headline: A Sudden Affliction, and a Lifetime of Sacrifices
text: Fourteen years later, the Bushati family still does not know just what happened the day their son, Gjergj, then 9, was found unconscious at school in Albania. He was having a piano lesson with a professor who had taken him under his wing. The professor briefly left Gjergj alone in the room, and returned to find him sprawled over a desk.

headline: A Day After a School Brawl, a Town Asks, Why?
text: LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 13 — It began as fisticuffs on Monday morning, but it quickly mushroomed into an hourlong brawl involving 150 students, more than four dozen police officers, pepper spray, and flying tables and chairs.

headline: Murdoch Said to Stress Free Access to Wall St. Journal’s Web Site
text: Rupert Murdoch says he plans to abolish subscription fees at The Wall Street Journal’s Web site, according to news accounts from Australia. This apparently was news to executives at his company and The Journal, who cautioned that the decision might not be final.

headline: Job Insecurities
text: Whether they blame the housing bust or the credit squeeze or globalization, Americans are increasingly worried about losing their jobs. When House members go home for their extended Thanksgiving break they can at least assure anxious constituents that they’re trying to make joblessness less devastating. Senators may have to think about vacationing elsewhere.

headline: Polls Find Voters Weighing Issues vs. Electability
text: This article was reported by Adam Nagourney, Marjorie Connelly and Dalia Sussman and written by Mr. Nagourney.

headline: A Wuthering Heights Worth Six Figures
text: A first edition of the Emily Brontë novel “Wuthering Heights,” published in 1847 under the pseudonym Ellis Bell because the author feared she faced prejudice as a female writer, sold at an auction in London yesterday for $236,000. It had been expected to fetch $62,000 to $103,000. A spokeswoman for Bonhams, the auction house, said the book had been bought by a private client and would remain in Britain. The book’s previous owner, Anne Reid, who is studying at the London Art Academy, received the book as a gift from her grandfather when she was a child. It had been in her family for four generations.

headline: Kurds and Arabs Shelter Side by Side in Distrust and Misery
text: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq, Nov. 7 — On a barren, trash-strewn plain on the outskirts of this city, two groups — one poor and Kurdish, the other displaced and Arab — huddle side by side in distrust and suspicion.

headline: Religious Metal: Same Evil, Different Result
text: From time immemorial, or at least the early 1970s, an arm pumped upward at a heavy metal show with a raised pinky and forefinger was the Devil’s horns, signifying real or mocking Satanism. No more. Some Christians love metal too.

headline: Weak Dollar May Reduce European Bonuses
text: LONDON, Nov. 13  The drop of the American dollar against the British pound and the euro may claim some of the bonus money of European investment bankers as the latest victim.

headline: Stem Cells Taken From Cloned Monkey Embryos
text: Researchers in Oregon are reporting today that they used cloning to produce early monkey embryos and then extracted stem cells from those embryos.

headline: Cable Plays Hardball With the N.F.L.
text: Power is what the N.F.L. is about, and power is what it desperately lacks in its battles against cable operators who will not carry the NFL Network on basic or digital basic.

headline: The Yellowing of the Potato Fields
text: AMERICA’S potato farmers spent decades narrowing their crop to a few breeds best suited to frozen French fries and dehydrated mashed potatoes. Now, even large-scale growers are expanding their horizons, following the lead of small farmers with paradigm-changing yellow potatoes like Yellow Finn, Bintje, Butterball, Gold Rush, Carola and Désirée.

headline: Raising a Glass to Turkey and Tradition
text: NO Thanksgiving is complete without a turkey. Usually it’s me.

headline: Abu Dhabi to Guide Buying for Its Guggenheim Branch
text: The government of Abu Dhabi will oversee acquisitions for the new Guggenheim museum in the United Arab Emirates, officials announced yesterday.

headline: Chemical Plant Security
text: To the Editor:

headline: Birder Admits Killing Cat, but Was It Animal Cruelty?
text: GALVESTON, Tex., Nov. 13 — Jurors heard opening arguments on Tuesday in the trial of a bird-watching enthusiast who fatally shot a cat that he said was stalking endangered shorebirds.

headline: Four Transplant Recipients Contract H.I.V.
text: Four transplant recipients in Chicago have contracted H.I.V. from an organ donor, the first known cases in more than a decade in which the virus was spread by organ transplants.

headline: From Boutique to Big Time
text: THE first time Jennifer Morrill’s father suggested that she leave the corporate world to help run his small business, she turned him down.

headline: Where Savage Parasites Rot a Nation From Within
text: In the United States organized crime has entered a Tony Soprano twilight, as small-time bosses carve up ever-smaller wedges of a shrinking pie. In Italy, by contrast, all systems are go. In shipping, fashion and construction, to name just three booming businesses, the mob holds sway, often acting through, rather than despite, local government. All told, according to a recent report by an Italian small-business association, mob-related activity accounts for the single largest sector of the Italian economy.

headline: Turkish Aircraft Attack Abandoned Iraqi Villages
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 13  Turkish military aircraft attacked a handful of abandoned villages in northern Iraq on Tuesday, Iraqi officials said, in the first confirmed cross-border assault since tensions between Turkey and Kurdish rebels began intensifying last month.

headline: Thomas Crown Goes to the Middle East
text: Pierce Brosnan is to return as the debonair thief and corporate raider Thomas Crown in a sequel to the 1999 remake of the 1968 “Thomas Crown Affair,” which starred Steve McQueen and Faye Dunaway, Variety reported. Tentatively titled “The Thomas Crown Affair 2,” the MGM film, to be directed by Paul Verhoeven, will be set in the Middle East, where Crown becomes enmeshed in a feud and must decide how much he will risk for love.

headline: Recipe: Curried Lentils With Sweet Potatoes and Swiss Chard
text: Time: 1 hour

headline: Youth Handles the Serving, in Large, Robust Portions
text: Inevitably, the Sunday afternoon concert at Carnegie Hall by the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela became an occasion to assess the work of the ensemble’s talked-about and fast-rising music director, Gustavo Dudamel, making his New York debut.

headline: Rivera Turns the Tables, Making the Yanks Wait
text: The Yankees’ latest offer to Mariano Rivera — three years for $45 million — would make him by far the highest-paid closer ever, and team officials are somewhat surprised he has not yet accepted. The initial offer was for $5 million less, and the Yankees have no plans to change it again.

headline: How the Polls Were Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News polls of Iowa and New Hampshire are based on telephone interviews conducted with likely caucusgoers and primary voters, respectively, throughout each state.

headline: Korean Leaders Open Talks
text: SEOUL, Nov. 14 — Meeting for the first time in 15 years, the prime ministers of North and South Korea today discussed turning their disputed western sea border, the site of naval skirmishes as recent as five years ago, into a “peace and cooperation zone” for joint fishing and manufacturing.

headline: A Lover Is Dumped, With Bel Canto Drama
text: Opera is drama, so we want to see realistic-looking people on stage. Opera is music, so we want to hear dramatic, compelling voices. These, roughly speaking, are two prevalent schools of thought about opera. And they went head to head in the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Bellini’s “Norma” on Monday night.

headline: New Princeton Coach Aims to Revive Tradition
text: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13 — Sydney Johnson does not like to look too far beyond his next challenge, which is Wednesday against Iona. But Johnson, the first-year Princeton coach and former Tigers star, understands that he has to a lot more to do than win basketball games. He is in charge of bringing the mystique back to Princeton.

headline: Recipe: Brussels Sprouts and Chestnuts in Brown Butter Sauce
text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: Strike Cripples Travel in Parts of France
text: PARIS, Nov. 14 — A national transport strike crippled parts of France on Wednesday as labor unions and President Nicolas Sarkozy faced off in a potentially decisive confrontation over his plans to curb the early retirement benefits of a small group of public sector workers.

headline: Apocalypse Soon: A Mushroom Cloud Doesn’t Stall 2008 Electioneering
text: “Southland Tales,” Richard Kelly’s funny, audacious, messy and feverishly inspired look at America and its discontents, opens with the very biggest of bangs. The place is Texas, the time is 2005, and a crowd of laughing men, women and children are celebrating the Fourth of July when a mushroom cloud blooms in the sky, igniting World War III. Not long after the smoke clears, Justin Timberlake, playing an Iraq war veteran with a thing for quoting Revelation, ominously intones in voice-over: “This is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends, not with a whimper but with a bang.”

headline: Rocky’s Next Arena: Broadway?
text: A musical version of Sylvester Stallone’s 1976 Academy Award-winning film, “Rocky,” is in the works, Playbill.com reported. The Tony winner Thomas Meehan, who wrote the books for “Annie,” “The Producers” and “Young Frankenstein,” is writing the libretto. He said that Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty, who teamed for “Ragtime,” “Seussical” and “Glorious Ones,” are composing lyrics and music, and that Joe Mantello (“Wicked”) is in line to be the director. Mr. Meehan said, “Sylvester Stallone won’t be in it, but he’s given us his blessing.” Ms. Ahrens said the project was in its “exploratory” stage, adding, “I really think it’s premature to discuss anything about it.”... “Little House on the Prairie,” a musical based on the “Little House” children’s novels by Laura Ingalls Wilder (1867-1957), will have its premiere next year at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, The Associated Press reported. Joe Dowling, artistic director of the Guthrie, said the show would be directed by Francesca Zambello, who brought the property to his attention. The book is being written by Rachel Sheinkin, who won a 2005 Tony Award for best book of a musical for “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee.” The “Little House” books draw from the 1870s and ’80s, when Wilder was growing up as a member of the Ingalls family in Wisconsin, Kansas, Minnesota and South Dakota. Mr. Dowling said Wilder’s work “has a deep and powerful connection to the people of the Midwest,” adding, “This musical fits perfectly within the Guthrie’s goal to develop new work that speaks directly to this community.”

headline: Side Dish or Main, Depending on Who’s Eating
text: FROM an omnivore’s perspective, Thanksgiving should be a vegetarian’s feast. After all, aren’t the side dishes usually the best part of the meal?

headline: Jets’ Vilma Speaks, a Little, About His Knee and Surgery
text: Jonathan Vilma, the Jets’ star inside linebacker and defensive captain, finally spoke yesterday about the mysterious knee injury that ended his season. But he did not tell much.

headline: O.J. Simpson Faces Trial in Hotel Confrontation
text: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 14 — O.J. Simpson will once again face a trial, this time on a dozen charges stemming from a Sept 13 hotel-room confrontation here that could send him to prison, possibly for life, if he is convicted.

headline: Should Hillary Pretend to Be a Flight Attendant?
text: In 2005, a year after Ellie Grossman, a doctor, met Ray Fisman, a professor, on a blind date, she was talking to her grandmother about her guy.

headline: HSBC Takes $3.4 Billion Charge
text: LONDON, Nov. 14  HSBC Holdings warned today that losses in the United States housing market were spreading to credit card and other consumer loans, forcing the bank to set aside $3.4 billion to cover bad loans, more than it had forecast about four months ago.

headline: Send the State Department to War
text: Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

headline: No Blue Monday at ABC
text: ABC remained No. 1 in the ratings on Monday thanks to consistently solid audiences for “Dancing With the Stars” and “Samantha Who.” The celebrity dancing competition earned the night’s top ratings as usual, with an average of 21.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Following it, ABC’s “Samantha Who,” with Christina Applegate, drew 14.3 million, just shy of that series’s largest audience to date. CBS’s comedy lineup ranked second in the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, helping that network finish a strong runner-up for the night over all. Among adults 18 to 49, CBS nearly tied ABC, partly due to dominating the 10 o’clock hour with “CSI: Miami” (15.4 million), which eclipsed ABC’s “Bachelor” (9.2 million) and NBC’s “Journeyman” (6.2 million). NBC ranked third over all with mediocre results from “Chuck” at 8 (7.6 million). NBC’s “Heroes” at 9 (11.1 million) showed slight improvement in its time slot to earn its best ratings in four weeks. Fox was fourth for the night with “Prison Break” at 8 (7.2 million), followed by “K-Ville” at 9 (4.7 million).

headline: For G.M., Better Cars, Worse Sales
text: DETROIT, Nov. 13 — This year, General Motors has been getting some attention that it isn’t accustomed to: warm reviews for its new cars.

headline: Massachusetts: Abortion Clinic Buffer Zones
text: Gov. Deval Patrick signed a bill establishing a 35-foot zone around abortion clinics that protesters cannot enter. Supporters of the law say it is meant to shield women entering the clinics from harassment and unwanted attention. Opponents say the law violates free speech. Previous state law, enacted in 2000, said protesters could not go within six feet of a person if they were within an 18-foot zone outside a clinic.

headline: France: Nationwide Transit Strike
text: Most trains in France stopped running as rail unions walked out in a strike that was expected to last until at least Friday. The national strike, the second in a month, is being held to protest plans by President Nicolas Sarkozy to overhaul early retirement arrangements for about 500,000 workers in the public sector. Five of six national trains had stopped, the state-owned rail company SNCF said on its Web site. Suburban and intercity networks were expected to shut down most operations. The chaos was expected to be greatest in and around Paris.

headline: For the Guy Who Wants More Than a Little Off the Top
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: These Angels Like to Work as a Team
text: YOU would think that if a quarter of a million angel investors were pouring $25.6 billion into fledgling companies, as they were last year, finding one to put money in your own venture would not be hard. Think again: wealthy investors, or angels, don’t advertise themselves.

headline: Unfazed by Market Ills, Hedge Fund Has Debut
text: FIRST came the private equity and hedge fund public offering frenzy, then the bust. Now comes I.P.O.’s, Act II.

headline: Two Coasts, Two Strikes: Notes From the Field
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rebuffing U.S., Musharraf Calls Crackdown Crucial to a Fair Vote
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 13 — Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, on Tuesday rejected an appeal by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to lift his state of emergency, insisting in an interview that it was the best way to ensure free and fair elections.

headline: The Villain Everyone Loves to Hate
text: A Shakespeare comedy opened the Classic Stage Company’s season last night. But it is not one of those larky romps in which mismatched romances are sorted out happily, or cross-dressing dames show everyone the way toward wedded bliss. This comedy ends not with a bouquet of blissful unions but a stage filled with corpses and ghosts. It’s called “Richard III.”

headline: Personal Assistants on Call, Just Not in the Next Office
text: IN the latest twist on the information-age truism that technology is making the world even smaller, entrepreneurs in India are trying to build a new market for the offshore services they offer: helping small businesses cope with even the most mundane day-to-day tasks.

headline: Pre-Lawsuit Papers Call Bank Building a ‘Tinderbox’
text: The families of two firefighters killed this summer fighting a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building near ground zero have filed legal papers contending that “dangerous conditions” and a failure to inspect for them turned the site into “a veritable tinderbox.”

headline: Near Seattle, Tribal Casinos Lead to Even Bigger Bets
text: TULALIP INDIAN RESERVATION, Wash. — For many American Indian tribes, a watershed moment occurs when they open a casino, which provides a stream of steady income. For the Tulalip tribes, a group of several tribes on this reservation about 35 miles north of Seattle, the casino was also a springboard for new real estate ventures — which in turn are helping to transform a rural area into one of Washington state’s fastest-growing suburbs.

headline: Facing Possible Expulsion, Lawmaker Will Step Down
text: HARTFORD, Nov. 13 — The former State Senate minority leader said Tuesday that he would resign from the Senate rather than risk expulsion for asking a trash hauler with reputed ties to organized crime to threaten his granddaughter’s husband, who he claimed had been abusing her.

headline: Pairings
text: TASTES are not colorblind, and the turkey is usually the decider: a preference for white or dark meat on the plate becomes white or red wine with Thanksgiving dinner. An accommodating host might wisely open both. But what about the rest of the menu?

headline: Investor Safe Haven Becomes a Concern
text: In another sign of turmoil in the credit markets, large investment firms, having sought out the high yields for their money market funds, are being forced to protect the funds from losses brought on by investments that no longer seem safe.

headline: Bhutto Calls for President to Resign
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 13 — Hundreds of riot policemen blocked the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto and her supporters from setting out today on a planned march from Lahore across 160 miles of Punjab Province to the capital, Islamabad.

headline: Anti-Bush Sign Has Bridge World in an Uproar
text: In the genteel world of bridge, disputes are usually handled quietly and rarely involve issues of national policy. But in a fight reminiscent of the brouhaha over an anti-Bush statement by Natalie Maines of the Dixie Chicks in 2003, a team of women who represented the United States at the world bridge championships in Shanghai last month is facing sanctions, including a yearlong ban from competition, for a spur-of-the-moment protest.

headline: Hedge Fund Seeks Delta-United Deal
text: Pardus Capital Management, a New York hedge fund, has sent a letter to the management of Delta Air Lines asking it to seek a merger with UAL, the parent of United Airlines, in a deal that would create the world’s largest airline and could prompt sweeping consolidation in the industry.

headline: Come for the Karts, Stay for the Cocktails
text: A once-abandoned warehouse in a prosperous community in Westchester County is being transformed to serve a highly unusual dual function: kart raceway and conference center.

headline: Google Hits European Hurdle on DoubleClick Deal
text: PARIS, Nov. 13 — European regulators refused Tuesday to approve Google’s $3.1 billion purchase of the Internet advertising company DoubleClick. They ordered a review of the deal amid opposition from rivals, publishers and consumer groups.

headline: Benefits in a Pension, for Now and Beyond
text: FOR a long time, owners of small businesses have been able to put more income into a pension plan than salaried employees can, deferring tens of thousands of dollars in taxes. Gradual changes in the tax law and the advent of simpler ways to maximize contributions have sweetened that perk, especially for small-business owners who can afford to divert more of what they make into pensions.

headline: Rural Channel Will Carry Imus Show
text: Don Imus, whose cowboy hat and western wear looked out of place on MSNBC, may have found a more comfortable saddle. On Dec. 3, when he returns not only to radio but also to television, it will be on RFD-TV, a cable and satellite channel that caters to farmers, ranchers and equestrians, as well as others who merely aspire to live a small-town life.

headline: Bush Gives Clearances for N.S.A. Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — Just four days after Michael B. Mukasey was sworn in as attorney general, Justice Department officials said Tuesday that President Bush had reversed course and approved long-denied security clearances for the Justice Department’s ethics office to investigate the National Security Agency’s warrantless surveillance program. The department’s inspector general has been investigating the department’s involvement with the N.S.A. program for about a year, but the move suggested both that Mr. Mukasey wanted to remedy what many in Congress saw as an improper decision by the president to block the clearances and that the White House chose to back him.

headline: Pushing Their Luck, Sitcoms Are Playing With Race Cards
text: “Remarkable people, the Blacks,” Alec Baldwin says on an episode of “30 Rock” on NBC. “Musical, very athletic, but not very good swimmers, and again, I’m talking about the family.”

headline: AT&T to Sell Equipment to Monitor Workplaces
text: AT&T plans to introduce a nationwide program today that gives owners of small- and medium-size businesses some of the same tools big security companies offer for monitoring employees, customers and operations from remote locations.

headline: Ford Chairman Says New Fuels Are Developing Too Slowly
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 13 — The chairman of Ford Motor, William Clay Ford Jr., expressed frustration Tuesday night at the slow pace of alternative fuel development, saying industry leaders expected better progress by now.

headline: In Gesture, Iran Provides Nuclear Document
text: VIENNA, Nov. 13  After two years of stonewalling, Iran has given the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency a document showing how to cast uranium metal into hemispheres to form the core of an atom bomb, European officials said Tuesday.

headline: Stocks Soar on Hopes Fed by Wal-Mart and 2 Banks
text: After several painful days of declines, stock markets moved into positive territory yesterday as the Dow Jones industrials surged nearly 320 points on sunnier forecasts from Wal-Mart and two major banks. But many analysts doubted the high spirits would last.

headline: Things Go From Bad to Worse for the Knicks
text: PHOENIX, Nov. 13 — Misery paid an early visit to the Knicks this season and, unlike several of their players, has firm plans to stick around for a while.

headline: Readers’ Responses

headline: Brooklyn: Unlicensed Meat Imports Defended
text: A lawyer for a Staten Island woman charged with importing meat without proper licenses and mislabeling a shipment argued in Federal District Court yesterday that the charges should be dismissed because they impinge on the importer’s right to freedom of religion. The woman’s lawyer said the meat of African wild game had religious significance for the woman, Mamie Manneh Jefferson, 39, who is originally from Liberia. Federal prosecutors have said Ms. Jefferson catered to the nostalgic rather than religious tastes of African immigrants. Ms. Jefferson was charged after federal agents found primate parts in a shipment of dried fish in January 2006.

headline: ‘Seaweed’ Clothing Has None, Tests Show
text: Lululemon Athletica has been a standout performer on Wall Street since it went public in July, thanks to the popularity of its costly yoga and other workout clothes, which are made with unusual materials, including bamboo, silver, charcoal, coconut and soybeans.

headline: Danish Prime Minister Narrowly Wins 3rd Term
text: COPENHAGEN, Nov. 13  Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the center-right Danish prime minister who presided over a thriving economy and steered his country through a global uproar over cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad, narrowly won his third term in office on Tuesday.

headline: Stagehands and Producers Plan Talks
text: The Broadway producers’ league and the stagehands’ union, which has been on strike for five days, announced this afternoon that they would meet for negotiations this weekend.

headline: Paying to Hear the Complaints
text: Through focus groups, surveys and random interviews, big businesses have been tapping the wisdom of their customers in some form for years. Now new Web-based services are making it easier for smaller businesses to compile important customer information, too.

headline: Co-Host Quits New NPR Show
text: Just weeks after its Oct. 1 start, NPR’s alternative morning program, “The Bryant Park Project,” is losing its co-host, Luke Burbank, right. He said yesterday that he is returning to his hometown, Seattle, to be near his 13-year-old daughter, whose wistful voice-mail message he played in making the announcement. In an interview, Jay Kernis, NPR’s senior vice president for programming, said, “I think it was just too difficult a situation” for Mr. Burbank to be a long-distance dad. While the show is sorry to lose Mr. Burbank, Mr. Kernis said, “if we thought we couldn’t do it without him, we wouldn’t have released him” from his contract. NPR budgeted $2 million for the start-up of this New York-based program, which was more than a year in development and has a conversational style intended to appeal to a younger audience than traditionally tunes in to NPR. Audience reaction has been mixed. Visits to the program’s Web site have grown markedly, but listeners to Salt Lake City’s KCPW, which precedes the popular “Morning Edition” with the new program, complained that it isn’t substantive enough and some have said they will withdraw financial support. Mr. Kernis said that NPR hoped to have a replacement join the co-host, Alison Stewart, by the time Mr. Burbank leaves in mid-December.

headline: Chinese Prices Surge Again, Despite New Controls
text: GUANGZHOU, China, Nov. 13 — Consumer prices unexpectedly surged again last month in China despite price controls on a wide range of industries, and this month holds the prospect of even higher inflation.

headline: City Lawyer, Country Chickens
text: Hopewell Junction, N.Y.

text: The police charged a man with manslaughter yesterday in the stabbing death of a man in Brooklyn.

text: John A. Thain, the chairman and chief executive of NYSE Euronext and a former co-president of Goldman Sachs, has been selected to be the next chief executive of Merrill Lynch, according to a person briefed on the situation.

headline: Manhattan: Charge in Poker Killing
text: A Bronx man has been charged with murder and robbery in the Nov. 2 holdup of a crowded Manhattan poker club, the police said yesterday. William Delvalle, 35, was taken into custody over the weekend, said investigators, who are seeking others in the case. The investigators declined to discuss any of the specifics in Mr. Delvalle’s case, including whether Mr. Delvalle was believed to have carried the shotgun that discharged and killed Frank DeSena, 55, a former math professor from New Jersey. The police said that more than one masked man entered the club in rented office space at 28th Street and Fifth Avenue.

headline: Coulda, Woulda, Shoulda
text: Two dates — two numbers. Read them and weep for what could have, and should have, been. On Sept. 11, 2001, the OPEC basket oil price was $25.50 a barrel. On Nov. 13, 2007, the OPEC basket price was around $90 a barrel.

headline: Letter by Oswald Is Found With Late Senator’s Papers
text: The box had sat untouched in the attic of a Washington house until recently, when the sale of the house forced some cleaning out, some poking around in long-overlooked places.

headline: Apple Shares Soar on Chinese Interest in iPhone
text: Apple’s shares rose more than they had in over a year after China Mobile, the world’s biggest wireless operator, said it was in talks to sell the iPhone.

headline: Working the Picket Line Instead of the Big Stage
text: The musical was one of Stephen Sondheim’s  “Passion”  and a scene in the script called for beef and gravy. But actors can’t eat beef and gravy eight times a week. The stagehand thought it over.

headline: Citigroup Overhauls Capital Markets Unit
text: Citigroup’s embattled capital markets unit will be regrouping under a new leader.

headline: Musharraf Foe Is Detained in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 14 — The opposition politician Imran Khan emerged from hiding today to the cheers of hundreds of students at a protest demonstration against Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, at a university here and was quickly seized by hard-line students and turned over to the police, witnesses said.

headline: At an Enthusiastic Christie’s Sale, ‘One Million Dollars Is the New 10 Grand’
text: Despite fears that the art market might finally begin to crack, an overflowing salesroom of enthusiastic bidders last night at Christie’s proved the naysayers wrong as 16 record prices, for artists including Jeff Koons, Gerhard Richter and Lucian Freud, propelled the market for postwar and contemporary art to new heights.

headline: South Korea’s Leader Calls for Haste on Treaty to End Korean War
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Roh Moo-hyun of South Korea called on Tuesday for a meeting of the leaders of the United States, China and the two Koreas to speed up North Korea’s denuclearization and achieve a peace treaty on the divided Korean Peninsula.

headline: Politics and the Brain
text: To the Editor:

headline: President of Columbia Is Criticized
text: Lee C. Bollinger, the president of Columbia University, was confronted yesterday by discontented professors who gathered more than 100 faculty signatures for a document criticizing his leadership.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Favre Sets Marks in Winning Way
text: This season, Brett Favre has set the N.F.L. career records for victories (topping John Elway’s 148 on Sept. 16) and touchdowns (topping Dan Marino’s 420 on Sept. 23), and is closing in on Marino’s mark for passing yards. All this has happened in a season in which the Packers (8-1) are looking like a playoff team for the first time since 2004.

headline: Mentally Ill in Serbia Are Abused, Report Says
text: BRUSSELS, Nov. 13 — A 21-year-old man with Down syndrome tied to a metal crib for 11 years. Children, naked from the waist down, left to eat and defecate in their beds. A 7-year-old girl with fluid in her brain left untreated “because she will die anyway.”

headline: Weekly Wrap: How Favre Is Not Like Marino
text: The Fifth Down’s contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

headline: Outside Sulaimaniya
text: Arabs and Kurds, displaced from other parts of Iraq, live side by side in a tent city outside Kurdistan's largest city.

headline: Extraordinary Exhibitions
text: Images from the show at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles.

headline: ‘Gomorrah’
text: The container swayed as the crane hoisted it onto the ship. The spreader, which hooks the container to the crane, was unable to control its movement, so it seemed to float in the air. The hatches, which had been improperly closed, suddenly sprang open, and dozens of bodies started raining down. They looked like mannequins. But when they hit the ground, their heads split open, as if their skulls were real. And they were. Men, women, even a few children, came tumbling out of the container. All dead. Frozen, stacked one on top of another, packed like sardines. These were the Chinese who never die. The eternal ones, who trade identity papers among themselves. So this is where they'd ended up, the bodies that in the wildest fantasies might have been cooked in Chinese restaurants, buried in fields beside factories, or tossed into the mouth of Vesuvius. Here they were. Spilling from the container by the dozen, their names scribbled on tags and tied with string around their necks. They'd all put aside money so they could be buried in China, back in their hometowns, a percentage withheld from their salaries to guarantee their return voyage once they were dead. A space in a container and a hole in some strip of Chinese soil. The port crane operator covered his face with his hands as he told me about it, eyeing me through his fingers. As if the mask of his hands might give him the courage to speak. He'd seen the bodies fall, but there'd been no need to sound the alarm. He merely lowered the container to the ground, and dozens of people appeared out of nowhere to put everyone back inside and hose down the remains. That's how it went. He still couldn't believe it and hoped he was hallucinating, due to too much overtime. Then he closed his fingers, completely covering his eyes. He kept on whimpering, but I couldn't understand what he was saying.

headline: Paris Auction 101- buying for beginners
text: The myth of the centuries old Hôtel Drouot is that this magical museum of an auction house is open only to seasoned antique dealers who know the mysterious rituals to snap up treasures from Chagall lithographs and Paul Gauguin sketches to gilded mirrors and used Louis Vuitton bags.

headline: Highlights From the L.A. Auto Show
text: Highlights from the first press preview day at the 2007 Los Angeles Auto Show.

headline: You’re Fired! But First, Run the Gauntlet.
text: There’s nothing more humiliating in sports than a doomed college football coach playing out the string. It’s like watching someone poke a wounded animal on its last breath. This year’s walking dead include Nebraska’s Bill Callahan, Texas A&M’s Dennis Franchione, and possibly even Tennessee’s Phillip Fulmer, who won the national championship in 1998 but hasn’t done much since. While a coach’s final days have never been a happy affair (ask every Notre Dame coach since Lou Holtz), the Internet has made them even more torturous.

headline: Avoiding Infamy
text: On Sunday, the New England Revolution will try to avoid becoming the Buffalo Bills of that other kind of football. The team will play in its third consecutive Major League Soccer Cup title game, and its fourth overall. Like the Bills from 1991 to 1994, the Revs have come up empty each time, the epitome of great expectations unfulfilled.

headline: Vertically Inclined
text: For most of us, sliding down a mountain on skis or a board is pleasure enough. But for the sort who likes to brag at the office, it helps to measure pleasure -- like the number of vertical feet covered in a day or year. For them, help is here.

headline: A Spygate Asterisk?
text: Last week Don Shula, the legendary coach whose 1972 Miami Dolphins were the last team to finish a season undefeated, suggested that if the New England Patriots finish the season unbeaten, the feat would be tainted because the team videotaped the signals of an opposing team. Do you agree with the Hall of Fame coach?

headline: What You Said
text: "One of the great things about baseball is that things happen in an instant and the umps have to react to it the same way the players do. Then everyone can whine and complain about the call. Who doesn’t love that?"

headline: Race Jokes on TV
text: In TV Watch, Alessandra Stanley writes on what passes for funny in television comedy lately. It’s pushing its luck by playing the race card, for example “Curb Your Enthusiasm” on HBO:

headline: Shareholders Back Satellite Radio Deal
text: Shareholders approved a deal Tuesday to allow Sirius Satellite Radio to acquire its rival, XM Satellite Radio Holdings, for about $5 billion, but the largest hurdle has yet to be faced: regulatory approval in Washington.

headline: Taking a Whack at Making a Car
text: A generation of digital-era Henry Fords, unabashed and brimming with confidence, has emerged. Born of Silicon Valley and the dot-com culture, they are trying to apply to carmaking the same entrepreneurial spirit that built the information superhighway.

headline: Weak Dollar May Reduce European Bonuses
text: The drop of the American dollar against the British pound and the euro may claim some of the bonus money of European investment bankers as the latest victim.

headline: This Week
text: Because of the Thanksgiving holiday, the PLAY newsletter is being published on Wednesday this week. It will return to its regular Thursday schedule next week.

headline: Google Hits European Hurdle on DoubleClick Deal
text: In what will no doubt be welcome news to the likes of Microsoft and Yahoo, European regulators refused Tuesday to approve Google‘s $3.1 billion purchase of the Internet advertising company DoubleClick. They ordered a review of the deal amid opposition from rivals, publishers and consumer groups.

headline: Banks’ Good News Helps Spark Market Rally, for Now
text: After several painful days of declines, stock markets moved into positive territory Tuesday as the Dow Jones industrials surged nearly 320 points on sunnier forecasts from Wal-Mart, as well as JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs. But many analysts doubted the high spirits would last.

text: Fashion meets funk in Little Five Points.

headline: ’24’ — the Lost 1994 Pilot
text: Stressed because “24” has been postponed by the writers’ strike? Soothe your withdrawal pangs with this sendup from a technogically backward era:

headline: Initiate Systems Aims to Raise $75 Million in I.P.O.
text: Initiate Systems, a Chicago data-management software-maker, filed documents Tuesday afternoon covering an initial public offering of up to $75 million.

headline: Madison Dearborn Closes on Nuveen Deal
text: Nuveen Investments said Tuesday afternoon that it has formally been acquired for $5.75 billion by an investing group led by private equity firm Madison Dearborn Capital Partners.

headline: Prosecutors Oppose New Trial for Enron Ex-C.E.O.
text: Prosecutors asked a federal appellate court Tuesday to keep former Enron Chief Executive Jeff Skilling behind bars for two more decades without retrying any part of the case.

headline: 2 West Coast Wealth Management Firms Unite
text: A San Francisco financial-management powerhouse that caters to the super-rich said Monday that it will merge with a comparably sized Los Angeles firm, creating one of the largest independent wealth-management firms.

headline: VeriSign Says It Will Sell Assets
text: Internet service provider VeriSign said on Wednesday that it plans to divest itself of several business units as part of a corporate overhaul.

headline: Analyst Predicts More Write-Downs for Merrill
text: After reporting a whopping $8.4 billion write-down in the third quarter that led to the ouster of its chief executive, one analyst is predicting more pain for Merrill Lynch.

headline: E*Trade C.E.O. Said to Cancel Conference Appearance
text: E-Trade‘s chief executive, Mitch Caplan, canceled a scheduled appearance at a Merrill Lynch banking conference, according to published reports Tuesday, fueling concerns that the online brokerage firm was having financial difficulties.

headline: Ventana Opens Its Books to Roche
text: Roche‘s $3 billion bid to acquire Ventana Medical Systems seemed to take a friendlier turn on Tuesday when the two sides struck a confidentiality agreement.

text: New York entrepreneurs and their startups are the focus of a special report from The Deal’s Tech Confidential, which includes video interviews with Justin Townsend, the chief executive of IGA, and Robert Levitan, an iVillage founder and chief executive of Pando Networks.

headline: Northern Rock Seeks to Block Leak of Bidding Memo

Northern Rock said Wednesday that it had obtained a court injunction barring further publication of a confidential memo prepared for potential bidders for the troubled mortgage lender.

headline: A Gore Family Christmas?
Former Bear Stearns Agent Expected to Plead Guilty
text: Federal prosecutors expect a former registered representative at Bear Stearns to plead guilty “shortly” to criminal charges, according to a court filing made public on Tuesday.

headline: London’s Gaucho Grill Pulls I.P.O.
text: Argentine steakhouse chain Gaucho Grill, a favorite for London’s financial set dining out on expense accounts, has abandoned its initial public offering.

headline: F.C.C.’s Media Proposal May Lead to Asset Sales
text: The head of the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday announced the details of his plan to relax the longstanding rule that had prevented a company from owning both a newspaper and a radio or television station in the same city.

headline: The Interpersonal Side of Work
text: Based on the titles of books that have been filling my mailbox, we are living in an era when improving relationships at work is in vogue. There’s something for everyone, from the shy to the looking for love. Here’s a peek at what’s on my desk at the moment, along with my take on who should be reading them:

headline: Note to Readers
text: Due to the extraordinarily high volume of reader monologue jokes sent on occasion of the Hollywood writers’ strike, we here at Laugh Lines have discovered that we can’t read that fast and that we tend to move our lips when we do so. So we ask your forebearance. We’ll be parceling out your jokes in separate posts in the days ahead. Meantime, keep ’em coming (via the comment link below). Here’s one from Patrick Gorse of Pasadena, Calif.:

headline: Third Point Sells PDL Stake
text: Third Point chief Daniel S. Loeb has officially washed his hands of PDL BioPharma. Third Point liquidated its remaining stake in the biotechnology company as a result of being denied a seat on its board.

headline: Vivox Scores $7.8 Million
text: Vivox, an online gaming and virtual community infrastructure developer, raised $7.8 million in a second round led by Benchmark Capital to accelerate expansion of sophisticated multiplayer communications services using voice-over-Internet-protocol technology.

headline: Mad About Facebook, or Just Plain Mad?
text: A venture capitalist crazy for Facebook may be just plain crazy, according to some of his Silicon Valley compatriots.

headline: Copying Fortress’ Playbook
