headline: Clinton Addresses DNC
text: Senator Clinton addressed the Fleet Center crowd on the first night of the 2004 Democratic National Convention in Boston.

headline: Hawk’s Blog
text: This season fans have been getting an inside view of what makes Colorado Coach Dan Hawkins tick.

headline: Being Adopted, and Being Me
text: Being adopted is different. It can be confusing to the adopted kid and to other people (especially if you are a transracial adoptee, because they spot the difference and then want answers). So, adoption to me is black – and my family is white.

headline: Why Do We Do It?
text: Harvard fullback Noah Van Niel has made a name for himself nationally by pulling off the rarest of duets. He’s both the bruising starting fullback for the Harvard football team and a promising opera singer who is a regular in campus musical productions. He plans on pursuing singing opera as a career when he graduates this spring. But before that, he has one final game against Yale on Saturday to determine the Ivy League championship. Here are his thoughts on why he and his fellow seniors have traded 355 days of pain for 10 days of bliss each fall.

headline: A 4th Climate Warning. Anyone Listening?
text: It was the culmination of an extraordinary meeting on the human-changed atmosphere. For three days, scientists had described how a buildup of long-lived gases emitted by burning fuels and forests would, if it continued, raise temperatures, raise seas and disrupt weather patterns important to agriculture, water supplies and wildlife.

headline: Q & A: M.L.S. Commissioner Don Garber
text: Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber sat down with The New York Times for a wide-ranging interview to discuss the status of the league. Excerpts from the 45-minute interview appear in the “Saturday Interview” in the Business section. The full transcript follows.Q: The obvious first question is about the impact of David Beckham, on and off the field, especially considering how much time he missed because of injuries.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Hillary Fries the Waffle
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Nov. 17 column.

headline: Jack Kuney, 88, Producer of Notable Early TV Shows, Is Dead
text: Jack Kuney, who produced and directed some of early television’s most widely praised shows, and who also produced a rarely seen, made-for-television farce by Woody Allen that lampooned the Nixon administration, died on Nov. 7 in Bradenton, Fla. He was 88 and had lived in Bradenton in recent years.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Nov. 1 about the death of Linda S. Stein, a Manhattan real estate agent and a pioneer of the punk music scene during her marriage to Seymour Stein, the founder of Sire Records, attributed an erroneous distinction to him. Although several publications say Mr. Stein was the creator of the Billboard Top 100 music charts, now known as the Hot 100, they were in fact created by Tom Noonan, Mr. Stein’s boss at the time. The caption for a picture in some editions showing Ms. Stein and some of her music industry associates in 1979 misstated the surname of the wife of the musician Dee Dee Ramone. She is Vera Ramone, not March.

headline: A Costly Kiss
text: A judge in Avignon, France, fined a woman 1,500 euros ($2,200) for leaving a lipstick kiss mark on a pure white canvas by the American artist Cy Twombly, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. The judge also told the woman, Rindy Sam, 30, above, to pay a symbolic one euro in damages to the 79-year-old artist. Ms. Sam, an artist herself, was arrested in July after she planted the kiss on a panel of Mr. Twombly’s triptych Phaedrus, in the Museum of Contemporary Art in Avignon. The painting is valued at $2.8 million. At her trial last month, Ms. Sam said: “It was an act of love, when I kissed it, I wasn’t thinking. I thought the artist would understand.” But Agnes Tricoire, the lawyer for the plaintiffs, said, “For me love requires the consent of both sides.”

headline: Questions for Roddick After Rout by Federer
text: SHANGHAI, Nov. 16 — Although Friday’s matches at the Masters Cup were not unreasonably long — indeed one was rather fast — setting up the event’s semifinal matchups had a laborious feeling.

headline: Figuring the Ultimate Odds
text: The recreational gambler dubbed Old Man was at an adjoining poker table when three masked men broke in from Fifth Avenue, bagged $100,000 and — in what looked like a grotesque accident — shot an innocent player to death. “One of these crazies dropped his shotgun and, boom!” said Old Man. He was still shaken days later as the police sought the thieves who got the drop on private guards and fleeced 150 players in one of the many illegal poker dens that usually operate in quietude at night across the city’s high-rise skyline.

headline: Not Much Room for Furniture, but That’s Part of the Game
text: The man at the table wears a gray suit, brown shoes, no tie and a face that looks as if it has seen a thing or two. He doesn’t speak. He takes only one sip from his shot glass.

headline: Zimbabwe: ‘Mugabenomics’ Gathers Pace
text: Zimbabwe’s annual inflation rate, already the world’s highest by far, rocketed to nearly 15,000 percent in October, almost twice the rate for the previous month, the privately owned newspaper The Zimbabwe Independent reported. The government, which normally issues inflation reports early in the month, refused to confirm the report, but similar leaks have proved accurate in the past. The latest rate of price increases amounts to a jump of 132 percent a month, well above the 103-percent-a-month rate reported for September. President Robert G. Mugabe issued a defiant statement, saying that inflation was a plot by “Western destructive forces” and vowing that “Zimbabwe will not collapse, now or in the future.”

headline: Smoke and Mirrors in the Education Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Immigration Quandary: A Mother Torn From Her Baby
text: Federal immigration agents were searching a house in Ohio last month when they found a young Honduran woman nursing her baby.

headline: With Mustache, Without Arrow
text: BOSTON — In person, Steve Martin, now 62, is far from a wild and crazy guy — if he ever really was one. His hair is snow white. Though still youthful, his famously mobile face is mostly in repose. He’s a lot like your tax accountant, only a little shyer.

headline: Journalists Killed by Indonesian Army in 1975, Inquiry Finds
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 — An Australian coroner concluded Friday that the Indonesian Army killed five Australia-based journalists at the beginning of its 1975 invasion of East Timor to prevent news of an Indonesian attack from reaching the outside world.

headline: Off for Break, Congress May Still Face Stalemate
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 — Congress departed on Friday for a two-week break, leaving behind a stack of unfinished work as a major farm bill became the latest victim of a stalemate that has bedeviled Congress all year.

headline: Experts Advise a Grain of Salt With Mail-Order Genomes, at $1,000 a Pop
text: The revolution in human genomics, still barely understood in the doctor’s office, is about to hit the street, at least for those able to pay about $1,000 for a glance at their entire genome.

headline: Pierce Says He Is Ready to Play
text: Giants middle linebacker Antonio Pierce practiced yesterday for the first time since sustaining what the team called a mild concussion last Sunday. The Giants said Pierce would play in tomorrow’s game at Detroit.

headline: Turkey: Legal Moves to Ban Kurdish Party
text: Supreme Court prosecutors accused the only Kurdish political party in Parliament of colluding with separatist rebels and moved to disband it, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported. If convicted of the charges in a 121-page indictment, 221 registered members of the Democratic Society Party, including 8 of its members in Parliament, could face a five-year ban from politics. The prosecutors contend that there are direct links between the party’s founders and the rebel group known as the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or P.K.K., and that the Democratic Society Party, which won seats in Parliament in July, was simply a re-invention of banned Kurdish parties. The action comes amid tensions with Iraq over Turkey’s threat to make cross-border attacks on P.K.K. bases.

headline: Silencing La Scala
text: La Scala’s 800 workers will go on strike today, forcing the Milan opera house to cancel two shows, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. The strike over better wages and working conditions follows a similar walkout last Friday, which forced the cancellation of a performance of Verdi’s “Requiem.” La Scala will again cancel “Requiem” today, which was to have been conducted by Daniel Barenboim in Parma as part of the 50th-anniversary celebrations of the death of the conductor Arturo Toscanini.

headline: Corrections
text: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday about “The Cat Who Went to Heaven,” a puppet musical at Culture Project, in SoHo, included outdated schedule information. After the section went to press, Culture Project said the production, scheduled to open today, had been postponed indefinitely.

headline: Looking for the Truth When It Keeps Changing
text: “This is a piece of fiction,” Faustin Linyekula says at the start of “Festival of Lies,” which opened on Wednesday night at Bricstudio in Brooklyn. “But one thing is indisputably real: the food and the bar.”

headline: Bhutto Rejects Caretaker Government
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 16 — Hours after being released from house arrest, the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto on Friday rejected a new caretaker government appointed by the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to oversee elections and repeated her vow not to reopen talks with him.

headline: On Strike to Protect the Gains of the Past, With an Eye on the Future
text: Suddenly, it seems, organized labor is flexing its muscles again.

headline: Reagan in Neshoba
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hoping (Dreaming?) of Soccer as National Pastime
text: DON Garber became the commissioner of Major League Soccer in August 1999, after the league lost $250 million over its first five seasons and shrank by two teams to 10. At the time, it appeared to be the latest failure of a soccer league in North America.

headline: M.T.A. Executive Gets Political Donation From Bidders on Railyards
text: A vice chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who is running for Congress in New York’s northern suburbs has taken political donations from two developers bidding for the right to build a mammoth residential and commercial complex over the authority’s West Side railyards, according to federal election filings.

headline: Memphis Squanders Early Lead Before Beating Connecticut
text: The best thing that could be said about Connecticut last night was that the Huskies were resilient. It was just that they needed to be something more.

headline: Finding Her Haven From Terror, a Continent Away
text: In 1994, Carlos Raul Bonilla was kidnapped by a guerrilla group known as FARC, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. His wife, Martha Palomino, who had no idea he was a target, never saw him again.

headline: Railroad and Hedge Fund Square Off
text: Directors at CSX, the railroad operator, publicly supported management Friday and rebutted criticisms by a hedge fund that the company had overspent and failed to match its peers’ performance.

headline: CBS Takes Thursday
text: For the second consecutive Thursday, CBS edged out ABC in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49, although ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” remained No. 1 in that demographic. CBS dominated with “Survivor: China,” (14.8 million viewers) at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated, and at 9 its “CSI” attracted 21.3 million viewers, two million more than “Grey’s Anatomy” in the hour. At 10, a special broadcast of ABC’s “Women’s Murder Club” came in third (8.9 million), behind CBS’s “Without a Trace” (14.5 million) and NBC’s “ER” (9.5 million). NBC ranked third, ahead of Fox, as both “30 Rock” at 8:30 (6.5 million) and “The Office” at 9 (8.9 million) delivered their best ratings since the shows’ season premieres. On Wednesday, the fourth season’s premiere of “Project Runway” on Bravo drew 2.9 million viewers, the largest audience ever for a premiere on the cable channel.

headline: Brodeur Fails to Win No. 500 on Third Try
text: NEWARK, Nov. 16 — Devils defenseman Mike Mottau skated backward with the puck in his zone Friday, scanning the ice for just the right moment to launch another power-play rush. What happened next typified the Devils’ frustrating season so far.

headline: Evaluating Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: China Tilting Away From Longtime Trading Partners
text: THE economy of China continues to grow rapidly, but the benefits of that growth are no longer being spread as widely around the world, with Europe a particular loser as its exports to China begin to fall.

headline: Pigeon-Rights Groups Rush to Defend Their Feathered Friends
text: When Councilman Simcha Felder, a Democrat from Brooklyn, announced on Monday that he was going to introduce legislation that would make feeding pigeons an offense punishable by a fine, he made plain his feelings about “rats with wings,” a phrase used by a parks commissioner, Thomas P. F. Hoving, in the 1960s and popularized by Woody Allen in his 1980 film “Stardust Memories.”

headline: Gore Plans for a Date at the White House
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 — President Bush and former Vice President Al Gore have spoken just a few times since the evening of Dec. 13, 2000, when Mr. Gore conceded the presidential race, five weeks and a Supreme Court ruling after the voting had ended.

headline: Art Sale Still Blocked
text: The Virginia Supreme Court has temporarily blocked the sale of four paintings by the financially troubled Randolph College in Lynchburg, Va., The Associated Press reported. The move came after a group opposed to the sale of the art failed to post a $10 million bond on Thursday that would have kept a lower court’s injunction against the sale in effect. The state Supreme Court stepped in and lowered the bond to $1 million and gave opponents until Dec. 3 to post it. The works, from the college’s Maier Museum of Art, include a George Bellows painting that Christie’s has valued at $25 million to $35 million. The first auction of the works had been scheduled for Monday and a second for Nov. 29 at Christie’s in New York.

headline: Ex-Judge Is Sentenced After Sting by F.B.I.
text: A former judge from Long Island was sentenced yesterday to 33 months in prison for conspiring to launder almost $400,000 in proceeds from stolen jewelry.

headline: $30 Million for U.C.L.A. Music School
text: The University of California, Los Angeles, received $30 million from the trumpeter and record company executive Herb Alpert, left, and named a new music school after him, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. Mr. Alpert’s donation is the largest to support the arts in the University of California system, the university said. The U.C.L.A. Herb Alpert School of Music will encompass the university’s departments of music, musicology and ethnomusicology and will be devoted to the performance and study of a range of musical styles, including jazz, world, popular and classical, the university said. The school will “contribute to what we hope will be a transformation of music studies in American higher education through an open and inclusive approach to all music,” said Christopher Waterman, dean of the university’s School of the Arts and Architecture.

headline: Some Hunches About Intuition
text: CAN people improve their intuition?

headline: Closing Time for a Diner That Fed the Body and Soul
text: CHAFFEE, N.Y.

headline: The Bridge Champs Who Did Not Vote for Bush
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tax Inquiries Can Combine Guesswork and Digging
text: Unlike Superman, a tax auditor does not have X-ray vision. When building a case against someone who files a tax return as a nonresident but has an apartment in New York, the auditor cannot look inside the apartment.

headline: Cyclone Kills Hundreds in Bangladesh
text: NEW DELHI, Nov. 16 — Packing winds of over 100 miles an hour, the furious cyclone that swept across the low-lying watery edges of southern Bangladesh late Thursday downed trees, sent cellphone towers crashing and swept away mud and thatch homes, leaving at least hundreds dead.

headline: Giuliani, Foe of ‘Socialized’ Medicine, Expanded Public Care
text: In campaigning for president, Rudolph W. Giuliani has criticized Democrats for promoting “socialized” medicine, boasted about his record as mayor of New York City for dramatically reducing public assistance, and vigorously opposed expanding government health insurance for children.

headline: A Plane to Beat All Planes
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Least 15 Died in Crackdown, Myanmar Tells Envoy
text: BANGKOK, Nov. 16 — Paulo Sérgio Pinheiro, the United Nations human rights envoy to Myanmar, said Friday that Burmese officials had acknowledged that 15 people, not 10 as they previously said, were killed in the military government’s crackdown on protesters in September.

headline: Merrill to Pay Chief $50 Million, More if Stock Rises
text: Call him Wall Street’s richest mop-up man, at least for now.

headline: Marbury Says He Is Willing to Accept Role as a Backup
text: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 16 — His practice jersey was white, a symbol of his reduced status. His left knee was wrapped in ice, a reminder of his decline. His personal space was cramped by reporters — a sure indication that Stephon Marbury’s travails are far from over.

headline: Corrections: or the Record
text: The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about “Born Standing Up,” by Steve Martin, misstated his connection to “Saturday Night Live.” While he has appeared on the show many times, he was not a cast member.

headline: Florida: Former Sheriff Is Sentenced
text: A former Broward County sheriff was sentenced to a year and a day in prison after resigning as sheriff and pleading guilty in September to federal tax evasion and mail fraud charges. The former sheriff, Ken Jenne, 60, was charged with secretly accepting tens of thousands of dollars from contractors doing business with the sheriff’s office and falsifying his tax returns in 2001, 2002 and 2004. Mr. Jenne had served as the Broward sheriff since 1998. Before that, he was a state senator for almost 20 years, four of them as Senate Democratic leader.

headline: U.S. Acts to Bolster Supply of Water for Atlanta
text: ATLANTA, Nov. 16 — With only a few months of readily available drinking water remaining for Atlanta, federal biologists on Friday allowed Georgia to keep more water in a reservoir that supplies the city and elsewhere in the northern part of the state, a decision that reduces flows to Florida.

headline: Coin Dealers Sue State Dept. for Details on Import Bans
text: Three organizations representing coin collectors and dealers have filed a lawsuit against the State Department demanding greater disclosure of how the government makes decisions on the import of ancient artifacts from abroad.

headline: Joe Nuxhall, Modern Baseball’s Youngest Player, Is Dead at 79
text: Joe Nuxhall, who became the youngest player in modern major league history when he pitched in one game for the 1944 Reds at age 15, then went on to spend more than half a century with Cincinnati as a pitcher and broadcaster, died Thursday in Fairfield, Ohio, outside Cincinnati. He was 79.

headline: Election Watchdog Group Cancels Russia Mission
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 16 — Western election observers on Friday pulled out of a mission to monitor Russia’s Dec. 2 parliamentary vote, citing restrictions imposed by the Kremlin on their work.

headline: Bread Is Broken While Interfaith Bonds Are Built
text: FRISCO, Tex., Nov. 15  The outcome was uncertain when a group of mostly strangers sat down together for dinner Thursday night at a home in this Dallas suburb. Among the gathering were three Jews, two Mormons, three Muslims, two Bahais, two secular humanists and a Catholic-Baptist.

headline: A Smokers’ Tax, Defeated in Oregon
text: To the Editor:

headline: O’Neill’s Landscape, Still Untrodden
text: The early, little-known Eugene O’Neill one-acts presented as “The Pioneer” by the Metropolitan Playhouse show the playwright’s dramatic universe in embryo. Here, born battling, are all the downtrodden and trapped who grope for meaning in his world: the prostitutes, pimps and pipe-dreamers, sailors and drunks, mismatched husbands and wives.

headline: Doping Officials Question Baseball’s Policy on Drugs
text: MADRID, Nov. 16  After years of criticizing Major League Baseball for what he called useless, toothless drug-testing policies, Dick Pound, chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency, chastised the sport again Friday, saying that Barry Bonds’s indictment on perjury charges confirmed that the league’s doping problems were “out of control.”

headline: Shopping Bargains Before the First Bite of Turkey
text: Yes, the economic outlook is grim.

headline: Abu Dhabi Takes 8% Stake in Advanced Micro
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 — Advanced Micro Devices said Friday that an investment arm of Abu Dhabi’s government had taken an 8 percent stake in the company for $622 million.

headline: China: Loans Cut for Polluters
text: The government suspended bank loans to 12 polluting companies as part of its new “green-credit policy,” the newspaper China Youth Daily reported. The report did not name the companies but said they included a brewery and a power company. “The purpose of this move is to force enterprises to pay the price for environmental violations,” the newspaper quoted an Environmental Protection Administration official as saying.

headline: In U.S. Name Count, Garcias Are Catching Up With Joneses
text: Step aside Moore and Taylor. Welcome Garcia and Rodriguez.

headline: Kmart Items Marked Safe Had Lead
text: Kmart said yesterday that it would remove all jewelry advertised as “lead free” from its shelves after workers at lead monitoring programs who tested the pieces found that some actually contained high concentrations of the metal.

headline: Timing of Bonds’s Indictment Feeds Speculation
text: Why now? A defense lawyer for Barry Bonds and two outside legal experts raised questions yesterday about the timing of the perjury indictment against Bonds, saying they did not understand why it came this week and not months or even years ago.

headline: U.N. Report Describes Risks of Inaction on Climate Change
text: VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 17 — Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, describing climate change as “the defining challenge of our age,” released the final report of a United Nations panel on climate change here Saturday and called on the United States and China to play “a more constructive role.”

headline: Living History, in Veterans
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Doctors Inject a Disease
text: The discovery of a Long Island doctor’s astonishingly lax approach to infection control has raised troubling questions about the adequacy of medical oversight in New York State  and the packaging of medicines in vials that are easy to contaminate.

headline: Swedish Warhols Are Fake
text: Six wooden Brillo boxes in the Andy Warhol collection at a Swedish museum are fakes that were made in 1990, three years after Warhol died, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Warhol created the original reproductions of Brillo soap pad cartons as part of a 1964 exhibition of art resembling supermarket products. (At right is a version of the 1964 original.) The museum, Moderna Museet in Stockholm, said it had investigated the six Brillo boxes, donated in 1995 by its former director, Pontus Hulten, after a Swedish newspaper claimed that they were copies. In a letter to the Andy Warhol Art Authentication Board in New York, the museum director, Lars Nittve, confirmed the claims. “These boxes are not authorized by the artist and should be removed from the official list of Andy Warhol Brillo boxes,” Mr. Nittve wrote. The Swedish paper Expressen reported in June that Mr. Hulten, who was director of the museum in the 1960s and the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris in the 1970s and 1980s, had Swedish carpenters build 105 copies of the box for an exhibition in Russia in 1990. Expressen claimed that Mr. Hulten, who died last year, sold a number of the copies with certificates falsely stating that they were made for a Warhol exhibition in Stockholm in 1968.

headline: OPEC Gathering Finds High Oil Prices More Worrisome Than Welcome
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 16 — As oil prices hover around $95 a barrel, OPEC might be expected to celebrate. Its members are reaping record revenues, demand for their product keeps rising and the world economy seems capable of sustaining oil prices that would have seemed unthinkable a few years ago.

headline: Rhode Island Will Trim State Work Force
text: BOSTON, Nov. 16 — About 500 state employees in Rhode Island are expected to lose their jobs, Gov. Donald L. Carcieri announced on Friday. The state is trying to close a projected $450 million budget gap for the next fiscal year.

headline: Judge Declares a Mistrial in Texas Cat Killing Case
text: A judge in Galveston, Tex., declared a mistrial on Friday in the case of a bird enthusiast who killed a cat that he said was stalking endangered birds. Jurors said they were hopelessly deadlocked.

headline: Canada Bars Seaweed-Apparel Health Claims
text: Lululemon Athletica, a yoga apparel maker, has agreed to stop making health claims in Canada about its VitaSea clothing, a line that the company says is made with seaweed.

headline: Democrats Find Their Voice
text: It has been two long months since Gen. David Petraeus, the top commander in Iraq, cowed Congressional Democrats into silence, championing President Bush’s misguided course on the war. We’re pleased to see that the effects of his briefing are finally wearing off. The bad news, as ever, is that Mr. Bush and his Republican allies continue to resist reason.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Awareness of Dog Abuse
text: To the Editor:

headline: Keeping Track of the Tracks
text: The private racing club concept is becoming popular, though the road from pipe dream to pavement can be long and difficult. In addition to the track at Monticello, there are others in varying stages of development. Here are a few:

headline: Judge Demands Documentation in Foreclosures
text: After the recent dismissal of 14 foreclosure cases by a federal judge in Cleveland, another federal judge in Ohio has given lenders 30 days to prove that they own the properties they intend to seize from troubled homeowners in 27 other cases.

headline: More Than a Social Worker, a Friend
text: Mariana Duenas is a caseworker from Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, where she has worked for almost four years. She has been working passionately on behalf of her client Martha Palomino for almost that long.

headline: A Taste of Baboon and Monkey Meat, and Maybe of Prison, Too
text: It takes strategic thinking to find monkey meat in New York. Best to avoid the word “monkey,” for one thing — start with something innocuous-sounding, like “dry meat,” or common, like “grass cutter,” a rodent similar to the guinea pig. Seek out the proprietors of tiny West African restaurants, or the “bushmeat market queens” who do business out of their homes.

headline: Indian Coalition Wins Political Dispute Over Nuclear Pact
text: NEW DELHI, Nov. 16  The government’s Communist allies gave Prime Minister Manmohan Singh significant breathing room on Friday to push ahead in pursuing a landmark nuclear accord with the United States.

headline: In Theater District Bars, Many of the Glasses Are Half-Empty
text: Broadway, like the old Fulton Fish Market, is a business and a culture — once described by Stanley Walker, the Jazz Age city editor, as “an excited condition of fourth-rate emotions” realized, at street level, in “chow-meineries, peep shows for men only, flea circuses, lectures on what killed Rudolph Valentino” and other amusements that he was too much of a prude to put in print.

headline: Hard-Working Plagiarist Just Wants to Keep Her Job
text: There’s a top-notch satire, probably a one-act, lurking in “Body Parts,” a full-length work by Ishmael Reed receiving its East Coast premiere at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe. Mr. Reed, though, is a man angry about many things, and all of them are crammed into this play, which makes it more like target practice with a machine gun than like well-aimed criticism.

headline: The Bluefin Slaughter
text: The hunting of highly valued animals into oblivion is a symptom of human foolishness that many consign to the unenlightened past, like the 19th century, when bird species were wiped out for feathered hats and bison were decimated for sport. But the slaughter of the giant bluefin tuna is happening now.

headline: Sorenstam Ends Season Without a Win
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 16  Annika Sorenstam was about to hit her last full shot in her last official L.P.G.A. competition of 2007, a 5-iron from the middle of the 18th fairway. In years past, when Sorenstam ruled women’s golf, such a shot would have been almost as routine as hitting a wedge from 100 yards.

headline: Angioplasty and Stents
text: To the Editor:

headline: Car of Today Is Laps From Being Yesterday’s News
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 16  Chad Knaus, crew chief for the Nascar driver Jimmie Johnson, made a quick pitch when asked what Hendrick Motorsports planned to do with all the racecars that Johnson, Jeff Gordon and others have put in victory lane over the years.

headline: French Transit Strike Falters, but Stretches Into Weekend
text: PARIS, Nov. 16  No relief was in sight for weekend travelers as a strike that has snarled public transportation across France appeared likely to continue into next week.

headline: Chávez’s Vision Shares Wealth and Centers Power
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 16 — In two weeks, Venezuela seems likely to start an extraordinary experiment in centralized, oil-fueled socialism. By law, the workday would be cut to six hours. Street vendors, homemakers and maids would have state-mandated pensions. And President Hugo Chávez would have significantly enhanced powers and be eligible for re-election for the rest of his life.

headline: Stretching and Soaring to Bach, Balanchine and Shostakovich
text: The Pennsylvania Ballet opened its second night at City Center on Thursday with “Concerto Barocco,” George Balanchine’s classic set to Bach’s Concerto in D minor for Two Violins, and that choice signified more than just another repertory evening. In 1964 “Concerto Barocco” was part of the first program presented by the company, formed the year before by the intrepid Barbara Weisberger, who had been Balanchine’s first child pupil. He didn’t, it should be noted, charge her a cent for “Barocco.” Those were the days.

headline: The M.B.A. Under Attack
text: THERE is a rising reaction against management theory, according to The Economist. A new book by the management expert Gary Hamel, “The Future of Management,” notes that several well-known executives of hot companies  among them, Sergey Brin and Larry Page of Google and John P. Mackey of Whole Foods Market  did not go to business school.

headline: Why Must ID Security Be So Hard?
text: TWO and a half years ago, someone managed to swipe just enough of my personal data to create a fake debit card that was linked to my checking account. Through a series of shopping sprees — nicely detailed in my online account statement — the thief charged about $1,700 before I noticed, called the bank and stopped the crime.

headline: Drama, Perhaps, but Only From Negotiations
text: The producers’ league and the stagehands’ union are set to sit down for talks this morning to try to end the strike that has kept most of Broadway dark for a week.

headline: Forget Fair; It’s Litigation as Usual
text: They had the kits ready to go. The “trial package,” they called it.

headline: WADA Election Now 2-Man Race
text: MADRID, Nov. 16  The election of a chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency to succeed the controversial and outspoken Dick Pound went from simple to decidedly complex Friday, when the presumptive new leader of the antidoping agency  who was running unopposed  found out a day before the vote that he might have competition.

headline: Koreas Announce New Cooperation
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 16 — The prime ministers of North and South Korea announced a significant package of cross-border economic projects today to help rebuild the North’s broken economy and ease military tension on the divided Korean Peninsula by increasing human and cargo traffic across the demilitarized zone. At the end of three days of talks here, North Korea’s prime minister, Kim Yong-il, and his South Korean counterpart, Han Duck-soo, agreed to start cross-border freight-train service for the first time in more than half a century, scheduling the first, and highly symbolic, border crossing a week before South Korea holds presidential elections on Dec. 19.

headline: Storied Rembrandt to Be Shown at the Getty
text: An early Rembrandt portrait that has not been on public view for more than two decades and has a lively criminal past — it was stolen at gunpoint from the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, more than three decades ago — will re-emerge for several months, beginning on Tuesday at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles.

headline: New Plays Inspired by Those Oldsters, Homer and Stravinsky
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 — Making old things new again is a frequent preoccupation of artists in many mediums. Classic stories are revisited by writers hundreds of years apart; an image in an old master painting inspires a contemporary riff; a Jane Austen novel becomes a glossy popular movie.

headline: Harold Alfond, Donor and Shoe Factory Owner, Dies at 93
text: Harold Alfond, a former factory laborer who parlayed a hitchhiker’s tip into a fortune by founding the Dexter Shoe Company and running it for four decades, died Friday at a family home in Belgrade Lakes, Me. He was 93 and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Gaza: Rally Detainees to Be Released
text: The Hamas-run Interior Ministry in Gaza announced the release of “dozens” of Fatah supporters detained after Monday’s pro-Fatah rally. A Fatah spokesman, Hazem Abu Shanab, said that just a “small number” of the scores arrested had been freed. The mass rally ended in violence, with at least seven civilians killed by Hamas police fire. Yesterday, thousands of Hamas supporters rallied after noon prayers outside the abandoned Gaza home of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, of Fatah. A Hamas leader, Khalil al-Hayya, warned Mr. Abbas against making any concessions to Israel on Palestinian rights or Al Aksa mosque in Jerusalem, threatening a “huge explosion.” Mr. Abbas governs from the West Bank and has not been in Gaza since Hamas took control there in June.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Those Smart Women?
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Measure Against Rape Fails at U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 16  The United States has failed to obtain a General Assembly resolution focused on rape used by governments and armed groups to achieve political and military objectives.

headline: British Composer Sits In With Visiting Berliners
text: Thursday was a rare night off for the Berlin Philharmonic, a mainstay of Carnegie Hall’s Berlin in Lights festival. You could not have blamed the musicians for wanting some time to relax.

headline: Thefts at Open Houses Put Marketers on Alert
text: While the Manhattan real estate market, defying national trends, still remains strong, city brokers are being warned to turn away two potential buyers: a team of thieves who, the police say, have attended at least six open houses in recent weeks and stolen expensive items like diamond rings, a fur coat, handbags and a bottle of Champagne.

headline: Gift to Smithsonian Is Rescinded
text: The American Petroleum Institute has rescinded a controversial $5 million gift to the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of Natural History’s Ocean Initiative exhibition hall. The Smithsonian said it received notice of the withdrawal in a one-sentence letter from the institute. The Smithsonian Board of Regents had been scheduled to vote on Monday on whether to accept the donation. Cristián Samper, the former director of the natural history museum, who is now acting secretary of the Smithsonian, approved the gift, but some regents have questioned its appropriateness. Mr. Samper, a candidate for the secretary position, has been serving since March, when Lawrence M. Small resigned the post after revelations about lavish personal spending. The Washington Post reported yesterday that some government scientists had complained that Mr. Samper ordered last-minute changes to the museum’s 2006 exhibition on the Arctic to avoid political problems. The additions suggested that there was scientific uncertainty about climate change, The Post said, but Linda St. Thomas, a Smithsonian spokeswoman, said yesterday that the show “was never intended to be a comprehensive exhibition on climate change.”

headline: First Tourney Win for Hofstra Women
text: The junior midfielder Edel Malone and goalkeeper Krystal Robens carried Hofstra to a 1-0 victory over Ohio State yesterday in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. tournament at Penn State’s Jeffrey Field. Robens set university records with her seventh consecutive shutout and 12th of the season in the Pride’s first N.C.A.A. tournament victory. Hofstra (18-3) will face top-seeded Penn State tomorrow.The Pride scored 7 minutes 38 seconds into the second half when the freshman forward Kayla Pifer sent a low cross through the middle, where Malone was waiting at the far post.

headline: Growing Focus on Reused Medicine Vials
text: Tucked inside the tale of a Long Island pain management doctor who used unsafe infection control practices is a growing public health concern: the risks of transmitting blood-borne diseases through medicine vials that hold more than one dose and can be used for injections for multiple patients.

headline: Sergio del Valle, a Castro Stalwart, Dies
text: HAVANA, Nov. 16 (AP) — Gen. Sergio del Valle Jimenez, a doctor in Fidel Castro’s rebel army in the late 1950s and army chief of staff during the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis, died on Thursday, the state media reported today.

headline: Boston Scientific and Consultant Settle a Lawsuit
text: With a Dec. 3 trial date fast approaching, Boston Scientific and the ECRI Institute have settled a potentially controversial lawsuit that could have spotlighted efforts by Boston Scientific and other medical device companies to keep the prices of their major products secret.

headline: A Clinton Friend’s Role Sets Off Intense Criticism of CNN and a Re-examination
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton prepared for a battle with her Democratic rivals at the CNN-sponsored debate on Thursday night. She did not have much to fear from the postdebate round table.

headline: Giuliani Vexes Audiences With His Abortion Views
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 — On the campaign trail, Rudolph W. Giuliani has made the case that while he believes that abortions are wrong, he thinks the ultimate decision of whether to have them should be up to women, and not the government. But he has also pledged to appoint the kind of conservative judges who might be expected to rule against abortion.

headline: Envoy Elicits No New Promises From Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 17 — Continuing to defy the United States, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan declined to say when he would lift a two-week-old state of emergency during a meeting with a senior American envoy today, Pakistani and Western officials said.

headline: Yankees Use Economics to Their Advantage
text: With Alex Rodriguez virtually back in pinstripes, the Yankees have come full circle in an episode that epitomizes what separates them from the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Swedish Warhols Are Fake

headline: Brothers, Bad Blood and the Blackwater Tangle
text: BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 — They were smart, scrappy brothers who rose from modest circumstances in Baltimore to become lacrosse stars at Princeton, succeed in business and land big government jobs.

headline: Georgia: Emergency Rule Lifted
text: As promised, the government of President Mikheil Saakashvili lifted a state of emergency imposed nine days ago after a crackdown on street protests. Mr. Saakashvili, left, also appointed a new prime minister, Lado Gurgenidze, chief of the private Bank of Georgia, to replace Zurab Nogaideli. Mr. Saakashvili is expected to resign his post next week, a legal requirement as he prepares for a presidential election he called for Jan. 5.

headline: State of Emergency Lifted in Georgia
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 16 — Georgia’s government lifted a state of emergency as promised today, nine days after the emergency was imposed following a crackdown on anti-government protests. The crackdown and emergency drew harsh Western criticism of a country considered to be one of the region’s most democratic.

headline: Cousins Sue Over Gipp Exhumation
text: Two distant cousins of George Gipp filed suit yesterday in a Michigan court against his great-nephew, ESPN, a biographer of Gipp’s and several others over the exhumation last month of the remains of Gipp, the Notre Dame halfback who died in December 1920.

headline: Sunni Group Says U.S. Killed Its Members
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 16 — A tribal group tapped by American forces to root out extremists here said Friday that more than four dozen of its members were killed during United States air and ground strikes north of the capital this week. But the United States military insisted that the attacks had been aimed instead at Al Qaeda and had killed 25 insurgents.

headline: Herbert Barrett, Musicians’ Manager, Is Dead at 97
text: Herbert Barrett, a leading business manager who oversaw the careers of prominent musicians, particularly in classical music, for more than half a century in New York and helped organize the first Great Performers series at Lincoln Center, died on Nov. 5 in Manhattan. He was 97 and had lived in Manhattan his entire life.

headline: The Russian Songbook, Under Western Influence
text: European culture has been chipping away at Russia for three or four centuries, with varying success. Dmitri Hvorostovsky’s elaborate evening at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday went back and forth on the subject.

headline: It’s Not Just the Uninsured
text: Sandra Hightower never thought of herself as particularly political. She worked, and much of her free time revolved around her daughter, Brittney, a fiercely outgoing teenager with a passion for cheerleading at her high school in Nacogdoches, Tex.

headline: Photos Add to Problems of Beset Hoboken Police
text: HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 16  It has been a difficult few weeks for the Police Department in this trendy riverfront town. The beleaguered mayor, David Roberts, heaved a sigh as he summed it all up in a news conference this week: “We have been on a slippery slide of matters getting worse.”

headline: Adding Math to List of Security Threats
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 — One of the world’s most prominent cryptographers issued a warning on Friday about a hypothetical incident in which a math error in a widely used computing chip places the security of the global electronic commerce system at risk.

headline: Judge Finds Tampering in Verdict on Teacher
text: SYRACUSE, Nov. 16  A music teacher charged in what prosecutors had called one of the largest molestation cases in central New York won the latest in a series of legal victories on Friday when a judge threw out his convictions, finding that two jurors had tried inappropriately to sway the others toward guilty verdicts.

headline: As Presidential Vote Nears, Beirut’s Residents Sense They Won’t Be the Winners
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 16 — Mireille Adas took part in a march through downtown Beirut this week, demanding that Hezbollah end its yearlong occupation of the city’s commercial center. Her jewelry shop, steps away from the organization’s tent camp, has suffered major losses as a result of the power struggle between Hezbollah and the government, which has paralyzed the capital and brought Lebanese politics to a standstill for nearly a year.

headline: Barcelona Party Boys Mix Styles and Languages for a Good-Time Electronic Vibe
text: “Is everybody happy?” asked a voice from the stage as the Pinker Tones headed into the last stretch of their set at S.O.B.’s on Thursday night. The grinning, dancing audience — small but elated — made the answer obvious. No one onstage had spoken; the words were samples, but that didn’t make them any less sincere. The Pinker Tones are a trio of producers and disc jockeys from Barcelona who aim for nothing less than euphoria.

headline: Condemned to Death and Capitalism
text: In recent years politically minded American filmmakers have, with reasonable cause, turned their artistic attention to the Iraq war and the various domestic policy issues that have arisen from it. And so the treatment of struggles in other parts of the world may have been sacrificed in some sense to that cinematic fashion.

headline: A Health Dept.’s Quandary: Warn the Public or Supervise the Doctor?
text: Days after a cluster of hepatitis cases in 2002 led health investigators to a clinic in Norman, Okla., the state’s chief epidemiologist held a news conference to urge anyone who had been a patient there to get tested immediately for blood-borne diseases. A nurse’s improper use of syringes was said to be the cause.

headline: Detective Is Accused of Making Drug Runs
text: A police detective was arrested yesterday and accused of taking cocaine from the Bronx to Virginia as part of a drug-trafficking operation, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Nets Start Slowly and Never Catch Up to Magic
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 16 — The past week has not been kind to the Nets.

headline: School Lesson
text: To the Editor:

headline: My Genome, Myself: Seeking Clues in DNA
text: The exploration of the human genome has long been relegated to elite scientists in research laboratories. But that is about to change. An infant industry is capitalizing on the plunging cost of genetic testing technology to offer any individual unprecedented — and unmediated — entree to their own DNA.

headline: Footnotes
text: The soprano Dawn Upshaw will perform Berio’s “Folk Songs” with the New York Philharmonic from March 5 to March 8. She replaces Audra McDonald, who withdrew because of a scheduling conflict. The concert is part of a program that includes Haydn’s Symphony No. 48, “Maria Theresia,” and Beethoven’s Symphony No. 4. ...Sandy Duncan, Fred Willard, above, Shonn Wiley and Mara Davi will join Rosie O’Donnell and Beth Leavel in “No, No, Nanette,” the final 2008 Encores! presentation, with performances from May 8 to May 12 at New York City Center; nycitycenter.org.

headline: Football Bruiser With Pavarotti Dream
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 — For the final performance of his football career at Harvard, the senior Noah Van Niel can picture the perfect closing scene.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Newly Released column on Thursday, about books, referred imprecisely to Jonathan Hayes, author of “Precious Blood,” a novel described in the column. Dr. Hayes continues to work as a medical examiner for New York City.

headline: Coin Collectors Sue State Department Over Import Rules
text: Three organizations representing coin collectors and dealers have filed a lawsuit against the State Department demanding greater disclosure of how the government makes decisions on the import of ancient artifacts from abroad.

headline: U.N. Report Describes Risks of Inaction on Climate Change
text: VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 16 — In its final and most powerful report, a United Nations panel of scientists meeting here describes the mounting risks of climate change in language that is both more specific and forceful than its previous assessments, according to scientists here.

headline: With a Full Quiver, Eager to Join the Band of Merry Men
text: I GRIPPED the plastic handle of my 66-inch-long rented bow, pretending to be a modern day Robin Hood. My surrogate Sherwood Forest was Pro Line Archery Lanes, an indoor range in Ozone Park, N.Y., with an outdoors motif. Deer, boar and bear heads adorned the walls.

headline: Love Takes a Tumble Amid a Brewing Storm
text: Love and the weather: what else is there, really? These far-reaching, changeable systems dominate our lives in myriad ways, big and small.

headline: Court’s Fuel-Economy Ruling May Prod Congress to Set Even Higher Requirements
text: DETROIT, Nov. 16 — A ruling by a federal appeals court this week to throw out proposed fuel-economy standards is likely to accelerate efforts in Congress to set higher requirements for all vehicles, industry analysts said Friday.

headline: Wal-Mart and Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jets’ Washington Sees an Opening in the Pro Bowl
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 16 — It is not easy to find a Pro Bowl candidate on a team with a 1-8 record, but the Jets have one in Leon Washington.

headline: Prosecution’s Best Pitch Is Precision, Experts Say
text: As news of Barry Bonds’s indictment on federal charges of perjury and obstruction of justice spread, handicapping a likely trial and predicting possible strategies immediately became popular throughout the nation’s law schools.

headline: Hillary Fries the Waffle
text: It’s remotely possible that some of you missed the very important and very lengthy Democratic debate this week. Perhaps you started watching it but had to switch off during the section on trade relations when you discovered your children had grown up and wanted to say goodbye before they left for college.

headline: Corrections
text: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday about “The Cat Who Went to Heaven,” a puppet musical at Culture Project, in SoHo, included outdated schedule information. After the section went to press, Culture Project said the production, scheduled to open today, had been postponed indefinitely. (Go to Article)

headline: Too Small a Sample

headline: When Their Alter Egos Come Out to Play
text: By day, Jennifer Donovan works as an astronomer, listening for the faintest whispers from atoms in deep outer space, the tracings of movement in galaxies millions of light-years from Earth.

headline: Obstacles: Crowded Sidewalks and Misconception
text: In a blur, the New York University men’s cross-country team ran west on 14th Street toward the Hudson River, passing through a bustling Union Square at midday. After the team crossed the West Side Highway, the Chelsea Piers descended quickly from the horizon as the runners headed south on a scenic pedestrian path in Hudson River Park and Battery Park.

headline: Glavine Is Given an Offer by Braves
text: The likelihood that Tom Glavine will finish his career where it began increased yesterday when the Atlanta Braves offered him a contract. Last season, Glavine’s decision to re-sign with the Mets was made easier by the Braves’ inability to make him an offer. But this time Glavine has the option of returning to Atlanta, where his family lives.

headline: When a Bad Break Is Good, and Other Lessons
text: The Internet has shrunk the world. At www.bridgebase.com we can watch live play in important bridge tournaments around the globe. Last weekend, while the European team champions were competing in Poland, the first semifinal of the English open trial took place at the West Midlands Bridge Club in Solihull.

headline: Fed Official Hints at No Rate Cut
text: A Federal Reserve governor said yesterday that another interest rate cut would probably offer few additional benefits to the economy, a hint that the central bank plans to hold rates steady at its meeting next month.

headline: The Case of the Rosenbergs: Their Sons’ View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Bars Secret Papers in Eavesdropping Case
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 — A federal appeals court said Friday that secrecy laws had forced it to exclude crucial evidence about the government’s wiretapping of an Islamic charity, making it far more difficult for the charity to proceed with its challenge to the National Security Agency’s eavesdropping program.

headline: The Vitality of Youth Meets the Ripeness of Experience
text: International youth orchestras have become useful symbols for the world peace lobby. The UBS Verbier Festival Orchestra, which played at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, advertises musicians from ages 17 to 29 and from 29 countries, among them a Chinese concertmaster and a Bulgarian timpanist.

headline: Knicks Fall in Double Overtime, Stretching Losing Streak to Five
text: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 16 — For one night, the Knicks had more pressing concerns than demotions, hurt feelings and their point guard’s frequent-flier miles. The problems were more fundamental: missed layups, fumbled rebounds and frequent miscues at the worst possible times.

headline: Discontented, DreamWorks Is in Talks to Join NBC
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 — Seeking a way out of an acrimonious relationship at Paramount, the DreamWorks principals — two Hollywood heavyweights, David Geffen and Steven Spielberg — have been negotiating to move their operation to NBC Universal, according to people close to the talks. But negotiations have hit a wall over financing.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about the departure next month of a co-host of the new National Public Radio morning program “The Bryant Park Project” referred imprecisely to the program’s scheduling on KCPW in Salt Lake City, where some listeners have complained that the program lacks substance. It did not replace NPR’s “Morning Edition” on that station; “Morning Edition” follows it.

headline: Set to Electric Violin, Thoughts Posted on YouTube
text: Daniel Bernard Roumain has built his career so far on small-scale works, partly because the orchestral commissions a young composer gets tend to be for scores lasting less than 15 minutes, and partly because his pop hybrids  the “Hip-Hop Studies and Études,” for example  demand concision. So his 80-minute multimedia piece, “One Loss Plus,” which had its premiere at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday evening, is a technical and conceptual leap for him.

headline: Herbert Barrett, 97, a Manager of Musicians, Dies

headline: One Market Remains Sound: Money Is Still There for Best Art
text: Never mind the gyrations on Wall Street or the subprime mortgage and equity crisis. There’s still plenty of money out there and an unquenched appetite for art. At least that seems to be the verdict after a two-week round of auctions at Christie’s, Sotheby’s and Phillips de Pury & Company, with bidders paying record prices for everything from a rare Matisse to a red heart sculpture by Jeff Koons.

headline: “Two Words”
Perelshteyn Wins Spice Cup
text: Eugene Perelshteyn, a grandmaster from Massachusetts, won the Spice Cup, a tournament at Texas Tech University in Lubbock, Tex. He led from start to finish, scoring 6.5 out of 9. Gilberto Hernandez, a grandmaster from Mexico, finished second, a half point back. The games from the tournament can be replayed at Monroi.com. The tournament, which was a memorial to Samuel Reshevsky, the Polish-born American grandmaster, was organized by Susan Polgar, chairwoman of the United States Chess Federation, and Paul Truong, Polgar’s husband.

headline: Long-run budget math
text: Some commenters have asked for more about Social Security’s role in the long-run budget problem, and in particular an explanation of my assertion that the Beltway obsession with Social Security reflects ignorance. So here’s a quick, informal explanation.

headline: Mystery of the mortgage mess
text: There’s a very good Economic Letter from the Dallas Fed about the housing crisis, which explains a lot about how the mess happened. In short: lenders began making lots of dubious loans in large part because they were able to slice and dice the loans and sell them off to investors who didn’t know what they were buying. My only fault with the letter is that it doesn’t emphasize the extent to which borrowers were also suckered in.

headline: Saturday Morning Kickoff
text: In the wake of the news that Oregon quarterback Dennis Dixon will miss the rest of the season with an injured left knee, John Hunt of the Oregonian reports that Dixon actually tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his knee against Arizona State two weeks ago. After discussing the situation with his family and the Ducks coaching staff, he decided to continue to play despite the injury.

headline: L.A. Auto Show: Governor Schwarzenegger’s Environmental Message
text: LOS ANGELES — For the second year running, the biggest power name at the L.A. Auto Show was Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger. When it comes to the environment and California, he’s the state’s A-list celebrity in more ways than one. And for an event that has become overwhelmingly green, he’s the ultimate display-booth babe.

headline: The Early Word: Giuliani’s New York Trail
text: Following his speech before the Federalist Society, a conservative legal group, Rudolph W. Giuliani is in the news. So is his wife, Judith, and in a departure, she’s getting much better press than he is.

headline: The Scene in Ann Arbor
text: While the national relevancy of Ohio State-Michigan is only a fraction of what it was last season, it goes without saying that folks around Ann Arbor are still fired up for this grandest of rivalry games.

headline: Ratings: ‘SpongeBob’ Earns 8.8 Million Viewers
text: On Monday on Nickelodeon, the first-ever made-for-TV “Spongebob” movie, “Atlantis SquarePantis,” attracted a staggering 8.8 million viewers at 8 p.m. The movie, which featured a special voice-over by David Bowie, was Monday night’s No. 1 entertainment program on cable.

The company invited the public to vote online for their favorite — Beat, Trax or Groove — promising that the winner would be greenlighted for production.

headline: Last Call for Carr?
text: No one came out and said it. But if you listened to the tone and heard the way people talked about Michigan Coach Lloyd Carr after his fourth consecutive loss to Ohio State on Saturday, it certainly seemed as if it was his last game as a head coach at Michigan Stadium.

headline: Personnel File: Bengals Hope Henry Gets Back on Track
text: The return of the suspended wide receiver CHRIS HENRY should have been a boon for Cincinnati last week. Henry, who was sidelined by legal troubles, had averaged a touchdown every 4.46 receptions entering 2007 and was expected to draw attention from the Bengals’ other receivers while being a weapon himself.

headline: Week 11 in Preview: Pressure Is on Panthers to Stop Favre
text: There are those who say the Packers — a young team led by an old quarterback — have been winning with mirrors. That may be the only thing they have not tried this season. They beat Philadelphia on a last-second field goal. They beat Denver on an 82-yard pass in overtime. They beat Minnesota last week with their first shutout in five years.

headline: Nutt Reacts to Reports
text: After Arkansas’s 45-31 victory over Mississippi State today, Razorbacks Coach Houston Nutt addressed recent reports that have said he would not be back next season.

headline: Living With the Three Gorges Dam
text: According to an official count, more than a million people were displaced by the building of the world's biggest dam. Now the "hidden dangers" of the project are coming to light.

text: This Sunday’s breakfast menu focuses on quality over quantity, with shows devoting their programs to a small number of big-name guests.

headline: Friday Night Fights
text: A group of New York's firefighters and police officers spent Friday night punching one another's faces at a gym in Brooklyn.

headline: You Asked. Now the Candidates Answer.
text: We’ve told you before about 10Questions.com, an effort (with which The Times Editorial Board is affiliated) to let voters around the country decide which questions to ask the presidential candidates. Today, the second round officially begins, with users’ top 10 questions posted and candidate responses beginning to come in.

headline: Liquid Gold in Morocco
text: The road from Marrakesh to Essaouira is craggy and bleak, an arid moonscape dotted only by a few roadside towns and the occasional Berber village. In the ’60s and ’70s, Essaouira was a stop on the hash-filled hippie trek — land in Marrakesh, load up your magic bus and head west for the windswept beaches and clear blue waters of this former Portuguese fishing village. Back then, Jimi Hendrix made the pilgrimage, as did Bob Marley and Cat Stevens. Essaouira still has remnants of its boho past: crocheted Rasta beanies are sold alongside fezzes in the souk; surfers come to lap up the waves in what is now one of the world’s top windsurfing and kiteboarding spots; and a dilapidated fort, which legend has it was the inspiration for Hendrix’s “Castles Made of Sand” (he actually recorded the song nearly two years before touching down here), is just south of town.

headline: The Cleanup After the Cleanup
text: THE year 1999 seemed to mark the end of an era for the Gowanus Canal, and a smelly era it was. In summers past, said Craig Hammerman, the district manager of Community Board 6 in Brooklyn, “the odor would curl your toes.”

headline: The Lottery Industry’s Own Powerball
text: STANDING recently in a Knoxville stadium filled with roaring University of Tennessee football fans, Rebecca Paul Hargrove, the highflying impresario of legalized gambling, proudly waved a symbolic check for a billion dollars. The moment, captured on jumbo screens across the stadium, was among the countless plugs for the fund-raising prowess of Tennessee’s lottery, which Ms. Hargrove started four years ago.

headline: Helsinki’s Grub Club
text: Each night in Helsinki, Finland, a random assortment of people, from celebrities to the living dead, line up in front of a tiny metal hutch tucked behind the Finnish parliament building. Inside the kiosk sits an old woman sporting granny glasses and a Soviet-era dye job that tints her hair an iridescent tangerine. Two outsize condiment dispensers hang, udderlike, from the ceiling; meat patties in puck form are lined up in front of a grill. The Finns have a word for their proudest national characteristic: sisu, or, roughly, “guts.” It takes sisu — a lot of sisu — to eat at Ykkos Jaskan Grilli.

text: Like Beaujolais nouveau, which arrived Thursday, Macari’s Early Wine, a Long Island chardonnay, is suitable for Thanksgiving. The 2007 edition is aromatic and vivacious.

headline: Bicyclist Killed in Fall on Bridge
text: A bicyclist riding on the Manhattan Bridge late Friday died after taking a wrong turn and flipping over a retaining wall on the bridge’s upper level, causing him to fall 15 feet to the lower level, where he was hit by a car.

headline: Every Workday Needs a Game Plan
text: Q. You just finished an eight-hour day at the office and, looking back, you barely got anything done. Now you feel guilty and worthless. What happened?

headline: 2 Koreas Agree on Aid to North and Trains Across Border
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 17  The prime ministers of North and South Korea have announced a significant package of economic projects to help rebuild the North’s broken economy and ease military tension on the divided peninsula by increasing traffic across the demilitarized zone.

headline: Crazy Little Thing Called Risk
text: BACK when I was managing other people’s money, I had a client, a doctor, who enjoyed giving away money to his daughters. He was lucky, because an extended bull market was under way with only minor interruptions. The more he gave away, the more the market replaced what he had parted with. As generosity appeared to be a cost-free form of recreation, he considered the whole thing a riskless enterprise.

headline: Don’t Call Him a Filmmaker, at Least Not First
text: THE paintings on broken plates that made Julian Schnabel an art-world star in the early 1980s seemed to announce their importance not just by their retrograde swagger but also by their sheer weight. Hanging one on a wall was like suspending a cabinet full of Buffalo china.

headline: Correction: Joy de Menil and Laird Reed
text: A report on Oct. 7, about the marriage of Joy de Menil and Laird Reed, misstated the title held by Ms. de Menil in 2005 when she worked at Heinemann Publishers in London. She was editorial director, not senior editor.

headline: Clinton & Clinton
text: It is a brave author indeed who, without benefit of full hindsight or personal experience, proposes to write yet another nearly contemporaneous account of the most overexposed presidency of modern times. Bill and Hillary Clinton, separately and together, have inspired dozens of journalists, historians, prosecutors and partisans — not least themselves — to disgorge millions of words in biographies, memoirs, apologias, polemics and official independent counsel reports. Many of these narratives — notably Bob Woodward’s “Agenda,” George Stephanopoulos’s “All Too Human” and Dick Morris’s “Behind the Oval Office” (to say nothing of “The Starr Report”) — flooded the bookstores in the midst of the two-term Clinton presidency, whose triumphs, failures and grubby melodramas were already 24/7 grist for the cable news networks and the emerging World Wide Web.

headline: In a Battle With Illness, Co-Workers Can Inspire
text: IN 2001, I learned I had ovarian cancer. I had no symptoms. One night I stepped off the treadmill and my stomach muscles seemed tighter. I reached down to feel them and found a lump on the left side of my abdomen. I knew it shouldn’t be there.

headline: Remains of the Day
text: There is a milking stool in Achille Castiglioni's design studio, the wooden kind that Swiss farmers have used to milk their cows for centuries. It isn't what you'd expect to find in the studio of one of the 20th century's most famous industrial designers, but Castiglioni rarely did the expected.

headline: Nicole Dunn, Steven Fisher
text: Nicole Ashley Dunn, a daughter of Mitchell P. Dunn of Hewlett, N.Y., and the late Pauline Dunn, was married last evening in Lawrence, N.Y., to Steven Harris Fisher, a son of Susan and Mark I. Fisher of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence.

headline: Democrats Outline Plans to Improve Environment
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 — Three Democratic presidential hopefuls described their plans to combat global warming and promote energy independence at a forum here Saturday, with each emphasizing the need for government mandates to reduce greenhouse gases and voicing commitment to treaties on the environment.

headline: Ochoa Trying to Build a Foundation for the Future
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17 — For the first time in a long time, the L.P.G.A. has what appears to be a “can’t miss” story line as it closes out 2007 and looks ahead to the coming season.

headline: Oceanic World Orders
text: It is impossible to imagine George W. Bush eating cucumber sandwiches on an English lawn while discussing the latest cricket scores. Yet this president, the one with the fewest English airs, has nonetheless inspired rampant Anglophilia among some foreign policy experts. With his unashamedly “civilizing” mission in the Middle East, and his deployment of gunboats as a tool of diplomacy, Bush has sent intellectuals dashing back to the British Empire for parallels and predecessors.

text: Aileen Ford Humphreys, the daughter of Virginia L. Humphreys of Lancaster, Pa., and the late James A. Humphreys III, was married last evening to Capt. Matthew Mackenzie James, the son of Lois M. James and Alan M. James of Lititz, Pa. The Rev. T. Alan W. Garrity, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Coral Beach and Tennis Club in Paget, Bermuda.

headline: A Loud Legal Voice on Warming
text: While Washington’s politicians dither, the federal courts have become increasingly active in the debate over global warming, aggressively pushing the White House and Congress to regulate greenhouse gases or explain why they cannot. These rulings add the force of law to the demands for action from scientists, a growing number of business leaders, and many state governors.
