headline: Perlman Takes Post With Philharmonic
text: ITZHAK PERLMAN, the heralded violinist who counts among his fans several presidents, Queen Elizabeth II and Elmo of “Sesame Street,” has been appointed music director of the Westchester Philharmonic, beginning with the 2008-9 season.

headline: With Carter Out Again, Nets Lose Fifth in a Row
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 17  The lineup may have been different Saturday night, but the result was a familiar one for the Nets. They lost again, this time to the Miami Heat, 91-87. That is five losses in a row for a team that continues to sputter without Vince Carter.

headline: The Food of Love
text: Reading “Service Included,” Phoebe Damrosch’s memoir about waiting tables at the acclaimed Manhattan restaurant Per Se, I was reminded of George Orwell. The waiter’s skill, Orwell wrote, “is chiefly in being servile. ... He lives perpetually in sight of rich people, stands at their tables, listens to their conversation, sucks up to them with smiles and discreet little jokes. He has the pleasure of spending money by proxy.” Orwell quotes one waiter waxing rhapsodic about a particular meal: “It was splendid, mon p’tit, mais magnifique! Jesus Christ! The Champagne, the silver, the orchids — I have never seen anything like them, and I have seen some things. Ah, it was glorious!”

headline: In a Catalog of Catastrophes, Hurricanes Rule
text: A calamity-ridden part of the year — hurricane season — is about to end, and the United States was lucky to dodge the worst of its wrath in 2007. Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean bore the brunt of the damage this time.

headline: In Frying Pan and Fire
text: WAR is hell, as General Sherman observed, but it’s many other things besides. Like no other earthly endeavor, war calls forth the best and the ugliest that humans can be: brave, brutal, petty, loyal and bored. The American venture in Iraq has summoned the whole range of human experience, from the hopes and hubris of the invasion’s first days to the dark and uncertain place the country is today.

headline: Datebook
text: WALLAND, TENN.

headline: For Late Autumn, Apple Gathering
text: The hayrides into the apple orchards of March Farm, in rural Bethlehem, ended a few weeks ago, but you can still enjoy the pretty panorama of farmland and surrounding hills by gathering apples yourself.

headline: Fighting to Fix What’s Not Broken
text: Social Security isn’t broke. So why are Democrats fighting so hard right now over how to fix it?

headline: A Personal Salute to a Hero’s Memory; To Keep Oceans Full of Bluefin Tuna; The Yonkers City Council and a Historic Home (3 Letters)
text: A Personal Salute to a Hero’s Memory

headline: As You Live and Breathe
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shake, Rattle and Roll
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Protocons
text: In the years between Franklin Roosevelt’s first victory in 1932 and Richard Nixon’s resignation in 1974, the Republican Party experienced many disasters. Behind them was a conservative movement that started in the political wilderness, a band of maverick intellectuals exiled from fashion and power in the 1940s and ’50s, doubtful of their claim on the future.

headline: When One Job Is Enough
text: When Joseph Lieberman hedged his bets by running for the United States Senate at the same time he ran for vice president, his dual candidacy was allowed because Connecticut law does not prevent one person from running for two seats.

headline: A Private Club Where the Privileged Can Play With Cars
text: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

headline: Letters: Is (His) Biography (Our) Destiny?
text: Those who feel safer with Hillary Clinton’s old-school “big stick” diplomacy than with the kind of intelligent use of “soft power” that Barack Obama endorses are living in the past. Our experiences in Vietnam and Iraq have established that use of force does not necessarily lead to beneficial results. What a President Obama would offer is a new avenue to power and respect, not through military might, but through cooperation and understanding. There is no strength more powerful than countries and peoples working together for the common good; and in the face of the dire threats we all share — from global warming to desperate acts born of social inequity — such cooperation can occur none too soon.

headline: Stagehands’ Strike Continues, but Negotiations Resume
text: The producers’ league and the stagehands’ union negotiated into the night yesterday in an attempt to bring an end to the strike that has darkened most of Broadway for more than a week. They plan to begin talking again this morning at 9:30.

headline: A Park That Ran With the Wrong Crowd
text: SALEM, Ore.

headline: Harold J. Berman, 89, Who Altered Beliefs About Origins of Western Law, Dies
text: Harold J. Berman, a scholar whose expertise in Russian law took him to a Soviet courtroom to fight for royalties owed Arthur Conan Doyle, and whose forceful scholarship altered thinking about Western law’s origins, died on Nov. 13 in Brooklyn. He was 89.

headline: Alison David, Adam Cole-Kelly
text: Alison Nicole David, the daughter of Cookie David and Brian David of Chicago, was married there last evening to Adam Cole-Kelly, the son of Kathy Cole-Kelly of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Thomas Kelly of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Daniel G. Zemel officiated at the Peninsula Hotel.

headline: New Japanese Immigration Controls Worry Foreigners
text: TOKYO, Nov. 17 — Japan has tried hard in recent years to shake its image as an overly insular society and offer a warmer welcome to foreign investors and tourists. But the country is about to impose strict immigration controls that many fear could deter visitors and discourage businesses from locating here.

headline: So Many ‘Nutcrackers,’ So Little Time
text: “WELL, we are one more ‘Nutcracker’ nearer death,” the British critic Richard Buckle wrote in 1972. You get the tone. Here is the true sophisticate (note the royal “we”), jaded to the core, but there is this unkillable ballet, this glut of sweetness, this inevitable part of the dancegoer’s Christmas routine. If you think “The Nutcracker” is all tinsel, sugar and infantile twee-ness, then that’s the tone you too should adopt at this time of year. In the United States, several stagings of “The Nutcracker” start on Thanksgiving weekend, and we won’t be out of this “Nutcracker” season until after the New Year.

headline: City of Priam
text: Peter Ackroyd belongs to another age. The author of more than a dozen novels, as well as volumes of poetry, plays and miscellaneous works of nonfiction, he recalls a time when it was commonplace for writers not merely to be prolific but to exhibit a sometimes bewildering catholicity of interest. In addition to biographies of Shakespeare, Dickens, T. S. Eliot and the city of London, he has written a book on transvestism and children’s guides to ancient Greece and Rome. Most of his novels are historical, depicting figures as diverse as Milton, Chatterton and Oscar Wilde. Now, in “The Fall of Troy,” he turns his attention to the 19th-century German archaeologist Heinrich Schliemann, whose quest to discover the ancient city of Troy becomes the occasion for a novel that is engaging, disturbing, intellectually complex and just a little kitschy.

headline: Outside Yale Bowl, Plenty of Wine and Cheese
text: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17 — With a Proud Yalie sticker on the lapel of his trenchcoat, Stuart Tisdale stood outside the Yale Bowl Saturday afternoon, his face expressionless. Inside the Bowl, the final minutes were ticking away in Harvard’s 37-6 rout of the favored Bulldogs.

headline: Garden City Gets Closer to Saving a Landmark
text: AFTER nearly 15 years, two lawsuits and several rejected proposals, Garden City is edging toward a decision to save the historic 500-room Cathedral School of St. Paul’s, a stately landmark in the heart of the village.

headline: Amy Goldman, Eric Falkenstein
text: Amy Elizabeth Goldman, a client relations manager for a law firm, and Eric Matthew Falkenstein, a Broadway theater producer, were married last evening. Rabbi Sylvin L. Wolf officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Key Biscayne, Fla.

headline: Channeling Dick Cheney
text: I have no idea who is going to win the Democratic presidential nomination, but lately I’ve been wondering whether, if it is Barack Obama, he might want to consider keeping Dick Cheney on as his vice president.

headline: Without a Trace
text: Not knowing is one of the more uncomfortable, if not terrifying, states of being. Without a clear ending, there’s no escape. When the television goes to black, we find it far safer to assume that the cable connection is out, rather than accept that the self-reflective screen is all we’ll get.

headline: Steelers at Jets
text: JETS’ RUSHING OFFENSE

headline: Sweeping the Clouds Away
text: Sunny days! The earliest episodes of “Sesame Street” are available on digital video! Break out some Keebler products, fire up the DVD player and prepare for the exquisite pleasure-pain of top-shelf nostalgia.

headline: Italian Newcomer With a Bold Outlook
text: BRIVO is the kind of restaurant Long Islanders love. It is Italian, the Island’s favorite. It is fancy enough for a special occasion, with crystal chandeliers, a waterfall wall and large mirrors framed in black wrought iron. Best of all, its menu is exciting, loaded with dishes I couldn’t wait to try.

headline: Finding That Hidden Gem
text: WHEN she relocated to New York three years ago, Karen Yau looked at dozens of apartments before finding her one-bedroom rental in London Terrace Gardens in Chelsea. It was lovely and large, with a classic layout. “I thought I was never going to leave,” she said.

headline: You From Around Here?
text: Nobody wants to eat at a chain restaurant on vacation. And in more and more cities, you don’t have to. The virtue of localism, long cherished by small towns, is taking hold in urban centers across the country. The new $41 million SouthBridge complex in Scottsdale, Ariz. (right), is devoted entirely to one-off, locally owned stores and restaurants — no chains allowed, not even Starbucks. Although a few public efforts, like San Francisco’s Hayes Valley (see Page 38) and Denver’s Cherry Creek North shopping district (which is 75 percent chain-free), have succeeded in fending off franchises, SouthBridge is the first private urban development of its size to go completely indie. Other projects have made a similar effort. The Second Street District shopping center in Austin, Tex., opened in 2005 with 65 percent local tenants, and the owners of Larimer Square in Denver have spent the last several years letting the leases of places like Williams-Sonoma lapse and replacing them with regional businesses. It all adds up to a more exciting urban landscape. “When I go to New York, I love to find the little restaurant no one’s heard of,” says the SouthBridge developer Fred Unger. “I think that’s what we’re all yearning for, going back to Mayberry and Floyd the barber.”

headline: Preventing Shocks and Electrical Fires
text: HOME electrical fires kill some 480 people a year in the United States, injure more than 2,000 and destroy more than $868 million in property, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association says. And while smoke detectors can alert the household to a fire, other devices can help prevent a fire in the first place. There are also devices that can protect people from electrical shock.

headline: These Pour Well With Turkey
text: Lieb Family Cellars is a producer whose name is apt for Thanksgiving. When Long Island families sit down to turkey on Thursday, Lieb’s newest whites and reds could easily accompany a broad spectrum of first and second courses.

headline: Saluting a Champion of All That Jazz
text: More than 800 people turned out last week to pay tribute to Ed Bradley, the late “60 Minutes” correspondent, at a benefit for Jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan. Mr. Bradley was a member of the organization’s board and host of its weekly radio show.

headline: Correction: At Shelters, It’s Raining Cats ... and More Cats
text: An article last Sunday about county animal shelters being inundated with pregnant cats and kittens misstated the role of Dr. Michael Woltz at the Central Animal Hospital in Scarsdale. He is the owner, not the co-owner.

headline: Aboriginal Lit
text: When “Carpentaria,” Alexis Wright’s epic novel about Aboriginal life, appeared last year, readers in Australia were slow to warm to its magisterial yet colloquial voice, which transformed the oral tradition of the country’s indigenous people into a swirling narrative spiked with burlesque humor and featuring a huge cast of eccentric characters. Despite highly laudatory reviews, Wright’s 500-plus-page tale of the tortured relations between blacks and whites in the sparsely populated desert country around the Gulf of Carpentaria in northern Queensland languished on bookstore shelves. With a few exceptions, the independent bookstores run by political liberals, who have often expressed embarrassment at the sorry treatment of Australia’s indigenous people, were reluctant to promote it. Too difficult stylistically, said the salespeople at the Macleay Bookshop and Bookoccino, two of Sydney’s top literary outlets, where Wright’s novel was hard to find in the months after its publication.

headline: NY1 Anchor Quits After Calling a Show on the Station Under a False Name
text: Gary Anthony Ramsay, a longtime reporter and a weekend anchor for NY1 News, left the station this week, days after calling in to one of the channel’s live shows under a false name and commenting on a news story, a lapse in judgment that Mr. Ramsay described as “a flash moment of frustration.”

headline: These Scientific Minds Think (and Drink) Alike
text: THE young men and women crowded into the basement of the Union Hall bar in Brooklyn looked as if they were used to spending time in dark steamy rooms. Dressed in plaid flannel shirts and corduroy coats, and carrying canvas bags, they could have come in search of the latest breakthrough band.

headline: Bread Making and Truffle Hunting in Italy
text: Lush, green Piedmont in northern Italy is the center of the slow-food movement, which emphasizes local produce — not exactly a hardship for the truffles-and-wine-rich region. Martin Randall Travel (www.martinrandall.com) in London is capitalizing on Piedmont’s natural attributes with its new culinary walking tour there. From Sept. 21 to 27, “Gastronomic Piedmont” will take participants to restaurants and wineries, on truffle-hunting trips near Alba and on tours through a sausage factory and cheese farms. The package, excluding airfare, includes private bus transportation, lodging with breakfast, five lunches, one picnic, four dinners with wine, and wine tastings, and costs £1,710, about $3,560, at $2.14 to the pound.

headline: Producer? So’s Your Old Man
text: THE name Gersten is back on an office door at the Public Theater.

headline: U.N. Chief Seeks More Climate Change Leadership
text: VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 17  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, describing climate change as “the defining challenge of our age,” released the final report of a United Nations panel on climate change here on Saturday and called on the United States and China to play “a more constructive role.”

headline: On a Deadly Day, U.S. Reports Drop in Iraq Attacks
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 18 — An American official announced Sunday that attacks and attempted attacks across Iraq last week dipped to their lowest point for any week since January of last year, and that attacks had dropped by more than half since the United States increased its troop levels in June.

headline: Dressed to Sip
text: TO the sartorially challenged, the closet usually appears half-empty. When you’re dressing for Stacy London, who mends errant wardrobes on TLC’s “What Not to Wear” with all the tenderness of a darning needle, your closet might as well be bare.

headline: A Fiddler and Painter Whose Love of Music Shaped His Work
text: Last year, the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages put together a major, revealing exhibition on William Sidney Mount (1807-1868) and his brother Shepard (1804-1868), two often-overlooked artists who were also native Long Islanders. This year, to observe the 200th anniversary of William Sidney Mount’s birth, the museum has installed a small but still significant new show, “Praise for the Artist: William Sidney Mount at 200.”

headline: The Perfect Shade of Papaya
text: APATHY comes in many forms. But to Elaine Ryan, it comes in just one color — beige — though it may use dangerously seductive aliases: vanilla, mocha, crème caramel. To her, these shades represent nothing short of a renunciation of the inalienable right to happiness in home décor.

headline: In a City of Sprinters, One Eye on the Clock
text: NEW YORKERS who have visited cities like Washington and San Francisco, and watched the blinking numbers on electronic traffic signals counting down the seconds to cross, often wonder, sometimes enviously, why they can’t have blinking numbers of their own.

headline: A Little Bit Country in Florida
text: It takes many fingers to count all of the allurements Florida claims for itself. According to assorted tourist literature, the state simultaneously contains the Winter Strawberry Capital of the World (Plant City), the Indoor Foliage Capital of the World (Apopka) and the Lightning Capital of the World (the whole state), among lots of other Capitals of the World, including the Cigar, the Nudist, the Possum, the Shark Attack, the Golf, the Phosphates, the Scientology and the Sponge.

headline: Hockey Rivalries Take to the Rails
text: Newark

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: Forty Acres and a Gap in Wealth
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Deborah Glickstein, Brett Feltingoff
text: Deborah Joy Glickstein, the daughter of Eydie Glickstein and Neil E. Glickstein of Allentown, Pa., was married there last evening to Brett David Feltingoff, the son of Arlene Feltingoff, also of Allentown, and the late Barry Feltingoff. Rabbi Moshe Re’em officiated at Temple Beth El, with Rabbi Robert B. Lennick taking part.

headline: Johnson Making New Era His Own
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 17  With four Cup championships in his trophy case, Jeff Gordon already has a secure place among the great drivers in Nascar history. Now Gordon’s teammate and protégé, Jimmie Johnson, is about to join him among the Nascar elite.

headline: Values on Rise for Rare Collectibles
text: In the fall of 2005, Charles Hack, a New Yorker who has made a fortune in real estate and spent a lot of it on old master paintings and Renaissance sculpture, noticed a newspaper advertisement for an auction of a rare stamp.

headline: For Kevin Bacon and Local Arts Scene, Zero Degrees of Separation
text: THE Stamford Town Center Plaza may seem like an odd place for a performance by the Bacon Brothers, but early next year, Kevin Bacon plans on being there with his brother, Michael, to celebrate the newly expanded mall with some of the new songs they are preparing to release on an album next spring. This is the sort of local thing that Mr. Bacon, a part-time resident of Sharon, likes to do, despite his frenetic movie career.

headline: Cupcakes a Chicken Can Love
text: Cupcakes are inherently cute, but at Sweet Avenue Bake Shop in Rutherford they’re also playful and sometimes even slightly psychedelic.

headline: But Soft! Less Woe for Juliet and Her Romeo
text: “LET’S start with Act IV, No. 51,” Leon Botstein, the conductor, says after bringing the rehearsal to order. “The happy ending.”

headline: For the Police and Fire Departments, a Night to Get Their Jabs In
text: The jurisdictions were unmistakable.

headline: Ching May Miss Dynamo Title Defense
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 — Brian Ching is exactly where he and the defending Major League Soccer champion Houston Dynamo wanted to be — back in the M.L.S. Cup. The league’s championship game Sunday at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium is a rematch of last year’s game between Houston and the New England Revolution.

headline: Love in the Time of Dementia
text: SO this, in the end, is what love is.

headline: Caroline Cohen, Robert Wall
text: Caroline Elizabeth Cohen, a daughter of Joanne Bernstein-Cohen and Dr. David Cohen of Manhattan, is to be married this afternoon to Robert Peter Wall, a son of Ellen Wall and Basil Wall of Freelton, Ontario. Marilyn D. Go, a United States magistrate judge for the Eastern District of New York in Brooklyn, is to officiate at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: Funnyman, Who Art Thou?
text: BURBANK, Calif.

headline: Manhunt
text: Stories and novels, Walter Mosley once observed, “are entertainments that help us cope with the intense pressures mortality brings.”

headline: Words of Wisdom for the Toastmaster
text: SISTER WENDY ON PRAYER

headline: A Personal Salute to a Hero’s Memory; To Keep Oceans Full of Bluefin Tuna (3 Letters)
text: A Personal Salute to a Hero’s Memory

headline: Among the Contenders: Appetizers and Espresso
text: IF it’s possible to judge a restaurant by its espresso, Due Terre is excellent. Deep, dark and mesmerizing, with a beautiful caramel swirl of crema on top and without a hint of bitterness, the espresso comes with a miniature pitcher of steamed milk for a do-it-yourself macchiato.

headline: Expanding the Frontiers of the Vegetarian Plate
text: VEGETARIANISM is a simple idea — don't eat animals — with an ancient pedigree. According to the Vegetarian Resource Group, 4.7 million American adults are vegetarians or vegans (people who avoid all animal products, including cheese and eggs).

headline: Countrywide’s Chief Salesman and Defender
text: An article last Sunday about Countrywide Financial misidentified the institutional investor that has called for the resignation of three directors at the company. It is the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees Pension Fund, not the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Investment Fund.

headline: Grazing from Delhi to London
text: THINK of Brick Lane, and images of London's most famous immigrant street, depicted in Monica Ali's novel (and soon-to-be film) of the same name, come to mind, as do the spicy smells of cumin, cardamom and turmeric emanating from the more than 50 Bangladeshi restaurants that line the historic thoroughfare.

headline: Maryland Parents Told to Have Children Immunized
text: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Nov. 17 — Hundreds of parents, who had been warned that they might face fines and jail time unless they had their children immunized, brought their children to a courthouse here Saturday for the vaccinations.

headline: Bengals Hope Henry Gets Back on Track
text: The return of the suspended wide receiver CHRIS HENRY should have been a boon for Cincinnati last week. Henry, who was sidelined by legal troubles, had averaged a touchdown every 4.46 receptions entering 2007 and was expected to draw attention from the Bengals’ other receivers while being a weapon himself.

headline: Patients Without Borders
text: Long before the dentists and the doctors got there, before the nurses, the hygienists and X-ray techs came, before anyone had flicked on the portable mammography unit or sterilized the day’s first set of surgical instruments, the people who needed them showed up to wait. It was 3 a.m. at the Wise County Fairgrounds in Virginia — Friday, July 20, 2007 — the start of a rainy Appalachian morning. Outside the gates, people lay in their trucks or in tents pitched along the grassy parking lot, waiting for their chance to have their medical needs treated at no charge — part of an annual three-day “expedition” led by a volunteer medical relief corps called Remote Area Medical.

headline: Whitney Wright, Brett Ehrlich
text: Whitney Elizabeth Wright, a daughter of Robin F. Wright and Richard N. Wright of Greensboro, N.C., was married last evening to Brett Stuart Ehrlich, the son of Ronnie Ehrlich and Harvey D. Ehrlich of New City, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. J. Christian Wilson, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C.

headline: A Blues Icon Comes to Life Through a Kindred Voice
text: There is much in the life of the blues icon Bessie Smith that has the makings of potent drama: racism, domestic violence, alcoholism, bisexuality, all set against the suffocating backdrop of a largely segregated America in the Prohibition and Depression eras.

headline: Profiling by the Numbers
text: On Nov. 9, the New York Police Department quietly released its latest figures about the number and race of New Yorkers whom police officers stopped and frisked, giving the public access to data from Jan. 1, 2006, to Sept. 30, 2007. An analysis of these figures shows that racial profiling continues in the city, and that blacks are bearing the overwhelming brunt of police stops.

headline: Letters
text: A Search for Answers

headline: Feminine, but Not Much to Explain the Mystique
text: Billed as a showcase of contemporary art by women addressing feminist issues, “The Feminine Mystique: Contemporary Artists Respond” is little of the sort. The more than two dozen artists in the show are women, but much of the work is insubstantial.

headline: Museums Solicit Dealers’ Largess
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: 36 Hours in San Sebastián
text: WHAT is it about San Sebastián that has foodies reaching for superlatives (“culinary capital of Europe”; “best place to eat in the world”)? Maybe it was the French aristocracy, who imported their haughty chefs in the 19th century, turning this belle époque town on the Basque coast of northern Spain into an epicurean resort. Or maybe it's the food-rich geography, a scallop-shaped coastline sandwiched between the fertile sea and mountainous farmlands. And then there are the Basques themselves, who approach eating with the same fervor as they do soccer. Whatever the case, this laid-back surfing resort is not for weak-willed dieters. There are sweet-smelling cafes and mouth-watering bites to tempt you at every turn — not to mention having one of the highest concentrations of Michelin stars in the world.

headline: The Sleep-Industrial Complex
text: Pete Bils’s background is in sales — or, as he puts it, “retail concepts.” He joined Select Comfort 12 years ago to teach its salespeople how to better sell the company’s Sleep Number Bed. The Sleep Number Bed is an air-filled mattress. Each side can be inflated with a little remote control to the ideal level of firmness for the person sleeping on it — his or her “sleep number,” zero to 100 — thus accommodating a husband who prefers his side firm and a wife who likes hers softer. You may recognize the Sleep Number Bed from its television commercials featuring the original Bionic Woman, Lindsay Wagner. Or you may have seen Bils himself explicating its many features and benefits in the loneliest hours of the night on the QVC shopping network.

headline: Artificial Intelligence
text: IN the last months before the American-led invasion of Iraq, as we now know all too well, the administration of President George W. Bush showed a fine disregard for truth or consequences. This manifested itself in many ways, from insinuations about Saddam Hussein’s ephemeral Qaeda connections to the Pentagon’s willful refusal to address the human and economic costs of occupation. Bookstore shelves now groan with wide-ranging accounts struggling to chronicle the pathological hubris that drove the United States onward to Baghdad.

headline: Susan Becker, William Gould
text: Susan Lavinia Becker, the daughter of Jeffrey Becker of New York and the late Tess Becker, was married last night to William Harris Gould, the son of Jean Gould and Bruce Gould of Great Neck, N.Y. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

headline: Talk Softly but Carry a Big Louis XIV Foot
text: AT the moment, Picasso has nothing on John Richardson. Sure, Picasso was the greatest artist of the 20th century, redrawing the lines of perspective, politics and portraiture (to start with the P’s). Even in his complicated personal life, flawlessly excavated in Mr. Richardson’s new volume of biography, “A Life of Picasso: The Triumphant Years, 1917-1932” (Knopf), he recast old ideas of an artist’s relationship with his subjects.

headline: N.F.L. Matchups Week 11
text: REDSKINS at COWBOYS

headline: What to Do When Goliaths Roar?
text: AS shoppers arm themselves for post-Thanksgiving bargain hunting later this week, they’ll also indulge in another, newer annual tradition: surfing the Web for advance information about Black Friday retail sales. By organizing sale prices from scattered newspaper circulars into a single database, the Internet has made it easy to search for particular items and compare prices — too easy, at least in the eyes of many major retailers.

headline: Iraq Credits Iran for Helping to Curb Attacks by Militias
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 17 — The Iraqi government on Saturday credited Iran with helping to rein in Shiite militias and stemming the flow of weapons into Iraq, helping to improve the security situation noticeably.

headline: 1. Find Drum. 2. Grab Stick. 3. Bang! Boom!
text: JENS HANNEMANN might be the funniest drummer who has no idea that people are laughing at him. In a scene from his latest instructional DVD, this vaguely Teutonic musician has just finished demonstrating the step-by-step mechanics of an overly elaborate rhythm: in this case a two-handed drum pattern from his song “Just in Time” that he illustrates by calling out the words “left” and “right,” seemingly at random, about 31 times in a row. Then he turns to the camera and with a straight face tells his would-be pupils, “You might want to memorize that for when you’re practicing at home.”

headline: Builders Return to Class for Lessons in ‘Green’
text: Because of an editing error, the National Perspectives article last Sunday about developers learning to build environmentally friendly houses and condominiums referred imprecisely to the development of the Withers Preserve, a housing project in Myrtle Beach, S.C. The developers are building around the wetlands, not “on” them.

headline: In Luxurious Detail
text: WAY back in 1999, the last time Tony Duquette, the brilliant and eccentric California designer of interiors, stage sets and jewelry, was rediscovered, Amy Spindler, the style editor of The New York Times Magazine, made an observation in these pages that still rings true. “When a Banana Republic catalog starts to look like the trendy, vacuous pages of Wallpaper, and Club Monaco is indistinguishable from Prada,” she wrote, “you know it’s time for high style to move on.”

headline: Needle and Thread and the Chinatown Night
text: A GOLDEN phoenix and a dragon kept watch over the wedding reception at the Golden Unicorn dim sum palace in Chinatown, their tiny light bulb eyes blinking like Christmas lights. It was 7:30 on a Saturday night in September, and just as I was tucking into the second dish of the 10-course banquet, the spaghetti strap on my black designer dress snapped and hung like a lo mein noodle.

headline: Blowing the Whistle, Many Times
text: WHEN Cynthia Fitzgerald started out in pharmaceutical sales 20 years ago, she received ample training on the right and wrong ways to sell medical products. Right was selling on the merits. Wrong was luring customers with perks and freebies. It was O.K. to buy doctors lunch or dinner, for example, but tempting them with lavish gifts was taboo.

headline: Immigrants Could Face Tighter Rules in Michigan
text: Several Michigan lawmakers, frustrated with the defeat in Congress of an immigration law overhaul, are proposing state laws to punish employers who hire illegal immigrants.

headline: Watch and Release
text: THE news media have a penchant for reliving major events on significant anniversaries. So it came as no surprise this year that we were bombarded with 30-year-old memories of the summer of 1977, when the Bronx was burning, the Son of Sam was on the loose and a blackout led to days of widespread looting.

headline: U.S. Secretly Aids Pakistan in Guarding Nuclear Arms
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 — Over the past six years, the Bush administration has spent almost $100 million on a highly classified program to help Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s president, secure his country’s nuclear weapons, according to current and former senior administration officials.

headline: The Patriots Are Coming, and the Bills Are Ready
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Nov. 14  They are all there in a gallery of large, fading photographs that decorate the walls of the Buffalo Bills’ field house. Bruce Smith, Andre Reed, Jack Kemp: plexiglass-encased reminders that the best days of the Bills have often seemed to be behind them.

headline: Sergeant Fled Army, but Not the War in His Head
text: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 15 — The psychotherapist remembers the strapping young soldier, slouched in a chair in her office one morning last month, asking if God could be punishing him because he had once thought it would be exciting to fight in a war.

headline: Two Sides of Mr. Sarkozy
text: The picture of a French president who jogs, vacations in New Hampshire and even seems comfortable around President Bush is so unusual that it has earned Nicolas Sarkozy the nickname of Sarko the American. That, along with France’s toughened stand against Iran’s nuclear appetites, won Mr. Sarkozy bipartisan applause in Washington this month.

headline: Elizabeth Davison and Van Gothner
text: Elizabeth Anne Davison and Karl Ivan Folke Gothner were married yesterday afternoon at St. Paul’s Chapel on the campus of Columbia University in New York. The Rev. Kathryn Kibbie Laird, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Lobbying Helps Spur Talks in Writers’ Strike
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 — An agreement by striking writers and Hollywood studios to resume bargaining was prompted by back-channel talks and mounting worries on both sides about their image, people with knowledge of the situation said Saturday.

headline: Truck Rated Safe, With Asterisk
text: WHEN the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety announced the latest list of what it considers the safest vehicles last week, there was a surprising newcomer: a pickup truck.

headline: Seeking a Homer, Rejoicing in Singles
text: WOODMERE, N.Y.

headline: As Theatergoers Alter Plans, a Juggling Act for Ticket Agents
text: Most of the big-ticket plays and musicals were quiet last week, but there was plenty of Broadway drama around the country.

headline: Federer Defeats Ferrer in Masters Cup
text: SHANGHAI, Nov. 18 — Roger Federer, who ended his season on Sunday with a straight-set victory over the hottest player in the Masters Cup tournament, now gets to rest a bit before taking on his only serious remaining opponent: history.

headline: Amanda Entin, Patrick Nichols II
text: Amanda Sue Entin, a daughter of Lois J. Entin and Alvin E. Entin of Tamarac, Fla., was married last evening to Patrick James Nichols II, the son of Beth C. Nichols and Mr. Nichols of Great Falls, Va. Sheldon R. Schwartz, a county court judge for Florida’s 11th Judicial Circuit, officiated at the Hyatt Regency Pier 66 Hotel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: Take Me Out to the Courtroom
text: Buy yourself some peanuts and Cracker Jack, court fans, as a fascinating trial is coming. Can the government convict Barry Bonds of perjury? Will Mighty Casey strike out? Unless the government has an undisclosed eyewitness who saw Bonds receive injections or heard him admit to steroid use, this trial stacks up as a classic credibility contest.

headline: Doc Holiday
text: For decades, travelers have journeyed to spas not only for healthy food and daily massages but also for spiritual sustenance, a chance to look inward in a pampering environment. And in recent years the menu has veered off into New Age la-la land with chakra balancings, sage clearings and Zen archery. But now, at an increasing number of spas, resorts and hotels, travelers are being offered a chance to look inside literally — at their DNA, bone density and cardiac stress levels. So long, drum circle: the wellness quest has evolved from navel gazing to the science of longevity.

headline: In Korea, a Boot Camp Cure for Web Obsession
text: MOKCHEON, South Korea — The compound — part boot camp, part rehab center — resembles programs around the world for troubled youths. Drill instructors drive young men through military-style obstacle courses, counselors lead group sessions, and there are even therapeutic workshops on pottery and drumming.

headline: In Poor Health
text: For anyone who still believes that New Jersey’s health care system actually works, a recent study should come as a shocker. In a ranking of states based on overall health, New Jersey declined sharply in the past year, slipping from 14th to 21st. Experts say a major reason is the alarming increase in the number of residents without health insurance.

headline: Practicing Different Religions (but United on the Issue of Pork)
text: ON the morning in August 2005 when Sam Habib and Cindy Gluck opened their first Dunkin’ Donuts, they awoke at dawn to make sure that the glazed fritters and French crullers were out on the counter. Then Mr. Habib sneaked off to the neighboring mosque to pray, and Ms. Gluck, panicky about the prospects of their new venture, went to the back of the store to cry.

headline: A Culinary Explorer in a Land of Opportunity
text: IN July 2007, Neil Ferguson, having been abruptly dismissed as chef de cuisine at Gordon Ramsay’s New York City franchise, saw an opening up the Hudson, adjusted his toque, and headed against the current to claim new ground. As executive chef at Monteverde at Oldstone Manor, a handsomely renovated restaurant, inn and spa on a river estate near Bear Mountain, Mr. Ferguson has brought fresh talent to fill Monteverde’s luffing sails.

headline: Snowbound in Japan
text: It was after a three-hour train ride north from Tokyo, heading for Tsurunoyu Onsen, that I learned Tsurunoyu isn’t an onsen at all. “It’s really more of a hitou,” Moto, my guide, delicately pointed out. We were in Honshu Island’s far-north prefecture of Akita, winding our way up the unpaved road to the 300-year-old mountain lodge, and Moto seemed especially intent on setting me straight. An onsen, he explained, is a natural hot spring. A hitou is a natural hot spring that is hidden. Ah. Hiddenness being perhaps the most prized characteristic in Japanese culture — second only to a love of drawing precise distinctions on a minute scale — I undertood this was a critical difference.

headline: Lips Move, but No Mergers Result
text: ATLANTIC CITY

headline: When a Sixth Avenue Flagship Struck Its Colors
text: The Streetscapes column on Oct. 21, about the first B. Altman department store, at 19th Street and Sixth Avenue, misstated the given name of the founder of Greenhut & Company, which opened at the site after Altman moved. He was Joseph B. Greenhut, not Jacob.

headline: Beckoned by Bivalves
text: MY usual method for harvesting oysters goes something like this: I lift my right hand. I extend it toward a neatly arranged platter on a tidily set table, taking care, at least on my better days, not to drag my sleeve through a ramekin of mignonette sauce.

headline: The Day’s Best
text: JEREMY MACLIN, left, scored 3 touchdowns for Missouri, including a 99-yard kick return, and had 252 total yards to set the N.C.A.A. single-season freshman record for all-purpose yards.

headline: In Rustic Tavernas, a Classic Cuisine Gets Its Due
text: WINE surely isn’t supposed to be brown. Not anywhere. True, a Provençal rosé can have a hint of rustiness in its depth, but flat-out brown — surely not a good sign. But Crete is full of surprises, and when you order a copper carafe of local wine at the Old Phoenix Hotel on the south coast, near the town of Loutro, it’s possible the wine that comes out of it may even be the color of fresh engine oil.

headline: Here at the New Yorker
text: When the New Yorker Hotel swung open its brass doors at Eighth Avenue and West 34th Street at the beginning of the Depression, the 2,500-room Art Deco structure was considered a marvel of engineering and construction. A private tunnel whisked guests directly from the 43-story hotel into nearby Penn Station, and a laundry handled 15 tons of linen daily.

headline: Marianna Olszewski, Christopher Rounick
text: Marianna Olszewski and Christopher Robert Rounick were married last evening at the Union Club in New York. Bruce M. Kaplan, a retired New York State Family Court Judge, officiated.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: A LIFE OF PICASSO: The Triumphant Years, 1917-1932, by John Richardson. (Knopf, $40.) The third, penultimate installment in Richardson’s powerhouse of a biography spans a dauntingly complicated time in Picasso’s life and in European history.

headline: The Stomach-Surgery Conundrum
text: Bariatric Surgery

headline: The Blue-Collar Thoroughbred
text: LIKE many New Yorkers, she came to the city from someplace else, aiming to go as far as her talent could take her. She was just starting out, and when she arrived from rural Florida, she moved into a small place in South Ozone Park, Queens, so close to Kennedy Airport she could hear the planes roaring overhead as she ate breakfast.

headline: Energy, Tech and Wal-Mart Aid the Market
text: The stock market rose last week, bolstered by better-than-expected earnings from Wal-Mart Stores, a big stock buyback by Cisco Systems and analyst upgrades of some technology and energy stocks.

headline: Argentina Without the Long Trip
text: The next time you’re craving empanadas, you won’t have to hop a flight to Buenos Aires. Pittsburgh will do, or even Denver. Through February, select Omni Hotels are offering the “Discover Argentina” package, which introduces guests to the foods and wines of Argentina, South America’s second-largest country. The package has a cooking class that includes a three-course dinner, a wine and cheese plate, and a leather wine tote with Malbec and Torrontés wines and a CD with tango music. Menu items — featured in all Omni Hotels restaurants — include grilled meats like tira de asado braseada al Malbec (Malbec-braised beef short ribs, above), sauces like chimichurri, desserts like dulce de leche crepes and wines from Mendoza. Packages start at $350, double occupancy (www.omnihotels.com).

McCabe of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in New York.

headline: M.T.A., Lend Them Your Ears
text: Riders in large numbers showed up at eight public hearings this month, invited by the board of the state-run Metropolitan Transportation Authority to share their thoughts on its plan to raise fares for subways, buses and commuter rails, as well as tolls at bridges and tunnels.

headline: Moira Egan and Damiano Abeni
text: THE muse blessed Moira Egan with the gift of words. But numbers have been known to trouble her, — or at least they did when she met Dr. Damiano Abeni.

headline: Improvements in a Rental
text: Q I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan. As apartments become vacant, the owner is making major improvements to the kitchens (new refrigerators, stoves, cabinets, etc.).

headline: Talks Continue in Broadway Strike
text: Talks continued today between the producers and theater owners and the stagehands’ union, with both sides negotiating over a settlement that would end the strike that has darkened most of Broadway for over a week.

headline: Letters: Recipe Redux: Teddie’s Apple Cake
text: I’ve been baking what I call Jean Hewitt’s version of the cake since 1973, when, as a junior in college, I read the recipe in The Times Magazine (Amanda Hesser, Nov. 4). The cake is delicious, easy to make and affordable — and thus proved useful to me as a college student, graduate student, young professional and working mother. The serving of this cake (at dinner parties, potluck suppers, fund-raisers at my children’s schools) always elicits requests for the recipe, which I have amended over the years to include some brown sugar, a bit of whole-wheat flour, lots of vanilla, more cinnamon, nutmeg, a variety of raisins and about twice as many apples. Tart are best, as you note. The cake also freezes well, but that rarely happens. Years ago, a roommate wrote on the recipe I clipped from the magazine — “Let cool before inhaling the entire cake.”

headline: ‘The Game’ Is Not Even a Contest: Harvard Routs Yale for the Ivy Title
text: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17  Buying time by scrambling, Harvard quarterback Chris Pizzotti looked upfield and spotted wide receiver Matt Luft, who had abandoned his pattern to look for some room deep in the secondary.

headline: What You Get for...$900,000

headline: The Life of Riley
text: It is Sam Riley’s first time in New York City, but given the elegantly dilapidated state of his surroundings — a grand house that has been through better days, on a soundstage at Pier 59 Studios — it might as well be Leeds. The weather outside is what you might imagine Leeds to be: gray, drizzly, vaguely depressing. Yet today, Riley, who is 27, couldn’t be farther from his English roots. Little more than a year ago he was folding shirts in a Leeds warehouse, his dreams of becoming a rock star — not to mention his band, 10,000 Things — shelved indefinitely by the record label and a vindictive 1-out-of-10-points review. Things can’t get any worse, he thought, so he might as well act. “Maybe I’m going to have to swallow my pride and do TV or something just to get some money,” Riley recalls thinking. “I’m never going to be a singer again.”

headline: Real Retirees, in a ‘Virtual Village’
text: The “In the Region” article in some copies last Sunday about “virtual villages,” in which older people stay in their own homes with help from a grass-roots support network, included an incorrect time frame provided by Staying Put, a virtual village in New Canaan, for its goal to recruit 150 household memberships. The group aims to achieve this total by the end of 2008, not the end of this year.

headline: Suicide Artist
text: It is Rome, 1948, and Dante Sabato, a poet and translator — having negotiated his own survival throughout the war — is ready to end it all. Contemplating a dive off the Ponte Sisto bridge and into the Tiber, he is interrupted by an American G.I., who escorts him straight to a party. There Dante meets the Godfrey sisters, Gladys and Prudence, American actresses trying to make it in the booming Italian film industry. Gladys is a sexual adventurer, self-possessed and assertive. She fulfills all her wants and needs and, along the way, some of Dante’s. She appreciates Dante’s fervent lovemaking and the fact that he’s a busy man, busy with his work, busy with his other women, and doesn’t have the time or inclination to control her. Prudence, rumored to be fleeing an unfortunate affair with the director Billy Wilder, is reserved, the more beautiful of the two. Shuttling between them both, Dante finds — in the sum — love.

headline: With Parents Ill, Happiness Seems Worlds Away
text: “All my happiness was in Poughkeepsie,” said Kajahda McKoy, 9, sitting on her bed. Tears rolled down her cheeks as she looked out her window in her family’s three-bedroom basement apartment in the Bronx.

headline: Back to the Lighthouse
text: “Paris has her tower,” the promotional blurb reads. “London has its bridge. China has the Wall. Long Island will have ... THE LIGHTHOUSE.”

headline: Norway’s Message in a Bottle
text: The scene at Fyret, a dimly lit aquavit bar in central Oslo, looked like a scene from a Flemish painting: a well-padded blond barkeep kept the howling patrons in line while doling out steins of beer alongside shots of the fiery homegrown spirit. The rollicking atmosphere was so convivial, I had to wonder: why is it so rare to find aquavit drinkers in Norway these days?

headline: Paperback Row
text: THANKSGIVING NIGHT, by Richard Bausch. (Harper Perennial, $15.95.) Bausch’s 10th novel, set in the fictional town of Point Royal, Va., as its citizens prepare to celebrate the “last Thanksgiving of the century,” is old-fashioned — generously full of quirky characters, humor and details as well as real emotion. “It’s as if Bausch had set out to create the biggest dining table he could find, then put everyone he could think of around it,” Meg Wolitzer wrote in the Book Review. A very different Thanksgiving dinner, this one in Concord, Mass., is the subject of THE GHOST AT THE TABLE, by Suzanne Berne (Shannon Ravenel/Algonquin, $13.95). Two sisters — the elder determined to make everything perfect, the younger sullen and aloof — battle over their memories of childhood, particularly the death of their mother. One critic called it “a witty, moving and psychologically acute story.”

text: NEW Yorkers who remember Rudy Giuliani as the bullying New York mayor, not as the terminally cheerful “America’s Mayor” cooing to babies in New Hampshire, have always banked on one certainty: his presidential candidacy was so preposterous it would implode before he got anywhere near the White House.

headline: Records Are Made to Be ... Overstuffed With Significance
text: BARRY BONDS’S indictment Thursday on four counts of perjury and one count of obstruction of justice put a kind of official imprimatur on his presumed villainy. Bonds, who broke Hank Aaron’s career home run record on Aug. 7, has long been suspected of using performance-enhancing drugs. And though he has not been convicted, his indictment goes a step further in raising doubts about how Bonds accrued his 762 home runs, and threatens to emblazon the record with baseball’s favorite punctuation mark, the asterisk.

When he's not balancing budgets, Fernández, a representative in the legislature, oversees the menu.

headline: Handcuffing the Wounded: A Police Tactic Hits a Nerve

headline: Letters: The Perils of Petrocracy
text: At last someone in the north is hammering out details of what Venezuelan bloggers have been saying for a long time — that under Hugo Chávez, what was once one of the best-managed oil industries in the world is heading for disaster. What Tina Rosenberg (Nov. 4) doesn’t address is the fact that Chávez probably knows this. Which may be why his forceful governance and love song to the poor are being rushed into place. There is little reliable data on the extent of his misiones for the poor (financed by oil revenue). But while filming for two weeks in October, for HDNet World Report in Maracaibo, Caracas and at a massive cult gathering of 10,000 spiritualists outside Barquisimeto (celebrating Chávez’s Day of Indigenous Resistance, formerly Columbus Day), I talked to people from all over Venezuela. All reported that misiones are visibly active in their town, city, state.

headline: Learning Young to Help Heft a Family’s Burdens
text: At 5 on a recent afternoon, the smell of baked chicken wafted through the Serranos’ three-bedroom apartment in the Bronx. Victor Serrano, 45, and his wife, Brenda, 39, were in the living room with their children Samantha, 14, Sabrina, 12, and Victor, 11.

headline: Yes, Thank You
text: The meal was lavish. The hosts very gracious. One told me as I was leaving: “Don’t bother writing a thank-you note. You don’t have to kiss up to us.”

headline: Retronymy

headline: Electoral Landscaping
text: Morton Keller’s “America’s Three Regimes: A New Political History” is unusual in two respects. Academic historians like Keller — a Brandeis professor emeritus — are often said to be incapable of writing the kind of lively, engaging accounts the public yearns for. But Keller, known for substantial but less than sparkling histories of American administrative practices, has put together one of the most engaging and accessible portraits of America’s political evolution of recent years. He leavens his discussion with lively quotations and a sprinkling of apt statistics. Just as striking is that in the course of writing this popular overview, Keller effectively challenges the reigning academic assumptions regarding what are called “realigning elections.”

text: Mineola
