text: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 17 — The surveyor’s outlines in the concourse of Michigan Stadium hint at an off-season change: luxury boxes are to be hoisted atop this grand edifice.

headline: Letters: Questions for John Bolton
text: I enjoyed the irony of the headline “The Diplomat” on the John Bolton interview. When you dismiss those who disagree with you (including the vast majority of climate scientists, in this case), you pretty much close down the discussion — not a useful tactic for a diplomat.

headline: Don’t Let the Titles Fool You
text: First installed at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 2002, the “Farrah Fawcett” project by Keith Edmier may well be the most daft in a long line of ill-conceived collaborations involving celebrities undertaken by contemporary artists. Mr. Edmier and Ms. Fawcett created nude sculptures of each other.

headline: Wiseguys
text: The F.B.I. director J. Edgar Hoover long denied the existence of the Mafia in America. He did not deny the existence of criminals, of course, or the fact that many of them came from Sicily; but he did not believe, or said he did not, that these men, dispersed in cities across the nation, worked in conspiracy, either because he underestimated them, had been paid off or simply did not care. Hoover was obsessed with revolutionaries, Communists and anarchists; gangsters, no matter what else they do, tend to support the status quo — they like the world the way it is. So in the end, the Mafia was first understood not by G-men but by the bureaucrats at the federal government’s Bureau of Narcotics, a precursor to the Drug Enforcement Administration. By following drug traffic across the nation, the orderly flow from port to truck to distributor to consumer, these men inadvertently mapped the underworld, and in the process created thousands of files, with each page dedicated to another hoodlum, another cog in the machine — runner, killer, distributor, shylock, boss. In the late 1950s, Senator John McClellan used these records to guide the hearings that finally brought the underworld to light.

headline: After the Caudillo
text: Bona fide examples of poetic justice in politics, where the innocent are vindicated and the wicked get their just deserts, are about as rare in real life as they have been commonplace in popular culture, dating at least as far back as “The Count of Monte Cristo.” And yet to the extent that such things do occur, the political triumph of Michelle Bachelet, the current president of Chile — and the first woman in South America who can be said to have earned the title on her own merits — has been just such an event. The woman who was, as a 23-year-old medical student, briefly imprisoned along with her mother by the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet and whose father, Air Force Gen. Alberto Bachelet, was tortured and died in military custody in 1974, is now Chile’s chief of state — while the dictator died, his reputation in tatters, shortly after she took office.

headline: As the Calendar Turns, So Do Many Stocks’ Fortunes
text: IT’S hardly earth-shattering news when a particular stock performs better in one month than another. But what if those standout months — of especially strong or weak performance — remain the same, year in and year out?

headline: Uptown Epicure
text: If the Lower East Side has long been a place where many young hipsters hang, the Upper East Side has plenty of restaurants for grown-ups.

headline: Making Room Among Powers of the Pacific
text: Last season, the Anaheim Ducks finished atop the Pacific Division en route to their first Stanley Cup. The Dallas Stars and the San Jose Sharks, perennial powerhouses, finished 3 points behind.

headline: Where Everybody Really Did Know His Name
text: ASIDE from the green and white sign with the three-leaf clovers, there isn’t much to catch the eye about Mooney’s Pub on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, unless you’re a frequent passer-by with an apartment nearby and what you had always thought was an uncommon last name. In that case, you wonder idly what these other Mooneys are like, and make a mental note to stop in sometime and say hi.

headline: Kathleen Zebrowski, Michael McGraw
text: Kathleen Ann Zebrowski and Michael Scott McGraw were married on Friday in Weehawken, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Edward G. Lambro, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Chart House, a restaurant.

headline: DNA and Race: The Delicate Helix
text: To the Editor:

headline: Life, Liberty and a Musical’s Pursuit
text: Once upon a time, there were 13 colonies. The story of how they unshackled themselves from the greatest military power on earth has been reprised so often that it has come to seem as remote and magical as a fairy tale — a tale no less remote and magical for being true. And therein lies the secret of “1776,” the unlikely musical retelling of the nation’s creation.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,249,585.28

headline: Through the Roof
text: IN the classic New York City real estate dream, the sleeper discovers a room, maybe an entire wing, that he or she never knew existed. Then, just as the exhilaration of the newfound space starts to settle in, the dreamer awakens to crashing disappointment.

headline: Lingering Memories of Sarah and Israel; The Red-Diaper Baby and the Moving Van; To Keep Oceans Full of Bluefin Tuna (4 Letters)
text: Lingering Memories of Sarah and Israel

headline: A Grandson Tries to Give Back to the One Who Gave Her All
text: The most important person in Felipe Arbelaez’s life is his maternal grandmother, Luz Giraldo.

headline: Plane Rerouting Landing in Court
text: AS the holiday travel season nears, thousands of residents in the tristate region may have a new reason to dread the crush at the airport — even if they never leave home. The Federal Aviation Administration says it will begin phasing in its controversial plan to reroute flight paths in the congested skies over the Northeast in mid-December, which could put planes over some communities in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut for the first time.

headline: A Good Day for Baseball, and a Better One Looms
text: The prevalent reaction to Barry Bonds’s indictment was that it was a bad day for baseball, even a sad day. But to me, it was a good day for baseball. Or at least the dawn of a good day, a dawn without a cloud in the sky.

headline: Police Shoot Officer’s Son; by Accident, Officials Say
text: The 16-year-old son of a Plainfield, N.J., police officer was shot accidentally by a police officer in Roselle, N.J., during a confrontation on Friday evening, the authorities said yesterday.

headline: Young Man Behaving Badly
text: The winter of 1991 found me stunned and shivering in the aftermath of an imploded love affair. Being 26, I flung myself actorishly on London and without any intimations of my own ludicrousness spent two years showing God what I thought of him by letting myself go. I drank and took drugs sufficient to give me bleeding gums and a Parkinsonian head wobble, conditions that compromised but did not prevent my other main hobby — having sex as often as possible. A lot of girls didn’t mind. A lot of them had troubles of their own. It was a cheering surprise, the sort of dismal shape you could be in and still get into some maenadic self-harmer’s pants. Granted, these encounters never developed — no morning-after breakfast or fun in the shower — but encased as I was in the armor of nihilism, I wouldn’t have stuck around for any of that rubbish anyway.

headline: Letters: The Turning of an Atheist
text: Here’s hoping the gaggle of so-called believers chasing fading atheist Antony Flew find what they’re seeking in their quest to reduce deity to scientific certainty. With proof of their god’s easy accessibility to human inquiry, they can give up their already tattered pretense of faith.

headline: At Michigan, Even the Marching Band Has a Superfan
text: Rishi Moudgil’s approach to game day at Michigan Stadium is pretty straightforward.

headline: On 4th Try, Brodeur Earns 500th
text: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP)  Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur made 26 saves Saturday night to earn his 500th career victory in a 6-2 win over the Philadelphia Flyers.

headline: Mailer’s Nonfiction Legacy: His 1969 Race for Mayor
text: You could argue, as Herman Badillo did the other day, that Norman Mailer cost him the mayoralty of New York City in 1969.

headline: Migrant Money Flow: A $300 Billion Current
text: THE money flows in dribs and drabs, crossing borders $200 or $300 at a time. It buys cornmeal and rice and plaid private school skirts and keeps the landlord at bay. Globally, the tally is huge: migrants from poor countries send home about $300 billion a year. That is more than three times the global total in foreign aid, making “remittances” the main source of outside money flowing to the developing world.

headline: Correction
text: A review on Oct. 28 about “Legends of the Chelsea Hotel,” by Ed Hamilton, misidentified the place where William Burroughs wrote “Naked Lunch.” He wrote it at the Villa Muniria in Tangier and revised it for publication at the Paris rooming house known as the Beat Hotel; it was not written at the Chelsea.

headline: How to Rule the World
text: The emperor Claudius thought about the dynamics of imperial ingestion. He reminded the Roman Senate that the founder Romulus would “both fight against and naturalize a people on the same day.” Claudius argued that the Gauls, by logical extension, could be accepted into the Senate because “they no longer wear trousers” — that is, they could be counted on to come to work wearing the Roman toga and thus to have effectively become Romans.

headline: War and Morality
text: To the Editor:

headline: Torres Is Getting Older, but Swimming Faster
text: Dara Torres, the fastest female swimmer in America, plunged toward the bottom of the pool, like a child scavenging for coins. She came up for a breath, grinning. The lanes next to hers pulsed with swimmers pushing themselves through 100- and 200-meter timed sprints, but Torres was under orders from her coach to rest, the better to let her 40-year-old body recover.

headline: Jamie Rosenberg, Lewis Eisen
text: Dr. Jamie Bella Rosenberg, a daughter of Caryn G. Rosenberg and Dr. Leon I. Rosenberg of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Lewis Ari Eisen, the son of Carole Eisen and Martin M. Eisen, also of Cherry Hill. Rabbi Isaac Furman officiated at the Westin Mount Laurel hotel in New Jersey.

headline: Up Front
text: There’s no entry for “Allen, Woody” in “The Film Snob’s Dictionary,” the book David Kamp wrote with Lawrence Levi, but that doesn’t mean Kamp is not a fan (there’s also no entry for “Bergman, Ingmar” or “Fellini, Federico”). His favorites of Allen’s movies, he said in an e-mail message, are “Love and Death,” for “sheer pleasure”; “Stardust Memories,” for “the ideal balance of laughs and artiness”; and “Crimes and Misdemeanors,” for “insightfulness and Jerry Orbach playing a heavy.” Kamp, the author of “The United States of Arugula: How We Became a Gourmet Nation,” added: “We mustn’t discount Woody’s influence on the food world. His putting the original Dean & DeLuca in ‘Manhattan’ was a ratification of that store’s mission and the way of life it represented. And his literary comic short ‘Fabrizio’s: Criticism and Response,’ which I first read as a boy, alerted me to the possibilities of food humor.”

headline: Does Death Penalty Save Lives? A New Debate
text: For the first time in a generation, the question of whether the death penalty deters murders has captured the attention of scholars in law and economics, setting off an intense new debate about one of the central justifications for capital punishment.

headline: Up, Up and Away
text: LARCHMONT, N.Y.

headline: Musharraf Refuses to Say When Emergency Will End
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sunday, Nov. 18 — Continuing to defy the United States, Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, declined to tell a senior American envoy on Saturday when he would lift a two-week-old state of emergency, Pakistani and Western officials said.

headline: Julie Kanfer, Scott Polirstok
text: Julie Beth Kanfer and Scott Michael Polirstok were married last evening at Carlyle on the Green, an event space and restaurant in Farmingdale, N.Y. Rabbi Elyse Frishman officiated.

headline: For Sale From Puget Sound: 2 Fixer-Upper Ferries
text: SEATTLE, Nov. 17 — Look for two more items on the sale rack after Thanksgiving: the Chinook and the Snohomish, last seen ferrying people across Puget Sound. The big boats can be yours for $4.5 million each. As is. Exclusively at eBay.

headline: Memo to Yeats: Ireland Has Changed
text: IRELAND has changed dramatically in recent years thanks to a soaring economy and unprecedented prosperity, but in terms of its literature many still associate the country with its masters George Bernard Shaw, W. B. Yeats and James Joyce.

headline: If It’s Lunch Time, It’s Mix-and-Match Pasta
text: PONTE VECCHIO is a sweet-looking restaurant at the back of one of those ubiquitous strip malls that line Route 1 in Fairfield. The Italian-American menu is standard fare, with a few non-Italian additions.

headline: False Endorsement
text: Last Exit to Nowhere

headline: Merrill Winner, Cory Bronson
text: Merrill Beth Winner, a daughter of Rochelle and Stewart E. Winner of Tenafly, N.J., is to be married today to Cory Benjamin Bronson, a son of Andrea and Jon H. Bronson of Blue Bell, Pa. Rabbi Richard F. Steinbrink is to officiate at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Pittsburgh Allows Its Opportunities, and Rutgers, to Slip
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 17 — At the end of a slow, frustrating afternoon of missed opportunities at Rutgers, Pittsburgh had one final chance to steal the game.

headline: A Foggy Reunion With Horror’s Master
text: STEPHEN KING likes to joke that Frank Darabont, the director of “The Shawshank Redemption” and “The Green Mile,” has made a specialty not just of Stephen King movies but of Stephen King prison movies. You could argue that Mr. Darabont’s new film, “The Mist,” based on the King novella of that title, is in the same vein. The difference is that the characters are holed up not in a penitentiary but in a supermarket.

headline: Bad Grad, Good Grad
text: One of my grad students copied a term paper from the Internet, cutting and pasting from various uncredited sources. The university’s rules say expulsion or an F in the course is appropriate, but I proposed that she search out the several dozen articles she used to “compose” her paper and write each author an apology. I will mail the letters. My department chair thinks this is unethical — a cruel and unusual punishment. You? — P.R., Houston

headline: Sifting for Facts Amid the Promises
text: With what feels like a debate every other day, no one can say that the presidential candidates are suffering from any lack of exposure. But the voters are still being denied a complete look at the aspirants’ finances and their health records.

headline: Black Americans: One Race, or More?
text: The Pew Research Center released a nationwide survey last week on racial attitudes. More than a third of black respondents said that blacks no longer can be thought of as a single race because their community is so diverse. The results could reflect diverging social values and economic fortunes among blacks.

headline: Margaret Ellis, Walter Bottger
text: Margaret Holben Ellis and Walter Frederick Bottger were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall performed the ceremony.

headline: The New New List
text: Pied-à-terre are the new hotels. Who needs a penthouse suite when you can buy a penthouse? Global nomads with growing buying power are forgoing room service for serviced abodes in cities like New York, Berlin and Buenos Aires.

headline: Who’ll Stop the Ring Tones?
text: LONDON

headline: A Bond-Worthy Beauty
text: TESTED 2007 Aston Martin V-8 Vantage Roadster

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: A SOUTHERN GENTLEMAN

headline: Betting Against the Dollar? This Time, Asia May Deserve a Look
text: JIM O’NEILL, the chief economist of Goldman Sachs, has been down on the American dollar for at least 10 years. “Being bearish on the dollar has been one of the easiest things to do,” Mr. O’Neill said. And there are still lucrative currency bets to be made, Mr. O’Neill and many other financial professionals say, even though the direction of the American currency isn’t as obvious today. “It’s getting trickier,” Mr. O’Neill said.

headline: Bias Is Suspected in Attack on Teen
text: A 14-year-old boy in Lakewood, N.J., was beaten last night by a group of black youths yelling anti-Semitic slurs, the police said. The beating is being treated as a bias attack, at least the second in recent weeks in Lakewood.

headline: Raina Forman and Todd Silver
text: Raina Bree Forman and Todd David Silver were married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y. Rabbi Morris Zimbalist performed the ceremony.

headline: On the Q.T.: Rocco Forte
text: More than a decade old, the Rocco Forte Collection is verging on empire: 11 hotels and counting. We caught Sir Rocco amid a flurry of openings — Munich, check; Geneva, check; up next, Prague — and gave him the T Travel Questionnaire.

headline: A Cleaner Sound
text: Much progress toward a cleaner environment has been made through the market-based magic of pollution credits. The government sets a goal for reducing the levels of a given contaminant — sulfur dioxide, say — and allows polluters to reach it by negotiating among themselves. Efficient high achievers who surpass given cleanup targets earn credits that they can sell to those who do not. Laggards can buy time, but they cannot necessarily wriggle out of the obligation to come clean, or at least cleaner. That is because the tolerable level of a pollutant is gradually lowered, and lowered again, until the air — or water, or whatever it is — is clear.

headline: ‘Travel Time’ Signs Receive Mixed Reviews
text: NEW signs on the Northern State Parkway estimate the length of time it should take motorists to reach specific locations ahead, but some drivers say the signs are of uncertain value.

headline: Iceland, Nigeria, New York: Discovery and Rediscovery
text: Sigur Ros

headline: Silver Bullet
text: When Viscount David Linley thinks of his childhood, he remembers the family siphon fondly. “We always had a drinks trolley,” he says, and young David used the siphon to top up the adults’ whiskeys. “We” in this case includes Britain’s most glamorous couple of the 1960s and ’70s: his mother, Princess Margaret, and his father, the photographer Lord Snowdon.

headline: Bronwyn Spira, Mark Lieberman
text: Bronwyn Anne Spira and Mark Spencer Lieberman were married on Wednesday on Anguilla, in the Caribbean. Rev. John A. Gumbs, a Methodist minister, officiated at a law office in The Valley, the island’s capital. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson performed a religious ceremony last evening at the Malliouhana Hotel and Spa, on the island’s west end.

headline: A Harvest of Trash and Turmoil for an Agent Fighting Steroids
text: Jeff Novitzky is an unlikely contender for the role of Eliot Ness of the steroids age. He is an I.R.S. special agent, a position that is rarely glamorous. The work is often tedious and dull, poring over bank records and tax returns, and writing reports.

headline: Rumors of Drug Use Have Damaged for Decades
text: Barry Bonds may go to jail if a jury believes he lied about using steroids. Many other players could face suspensions next season if George J. Mitchell identifies them in his coming investigative report on steroids in baseball.

headline: Washingtonienne
text: Theodore Roosevelt’s older daughter, Alice, moved into the White House at the age of 17, in 1901, 100 years before the arrival of the Bush twins. To grasp the longevity of “Princess Alice” upon the Washington scene, one must imagine either Jenna or Barbara showing up for a party at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue in the year 2071, the way Alice Roosevelt Longworth took her seat in the Rose Garden for Tricia Nixon’s White House wedding 65 years after her own. Indeed, Mrs. Longworth survived for almost another decade, sticking around to oppose Jimmy Carter’s effort to give away her father’s boldest accomplishment, the Panama Canal.

headline: A Diesel Engine Woke Up Our Marriage
text: WHENEVER my husband casually says, “Hey, hon, come take a look at this Web site,” I know it’s going to cost me. All of our largest purchases were preceded by my being summoned to his computer in this manner. So, three years ago, when he said this a few weeks before his 40th birthday, I knew it was really going to cost me, and I don’t mean just financially.

headline: Betting on Buckhead
text: Standing in the August heat amid cranes and bulldozers in Atlanta’s affluent Buckhead district, the city’s mayor, Shirley Franklin, rallied a late-morning crowd by proclaiming a renaissance — “a resurgence of Atlanta” is how she put it — in this Southern metropolis. The occasion was the announcement of a $1.2 billion mega-development called the Streets of Buckhead. Scheduled to open in the fall of 2009, it will be a mini-town of fashionable hotels, boutiques, restaurants and condos. And along with it, public roads will be expanded into wide boulevards with tree-lined sidewalks. Since Atlanta’s boosters have always loved slogans (“The City Too Busy to Hate”; “Atlanta: People Seem to Like It Here”; “Every Day Is an Opening Day”), it’s likely that Franklin’s prophesy will soon be fashioned into a catchy new mantra.

headline: Torrealba Out of Mets’ Picture
text: The Mets are back in the market for a starting catcher after their negotiations with the free agent Yorvit Torrealba dissolved yesterday afternoon. Torrealba had agreed to a three-year, $14.4 million contract Thursday, pending a physical. But barring another sudden turn of events, he will not play for the Mets next season.

headline:
A Personal Salute to a Hero’s Memory; The Intimate Story of an Apple Tree; Why Raise Buffalo
Just to Kill Them? (3 Letters)
text: A Personal Salute to a Hero’s Memory

headline: Funny Songs Are Inspired by Sad Times for the Rich
text: It’s true that the country singer Merle Hazard has never been to the Hamptons.

headline: With Tank Drained, Knicks Fall Again
text: DENVER, Nov. 17 — As the hour grew late Saturday and the suspense had long since been drained from the Pepsi Center, there were really only two curiosities left. Would the Nuggets keep their starters on the court in another rout of the Knicks? And if they did, would the Knicks respond as violently as they did last year?

headline: Don’t Eat Your Vegetables
text: Storrs

headline: The Media Mogul
text: As the former C.E.O. of Disney and the founder of a privately held company that invests in the digital future, you were recently speaking at a conference when you used the words “stupid” and “insanity” to describe the Writers Guild strike. Can you explain? What I was driving at was that it was a foolish time to have a strike issue over a business and a marketplace that is not evolved enough to even know if there is a business or a marketplace there.

headline: Bragging Rights at the Plaza
text: THE Astor Suite was designed to be the most expensive condominium in the conversion of the storied Plaza Hotel on Fifth Avenue. In its previous life as a three-bedroom hotel suite, the Astor was layered in crystal and gold and with brocade in pink, cream and rose, with a dining room that seated 10 and a master bedroom that had a king-size canopy bed.

headline: Record Number of Nuisance Bears Are Killed
text: DENVER, Nov. 17 (AP) — A berry-killing drought and a late spring freeze pushed hungry Colorado bears into more confrontations with humans this year, and wildlife managers say a record 59 bears have been killed as a result.

headline: Harold Robbins, Pioneer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Memories of World War II, Still Fresh in Collectibles
text: WHEN Dan Crews was 15, he struck a deal that few boys his age would have considered. He swapped $20 worth of baseball cards with a neighbor for a musty World War II uniform brought back from Europe 30 years earlier.

headline: Coming Soon: Affordable Views
text: BAYONNE

headline: From Armory to Zoo to Museum to Offices
text: THE Arsenal, completed in 1851 in Central Park at East 64th Street, is near the end of a complete exterior restoration. This unusual structure, built to store explosives and ammunition to defend 19th-century New York State, later served as the American Museum of Natural History and as a zoo, and is now the headquarters of the city’s Parks and Recreation Department.

headline: Cambodia’s Coast of Utopia
text: Languidly reclining under a beach umbrella at the Sokha Beach Resort after a dip in the sea, a lithe woman in a bikini on the beach chair next to me sits up and decides to write postcards. Like Dorothy waking up in Oz, she looks around to get her bearings. There are no signs, no landmarks, just a glimmering ocean, an empty white-sand beach and the clear blue sky. This could be Thailand or Bali. In fact, it could be anywhere hot, exotic.

headline: Sarah Bainton, Zecharia Kahn
text: Sarah Elizabeth Bainton, the daughter of Linda Bainton and Wayne Bainton of Middletown, R.I., was married yesterday to Zecharia Seth Kahn, the son of Barbara Kahn of Warwick, R.I., and Paul Kahn of Paris. The Rev. William Wiethorn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary’s Church in Newport, R.I.

headline: All the President’s Powers
text: As the Bush administration enters its final year, how fares its effort to remake the law for the benefit of the presidency? With the resignation of Alberto Gonzales, the withdrawal of the infamous 2002 torture memos and setbacks at the Supreme Court in the Guantánamo cases, executive supremacy no longer reigns entirely supreme. At the same time, it hasn’t been dethroned either: witness the recent revelations about further Justice Department memos that permit forms of torture, written in 2005 and still in place. And then there’s the testimony of Michael Mukasey, George W. Bush’s choice for attorney general, who surprised the Senate by unabashedly promoting the president’s authority to act outside statutory boundaries in sensitive areas like wiretapping and by refusing to renounce waterboarding. The salient question of the moment, then, is about Bush’s legal legacy. After his tenure, what will come of the changes his lawyers have wrought, especially their attempts to expand executive power?

headline: It’s in New Jersey, but It Screams Vermont
text: MAYBE the people who live in Hopewell Borough have Jersey fatigue. Or maybe they just yearn for a simpler place and time, before traffic jams and planned communities. Whatever the reason, they are quick to describe this small village in central New Jersey as the most un-Jersey-like town in the state.

headline: He Aimed at the Stars but Hit London
text: Wernher von Braun was a giant of the 20th century. But what, in the modern imagination, did he represent? Visionary science? Cynical manipulation? The marriage of science and technology? The convergence of war and peace? Was von Braun the Columbus of space? The brains of the military-industrial complex? The face of modernity? Was he a war criminal, as many of his contemporaries believed? Or was he, as Michael J. Neufeld argues in “Von Braun: Dreamer of Space, Engineer of War,” a modern Faust, in league with the devil?

headline: Geneva’s Swiss List
text: Geneva has long been known for its influence in banking and world affairs — but not exactly for its sense of style. Now, however, chefs, designers and artisans in the Italianate quarter of Carouge are lending the city a little boho cool.

headline: Slow Down? Never. Well, Maybe.
text: WEST BABYLON, N.Y.

headline: Colleen Walsh, Stephen Prostor
text: Colleen Elizabeth Walsh and Stephen Victor Prostor were married yesterday at St. Patrick’s Roman Catholic Church in Johnstown, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth J. Swain officiated at the ceremony, in which the Rev. Joseph Barker took part.

headline: Proposed Colorado Measure on Rights for Human Eggs
text: DENVER, Nov. 16 — A proposed amendment to the Colorado Constitution that would give legal rights to fertilized human eggs may be headed for the ballot next year, raising the prospect of a heated local debate over abortion at the same time that Democrats are gathering here for their national convention.

headline: Republican Uncertainty Amid a Push by Giuliani
text: DES MOINES, Nov. 17 — With a surge of radio advertisements, telephone calls and mailings, Rudolph W. Giuliani is stepping up his efforts to compete in the Iowa Republican caucuses, complicating Mitt Romney’s effort to nail down a clean victory here and underscoring the fluid nature of the contest less than seven weeks from the voting.

headline: Duplicate Motion, Then Capture Emotion
text: SWEET-FACED children on a magical train trip to the North Pole present one kind of challenge; hulking warriors soaked in sweat and engaged in bloody battle pose an entirely different set of problems.

headline: A Personal Salute to a Hero’s Memory; Will Rutgers Sell Its Soul for a New Stadium?; To Keep Oceans Full of Bluefin Tuna (3 Letters)
text: A Personal Salute to a Hero’s Memory

headline: Stock Market Likely to Stay Under Pressure
text: As the air came out of the technology and telecommunications bubble this decade, the stock market found a new champion in the financial sector.

headline: Vocabulary
text: trophy / (tro fe) / adj. / prized for prestige-enhancing qualities. In the world of travel, applied to places, experiences and things that are sought after because they are little known or inaccessible to hoi polloi, as in, “Everyone who’s anyone will be in Miami for Art Basel — the art-show circuit is the new trophy trip,” or, “Southern Cambodia is so great, I’m sure it’s going to be the next trophy beach destination.”

headline: Rupert Murdoch, Embroiled in the Caucasus
text: TBILISI, Georgia

headline: In Transition, a Thanksgiving Tradition
text: “TOIKEY.” That’s what my Eastern European grandmother called a kind of poultry she didn’t know or trust. And roasting that bird was never high on Gertrude Goldberg’s list of priorities. In late November, she was too preoccupied struggling to get through the busy season in the mom-and-pop fruit store in Philadelphia that she owned with Joseph, her sweet, silent husband, to worry about “toikey.”

headline: The Grand Tour
text: I arrived in Miami knowing nothing. I was ignorant, to put it mildly, an art-world neophyte embarking on the first leg of what would become a delirious journey: one year, four countries, two art fairs, one biennial and, God help me, one quinquennial — a trip propelled by planes, trains, automobiles, water taxis and more alcohol than I had consumed during all of college. My education would begin with a primer at Art Basel Miami Beach in December, a five-day contemporary art fair known as the feistier sister production of Art Basel in Switzerland, the granddaddy of the fair circuit, which I would also stop by, come summertime, as part of the glittering cattle call known in the art world as the “grand tour.” Once each decade, the planets align and four major events open within days of one another: first there is the Venice Biennale; then Art Basel; followed by Documenta, a serious survey of contemporary art that takes place every five years in the German town of Kassel; and finally Sculpture Projects Münster, a show of mainly massive sculptures that is held every 10 years in the nearby German hamlet.

headline: Melissa Dittmar and Stephen Bruno
text: Melissa Elizabeth Dittmar, a daughter of Zenaida M. Dittmar of San Marino, Calif., and the late William H. Dittmar, was married yesterday to Stephen Douglas Bruno, a son of Karen R. Jacobson of Blue Bell, Pa., and Dr. Leonard A. Bruno of Philadelphia. The Rev. J. P. Reynolds, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Ritz-Carlton, Huntington Hotel & Spa in Pasadena, Calif.

headline: Markets as Both Feast and Spectacle
text: IT is a given that no serious traveler would forgo visits to museums, cathedrals, castles, monuments and legendary streets. Yet food markets deserve equally high billing on a must-see list. For as inspiring as the more standard sights can be, they do not rival the ebullience of modern-day markets and their colorful links to the economy, customs and even dialects of a city.

headline: Rita Hillman, Art Lover and Advocate for Nursing, Dies at 95
text: Rita K. Hillman, a philanthropist and art collector who used the proceeds from the sale of Picasso’s “Mother and Child” to support the education of hundreds of nurses, died on Nov. 8 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, one of the institutions that benefited from her charity. She was 95 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Correction: December Release Schedule
text: An article on Nov. 4 in the Holiday Movies section about the film adaptation of “Sweeney Todd” misstated the number of Tony Awards that musical won for its original Broadway run in 1979. It was eight, not seven.

headline: Affordable Family Planning
text: Budgeting is an important part of a college education. But try to factor this into monthly expenses: prescription contraceptives that cost $10 for last month’s supply will now cost $50.

headline: A Blue State Gets Bluer
text: Republicans might have seen last year’s election results, in which Democrats made big gains, as part of the backlash from an unpopular war. Republicans lost two Congressional seats to Democrats, and in the Legislature, the Democrats gained seats in both the House and the Senate.

headline: Seeking Asylum
text: Every family has a kook in its ranks. In mine, it was my Great-Aunt Affie, who’d drop by our house in Indiana unannounced as she drove across the Midwest. She always had a mysterious, brooding child in the back seat, surrounded by toys and hamburger wrappers. The kid — it was a different one each time — was never introduced and never got out of the car. After a short visit in the driveway, Aunt Affie would leave as abruptly as she’d arrived, to my parents’ palpable relief. “Your Aunt Affie is ... unique,” was all they’d say. Meaning, in that time and place: “She’s absolutely bonkers.”

headline: Pieds Can Be à Terre Here, Too
text: The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about foreign and out-of-state buyers and renters seeking pieds-à-terre near the Hudson River in New Jersey misstated the name of a Midtown Manhattan brokerage firm active in the area. It is Marketing Directors, not Market Directors.

headline: Trend Spotting | Liner Notes
text: Cruising less-traveled waters used to mean “rustic” cabins and close quarters. Now several high-end cruise lines are sending some of their poshest boats to exotic destinations. This January, Aqua Expeditions will launch the 12-suite M/V Aqua, which will sail the Peruvian Amazon year-round and serve nouveau Andean dishes courtesy of the Lima chef Pedro Miguel Schiaffino (www.aquaexpeditions.com; $1,950 to $4,550 per person). In Russia, the 58-cabin Volga Dream — decked out in mahogany and etched glass — sets sail on the Volga from Moscow to St. Petersburg (May through September; 800-633-1008; www.exeterinternational.com; from $6,700 per person). And come spring, Silversea, the company that stocks its ships with goods from Loro Piana and Acqua di Parma, will make stops in Iran; the Silver Cloud is set to dock in Bandar Abbas on its Dubai to Dubai cruise (800-722-9955; www.silversea.com; from $2,937 per person).

headline: Private School, Public Fuss
text: IT was an “O captain! My captain!” moment.

headline: Drama Is Building in the L.P.G.A.’s Game of Survivor
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17  The entertainment just kept coming at the ADT Championship, where the day began with golfers lighting up the leader board with birdies and eagles and ended with the eight lucky and talented finalists all seated on a makeshift stage, cracking jokes and picking their own tee times for Sunday’s final-round pairings.

headline: The Sweet Hereafter
text: For Gail Monaghan, memory lane is paved with dessert. Blum’s coffee crunch cake. The Brown Derby’s orange chiffon cake. Butterscotch sundaes from Schrafft’s — all vestiges of the vanished coffee-shop culture of her childhood. And then there are the tortes, fools, charlotte russes and other sweets that have gone the way of the dessert trolley. While Monaghan, a New York cookbook author and cooking teacher, could appreciate what we’ve gained — individual chocolate pudding cakes and cleverly concocted confections — she wondered more about what had been left behind.

headline: Teutonic Plates
text: Before the meal proper begins at Silk, Frankfurt's most futuristic restaurant, you're handed a ceramic spoon containing what appears to be the yolk of an egg. It isn't. The blob quivers like a yolk and looks like a yolk. But the color is emphatically, undeniably green.

headline: Paris: Goumanyat & Son Royaume
text: Situated in an obscure patch of Paris between the Marais and the less chic Place de la République, Goumanyat & Son Royaume is not an ordinary spice emporium. Set in what was once an apothecary shop, it is open only four afternoons a week and from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Saturdays. Pierre Gagnaire and Alain Ducasse are among the star chefs who buy spices there. You have to ring to be let in. You are greeted by the tinkle of a wind chime and the expertise of the owner, Jean Thiercelin.

headline: Who Can Tell You What
text: FINDING out whether you can build an addition on your building’s roof is more complicated than you might think.

headline: Auction Houses in the Suburban New York City Region
text: Here is a list of auction houses in the suburban New York City region, with some coming auctions included.

headline: A Sea Toy James Bond Would Envy

headline: For ‘Chairman Moe,’ One Last Salute
text: EVEN into his 90s, Moe Fishman never missed a protest. So it was only fitting that the memorial service for Mr. Fishman, an Astoria-born radical who fought Fascism in Spain in the 1930s and in his later years demonstrated against the Iraq war from his folding chair in Greenwich Village, was equal parts a celebration of his life and a rousing antiwar rally.

headline: Paige Lance, Alexander Hahn
text: Paige Virginia Lance and Alexander Mark Hahn were married yesterday in Charleston, S.C. Rabbi Anthony D. Holz officiated at the William Aiken House.

headline: Life as the Regginator
text: I GREW up in a lower-middle-class environment, usually the lone minority among my classmates. My parents, both immigrants from Haiti, had a Romeo-and-Juliet type of story. My maternal grandfather, a doctor by training, was in the Haitian government. My paternal grandfather was in the opposing military. As young adults my mother and father came to New York, where their romance was able to flourish.

headline: As Owners Feel Mortgage Pain, So Do Renters
text: LAS VEGAS — In the foreclosure crisis of 2007, thousands of American families are losing their homes without ever missing a payment. They are renters in houses whose owners default on their mortgages — a large but little noticed class of casualties.

headline: Jessica Kouvaros and Marc Wiener
text: Jessica Megan Kouvaros, a daughter of Anna R. Kouvaros and Michael A. Kouvaros of Reading, Pa., was married yesterday to Marc Douglas Wiener, a son of Susan A. Wiener and Michael Wiener of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Arthur Eccleston, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York.

headline: Woody Talks
text: Not only does Woody Allen profess not to care one whit about his legacy as a filmmaker; he’s also fashioned some choice Woodyisms on the topic. Here’s one: “I’m a firm believer that when you’re dead, naming a street after you doesn’t help your metabolism.” Here’s another: “Rather than live on in the hearts and minds of my fellow man, I’d prefer to live on in my apartment.”

headline: Forever Weird
text: On July 2, 1974, I started work as deputy Washington bureau chief for Rolling Stone magazine. My unlikely boss was Richard Goodwin, the former Kennedy speechwriter, who invited me to join him in temporary residence at Ethel Kennedy’s home in McLean, Va. (the owner was in Hyannis for the summer). On July 3, Hunter Thompson joined us. Much of what ensued that holiday weekend is lost in the mists of history and a fog of controlled substances. There were extensive conversations about the viability of renting a truck, filling it with rats and dumping them on the White House lawn. There was also an effort to remove all the Andy Williams songs from the Kennedy jukebox and replace them with Otis Redding. But mostly I remember having a marathon conversation with Hunter about books and writers, settling finally on Joseph Conrad’s exhortation in “Lord Jim”: “In the destructive element immerse!”

headline: Mind of a Rock
text: Most of us have no doubt that our fellow humans are conscious. We are also pretty sure that many animals have consciousness. Some, like the great ape species, even seem to possess self-consciousness, like us. Others, like dogs and cats and pigs, may lack a sense of self, but they certainly appear to experience inner states of pain and pleasure. About smaller creatures, like mosquitoes, we are not so sure; certainly we have few compunctions about killing them. As for plants, they obviously do not have minds, except in fairy tales. Nor do nonliving things like tables and rocks.

headline: Plane Rerouting Landing in Court
text: AS the holiday travel season nears, thousands of residents in the tristate region may have a new reason to dread the crush at the airport — even if they never leave home. The Federal Aviation Administration says it will begin phasing in its controversial plan to reroute flight paths in the congested skies over the Northeast in mid-December, which could put planes over some communities in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey for the first time.

headline: Plane Rerouting Landing in Court
text: AS the holiday travel season nears, thousands of residents in the tristate region may have a new reason to dread the crush at the airport — even if they never leave home. The Federal Aviation Administration says it will begin phasing in its controversial plan to reroute flight paths in the congested skies over the Northeast in mid-December, which could put planes over some communities in Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey for the first time.

headline: Bush Failed to See Musharraf’s Faults, Critics Contend
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 — In the six years since Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, joined President Bush in the fight against Al Qaeda, it has been an unlikely partnership: a president intent on promoting democracy and a military commander who seized power in a bloodless coup.

headline: Correction: January Release Schedule

At her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan recently Ms. Cook moved her fingertips across the gadget’s small screen to show off some of the miscellany she had stored: a YouTube video of the conductor Gustavo Dudamel, photographs of a friend’s artwork, links to clips of herself in performance.

headline: State Gets a Taste for Goats

headline: On the Tequila Trail in the Place Where It’s Made
text: It can make you crazy. It can calm you down. It can make you hallucinate or just have a really colorful night on the town. It’s tequila, the spirited spirit from Mexico with a history that can be traced to the Aztecs. Starting Dec. 20, aficionados of the blue agave concoction can take advantage of the tequila package offered by the Presidente InterContinental Hotel Guadalajara (www.intercontinental.com). The package includes a tour of the town of Tequila and visits to an agave plantation and Mundo Cuervo, the oldest distillery in the Western Hemisphere. Through March 1, the package starts at $364 a couple and includes lodging, breakfast and tequila cocktails upon arrival. Guests who aren’t satisfied after one round can visit the hotel’s new tequila lounge, where 100 tequilas are available.

headline: Letters

headline: Out of the Blue in the Caribbean
text: Is an archipelago off the coast of Venezuela, 45 minutes, “Fantasy Island”-style, by propeller plane from Caracas. From above, the more than 300 islands scatter over the Caribbean's blue water in various sizes and shapes: one just a long stripe of green mangrove trees, others with paisley-shaped coves, and countless impossibly small sand mounds with a lone palm tree, like one of those New Yorker cartoons. The biggest island, Gran Roque, stands out from these specks like three lumps of coffee ice cream. Most Roquenos live there; it has an airstrip and a town that is about twice the size of the airstrip.

headline: The Woman in the Shadow
text: OF all the vivid characters who came and went in the tumultuous 84-year life of Norman Mailer, perhaps none played such a sensational role, and then vanished so completely from the public eye, as the author’s second wife, Adele. Forty-seven years ago Tuesday, during an all-night blowout party at the couple’s Upper West Side apartment, Mr. Mailer, who died last weekend, came home in an alcohol-soaked rage and stabbed Adele Mailer near the heart with a penknife he’d found in the street.

headline: Record in the Making
text: PAUL DAVIES, the British interior designer and developer of luxury homes, has signed a contract to buy three upper floors in the glass tower on East 22nd Street known as One Madison Park. Mr. Davies’s $31 million transaction may set a record for a downtown Manhattan condominium.

The Democratic candidates have begun to tread more warily on the issue, as their debate last week in Las Vegas showed, but they still favor the language of accommodation over alarm.

headline: Inside the List
text: LONG-RANGE FORECAST: The 2008 edition of the Old Farmer’s Almanac has been loitering on the paperback advice extended list in recent weeks. Over the decades, this publication has lost little of its folksiness. This year’s version is filled with advertisements for things like bag balm, and articles on topics like how to grow your own popcorn and “All the Right Reasons to Raise Pigs.” The almanac makes the biggest headlines each year for its long-range weather forecasts. (This year in the Northeast, it reports, “winter will be about a degree milder than normal, on average, with slightly above-normal precipitation. ... The snowiest periods will be in mid-December, mid- and late January, and early to mid-March.”) How accurate was last winter’s forecast? Don’t ask. The editors write: “Our forecast for the winter of 2006-07 resulted in our lowest verification scores ever, with a 61 percent accuracy rate on the monthly regional precipitation and a 49 percent accuracy rate on monthly regional temperatures. A coin toss would have beaten our monthly regional temperature forecasts by 1 percent.” But the optimists at the almanac conclude: “We expect to do much better in our forecast for the winter of 2007-08.”

headline: Erica Greenbaum, Mark Gerson
text: Rabbi Erica Rachel Greenbaum, the daughter of Sandra and Kenneth Greenbaum of New York, was married last evening to Mark Lee Gerson, a son of Susan and Michael Gerson of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Matthew Reimer officiated at the couple’s vacation home in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

They beat Philadelphia on a last-second field goal. They beat Denver on an 82-yard pass in overtime. They beat Minnesota last week with their first shutout in five years.

headline: Creative Loans, Creative Compensation

Its stock plummeted last week on news that the company lost $64.05 a share in the third quarter, that it had canceled its preferred stock dividend and that it was no longer able to reap the tax advantages of a real estate investment trust status.

There's the parking lot, the grocery store, the kids' school, the cleaner's, the gas station, and then your front door.

headline: Berlin in Lights: A Collage of Images and Voices
text: One particular focus of the Berlin in Lights festival has been Berlin in the years 1927 and 1928. We’ve had Walter Ruttmann’s abstract documentary film “Symphony of a City” (1927), excerpts from the Brecht-Weill “Threepenny Opera” (1928), and “Berlin Alexanderplatz” (1929, but set mainly in 1927 and 1928). P.S. 1 is showing “Berlin Alexanderplatz,” Fassbinder’s monumental made-for-TV film, nonstop through January; for its contribution to the festival, the Goethe Haus, on Saturday, offered a marathon reading of the no less monumental novel by Alfred Döblin on which it was based.

headline: Pawns of St. Petersburg
text: Ronan Bennett’s ZUGZWANG (Bloomsbury, $24.95) takes its title from a chess term for those endgame maneuvers in which a player must execute moves that can only lead to defeat. However inelegant the word sounds when applied to a thriller set in St. Peters burg in 1914, it aptly conveys the refined cruelty of the games of intrigue that entrap a respected psychoanalyst, Otto Spethmann, when he undertakes the treatment of two problematic patients.

headline: A Problematic Park
text: A series of events this year led officials to believe that Holman State Wayside Park was no longer providing 10 acres of wholesome diversion to Oregon's residents.

headline: Sunday Morning Kickoff
text: Oklahoma’s loss to Texas Tech last night provided another B.C.S. shakeup. As SI.com’s Stewart Mandel tells us, West Virginia was the big winner last night, with the door also slowly cracking for Ohio State to possibly sneak back into the national championship picture. ESPN.com’s Pat Forde writes that West Virginia is in a good position to make the title game.

headline: They’d Rather Be Hookers
text: That’s the finding of an informal “Would You Rather” poll on our companion blog Freakonomics, asking if you’d rather be arrested for embezzlement or prostitution. By a measure of nearly 4-to-1, respondents chose prostitution. Read more …

headline: B.C.S. Down to Four, Maybe
text: The race for the two B.C.S. title-game spots is seemingly whittled to four teams. Unless, of course, more chaos ensues in the following weeks. Those teams are No. 1 L.S.U. (10-1), No. 2 Kansas (11-0), No. 3 West Virginia (9-1) and No. 4 Missouri (10-1).

headline: Berlin in Lights: Simon Rattle, Absent and Present
text: Some years ago my boss stopped by my desk one day to ask, “Is there something called ‘The Rite of Spring’?” Yes, there is -­ or rather, there are. In the last 18 months or so, I’ve probably seen a dozen variations on the Stravinsky-Nijinsky theme: Tero Saarinen’s, Emanuel Gat’s, Shen Wei’s, Johan Inger’s for Nederlands Dans Theater II … (I was on vacation during Wall to Wall Stravinsky at Symphony Space in March 2006, and so missed the belly dance version by Sharita.)

headline: Berlin in Lights: The Berlin Philharmonic Takes the A Train
text: I have heard some renowned ensembles perform in unusual places. But, I never would have imagined that I would someday hear the mighty Berlin Philharmonic performing in a converted movie palace in the Washington Heights section of northern Manhattan.

headline: Burress and Pierce Play, but Kiwanuka Is Hurt
text: Plaxico Burress, playing all season with an injured right ankle, was back in the starting lineup for the Giants Sunday at Detroit and caught a pass for a nine-yard gain on the Giants’ first play from scrimmage. Antonio Pierce, the middle linebacker who missed two practices last week with a mild concussion, also was back in the lineup for the Giants.

headline: Clinton Is New to Nafta Criticism, Obama Says

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter: Huckabee’s Record
text: On a talk-show lineup dominated by three presidential contenders, Chris Wallace gave Mike Huckabee a pretty good going-over – perhaps signifying that the Arkansas politician is indeed joining the mix of Republican contenders seen as serious (a national Gallup Poll on Friday among likely Republican voters put him in double digits – at 10 percent – for the first time, and he is showing up in second place in some polls in Iowa).

headline: Martin Honored by Jets
text: Curtis Martin addressed reporters before the Jets-Steelers game on Sunday. He looked dapper in his pinstripe suit, pink shirt and striped tie. He looked like he could still play, although Martin did say his knees hurt after jogging, and he has been told the pain will “never get better.”

headline: Dollar panic
text: Warning: economistic post, plus I’m not quite sure what I think myself.

headline: Suphala | Musician
text: For Suphala, home is where the rhythm is. “Once I’m onstage, I feel complete,” says this New York-based tabla player, who was the first female musician to perform in post-Taliban Kabul. A Minneapolis native, she studied tabla — a traditional North Indian drum — with the master Alla Rakha and has collaborated with the hip-hop producer Timbaland. She takes her blend of electronic and classical Indian music everywhere, from Brooklyn (where she recorded her most recent album, “Blueprint”) to a royal palace in Jodhpur, India (“the acoustics are amazing”), but Suphala finds some of her most attentive audiences at the airport. “It’s a given that my tabla gets lots of looks at security,” she says. “The case does look like something out of ‘Star Wars.”’

headline: We’re even more doomed
text: So far, media behavior in the 2008 campaign has been even worse than in the 2000 and 2004 campaigns. We’re mired in a disastrous war, there’s a crisis in the housing market, the health care system is collapsing — yet the coverage is all about the horserace, rather than the issues.

headline: Hot Stove Roundup
text: With Alex Rodriguez almost certainly heading back to the Yankees, where does that leave the Marlins’ Miguel Cabrera? Cabrera, who is likely to be traded as Florida looks to cut its payroll, was considered a candidate to replace A-Rod at third base.

headline: Scattered Among Many
text: Almost eleven years ago, I stood in the orphanage in Hoa Binh, Vietnam, waiting to meet my adoptive parents for the first time. I was just six years old. This past spring, we journeyed back to Vietnam for my first visit since my adoption. We visited my orphanage and many other wonderful places in Vietnam. My visit to the orphanage triggered so many memories of my time there and of that first meeting with my new parents. The poem I wrote reflects some of those memories and instances. There were so many but that first meeting was what stood out most in my remembrances. Time changes many things but our memories somehow survive. I look back now and don’t have any regrets or fears about changing my life. This experience has enabled me to revisit the past with a new outlook.

headline: Morriss Out at Baylor
text: What has long been reported and speculated became official Sunday, as Baylor announced that it was firing Coach Guy Morriss. This is somewhat old news at it had been leaked out weeks ago, but it will be interesting to see who takes over this most difficult of jobs.

headline: The Black Pantsuit as Uniform
text: Since so many of you have commented about the first-woman-candidate thing, let me suggest a subject that’s obviously trivial, but one I’ve always found interesting. When Hillary Clinton first ran for the U.S. Senate in New York, she wore the same thing virtually every day–a black pantsuit and a pink blouse. She was doing exactly what men do, which is to adopt a kind of uniform.

headline: Ask Activist Dai Qing About the Three Gorges Dam
text: Welcome back to our expert roundtable discussion of China’s environmental crisis. Later today we will be posting answers to reader questions from Peter Bradford, an expert on renewable energy, on possible solutions to China’s need for energy to fuel industrial expansion. On Wednesday, we will be joined by Dai Qing, a prominent activist in China, who has been an outspoken critic of the Three Gorges Dam for two decades and was the editor of “The River Dragon Has Come: The Three Gorges Dam and the Fate of China’s Yangtze River and Its People.”

headline: Carr Officially Retiring
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich, Nov. 18 – The inevitable became a reality Sunday when Michigan Coach Lloyd Carr gathered his players at a 4 p.m. meeting and told them he planned to retire at the end of the season.

headline: Glad I’m not young anymore
text: Twenty-five years ago I was on the staff of the Council of Economic Advisers (yes, it was the Reagan administration — but I had a technocratic, non-political position, and was one of a number of Democrats working there, including a guy by the name of Larry Summers). And one of my jobs was to go to international meetings, where I helped draw up communiques. These communiques were, by design, bland and uninformative — because consensus, not insight, was the goal, so anything controversial was fuzzed over.

headline: Van Niel’s Swan Song
text: Harvard fullback Noah Van Niel ended his career on a fitting note Saturday in the Crimson’s 37-6 victory over Yale, which gave the Crimson an Ivy League championship. Van Niel has received national recognition by virtue of the fact that he is a rare combination of a bruising fullback and a promising tenor, and he particularly enjoyed the postgame celebration.
