text: Once again, with late-night comedy writers on strike and the talk shows in reruns, Laugh Lines readers step in to fill the void (send your monologue jokes via the comment link below):

headline: After Global Agreement, Companies May Bid Higher at Wireless Auction in U.S.
text: PARIS, Nov. 18 — When and if Google, Apple, Yahoo and the other potential bidders participate in the auction for wireless licenses in the United States in January, the prices they offer could be the first measure of the impact of the monthlong global radio-frequency spectrum conference that ended in Geneva on Friday.

headline: A Fresh Flip Through the Pages of Swing
text: The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra has been around long enough to have its regulars, in the form of audience members and paper on music stands. Both showed up for “Best of the Big Bands,” the orchestra’s speed tour through American dance-palace ingenuity at Rose Theater on Friday night.

headline: Martin D. Raab, 75, an Architect for the City, Is Dead
text: Martin D. Raab, a former senior partner at one of New York’s prominent architecture firms who was chosen by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to lead the city’s School Construction Authority at a time when the agency was struggling with long-delayed projects, cost overruns and charges of corruption, died Wednesday in Hartford. He was 75 and had homes in Manhattan and Stockbridge, Mass.

headline: The All-American Family Man
text: This 30-second advertisement for the Republican presidential campaign of former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts is to begin running in Iowa and New Hampshire on Monday.

headline: Humor Can Bring Back an Audience
text: If the writers’ strike drags on, one TV show after another will exhaust its supply of fresh episodes and move into repeats. Executives are aware of the wide disparity in how different types of programs are received the second time around.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A (Bronx) Zoo Tale
text: A colorful campaign aimed at parents and children is playing up the “wild” in the premier attractions owned and operated by the Wildlife Conservation Society.

headline: Keeping Americans in Their Homes
text: The nation’s housing market is in a deep recession, and further declines in new construction, sales and prices are imminent. By the end of next year, falling home values, combined with rising payments on adjustable mortgages, tighter lending conditions and, in all probability, a faltering job market, will have unleashed mass foreclosures — estimated at several hundred thousand to two million — unless something is done to help keep Americans in their homes.

headline: Steelers Are Hit Where It Hurts
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 18  Before Sunday’s game, the numbers suggested the Jets would get blown out by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

headline: Web Sites Go Fishing in TV’s Advertising Revenue Stream
text: LONDON, Nov. 18 — Web sites have been “draining the life out of newspapers and radio for years,” according to one of the founders of an Internet video site, and now they are going after the advertising revenue stream of television as well.

headline: Publishers Seek to Mine Book Circles
text: In early June, at Book Club Expo, a gathering of reading group members and book lovers, the author Khaled Hosseini opened the first session with heartfelt thanks to the attendees.

headline: Dynamo Repeat as M.L.S. Champions
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  It probably should not come as a surprise that Dwayne De Rosario scored the goal that gave the Houston Dynamo its second consecutive M.L.S. Cup title.

headline: A ‘9 to 5’ Musical and Theater Notes
text: The Grammy-Award-winning singer-songwriter Dolly Parton has another job, writing the music and lyrics for a new stage version of “9 to 5,” based on the 1980 movie starring Ms. Parton, left, Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin and Dabney Coleman. Patricia Resnick, a co-author of the original screenplay, wrote the new book. Joe Mantello (“The Ritz”) is slated to direct the production, which is to have its premiere at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles next fall. Andy Blankenbuehler (“In the Heights”) will handle the choreography. Previews are scheduled to begin Sept. 3. The main roles have been cast: Allison Janney of the TV series “The West Wing,” Stephanie J. Block (“The Pirate Queen,” “Wicked”) and Megan Hilty (“Wicked”) as the three co-workers who take control of the office from their egotistical boss, Franklin Hart Jr., to be played by Marc Kudisch (“The Glorious Ones”). ... Speaking of “In the Heights” and Mr. Blankenbuehler, he and the Broadway-bound show’s director, Thomas Kail, are the winners of the 2006-7 Joseph A. Callaway Awards for excellence in direction and choreography. The awards have been presented annually since 1989 by the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, and winners are chosen by a committee of society members. The presentations will be made tonight at the group’s annual membership meeting. “In the Heights,” with music and lyrics by Lin-Manuel Miranda and a book by Quiara Alegría Hudes, will begin previews Feb. 14 at the Richard Rodgers Theater, with opening night scheduled for March 9.

headline: Knicks Look Ahead to Long Season
text: A few weeks ago, when the season was new and a reasonable optimism filled the air, Stephon Marbury was asked to assess the Knicks’ chances. He hesitated.

headline: Stagehands and Producers Break Off Talks
text: The latest round of talks between the producers’ league and the stagehands’ union broke down last night, leaving no end in sight for the strike that has darkened most of Broadway for nine days.

headline: Part of an Oil Book Relied on Wikipedia
text: The publisher John Wiley & Sons confirmed last week that its book “Black Gold: The New Frontier in Oil for Investors” by George Orwel had lifted almost word for word about five paragraphs from a Wikipedia article on the Khobar Towers bombing in Saudi Arabia.

headline: U.S. Considers Enlisting Tribes in Pakistan to Fight Al Qaeda
text: This article was reported and written by Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Carlotta Gall.

headline: Goldman Sachs Rakes In Profit in Credit Crisis
text: For more than three months, as turmoil in the credit market has swept wildly through Wall Street, one mighty investment bank after another has been brought to its knees, leveled by multibillion-dollar blows to their bottom lines.

headline: 4 More Years: Castillo and Mets Nearing Deal
text: The Mets, who spent a tumultuous weekend unexpectedly re-entering the market for a starting catcher and preparing for life without Tom Glavine, edged closer to filling their vacancy at second base last night. Luis Castillo and the Mets are nearing completion on a four-year, $25 million deal that will establish continuity at a position that has lacked it during Manager Willie Randolph’s tenure.

headline: Irvington: Woman Wounded by Stray Shot
text: A woman returning home from church yesterday afternoon was wounded by a stray gunshot, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released, was a passenger in a car that had parked in front of a home on Montrose Terrace. As she got out of the car, a bullet crashed through the rear window and struck her on the left side of the face. She was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where her injuries were described as not life-threatening. The police said that the bullet appeared to be a stray shot from several that were fired from a nearby white car at a black car. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Ochoa Wins ADT Championship in Stunning Fashion
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 18 — Lorena Ochoa picked the perfect time and place Sunday to bury any lingering doubt about her ability to finish. On the frightening final holes of the course built by the author of “The Art of the Deal,” Ochoa, 26, wrote a chapter of her own on how to close the deal on the richest season a female golfer has had.

headline: Strike or No Strike, for a Select Few, Saturday Night Was Live
text: Thirty minutes before showtime just about all the cast members of “Saturday Night Live” were gathered in a green room, going over their bits. “Fred, remember on the cold open, you wait for Darrell,” Seth Meyers, one of the show’s head writers, instructed Fred Armisen. Kenan Thompson ran his lines and brushed his teeth; Rachel Dratch adjusted her Debbie Downer wig; Kristen Wiig gathered her props. Norah Jones, a surprise guest, arrived and greeted the guest host, Michael Cera, the deadpan boy-hero of “Superbad.”

headline: Electrical Problem Halts Trains
text: All train service between Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and Penn Station in Newark was disrupted for nearly six hours yesterday after an eastbound New Jersey Transit train became entangled in overhead wires in a tunnel under the Hudson River. The break in service, which began about 8:30 a.m., affected dozens of Amtrak and New Jersey Transit trains and more than 30,000 riders, according to representatives of the railroads. The disabled train, traveling from Long Branch, N.J., was carrying about 300 passengers, who were transferred in the tunnel to a Long Island Rail Road train, a New Jersey Transit spokeswoman said. Both railroads said that normal service resumed in the afternoon and that the disruption was not expected to affect this morning’s commute.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Beowulf Destroys the Competition

headline: In Railyards, Seeing a Blank Canvas on the Hudson
text: Five developers are competing to buy the development rights over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority railyards that straddle 11th Avenue, between 30th and 33rd Streets. They have submitted billion-dollar offers and elaborate development plans for what would be the largest project in Manhattan, on 26 acres stretching across the equivalent of six city blocks overlooking the Hudson River.

headline: Creativity, Strikes and Power
text: It was a good weekend for the labor that is organized around the creative arts.

headline: Rudi Schmid, 85, Leading Liver Researcher, Is Dead
text: Dr. Rudi Schmid, a liver specialist and medical educator who was an early champion of establishing organ transplant centers to make donor livers widely available, died on Oct. 20 in Kentfield, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Carr to Retire From Michigan
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18  In the chilly parking lot outside Schembechler Hall on Sunday night, reporters hovered around Lloyd Carr’s silver Lexus sport utility vehicle.

headline: Big Fish May Be Easier Targets
text: In the past two months, three of the world’s most highly visible professional athletes have been fingered for wrongdoing, one in connection with dogfighting, two in connection with the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: McCain’s Rocky Relationship With the Hawkeye State
text: There was a particularly striking number contained in The New York Times/CBS News poll of Iowa caucus-goers last week and it told the story of the complicated — and cool— relationship that Senator John McCain has always had with Republicans in Iowa. The number was four— the percentage of Iowa Republicans who said they would support him. He is running fifth in the state.

headline: Injury Report
text: Donovan McNabb sprained his ankle in the second quarter of Philadelphia’s game against Miami. A. J. Feeley played well in relief, but Coach Andy Reid moved quickly to head off a quarterback controversy. “If Donovan’s healthy, he’s the quarterback,” Reid said. ... Receiver Santonio Holmes left the Steelers’ game against the Jets with an ankle injury and did not return. ... Jaguars linebacker Mike Peterson will be out indefinitely after breaking his right hand against the Chargers.

headline: Rendition, Torture and Accountability
text: Maher Arar, a Syrian-born Canadian, was stopped at Kennedy Airport in 2002 while returning from a family vacation. After being held in solitary confinement in a Brooklyn detention center and interrogated without proper access to a lawyer, he was spirited off to Syria. He was tortured there for months before officials decided that their suspicions that he was a member of Al Qaeda were mistaken and let him go.

headline: Craig Smith, Boston-Based Conductor Noted for Bach Cantatas, Dies at 60
text: Craig Smith, who as the founding music director of the Emmanuel Music orchestra and chorus in Boston led the first complete cycle of Bach’s cantatas in the United States as well as expansive explorations of works from the 16th century to the present day, died on Wednesday in Boston. He was 60.

headline: Diplomacy With the Devil
text: Washington

headline: Federer Shows the Upstart Ferrer Who’s No. 1
text: SHANGHAI, Nov. 18  Roger Federer, who ended his season with a straight-sets victory over the hottest player in this elite, year-ending tournament, can now rest a bit before taking on his only serious remaining opponent  history.

headline: U.S. Approves $1.3 Billion for 2nd Avenue Subway
text: The long-dreamed-of Second Avenue subway will take another important step toward becoming a real thing of concrete and steel today, as the federal government plans to announce that it has formally approved $1.3 billion in financing for the project’s first phase.

headline: In a Quiet Suburb, a Quiet Life Darkened
text: Maybe she taught you ballet, or piano, or the violin. She might have been your kindergarten teacher, or the neighbor lady who baby-sat, or your favorite grandmother. She wore pastel cardigans and eyeglasses that hung from a chain around her neck. She smelled like nobody else, of flowers and powder and gentle decay.

headline: Advertising Accounts and People
text: Accounts

headline: Celgene to Acquire Pharmion
text: The biotechnology company Celgene said yesterday that it would pay $2.9 billion in cash and stock to acquire Pharmion, strengthening Celgene’s cancer drug portfolio and its distribution in Europe.

headline: Remember the War on Drugs?
text: It is good to see Mexico and the United States working together to battle the drug cartels that deliver hundreds of tons of illegal drugs to American consumers every year, killing more than 2,000 Mexicans annually along the way. Still, the Bush administration’s proposed $1.4 billion counternarcotics aid package falls far short of what is needed to confront the problem.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Beats Earnings Estimates
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 — Hewlett-Packard, the world’s largest technology company, today reported fourth-quarter sales and earnings that well exceeded Wall Street’s estimates.

headline: Defense Carries Giants Over Lions
text: DETROIT, Nov. 18 — After the Giants earned a tense and rugged 16-10 victory against the Lions at Ford Field on Sunday, someone told Michael Strahan that Detroit quarterback Jon Kitna said that the Giants were not the better team.

headline: Off City Turf, Haggling for Food
text: Until Jennifer McLean and two drivers from City Harvest showed up at Joe Sidoti’s farm last Friday, the radishes still growing in his field were goners.

headline: Sometimes a Double Gives Away Too Much
text: Gandhi said, “If I had no sense of humor, I would long ago have committed suicide.” One hopes that West has a sense of humor because he committed metaphorical suicide on the diagramed deal, which occurred during a knockout team event at the Lancaster Red Rose Regional in Lancaster, Pa., this month.

headline: French Commuters Face Longer Strike
text: PARIS, Nov. 18  Exasperated French commuters braced for a sixth day of no train service and snarled traffic on Monday after transportation unions voted Sunday to press on with their strike against the government’s effort to change some early retirement benefits.

headline: ‘... And the Pursuit of Happiness’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Where Schusses Overcome Kosovo’s Ethnic Schisms
text: BREZOVICA, Kosovo — War is not forgotten here, but there is at least one place — at this ski resort, 5,600 feet high on a mountain blanketed with snow during winter — where Kosovo’s Albanians and Serbs try, however uneasily, to get along.

headline: Gala to Honor Plácido Domingo
text: This past weekend was the 40th anniversary of Plácido Domingo’s Los Angeles debut: He was on tour with the New York City Opera when he first stood on stage at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, on Nov. 17, 1967, singing the title role in Alberto Ginastera’s “Don Rodrigo.” To commemorate the event, the Los Angeles Opera has announced the Plácido Domingo 40th Anniversary Gala on April 18. Since 2003, he has been the Eli and Edythe L. Broad General Director of the Los Angeles Opera.

headline: Bronx: Firefighter Injured in Fall
text: A firefighter was hurt yesterday afternoon when he fell from an aerial bucket while battling a blaze in an apartment in Highbridge, the Fire Department said. The firefighter, Brian Smith, 43, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was listed in serious but stable condition. One apartment resident was also injured in the fire, neighbors said. The fire was on the second floor of a six-story building on Shakespeare Avenue. Melissa Gonzales, who lives above the apartment that was on fire, said she believed that Firefighter Smith was trying to break a window on her floor to gain access. A bystander’s video of the accident shows two firefighters in the bucket, and one falling.

headline: Environmental Groups Cutting Catalog Stacks
text: Consumers who curse the growing stacks of holiday catalogs in their mailboxes have a new alternative: a coalition of environmental groups has introduced a free Web site, CatalogChoice.org, that allows people to remove themselves from more than 1,000 mailing lists.

headline: Jets Show They Remember How to Win
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 18 — Through the doors of the Jets’ locker room came the unfamiliar sounds of celebration: grown men singing in the shower, the hooting and hollering of a team that had watched 55 days pass between its first and second victories.

headline: New CDs
text: CELINE DION “Taking Chances”  (Columbia)

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,249,585.28

headline: Notes on Mortality and Darkness
text: Thomas Bernhard once wrote that all of Austria was suicidal, but that not all of its citizens followed through on the inclination. The Berlin Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday, the third and last of a series and a centerpiece for the Berlin in Lights festival just ended, seemed at one moment to be running into the arms of death and at the next backing away. The music was Gyorgy Kurtag’s “Stele” and Mahler’s 10th Symphony. Simon Rattle conducted.

headline: Greece and Turkey Open Gas Pipeline
text: ATHENS, Nov. 18 — Greece and Turkey opened a $300 million pipeline on Sunday, creating an energy corridor that connects the rich natural gas fields in the Caspian Sea region to Europe, bypassing Russia and the volatile Middle East.

headline: Faith and Family Boost a Man’s Resolve
text: Noel M. Hall sometimes found the chemotherapy so unbearable that he wanted to quit. He wanted to let the cancer take his liver and his life.

headline: Study Finds Higher Costs for Caregivers of Elderly
text: The out-of-pocket cost of caring for an aging parent or spouse averages about $5,500 a year, according to the nation’s first in-depth study of such expenses, a sum that is more than double previous estimates and more than the average American household spends annually on health care and entertainment combined.

headline: Making News, Without Saying a Word
text: As journalistic blunders go, it wasn’t quite up there with “Dewey Defeats Truman.” But last week, The Associated Press had to eat its words after running a news article about Paris Hilton’s supposed desire to publicize the plight of elephants in northeastern India.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC SIGNALS The main economic news of the week will come on Tuesday, when the Federal Reserve releases the minutes from its October meeting and issues its first of its new economic forecasts.

headline: Manhattan: Man Found Fatally Shot in Hallway
text: Police officers responding to a report of an unconscious person in Hamilton Heights yesterday found a dead man who had been shot, the police said. The officers were summoned to the third-floor hall at 201 West 146th Street about 8:45 a.m. and found a man, 39, lying there with a single gunshot wound to his chest, according to the police. His name had not been released yesterday evening because his family had not yet been notified, the police said.

headline: Pakistani Group, Suspected by West of Jihadist Ties, Holds Conclave Despite Ban
text: RAIWIND, Pakistan, Nov. 18 — For six days they came: hundreds of thousands of Pakistani men squashed onto a barren rice field, dressed in baggy trousers, crocheted caps on their heads, sandals on their feet and long beards a common feature.

headline: Children Play With Fire by Doing Riffs on Stravinsky
text: The Berlin in Lights Festival neared its close on Saturday night with the charming “Rite of Spring Project,” an evening of music and dance created by members of the Berlin Philharmonic, a guest choreographer and some 200 children from schools in New York City. But is charm all that appropriate, given the raw and pounding violence of the Stravinsky classic that inspired the program, performed at the resplendently funky United Palace Theater in Washington Heights?

headline: Fox Cable Guy Edges Into the Big Pay Leagues
text: Roger Ailes, the chairman of the Fox News Channel, calls Shepard Smith his “go-to guy,” the person he wants leading the channel’s coverage any time news breaks.

headline: Chinese Dam Projects Criticized for Their Human Costs
text: JIANMIN VILLAGE, China — Last year, Chinese officials celebrated the completion of the Three Gorges Dam by releasing a list of 10 world records. As in: The Three Gorges is the world’s biggest dam, biggest power plant and biggest consumer of dirt, stone, concrete and steel. Ever. Even the project’s official tally of 1.13 million displaced people made the list as record No. 10.

headline: A Delicate Glass Roof With Links to the Past
text: WASHINGTON — However entertaining you may find its cutthroat political atmosphere, this city has long been a backwater in terms of contemporary architecture. More often than not, when anyone here tinkers with old landmarks, they turn them into kitsch.

headline: Strike Causes NBC to Skip Event for TV Journalists
text: Come January, television networks hobbled by the writers’ strike may not have many new shows to promote. So, for the first time in 20 years, one network is not attending the twice-yearly conference for television journalists, and the other broadcast networks are uncertain about their participation.

headline: New Jersey Moves to End Death Penalty
text: TRENTON, Nov. 18  The eight men confined to the Capital Sentences Unit of 3 Wing in the New Jersey State Prison, ranging in age from 77 to 30, have a better chance of dying of old age than they do of lethal injection on an executioner’s gurney.

headline: Examining the Many Hues That Create Black and White
text: What is “black dance”? The question, usually asked by white dance writers, tends to be greeted by groans from black choreographers, company directors and performers. But Gesel Mason, herself a black dancer and choreographer, plunged headlong into the subject on Friday night at Joyce SoHo in “No Boundaries: Dancing the Visions of Contemporary Black Choreographers” and came up with some provocative responses.

headline: Baby Shower in Brooklyn Ends in Deadly Gunfire
text: A manager at a Brooklyn banquet hall shot three people outside the hall early yesterday, one of them fatally, and was then shot by one of two men who intervened, the police said. The men were arrested moments later, after a police sergeant fired at them twice during a foot chase, striking one of the men in the leg, the authorities said.

headline: Jesuit Order Settles Suit on Sex Abuse in Alaska
text: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 18 (AP)  A Roman Catholic religious order has agreed to pay $50 million to more than 100 Alaska Natives who say they were victims of sexual abuse by Jesuit priests, a lawyer for the victims said Sunday.

headline: A Russian Pianist Finds a Place for Both a Hush and a Roar
text: The atmosphere was electric before a recital by the pianist Denis Matsuev at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, and the accent of the throng was mostly Russian. Mr. Matsuev, 32, won the prestigious International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow in 1998. He has since been heralded by some critics as the successor to Russian keyboard lions like Evgeny Kissin and Arcadi Volodos, and perhaps to Vladimir Horowitz as well.

headline: Reform and Consumer Safety
text: With the recent reports about toxic toys from China, the public is right to be alarmed by the withering of the government’s consumer product safety protections. Congress has been moving ahead on reform bills, but Congressional leaders will have to act deftly to prevent rivalry between the House and Senate from hampering passage of a truly effective final measure. Industry lobbyists are working hard to promote gridlock and stop the tough changes consumers need.

headline: Johnson Wins 2nd Nascar Championship
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 18  To understand the level of dominance displayed by Jimmie Johnson in this year’s Nascar Nextel Cup series, consider that it has been nine seasons since any driver has won as many as 10 races in a season. Even when Jeff Gordon managed 13 victories in 33 races back in 1998, only 17 drivers competed in every race.

headline: Cost of Elderly Care Is Double Prior Estimates
text: The out-of-pocket cost of caring for an aging parent or spouse averages $5,531 a year, according to the nation’s first in-depth study of such expenses, a sum that is more than double previous estimates and more than the average American household spends each year on health care and entertainment combined.

headline: Financials, Once a Balm, Now Hamper the Market
text: As the air came out of the technology and telecommunications bubble this decade, the stock market found a new champion in the financial sector.

headline: Hollywood Producer of Varied Interests, Many Hits, but Little Fame
text: LOS ANGELES — Brian Grazer, one of the most successful producers in Hollywood, would seem to be a memorable guest, with his energetic manner and elaborately spiked hair. But to make sure he is not forgotten, he will often leave behind a small photo of himself in an inexpensive heart-shaped frame after attending a dinner or party, hiding it among his host’s family photographs.

headline: Homeland Security Adviser Resigns
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Frances Fragos Townsend, the White House adviser on terrorism and homeland security, whose tough and aggressive approach had made her one of President George W. Bush’s most trusted aides, has resigned.

headline: The iPhone?  Microsoft Shrugs
text: The iPhone? Microsoft Shrugs

headline: Monday’s Matchup
text: Titans quarterback Vince Young threw for a career-high 257 yards last Sunday, but given his shaky passing this season (4 touchdowns, 10 interceptions) it may be safer for Tennessee to keep the ball on the ground. Fortunately for the Titans, the Broncos rank 31st against the run, giving up 151 yards a game. LenDale White will have some help attacking that defense with the expected return of Chris Brown from an injury. Travis Henry’s sore knee may keep him out of the Broncos’ lineup, leaving Selvin Young to stare down the Titans’ second-ranked defense. If he cannot move the ball on the ground, Jay Cutler (nine touchdowns, nine interceptions) will have to pass it. The good news for Cutler is that he may not have to worry about Albert Haynesworth, who is nursing a hamstring injury. ANDREW DAS

headline: A Blues Diva in Weimar, Visiting on Her Own Terms
text: Cassandra Wilson ventured out of her normal comfort zone on Saturday evening to give a recital of popular standards at Café Sabarsky as the final event in the Neue Galerie’s cabaret sidebar to Berlin in Lights, a festival presented by Carnegie Hall. Talk about crossover! Ms. Wilson is a singer who plays by her own rules. With her dark, loamy jazz and blues voice, she likes to make it up as she goes along, even in a recital format.

headline: Retailers Explore New Ways of Being Paid
text: A DECADE ago, PayPal was best known as the payment method of choice for Beanie Babies purchases on eBay. This holiday season, it could pay for a diamond ring on the online jeweler Blue Nile.

headline: Stocks Fall on Fresh Woes in Banking Sector
text: Stocks fell sharply today, led lower by the financial sector, with the Dow Jones industrial average declining more than 200 points and closing below 13,000. It was the Dow’s lowest close since the depth of the markets’ plunge in August.

headline: Capturing the Moment With Fewer Minutes
text: Pop stars have kept photojournalists in check for a long time now, having them restricted to pens or escorted from concert halls after only a few songs. But lately some leashes have been especially short. At Stevie Wonder’s concert at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, photographers were told they could shoot only the first 5 to 10 seconds of Mr. Wonder’s entrance and the first 60 seconds of his first song. Then they had to leave.

headline: A Web Site for Pet Lovers, and Marketers Who Love Them
text: KNOWING that you can never underestimate people’s love for their cats and dogs, NBC Universal and Procter & Gamble have set up a Web portal that looks something like a Yahoo or AOL for pet owners, with a bit of Facebook and MySpace thrown in.

headline: A Deeply Green City Confronts Its Energy Needs and Nuclear Worries
text: FORT COLLINS, Colo. — This city takes pride in being green, from its official motto, “Where renewal is a way of life,” to its Climate Wise energy program, which helps local businesses reduce the carbon emissions that scientists say can contribute to global warming.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,859 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Footnotes
text: On Thursday Lindsay Lohan spent just 84 minutes in the Century Regional Detention Facility in Lynwood, Calif. (the old stomping grounds of Paris Hilton). Ms. Lohan, 21, was to serve a one-day sentence passed in August for a drunken driving and cocaine-possession conviction. ... “Barbara Cook’s 80th Birthday Celebration” with the New York Philharmonic, tonight and tomorrow night, will have an encore performance. Ms. Cook will return on Jan. 8, with tickets already on sale. The January program will be the same as this week’s: a mix of Broadway songs and popular standards with Lee Musiker conducting. {hellip} Brent Weinbach, a stand-up comedian who works in the Bay Area, won the Andy Kaufman Award at the Comedy Festival in Las Vegas on Friday night. The award, which was inaugurated in 2004 and recognizes a comedian with an original approach, had previously been presented as part of the annual New York Comedy Festival. ... Calvin Levels will perform his solo play “James Baldwin: Down From the Mountaintop” from Dec. 7 through Dec. 9 as part of a 20th-anniversary commemoration of the writer, who died in 1987. Performances will be at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem. There will also be a panel discussion on Dec. 9, moderated by Amy Goodman of Democracy Now. Panelists scheduled to participate include Cornel West and Amiri Baraka. Visit JamesBaldwinPlay.com for details.

headline: A Guerrilla Video Site Meets MTV
text: Vice magazine has built a small media empire out of a raw, ironic sensibility, risqué photographs and a willingness to deal in taboo subjects.

headline: St. Anthony’s Wins Title
text: St. Anthony’s of South Huntington, Long Island, won its seventh consecutive Catholic High School Football League AAA title yesterday, beating Mount St. Michael of the Bronx, 26-20, at Hofstra’s Shuart Stadium. Mount St. Michael also lost in last year’s final.The Rutgers-bound defensive tackle Scott Vallone had nine tackles, two sacks and a fumble recovery. He also made a potential game-saving tackle, taking down quarterback Jayson Holt short of a first down at the St. Anthony’s 15 with 59 seconds remaining. William Ruggiero scored two rushing touchdowns for St. Anthony’s (10-1).

headline: Study Links Drop in Test Scores to a Decline in Time Spent Reading
text: Harry Potter, James Patterson and Oprah Winfrey’s book club aside, Americans — particularly young Americans — appear to be reading less for fun, and as that happens, their reading test scores are declining. At the same time, performance in other academic disciplines like math and science is dipping for students whose access to books is limited, and employers are rating workers deficient in basic writing skills.

headline: MTV Heads to the Middle East
text: Hoping to take advantage of demographics in the Arab world, where about two-thirds of the population is under 30, MTV started MTV Arabia in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, at midnight Saturday night, the BBC and The Associated Press reported. MTV Arabia, entering a market already teeming with more than 50 music channels, will present Arab music videos and other shows, and adapt current hits like “Pimp My Ride” for a new audience. The channel will also broadcast new reality shows like “Hip HopNa,” featuring two Arab hip-hop stars. The first program on Saturday night, a pretaped show, featured the Grammy-winning rapper Ludacris, above, the Senegalese soul singer Akon and the Lebanese-born singer-songwriter Karl Wolf of Montreal.

headline: Broadway Strike Threatens to Take a Toll on City
text: With Broadway theaters shutting down for the rest of the busy Thanksgiving week, and possibly longer, because of a strike, businesses around Times Square are bracing for what could be a major loss of customers and revenue during their busiest time of the year.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Brazil Discovers an Oil Field Can Be a Political Tool
text: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 17 — With the price of oil hovering near $100 a barrel, the discovery of the biggest deep-water oil field off the southeastern coast has the potential to transform Brazil into a global energy powerhouse and to reshape the politics of this energy-starved continent.

headline: The Day’s Best
text: Antrel Rolle scored on two interception returns as the Cardinals beat the Bengals, 35-27. He also returned a third interception for a score, but it was called back because of a penalty.

headline: Calling Country Stars of Tomorrow
text: Country Music Television and FremantleMedia North America, the production company behind “American Idol,” have announced the date for open auditions for “Can You Duet?,” a new music competition show that aims to find the next big pair in country music. The cattle call will take place in Nashville on Jan. 12, but future Johnny and Junes or Kenny and Dollys can also submit videotaped auditions. (Details are at canyouduet.com.) Judges for the show, expected to reach the air next spring, have yet to be announced.

headline: Keeping Witnesses Off Stand to Keep Them Safe
text: The strategy sounds almost illogical: Detectives in New Jersey are being urged to build criminal cases with as few witnesses as possible. Or with none at all.

headline: Democrats Say They Won’t Back Down on War
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 — Democrats in Congress failed once again Friday to shift President Bush’s war strategy in Iraq, but insisted that they would not let up. Their explanation for their latest foiled effort seemed to boil down to a simple question: “What else are we supposed to do?”

headline: U.S. Hopes to Use Pakistani Tribes Against Al Qaeda
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 — A new and classified American military proposal outlines an intensified effort to enlist tribal leaders in the frontier areas of Pakistan in the fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban, as part of a broader effort to bolster Pakistani forces against an expanding militancy, American military officials said.

headline: Child Matadors Draw Olés in Mexico’s Bullrings
text: MÉRIDA, Mexico — Michelito Lagravere Peniche, 9, put his fingers to his head to create mock horns and charged at Jairo Miguel, 14, who gracefully dodged him on the first pass. But Michelito was an aggressive bull and he circled back, this time striking his friend Jairo in the leg. Both boys erupted in laughter.

headline: Israel, Palestine, Crab Cakes
text: I would like to invest hope in the Annapolis Middle East peace conference, or meeting, or parley, or whatever the term is. Really, I would. The 59-year battle for the same land of Zionist and Palestinian national movements has not been good for anyone.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Roger Ardan joined Gibbs & Soell Public Relations, New York, as vice president and group head at the professional and financial services group. He had been senior vice president and head of the legal and professional services group at Edelman, New York, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc.

headline: With No Suspense, Patriots Stay Unbeaten
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Nov. 18  The evening started promisingly enough for the Buffalo Bills, with Kevin Everett making his first public statement since he sustained a severe spine injury 10 weeks ago, exhorting his teammates from the big video screen, “Let’s beat the Patriots.”

headline: Paul Tibbets at Hiroshima: What Is His Legacy?
text: To the Editor:

headline: McCain Takes On Clinton, With an Eye to Civility
text: RINDGE, N.H., Nov. 18 — Senator John McCain tried Sunday night to make the case that he was best positioned to defeat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in a general election, outlining a series of contrasts with her on issues including national security and health care.

headline: U.S. Says Attacks in Iraq Fell to Feb. 2006 Level
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 18 — The American military said Sunday that the weekly number of attacks in Iraq had fallen to the lowest level since just before the February 2006 bombing of the Shiite shrine in Samarra, an event commonly used as a benchmark for the country’s worst spasm of bloodletting after the American invasion nearly five years ago.

headline: How to Tell Someone She’s Being Sued, Without Really Telling Her
text: Along with the media gossip and real estate erotica that fill The New York Observer, a dishy weekly newspaper for Manhattan’s political and media clans, there are more than four pages of advertisements in tiny type aimed at a different readership.

headline: Increase in Teacher Resignations
text: More teachers resigned during the last school year than at any time in recent history, according to figures released yesterday by the United Federation of Teachers, the city’s teachers union. According to the figures, 4,606 certified teachers resigned last year, not including teachers who retired or had problems with certification. The numbers have been steadily increasing since 2001, when 2,544 resigned; last year 4,273 teachers did so. Of the 7,069 teachers who were hired in 2006, nearly 14 percent resigned by the end of the year, the union said, up from about 11 percent the year before. The numbers showed that “losing good teachers is the predominant staffing issue that the City Department of Education needs to address,” said Randi Weingarten, the president of the union. Chris Cerf, a deputy chancellor at the Education Department, said in a statement that the numbers were inaccurate, and called the release of the figures a “media stunt.”

headline: Critics Assail Weak Dollar at OPEC Event
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 18 — A rare meeting of the heads of state of the OPEC countries ended here today on a political note, with two leaders — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran — blaming the weakness of the United States dollar for high oil prices.

headline: Owens Has Hands All Over Dallas’s Win
text: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 18  Only a prayer remained in the playbook for the Washington Redskins, who appeared ready to knock the Dallas Cowboys off the razor wire they had been straddling at times this season.

headline: Stevie Wonder and Friends, Here and Gone
text: Stevie Wonder has asked some unanswerable questions in his songs, but he deals mostly in optimistic certainty; the ideas of eternity and unconditional love don’t vex him.

headline: Two More Injuries Could Be Costly for Giants
text: DETROIT, Nov. 18 — The Giants took a big step toward a possible playoff berth Sunday, but they have still not managed to shake the injury bug that has dogged them this season.

headline: Brooklyn: Driver Injured Fleeing Crash, Police Say
text: A man was seriously injured early yesterday after fleeing the scene of a car crash in Flatbush, the police said. Shortly after midnight, a police officer spotted a car that had jumped a curb and hit a light pole near the intersection of Avenue H and East 16th Street, the police said. The driver ran down an alley and jumped over a fence. He was seriously injured because the ground dropped about 20 feet on the other side of the fence, the police said. The driver, whose name was not released, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was in serious but stable condition yesterday evening, the police said. The crash was under investigation.

headline: Bulletins From a Bustling ‘Undiscovered’ Land
text: It’s a little embarrassing to watch the New York art world “discovering” Latin American modernist art year after year, as if forever only half-aware of its existence. And it’s depressing to know that the Museum of Modern Art, which could have been collecting widely in the field for decades, had to wait for a windfall in the form of a gift collection to deal with this material in a serious and committed way. We are, after all, talking about the art of a continent and a century, not just a fad from yesterday.

headline: ‘Beowulf’ Destroys the Competition
text: “Beowulf,” the Old English epic poem being brought to gory, 3-D life through performance-capture technology (the film is neither live nor animated but somewhere in between) slew all rivals at the box office over the weekend. The film, Robert Zemeckis’s latest effort, which stars Ray Winstone, above, in the title role battling the monster Grendel (Crispin Glover) and his vengeful mother (Angelina Jolie), took in $28.1 million in its first weekend, according to studio estimates. The film, with a screenplay by Neil Gaiman and Roger Avary, cost Paramount Pictures about $150 million to make and employs technology similar (though updated) to that used by Mr. Zemeckis in “The Polar Express” in 2004. More than 40 percent of the total receipts came from the 742 3-D theaters showing the film. DreamWorks Animation’s comedy “Bee Movie,” starring the voices of Jerry Seinfeld and Renée Zellweger, fell from first to second place with $14.3 million in its third weekend. The movie’s cumulative total to date is $93.9 million. Also dropping one spot, to No. 3, was “American Gangster” (Universal), the 1970s crime thriller starring Denzel Washington and Russell Crowe. That film, directed by Ridley Scott, took in $13.2 million in its third weekend, bringing the total haul so far to $101 million. Falling from third to fourth place was the Vince Vaughn comedy “Fred Claus” (Warner Brothers) with $12 million in its second weekend and a total of $35.8 million to date. And rounding out the Top 5 was the new Dustin Hoffman fantasy, “Mr. Magorium’s Wonder Emporium” (20th Century Fox), earning $10 million in its opening weekend.

headline: Italians Tune in to Real-Life ‘Sopranos’
text: ROME — It’s said that the Mafia has a hold on Italy. Of late that has been especially true on Thursday nights, when millions of television viewers have tuned in to watch the biographical rise-and-fall saga of Salvatore (Totò) Riina, the murderous mob boss who once commanded organized crime in Sicily.

headline: U.S. Pushes for Turnout at Middle East Conference
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 — By pushing Israel to accept immediate negotiations with the Palestinians on the thorny “final status” issues, with the aim to conclude a peace settlement within a year, the Bush administration is trying to attract a significant Arab presence at the peace conference in Annapolis, Md.

headline: Navigating Two Worlds With a Compass of Lies
text: There are two genuinely honest characters in Roopa Farooki’s fizzy debut novel, “Bitter Sweets.” One is named Candida, the other Verity Trueman. While these monikers may sound heavy-handed, Ms. Farooki makes them genially absurd by putting them in context. Everyone else in this boisterous, multigenerational tale is a congenital liar.

headline: Republicans and Race
text: Over the past few weeks there have been a number of commentaries about Ronald Reagan’s legacy, specifically about whether he exploited the white backlash against the civil rights movement.

headline: New Twist in 1990 Murder Case as Star Witness Vanishes
text: This much is known about Thomas Morales. He is known as Spanky on the street, and also goes by the name Jimmy Rodriguez. He is about 5-foot-8 and in his 40s, thin, wears an earring in his left ear and a mustache.

headline: Police Kill a Man Armed With a Broken Bottle
text: A blood-streaked, shirtless man wanted for stabbing a roommate was killed in a hail of gunfire by two police officers on a Brooklyn street yesterday when, the police said, he brandished a broken wine bottle, advanced on them as they backed away, ignored their orders to drop it and finally lunged at them.

headline: Around Baghdad, Signs of Normal Life Creep Back
text: With security in Baghdad improving, residents across the city are taking steps to return to normalcy.

headline: Farmers Feed City's Hungry
text: The Times's Patrick McGeehan meets a farmer in Orange County, N.Y., who is working with City Harvest to provide produce to New York's hungry.

headline: Week 11 Talking Points
text: 1. The Patriots are back in action and back to their old tricks, reasserting their power in the A.F.C. on a day when the Steelers lost to the Jets and the Colts looked shaky for the second week in a row. A lot seems to have happened since Week 9, but is it all back to where it started, with the Patriots light years ahead?

headline: Kramnik Dominates
With Not a Joke Written, Jimmy Kimmel Hosts Music Awards
text: More than 13 minutes into ABC’s live broadcast of the American Music Awards last night, after musical numbers by Fergie, will.i.am and Nicole Scherzinger, the host finally made his appearance and opened with the lines: “I’m Jimmy Kimmel and this is my fourth time hosting the show and, uh, my first time hosting it drunk. So I’m very excited to be here.” Presumably it was an ad-lib: Mr. Kimmel went on to explain that as a member of the Writers Guild he was on strike — “in my heart,” at least — and couldn’t write any jokes.

text: Child bullfighting has become popular in Mexico, where there are no age limits for matadors. (This video contains footage that may be disturbing.)

text: Swiss Life Holding, Switzerland’s largest life insurer, agreed to sell its Dutch and Belgian units for as much as 1.54 billion euros ($2.3 billion) and said it would use the proceeds to buy back shares.

text: For more than three months, as turmoil in the credit market has swept wildly through Wall Street, one mighty investment bank after another has been brought to its knees, leveled by multibillion-dollar blows to their bottom lines.

text: As John A. Thain prepares to take the helm at Merrill Lynch and Citigroup continues its search for a new captain, rumors are surfacing that the two banks may soon consider floating minority stakes in their brokerage arms.

text: Pearl Assurance, the British closed-life fund manager, on Friday agreed to acquire a rival, Resolution, for 4.98 billion pounds ($10.21 billion), after a competing bid from a traditional insurer, Standard Life, collapsed the previous weekend.

headline: Zosano Pharma Swallows $90 Million
text: Zosano Pharma closed on the final tranche of a $90 million Series A funding that will enable the company to complete Phase 2 clinical trials of a lead drug candidate to treat osteoporosis and advance preclinical development of other drugs using the company’s proprietary drug delivery patch technology.

text: SABMiller, the world’s second-biggest brewer, has agreed to buy a Dutch rival, Grolsch, for 816 million euros ($1.2 billion) to strengthen its position in the fast-growing premium beer market.

headline: At Bonus Time, Keeping Up With the Goldmans
text: Shareholders in the securities industry are having their worst year since 2002, losing $74 billion of their equity. That won’t prevent Wall Street from paying record bonuses, totaling almost $38 billion, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Private Equity M&A May Have Peaked, Report Says
text: Mergers and acquisitions by private equity firms might have peaked, according to an investment bank report. The number of deals is falling and sovereign wealth funds will fill up the breach, according to Brian O’Reilly, director and global equities strategist at UBS wealth management.

headline: Spains Bankinter Sells $1.18 Billion Stake to Credit Agricole
text: Spain’s Bankinter said Monday it had agreed to sell a 20 percent stake to France’s Credit Agricole for 809 million euros ($1.18 billion).

headline: When Foreign Governments Buy American
text: Funds owned by foreign governments have been buying up United States assets, as shown by last week’s investment by Abu Dhabi in the chip maker Advanced Micro Devices.

headline: Abu Dhabi Fund Seeks to Invest in Emerging Markets
text: The $650 billion Abu Dhabi Investment Authority is seeking to invest more in emerging markets to get higher returns than from its assets in Europe and the United States, a senior HSBC executive said on Sunday.

headline: DreamWorks Is Said to Hold Talks With NBC Universal
text: Seeking a way out of an acrimonious relationship at Paramount, the DreamWorks principals – two Hollywood heavyweights, David Geffen and Steven Spielberg – have been negotiating to move their operation to NBC Universal, The New York Times reported on Saturday, citing unnamed people close to the talks. But negotiations have hit a wall over financing.

headline: Univision Music Bidders Said to Cut Offers
text: Potential bidders for the music assets of the Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications are reportedly shaving their offer prices by at least $50 million becasue of concerns over its artist contracts and access to advertising on the television network.

headline: To Some, New Media Proposal Is Same Old Song
text: The last time federal regulators tried to change the rules on how many media outlets companies could own, the effort bombed like a bad movie. According to The Los Angeles Times, the sequel appears to be headed for the same fate.

headline: My Pet Peeves About Informational Interviews
text: In reading through the comments on this blog, I stumbled onto this smart blog post by Steve C. Wilson about how to think about and conduct informational interviews. I’m a fan of informational interviews, and as Mr. correctly points out, they can be very handy not only when you’re searching for a job but at other moments in your career, like when you’re searching for a mentor.

headline: Obama: Takes Terrorism ‘Deadly Serious’

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports

He dominated the season like no driver has since Jeff Gordon won 13 races in 1998. This year, in a more competitive field, Johnson won 10, including four straight heading into the finale at Homestead, where he played it safe.

headline: Estimating the Broadway Strike’s Economic Cost

headline: Is Manhattan Turning Against Congestion Pricing?

The poll also found that Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly’s popularity has slipped after the fatal police shooting of a mentally disturbed Brooklyn teenager on Nov. 12.

headline: Road Stories
text: The best-ever book on tape, I’ve claimed in print, is Amanda Plummer’s reading of Joyce Carol Oates’s “Black Water,” a slim 1992 novel based loosely on Chappaquiddick. In Plummer’s telling, the story is pointillistic, onrushing and spooky; it casts the kind of spell that lets 300 miles roll under your wheels before you’ve had the chance to notice your coffee’s gone cold.

headline: From King of All Spaniards to King of the Web

headline: Amazon Pitches a Wireless iPod for Books
text: Amazon.com introduced its electronic book reader today at a packed event in New York. Unlike other products in this area, Amazon’s $399 Kindle is designed to be used without ever connecting to a computer. Instead it has a wireless Internet connection that lets users browse Amazon’s online store on the device and download a book in less than a minute.

headline: Gawking at the Kindle

headline: The Many Roads to Happiness
text: Happiness seems to be one of those squishy, hard-to-pin-down states of mind that you can’t really aim for — you just know it when you get there.

headline: All Pumped Up for Baseball’s Next Act
text: Steroids: They’re the cloud hanging over America’s pastime — one that never quite turns into a rain delay since everyone’s making so much money from them. Barry Bonds’ indictment last week for lying arrives just before the Mitchell report, the inquiry commissioned by baseball that is expected to name Names. Timed for the winter meetings, the Mitchell report is meant to allow owners to cut salaries of named players. to restore the sport’s credibility. To guide you through this complex scandal, here’s help with some frequently asked questions:

headline: Holiday Business in Bryant Park, Once Cold as Ice, Heats Up
text: Over the last five years, the holiday market at Bryant Park has been transformed from being a static and tepid street fair to a bustling showcase of plexiglass booths with $5 million to $6 million in total retail sales for its vendors. But in the early days, the market struggled to fill up the slots with mass mailings, recruiting at street fairs, and persuading skeptical retailers to open a second location in Bryant Park for the holidays.This year, the market, which opened on Saturday and will run for six weeks, had 300 applications for the 100 or so booths, which cost from $9,000 to $40,000 to rent. Vendors — which generally sell high-end crafts, jewelry and clothing — now do an average of $60,000 to $70,000 in sales, with a handful breaking $100,000. The top vendor clears $300,000 in merchandise during the period.

headline: Strike News: NBC to Press, “No Tour For You!”
text: NBC isn’t attending January’s Television Critics Association press tour because of the writers’ strike, and the other broadcast networks say they are still deciding whether to attend.

headline: Food for Thought
text: Are food banks counterproductive? Writing in The Washington Post’s Sunday Outlook section, Mark Winne, who founded a food bank in Hartford, Conn., says Americans need to “rethink our devotion to food donation.” Winne says one of the “most lasting effects” of emergency food programs “has been to sidetrack efforts to eradicate hunger and its root cause, poverty.” Later in the article, Winne explains:

headline: Dubai Feels Sting as Och-Ziff Slides
text: Funds from overseas have been eagerly acquiring stakes in United States-based private equity firms and hedge funds, with mixed results so far. The Chinese government’s $3 billion investment in the Blackstone Group has been a money loser. On Monday, Dubai’s big bet on Och-Ziff Capital Management offered another cautionary tale.

headline: Talking Replacements at Michigan
text: Michigan Athletic Director Bill Martin shed some light on the process of replacing Lloyd Carr as Michigan’s coach. He said he will not hire a search firm and he has already whittled a list of 30 candidates down to 20. He said that a large buyout would likely not turn him off of a candidate. He said he’s also not averse to waiting a few weeks, as the decision is of a magnitude that its going to reverberate for years.

headline: Benchmarks: ‘Passed the Difficult Stage in Baghdad?’
text: Update, 10:41 p.m. Just published on NYTimes.com: Baghdad Starts to Exhale as Security Improves ***

headline: Thinking about the dollar
text: I have to do some teaching on the subject of the falling dollar and whether it’s recessionary. So herewith some ruminations. WARNING: FAIRLY WONKISH.

headline: MTV Sans Frontières
text: Hey, what’s that little icon you click to signify that you want to watch MTV Arabia in English? A polar bear? And there’s a palm-tree-desert-island that gets you Arabic. As a wintry Anglophone, I guess I’m clicking the bear, but I’m not thrilled about it.

headline: A Real Question About Global Warming
text: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — Hillary Rodham Clinton just wrapped up a speech on the economy — much more on that soon — but there was one moment in the Q & A that is worth highlighting quickly.

headline: What Are These Bands Trying to Say?
text: Interpretations of promotional photos.

headline: In One Fell Swoop, Jay-Z Impresses Critics, Fans, the U.N. and Wall Street
text: The accolades Jay-Z have recently poured forth from all sectors. His new album was critically acclaimed and sold more than any other last week, which tied him with Elvis at 10 chart-topping albums.

headline: Enough About Kindle 1.0. What About Kindle 2.0?
text: As Saul Hansell described below, Amazon is trying to awaken the slumbering electronic-book business with the Kindle, its long-awaited e-book reader and online service, which we first wrote about in September. Remarkably, this is the first physical product from the Seattle-based Internet retailer, and a major commitment by its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, to forging the future of books.

headline: Clinton and Obama Spar Over the Economy
text: KNOXVILLE, Iowa – Underscoring the fierce competition to win the Iowa presidential caucuses in January, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton this morning intensified her critique of a leading Democratic rival, Barack Obama, suggesting that he lacked her ability and experience to manage the economy.

headline: The Gift of Potties, the Latest in a Quest for Public Toilets
text: The Charmin public toilets are back. Charmin said the 20 temporary potties — part toilet paper promotion and part public service — were used more than 500,000 times last year.

headline: Sooners’ Road Woes
text: Oklahoma’s loss Saturday night to Texas Tech, which was unranked, further illustrates the Sooners’ recent road woes under the ninth-year coach Bob Stoops.

headline: You’ve Got to Have Friends
text: When I was reading over the Q and A that Jimmy Bradley completed for this blog, I noticed what seemed to be an acknowledgment of a close friendship with Jonathan Waxman, and I found myself curious about the relationships between chefs in this city. Who hangs out with whom? Are there small, tightly knit groups of chefs who spend enough time together to constitute culino-social posses?

headline: Mark Your Calendars!
text: Yes, there are more debates in your future. The Commission on Presidential Debates has announced the debate dates and sites for next year’s general election:

headline: Ratings: Sunday Means Cartoons (and ’60 Minutes’)
text: Fox’s animated comedy line-up ranked No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday in the much sought-after demographic of adults 18 to 49, as “The Simpsons” and “Family Guy” earned the night’s top ratings in that age group. Both shows fared more modestly in terms of total viewers. “The Simpsons” drew 10.6 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, while “Family Guy” garnered 10.5 million at 9.

headline: Pier D Stands Out in the West Side’s Industrial Past
text: It isn’t your conventional luxury amenity.

headline: Avoiding Hospital Gridlock
text: Faut Sarieminli, 41, is a hospital transporter at Long Island College Hospital, acting as a combination of hospital bellhop and parking attendant.

headline: ‘These Wonderful Warriors’
text: The United States reaped a new crop of “green card soldiers” this month.

headline: It’s the End of the World, and They Built It
text: Last week, pictures of a scale model of an apocalyptic Manhattan caught the attention of City Room, mainly because they were not scenes from either of the forth-coming Hollywood films that destroy New York but also because something about the apartment used for the giant model seemed vaguely European. (Look closely at the radiators.)Well, as it turns out, the project is the creation of group of Swedish artists and set designers and the apartment is in Skelleftea, Sweden. One of the artists, Magnus Johannson, first posted images of “Apocalyptic Manhattan (in an Apartment)” on a game-designing forum in October.

headline: Atlas Provides Jets With Premonition
text: Teddy Atlas holds an interesting title in the Jets media guide – special assistant, boxing. But the famed boxing trainer might want to add the title of team prophet to his business card after the voicemail he left for Coach Eric Mangini before the team stunned the Steelers on Sunday.

headline: Ex-Principal of Arabic School Sues City
text: Debbie Almontaser, the founding principal of the city’s first Arabic-language school, filed a federal lawsuit today [pdf] against the city’s Education Department, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, charging that they violated her right to free speech and “conspired to deny her the opportunity to regain her position as principal” of the school, the Khalil Gibran International Academy.

headline: McCain’s 9/11 Endorsement
text: BOSTON – Despite the best attempts by a large contingent of local and national media gathered at Logan Airport here, former New Jersey Gov. Thomas Kean, co-chairman of the 9/11 commission, declined today to criticize Rudy Giuliani directly. But the mere fact that he officially endorsed Senator John McCain was criticism enough.

headline: An Avocado a Day…
text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: Beaujolais Nouveau That’s Worth a Try
text: Last Thursday was Nov. 15, which, as assiduous students of mass marketing know, is the day that the Beaujolais nouveau can legally be sold. Despite the slogan — le Beaujolais nouveau est arrivé — it usually arrives days before and sits until the 15th.

headline: Whacking Those Moles
text: Building a custom house is like playing Whac-A-Mole, the arcade game. As fast as we tackle one problem, another appears, so it feels like we’re not making much progress.

headline: Hearing Planned on Gang Insignia on Clothing
text: Updated, Nov. 21 | Are apparel manufacturers and retailers deliberately selling sports-themed clothes with gang colors and symbols?

headline: An Accidental Beneficiary of Warfare: Wildlife
text: [UPDATE, 4/5: Carl Zimmer passes along news about a deadly virus spreading through bonobos. Anyone know more?]

headline: Ferrari Promises CO2 Reduction in Future Models
text: This just came in through the wires: Ferrari is setting a goal to produce cars that are 40 percent more fuel efficient by 2012:

headline: Strike News: An Ending, Not End, For ‘Heroes’
text: The writers’ strike appears to have prompted NBC to promote the last original episode of “Heroes” as a mid-season finale.

headline: Strike News: CBS News Staffers Authorize Action
text: Several hundred CBS News staffers represented by the Writers Guild of America have voted to authorize a strike against the company, union officials said Monday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Killing Fields
text:
From Cambodia, Megan McArdle of The Atlantic assesses the legacy of Khmer Rouge rule.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: R6’s Rosenberg Jumps to Eton Park
text: From DealBook colleague Jenny Anderson:

headline: AT&T Actor Ad
text: AT&T commercial where city names are "mashed up" to create amalgams.

headline: AT&T Businessman Ad
text: AT&T commercial where city names are "mashed up" to create amalgams.

headline: The Top of The Times
text: Nick Bilton climbs the mast at the top of The New York Times building.

headline: Ahead of Schedule on Punta Mita
text: On Punta Mita, the peninsula north of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, developers are seeing little indication of a slowdown in the American market.

headline: Re-enter Sandman: Mariano Rivera Returns to the Yanks
text: A friend of mine sent me a postcard from the Hall of Fame the other day. On the front was the plaque of Kirby Puckett. Delightful in its simplicity, it lists just one team under his name: Minnesota, A.L., 1984-1995.

headline: I Am Not a Bridge
text: The town where I grew up was small and less than an hour’s drive from Dallas. Miles of farming land surrounded this small pocket of humanity. The population consisted of mostly white residents with a minority of African- and Latino-American residents and me. It was the 1970s — the Age of Aquarius, disco and human rights awareness — but the population was still split into black and white. The war in Vietnam had come to an end and America was still counting its losses. It was in this setting that I grew up loved and protected.

headline: Monday Injury Roundup
text: UPDATED

headline: The 'Surge' in Baghdad
text: Iraq may feel safer since the "surge" in U.S. troops, but for two Baghdad women recovery remains limited.

headline: Attention Paid, and Paying Off
text: Some voters outside the early voting states have been grumbling lately about all the attention being paid to the people of Iowa and New Hampshire. But voters in those two states seem to be taking their civic duty seriously.

headline: Patterns: Children With Hearing Loss Spend More Time in E.R.
text: Children who have hearing problems are much more likely than other children to end up in an emergency room with a wide variety of injuries, researchers say.

headline: A Most Valuable Performance
text: We salute the great Alex Rodriguez today not only for his third American League Most Valuable Player award, but for his powerbroker’s enlistment of a virtual league of American business savants in pursuit of the capitalist dream with a self-serving spin:

headline: Pakistan’s Court Dismisses Election Cases
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 19 — Pakistan’s Supreme Court, filled with supporters of the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, after he imposed emergency rule on Nov. 3, dismissed on Monday the main challenges to his re-election, all but ensuring his confirmation to another term by the court this week.

headline: For His 50th Birthday, a Test of Virtuosic Mettle
text: To celebrate his 50th birthday  and also to benefit a scholarship fund at Ben Gurion University of the Negev, in Israel  the violinist Shlomo Mintz played Paganini’s caprices, all 24, at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening.

headline: Companies Bolster Sales Abroad to Offset Weakness at Home
text: SALISBURY, N.C., Nov. 16 — If the fortunes of the Power Curbers company were tied solely to business in the United States, these would be grim days at its factory on the fringes of this Piedmont town. The small, family-owned company makes machines that turn concrete into curbs, and with the American construction industry in distress, domestic sales are expected to drop at least 10 percent this year.

headline: Choreographic Challenge: Another Dive Into the Enduring Mystery of ‘Rite of Spring’
text: Once upon a time (1913), in a magical kingdom far, far away (Paris), two kings (Stravinsky and Nijinsky) shocked the world with a grand collaboration (“The Rite of Spring”).

headline: Ant Power
text: Q. Where does that famous ant that can lift something like 20 times its weight get its power? Is it muscle fibers or some sort of hydraulic fluid?

headline: Kidman in Court
text: Nicole Kidman told a jury in Sydney, Australia, that she had been reduced to tears and feared a car accident as she was chased by a celebrity photographer two years ago, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Ms. Kidman was testifying in the photographer’s defamation suit against a Sydney newspaper that said he had hounded her. She said that a trip in a chauffeured car in 2005 turned into a dangerous chase as she was pursued by Jamie Fawcett, who is suing The Sun-Herald newspaper for defamation over an article that said he was Sydney’s most disliked freelance photographer and was determined to “wreak havoc” on Ms. Kidman’s private life. A jury previously found that the article defamed Mr. Fawcett; the current hearing is to decide whether the newspaper’s publisher, Fairfax Media, should pay the photographer damages, and how much.

headline: Bringing Chaos to This Part of Universe
text: When Nergal, the leader of the long-running Polish metal band Behemoth, starts a concert by growling, “Get ready for chaos,” he’s not kidding.

headline: Judge Orders 17-Year-Olds’ Cases Moved to Family Court
text: BOSTON, Nov. 19  A judge in Rhode Island has ruled that some of the 400 or so 17-year-olds charged with misdemeanors in the four months this year when a change in law treated 17-year-olds as adults in the criminal justice system should have their cases moved to Family Court.

headline: Raising Children Behind Bars
text: The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 created a far-sighted partnership between the federal government and the states that agreed to remake often barbaric juvenile justice systems in exchange for federal aid. Unfortunately, those gains have been steadily rolled back since the 1990s when states began sending ever larger numbers of juveniles to adult jails  where they face a high risk of being battered, raped or pushed to suicide. The act is due to be reauthorized this year, and Congress needs to use that opportunity to reverse this destructive trend.

headline: A Bit of Broadway, but Drama’s Mostly Offstage
text: If you go to one of the eight Broadway shows still running, you’ll find tiny strike-related differences. Some are just sad: When cast members make their semi-annual, post-curtain-call plea for contributions to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, you realize how severely that charity must be hit since 27 other shows are not collecting donations. Other differences come with silver linings: It is so easy to find a free taxi sailing up Eighth Avenue or down Broadway at 10:15 p.m.

headline: Beat-Up vs. Unbeaten: McNabb May Face Patriots
text: The Philadelphia Eagles got some good news yesterday: quarterback Donovan McNabb does not have a high ankle sprain, just a regular one that may not even keep him out of Sunday’s game.

headline: F.A.A. Oversees Aerial Ballet and Foot Shuffling
text: HERNDON, Va., Nov. 21 — The Federal Aviation Administration’s Strategic Command Center here got started early on Wednesday, with the first conference call with the airlines at 5:15 a.m. instead of the usual 7:15, a head start usually used only when there is a prediction of snowstorms or thunderstorms.

headline: For Want of a Proofreader, or at Least a Good One, a Reading Exam Is Lost
text: In an episode that has embarrassed the Department of Education, thousands of flawed testing booklets forced the invalidation of United States reading scores on an international exam administered without major mishap in 56 other countries.

headline: Parasite and Host in Constant Game of Catch-Up
text: In evolution, host and parasite can engage in a kind of arms race. One side adapts and evolves; the other side adapts and evolves to keep up. At the end of the day, neither side is necessarily better off than the other.

headline: Equity Firm Is Sued Over Withdrawal From Deal
text: United Rentals, the rental equipment provider, sued the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management yesterday over its cancellation of a $4 billion buyout of the company.

headline: A Swarm of Swindlers
text: Chicago

headline: When Works Are Staged as Well as Played
text: Jo Kondo, an eminent Japanese composer, and Robert Wilson, the internationally renowned stage director, have both drawn on elements of traditional Japanese art in their work. You might have anticipated that their idioms would merge seamlessly in a collaboration presented on Sunday night at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: Cyclone Toll Exceeds 3,100 in Bangladesh
text: The number of people left dead after the powerful cyclone that swept through Bangladesh on Thursday rose to more than 3,100 yesterday, the government said. The United Nations estimated that a million people had been left homeless, many of them in remote areas without predictable food supplies.

headline: New Worries About Credit Drive Down Stock Markets
text: Where will it end?

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Ex-Getty Curator Is Now on Trial in Greece

headline: Cambodia Arrests Former Khmer Rouge Head of State
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 19 —­ The former Khmer Rouge head of state Khieu Samphan, who was taken from a hospital here and arrested on Monday, is the last of five top figures targeted by prosecutors in advance of trials expected next year for the atrocities of the late 1970s.

headline: Amway Adds Entertainment to Product Line
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 — Amway, the door-to-door peddler of vitamins and soap, wants to reinvent how Hollywood sells entertainment.

headline: Bees on the Big Screen (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fox Toons Triumph
text: Fox’s animated comedy lineup ranked No. 1 on Sunday among adults 18 to 49, as “The Simpsons” and “Family Guy” (with the guest star Wallace Shawn providing the voice of Stewie’s archrival, Bertram, below) earned the night’s top ratings in that age group. “The Simpsons” drew 10.6 million total viewers at 8, and “Family Guy” 10.5 million at 9, Nielsen estimated. Fox’s ratings for the night also benefited from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage, which meant more than 20 million viewers were tuned in to the network as prime time began at 7. NBC and ABC tied for second in the 18-to-49 set. NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” match-up drew approximately 12.4 million viewers, while ABC’s broadcast of the 2007 American Music Awards, from 8 to 11, averaged 11.8 million, the show’s largest audience in three years. CBS ranked fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic but led the night in total viewers, thanks to “60 Minutes” at 7 (14.6 million), “The Amazing Race” at 8 (12.5 million), “Cold Case” at 9 (13.9 million) and “Shark” at 10 (13 million).

headline: Audit Finds Misuse of $34 Million Student Loan Subsidy
text: The student loan corporation in Pennsylvania improperly exploited a subsidy program to collect $34 million from the government, said a report released yesterday by the inspector general of the federal Education Department.

headline: Footnotes
text: Natalie Merchant, who came to fame with 10,000 Maniacs in 1981, will play five or six shows — her first full concerts in four years — at Club Hiro in New York. The first is scheduled for Jan. 4. ... Cirque du Soleil said that it would create a show for the Kodak Theater, home of the Academy Awards, in Los Angeles. Under a 10-year agreement, a cast of 75 will present a show in the 3,400-seat theater 368 times a year. Guy Laliberté, the circus’s founder, said the show would focus on Hollywood’s place in movie history. ...The Vineyard Theater, at 108 East 15th Street in Manhattan, announced a two-week extension of Julia Cho’s play “The Piano Teacher,” starring Elizabeth Franz, about a retired piano teacher who reaches out to her former students to find out why they abruptly stopped taking piano lessons years before. The play, originally to have run through Dec. 9, will now run through December 23. ... The Kohar Symphony Orchestra and Choir from Armenia will play Carnegie Hall tonight as part of a North American tour, its first. Information: koharconcert.com or (323) 469-7356.

headline: With Shows Now Dark, Visitors Improvise
text: You came to New York with dreams of Broadway theater. Now most of those productions remain dark, with no end in sight to the stagehands’ strike that has canceled performances of 27 shows, at least through Sunday. But if it’s live performance you want, hope springs eternal.

headline: Suit on Apple Options Is Dismissed
text: Apple won dismissal yesterday of a lawsuit claiming that company directors and managers, including the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, lied to shareholders about the backdating of option awards.

headline: Pioneer Lodging Chain Aims to Get Its Consistency Back
text: IN the late 1950s, I had an aunt who was widely regarded as putting on airs, and who displayed in her guest bathroom a pair of those iconic Holiday Inn towels with the big green stripes.

headline: Release Justice’s Secrets
text: MICHAEL MUKASEY has been confirmed as attorney general. But the profound moral, legal and constitutional issues raised at his Senate Judiciary Committee hearings are unresolved. Mr. Mukasey should open the door to their resolution by releasing the Justice Department’s long-secret legal opinions that have warped our fight against terrorism.

headline: U.S. Attorney in Minnesota Is Reassigned
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 — The embattled United States attorney in Minnesota announced today that she would be stepping down to go work at the Justice Department in Washington on legal policy issues.

headline: Helping Finance Documentarians
text: The Tribeca Film Institute and Gucci have joined to create the Gucci Tribeca Documentary Fund, which will offer financing and production guidance to help independent filmmakers complete documentaries that promote social change, focusing on issues neglected by the mainstream news media. The fund will provide grants totaling $80,000 to a minimum of three filmmakers in 2008 and will be administered by the Tribeca Film Institute. Recipients will be selected by the Tribeca Film Institute, along with Gucci and a selection committee of documentary filmmakers. All documentary filmmakers who have projects in production or postproduction may apply. Applications can be sent from Feb. 5 to April 11, 2008. Recipients will be announced next summer. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.

headline: Ate Too Much? Tight Pants May Be the Smallest Worry
text: This week marks the beginning of the gluttony season, the time when even the most health-conscious diner succumbs to the temptations of the holiday buffet.

headline: Freddie Mac Posts a $2 Billion Loss
text: Turmoil in the housing sector continued to reverberate today across several parts of the industry, reinforcing the mood among investors that the downturn has not yet reached its bottom.

headline: New Hampshire Sets Jan. 8 Primary
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 — The New Hampshire primary, a tradition-steeped event in American presidential politics, will be held on Tuesday, Jan. 8, the New Hampshire secretary of state, William M. Gardner, decreed this afternoon.

headline: Fed Report Trims Economic Outlook
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Policy makers at the Federal Reserve expect the economy to keep expanding over the next year, but they have lowered their forecasts and are much more uncertain about the outlook than just four months ago, the central bank reported today.

headline: Switzerland: Insurer to Sell Units
