text: Swiss Life Holding, Switzerland’s largest life insurer, agreed to sell its Dutch and Belgian units for as much as 1.54 billion euros ($2.3 billion) and said it planned to use the proceeds to buy back shares. SNS Reaal, a Dutch financial services company, is buying the units, Swiss Life said. Swiss Life shares rose as much as 5.8 percent in Zurich trading after the insurer said proceeds from the sale would be used to buy back up to 2.5 billion francs ($2.2 billion) of shares over 18 months. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: The Family Redgrave, Together Onstage
text: The siblings Vanessa, Lynn and Corin Redgrave have joined the journalists, military officials, entertainers and academics participating in “A Question of Impeachment,” a series of evenings, presented by the Culture Project, exploring the case for the impeachment of President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney. The first event in the series took place yesterday at the Culture Project theater at 55 Mercer Street in SoHo. “The Redgraves: Poems From Guantánamo,” which will take place on Dec. 9 at 7:30 p.m., includes recitations from “Guantánamo: The Detainees Speak” (University of Iowa, 2007), a collection of poems written by detainees. Marc Falkoff, a lawyer for some of the detainees and the editor of the collection, will take part in the event. For information: cultureproject.org.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,861 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Speaking Up for the Stagehands
text: The man at the center of the breakdown in the talks between the Broadway producers’ league and the striking stagehands’ union had one thing he wanted to say before the first question in an interview yesterday: It is not about him.

headline: Icahn Acquires More Shares of Blockbuster, Nudging His Stake to 16%
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has raised his stake in the Class A shares of Blockbuster, the video rental chain, to 16 percent, from 15 percent.

headline: Where ‘Never Again’ Is Happening Now
text: With every news outlet and cause-oriented celebrity having discovered Darfur by now, the very word may activate your plug-ears/cover-eyes instinct. But “On Our Watch,” tonight’s “Frontline” on PBS, isn’t just another report on that bloodstained region of Sudan. It’s more like an indictment.

headline: Congo Creates Massive Reserve to Protect Close Human Cousin
text: Congo has announced the establishment of a rain-forest preserve intended to shield the bonobo, one of human beings’ two closest ape relations, from wildlife poachers and deforestation.

headline: From Queen to Academe
text: Brian May, the guitarist in the band Queen, has been appointed chancellor of Liverpool John Moores University, The Associated Press reported. Mr. May was an astrophysics student at the university before he joined Freddie Mercury and Roger Taylor to form Queen in 1970, and was awarded his doctorate in the field this year. Liverpool John Moores University has a well-known astrophysics research institute. Mr. May will be installed in the ceremonial chancellorship early next year. He succeeds Cherie Blair, wife of former Prime Minister Tony Blair.

headline: Republican Congressman in New Jersey Will Retire
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 — Representative Mike Ferguson of New Jersey, a Republican who narrowly won re-election last year and faced the prospect of another tough race in 2008, announced on Monday that he will retire, dealing an unexpected setback to national leaders of his party.

headline: Holiday on Thursday: Thanksgiving Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: In Thanksgiving Speech, Bush Urges Americans to Give Back
text: CHARLES CITY, Va., Nov. 19 — In a reflective mood as he looks toward his final year in office, President Bush delivered his first official Thanksgiving speech Monday, urging Americans to “show their thanks by giving back” and to remember that “our nation’s greatest strength is the decency and compassion of our people.”

headline: New Haven: Police Chief to Resign
text: The New Haven police chief, Francisco Ortiz, announced yesterday that he would resign in January to take a security post at Yale University. Chief Ortiz, left, 48, a member of the force for nearly three decades and chief since 2003, had faced calls for his resignation this year after an F.B.I. sting exposed corruption in the Police Department’s narcotics division and gun violence spiked in the spring. The former chief of narcotics and two detectives pleaded guilty last month to federal charges, and an independent report released last week said the department needed an overhaul “in order to regain the public trust.” But the mayor, John DeStefano Jr., praised Chief Ortiz for helping to reduce crime by more than 40 percent over the last decade. “The city has been made a much better place,” Mr. DeStefano said.

headline: City Bows to State on a School Improvement Plan
text: After months of negotiation, the City Department of Education capitulated to state education officials on how to spend millions of dollars in new state aid by agreeing to shift more money to reduce class sizes and to spend more on low-performing schools.

headline: Disparities: With Cancer Treatment, an Edge for Rural Patients
text: It seems only natural to assume that when cancer strikes people who live in rural areas, more time will pass before it is discovered than for people in cities.

headline: Sarkozy Takes Unfamiliar Stance on Strikes: Silence
text: PARIS, Nov. 19 — President Nicolas Sarkozy has been called France’s Energizer bunny, a hyperactive head of state criticized for doing the jobs of his ministers, hogging the airwaves and refusing to rest or reflect.

headline: On the Job, Everywhere
text: One challenge of the work-anywhere lifestyle is that not everywhere is designed for people who need to do work.

headline: U.S. Prosecutors Subpoena Blackwater Employees
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 — Federal prosecutors have issued grand jury subpoenas to some of the Blackwater employees present at a Sept. 16 shooting in Baghdad in which the company’s security personnel killed 17 Iraqi civilians, lawyers in the case and government officials briefed on the matter said Monday.

headline: City Claims Final Private Island in East River
text: South Brother Island, seven acres of dense forest, bittersweet vines, flocks of wild birds and little else, is a speck in the East River — and a glimpse of what the rest of the city might have looked like thousands of years ago.

headline: Suicide Attack in Afghanistan Kills 7 but Spares Governor
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 19 — A provincial governor in southwestern Afghanistan narrowly escaped a suicide attack on Monday, but his 25-year-old son and five of his bodyguards were killed in the blast. A civilian bystander was also killed, and 14 others were wounded, the police said.

headline: Separatist Rebels Accuse Ethiopia’s Military of Killing Civilians in Remote Region
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 19  Separatist rebels fighting in the Ogaden region of Ethiopia accused the government on Monday of strafing nomads in recent days at a watering hole with helicopter gunships, killing up to a dozen civilians.

headline: Georgia: Young Boys Charged With Rape
text: Three boys, one 8-year-old and two 9-year-olds, were charged with kidnapping, rape, false imprisonment and sexual assault after an 11-year-old girl accused them of attacking her in the woods behind the apartment complex where the children live. Capt. Wayne Dennard of the Acworth Police Department north of Atlanta said the girl told officers she was playing with the boys on Thursday when they lured her into the woods and raped her. “The investigators who are working the case are confident that they have evidence to support the charges,” Captain Dennard said. But the father of one of the accused third-grade boys told The Associated Press that what happened was consensual.

headline: Clemens Finds Time to Shine During Jets’ Late Comebacks
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 19  As the seconds tick away in the fourth quarter and the Jets try to whittle another deficit, Kellen Clemens transforms from promising first-year starter into a green-and-white-clad Captain Comeback.

headline: Manhattan: Suspect Sought in Drugstore Holdups
text: The police are seeking a man who has robbed six drugstores in Manhattan in the past two months. The man, described as slightly over 6 feet tall and wearing a hooded sweatshirt, seeks out the store’s manager and starts a conversation before pulling a revolver and forcing the manager into an office, the police said. So far, the man has robbed three Duane Reade stores, a CVS, a Rite Aid and a Walgreens, the police said. The last holdup was on Nov. 15, at the Walgreens at 350 Fifth Avenue, the police said.

headline: Ian Douglas Smith, Ex-Leader of Rhodesia, Dies
text: Ian Douglas Smith, the former prime minister of the rebellious British colony of Rhodesia, who rose to power and then slipped from it again, committed all the while to an unshakable belief that Africa without whites would not work, died today. He was 88.

headline: Ear Pendants Reveal the Antiquity of Commerce in Jade
text: Jade has been prized for thousands of years, and has been traded for nearly as long. The extent of the trading has been demonstrated by Hsiao-Chun Hung of the Australian National University and colleagues in a study of jade ornaments from Southeast Asia.

headline: Queens: Man Admits Strangling Wife
text: A Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to the 2004 strangulation of his wife, whose body was found five days later in a car along with her 2-year-old daughter, prosecutors said. The man, Leonardo Almonte, 40, of 115th Avenue in Jamaica, is scheduled to be sentenced to 20 years in prison for manslaughter, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said in a statement. Prosecutors said Mr. Almonte, a bodega owner, strangled his wife, Cesarina Colon, 32, on Oct. 23, 2004, at the family home. He left her body, along with her daughter, in a vehicle he parked about a mile away, prosecutors said. A pedestrian who spotted the body called 911, and firefighters rescued the child, who was strapped into her car seat, prosecutors said.

headline: Sometimes Con Men Wear Lab Coats
text: Curing cancer would be nice, to be sure, but does it really compare to the feeling of being published in The New England Journal of Medicine, winning a Nobel Prize or sleeping with your beautiful lab assistant?

headline: Surprise Pressure From Myanmar’s Neighbors
text: SINGAPORE, Nov. 19 — An emerging rift among Asian leaders over Myanmar burst into the open at a regional summit meeting on Monday when the Philippine president suggested that her country might not ratify a new regional charter unless Myanmar committed to democratic reforms and released the pro-democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi.

headline: The Garden May Be No Place Like Home
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 19  Stephon Marbury disappeared again Monday afternoon, not because of an aversion to his coach, but because of a much stronger impulse: to avoid television cameras, microphones and notepads.

headline: Sect Leader Is Sentenced in Utah
text: ST. GEORGE, Utah, Nov. 20 —The polygamous leader of a fundamentalist Mormon sect was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years to life in prison for forcing a 14-year-old girl to “spiritually” marry her 19-year-old cousin and commanding the naïve bride to submit to sexual relations against her will.

headline: Britain: A Diamond Year for the Crown
text: About 2,000 people, including more than 30 members of the royal family, attended a service at Westminster Abbey observing the 60th wedding anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip. Dame Judi Dench read a poem, “Diamond Wedding,” by the poet laureate, Andrew Motion, and everyone sang “The Lord’s My Shepherd,” the hymn chosen by Elizabeth for her wedding. Afterward, the two greeted 10 couples who had married on the same day, Nov. 20, 1947.

headline: Baghdad’s Weary Start to Exhale as Security Improves
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 19 — Five months ago, Suhaila al-Aasan lived in an oxygen tank factory with her husband and two sons, convinced that they would never go back to their apartment in Dora, a middle-class neighborhood in southern Baghdad.

headline: Amazon Reading Device Doesn’t Need Computer
text: Jeff Bezos knows that the world is not exactly clamoring for another way to read electronic books.

headline: Power to Soothe the Savage Breast and Animate the Hemispheres
text: In books like “The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat” and “An Anthropologist on Mars,” the physician Oliver Sacks has given us some compelling and deeply moving portraits of patients in predicaments so odd, so vexing, so metaphysically curious that they read like something out of a tale by Borges or Calvino.

headline: Dick Wilson, Squeezer of Tissue Rolls on Television, Dies at 91
text: Dick Wilson, a British-born character actor who won American television fame as Mr. Whipple, the comically fussy star of two decades of Charmin toilet paper commercials, died on Monday at the Motion Picture & Television Fund Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 91 and had lived at the organization’s residence in Woodland Hills since 2002.

headline: Panel Picks 4 Debate Sites, Angering Excluded New Orleans
text: The Commission on Presidential Debates has picked Oxford, Miss.; St. Louis; Nashville; and Hempstead, N.Y., as the sites of the presidential and vice-presidential debates in the general election campaign next year.

headline: New Bribery Allegation Roils Samsung
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 19 — Samsung, which has vigorously denied bribery charges in a snowballing corruption scandal, sustained another blow to its image on Monday when a former legal adviser to President Roh Moo-hyun said the company had once offered him a cash bribe.

headline: In Iowa, Democrats Focus on Economy and Experience
text: KNOXVILLE, Iowa, Nov. 19 — Gloomy news about the economy formed a backdrop for the leading Democratic presidential candidates Monday as they intensified their fight over which one had the best experience to lead the nation.

headline: James Joseph Claffey Jr.
text: BORN: Jan. 24, 1964, in New York.

headline: Halting Steps Taken to Frame Mideast Talks
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 19 — Israeli and Palestinian leaders made new efforts on Monday toward preparing a joint statement before an international peace gathering planned for next week, but some issues have yet to be resolved, Israeli and Palestinian officials said.

headline: Democrats and White House Continue Feud Over Money for Iraq War
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — House Democrats and the White House continued their public relations battle over money for the Iraq war today, as two leading lawmakers accused the administration of trying to scare people for political gain.

headline: 43 in Contractor’s Convoy Held After Baghdad Shooting
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 19  The Iraqi military detained 43 people in a convoy for a contractor with the United States military on Monday after the shooting of an 18-year-old woman in central Baghdad, the military said.

headline: Surge in Wages on Wall Street in First Quarter Helps Borough
text: On Wall Street, the first quarter of 2007 may wind up as one of those periods, like the height of the dot-com bubble in early 2000, that is remembered wistfully for years.

headline: Swiss Re Takes $1 Billion Write-Down
text: LONDON, Nov. 19 — Swiss Reinsurance, the world’s biggest reinsurer, said Monday that it had taken a $1.07 billion write-down on the value of some derivatives backed by mortgage securities.

headline: Once Again, Islanders Handle the Rangers
text: For everything the Rangers have done right in climbing to the top of the Atlantic Division this season, they seem at a loss when they play the Islanders.

headline: Webisodes of ‘Lost’: Model Deal for Writers?
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 — On the picket lines, striking television and film writers adamantly claim that studios are refusing to pay for the use of writers’ scripts on the Internet.

headline: Pay Me for My Content
text: INTERNET idealists like me have long had an easy answer for creative types — like the striking screenwriters in Hollywood — who feel threatened by the unremunerative nature of our new Eden: stop whining and figure out how to join the party!

headline: To Resolve Strike, Mayor Prefers a Backstage Role
text: To some, the situation seems dire: most of Broadway staying dark as the bustling holiday season begins, restaurants losing customers at a critical money-making time and the striking stagehands trudging picket lines in the bitter cold.

headline: A New Science, at First Blush
text: GRASSE, France — The delicate hybrids thriving in the balmy climes of Provence, southern France’s traditional perfume region, include sweet jasmine, May roses — and fresh layers of artificial human skin.

headline: Japan: Olympus Plans to Expand
text: The Olympus Corporation, a maker of cameras and other optical products, agreed to buy the Gyrus Group of Britain, a maker of surgical tools, for about £935 million ($1.9 billion) to gain tools that allow quicker and less painful surgical procedures. Olympus bid 630 pence a share, a premium of 58 percent to Gyrus’s closing price Friday. The acquisition gives Olympus surgical devices that will help it expand in the United States, a market that accounted for about 80 percent of Gyrus’s £213 million in sales last year. Olympus is based in Tokyo. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: Are Scientists Playing God? It Depends on Your Religion
text: Now that biologists in Oregon have reported using cloning to produce a monkey embryo and extract stem cells, it looks more plausible than before that a human embryo will be cloned and that, some day, a cloned human will be born. But not necessarily on this side of the Pacific.

headline: Options Narrowing as Britain Tries to Stabilize Bank
text: LONDON, Nov. 19 — Northern Rock, the troubled regional mortgage lender, said on Monday that it had received a number of disappointing takeover proposals, increasing the pressure on the British government to either find a solution or consider nationalizing the bank.

headline: Europe Warns Kosovo on Separation
text: European Union foreign ministers warned Kosovo against unilaterally declaring its independence, cautioning that such a move could spur the Serbian minority to ally with Belgrade and the Serb half of Bosnia and Herzegovina to push for statehood. The warning came after Hashim Thaci, whose party claimed victory in Saturday’s parliamentary elections, said Kosovo would declare independence after a Dec. 10 deadline. Jean Asselborn, foreign minister of Luxembourg, warned: “There’s a certain explosiveness in this region.”

headline: On Broadway, Growing Gloom About the Holidays
text: After strike talks between the Broadway producers’ league and the stagehands union unexpectedly broke down on Sunday night, the quick return to work that many had expected just hours earlier turned today into a gloomy prospect of absent paychecks and huge losses during the lucrative holiday season.

headline: Ex-Getty Curator Is Now on Trial in Greece
text: A former antiquities curator for the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles went on trial yesterday in Athens on charges of conspiring to acquire an ancient gold funerary wreath that Greek officials say was illegally removed from Greek soil about 15 years ago. The former curator, Marion True, did not attend the hearing. Her lawyer, Yannis Yannides, submitted a motion for dismissal, citing a California state law that sets a three-year statute of limitations for prosecution once a stolen artifact’s whereabouts have been made known. (The Getty acquired the wreath in 1993 and agreed to return it nearly a year ago, citing concerns about its provenance.) Greek investigators assert that the gold wreath was illegally excavated from an archaeological site in the northern province of Macedonia. Ms. True is also on trial in Italy on charges of trafficking in stolen antiquities acquired for the Getty. She has denied wrongdoing in both cases. In a related development The Associated Press reported that a judge in Pesaro, Italy, yesterday dismissed a local prosecutor’s legal claim to a bronze statue of a youth that is in the Getty’s collection. (The statue has also been claimed by Italy’s national government.) After long negotiations, the museum agreed in August to return 40 other artifacts to Italy. Italy said it would consider whether to press its case on the bronze after the case in Pesaro was resolved.

headline: For Children of Norway, a Rift With the Mother Country
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Around a table at Ingebretsen’s, an 86-year-old market stocked with Norwegian staples like lutefisk, meatballs and fruit soup, the women of the Monday knitting club were upset.

headline: New DVDs
text: SUSAN HAYWARD

headline: Vatican: Pope Lashes Out on Abortion
text: Pope Benedict XVI accused international agencies of promoting abortion in Africa and blamed “disordered notions” of marriage and the family for the spread of sexually transmitted diseases there. “The globalized secular culture is exerting an increasing influence on local communities as a result of campaigns by agencies promoting abortion,” he told a visiting group of bishops from Kenya. While Benedict did not single out particular agencies, the Vatican has in the past criticized the human rights group Amnesty International for backing a woman’s right to an abortion in the event of rape or if her life was in danger.

headline: Mary Walker Phillips, 83, Knitter of Art, Is Dead
text: Mary Walker Phillips, a prominent textile artist who took the utilitarian craft of knitting and gave it bold new life as a modern art form to be displayed on the walls of museums around the world, died on Nov. 3 at her home in Fresno, Calif. She was 83. A longtime resident of Greenwich Village, Miss Phillips had lived Fresno in recent years.

headline: As Somali Crisis Swells, Experts See a Void in Aid
text: AFGOOYE, Somalia, Nov. 19 — The worst humanitarian crisis in Africa may not be unfolding in Darfur, but here, along a 20-mile strip of busted-up asphalt, several top United Nations officials said.

headline: Even a Trump Can Trigger an Alarm
text: I’VE been traveling my entire life. With parents like mine, I’m sure that’s no surprise. I was in Central Europe, the south of France and the Amalfi coast all before I was 6 years old.

headline: The Lure of Togetherness ( 2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Starting a Small Business? A Retired Executive Wants to Help
text: The saying that nothing good in life is free may be true most of the time. But Martin R. Lehman’s little office in Manhattan is one of the exceptions.

headline: A New Condom for Women
text: To the Editor:

headline: Exploring the Elements of (Human) Nature
text: Science tells stories that help us negotiate the world around us; the stories change with our needs. Euclid works for carpenters but not astrophysicists. The fact that one story — the theory of the four elements and their corresponding four temperaments in human life — endured for 2,000 years is a triumph of wishful thinking over cold evidence.

headline: Denial Makes the World Go Round
text: For years she hid the credit card bills from her husband: The $2,500 embroidered coat from Neiman Marcus. The $900 beaded scarf from Blake in Chicago. A $600 pair of Dries van Noten boots. All beautiful items, and all perfectly affordable if she had been a hedge fund manager or a Google executive.

headline: Vick Begins Serving Time Ahead of Sentencing
text: In an apparent attempt to speed his return to football, Michael Vick began serving time in prison yesterday, more than three weeks before he is scheduled to be sentenced after pleading guilty to federal dogfighting charges.

headline: Many Treatments Can Ease Chronic Pain
text: There is one undeniable fact about chronic pain: More often than not, it is untreated or undertreated. In a survey last year by the American Pain Society, only 55 percent of all patients with noncancer-related pain and fewer than 40 percent with severe pain said their pain was under control.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,257,285.28

headline: On Broadway, Growing Gloom About the Holidays
text: After strike talks between the Broadway producers’ league and the stagehands’ union unexpectedly broke down on Sunday night, the quick return to work that many had expected just hours earlier turned into a gloomy prospect of absent paychecks and huge losses during the lucrative holiday season.

headline: Brooklyn: Action Filed Over School Admissions
text: A public-interest law firm in Washington filed a class-action lawsuit against the New York City Education Department yesterday, charging that a program created to increase the number of black and Hispanic students in the city’s elite specialized high schools violates the Constitution by excluding whites and Asians. The law firm, the Center for Individual Rights, filed the suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on behalf of three Chinese-American parents whose children were denied admission to the Specialized High School Institute, which prepares students for the test determining admission to schools like Stuyvesant and the Bronx High School of Science. Andrew Jacob, a spokesman for the Education Department, said it was “reviewing the program’s eligibility criteria” in light of a June decision by the Supreme Court that struck down two race-based school integration programs. Since the institute’s creation more than a decade ago, the proportion of black and Hispanic students at the city’s most elite high schools has actually decreased; last year, 2.2 percent of Stuyvesant students were black.

headline: A Subway for 2nd Avenue (Really)
text: The Second Avenue Subway seems like the stuff of urban legend. City and state officials have been promising since the 1920s to build another line on Manhattan’s East Side to relieve overcrowding on the Lexington Avenue line. They have already presided over four groundbreakings. These promises look as if they could finally come true now that the federal government is adding $1.3 billion to the effort.

headline: Morality and the Death Penalty
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Health System’s ‘Miracles’ Come With Hidden Costs
text: HAVANA, Nov. 16 — A shiny new tour bus pulled up to the top eye hospital in Cuba on a sunny day this month and disgorged 47 working-class people from El Salvador, many of whom could barely see because they had thick cataracts in their eyes.

headline: Imitation Hits the Marketing Business. Again.
text: THEY say that imitation is the sincerest form of advertising, and once again a skein of look-alike, sound-alike, seem-alike campaigns is raising eyebrows along Madison Avenue.

headline: Allies Shun Berlusconi’s New Party
text: ROME, Nov. 19  With his customary brio, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi is forming a new political party to propel him back to power, vowing Monday to go forward without his allies on the center-right, who are growing exhausted with him.

headline: Through Genetics, Tapping a Tree’s Potential as a Source of Energy
text: It might be true that “only God can make a tree,” as the poet Joyce Kilmer wrote. But genetic engineers can fundamentally redesign them.

headline: Freed From Debt, a Hair Stylist Looks to a Brighter Future
text: The Jolie Femme hair salon is carved out of a barbershop in Harlem. Past the black combs soaking in blue Barbicide and the buzzing clippers, Aurea Casellas, 33, tends to her clients. She twists women’s hair into up-dos, or irons spiral locks pin-straight. Her specialty, however, is weaves.

headline: Employees at CBS News Vote to Authorize a Strike
text: Several hundred CBS News employees represented by the Writers Guild of America have voted to authorize a strike against the company, union officials said yesterday.

headline: Katrina’s Damage to Trees May Alter Carbon Balance
text: The world knows the kind of destruction that Hurricane Katrina brought to New Orleans and other cities and towns on the Gulf Coast.

headline: Health Care, Denied
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Hazy Future for a ‘Jewel’ of Space Instruments
text: The next time an unexpected comet shows up in the inner solar system, Amy J. Lovell may not get time at the Arecibo radio telescope in Puerto Rico to observe it before it swings back out.

headline: Pride and Nostalgia Mix in The Times’s New Home
text: Writing about your employer’s new building is a tricky task. If I love it, the reader will suspect that I’m currying favor with the man who signs my checks. If I hate it, I’m just flaunting my independence.

headline: Guns and Random Death: Be Careful Out There
text: The bullets were meant for him, but Andre Santana ducked in time. Or maybe the gunmen were just lousy shots. Whatever, he lived and a woman died, having committed the sole crime of walking along the wrong street at the wrong time.

headline: As Carr Reflects, Michigan Starts to Move On
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 19 — Lloyd Carr announced Monday that he was retiring as Michigan’s football coach, a move that opens one of the premier jobs in college football and ends the career of one of the game’s top coaches.

headline: U.S. Withdraws Approval for Tyson’s Antibiotic-Free Label
text: Tyson Foods was widely hailed in June when it announced that it would produce all of its branded fresh chicken from birds raised without antibiotics. The company, hoping to cash in on consumer demand for more natural products, said it would promote the antibiotic-free birds as part of a $70 million advertising campaign.

headline: As Nascar Changes, Johnson Seeks the Same Success
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 18 — The cloud of smoke from Jimmie Johnson’s celebratory burnout at the Homestead-Miami Speedway finish line had not yet cleared Sunday night when his intense crew chief, Chad Knaus, started talking about 2008.

headline: A Reprieve on Foreclosures
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Scientists Speak
text: The world’s scientists have done their job. Now it’s time for world leaders, starting with President Bush, to do theirs. That is the urgent message at the core of the latest — and the most powerful — report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of 2,500 scientists who collectively constitute the world’s most authoritative voice on global warming.

headline: Helping Documentarians
text: The Tribeca Film Institute and Gucci have joined to create the Gucci Tribeca Documentary Fund, which will offer financing and production guidance to help independent filmmakers complete documentaries that promote social change, focusing on issues neglected by the mainstream news media. The fund will provide grants totaling $80,000 to a minimum of three filmmakers in 2008 and will be administered by the Tribeca Film Institute. Recipients will be selected by the Tribeca Film Institute, along with Gucci and a selection committee of documentary filmmakers. All documentary filmmakers who have projects in production or postproduction may apply. Applications can be sent from Feb. 5 to April 11, 2008. Recipients will be announced next summer. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.

headline: Known for Delays, Denver Shows Dispatch
text: DENVER, Nov. 21 — The light snow that dusted the city early today was far less than the crippling blizzard that closed Denver International Airport for nearly two days just before last Christmas. Lines at the airport’s security checkpoints, which set national records between September 2006 and October 2007, moved briskly, which had travelers and airport officials smiling.

headline: The Power of Suggestion (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Amid Turmoil, U.S. Attorney Will Shift to Headquarters
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 — The embattled United States attorney in Minnesota announced on Monday that she would step down to go to work at the Justice Department in Washington on legal policies.

headline: Smithsonian Is Planning a Big Fund-Raising Push
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The Smithsonian Institution’s Board of Regents voted Monday to undertake a major capital campaign to help raise the $2.5 billion needed to improve and repair its buildings. It is the first large-scale private fund-raising effort in the organization’s history.

headline: Victor Rabinowitz, 96, Leftist Lawyer, Dies
text: Victor Rabinowitz, a leftist lawyer whose causes and clients over nearly three-quarters of a century ranged from labor unions to Black Panthers to Cuba to Dashiell Hammett to Dr. Benjamin Spock to his own daughter, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.

headline: Pocket Change for Pockets Already Full
text: Oh what a relief it is. No one has to buy Alex Rodriguez lunch today. Even better, no one has to buy dinner for him and his family tonight. He’s got it covered.

headline: Whites Take a Majority on New Orleans’s Council
text: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 19 — In one of the clearest signs yet of Hurricane Katrina’s lasting demographic impact, the City Council is about to have a white majority for the first time in over two decades, pointing up again the storm’s displacement of thousands of residents, mostly black.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Sunday about Jeff Novitzky, a special agent for the I.R.S. who is the government’s leading investigator of doping in sports, misstated the name of a performance-enhancing drug and referred imprecisely to one of Mr. Novitzky’s high school athletic accomplishments. The drug is erythropoietin, a blood-boosting hormone; there is no steroid known as eritropotin. Although Mr. Novitzky indeed cleared 7 feet in the high jump, he did not set a state record. (Go to Article)

headline: Memo Pad
text: THANKSGIVING TRAVEL With gasoline prices averaging well over $3 a gallon nationally, the overall number of Americans traveling during the Thanksgiving holiday season will rise by a slight 1.5 percent this year, the automobile and travel association AAA says. “A year ago, prices were in the range of $2.20 a gallon, so this year travelers are really feeling the pinch,” Robert L. Darbelnet, the group’s president, said in a statement. (AAA has a state-by-state gasoline cost and fuel-mileage calculator at www.fuelcostcalculator.com.) While other surveys show that rates at luxury and big city hotels are up, there is some good news. Rates at midlevel hotels with AAA Three-Diamond ratings are down 3 percent from last year. THE BRITISH ARE NOT COMING Although the weak dollar compared with the pound makes travel in the United States a bargain for Britons, British leisure and business travel to the United States is down by 11 percent since 2000, says the Discover America Partnership, a travel industry group. It cited Commerce Department figures. Without the lure of the exchange rate, “the persistent decline in British travelers would be even worse,” the group says. It blames time-consuming and sometimes rude Customs and Immigration procedures at airports and a poor image of the United States abroad for an overall 17 percent decline in overseas travel to the United States since late 2001.

headline: Spitzer Calls for M.T.A. to Keep Base Fare at $2
text: New York State Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced today that he was calling on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to throw out a controversial proposal to raise subway and bus fares and to keep the base fare at $2 per ride.

headline: Glimpses of Life in a City Yearning for Normalcy
text: THE happy couples announced their unions with the blare of car horns, bursting from freshly washed sedans draped with garlands of sunshine-yellow flowers. A wedding!

headline: U.N. to Say It Overstated H.I.V. Cases by Millions
text: The United Nations’ AIDS-fighting agency plans to issue a report today acknowledging that it overestimated the size of the epidemic and that new infections with the deadly virus have been dropping each year since they peaked in the late 1990s.

headline: Giants Assess Damage and Have Holes to Fill
text: The Giants are 7-3 after a satisfying but far from artistic victory over the Detroit Lions, but Coach Tom Coughlin has concerns. Linebacker Mathias Kiwanuka has a broken left leg and is out for the season, and the fleet of running backs is no longer deep.

headline: Glavine Will End Career on Own Terms in Atlanta
text: No one on the Atlanta Braves has worn No. 47 since 2002, out of respect for the man who wore it last. That man, Tom Glavine, will wear it again next season after what had been apparent all along became official yesterday.

headline: Dirty, Sexy and Sold
text: “Dirty Sexy Money,” the freshman drama on ABC, has been picked up for a second season, and Lolita Davidovich, above, has joined the cast in the recurring role of a hospital administrator who is a potential love interest for the character played by Donald Sutherland, Reuters reported. The show is the first on any network to be picked up since the start of the writers’ walkout.

headline: Fighting Gridlock Where Minutes Can Mean Life or Death
text: “Fuat! We’ve run out of stretchers!”

headline: Manhattan: Principal of Arabic School Sues City
text: The founding principal of the city’s first Arabic-language school has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court against the city’s Education Department, Chancellor Joel I. Klein and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, claiming that they violated her right to free speech and “conspired to deny her the opportunity to regain her position as principal” of the Khalil Gibran International Academy, in Brooklyn. The principal, Debbie Almontaser, resigned under pressure this summer, following a furor that erupted after she was quoted in The New York Post defending the use of the word “intifada” on a T-shirt sold by a Brooklyn-based organization of Arab women. Last month, Ms. Almontaser said she was a victim of a smear campaign by conservatives and would apply to get her job back. But Education Department officials said they would not consider her application among the 25 others that were submitted at the time.

headline: The Segmented Society
text: On Feb. 9, 1964, the Beatles played on “The Ed Sullivan Show.” Or as Steven Van Zandt remembers the moment: “It was the beginning of my life.”

headline: Another Very Scary Germ
text: The bacterial infection that killed a Brooklyn middle school student, panicked many parents and sent school officials in many states into a frenzy of cleaning and disinfecting is only the latest manifestation of a very dangerous problem: the development of bacterial strains that are resistant to many antibiotics. It is a problem that needs to be tackled broadly, not just in a hasty reaction to the recent incidents.

headline: Gun Dealer’s Lawsuit Moves Ahead
text: A South Carolina judge has ruled that a lawsuit against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York City over tactics used against out-of-state gun dealers can go ahead. Roger M. Young, a State Circuit Court judge in Berkeley County, found against the city’s motion to dismiss the 2006 lawsuit, brought by the Mickalis Pawn Shop of Summerville, S.C., according to papers filed yesterday. The suit was filed in response to city lawsuits against gun dealers in Georgia, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Virginia alleging that improper sales practices had led to a large number of guns ending up in criminals’ hands in New York. Some of the dealers settled the suits and agreed to work with a court-appointed monitor, but the owner of the Summerville shop, Larry Mickalis, countersued, accusing Mr. Bloomberg and the city of conspiracy, fraud and libel, among other charges.

headline: Decline of the Tenure Track Raises Concerns
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Professors with tenure or who are on a tenure track are now a distinct minority on the country’s campuses, as the ranks of part-time instructors and professors hired on a contract have swelled, according to federal figures analyzed by the American Association of University Professors.

headline: Rodriguez Is M.V.P.; Rivera Says He’ll Re-Sign
text: When it seemed as if Alex Rodriguez would become an ex-Yankee, and he was seeking counsel from all manner of friends and tycoons, Mariano Rivera was a voice of reason. Rivera spoke regularly to Rodriguez, urging him to broker a peace with the Yankees and show them that he wanted to return despite opting out of his contract.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Addiction: Lowering Nicotine Levels May Help Cut Smoking
text: Smokers who were given nicotine-reduced cigarettes for five weeks and then allowed to return to their regular brands ended up smoking less, according to the authors of a small study.

headline: As U.S. Cools, World Demand Helps H.P. Outpace Rivals
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 — Buoyed by its heavy international presence, Hewlett-Packard appears to have sidestepped the softening demand from corporations inside the United States for new technology.

headline: Looking Ahead After a Frightening Day
text: A vacation in Italy was about to come to an appropriate end, a trip to a soccer game between Roma and Cagliari. Leslie Osborne, Heather O’Reilly and Lindsay Tarpley, members of the United States women’s national team, were on a bus, and Rome’s Olympic Stadium was in view.

headline: Is Gorbachev Cashing in? Give an Icon His Due
text: To the Editor:

headline: Aging: Walking Faster and Outpacing Death
text: Researchers who followed the health of nearly 500 older people for almost a decade found that those who walked more quickly were less likely to die over the course of the study.

headline: Rescuing Newspapers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ministering to Chaos Abroad, Echoing at Home
text: The Huey lands gracefully, a butterfly alighting on a rose, its high mast and tail rotor making a wind that turns pages and reinvigorates the dust. I have to grab my cap.

headline: The Claim: White Meat Is Healthier Than Dark Meat
text: THE FACTS

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Gun Control Case
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — The Supreme Court announced today that it would l decide whether the Constitution grants individuals the right to keep guns in their homes for private use, plunging the justices headlong into a divisive and long-running debate over how to interpret the Second Amendment’s guarantee of the “right of the people to keep and bear arms.”

headline: Twins on a Medical Odyssey After a Diagnosis of Diabetes
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y.  — On Oct. 3, 2005, the eve of Rosh Hashana, Ali and Marissa Newman and their parents, Stacey and Rick, drove from their home here to Long Island to have dinner with cousins. It was supposed to be a pleasant holiday, a time to be with family and to celebrate the Jewish New Year in temple.

headline: At Jets Game, a Halftime Ritual of Harassment
text: At halftime of the Jets’ home game against the Pittsburgh Steelers on Sunday, several hundred men lined one of Giants Stadium’s two pedestrian ramps at Gate D. Three deep in some areas, they whistled and jumped up and down. Then they began an obscenity-laced chant, demanding that the few women in the gathering expose their breasts.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in the special Giving section on Nov. 12 about young philanthropists misstated the name of an organization that Jonathan Holmes, a 27-year-old who was asked to run his family’s foundation, went to for support. It is the Association of Small Foundations, not the Association for Small Foundations.

headline: Hepatitis Found Again Among Doctor’s Patients
text: Nassau County health officials yesterday reported another positive test for hepatitis among the patients of an anesthesiologist on Long Island whose faulty infection-control practices put hundreds of people at risk.

headline: Home, or Not, for the Holiday
text: Most years, it might appear unseemly to mix presidential politics with Thanksgiving. But rules of political etiquette may not apply this year, considering the holiday falls six weeks before voting begins.

headline: Ron Paul’s Tight-fisted Campaign
text: Voters looking for a candidate who will be tight with their money might have found their man in Ron Paul, if campaign spending is any indication. At the moment, Mr. Paul, a Texas congressman who is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, is rolling in cash. He already had raised $5 million this year when a one-day Internet drive tied to Guy Fawkes Day on Nov. 5 brought in another $4 million.

headline: Intipa Awachan? Helia? Phaethon? Fred?  The Solar-Twin Naming Contest Flares Up
text: The grand prize — your very own copy of “Bullfinch’s Mythology” — is still up for grabs, but we’ve had some promising names and myths nominated for the newly discovered twin of the Sun. (You can read about the contest and see some nominations here.)

headline: A Statistical Tie in Iowa
text: It is increasingly evident that Iowa is not going to be as easy terrain for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as her campaign had hoped. Mrs. Clinton and Senator Barack Obama are in a tough fight in that state, as a Washington Post/ABC News poll of Iowa Democrats released yesterday seems to show.

headline: Paris strike comfort food: hot chocolate and pastries
text: As the Paris transportation strike lingers into its seventh day along with a general walkout, I think it’s fair to say that French residents and tourists deserve comfort food for coping with the perils of crowded platforms and mobbed metros.

headline: Love, the Universal Language?
text: It’s a match made in Babel when a translation Web site gets involved:

headline: Icahn Nudges Blockbuster Stake to 16%
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has raised his stake in the Class A shares of Blockbuster, the video rental chain, to 16 percent, from 15 percent.

headline: Suit on Apple Options Is Dismissed
text: Apple won dismissal Monday of a lawsuit claiming that company directors and managers, including the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, lied to shareholders about the backdating of option awards.

headline: Before Stockpickr.com, a Hedge Fund Deal Not Done
text: In a mini-profile of a hedge fund manager, James Altucher, and his investment Web site Stockpickr.com, BusinessWeek reports that Mr. Altucher eschewed a tantalizing offer from a large hedge fund to bring his investment strategy — and that of Warren E. Buffet and George Soros — to the masses.

headline: Madison Dearborn Chief Steps Down
text: John Canning, the chief executive of Madison Dearborn Partners, a private equity firm in Chicago, has stepped down as the company begins a $10 billion fundraising drive.

headline: Calpine Chief Gets $10.9 Million Stock Incentive
text: Calpine‘s chief executive, Robert May, can expect a $10.9 million stock incentive for guiding the struggling San Jose-based power producer out of the largest United States bankruptcy of 2005, according to papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York.

headline: What About the Strategy?
text: Let’s set aside the appropriateness of going for it on fourth down — and keeping the starters in — with a gigantic lead in the second half.Patriots fans have made their point. For those interested in revisiting that issue, see the post below. (Bill Belichick as an Ayn Rand disciple — only in The New York Times).

headline: Applied Materials Scoops Up Baccini
text: A semiconductor equipment maker, Applied Materials, said Monday it was purchasing  Baccini, a supplier of automated metalization and test systems for making solar systems, for about 225 million euros ($330 million).

headline: Former Countrywide Executives Sentenced to 3 Years Probation
text: Three former executives of Countrywide Financial who pleaded guilty to criminal insider trading charges were sentenced Monday to serve three years’ probation, the United States attorney’s office said.

headline: Russian Energy Concern Files Suit Against Abramovich
text: An affiliate of Sibir Energy is seeking what could be billions of dollars in damages in a lawsuit in London against the billionaire Roman Abramovich and his investment company, Millhouse Capital, saying that it was cheated out of its Russian assets.

headline: Hedge Fund Co-Founder Enters Guilty Plea
text: Portus Alternative Asset Management‘s co-founder, Michael Mendelson, was sentenced Monday to two years in prison after pleading guilty to fraud related to the collapse of the company, a Canadian hedge-fund firm, in 2005.

headline: Looking for Diamonds in Rough Times for Financial Stocks
text: It has been a rough few months for America’s vaunted financial institutions, which are under siege. Shares of many Wall Street bank and Wall Street investment houses have taken a beating amid losses related to the mortgage market meltdown and the abrupt exits of several chief executives.

headline: China Railway Said to Seek $5.5 Billion in I.P.O.’s
text: The China Railway Group, a construction contractor, plans to raise up to $5.5 billion from its Hong Kong and Shanghai initial public offerings amid booming railway investment in China, Reuters reported.

headline: Facebook Denies Talks for China Deal
text: Facebook is denying a report that it is chasing a Chinese social network, Zhanzuo.com.

headline: SAP May Sell Unit as Senior Managers Resign
text: The software maker SAP said Monday that it might sell its TomorrowNow business following an announcement that senior managers at the unit, which has embroiled the company in a legal dispute with a rival, Oracle, had resigned.

headline: Hudson Capital Said to Deal for Former Warner Studio
text: A Los Angeles investment firm, Hudson Capital, has a preliminary agreement to buy a former Warner Brothers studio that is now home to station KTLA-TV Channel 5, according to The Los Angeles Times.

headline: S.E.C.’s Cases Grow, but Fines Shrink
text: Sanctions imposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission fell this year to the lowest level since 2002, after Republican commissioners complained that heavy penalties hurt investors and the agency brought fewer billion-dollar accounting fraud cases.

headline: Wall Street’s 1st-Quarter Surge Lifted Manhattan Wages
text: On Wall Street, the first quarter of 2007 may wind up as one of those periods, like the height of the dot-com bubble in early 2000, that is remembered wistfully for years.

headline: New Buyout-Loan Chill Hitting Chrysler?
text: Is demand for buyout-related debt drying up again? That question was raised late Monday by reports that the planned sale of $4 billion in loans tied to Cerberus Capital Management‘s acquisition of Chrysler will likely be postponed amid weak demand.

headline: Hedge Fund Counter-Sues Fairfax Financial
text: A hedge fund has filed a counter-claim against an insurer, Fairfax Financial Holdings, and its law firm for defamation and using private investigators to harass its employees.

headline: Rio Tinto May Offer BHP an Alliance, Report Says
text: Rio Tinto is considering offering joint ventures with BHP Billiton as an alternative to BHP’s proposed $140 billion takeover, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Travel Basics: Moscow
text: by Sophia Kishkovsky

headline: Clinton Confronts ‘Polarizing’ Issue
text: TAMA, Iowa – On one of the most provocative political questions of the day – is Hillary Rodham Clinton too polarizing to be president? – Mrs. Clinton delivered a punchy and pointed rejoinder at a town meeting last night, using some of her most memorable language in a recent string of campaign stops in Iowa.

headline: Blowtorch Sparks Up $50 Million Round
text: Blowtorch Entertainment has raised $50 million in first-round funding for its plans to create a digital media company that distributes its content through all the channels used by the coveted demographic of always-connected young adults.

headline: Edith Wharton Letter
text: A newly revealed letter from Edith Wharton sheds light on the ending of "The House of Mirth."

headline: In Blast from the Past, Flowers Leads $1.8 Billion Shinsei Bid
text: J. Christopher Flowers just can’t seem to get enough of Shinsei Bank.

headline: A Poem Called ‘Spell Checker’
text: Looks like Keats can rest easy. A bit of verse found here:

headline: Sears May Make Rival Bid for Restoration Hardware
text: Sears Holdings, the parent of retailers Sears and Kmart and run by Edward S. Lampert, has bought a 13.9 percent stake in Restoration Hardware and is considering a possible takeover, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Monday.

headline: Vintage shopping in Berlin
text: By Natasha Montrose

headline: King Tut Does London — Again
text: O2 (at night) now hosts King Tut by photo by colin philip

headline: UBS Asks Judge to Let It Out of Genesco Deal
text: Genesco, the shoe retailer seeking to be bought by Finish Line, fell the most in five years after UBS asked a judge to let it out of an agreement to finance the $1.5 billion acquisition.

headline: Will Buyout Targets Bid Adieu to Break-Up Fees?
text: The legal fight between United Rentals, the rental equipment provider, and Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that is trying to cancel its $4 billion buyout of the company, has Breakingviews wondering if these “reverse” break-up fees, which allow buyers to walk away from a deal freely for a nominal sum, might become a thing of the past.

headline: Candover Buys Alama Consulting From Apax
text: A London buyout shop Candover, announced an agreement Monday to buy the Alma Consulting Group, a French tax recovery and cost reduction services company, from a private equity firm in Paris, Apax Partners, an independently managed member of the Apax Group, and Chequers Capital, a private equity firm also in Paris.

headline: Done Anything for Your Brand Lately?
text: There’s been a lot of talk about personal branding lately. A few weeks ago, I heard Catherine Kaputa, author of U R a Brand, speak at a conference. She told a story about a book with a great idea that achieved only modest sales. But then it was repackaged with some attention paid to branding and went on to captivate dieters around the country. The book’s original title was The Moderate Carbohydrate Diet. The book’s modified title? The South Beach Diet. Ms. Kaputa’s book is about how to apply this kind of thinking to ourselves.

headline: Still More of Your ‘Late Night’ Jokes
text: Readers continue to prove that even with late-night comedy writers on strike, there’s no shortage of shtick out there (send your jokes via the comment link below). Here are some from Alan Ray of Stockton, Calif., who runs a daily comedy service for radio shows, newspapers, and comedians:

headline: Options to Stabilize Northern Rock Are Narrowing
text: As Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, confirmed that it had received a number of disappointing takeover proposals, The New York Times says that the British government is under increasing pressure to either find a solution or consider nationalizing the bank.

headline: Freddie Mac May Seek Capital After Big Loss
text: Freddie Mac, the No. 2 guarantor of home mortgages in the United States, reported a much bigger-than-expected $2 billion loss for the third quarter and said Tuesday it had hired Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers to help it consider “very near-term capital raising alternatives.”

headline: Gloom Mounts on Broadway as Strike Goes On
text: The stagehands’ strike is costing the city’s economy millions of dollars each day and is especially painful this week, one of the busiest of the year. Campbell Robertson, who covers Broadway for The Times, reports that the big shock came on Sunday night, when the league of theater producers and owners and the union suddenly broke off talks, after spending the weekend trying to end the strike. The sticking point in the talks has been the league’s desire for looser work rules for members of the union.

headline: The Early Word: Polls, Policy and Politics
text: With the latest Washington Post-ABC News poll showing a tight race between Democratic candidates Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton in Iowa, The Times’s Adam Nagourney points out that nothing can be taken for granted in the Hawkeye State.

headline: Radiohead Frontman Pays Nothing for His Album
text: Rock fans and the music industry have watched with great interest as Radiohead offered downloads of its latest album, “In Rainbows,” to the world at the vaguest of price points. Allowed to pay whatever they wanted, how many would jump at the chance to pay zero?

headline: Spitzer Directs M.T.A. to Keep Base Subway and Bus Fare at $2
text: Updated, 4:13 p.m. | Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced this morning that he was directing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to scale back its plan to increase subway and bus fares, holding the base fare at $2 per ride. His plan would still allow the authority to increase some fares, including the cost of the 7-day and 30-day unlimited-ride MetroCards and fares on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad.

headline: Much Ado About Huckabee
text: Huckabacklash: Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor who is in second place in Iowa right now according to many polls, is doing well enough that it’s time for opinion writers to find fault with him. The Washington Post’s Richard Cohen, for example, says that he finds Huckabee’s religiosity more worrisome than Mitt Romney’s Mormonism. Cohen writes:

headline: Will H&R Block’s Shake-Up Lead to Break-Up?
text: Score another point for Richard Breeden, the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman turned activist investor. Two months after winning seats on the board of H&R Block, Mr. Breeden was named chairman of the tax-preparation company on Tuesday, filling a post created by the abrupt resignation of Mark Ernst.

headline: New Clinton Ad: ‘Machine’
text: In a new television ad running in New Hampshire, Hillary Rodham Clinton ignores her Democratic opponents and takes on the “Republican attack machine.”

headline: An Effort to See That Carbon Saved Is Carbon Earned
text: It’s worth exploring a fine blog at our sister paper, the International Herald Tribune, called Business of Green.

headline: Eagleton v. Amis v. Islam
text: What does it mean to be an Islamophobe, and once we have that sorted out, is Martin Amis an exemplar of the species?

headline: The Romantic Toll of Diabetes
text: Most people with diabetes worry about the effect the disease has on their bodies. But what about the effect it has on their relationships?

headline: Vizio Stays on Top in L.C.D. TVs
text: As the hard-core deal hunters ready their thermoses so they have coffee while camping out early Friday morning for the “doorbuster” sales at Best Buy, Wal-Mart and so on, returns from the third-quarter electronics derby are coming in.

headline: Brown's Lobster Pound
text: Students from Harvard University's Institute of Politics talked to Bruce Brown, owner of a popular New Hampshire stop for Republican candidates.

headline: $20 Million Homes
text: Properties on the market in California, Florida and New York.

headline: Amphicar Ahoy!
text: PARIS — The  transit strike that brought train service in Paris and other parts of France to a screeching halt for the last week is causing commuters no end of pain and annoyance. But Parisians are coping with the inconvenience by taking advantage of the city’s new rent-a-bike program, car-pooling, or by putting on their most comfortable walking shoes. To see how the strike had affected everyday life in my new hometown, I decided to take a walk through the Place de la Concorde.

headline: Tuesday Links: This Has Nothing to Do With the Patriots
text: Watching last night’s game, I was at first wondering, “Weren’t the Broncos just on ‘Monday Night Football’?” But by the end, it seemed as if this was an entirely different team than the one that lost to the Packers on “MNF” three weeks ago (Here is some video to compare: Week 8 vs. Week 11). And Denver might be peaking at the right time. The A.F.C West is a mess, just waiting for a team to take charge. After the 34-20 victory over the Tennessee Titans (6-4), the Broncos (5-5) are now tied for first place with the confounding San Diego Chargers.

headline: Tuesday Morning Kickoff
text: No one has ever accused football coaches of having the best perspective. Nick Saban, when talking about Alabama’s back-to-back losses to Mississippi State and Louisiana-Monroe had this to say, according to Kevin Scarbinsky of the Birmingham News:

text: I suppose I knew it already, but a recent visit to the restaurant Fiamma in SoHo hammered home this lesson:

headline: Thanksgiving’s Modern Joys
text: The Onion reports that Americans are enjoying their Thanksgiving tradition of waiting around at the airport:

headline: Cellphones Get Cheaper, So People Pay More
text: There’s no place that the relentless reduction in prices for technology products is more visible than cellphones. It seems like only months between the time a phone is offered for sale at $300 and it is ready to be given away free in cereal boxes. (O.K. not quite, but that’s not a bad marketing idea.)

headline: Report Finds Racial Disparities in Police Searches
text: Updated, Nov. 21 | A study by the private nonprofit Rand Corporation found that blacks and Hispanics were more likely than whites to be searched when stopped by police officers, but the report does not accuse the department of racial profiling, according to Warren Robak, a spokesman for Rand.

headline: Finding the Traditional Seven-Fish Christmas Eve Dinner in Rome
text: I’m searching for a restaurant in Rome, preferably serving traditional seven-fish Christmas Eve dinner. Any suggestions?

headline: Poem-Based Movies
text: Seen “Beowulf” yet?

headline: Gobble, Gobble and Gobble Some More?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Strike News: ‘Daily Show’ and ‘Colbert’ Ratings Decline
text: The tentpoles of Comedy Central have recorded ratings declines in the first two weeks of the writers’ strike.

headline: Buffett and CarMax: Less Than Meets the Eye?
text: Four times a year, fans of Warren Buffett — and there are a lot of them — rush to see which stocks his Berkshire Hathaway has bought in the latest quarter, in hopes of getting a good investment tip or two. Last week, there was a flurry of excitement about CarMax, the seller of used cars, because it appeared that the legendary investor had added nearly 14 million CarMax shares to his portfolio. That was enough to send CarMax’s stock price soaring 7.5 percent in much heavier-than-normal trading.

headline: Electronic Books: If It Ain’t Broke . . .
text: At $400, Amazon’s Kindle seems rather expensive. The books may be cheap, but you would have to read well over 40 of them before you began to save any money. And really, who reads 40 books a year? Or even in two years?

headline: Ex-Bush Spokesman’s Tantalizing Snippet on C.I.A. Leak
text: The hints of intrigue and betrayal at the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. over the leaking of a C.I.A. agent’s identity grew even more intriguing today as a snippet made the rounds from the forthcoming memoir by Scott McClellan, who was President Bush’s chief spokesperson in 2006.

headline: Are Guggenheim’s True Colors Shining Through?
text: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will remain light gray.

headline: Thanksgiving Rush Is On at Hunts Point Market
text: Pumpkins are out. Cranberries are in. This is a peak week for the Hunts Point Cooperative Market, which is the source for approximately 60 percent of New York City’s produce. On Sunday night, the market opened at 6 p.m. instead of a normal 9 p.m. to handle the nighttime rush — about twice the volume of any other day. That day some 500,000 pounds of fresh cranberries — mostly from the bogs of Massachusetts and New Jersey — passed through the market.“Cranberries are a unique item in that more than half of the fresh cranberries are consumed at one meal, Thanksgiving Day,” said Matthew D’Arrigo, whose family has been distributing cranberries for 25 years. “Most of the rest of the year, we limp along and sell 20 to 40 boxes a day. And then I put 12,000 into storage and starting about 10 days before Thanksgiving they start flying out,” he said. “It’s a very encapsulated market.”

headline: Dianne Feinstein: Backlash on the Left
text: Liberal California Democrats — and liberal bloggers — have a new Public Enemy No. 1: Senator Dianne Feinstein. They have begun to make their objections very public.

headline: Scenes From Nimrod Nation
text: A series about a boy's varsity basketball team becomes more of a portrait of a small town.

headline: Sweatshop Crucifixes at the St. Patrick’s Gift Shop?
text: Charles Kernaghan stood in the rain before St. Patrick’s Cathedral this morning, brandishing a crucifix from the cathedral’s gift shop that he claimed had been made under terrible conditions at a factory in China. “It is immoral, it is unjust and it has to change,” he said.Mr. Kernaghan, the head of the National Labor Committee, an advocacy group that has unearthed past examples of abusive work conditions, and a veteran of battles with industries over the treatment of foreign workers, said the six-inch wooden crucifix and other religious articles are frequently made by women who toil for pennies an hour in an unrelenting grind of assembly work. (The Archdiocese of New York said today that it would investigate the charges.)

headline: Detroit: ‘Most Dangerous,’ or Most Disrespected?
text: A publishing company that each year ranks the “most dangerous cities” in the United States says it does so to encourage “local conversation” about crime prevention. But in the city that topped this year’s list, Detroit, people are talking only about how much they think the researchers manipulated and sensationalized the data.

headline: 'Starting Out in the Evening'
text: A. O. Scott reviews "Starting Out in the Evening," about a graduate student who writes her Master's thesis on a once-famous author.

headline: Some Voters Eye McCain Warily
text: Talk to moderate and independent voters who really liked John McCain in 2000 and very often, if they are leery of supporting him now, it has something to do with the past. They say it’s about what they see as his willingness to embrace his old foe President Bush as he campaigned in 2004 — even as he railed against the administration’s oversight of the war in Iraq — and making amends with the late Rev. Jerry Falwell, who worked hard to derail Mr. McCain’s campaign.

headline: Iraqi Answers: 'Is Baghdad Stable?'
text: Shema Al-Muhammad's heartfelt response.

headline: Buy High, Sell Low
text: If ever there was an example of the way share buybacks help the shareholders who flee — and can hurt those who hang around — it is provided by Freddie Mac today.

headline: Man’s Conviction for Standing on Sidewalk Is Overturned
text: The Court of Appeals, New York State’s highest court, threw out the conviction today of a man who was arrested for standing and not moving on a Times Square corner in June 2004.

headline: Ratings: ‘Dancing’ Holds ABC Aloft
text: Monday’s semifinal installment of “Dancing With the Stars” lifted ABC to an easy victory in the night’s ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 23.1 million viewers tuned in to the celebrity competition from 8 to 9:30 p.m., the series’ best showing since its fall finale last November. The strong ratings also helped boost ABC’s “Samantha Who,” which followed at 9:30 with a series-best 15.4 million viewers.

headline: Oxygen Takes Its Last Unaided Breath
text: Oxygen, a seven-year-old cable channel aimed at women, is now officially part of NBC Universal.

headline: Three Howls for Bryzgalov
text: Having just moved out to Arizona after 24 years in New York, I’m getting to see a lot of the Western teams you rarely see in the East, thanks to the N.H.L.’s goofy, rivalry-driven schedule.

headline: Clinton vs. Obama, Take 2 in Iowa
text: Updated SHENANDOAH, Iowa — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just sharpened her new attack on whether Senator Barack Obama is experienced enough to be president, questioning his recent statement that living overseas as a child contributed to his experience level.

headline: The New, Sedate J.R.
text: You never shrug when the subject of Jeremy Roenick comes up. The options are:

headline: Readers’ Questions: Stem Cells
text: Two teams of scientists have managed to produce stem cells from human skin cells, Gina Kolata reports today. Their achievement may end the enormous ethical debate surrounding the destruction of human embryos for scientific research.

headline: The Scent of a Borough
text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: On the Road: Obama Caters to Small-Town Media
text: CLARION, Iowa – Last week, Senator Barack Obama appeared on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” sitting in the venerable chair where presidential hopefuls have tested their mettle for 60 years. That, however, is not the only important interview Mr. Obama has conducted in recent days.

headline: Food Pantries and Soup Kitchens Are Struggling
text: This is a week for turkey lotteries for the city’s food pantries. Though with declining federal support, some pantries are finding they have no turkeys to ration.

headline: Everybody’s in Showbiz
text: With Ric Flair’s endorsement, Mike Huckabee appears to be quietly turning his campaign from a viable dark-horse bid into something far more ambitious: a surreal, postmodern satire on the intersection of celebrity culture and presidential politics.

headline: How The Strike Affects Your Favorite Shows
text: As the writers’ strike enters its third week, networks have been forced to scramble.Here’s how your other favorite shows have been affected. Check back frequently for updates.

headline: Pairing the Wine, When Dinner Is Solo
text: I will get to the Kermit Lynch wines soon, I promise. But first I need to vent a little bit.

headline: Answers From Peter Bradford
text: This afternoon we have answers to questions prompted by the fourth article in our series on China’s environmental crisis, on the country’s attempt to use hydropower to meet some of it energy demands. Our expert this afternoon is Peter Bradford.

headline: Living in Pomona
Is Hugo Chavez Smiling Over Kansas, or Coal?
text: [UPDATE, 5/5: The prolonged fight over proposed new coal plants in Kansas has ended with a compromise forged by the new governor. As Green Inc. reports, one plant would be built, with Republicans giving support to the new Democratic governor for a push on renewable energy.]

headline: Revisiting Flowers’ (First) Shinsei Deal
text: J. Christopher Flowers has been a busy globe-trotter lately. As The Financial Times’ Alphaville points out, the head of J.C. Flowers & Company has bid for, and subsequently tried to run away from, Sallie Mae; reportedly made an offer for Britain’s Northern Rock; and taken a stake in Germany’s HSH Nordbank. But on Tuesday, he returned to the deal that put him on the map, leading a consortium for a $1.8 billion stake in Japan’s Shinsei Bank.

headline: Nina
text: Chalk up one more term from the credit debacle.

headline: Coles Limited in Practice
text: Two rather talkative wide receivers remained mum. For Laveranues Coles, nursing another injury, it was expected. For Terrell Owens, coming off four touchdowns, it was a surprise.

headline: Cheerful thought of the day
text: From Brad Setser, on US foreign debt and the falling dollar:

headline: I get an endorsement from Tom DeLay
text: No comment:

headline: Rockefeller Tree Is Green, but Is It Green?
text: A City Hall news release today states that Rockefeller Center has installed its “first-ever ‘green’ Christmas tree.”

headline: K.K.R. Hires Deal Adviser as General Counsel
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts announced on Tuesday three high-ranking appointments, including its longtime outside legal adviser.

headline: Q & A: Baghdad Correspondent on End of the Surge
text: Damien Cave of the Baghdad Bureau of The New York Times is back assessing another rush of good news in Iraq (the last plateau was in late July). This time, the starting point is a front page article he wrote today with Alissa J. Rubin, Baghdad’s Weary Start to Exhale as Security Improves.

headline: In Defense of the Kindle
text: A lot of people are writing off Amazon’s Kindle book reader much too quickly.

headline: Studying Teen Gambling — And Adding to It
text: New York State experts were surprised recently when they tried to figure out how many teenagers in the state have a gambling problem. The answer, according to a new survey: an alarming 10 percent.

headline: The Butcher Carves a Turkey
text: Ray Venezia, the manager of the meat department at New York's Fairway Market, shows his technique for effectively carving a turkey.

headline: MoveOn Takes On Facebook
text: MoveOn.org is turning its organizing prowess on one of the very tools it uses for its mobilizing efforts. The liberal group’s Civic Action division mounted an effort today against Facebook’s Beacon advertising feature, claiming it infringes user privacy and “sullies” social networking communities.

headline: Family Football
text: Thomas and Julius Jones once shared a bunk bed. Now they are both starting N.F.L. running backs who will play against each other on Thanksgiving Day.

headline: Reunion
text: In the shady side yard of the adoption equation are birth mothers — silent, mostly invisible women who have given up their children without fanfare and often with considerable grief.

headline: Egypt’s Leader Endorses Peace Meeting
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, Nov. 20 — With the prime minister of Israel standing beside him, Egypt’s president, Hosni Mubarak, gave his full endorsement today to the American-sponsored Middle East peace gathering in Annapolis, Md., next week, and raised hopes among Israeli officials of wider Arab participation in it.

headline: Stocks Fall as Oil Flirts With $100 a Barrel
text: A late sell-off in the final minutes of trading sent stocks down sharply today, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level since April. The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, a broad measure of the equity market, fell into negative territory for the year.

headline: A Songwriter’s Gamut, Personal and Poignant With Notes in Between
text: Blue neon over the stage outlines a craggy face with a sardonic smile that hovers in afterglow even after the light is switched off. The face is that of William Finn, songwriter, and it is an appropriate illustration for a revue of his work, “Make Me a Song,” at New World Stages. Like the songs, at once slightly mocking and slightly cartoonish, it dominates the stage much as Mr. Finn’s persona dominates the songs, to such an extent that even when a voluptuous blonde (Sally Wilfert) is singing, you hear the dry voice of this gay Jewish songwriter coming through her own.

headline: Democrats and Bush Spar on Military Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — The Bush administration sought to ratchet up pressure on Congressional Democrats on Tuesday over a military spending bill for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. The White House and the Pentagon warned of dire consequences if the measure was not passed, including the potential layoffs of 100,000 civilian Defense Department employees.

headline: New Cable Head Named
text: NBC Universal completed its acquisition of the Oxygen cable channel yesterday and named Lauren Zalaznick as the executive in charge. Ms. Zalaznick will also remain president of the company’s Bravo channel. Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Universal, announced the agreement to purchase Oxygen Media in October; in its announcement yesterday NBC Universal placed the net value of the deal at $875 million. NBC Universal executives said they had sought the channel to reach more female consumers, a group the Bravo Channel, which has performed consistently well under Ms. Zalaznick, also appeals to.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: The Peppers Claim ‘Californication’ for Themselves

headline: Candidate Drops Bid for Congress
text: A vice chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, who was expected to pour his own money into a bid for Congress, abruptly dropped out of the running yesterday.

headline: 200 Neglected Buildings Get 4 Months to Improve
text: In a crackdown on some of the worst landlords in New York City, housing officials have identified 200 of the most poorly maintained apartment buildings and are renewing efforts to force owners to repair hazardous conditions.

headline: Khmer Rouge Hearing Ends
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 21 — More than 28 years after the killing stopped, the first Khmer Rouge defendant stepped into a public courtroom on Tuesday to answer for the deaths of 1.7 million people — a tiny, self-effacing man who once commanded an efficient and ruthless torture house.

headline: Recipe: Waldorf Slaw
text: 1/3 cup rice vinegar

headline: German Police Arrest Third Suspect in Perugia Murder Case
text: ROME, Nov. 20  The hunt for a 20-year-old man suspected in the puzzling slaying of a British student in Italy ended after he was picked up by the German police on Tuesday for riding a train without a ticket.

headline: Canada: Huge Conservation Area Set for North
text: The government plans to convert 25.5 million acres of northern woodland into a new national park and wildlife protection area that will be one of North America’s largest conservation areas. The land is within the boreal forest, a nearly contiguous band of mostly coniferous trees about 600 miles wide that sweeps across much of Canada and continues in Scotland, Scandinavia and Russia. About 77 percent of Canada’s forest is in the band. Under the plan to be announced tomorrow (cabinet orders putting it into effect were published to little notice last week), 8.5 million acres surrounding the eastern arm of Great Slave Lake in the Northwest Territories will become a national park. An additional 15.3 million acres between the new park and an existing wildlife refuge will be designated conservation land under the management of native groups. Farther northwest, near the Mackenzie River Valley, 3.7 million acres will be turned into a national wildlife area.

headline: Holiday Closures
text: NEW YORK

headline: In Shift, Fare for the Subway Will Stay at $2
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer abruptly announced yesterday that he was shelving a plan to raise the base subway fare, saying that an unexpected increase in ridership and other revenues have made it unnecessary.

headline: Cardiologists Question Delay of Data on 2 Drugs
text: Prescriptions for the cholesterol-lowering drugs Zetia and Vytorin are written for almost 800,000 Americans every week, at a cost this year of about $4 billion. Yet it still is not clear how well the drugs work.

headline: Clinton Challenges Obama on Foreign Experience
text: SHENANDOAH, Iowa, Nov. 20 — Fog may have diverted Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s plane from her campaign stop here on Tuesday, but that did not prevent her from continuing her attacks on Senator Barack Obama’s experience.

headline: Corrections
text: The VC Nation column on the Street Scene page of Business Day on Friday, about identity theft, misstated the background of Robert Maynard, a founder of LifeLock, a security firm in Tempe, Ariz.
