Although Mr. Maynard spent a week in jail on fraud charges, as The Phoenix New Times reported, he made restitution and was not convicted. Mr. Maynard does not have a criminal record. (Go to Article)

headline: Manhattan: Ambulette Injures Boy
text: An ambulette driver was charged with vehicular assault and driving under the influence after his ambulette struck and critically injured a 12-year-old boy yesterday, the police said. The driver was identified as Juan Ortiz, 57. The boy, who was hit while trying to cross East 20th Street near First Avenue, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said.

headline: Opponents of California Ballot Initiative Seek Inquiry
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20  The chairman of a committee formed to fight a ballot initiative to change how California’s electoral college votes are apportioned has asked the city attorney here to investigate a report that a group collecting signatures for the initiative has offered food to homeless people in exchange for signing the petitions.

headline: Redefining What’s Preferable
text: What is more humiliating for a player in the second half of a blowout defeat?

headline: New Stem Cell Method Could Ease Ethical Concerns
text: Two teams of scientists are reporting today that they turned human skin cells into what appear to be embryonic stem cells without having to make or destroy an embryo — a feat that could quell the ethical debate troubling the field.

headline: Democrats Move to Block Bush Appointments
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Who says the Senate cannot act quickly? It conducted a full day’s business in less than 30 seconds on Tuesday.

headline: Scientists Bypass Need for Embryo to Get Stem Cells
text: Two teams of scientists reported yesterday that they had turned human skin cells into what appear to be embryonic stem cells without having to make or destroy an embryo — a feat that could quell the ethical debate troubling the field.

headline: Fantasies Without Bounds for a Lothario With Limits
text: Crispin Hellion Glover’s planned trilogy of blatant weirdness continues with a second installment, “It Is Fine! Everything Is Fine.” Like last year’s Part 1, “What Is It?,” this follow-up (with David Brothers as co-director) will attract only the most adventurous filmgoers, who will have to wade through some rather repugnant material to weigh the movie’s merits.

headline: Stamford: Inmate Charged in Killing
text: Nearly five years to the day that a Stamford woman was found slain in her waterfront condo here, the authorities obtained a warrant on Nov. 6 to arrest a New York inmate serving a 25-year sentence for the attempted murder of her own husband. The Stamford police were seeking to extradite the woman, Sheila Davalloo, above, to stand trial in the killing of Anna Lisa Raymundo, 32, on Nov. 8, 2002. Ms. Davalloo was sentenced in April 2004 for stabbing her husband, Paul Christos, in 2003. The police said Ms. Davalloo tried to rid herself of both her husband and Ms. Raymundo, whose boyfriend, they said, she wanted to date. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Metropolitan Opera Performances Online
text: The Metropolitan Opera said yesterday that 100 recorded performances from its archives from as far back as 1937 were now available on the Rhapsody digital music service (rhapsody.com/metropolitanopera). More will be added, the Met said. The venture, announced last year, is part of efforts by the Met to distribute its performances outside of the house, including on the Internet and in movie theaters.

headline: Girardi Shows His Hands-On Approach
text: Two weeks ago, Joe Girardi was in Orlando, Fla., huddling with coaches at the general managers’ meetings to plan spring training for the Yankees. Last week, he was in the Dominican Republic at the team’s new academy, viewing tryouts and speaking to the players, some as young as 16.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Another Side of Bob Dylan, and Another, and Another ...
text: From Andy Warhol to Lonelygirl15, modern media culture thrives on the traffic in counterfeit selves. In this world the greatest artist will also be, almost axiomatically, the biggest fraud. And looking back over the past 50 years or so, it is hard to find anyone with a greater ability to synthesize authenticity — to give his serial hoaxes and impersonations the ring of revealed and esoteric truth — than Bob Dylan.

headline: Travelers’ Odds Decline on Airline Baggage
text: CHICAGO — Why do so many passengers get off the plane only to discover that their baggage did not make the trip with them?

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Art on Friday, about assessing presidential candidates, misstated the era in which The Monthly Magazine conducted its review of British politicians. The year 1823 was in the Georgian era, not the Victorian.

headline: Conviction for Standing in Times Sq. Is Overturned
text: The Court of Appeals, New York State’s highest court, threw out the conviction yesterday of a man who was arrested for standing and not moving on a Times Square corner in 2004.

headline: New York Aids in Jewelry Recall
text: The Consumer Product Safety Commission recalled 507,900 pieces of children’s jewelry this morning from stores like Michael’s and Big Lots because they contained hazardous levels of lead.

headline: Someday My Prince Will ... Uh, Make That a Manhattan Lawyer
text: The movies like to promise girls and women a happily ever after, but it’s unusual that one delivers an ending that makes you feel unsullied and uncompromised, that doesn’t make you want to reach for your Simone de Beauvoir or a Taser. “Enchanted,” an unexpectedly delightful revisionist fairy tale from, of all places, Walt Disney Pictures, doesn’t radically rewrite every bummer cliché about girls of all ages and their dreams. But for a satisfying stretch, the film works its magic largely by sending up, at times with a wink, at times with a hard nudge, some of the very stereotypes that have long been this company’s profitable stock in trade.

headline: Mets Acquire Estrada in a Trade for Mota
text: The Mets improved themselves on two fronts yesterday. They traded for a starting catcher and, in doing so, got rid of a player who, in many ways, embarrassed them in 2007.

headline: No Easy Solution for Congestion at J.F.K. Airport, Experts Say
text: It has become an agonizingly familiar formula for delays and frustration: high winds, rain and holiday crowds. And when those elements converge on Kennedy International Airport, as they do routinely at Thanksgiving time, the delays ripple out to airports across the region and often the nation, leaving millions of fliers angry.

headline: Manhattan: More Hunger in New York
text: Demand at New York City food pantries and soup kitchens jumped 20 percent this year, according to an annual survey released yesterday by the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. The demand, along with dwindling federal resources, has forced about half of the food providers surveyed to ration their supplies. The increase continues from 2006, when demand jumped 11 percent over the previous year. The survey was based on responses from 291 of the more than 1,200 agencies that run soup kitchens, food pantries and emergency food programs in the five boroughs.

headline: Anna Freud’s Insight
text: To the Editor:

headline: Border Fence Work Raises Environmental Concerns
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 — The Department of Homeland Security is ahead of schedule in building some 700 miles of fencing along the Mexican border, but some environmental groups, elected officials and local Indian tribes say too little attention is being paid to the environmental consequences of the barriers.

headline: Broadway Is Mostly Dark, but Oh, All the Other Places to Go
text: As you might just possibly have heard, Broadway is mostly dark this weekend, as the stagehands’ strike continues.

headline: For the Many Who Have Come, a Place for Them to Go
text: On a long, blustery day of hiking through Midtown, it was inevitable that members of the Yankton High School Marching Band and Colorguard, 268 strong and visiting from South Dakota, would discover one of the city’s timeless challenges.

headline: In Bangladesh, Picking Through the Pieces
text: KHATACHIRA, Bangladesh, Nov. 20 — The wind whipped through the sky. The river swelled above the tree line. And in a flash, Mamataz Begum’s youngest child, barely 2 years old, was swept from her arms, as a tidal wave smashed through the fragile mud homes of this village and scooped up everything in its watery arms.

headline: China Wins Trade Ruling About Paper
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  In a setback for American producers fighting Chinese imports, a federal trade panel ruled Tuesday against the American glossy paper industry’s request for tariffs on imported Chinese paper. The decision threw out duties that had been authorized by the Bush administration early this year.

headline: Pale Gray or Light Yellow? A Ruling on Guggenheim
text: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will remain light gray.

headline: Manhattan: Population Milestone
text: New York City’s population has passed another milestone, officially topping 8.25 million. The Census Bureau originally reported that from mid-2005 to mid-2006, the population grew by a statistically insignificant 587 people, with gains in Manhattan and Staten Island. But the Department of City Planning challenged the census count, drawing on construction permits and other documents. Yesterday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that the bureau had concurred that the city’s official count was 8,250,567, up more than 36,000 since the adjusted 2005 total. The mayor said the revisions would mean an additional $77 million in federal aid to the state by the end of the decade.

headline: Gleefully Upsetting the Artistic Apple Cart
text: Spoiler alert: The hero dies at the end, but shed no tears. Modernism, the artistic revolution that began with the poetry of Charles Baudelaire in the 1840s and quietly expired in the 1960s with Andy Warhol’s Brillo boxes, enjoyed “a good long run.” So Peter Gay concludes in the final sentence of “Modernism: The Lure of Heresy From Baudelaire to Beckett and Beyond,” his sweeping survey of the poets, playwrights, painters and architects who set out to rewrite the rules of art, transform consciousness and, wherever and whenever possible, shock the complacent middle class.

headline: Loan Crisis Entangles Freddie Mac
text: Losses at Freddie Mac underscored the continuing turmoil in the housing industry yesterday, and other developments reinforced the sense that conditions would not improve soon.

headline: Diplomacy Entails Compromise, Our U.N. Envoy Says
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Drug War Continues
text: To the Editor:

headline: Goldman Sachs Starts Drive to Build Philanthropy Fund
text: On the back of record profit so far this year, Goldman Sachs, the global investment bank, is starting a donor-driven philanthropy fund that aims to reach $1 billion over the next few years.

headline: Brothers Are Tied to Home, No Matter Where They Run
text: BIG STONE GAP, Va., Nov. 16 — The story of the brothers Jones, who once shared a bunk bed and now share a job title, starts in this sliver of southwest Virginia in the heart of coal country.

headline: Gates Halts Cut in Army Force in Europe
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has decided to freeze plans for further reducing Army forces in Europe and will maintain about 40,000 soldiers in Germany and Italy, nearly twice as many as had been envisioned under a drawdown that began two years ago, according to senior Pentagon and military officials.

headline: For Edwards, a Marriage Made in Politics That Never Quite Fit
text: John Edwards, accepting his party’s nomination for vice president, roused a cheering crowd at the 2004 Democratic convention with the kind of buoyant refrain that had become his trademark: “Hope is on the way.”

headline: Cave May Hold Secrets to Legend of Ancient Rome
text: ROME, Nov. 20 — Italian archaeologists have inched closer to unearthing the secrets behind one of Western civilization’s most enduring legends.

headline: Charges of ‘Traitor’ for Chávez Ally Turned Critic
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 18 — For years before rising to power here, President Hugo Chávez conspired alongside Raúl Isaías Baduel, who recently retired as army commander, in a secretive cell of leftist military officers intent on fomenting revolution. It was General Baduel who led the paratrooper raid that returned Mr. Chávez to office after he was briefly deposed by a coup in 2002.

headline: A Pianist’s Tour of Styles, From Weighty to Delicate
text: Competitions are now so plentiful as to be meaningless, the large ones as well as the small. Or at any rate, they have become useless at the business of star-making, and the most famous of them are scarcely better than the most obscure. They are, however, a part of the musical ecology. For young performers building their repertories and looking for performance opportunities, they offer chances to play for particularly nerve-racking audiences (juries), and the prospect of walking off with some cash and a few underwritten concerts.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article in some editions yesterday about lower estimates of the number of H.I.V. infections worldwide misstated a researcher’s explanation for a drop in infection rates in some African countries. The researcher, Daniel Halperin of the Harvard School of Public Health, said surveys indicated that people in Kenya and Zimbabwe chose to have fewer sexual partners rather than to use condoms more often. He did not mention circumcision to prevent AIDS as a consideration in those countries.

headline: Milo Radulovich, 81, Dies; Symbol of ’50s Red Scare
text: Milo Radulovich, who became a searing symbol of the excesses of anti-Communism in the 1950s when Edward R. Murrow broadcast an account of his firing as an Air Force reserve officer because of his relatives’ associations, died Monday in Vallejo, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Recipe: Turkey Artichoke Omelet Adapted from Mr.Breakfast.com
text: For the sauce:

headline: U.S. Accuses Iraqi Photographer of Aiding Rebels
text: The American military is sending an Iraqi photographer for The Associated Press it accuses of aiding the insurgency into Iraq’s criminal justice system, according to the American authorities and The A.P.

headline: A Modest Victory for Transit Riders
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer called on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to keep the basic subway and bus fare at $2. It is good that he has weighed in against the M.T.A.’s plan to raise the fare to $2.25 — and that the authority has just found a windfall of $220 million that it is committing to holding down fares and tolls. That does not mean that riders should start a conga line on the A train just yet. Even if the $2 fare is saved, riders who get discounts through multiple-use MetroCards should still brace themselves for a hit in the wallet.

headline: Eat, Drink, Pretend to Care About the Games
text: The Super Bowl is the National Football League’s yearly orgy of capitalism, but the role that the league plays in our Thanksgivings is perhaps even more vital: It allows us, mercifully, a few precious minutes away from our extended family. (Or at least something else to talk about besides than Aunt Carla’s drinking.) We tend to remember the great Thanksgiving game moments — the famous coin flip fiasco of 1998, Leon Lett’s brain-dead blocked field goal kick in the snow in 1993 — even better than we remember playoff games.

headline: Man Arrested in the Killing of a Dentist
text: It was a crude device, a silencer fashioned from a plastic bleach bottle wrapped in duct tape and left behind among the leaves in a Queens playground where a 34-year-old orthodontist was shot and killed as his estranged wife and 4-year-old daughter looked on.

headline: Moving on, a Step at a Time
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — After back surgery over the summer left him without feeling in his right foot, Ohio State Coach Thad Matta has still not adjusted to life with limited mobility.

headline: Dissents, Strongly Issued
text: With screenwriters and Broadway stagehands on strike, you might expect the spoken words of 1930s union organizers to land with an extra, galvanizing layer of meaning. But “Rebel Voices,” the Culture Project’s staged reading of monologues from the disenfranchised, is so flat and earnest that it seems detached from the moment even when it should speak eerily to the present.

headline: Labor Group Says St. Patrick’s Sells Sweatshop Goods
text: A workers’ rights group yesterday accused St. Patrick’s Cathedral of selling religious items made under terrible conditions in sweatshop factories in China.

headline: Ian Smith, Defiant Symbol of White Rule in Africa, Is Dead at 88
text: Ian Smith, the former prime minister of Britain’s rebellious colony of Rhodesia, who once promised that white rule in Africa would endure for 1,000 years, died yesterday in South Africa. He was 88.

headline: Musharraf Meets With Saudis to Discuss What to Do With One of His Rivals
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 20 — In his first trip out of the country since declaring emergency rule, the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, arrived in Saudi Arabia on Tuesday to discuss the future of one of his main political rivals, former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, who lives in exile there.

headline: Majoring in Mailroom Management
text: LOS ANGELES — There was the ant farm, the air-conditioner, the barbecue grill. Then there was the chalk, pool cues and pool balls, and the car tires and a bumper.

headline: Lowell Opts for Comfort and Stays With Red Sox
text: Mike Lowell wanted to keep playing third base for the Boston Red Sox, but he also wanted a four-year deal. The Red Sox wanted to re-sign Lowell, but they did not want to give him a contract for more than three years.

headline: Khmer Rouge Figure Appears in Court
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Nov. 20 — More than 28 years after the killing stopped, the first Khmer Rouge defendant stepped into a public courtroom on Tuesday to answer for the deaths of 1.7 million people — a tiny, self-effacing man who once commanded an efficient and ruthless torture house.

headline: Bridge World Brouhaha Ends With a Statement, Not Punishment for Players
text: The United States Bridge Federation has dropped its effort to punish six members of the women’s championship bridge team for holding up a sign that said “We did not vote for Bush” during an awards ceremony last month in Shanghai.

headline: Polygamist Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
text: ST. GEORGE, Utah, Nov. 20 — The polygamous leader of a fundamentalist Mormon sect was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years to life in prison for forcing a 14-year-old girl to “spiritually” marry her 19-year-old cousin and commanding the naïve bride to submit to sexual relations against her will.

headline: Ex-Alabama Star Survives
text: A van driven by the former Alabama star running back Siran Stacy was struck by a pickup truck at an intersection in Dothan, Ala., late Monday. Six people were killed, including Stacy’s wife and four of his children, the police said. The driver of the second vehicle was also killed. The police said the pickup was on the wrong side of the four-lane road when it struck Stacy’s van on the passenger side.Stacy, 39, the first pick of the Philadelphia Eagles in the 1992 draft, was listed in stable condition in surgical intensive care in Dothan. His 3-year-old daughter, Shelly, was taken to Children’s Hospital in Birmingham, which did not release her condition.The victims were identified as Stacy’s wife, Ellen Stacy, 36; their children, Lequisa, 18; Bronson, 10; Sidney, 8; and Ellie, 2; and the other driver, Adam W. Wayman, 29.

headline: Zeppelin Concert Is on Track
text: Jimmy Page, the Led Zeppelin guitarist, said that a broken finger on his left hand was healing well and that he was confident of performing in a reunion concert on Dec. 10, rescheduled from November, Reuters reported yesterday. “It’s going to be fine for the concert,” Mr. Page, 63, said. Led Zeppelin is getting back together to take part in a benefit concert to raise money for the Ahmet Ertegun Education Fund, named for the record executive who originally signed them in 1968; Mr. Ertegun died on Dec. 14. Demand for tickets was so great that the concert Web site, ahmettribute.com, crashed. One fan paid 83,000 pounds ($170,000) for two tickets in a charity auction.

headline: Southeast Asian Pact Exposes Rifts
text: SINGAPORE, Nov. 20 — Southeast Asian leaders signed a charter here on Tuesday that was drafted as a watershed document to bind the region together in a European-style economic community, but the pact has instead exposed the sharp divisions over one of its members, Myanmar.

headline: Broadway Visitors Find Other Games in Town
text: Last weekend, as Broadway’s strike talks resumed, there was a surge of optimism among theatergoers in New York and around the nation. When talks faltered on Sunday night, that optimism died.

headline: ‘Battlestar’ Goes Boldly Into the DVD Universe
text: Forget the robot killers with machine guns built into their arms. The DVDs are taking over.

headline: California Sues a Voting Machine Maker Over Changes
text: The California secretary of state, Debra Bowen, filed a lawsuit yesterday against a voting machine manufacturer for the reported sale of uncertified machines to five counties in northern California.

headline: U.S. and Iranian Officials Plan Talks on Iraqi Security
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 20 — On a day of scattered violence across Iraq, American and Iranian officials said they would meet for a fourth round of talks aimed at stabilizing the security situation here.

headline: Rollins Tops Holliday to Win M.V.P.
text: Jimmy Rollins predicted before the season that his Philadelphia Phillies would be the team to beat in the National League East, which proved true as they won the division. Rollins neglected to predict that he would win the Most Valuable Player award along the way, but that happened, too.

headline: The Peppers Claim Californication for Themselves
text: The Red Hot Chili Peppers are suing Showtime Networks over the new television series “Californication,” which is also the name of the band’s 1999 album and one of its songs, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The lawsuit, filed on Monday, states that the title is “immediately associated in the mind of the consumer” with the Chili Peppers. Additionally, the series, starring David Duchovny, features a character named “Dani California,” which is also the title of a Red Hot Chili Peppers song released in 2006, the lawsuit noted. The suit also names the show’s creator and executive producer, Tom Kapinos, and two production companies, Twilight Time Films and Aggressive Mediocrity Inc. The suit seeks a permanent injunction barring Showtime and the other defendants from using “Californication” for the show’s title, as well as other penalties.

headline: BlackRock Is Likely to Lead Banks’ Safety Net Fund
text: BlackRock, the big investment firm, is expected to be the main asset manager for a $75 billion fund being created by three large banks to help shore up the market for asset-backed securities, a person briefed on the situation said late yesterday.

headline: Artist at Work: Taste if You Dare
text: ALTHOUGH restaurant reviewers often have to divine a chef’s thinking, Sam Mason has spared us the effort. He’s spelled out his mind-set in big letters on a page of the publicity materials for his new restaurant, Tailor.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: NEW PLACES

headline: Wharton Letter Reopens a Mystery
text: Literary biography is never finished, Hermione Lee, the Goldsmiths’ professor of English at Oxford and author of acclaimed books about Virginia Woolf and Edith Wharton, said the other day. New information keeps turning up. In the case of Wharton, what has just turned up is a letter that casts new light on the vexing question of what exactly happens at the end of her 1905 novel, “The House of Mirth.” Does Lily Bart, the novel’s heroine, kill herself or die of an accidental overdose?

headline: How to Improve Your Prospects
text: If you are going to check bags this holiday season, a few suggestions:

headline: ABC Dances to the Top
text: Monday’s semifinal installment of “Dancing With the Stars” lifted ABC to an easy victory in the night’s ratings. Nielsen estimated that 23.1 million viewers tuned in to the competition from 8 to 9:30, the most since its fall finale last November. That helped ABC’s “Samantha Who,” which followed, draw its biggest audience, 15.4 million viewers. CBS ranked second for the night, leading the 10 o’clock hour with “CSI: Miami” (16.2 million). In third place over all, NBC benefited from “Chuck,” which delivered its largest audience in five weeks (7.8 million). Among adults 18 to 49, “Chuck” finished in a virtual tie for second at 8 o’clock, with CBS’s comedies in the hour, “How I Met Your Mother” (8.5 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (8 million). Fox ranked fourth over all.

headline: Teaching English to the Visually Impaired
text: Jacqueline Suh teaches English at the Guild for the Blind.

headline: Slaughter on Parade, Without Joystick
text: Based on the video game franchise of the same title, “Hitman” exploits every action-flick cliché imaginable and still manages to be dull. It’s bang, boom, blah — action movies for bored dummies.

headline: Irving Bluestone, 90, Top U.A.W. Negotiator, Dies
text: Irving Bluestone, chief negotiator for more than 400,000 workers at General Motors in the 1970s and an advocate of worker participation in management, died on Saturday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 90.

headline: From an Artist Who Wears Many Hats, a Recital of 20th-Century Works
text: As with the work of any living composer, people are bound to have varied reactions to Thomas Adès’s music. But no one can fairly question that this 36-year-old Englishman is among the most accomplished all-around musicians of his generation.

headline: In New Orleans, a Test of Mixed-Income Housing
text: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 — Despite the havoc wrought by Hurricane Katrina around this city, one slice of the devastated housing market is showing resurgence. The multifamily sector is more active than it has ever been, with nearly 5,400 units being created or undergoing major rehabilitation, according to a recent brokers’ report covering rental apartment complexes with 100 units or more.

headline: Three Sentenced in Death of Gay Man
text: In a case that put sexual identity, hatred and ultimately forgiveness in leading roles, three men were sentenced to prison yesterday for their roles in chasing a gay man to his death in highway traffic in Brooklyn last year.

headline: No Longer Wearing Two Hats
text: Lloyd Carr resigned this week as the University of Michigan football coach, prompting Josh Tyrangiel to wonder whether he might have one of the last pieces of autographed merchandise from Carr’s 13-year tenure in Ann Arbor. It came into his possession unexpectedly, after Carr sent an e-mail to Tyrangiel praising his article, “A House Divided,’’ in the November issue of PLAY. In it, Tyrangiel chronicled his extended family’s “Civil War’’ over the Michigan-Ohio state rivalry and his own conversion to Wolverine fever after years of neutrality.

headline: As a Life Is Celebrated, a Death Is Questioned
text: Not a whole lot was said about Khiel Coppin’s life at his funeral yesterday.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,257,285.28

headline: Knicks Start Marbury, but Nothing Changes
text: After another night of disjointed, distressing basketball, not to mention boos, taunts and chants, Isiah Thomas found a new person to blame last night.

headline: Jim Ringo, Pro Football Hall of Fame Center, Dies at 75
text: Jim Ringo, an undersized center who played 15 seasons in the National Football League and was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1981, died Monday in Chesapeake, Va. He was 75.

headline: A Zippy Update for a Mild-Mannered Standard
text: AS a child, whenever I wanted comfort food for dinner, I left the watercress-salad-and-fish confines of my parents’ kitchen and trotted down the block to the Coopers’ house.

headline: Recipe: Wild Turkey Hash From Topper’s at the Wauwinet on Nantucket
text: 1 shredded meat from 1 10- to 12-pound turkey

headline: After the Meal, the Credit Card Scanner Is Served
text: THE waiter gives you the bill. You check it and then, right at the table, you swipe your credit card in a portable device. A receipt pops out, you sign it, and you are on your way.

headline: A Stocking-Stuffer Idea: Lots of Old Resentments
text: In movies the holidays are a time when families come together, and a lifetime of secrets boil to the surface over a few short days.

headline: Instead of Fighting Ad Leaks, Some Retailers Embrace Them
text: Every year, retailers denounce the renegade Web sites that prematurely disclose leaked copies of discount-filled advertisements for the day after Thanksgiving.

headline: A 19th-Century Ghost Awakens to Redefine ‘Soul’
text: FOR nearly seven years Jan Longone, an antiquarian cookbook collector, has been haunted by a ghost. The spirit came into her life as thousands of other vintage volumes from book dealers had before: in a plain brown wrapper. But as soon as she held Malinda Russell’s “Domestic Cook Book: Containing a Careful Selection of Useful Receipts for the Kitchen,” she could see its author and her world — the small, seldom-discussed society of free blacks in the 19th century — coming to life before her eyes.

headline: Making Social Connections and Selling Cookies
text: FOR decades, Nabisco has sold cookies called Social Tea and crackers called Sociables. Now a competitor, Pepperidge Farm, is going all social, too, by entering the increasingly popular field known as social media with a Web site devoted to social networking.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,864 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Renewable Electricity
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Prophet With a Lot of Support
text: When you remember the House of Windsor’s origins, it is easier to accept that the British choral tradition also has a couple of Germans as its bedrock. Handel turned to oratorios in the first part of the 18th century, and if his operas dropped out of sight until relatively recently, “Messiah” has ruled the world uninterrupted.

headline: Manhattan: Contractor Guilty of Fraud
text: Tri-Built Construction, a New York drywall contractor, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to conspiring to defraud the carpenters’ union.. Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said the two owners, Patrick N. McCaul and James D. McGonnell, had diverted at least $6.5 million from the union’s benefit funds. They face up to five years in prison and agreed to forfeit $1.5 million.

headline: Berkeley’s Wine Radical, 35 Years Later
text: BERKELEY, Calif.

headline: Manhattan: H & M Workers Organize
text: The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union announced yesterday that it had organized more than 1,000 employees at nine H & M stores in Manhattan. Stuart Appelbaum, the union’s president, said the sales clerks, cashiers and other workers unionized through an expedited process.

headline: Recipe: Turkey Potpie With Chipotle and Cheese Sticks Crust
text: 1 quart low-sodium chicken stock or broth

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | EUROPE: Germany: Inflation Indicator Rises
text: German producer-price inflation, an early indicator of price pressures in the economy, accelerated more than economists expected in October after the price of oil rose to a record and the cost of food surged. Prices for goods ranging from newsprint to plastics climbed 1.7 percent from a year earlier after rising 1.5 percent in September, the Federal Statistics Office said. Economists had expected a 1.6 percent gain. “Price pressures are now definitely building up,” said Rainer Guntermann, an economist at Dresdner Kleinwort in Frankfurt.

headline: Singing About Dark Emotions, but Keeping Things Upbeat
text: Not far into his briskly energetic show at the Nokia Theater on Monday night, Caetano Veloso revisited a song from the early 1970s, the phase in his career when he was more of an upstart than an eminence. It was “Nine Out of Ten,” a product of his exile in London after running up against political pressures in Brazil; its lyrics, in English, celebrate “the sound of music banging in my belly,” with a spirit of wonder appropriate to the age.

headline: Recalling the New Deal: What Government Can Do
text: To the Editor:

headline: Will ‘The Grinch’ Escape a Strike? Ask the Judge
text: And on the 11th day, they went to court.

headline: Wiretap Issue Leads Judge to Warn of Retrial in Terror Case
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — A federal judge warned Tuesday that if the government did not allow lawyers to review classified material on possible wiretapping of an Islamic scholar convicted of inciting terrorism, she might order a new trial for him.

headline: Merrill Fires Executive in Asian Unit
text: Merrill Lynch ousted the co-head of its Asian fixed-income business yesterday amid a management shake-up after $8.4 billion of losses on subprime mortgage-related securities and bad loans.

headline: Soon the Bread Will Be Making Itself
text: I THOUGHT the Dining section published the easiest bread recipe possible last year when Mark Bittman wrote about the no-knead approach of Jim Lahey, owner of Sullivan Street Bakery.

headline: Turkey Again, Thanks to the Italians
text: TO the long and ever-growing list of things you can do with leftover turkey, you can add a hearty, pleasant and easily made barley risotto.

headline: Plant Approved, With Carbon Study
text: The Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission approved Duke Energy’s application yesterday to build a new coal-fired power plant, and ordered the company to submit a plan within six months on how to capture some of the carbon dioxide it would produce.

headline: City Police Stop Whites Equally but Frisk Them Less, a Study Finds
text: Whites and members of minorities have a roughly equal chance of being stopped by police officers and questioned on the street in New York City. But officers are more likely to frisk, search or arrest black and Hispanic people -- or to use force against them -- according to a study released yesterday.

headline: In Florida, Bear Tracks Everywhere
text: If you’re hunting for Golden Bear tracks — that is, a sampling of Jack Nicklaus’s course designs—you will surely bag your limit along Florida’s Gold Coast, where Nicklaus has resided since the early 1970s. Nicklaus’s design style is on display across Palm Beach County, where he has constructed more than a half-dozen courses. So is his largesse: Jack’s gift to his adopted hometown was to reconfigure its tired muni into a local treasure — North Palm Beach Country Club — and he did it for the princely design fee of $1. Reopened in November 2006, the rolling, 7,100-yard layout boasts two holes along the Intracoastal Waterway and a high season green fee that’s well south of $100.

headline: Recipe: Barley ‘Risotto’ With Turkey and Mushrooms
text: 4 tablespoons butter or extra virgin olive oil, or a combination

headline: Lottery Numbers
Obama Feels the Chill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Coaching Timetable
text: If Les Miles, the coach of the top-ranked L.S.U. Tigers, wants the open job at Michigan, his alma mater, when should he announce his interest? Now, so that the speculation doesn’t hang over the two schools? Or after the Tigers’ bowl game?

headline: Debating Iraq’s Transition
text: Watching Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice making repeated trips to Israel to try to broker some kind of deal between Israelis and Palestinians, while Iraq remains politically unresolved, leaves me feeling like my house is burning down and the fire department has decided to stop along the way to get two cats out of a tree.

headline: Near St. Louis, Where a Game Is More Than a Game
text: KIRKWOOD, Mo., Nov. 19 — For much of the past week, students in Tom O’Toole’s home maintenance class at Webster Groves High School have immersed themselves in the precise dismantling of wooden pallets. The goal is to create the perfect Thanksgiving Day pep rally bonfire.

headline: Queens: Toddler Falls to His Death
text: A 2-year-old boy died yesterday after falling six stories from a window in his family’s apartment in Rego Park, the police said. The police did not release the child’s name. His mother, Sandra Perez, said he had crawled out the window while she was taking a shower, a law enforcement official said. The boy fell shortly after 8 a.m., the police said, and he was pronounced dead at Elmhurst Hospital Center at 8:45.

headline: A High School Struggles With Surprise Students
text: Several weeks ago, Cristal Urena proposed what should have been the most prosaic of activities. As the student government president at Beach Channel High School in Rockaway Park, Queens, she asked the administration to allow an after-school dance in December to celebrate the coming holidays.

headline: Kohlberg Hires Deal Adviser to Be Top Lawyer
text: The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has hired as general counsel the lawyer who worked on several of its biggest deals, an indication that it may be moving ahead with plans to go public.

headline: Annapolis and the Mideast Divide
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Agency Denies Inflating Cases of H.I.V. Deliberately
text: After releasing new figures showing that the global AIDS epidemic is smaller than it previously reported, the United Nations’ AIDS-fighting agency denied yesterday that it had inflated estimates for years in an alarmist effort to raise funds.

headline: Behind Wheels of Black Cabs, Mostly White Faces
text: LONDON, Nov. 20 — As many tourists know from personal experience, London taxi drivers like to point out that unlike other cabbies, they actually know where they are going.

headline: New Jersey Senator Urges Delay on Repeal of Death Penalty
text: TRENTON, Nov. 20 — The leading social conservative in the New Jersey State Senate, Gerald Cardinale, accused Democrats on Tuesday of trying to rush a bill repealing the death penalty through the Legislature without sufficient deliberation.

headline: Marbury-Thomas Struggle Has No Winner
text: Can the point guard’s latest exasperating power struggle with yet another beleaguered coach be having the same effect on Isiah Thomas’s Knicks as it had on Larry Brown’s?

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING | EUROPE: Switzerland: U.S. Approves Spinal Treatment
text: Synthes, the world’s largest maker of devices to mend broken and malformed bones, won approval in the United States for a new spinal fusion strip. The synthetic ceramic bone graft substitute, called Chronos, is used to fill gaps in bones that result from surgery or traumatic injury, the company said. Synthes, based in Oberdorf, Switzerland, expanded its range of spinal products this month by purchasing the closely held N Spine, based in San Diego. “This new biomaterial offers surgeons increased handling options,” Synthes said.

headline: Thompson Wants Corporate Tax Cut
text: The Republican presidential candidate Fred D. Thompson said the top federal tax rate for corporations should be cut, to 28 percent from 35 percent to help keep companies competitive with those in other nations. “We have the second highest tax rate in the industrialized world," said Mr. Thompson, a former senator from Tennessee. “I look at our international competitors and see that 28 percent would be the norm.” He said he did not support proposals in Congress to lower the corporate tax rate in exchange for eliminating the tax breaks some companies enjoy. Mr. Thompson said he would release a plan outlining changes in tax policy in the next few days.

headline: Building a Clear Vision of Independence
text: Sitting in his living room in the Bronx on a recent afternoon, Jesus Pamias demonstrated his ability to read using a closed-circuit television, though he is legally blind. The device, which magnifies text on a monitor, helps Mr. Pamias, 47, to maintain a hard-won sense of independence.

headline: Hollywood and Strikers Watch Clock
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 — Sun Tzu, the Chinese sage, warned of the danger in prolonged conflict. “Let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns,” he wrote in “The Art of War.”

headline: As French Strikes Grow, Sarkozy Speaks
text: PARIS, Nov. 20 — President Nicolas Sarkozy urged transit workers to end their weeklong strike over pension benefits on Tuesday as civil service employees, including primary school teachers, firefighters, newspaper printers and weather service employees walked out in a separate dispute over job cuts.

headline: Make It an Early Bird
text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Limiting Power’s ‘Natural Tendency’
text: After a long and frightening period of acquiescence, Congressional Democrats are standing up to President Bush’s assault on civil liberties — demanding an end to spying on Americans without court supervision.

headline: Greeks Charge Ministry Employee
text: Greek police arrested a culture ministry employee after discovering dozens of ancient Greek and Byzantine antiquities in his home, Reuters reported yesterday. The collection included 57 clay amphorae — ceramic storage vases — as well as bronze coins dating back as far as the fourth century B.C. and two Byzantine religious icons. “He has been taken to the prosecutor to be charged with antiquities theft,” a police official said. The ministry worker told police the antiques had been passed down to him by his grandfather, the police said. The ministry in recent years has conducted vigorous searches for ancient artifacts in museums and elsewhere that were illegally excavated and smuggled out of the country.

headline: A Faded Downtown Gets Luxury Housing, but Retailers Stay Away
text: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 20 — When Ray Schramm, who owned a wine shop in Pelham, explains why he left a dependable business and risked opening a trendy wine bar, the Gnarly Vine, in this shabby downtown, he points to two new towers soaring above the local skyline.

headline: The Art of Hunting Deer the Old-Fashioned Way
text: ARCADE, N.Y. — Thomas Aquinas Daly, wielding a slender stick as straight as a conductor’s baton, pointed out a bright droplet of blood splashed across a yellow maple leaf. “She went off the trail again,” he muttered, hunched over and resting his palms on his knees. “No wonder we didn’t find blood where we’ve been looking.”

headline: Recipe: Kerry Moran’s Turkey Gobbler Frittata With Red Pepper Purée
text: 3 red bell peppers for sauce

headline: Heartbreak and Healing, Sometimes Both at Once
text: From the moment Barbara Cook planted herself on stage at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening and sang “Lucky to Be Me,” a blissfully confident declaration of well-being from “On the Town,” it was obvious that Ms. Cook, who celebrated her 80th birthday on Oct. 25, meant every word. “I could laugh out loud” became a whoop of joy. The concert found this Broadway lyric soprano not only alive and kicking but in great voice and the best physical shape (trimmer, walking without support and breathing easily) than I’ve seen her in many years.

headline: John D. Rock, Former G.M. Executive, Is Dead at 71
text: DETROIT, Nov. 20 — John D. Rock, a blunt-talking General Motors executive who tried unsuccessfully to save the Oldsmobile division, died Friday in Hot Springs, S.D. He was 71.

headline: Weather and Preparation Ease Holiday Travel
text: The annual American rite of Thanksgiving travel has begun, with millions of people escaping some of the driving and flying delays that have become as much a part of the holiday as overeating and family tension.

headline: Wanted: Participants for Mideast Talks
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — The Bush administration finally acknowledged publicly on Tuesday that it had issued formal invitations to 40 countries and organizations that it hopes will attend a heavily anticipated Middle East peace conference scheduled for next week in Annapolis, Md. But the long, drawn-out route that State Department officials followed before making the acknowledgment reflected the high-stakes gamble that the administration is taking, as well as the unsettled nature of the outcome. Even late Tuesday afternoon, administration officials were still in negotiations with their Arab counterparts over whether Saudi Arabia and Syria would send their foreign ministers to the conference, or make do with lower-level envoys.

headline: Justices to Decide on Right to Keep Handgun
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — The Supreme Court announced Tuesday that it would decide whether the Constitution grants individuals the right to keep guns in their homes for private use, plunging the justices headlong into a divisive and long-running debate over how to interpret the Second Amendment’s guarantee of the “right of the people to keep and bear arms.”

headline: French Ban Britney Spears Video
text: Louis Vuitton, the luxury goods maker, has won a French lawsuit that contended that a music video by Britney Spears violated counterfeiting laws, The Associated Press reported. A Paris civil court ordered Sony BMG and MTV Online to stop broadcasting or marketing the video for “Do Somethin’” and fined them 80,000 euros ($117,000) each, a spokeswoman for Louis Vuitton said on Monday. The ruling was issued last week. In the video, above, Ms. Spears appears in a pink Hummer; one shot shows fingers drumming on a dashboard upholstered with what looks like a Vuitton design, embossed with the LV logo. The ruling said the video constituted an “attack” on Louis Vuitton’s brands and its image, the spokeswoman said. It was not clear how the ban would be enforced, or whether the companies would appeal. The video was still on YouTube and other Web sites visible in France on Monday.

headline: Fight to Keep a Language on the Stage
text: When the Israeli filmmaker Dan Katzir met Zypora Spaisman, the Polish-born “Yiddish diva” and onetime mainstay of the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater (today called the National Yiddish Theater-Folksbiene), the result was a project he had never planned to make.

headline: Electronic Pioneer With Ties to Dance
text: The choreographer Merce Cunningham has played an invaluable role in fostering the creation of a substantial body of contemporary American music over the last half-century. “Experiments in the Studio,” a new series at Mr. Cunningham’s West Village headquarters, is taking stock of that impetus through concerts largely devoted to composers who have been associated with the company. Gordon Mumma, who worked with Mr. Cunningham from 1966 to 1974, was the subject of the second installment, on Monday night.

headline: Butcher’s Method Takes Carving Off the Table
text: BEFORE breakfast on Thanksgiving, as the first Americans rise to preheat the oven, the question of who is going to carve the bird starts to ripple anxiously across the land.

headline: Book Award Finalists
text: The Costa book awards, formerly the Whitbread Awards, released this year’s short list in the fiction, first novel, biography, poetry and children’s book categories. Winners, announced on Jan. 3, receive £5,000 ($10,260) each. The Book of the Year, to be announced on Jan. 22, receives £25,000 ($51,303). Only books by writers based in England and Ireland are eligible. The fiction short list includes “Skin Lane,” by Neil Bartlett; “Day,” by A. L. Kennedy; “Death of a Murderer,” by Rupert Thomson; and “The Road Home,” by Rose Tremain.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A pop entry in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure on Sunday misstated the dates for two concerts this week at Nokia Theater. Caetano Veloso ended its performance last night; it does not perform tonight and tomorrow. As noted, Youssou N’Dour performs tonight and tomorrow, but not on Friday.

headline: Method Equalizes Stem Cell Debate
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — It has been more than six years since President Bush, in the first major televised address of his presidency, drew a stark moral line against the destruction of human embryos in medical research.

headline: Cuba: Critical Elections Called for January
text: Cuba will hold elections on Jan. 20 to choose delegates for provincial assemblies and the National Assembly, the official newspaper Granma reported, in what could be the next step toward formally ending President Fidel Castro’s 48-year rule. For Mr. Castro to continue as president, he must hold a seat in the National Assembly. “It will be important to see if Fidel’s name appears on the ballot,” said Jorge Piñon, a senior researcher at Center for Hemispheric Policy at the University of Miami. “This is key to whether he remains president.” Mr. Castro, 81, handed interim power to his brother Raúl, 76, after gastrointestinal surgery last year.

headline: Clinton Takes On ‘Republican Attack Machine’
text: This television advertisement for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton began running yesterday in New Hampshire:

headline: IPhone Must Be Offered Without Contract Restrictions, German Court Rules
text: PARIS, Nov. 20 — Last month, French law forced Apple to promise that consumers could buy a version of its iPhone in this country without having to be locked into a long-term contract with Orange, the only mobile phone operator offering the new device.

headline: The Court and the Second Amendment
text: By agreeing yesterday to rule on whether provisions of the District of Columbia’s stringent gun control law violate the Second Amendment to the Constitution, the Supreme Court has inserted itself into a roiling public controversy with large ramifications for public safety. The court’s move sowed hope and fear among supporters of reasonable gun control, and it ratcheted up the suspense surrounding the court’s current term.

headline: Britain: 33 Years for Last Bomber in Failed 2005 Attacks
text: Manfo Kwaku Asiedu, a 34-year-old immigrant from Ghana who had admitted taking part in the botched July 21, 2005, suicide attacks on London’s transit system, was sentenced in London to 33 years in prison. He pleaded guilty this month to conspiracy to cause explosions. With his sentencing, all six men caught by the police for their part in the abortive plot are serving prison sentences. The cell planned to attack three trains and a bus. No one was hurt when the explosives failed to detonate completely.

headline: Fed Expects Slowdown to Deepen
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — The Federal Reserve expects economic growth to slow sharply next year, and policy makers there are worried that even this forecast may prove too optimistic, according to an assessment that the central bank released on Tuesday.

headline: Something Creepy This Way Creeps, and It Spells Bad News
text: Until the director Frank Darabont decides that he’s saying something important instead of making a nifty horror movie, “The Mist” isn’t half bad. In fact, until the monsters and the meaning start to emerge, this shivery story works your nerves far better than most recent horror does, largely because it knows that nothing scares moviegoers better than our own overactive, reactive imaginations. This is a film that knows how to make you jump in your seat simply by showing you next to nothing: It knows you’ll eagerly fill in the blanks all by your lonesome, genre-conditioned self.

headline: Picasso Suit Rejected
text: A New York judge has ruled that the Andrew Lloyd Webber Art Foundation, owner of a Picasso painting, cannot be sued by a German collector who contended that the Nazis had forced his relative to sell the work, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. The foundation and Christie’s auction house withdrew the work from sale a year ago after the collector, Julius Schoeps, said it was forcibly sold by his great uncle, Paul von Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, a banker in Berlin. The foundation argued that Mr. Schoeps couldn’t sue for restitution because he wasn’t appointed to represent his relative’s estate, and Justice Rolando T. Acosta of the State Supreme Court concurred. Christie’s had valued the 1903 “Portrait of Angel Fernández de Soto,” above, at $40 million to $60 million. A Christie’s spokesman declined to say if the painting would now be auctioned. A lawyer for Mr. Schoeps did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment.

headline: North Babylon: Three Found Dead
text: Three people died and two others were sickened by fumes at a North Babylon home, the Suffolk County Police said. The police said the deaths may have been caused by carbon monoxide poisoning. The bodies of Ricardo Pearce, 27, Tanisha Armstrong, 25, and Talani Johnson, 4, were discovered at 437 Route 27 when officers responded to a 911 call. The police said they removed a generator and kerosene heater from the home.

headline: Senator Decries Behavior at Jets Games
text: Richard J. Codey, the president of the New Jersey Senate, did not witness fans’ unruly behavior on a pedestrian ramp at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., when he attended the Jets-Steelers game on Sunday, but yesterday he emerged as the public official who seemed the most determined to crack down on the activities.

headline: Is That Music We Hear or a Tyke’s Beating Heart?
text: To describe “August Rush” as a piece of shameless hokum doesn’t quite do justice to the potentially shock-inducing sugar content of this contemporary fairy tale about a homeless, musically gifted miracle child. August Rush (Freddie Highmore) hears music everywhere. Whether it’s the wind in the grass or the roar of a subway, the sounds of the world are a symphony to his ears, and the movie’s soundtrack offers a Hollywood realization of a John Cage idea in which all sounds are music.

headline: Calendar
text: Food on the Edge

headline: Man Killed Fleeing Police After Botched Grenade Sale
text: An undercover operative’s attempt to buy a hand grenade in the Bronx last night ended with the suspected seller being fatally shot in the head as he tried to drive away from law enforcement officers, the authorities said.

headline: Deal Is Reached in New Orleans Bias Case
text: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20 — A multimillion-dollar race discrimination judgment that had threatened to shut down the district attorney’s office here will be paid largely by the state and the city, officials announced here on Tuesday.

headline: She’s No Morgenthau
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Recipe: Apple-Fennel Soup
text: 3 apples (Granny Smith, Winesap, Cameo or Cortland)

headline: Stalking the Placid Apple’s Untamed Kin
text: Geneva, N.Y.

headline: Republican Rivals Continue Attacks on Immigration
text: The back and forth between Mitt Romney’s and Rudolph W. Giuliani’s presidential campaigns over illegal immigration continued yesterday, with each side impugning the other’s record on the issue.

headline: Strike News: Thousands Attend Hollywood Rally
text: Screenwriters, represented by the Writers Guild of America East and the Writers Guild of America West, took to the streets of Hollywood with supporters from other unions on Tuesday afternoon in a demonstration that was meant to telegraph resolve. The show was complete with a performance by Alicia Keys and the presence of eight aging actors who played Munchkins in “The Wizard of Oz.”

headline: Bangladesh Struggles to Recover
text: Villagers try to pick up the pieces following the devastation of Cyclone Sidr.

headline: Weekly Wrap: The Proper Way to Win?
text: The Fifth Down’s contributors are Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic.

headline: Wednesday’s Links: All Over but the Winning
text: They are the new Evil Empire, these Patriots. Stealing a moniker hard-earned by the Yankees, perhaps even coveted by the Red Sox. New England runs up scores, it breaks records. Through it all, though, SI.com’s Peter King reminds us that Patriots Coach Bill Belichick is only human. On the other hand, ESPN.com’s Liz Merrill goes to great lengths trying to come to the same conclusion. …I don’t mean to condone gambling but it seems noteworthy to point out that the early line has the Patriots a 23.5-point favorite over the Eagles this week, the largest point spread for an N.F.L. game not involving an expansion team. And it could get larger if Donovan McNabb doesn’t play. …While we’re at it, Jackie MacMullan at the Boston Globe thinks there is something about the Patriots you’ve been overlooking. …And, finally, here’s this week’s Tom Brady Watch.

headline: 'Late Titian'
text: Images from the exhibition at the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.

headline: Light Touch
Cartoon Social Critic and Pain in the Butt
text: Meet “Bottom-Biting Bug” — a Japanese cartoon insect who bites rear ends and social consciences. The critter’s gone from an afternoon children’s television program to karaoke favorite to live stage show. He’s seen as a catalyst to end the everyday social isolation of Japanese:

headline: Merrill Fires Executive in Asian Unit
text: Merrill Lynch ousted the co-head of its Asian fixed-income business Tuesday amid a management shake-up after $8.4 billion of losses on subprime mortgage-related securities and bad loans.

headline: BlackRock Is Likely to Lead Banks’ Safety Net Fund
text: BlackRock, the big investment firm, is expected to be the main asset manager for a $75 billion fund being created by three large banks to help shore up the market for asset-backed securities, The New York Times reported.

headline: SolFocus Adds $11.6 Million to the Pot
text: SolFocus has now raised a total of $63.6 million in series B funding to move into production of its solar power plants.

headline: Newmont Plans Billion-Dollar I.P.O. for Franco-Nevada
text: The biggest stock introduction on the Toronto Stock Exchange so far this year was given the green light Tuesday, setting the stage for the billion-dollar rebirth of Franco-Nevada, the Canadian gold and energy royalty company sold to Newmont Mining in 2002.

headline: Abu Dhabi Deal for PrimeWest Is Approved
text: The Canadian government has approved the takeover of the PrimeWest Energy Trust by Abu Dhabi National Energy, but National Energy, which is owned by the Abu Dhabi government, will face new federal hurdles in its Canadian acquisition spree.

headline: British Brewer S&N May Break Up to Defeat Takeover Bid
text: Scottish & Newcastle ‘s chief executive, John Dunsmore, has signaled he would consider a partial break-up of the company, the biggest brewer in Britain, to guard its independence.

headline: News of Undervalued Bids Chips Away at Northern Rock Shares
text: The struggling British bank Northern Rock said it has received more rescue proposals, but warned that one of them contemplated an offer well below Tuesday’s closing price, sparking a new slide in its shares on Wednesday.

headline: Ahold Has Appetite for Deals
text: the Dutch supermarket group Ahold is on the lookout for acquisitions in the regions where it has operations, its chief executive said on Wednesday.

headline: SuccessFactors Jumps 40% in Debut
text: Shares of SuccessFactors, a human-resources software provider, climbed nearly 36 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday after the company’s initial public offering of 10.8 million shares priced at the high end of the expected range.

headline: Shareholder Sues Bear Stearns Over Subprime Exposure
text: Bear Stearns, which expects a fourth-quarter loss after writing down $1.2 billion linked to mortgages, got hit with a shareholder lawsuit that claims it should have known it was overexposed to subprime lending.

headline: More Deals Ahead for Software AG
text: After absorbing webMethods and seeing immediate returns from the deal, Software AG of Germany is shopping again.

headline: Bank of America Continues Shuffling Its Investment Bank
text: The Bank of America has reshuffled its investment management arm, as it continues to sort out senior staff changes at its investment bank.

headline: Candover Sells Nowegian Cable Firm for $1.1 Billion
text: The private equity arms of the Quadrangle Group and Goldman Sachs have agreed to acquire a Norwegian cable group, GET, for 5.8 billion Norwegian kroner ($1.1 billion) in a secondary buyout from Candover Investments of London.

headline: Medingo Gets $27 Million Injection
text: Medingo, an Israeli medical device start-up, closed a first round of outside financing, raising as much as $27 million to support continued development and regulatory advancement of a patch pump to deliver insulin to patients with diabetes.

headline: Hedge Fund Copper Arch to Liquidate, Reports Say
text: Copper Arch Capital, a New York-based hedge fund founded by Scott Sipprelle, a former banker at Morgan Stanley, is winding down operations, according to press reports.

headline: Delta Pilots Union Criticizes Fund’s Merger Proposal
text: Delta Air Lines‘ pilots union on Tuesday reiterated its deep hostility to a hedge fund’s recent proposal for a merger between Delta and the parent of United Airlines, UAL.

headline: DP World Raises $4.86 Billion in I.P.O.
text: DP World, the Dubai-owned port operator with terminals from Britain to China, raised $4.96 billion in the Middle East’s biggest initial public offering ever.

headline: Sears and the Return of the Strategic Bidder
text: If Sears Holdings, the parent of the retailers Sears and Kmart, decides to challenge Catteron Partners $366 million buyout of Restoration Hardware, it has a pretty good chance of winning, according to Breakingviews.

headline: Former Citadel Trader Hangs His Own Shingle, Report Says
text: Anand Parekh, a former head equity trader at the Citadel Investment Group, is setting up his own hedge fund, according to Reuters.

headline: Goldman Sachs to Build Philanthropy Fund
text: On the back of record profit so far this year, Goldman Sachs, the global investment bank, is starting a donor-driven philanthropy fund that intends to reach $1 billion over the next few years.

headline: How Child’s Play Can Shape Careers
text: In honor of Thanksgiving, I’m giving you a career story that may inspire some indulgence around the holiday table. And a link to a funny video for dessert.

headline: Gore May Still See Green From V.C. Firm
text: Al Gore made big news this month when he said he would join Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers as a partner focusing on clean-technology investments. At the time, much of the attention was focused on how he would donate his salary to a nonprofit advocacy group he founded.

headline: Banks Fail to Sell $4 Billion of Chrysler Debt, Reports Say
text: Chrysler‘s bankers failed to sell $4 billion of loans that backed the purchase of the automaker by Cerberus Capital Management , according to press reports.

headline: The Early Word: It’s All About Iowa
text: Most of the candidates are focusing on Iowa right now, and the state’s dedicated and not-so-dedicated voters. Lois Romano delves into the psyche of the fickle – or maybe just disenchanted – Iowa voter in today’s Washington Post. She looks at the solidly conservative town of Le Mars, where caucus-goers don’t feel strong loyalty toward any G.O.P. candidate, and frankly, they don’t even know if they’ll be caucus-goers, since the Orange Bowl will be held the same night as the Jan. 3 vote.

headline: Law Firm Bonuses: The Last Hurrah?
text: It’s a great time to be a young lawyer at a top firm. Or is it?

headline: Oprah May Campaign for Obama
text: Barack Obama has been dropping hints for months that Oprah Winfrey would be going out on the campaign trail for him, and he hinted again yesterday, in comments overheard by the Chicago Sun-Times, that plans are in the works for her to start stumping for him in Iowa.

headline: Making Every Step Count

headline: Will Preserving $2 Fare Help the M.T.A.’s Image?

headline: They hate me! They really hate me!
text: Wow. Early in my tenure at The NYT, I was advised that it’s a bad idea to devote a column to attacking another columnist — not just at The Times, but anywhere. Why? Because it makes you look small — as if you have nothing better to do than snipe at other commentators, rather than trying to deal with real problems.

The conservative estimate doesn’t include service industry jobs or the feature film sector.

headline: Strike News: Shhhh! Show Runners Returning

headline: Wednesday Morning Kickoff

It seems that Trump strongly recommended that Mike Leach be hired to replace Larry Coker, instead of Randy Shannon. The Palm Beach Post’s Jorge Milan reports that Trump sent a letter this week to Miami President Donna Shalala saying she should have listened to him.

headline: A look around the web and elsewhere
text: One thing I have been meaning to do as a regular feature since this blog started, but never got around to doing even once (I think), is to do a little roundup of news and views that appeal to me at other sites. So here’s a glance at the latest talk on a few blogs and other sites:

headline: Madame Bovary Deux Point Zero
text: This Thanksgiving, let’s all be grateful that no one we’re in love with frequents AshleyMadison.com. On the other hand, at 9:44 on Wednesday morning, 4,451 people were on the site. And evidently 1.6 million people have signed up.

headline: Farms Grow More Expensive
text: The average price for U.K. farmland is rising at the fastest rate in 30 years, according to Knight Frank, the property company. Values jumped 33.2 percent in 2007, hitting £4,178 per acre in the third quarter (€5,798), compared to £3,137 a year earlier (€4,353).

headline: As Merrill’s Stock Falls, So Does Thain’s Hurdle

headline: Come Fly With Me (and Me and Me and Me…)

Watch how the pulses of flights build as dawn sweeps east to west.

headline: Name America’s Most Liberal City

Giuliani is both predicating much of his presidential candidacy on his two terms as mayor here and also running against New York City, as a symbol of American liberalism.In a new advertisement (as political blogs, including The New York Observer’s, have pointed out), Mr. Giuliani promotes his record on cutting crime, slashing welfare rolls and holding the line on taxes in New York City. The ad describes New York as “America’s most liberal city.”

headline: Q & A: Giancarlo Giammetti
text: There are few people in the fashion world I like as much as Giancarlo Giammetti, Valentino’s business partner and alter ego, even though we occasional disagree and he doesn’t mince his words. Maybe that’s the source of warmth. I remember his portrayal in Michael Specter’s 2005 profile of Valentino, which captured, I think, the dynamic between these glamorous figures and their extended family, as well as Giammetti’s frank personality. Some might call him politically incorrect. I don’t think so. Anyway, what would you prefer? Giammetti and I met last week in his new apartment in New York. In January, of course, Valentino will retire.

headline: The Spread: Spreading to the N.F.L.?
text: The daily transcripts from Bill Belichick’s news conference that the New England Patriots send out are typically some of the most interesting things that pop up in my in-box every day. Belichick is often portrayed as dry and confrontational by those who cover the N.F.L. Since I don’t, the transcripts are often some of the most insightful things I read about football. Belichick may not talk much about injuries or running up the score or whatever the P.T.I. topic da jour is, but he has an astonishing grasp of football and its history. That’s why I particularly enjoyed his take when the use of the spread offense in college football came up at his new conference today.

headline: Putting the Atlantic Yards Arena in a Secure Place
text: Once the basketball arena at Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn gets built — assuming it does get built — it should be fairly obvious where it is. But until now, the precise location of where the arena is going to be has proved strangely elusive.The location matters, somewhat, because elected officials and opponents of the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project have raised questions about security at the site based on the arena setback. In Newark, where a new arena recently opened, that city decided at the last minute that at 20 feet from the curb, the arena was too close to the street for comfort, so now Newark closes streets around its arena during events.

headline: More Troubles for Mukhtar Mai
text: Word comes from Pakistan that Mukhtar Mai is up against tough times in the wake of the political crisis. Nick first wrote about her three years ago after she had been gang-raped on order of a local tribal council. Tradition in rural Pakistan would have had her commit suicide, but instead she prosecuted her attackers. She won her case and used the compensation money to start schools for girls. We visited her earlier this year in her village, Meerwalla.

headline: Spared Cyclone’s Worst, Area Still Suffers
text: KANAINAGAR, Bangladesh, Nov. 21 — To the naked eye, this looks like a village that Cyclone Sidr barely grazed. Most of the houses are standing. No one has died. The trees are not even decapitated, as they are in so many hamlets swallowed by the storm.

headline: Uh-Oh, Knicks (2-9) Are Headed Home

And no doubt the calls for team management to fire Coach Isiah Thomas will grow even stronger than they were during the Knicks’ 28-point loss to the Warriors on Tuesday.

The recent decision to remove her from the job is overdue and a hopeful sign that the new attorney general, Michael Mukasey, may be serious about fixing his department.

headline: Lost, Found and Sold
text: A painting by the Mexican artist Rufino Tamayo that was found next to garbage bags on a Manhattan sidewalk four years ago sold for $1.049 million Tuesday at a Sotheby’s auction in Manhattan. An undisclosed American collector bought the work. Sotheby’s estimated that the 1970 canvas, “Tres Personajes” (“Three People”), above, could fetch $750,000 to $1 million, so the hammer price, $900,000, was considered a strong result. (The final price includes the auction house’s commission.) The painting was purchased for $55,000 at auction in 1977 by a Houston man as a present for his wife, but disappeared after being placed in storage in a warehouse about a decade later. Then in 2003 Elizabeth Gibson, who was perusing trash on an Upper West Side sidewalk, spotted the canvas and took it to her apartment, little realizing that it was by a celebrated painter. The wife who received the painting in 1977 was the seller at auction, and gave Ms. Gibson a $15,000 reward; Sotheby’s also paid her a finder’s fee.

headline: Canada to Announce Vast New Park
text: OTTAWA, Nov. 21 — The Canadian government plans to announce today that it will convert 25.5 million acres of northern woodland into a new national park and wildlife protection areas.

headline: Helping Fight a Battle for a Friend Who Can’t

headline: An In-Car Bluetooth Mini Device With Maxi Features

headline: Berlin and Caracas Show New York a Thing or Two About Music Outreach
text: The main goal of Carnegie Hall’s Berlin in Lights Festival, which ended on Sunday, was to convey to concertgoers in the New York area what musical life in culturally diverse Berlin is like these days. We found out how the venerable Berlin Philharmonic is faring under the adventurous leadership of Simon Rattle. We heard leading Baroque, contemporary-music and chamber ensembles from Berlin. The vocalist Max Raabe, with his Palast Orchester, and the composer and chansonnier H K Gruber took us to the days of Weimar-era cabaret and theater music.

headline: Foreign Fighters in Iraq Are Tied to Allies of U.S.
text: BAGHDAD — Saudi Arabia and Libya, both considered allies by the United States in its fight against terrorism, were the source of about 60 percent of the foreign fighters who came to Iraq in the past year to serve as suicide bombers or to facilitate other attacks, according to senior American military officials.

headline: Tip of the Week: Reading Long Files on Your iPod
text: Want to read long files on your iPod or iPod Nano, but can’t get around the iPod’s 4-kilobyte size limit on text documents? Upload that hefty text or e-book file to the iPod eBook Creator site (snipurl.com/1tpx6) and get it back in a batch of linked 4K chunks. Copy those files into your iPod’s Notes folder and you’ve got a pocket book for the morning commute. You can find plenty of free e-book text files to download at Project Gutenberg (www.gutenberg.us).

headline: Museum Official Charged With Theft
text: The former chief financial officer of the Bellevue Arts Museum in Washington State has been charged with embezzling $300,000, The Associated Press reported yesterday. King County prosecutors filed 38 counts of theft against Janet Ellinger, 53, of Redmond, Wash. They said that she stole the money from the museum from October 2005 to May 2007, and that she took most of it by writing checks to herself and then covering them up with false entries in the museum’s financial ledger. Prosecutors said that Ms. Ellinger told investigators she took the money because she was separating from her husband and felt “financially compromised.”

headline: Friends’ Clash Reflects Battle Over Israeli Court
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 — In recent days, Aharon Barak, the internationally esteemed jurist and retired chief justice of Israel, has broken a self-imposed silence and spoken publicly against an old friend, Daniel Friedmann, Israel’s minister of justice.

headline: Togetherness Finally Arrives in the Form of Headphones That Double as MP3 Players
text: MP3 players have mostly left the heavy lifting of actually producing sound to speakers or headphones. Koss decided to mash the two together with its MP3 Tügo (as in “to go”), a pair of audiophile-style headphones with a built-in player.

headline: At the Grown-Up Table
text: I am sitting at the northwest corner of my grandmother’s table in a house on the edge of a small Iowa town. I’m young enough to feel that my presence at the table is a promotion. There’s something bewildering in the passing of plates, the coming and going of serving dishes, and I can see — looking into this memory from a long ways away — that the adults at the table find my presence a little comical. It makes them speak to each other in asides and to me in a language that seems both ironic and slightly formal, as if I were an ambassador from the everyday planet of children to the special planet of Thanksgiving, where dinner is eaten at three.

headline: Wizards Lose Arenas for Three Months
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP) — Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards had two surgical procedures on his left knee Wednesday and will miss about three months.

headline: Western Union Empire Moves Migrant Cash Home
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 — To glimpse how migration is changing the world, consider Western Union, a fixture of American lore that went bankrupt selling telegrams at the dawn of the Internet age but now earns nearly $1 billion a year helping poor migrants across the globe send money home.

text: I am making a list called Qualities We Don’t Want in the Next President, based on lessons learned from the Bush administration. The first undesirable attribute was loyalty, in the sense of valuing personal relationships over competence.
