headline: Denmark: Three Sentenced in Bomb Plot
text: A court sentenced two Danish Muslims and an Iraqi Kurd to prison sentences ranging from 4 to 11 years for planning a bomb attack in Copenhagen. A fourth man was acquitted. The men were accused of planning to bomb Copenhagen’s City Hall Square or the Tivoli amusement park to protest the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad in a Danish newspaper, as well as the presence of Danish soldiers in Iraq. The four were among nine people arrested last year and accused of collecting bomb-making materials.

headline: New York’s Gambling Dens
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who is already famous for getting rid of the smoke in New York City’s bars, has now taken on gambling. The mayor’s target is the city’s Off-Track Betting parlors, which were established more than 35 years ago to reroute profits from illegal back-room bookies to the state government. The misnamed parlors were also intended to offer a convenient alternative for bettors who could not get to the tracks.

headline: Bomb at a Market Shatters Lull for Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 23 — Last Friday, the Ghazil animal market was a crowded bazaar in a city willing itself into recovery. Cautious but hopeful parents led fun-starved children by the hand to show them parakeets, tropical fish and twittering chicks painted in bright, improbable hues.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review on Thursday about Liz Callaway, at the Metropolitan Room, misstated the evening of the performance that was reviewed. It was Tuesday evening, not Wednesday.

headline: A Turnaround Plan That Includes Baconators
text: KERRII ANDERSON believes she has a good story to tell about her tenure as chief executive at Wendy’s, but she has struggled to find anyone willing to listen.

headline: Lost in a Flood of Debt
text: CHICAGO

headline: Bargains Draw Crowds, but the Thrill Is Gone
text: American consumers flooded stores yesterday on the traditional first day of the holiday shopping season, but the irrational exuberance of the Black Fridays of the last five years has been replaced by pragmatic restraint.

headline: Fire and Con Ed Officials Defend Gas Leak Response
text: The Fire Department and Consolidated Edison yesterday defended their responses to a gas leak that resulted in a deadly explosion in a home in Sunnyside, Queens, on Wednesday.

headline: Serenading Sculptures in Dance at Louvre
text: PARIS, Nov. 23 — The space could hardly be more theatrical. Stretching 300 feet through two galleries of the Louvre, it leads from Michelangelo’s statue “The Dying Slave,” past the marble poses of Greek gods and Roman senators, to the foot of the grand staircase leading to “The Winged Victory of Samothrace.”

headline: Thomas’s Knicks Reign Appears Near an End
text: I had hoped that Isiah Lord Thomas would be the prince who turned the frog into a champion.

headline: Vote Is Postponed as Lebanese President Leaves
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Nov. 24 — The departing Lebanese president, Émile Lahoud, asked the military to take charge of the nation’s security on Friday, a few hours after the speaker of Parliament prolonged the country’s political crisis by postponing for a week a vote to choose a new president.

headline: Chris Long Depends on Hard Work More Than Famous Name
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 20 — Virginia defensive end Chris Long sat on a trainer’s table with an intravenous drip stuck in his left forearm. He had strep throat as well as a hesitancy to scale back, as evidenced by the 45-minute weightlifting session he had just completed.

headline: Russia: Deal for Nickel Complex
text: Three of Russia’s richest men are in advanced stages of negotiations over the sale of a 25 percent stake in the Norilsk Nickel mining and smelting complex in Siberia. The factory, built by gulag prisoners, produces 20 percent of the world’s supply of nickel, an alloy used in stainless steel.

headline: Broadway Now Brighter as ‘The Grinch’ Reopens
text: The stagehands’ strike had most of the theaters on West 44th Street dark. The Majestic Theater, home to “The Phantom of the Opera,” and the Shubert, festooned with posters for “Monty Python’s Spamalot,” stood empty.

headline: The Continuing Cult of Glenn Gould, Deserved or Not
text: When Glenn Gould died unexpectedly in 1982, a victim of a stroke at the unseemly age of 50, his red-hot reputation had calmed to a simmer. Gould, a sufferer from extreme stage fright but a winner in the stock market, had quit performing in public 18 years earlier, using the proceeds of his financial ventures to soften the burdens of early retirement. Much of his time later was spent with television projects in his native Toronto, not all of which had to do with the piano.

headline: Transit Strike Across France Winds Down
text: PARIS, Nov. 23  The transportation strike that snarled traffic, shortened tempers and frayed the fabric of daily life in France for 10 days wound down on Friday, with most trains, buses and subways rumbling back into service.

headline: Far From Beijing’s Reach, Officials Bend Energy Rules
text: QINGTONGXIA, China — When the central government in Beijing announced an ambitious nationwide campaign to reduce energy consumption two years ago, officials in this western regional capital got right to work: not to comply, but to engineer creative schemes to evade the requirements.

headline: Courthouse Bombings Strike 3 Indian Cities
text: NEW DELHI, Nov. 23 — At least 13 people were killed and more than 60 were wounded Friday in a series of nearly simultaneous bomb blasts outside courthouses in three cities in northern India, the authorities said.

headline: An American in Paris, Making Classical Dance Training (Gasp!) Fun
text: PARIS — Brooke Desnoës was 10 or 11 when her parents sought to enroll her in the Alabama Ballet School. “Can you frog?” asked Sonia Arova, the star ballerina turned teacher. What Ms. Arova meant, in ballet parlance, was could she lie on her tummy and splay her legs like a frog, a test to see if she had the flexibility to dance. Puzzled, young Brooke crouched down like a frog and began hopping around the room. “She died laughing,” Ms. Desnoës said.

headline: New Jersey Company That Recalled Hamburger Meat Declares Bankruptcy
text: The Topps Meat Company of Elizabeth, N.J., which nearly two months ago recalled 21.7 million pounds of hamburger meat, has declared bankruptcy, according to papers filed on Wednesday in federal bankruptcy court in Newark.

headline: A Brooklyn Arena and the Street: What’s the Right Distance?
text: Throughout the contentious prehistory of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, just about every fact and figure about the planned development has been passionately debated, from the height of its tallest building, to the number of apartments that will be affordable to those of modest means, to the amount of taxpayer financing it will require.

headline: Shortsighted Management
text: SENIOR managements that focus on immediate results have been blamed for ethical lapses and shortchanging their companies’ future. But that may be only the start of the story.

headline: Netherlands: Akzo Offers to Sell Assets
text: Akzo Nobel, the world’s largest maker of paints and coatings, has offered to sell assets including its British Crown brand to win European antitrust approval for its proposed $16 billion purchase of Imperial Chemical Industries.

headline: In Bush’s Last Year, Modest Domestic Aims
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  As President Bush looks toward his final year in office, with Democrats controlling Congress and his major domestic initiatives dead on Capitol Hill, he is shifting his agenda to what aides call “kitchen table issues”  small ideas that affect ordinary people’s lives and do not take an act of Congress to put in place.

headline: The War on Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kerik Loan Activity Is Brought to Light After Indictment
text: Bernard B. Kerik fully repaid a $250,000 personal loan cited in his recent federal indictment days after city investigators began asking about it in 2005, according to people who have been briefed on the transaction.

headline: Jump the Shark
text: WHILE there are, admittedly, figures more deserving of sympathy than unemployed pool players, the demise of the hustler is an occasion to be mourned. As recently as 10 years ago, it was possible for a pool player to earn a living hustling, provided he was armed with the requisite chops and disposition. Plenty of “roadmen” made plenty of money with scores at Chelsea Billiards in Manhattan or Mikey’s 24/7 in Oklahoma City or the Sports Palace in Columbia, S.C. Odds were good that there was at least one unsuspecting local in the joint with an inflated impression of his talent for pocketing balls, and thus a willingness to throw down “big timber” against the out-of-towner.

headline: There Are Alternatives: Insuring to Bridge the Gap or Opting Out
text: One way for Medicare Part D enrollees to deal with the “doughnut hole” is to insure themselves against it. Another way is to simply not get involved with Part D in the first place.

headline: The Tale of the Tuna
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Many Errors in Thinking About Mistakes
text: OF the many mistakes I have no doubt made over the last few weeks, two stand out: One cost me money and one cost me some pride.

headline: Municipal Fraud Inquiry Clouds Washington Anew
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 — It takes a lifetime to build a reputation — and a moment to destroy it.

headline: Robert McNair, Governor of South Carolina in the ’60s, Dies at 83
text: CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 23 — Former Gov. Robert E. McNair of South Carolina, the political moderate who was a finalist to become Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey’s running mate in 1968 but whose promising career was cut short by what became known as the Orangeburg Massacre, died last Saturday in Charleston. He was 83.

headline: A Revisionist Historian Looks at Religious Toleration
text: At this moment, there may be no more important story than the one Europeans and Americans proudly tell themselves about the rise of religious toleration. So please take note of Benjamin J. Kaplan’s argument that the story may be dangerously flawed.

headline: Taking Science on Faith
text: Tempe, Ariz.

headline: Two Blasts Target Pakistani Military
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 24 — Two suicide car bombers attacked military targets this morning in Rawalpindi, the site of military headquarters, killing at least 15 service personnel, a military spokesman said. The bombings raise tensions in the country, which is already beset with political and security problems.

headline: Britain: Banks Buy Utility
text: JPMorgan Chase and Commonwealth Bank of Australia agreed to buy the United Utilities power-distribution unit in Britain for £1.14 billion ($2.34 billion), adding electricity customers to their British water assets.

headline: For Film Companies, a State of Flux
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 — When Brad Pitt dropped out of the political thriller “State of Play” at the 11th hour on Wednesday, he did more than throw a wrench into the works of one of the highest-profile movie productions under way in a Hollywood already overheated by strike-related contingency planning. He might have helped tip the balance of power between actors and studios, at least temporarily, in the employers’ favor.

headline: Bearing Aid, U.S. Vows to Tread Lightly in Bangladesh
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Nov. 23 — As an American warship with more than 3,000 troops arrived off the coast of Bangladesh to help deliver food, water and medicine to the most remote corners of this cyclone-battered country, United States military officials took pains on Friday to say they would not take any steps that might seem intrusive.

headline: Asking Hard Questions About Iraq
text: To the Editor:

headline: Theft of Grave Markers Spurs Outrage and Call for Crackdown
text: CAYUGA, N.Y. — Under the outstretched limbs of oaks, Revolutionary-era headstones, some covered with lichen, tilt this way and that, while new monuments reveal the doting attentions of the living. As resting places go, Lake View Cemetery is special: five acres where generations of local families lie buried beside the clear waters of Cayuga Lake.

headline: The Circus Is in Town. All Over It, in Fact, in Six Troupes.
text: For three decades, the Big Apple Circus has virtually owned the Christmas-circus season, and has brought its one-ring show to Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center since 1980, after three years in considerably less iconic locales.

headline: One Way to Help
text: Last January, The Times profiled a bright young woman named Wanda Reynoso, a teenager whose bone marrow disorder left her weakened and ill.

headline: Subways Increasingly Running Late; Problem Is Worst During Morning Rush
text: More and more subway trains have been running behind schedule this year, part of a trend that has seen the number of late trains increase every year since 2004, according to data compiled by New York City Transit.

headline: A Year Later, Poisoned Agent’s Family Accuse Russia
text: LONDON, Nov. 23 — On a day of private grief and public anger, the family and friends of Alexander Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer poisoned in London a year ago, identified a Russian nuclear plant for the first time on Friday as the likely source of the radioactive isotope that killed him.

headline: Detective Misses 5 Calls to Testify in Beating
text: Despite a court order, a police detective has repeatedly failed to show up to give a deposition in a Brooklyn man’s lawsuit charging police brutality. Now the city says the detective has retired and cannot be found, an explanation that has failed to satisfy the judge overseeing the case.

headline: Saudis to Join Mideast Talks; Syria Wavers
text: CAIRO, Nov. 23 — Saudi Arabia joined 14 other Arab nations on Friday in an agreement to attend the American-sponsored Middle East peace conference in Annapolis, Md., next week, while Syria — the last key holdout — was inching closer toward agreeing to participate.

headline: Australia: Election Day
text: Australians are voting today in general elections that are expected to bring the end of 11 years in power for Prime Minister John Howard, one of President Bush’s closest allies. But opinion polls showed that Mr. Howard had closed some of the gap between his coalition and the Labor Party led by Kevin Rudd. Mr. Howard campaigned on his economic record, saying a Labor victory would threaten Australia’s prosperity. Mr. Rudd has said that one of his first steps if elected would be to negotiate a withdrawal of the country’s 500 troops in Iraq.

headline: Turning Things Around, and Up a Notch
text: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 18 — The new coach at the University of Evansville stalked the court one afternoon last week, clapping his hands, waving his arms, urging his young team to play tougher defense. At 6 feet 5 inches and about 300 pounds, Marty Simmons moved from the baseline to midcourt at Roberts Municipal Stadium, sweaty and scowling, before finally halting practice and bellowing, “Get over here.”

headline: Congressman Sees Bias in Chicago Traffic Stop
text: CHICAGO, Nov. 23 — A black Congressman who was issued a ticket this week after being pulled over while driving with three black passengers has accused the Chicago police of racial profiling in the traffic stop.

headline: Theatergoers Rejoice at Return of the Grinch
text: The ongoing stagehands’ strike had most of the theaters on West 44th Street dark. The Majestic Theater, home to “The Phantom of the Opera,” and the Shubert, festooned with posters for “Monty Python’s Spamalot,” stood empty. But the sidewalk outside the St. James Theater, where “Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical” reopened for an 11 a.m. Friday matinee, was thronged.

headline: The Wary Skies of Modern Travelers
text: Predictions that five million travelers will lose pieces of checked luggage at some point this year provide depressing food for thought as we line up belt-free and shoeless, clutching the see-through bags of mini-measured toiletry vials that are demanded of modern air travelers. There is plenty of time, while creeping through the security maze, to ruminate over questions like whether potential terrorists have the same preoccupations as the Homeland Security authorities who issue their increasingly detailed instructions.

headline: Bland Menu if Cable Goes à la Carte
text: Twice in the last few months, I’ve written columns about the bitter “carriage dispute” between the NFL Network and the nation’s two largest cable companies, Comcast and Time Warner. This column, I swear, is not going to be the third in a series. As annoyed as I remain over the tactics of the National Football League, I’ve had my say.

headline: With Thomas’s Job in Question, the Knicks Snap Streak
text: The worst Knicks losing streak in two seasons mercifully ended Saturday afternoon when they finally found a team in worse shape than they are.

headline: Knicks Face Bulls; Thomas Faces Fans

text: MILBRIDGE, Me. — They have worked since their teens in backbreaking seasonal jobs, extracting resources from the sea and the forest. Their yards are filled with peeling boats and broken lobster traps.

The Musical” referred imprecisely to a decision by the chain to impose new work rules last month on stagehands, who are now on strike. While it did not impose them on stagehands at the St. James, it did on the stagehands at its other four Broadway theaters.

headline: Britain: Slower Growth in Third Quarter
text: Britain’s economic growth unexpectedly slowed to the weakest pace in a year during the third quarter as service industries cooled and factory production stalled. Gross domestic product rose 0.7 percent in the three months through September, the Office for National Statistics said in London.

headline: F.D.A. Staff Recommends a Warning on Flu Drugs
text: Makers of the two most common drugs used to treat and prevent flu should add warnings that they may cause psychiatric side effects, federal regulators have recommended.

headline: Symphony Will Sell a Collection in Dispute
text: A group of investors, including businessmen who are twin brothers and amateur violinists, have agreed to buy a controversial collection of rare string instruments from the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. The investors are to pay the orchestra $20 million and a share of the proceeds from the instruments’ future sale.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Saturday about an illegal immigrant mother who was separated from her baby, an American citizen, after a search by immigration agents in Ohio misstated the minimum age when American citizens can petition for their parents to immigrate legally to this country. It is 21, not 18. (Go to Article)

headline: Citing Weak Dollar, Airbus Chief Talks of More Cost Cuts

headline: Publisher Gets Web Readers to Fill the Pages of Its Magazines
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 — A funny thing happened while Halsey Minor was trying to kill print journalism. He ended up publishing magazines — big, heavy magazines, with beautiful pictures on quality paper — the kind he and others had declared obsolete.

headline: Top-Ranked L.S.U. Falls; Title Picture Is Blurred
text: Unranked Arkansas stunned top-ranked Louisiana State in Baton Rouge, La., yesterday, further scrambling the national championship race and continuing a season-long pattern of upheaval in college football.

headline: Selling Jewelry Is Mostly Pitfalls, Not Much Glitter

headline: L.A. Auto Show: Driving Honda’s Fuel-Cell FCX
text: LOS ANGELES — Before hustling off to LAX for my flight home from the auto show last Sunday, I spent a morning driving what may be the most advanced road vehicle on the planet: the Honda FCX Clarity. This fuel-cell-powered car, unveiled in production-ready form at the convention center earlier in the week, will be built in small numbers and leased next summer to retail customers for their everyday use.

headline: Saturday Kickoff: Nebraska Fires Callahan
text: To the surprise of no one, Bill Callahan is out as Nebraska’s head football coach. Tom Osborne announced Callahan’s firing this morning, a day after the Cornhuskers lost 65-51 at Colorado to complete a 5-7 season. Brian Christopherson of the Lincoln Journal Star reports that Nebraska has already contacted the current L.S.U. defensive coordinator and former Cornhuskers defensive coordinator Bo Pelini about the job.

headline: The ‘Greench’ Who Guilt-Tripped Christmas

text: Virginia defensive end Chris Long admits he is quite competitive. The former Dallas Cowboys executive Gil Brandt witnessed this firsthand last May, when Long was riding a mechanical bull at a Playboy party.

text: The drawings, cartoon sketches and other work of Saul Steinberg show off the range of an artist as closely attuned to 20th-century American life as almost anyone.

headline: Personnel File: Once Again, Dayne Makes a Late Arrival
text: With the season’s end drawing near, it is once again time for Ron Dayne, a backup running back for the Texans, to stand tall. In the team’s past two games, Dayne, filling in for the injured Ahman Green, has rumbled for 211 yards and a touchdown. Similarly, from Weeks 13 through 16 last season, Dayne amassed 429 yards and 5 touchdowns.

headline: Week 12 in Preview: Buccaneers Face a Test of Their Progress
text: Going by division standings, the game between the Buccaneers and the Redskins today in Tampa, Fla., is a matchup of the first-place team in the National Football Conference South and a team tied for last place in the N.F.C East. But Tampa Bay (6-4) and Washington (5-5) are separated by only one game in the conference standings, and winning this game is vital to each team’s playoff hopes.

headline: Welcome to Morgantown, Center of the Universe
text: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — Here at the foot of the Allegheny Mountains, they are starting to party like it’s 1988.That’s the last time the Mountaineers had such a clear shot at the national title. That Major Harris-led team lost to Notre Dame in the Fiesta Bowl.If West Virginia defeats Connecticut today and Pittsburgh next week, it will most likely play for the national title on Jan. 7 in New Orleans. That notion hasn’t been lost on the locals.Zippy Shearer, a member of that 1988 team, said in the parking lot before the game that folks at a local Buffalo Wild Wings last night celebrated Arkansas’s upset of top-ranked Louisiana State by hoisting chairs in the air. The Arkansas victory put West Virginia, which entered the week No. 3 in the Bowl Championship Series, into the top two.“Our run came a little more out of nowhere,” Shearer said in comparing his team with the current team. “They were ranked to start the season.”The feeling that the Mountaineers are on the cusp of something special could be felt throughout the parking lots surrounding Milan Puskar Stadium.Bill Henderson had just finished deep-frying a turkey at his tailgate, which was marked by the pirate flag hanging over the trailer. He said the main talk of the morning was about making flight and hotel reservations for New Orleans.“There’s a lot more anxiety,” he said when asked the difference between today’s tailgate and most others.A few yards away, Greg Stevens was sipping Crown Royal from a plastic cup and savoring the moment. He has been a season-ticket holder for 20 years, and before that he patrolled the sidelines while working for the West Virginia State Police. He said he thought that the Mountaineers would beat Connecticut by 14 points. When Pittsburgh comes here next weekend, it could be a different story, however.“The backyard brawl is never easy,” Stevens said.He took another sip of Crown Royal and continued soaking in the rarefied air in Morgantown, the improbable center of the college football universe.

headline: Week 12 Fantasy Football Picks
text: So I had a couple misses on Thanksgiving. Clemens, Cotchery, Leon Washington for three. (Man, I really underestimated just how bad the Jets really are). But I’m still glowing like a debutante opening a Tiffany box about my dead-on call of Anthony Gonzalez’s 6 catch/105 yard game. I’m going to put that and last week’s Vince Young prediction on my gravestone. Which is kind of pathetic considering that those fantasy stats will bump things like “Loving Father” and “Devoted Husband.” I think my priorities might be a tad askew.

headline: Clinton Takes On Student Loan Industry
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton had some tough words Saturday afternoon for the college student loan industry, saying banks and other lenders had “ripped off” students with high interest rates and repayment plans that were onerous on recent graduates and their families.

text: MORGANTOWN, W. Va. — What would November be without some serious debate about college football? So we at The Quad want to know how you think West Virginia stacks up with Ohio State.

text: A platoon from the 82nd Airborne Division searched for Taliban fighters with Afghan security forces.

headline: Obama and Clinton Tangle Over Health Care
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa – As they campaigned in western Iowa today, two Democratic presidential rivals gently tangled over their health care plans, with Senator Barack Obama drawing criticism from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton after suggesting his plan would cut costs and help consumers more “than any other proposal in this race.”

headline: Radio Interview With ‘Relative Choices’ Writers
text: Listen to an interview on National Public Radio’s Talk of the Nation with three writers from “Relative Choices” — Katy Robinson, Jeff Gammage and Sumeia Williams, first broadcast on Nov. 20. The writers discuss their personal experiences with adoption and the stories they have shared this month.

headline: The Song of the Hunted Humpback Whale
text: The clash between Japan and many Western nations over killing whales clicked up another notch last week. As Japanese whalers, claiming to operate under the mantle of science, steamed toward waters near Antarctica, one of the new species on their harvest list was the humpback — a whale whose eerie song became a platinum-selling recording and whose full-body breaches are a draw for whale watching fleets worldwide.

headline: Chadron State 76, Abilene Christian 73. Honest.
text: Remember Danny Woodhead of tiny Chadron State in Nebraska? He was involved in one of the most exciting games in N.C.A.A. playoff history yesterday, when Chadron State rallied from a 29-point deficit to defeat visiting Abilene Christian, 76-73, in three overtimes.

headline: Ada Sheng, Brad Williams
text: Ada Yue-Hong Sheng, a daughter of Deborah W. Sheng and Ping Sheng of Princeton, N.J., and Hong Kong, was married on Tuesday to Dr. William Bradford Williams, a son of Carolyn L. Williams of Raleigh, N.C., and Bill C. Williams of Wilmington, N.C. Morris E. Lasker, a Federal District Court judge in Boston, officiated in his chambers. In August, Sujit Raman, a friend of the couple, led a ceremony at Prospect House, the faculty club at Princeton University, where the bride’s father gave a Chinese blessing.

headline: Raha Ramezani and James Brown
text: Raha Ramezani, the daughter of Mojgan and Mohammed Reza Ramezani of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to James Patrick Brown, a son of Linda and James Brown of Dover, N.J. The Rev. Leslie Harry, an interfaith minister, officiated at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan, where Jaleh Moslehi led a Persian cultural ceremony.

headline: Thompson Woos Gun Rights Contingent
text: LADSON, S.C., Nov. 24  Joe McCormick, a burly man over six feet tall, a World War II-era Mauser rifle at his side, said he was frightened.

headline: In Europe, Fractional Properties Have Room to Grow
text: Claus Soerensen became a fractional owner of a second home before the term was even coined. Years ago, Mr. Soerensen inherited a share of a vacation house that had once belonged to his great-grandfather. When other heirs sold their shares, he essentially owned the house in common with strangers.

headline: Correction: The Devil Went Down to Broadway
text: An article on Nov. 11 about the play “The Seafarer” misidentified the speaker of a line in Marlowe’s “Doctor Faustus.” It was a line from Mephostophilis, who is a messenger to Lucifer in the play, not Satan.

headline: Décor, Not Food, Gets the Edge
text: PAUL GARBUIO, the owner of Piave, a handsome new restaurant and bar, has an eye for décor. The best part of dining in Café Antico, his previous restaurant, was the romantic edge provided by dozens of candles multiplied in the reflection of the polished glass walls.

headline: Letters
text: Great Is the Truth

headline: Correction: The Week Ahead: Nov. 18-24
text: A dance entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday about a performance by Complexions Contemporary Ballet included outdated program information. The Rennie Harris piece “Endangered Species” was no longer on the program, and two works by Dwight Rhoden, “Precious Blood” and “Lament,” were added.

headline: The Afterbath
text: ROSIE PEREZ prides herself on her waitressing skills and her ability to make a perfect mojito, but on a trek to Socialista, the West Village restaurant and lounge, she was content to have someone else serve her. Ms. Perez — the choreographer turned actress turned documentary filmmaker — was fresh from a performance of “The Ritz,” a revival of the Terrence McNally comedy in which she stars as a bathhouse chanteuse. “The Ritz” is one of the few Broadway shows unaffected by the stagehands’ strike.

headline: The Butler Could Do It
text: PERHAPS you have heard of getting a free gift with a purchase? Now the purveyors of a $45 million triplex condominium atop a 60-story glass tower facing Madison Square Park have taken that concept to a new level: free butler with purchase.

headline: The Church in England: Downright Un-American
text: BATH, England

headline: Jody Beck, Ross-Alan Tisdale
text: Jody Beck, the daughter of Dr. Ruth Hanno Beck and Dr. Roy W. Beck of Tampa, Fla., was married at the home of her parents last evening to Ross-Alan Tisdale, a son of Donna-Francine Tisdale and Alan Tisdale of Daytona Beach, Fla. Rabbi Richard J. Birnholz officiated.

headline: A Time to Rethink AIDS’s Grip
text: IGNORE the fuss over the news last week — the United Nations’ AIDS-fighting agency admits to overestimating the global epidemic by six million people. That was a sampling error, an epidemiologist’s Dewey Defeats Truman.

headline: Correction
text: An article in the Arts & Leisure section last Sunday about the No Music Day campaign in Britain included several incorrect references to Muzak, the company that sells prerecorded background music.

headline: Ally of Bush Is Defeated in Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 24 — Australia’s prime minister, John Howard, one of President Bush’s staunchest allies in Asia, suffered a comprehensive defeat at the hands of the electorate on Saturday, as his Liberal Party-led coalition lost its majority in Parliament.

headline: Books of Style
text: THE BLACK DRESS

headline: When Ownership of a Home Turns Negative
text: When you buy a house, it isn’t supposed to work this way. Among homes bought in the last year, nearly 16 percent are now worth less than the amount of the original mortgage, according to third-quarter data from Zillow, a real estate research firm.

headline: Looking for ‘Green’ Lights in the Suburbs
text: HARDING TOWNSHIP, N.J.

headline: Barbecue, Brazilian-Style
text: WHEN Marcia’s Kitchen opened in Huntington Village in mid-August, it created a buzz. Everyone was talking about this small storefront that served huge portions of moderately priced Brazilian food.

headline: Yankees and Rodriguez Receive Approval for Deal
text: Four weeks after Alex Rodriguez walked away from his contract with the Yankees, he and the club have gained approval for a marketing deal tied to his home run milestones, the last significant step in completing a contract that restores Rodriguez to the Yankees’ roster.

headline: Aboard Planes, Class Conflict
text: OVER the past few years — and this will probably come as no surprise to anyone who has gotten on a plane over this Thanksgiving weekend — flying in coach has become an increasingly miserable experience. Legroom is practically nonexistent. Passengers are more tightly packed together. Hot meals have been eliminated. Ditto pillows and blankets. And the next time that guy in front of you leans his seat back directly into your face, few of your fellow passengers are likely to blame you if you feel a brief, murderous urge to strike back.

headline: Smoking Guns and Mushroom Clouds
text: It is a reasonable assumption that three nuclear powers, the United States, India and Israel, have prepared a variety of more or less robust contingency plans to neutralize Ptakistan’s nuclear arsenal of some 40 or so warheads, should Islamist militants appear to threaten the regime of President Pervez Musharraf. There have been ominous signs that other Middle Eastern states, including Egypt, Turkey and Saudi Arabia, are considering their own nuclear options as they contemplate a future that may feature a nuclear-armed Iran.

headline: Week 12 in Preview
text: SAINTS at PANTHERS

headline: Homing In
text: Though the Israeli author Meir Shalev attracts a primarily Jewish readership in the United States, his new novel, translated by Evan Fallenberg, is less concerned with the intricacies of a particular religion than with the question of what any person needs in order to be happy. “A Pigeon and a Boy” may be filled with references to Jewish traditions, but it’s told from a distinctly secular point of view — that of Yair Mendelsohn, an Israeli tour guide who sees himself as a casualty of modern life.

headline: Paul Roche, Poet in Bloomsbury Group, Is Dead at 91
text: Paul Roche, a noted English poet and translator who was among the last living associates of the Bloomsbury group, the skein of artists and writers twined around Virginia Woolf and her family, died on Oct. 30 at his home in Sóller, Majorca. He was 91.

headline: Bulls Go Cold, and Season Starts Black and Blue
text: Forward Andres Nocioni slumped at his locker after the Chicago Bulls’ latest loss, covered from knees to toes in ice. Bags hung on his kneecaps. His knees extended into an orange cooler, its contents so cold that his feet turned bright red.

headline: When Solar Power Is Short on Charm
text: BELLEROSE

headline: You’ve Got (No) Mail!
text: To the Editor:

headline: What You Get for ...$20 Million
text: Jupiter Island, Fla.

headline: Correction: The Perils of Petrocracy
text: A picture caption on Nov. 4 with a contents entry for an article about Venezuela and its nationalized oil misidentified a piece of equipment used in oil fields. It is a pump jack, not a drilling rig.

headline: Another Top Tennis Star Takes a Shot at Real Estate
text: Juan Carlos Ferrero of Spain and Andre Agassi were each ranked No. 1 in professional tennis in 2003. Now Mr. Ferrero appears to share Mr. Agassi’s passion for real estate. In September, Mr. Ferrero opened a luxury hotel near Valencia, Spain. (Mr. Agassi and his wife, Steffi Graf — another top-ranked tennis star — have hotels being built in Costa Rica and in Idaho.) Four years ago, at the urging of Antonio Martínez, his coach, Mr. Ferrero bought a 19th-century house and 120,000 square feet of land. They renovated for three years, spending seven million euros, about $11,720,000. The hotel — with a periwinkle exterior and a light-drenched, modern interior — has 12 suites, a swimming pool, a spa, two restaurants and, of course, tennis courts. Rates start at 250 euros a night (www.hotelferrero.com).

headline: Letters: Disappearing Into the Desert
text: As creative director of NASA’s Voyager Interstellar Message project, I wish to thank Nicole Krauss (Nov. 11) for her elegant description of our work and to clarify one statement she makes. The Voyagers are leaving our solar system but not the vastly larger Milky Way galaxy — unless, of course, they happen to be flagged down by the music-loving intergalactic travelers of some more advanced extraterrestrial civilization.

headline: Coast Guard Searches for Source of Long Island Oil Spill
text: Environmental crews using shovels and mesh scoops yesterday cleaned up the last remnants of a mysterious crude oil spill that began washing ashore in gooey blobs three days ago in Nassau County, the Coast Guard reported.

headline: A Congested Economy
text: Bellbrook, Ohio

headline: Puebla, Mexico: La Purificadora
text: THE BASICS

headline: Nedra Pickler, Eric Conner
text: Nedra Pickler and Eric Allen Conner were married yesterday in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. Maria de Lourdes Bravo Villanueca, a municipal judge, officiated at the Casa Schuck, a hotel.

headline: A Shift, but for Some Drivers, a Vicious Circle
text: Wall Township

headline: The Poor, Shortchanged Again
text: For anyone wanting an idea of how the poor get taken advantage of, the sad story of the Millard E. Terrell homes in Newark offers a graphic example.

headline: The Plight of the Part-Time Professor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pleased to Be Here
text: Run down to the bar and rouse the culture editor: the impossible has happened. In the dispiriting age of Bush and Britney, with our military still bogged down in Baghdad and our media still bewitched by Beverly Hills, an accomplished, respected American writer (a recent National Book Award Winner, in fact) has published a serious patriotic novel. Its title, “A Free Life,” is not altogether ironic. Its subject, everyday bravery and nobility in a system built on risk and too often based on mutual exploitation, is delivered straight. Finally, its Chinese-born author, Ha Jin (whose seven previous works of fiction have all been set abroad), seems positively pleased and proud to be here.

headline: Political Upheaval Follows a Rare Decision to Retire
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — New Mexicans like to hold on to their United States senators.

headline: At Odds Over Degrees of Assistance
text: WARMING centers began operating this month in Peekskill, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon as part of a campaign by the county to help get the chronically or “hard-to-place” homeless off the streets and into a shelter. Noticeably absent from the list, however, was White Plains, where local clergy members, homeless advocates and government officials are grappling with what constitutes fair treatment for those unable — or unwilling — to enter the county’s shelter system.

headline: Deborah Glasser, Adam Forchheimer
text: Deborah Lauren Glasser, the daughter of Alice and Steven T. Glasser of Plainview, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Irwin Forchheimer, a son of Rochelle and Mark V. Forchheimer, also of Plainview. Cantor Morris Wolk performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence in Lawrence, N.Y.

headline: ‘One-Word Review: Hilarious’
text: Overdreamt in New

headline: Talking About Sex. Then Again, Maybe Not.
text: NYACK, N.Y.

headline: A Remedy Against Vandals, but Now the Solution Is a Problem
text: EASTON

headline: Lisa Lalezarian, Richard Cohen
text: Lisa Lalezarian, a daughter of Flora and Frank Lalezarian of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Richard Manoochehr Cohen, a son of Joan and Edward Cohen of Katonah, N.Y. Rabbi Tom Weiner officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York, with Rabbi Howard J. Goldsmith taking part.

headline: Blind Woman Came to City for Marathon, and Stayed
text: Nihal Erkan’s eyes are nearly closed under the bill of her pink baseball cap.

headline: Art by the Beach, but No Sand Castles
text: ATTENDING Art Basel Miami Beach, the Lollapalooza of international art fairs, is a lot like going to college. You can party nonstop and still manage to get an amazing education. And the real action happens off campus.

headline: Neuberger, 104, Honored for Helping Young Artists
text: WHEN 104-year-old Roy R. Neuberger received a 2007 National Medal of Arts from President Bush in the East Room of the White House on Nov. 15, a large contingent of his extended family was on hand to celebrate the occasion. “He was also nominated last year,” his son James Neuberger said. “Luckily, he’s healthy.”

headline: Can a Co-op Sponsor Be an Officer?
text: Q Can a sponsor also be vice president of the co-op board? Isn’t this a conflict of interest?

headline: The Return of the Prince
text: Milford, Mich.

headline: Where Boys Grow Up to Be Jihadis
text: No one thought it was strange when Muncif Ben Aboud disappeared from his crowded, unkempt neighborhood in the Moroccan city of Tetouan. Men are always leaving Jamaa Mezuak, as the quarter is known. And Muncif, who was 21, had ventured off before, roaming the worn medinas of Casablanca and Marrakesh, posing stiffly for snapshots to take home. His curiosity pulled him in many directions. He was brilliant with numbers but would lose himself in novels. He began training to be a military pilot but then changed his mind and settled on engineering. A year later, in 2006, he switched to mathematics.

headline: Serendipity Transcends All Barriers
text: WHEN he was 20, Arturo Vidals told his father there were no good job opportunities in his hometown, Puebla, Mexico. “If you’re an eagle, then fly,” his father replied.

headline: Those City Report Cards: Did Good Schools Fail?; Battle Over Air Rights on the Upper East Side (5 Letters)
text: Those City Report Cards: Did Good Schools Fail?

headline: Discontent on a Tip of the Island at the Center of the World
text: ON a cold morning last week, bundled-up tourists strolled south along the East River from the South Street Seaport, past the pier where they could buy helicopter rides and the ornate Battery Maritime Building, where opaque green waves lapped against steel foundations.

headline: Injured in Iraq, a Soldier Hobbles Toward Recovery
text: FREDERICKSBURG, Va. — It is hard to know whether Master Sgt. Joseph Santiago was wincing from the pain creeping from the hole in his head to his atrophied legs or from the words of the politicians who were calling him a hero. After they were done commending his sacrifice on the battlefields of Iraq, he grabbed the microphone, handed his cane to his wife, and announced that he wanted to set the record straight.

headline: Constitutional Detour
text: "Hail to the Chief” has not always been No. 1 on the hit parade of American conservatives. In fact, for most of the 20th century, they viewed executive power as the great engine of an overreaching, war-prone federal leviathan. When liberals praised the energy and vision of crusading presidents like Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt and Lyndon Johnson, conservatives would wave The Federalist at them, warning of the dangers of royalism and insisting on the need for firm checks and balances as liberty’s safeguard.

headline: All Eyes on Durant
text: Second Pick at Forefront

headline: Idol of Evil
text: How did they get that way? That’s the natural question about history’s monsters. They all seem to start out the same as everyone else: “And who’s this little fellow in his itty-bitty robe? / That’s tiny baby Adolf, the Hitlers’ little boy!” as the Polish poet Wislawa Szymborska wrote. Many Georgian boys were beaten by their drunken fathers, but only one grew up to be Stalin. What were the factors of character and circumstance that made the crucial difference?

headline: You Can’t Hold It, but You Can Own It
text: ART can be defined, provocatively, as an intangible quantity that transforms an ordinary object — a urinal, a soup can, an unmade bed — into something worth many times more than its material value. Tino Sehgal seeks to isolate precisely that intangible quantity. His art is completely immaterial; it can be bought and sold without involving any objects whatsoever.

headline: 50 Years Ago, Modernism Was Given a Name: ‘Agon’
text: A MAN and a woman are alone onstage. He kneels, facing her, as if in fealty. She extends a leg high above his head like a sword, then rests it on his shoulder, perhaps in the traditional gesture with which a monarch dubs a squire a knight. (“Arise, Sir Arthur.”) But this scene isn’t medieval. She’s wearing black leotard and white tights; he has a white T-shirt over black tights. The music is 12-tone for strings playing without meter or pulse.

headline: Evangelicals Everywhere
text: In August, Washington watchers were titillated by a particularly fascinating insider account of the Bush White House: Matthew Scully, one former speechwriter, accused another, Michael Gerson, of egocentric careerism. It is not usually considered sinful in Washington to advance yourself; that is pretty much what the place is about. But Gerson, an evangelical Christian, had developed a reputation among the Washington press corps just this side of sainthood. One need not accept every word Scully wrote to conclude that Gerson had expended considerable energy on his own deification.

headline: The Lottery Industry’s Own Powerball
text: An article last Sunday about Rebecca Paul Hargrove, who has run state lotteries in Illinois, Florida, Georgia and now Tennessee, misstated a former title of her husband, Jere L. Hargrove. He was a Tennessee state representative, not state senator. The article also referred incorrectly to the location of two retailers that reflect Ms. Hargrove’s tastes as a consumer. The stores, Target and Tiffany’s, are across the street from each other in the Buckhead area of Atlanta, not in downtown Nashville.

headline: From Street to Scholar, a Writer Shows Off His Dexterity
text: JUNOT DÍAZ is up on the highest hill in Rome, the gift of a writing fellowship, far from the gritty neighborhood in Parlin, near Perth Amboy, where he grew up. As a boy, he spent hours reading everything he could in a local library. Yet, he says, he hung out on the street corners, half as a dodge to throw people off from his intellectual bent. He sometimes speaks in street argot, then switches abruptly to the precise language appropriate to the writing professor and novelist that he now is.

headline: Sampling the Best of the Northwest
text: THE dining room at Cascadia — one of Seattle's top restaurants, with a cutting-edge chef, luminous décor and a cellar lauded by Wine Spectator — was empty. No one sat on the green banquettes, eating Alaskan king crab with white-truffle gnocchi under the coppery mahogany paneling, and empty wineglasses sparkled on white tablecloths. Only an occasional wandering waiter disturbed this stillness.

headline: Pigeon Paranoia
text: WHILE a proposal by Councilman Simcha Felder, a Democrat from Brooklyn, to ban the feeding of pigeons in New York City — and fine the violators — may speak to those who detest the humble rock dove, the proposition itself is sadly misguided.

headline: Correction: Muslims on TV, No Terror in Sight
text: An article on Nov. 11 about the portrayal of Muslims on television misstated the month “Little Mosque on the Prairie” returned for its second season. It was in October, not November.

headline: The Latte War Around the Corner
text: JOU JOU CAFE is a bustling coffee shop on West 168th Street near Broadway. With its big, midpriced sandwiches and the usual array of flavored lattes, it is a favorite of the dangling-ID-card set from NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center down the block. And like many blocks of Washington Heights, this one has changed drastically since early 2001, when Jou Jou opened.

headline: A Web Tour Will Show Stores From the Inside Out
text: THREE-DIMENSIONAL mapping programs like Google Earth let people fly over the rooftops of virtual cities, and other online services lead them down individual streets.

headline: Jolly and Green, With an Agenda
text: LAST Christmas, Donna Hoffman, an ardent environmentalist who lives in Austin, Tex., came up with an unlikely gift for each member of her family: an energy-efficient compact fluorescent light bulb.

headline: A Touch Lighter
text: If those second helpings of Thanksgiving turkey left you craving lighter fare, consider these places in Astoria, Queens, for small plates of mezedes, or Greek tapas.

headline: Samantha Miller, Warren Bloom
text: Samantha Moriah Miller and Warren Jeffrey Bloom were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Jaymee D. Alpert officiated.

headline: Hard to Be an Audiophile in an iPod World
text: IN the heyday of the stereophonic recording boom, during the 1960s and later, there were several magazines for serious classical music buffs with reviews of almost every new recording. But what truly defined these publications, like High Fidelity and Stereo Review, were critical reports on stereo equipment. The big advertising bucks came from the makers of hi-fi equipment, and well more than half the pages of such magazines were devoted to coverage of the latest stereo system products.

headline: Town Resists Bidding Farewell to Beloved Diner
text: New Rochelle

headline: Paperback Row
text: WHAT WAS ASKED OF US: An Oral History of the Iraq War, by the Soldiers Who Fought It, by Trish Wood. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.99.) Wood, a Canadian investigative reporter, interviewed 29 American veterans of the Iraq war. The men and women came from different personal and ideological backgrounds, but their descriptions of their experience all display a sense of duty and courage in the face of war’s violence. Funny and horrible, coarse and colloquial, the soldiers’ accounts are “honest, agenda-free and chilling,” Tara McKelvey wrote in the Book Review.

headline: Developer Duets
text: NOT only does he come from a family of developers, but these days it also seems that Scott H. Rechler is the developer’s developer.

headline: A Touch of Tokyo, but Very California
text: SANTA MONICA

headline: In Maine, a Hardy Few Are Still Stalking Ducks in a Time-Honored Way
text: BOWDOINHAM, Me., Nov. 23 — There are wild goose chases, and then there are extremely deliberate ones. One hunter who prefers the deliberate ones is Alfred Hall of Topsham, Me.

headline: As Democrats See Security Gains in Iraq, Tone Shifts
text: As violence declines in Baghdad, the leading Democratic presidential candidates are undertaking a new and challenging balancing act on Iraq: acknowledging that success, trying to shift the focus to the lack of political progress there, and highlighting more domestic concerns like health care and the economy.

headline: Blame the Borrowers? Not So Fast
text: IT has become fashionable of late to say that America’s subprime borrowers themselves deserve a good part of the blame for the current mortgage mess. They were either greedy (looking for easy money in a bubbly real estate market) or irresponsible (assuming a debt whose terms they did not understand).

headline: Knicks Finally End Slide, but They’re Not Off Slope
text: A new feeling swept through Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, something that was neither elation nor misery and not easily defined. Cautious joy? Angst-riddled relief? Modest merriment?

headline: Amid the Willows and Chickadees, Bird-Watchers Spot a Red Flag
text: ONE recent morning, a 52-year-old computer technician and amateur naturalist named Rob Jett tucked a pair of binoculars and “The Sibley Field Guide to Birds of Eastern North America” into his bag and headed out of his Park Slope apartment for the F train.

headline: Attacks on Pakistani Military Kill 15
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 24 — Two suicide car bombers attacked military targets on Saturday morning in Rawalpindi, the site of the military’s headquarters, killing at least 15 service members, a military spokesman said. The bombings raised tensions in the country, which is already beset with political and security problems.

headline: Holiday Sales Climb, but Shoppers Spend Less
text: Black Friday was big — but with a big caveat.

headline: Media Studies
text: Q: Although you’re known best as the author of the highbrow murder mystery “The Name of the Rose,” you’re also a prolific political commentator whose essays have now been collected in a book, “Turning Back the Clock,” in which you warn against the dangers of “media populism.” How would you define that term? Media populism means appealing to people directly through media. A politician who can master the media can shape political affairs outside of parliament and even eliminate the mediation of parliament.

headline: West Virginia Wins Big East and Sets Sights on a Bigger Title
text: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Nov. 24  The leaves have mostly fallen here at the foot of the Allegheny Mountains. The barren trees set behind Milan Puskar Stadium offer a fitting backdrop as winter beckons in this cozy college town. In this season of incessant and unpredictable change in college football, No. 4 West Virginia has become the latest team to improbably thrust itself to the forefront of the national title race.

headline: A Defiant Coffee Shop Stares Back at Starbucks
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.

headline: William O’Neill, a Connecticut Governor, Is Dead at 77
text: William Atchison O’Neill, the son of a small-town tavern owner who rose through Connecticut politics to serve as governor for a decade, died yesterday. He was 77.

headline: Letters: Jewish Marrakesh
text: To the Editor: Marrakesh is surely a visitor’s delight for reasons you give in “36 Hours in Marrakesh, Morocco” (Nov. 11). You should add that the Jewish sites are just as exciting and deserve more mention than lunch next to the former Jewish quarter.

headline: Julie Krasnogor, Tamir Daniel
text: Julie Beth Krasnogor, a daughter of Norine and Lester Krasnogor of Stamford, Conn., is to be married this evening to Tamir Daniel, a son of Yael and Itzhak Daniel of Petah Tikva, Israel. Rabbi David Nadav will officiate at Cassiopeia, an event space in Herzliya Pituach, Israel.

headline: Suddenly, Connecticut Is Stem Cell Central
text: FARMINGTON

headline: Heaping Helping of Americana
text: TESTED 2008 Hummer H3 Alpha

headline: In Afghanistan, Hunt for Militants Can Be a Slog
text: ESPANDI, Afghanistan, Nov. 18 — First Lt. Aaron W. Childers stood before a doorway inside a mud-walled compound while an Afghan and American patrol searched behind him. Paratroopers swept metal detectors over the dusty ground, looking for buried weapons and ammunition.

headline: If Truman Were Here
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Goodbye to Paper Airline Tickets Is Speeding Up
text: China is the front-runner in the global race to convert from paper to e-tickets, according to a representative of the International Air Transport Association. Earlier this year, the association placed its final order for paper tickets — 16.5 million — to keep airlines supplied until the world goes paperless on June 1. After that date, paper tickets will no longer be available, except in very rare cases.

headline: Movie Deals
text: It’s high season for Oscar bait, and multiplexes are filled with literary adaptations, including the Coen brothers’ bloody take on Cormac McCarthy’s “No Country for Old Men” and Mike Newell’s film of Gabriel García Márquez’s “Love in the Time of Cholera.” Coming later this fall are big-screen versions of Ian McEwan’s “Atonement,” Philip Pullman’s “Golden Compass” and Marjane Satrapi’s “Persepolis,” among others.

headline: Gay Playwrights
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Big Sleep
text: Oxford, England

headline: Farmyard Stills Quench a Thirst for Local Spirits
text: ATCHISON, Kan. — The main still of the High Plains liquor company here was scraped together from junked parts of an old food processing plant. The tubing for the bottling equipment had been used to milk cows, and one of the tanks was actually an industrial vacuum cleaner.

headline: Letters: The Turning of an Atheist
text: Mark Oppenheimer (Nov. 4) mentions me as a source for “the science” that “turned” Antony Flew from skeptic to believer. Some people may believe that Flew, being old and therefore possibly senile, was duped by this “pseudoscience.”

headline: An Exhilarating Tease, but Really Just a Game
text: Donald Muller, the 12-year-old at the center of the 90-minute thrill ride that is “Doubt,” never shows up on the stage. But even if he did, the TheaterWorks audience, in Hartford, would be hard-pressed to figure out which of the play’s four adults is truly looking out for him.

headline: Parallel Processor
text: One of the most closely read chronicles of Silicon Valley over the past year or so has been “The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs,” a running satire written by an anonymous blogger who assumed the persona of Apple’s brilliant, enlightenment-seeking co-founder and chief executive.

headline: Why He Moved Into My Car, and Why I Let Him
text: IN the early ’90s, when I moved to New York, I brought my car with me. Being from the New Jersey suburbs, I felt that a car was like an essential organ. It was not something I was prepared to give up.

headline: Rumbling Across India to a New Life in the City
text: ABOARD THE PUSHPAK EXPRESS, India — The man with neatly parted hair stood in the doorway of the hurtling train. And then, at the perfect moment, he jumped.

headline: Plenty of Confidence, and No Pants
text: AS an encore at her recitals Susan Graham often sings the song “Sexy Lady.” Written for her by the composer and lyricist Ben Moore, it’s the comic complaint of a star mezzo-soprano trapped in an endless round of trouser roles: lovesick adolescents in operas by Mozart and Strauss, dysfunctional knights in Handel.

headline: The Namesake
text: Back in 1985, while working at Hughes Aircraft in Long Beach, Calif., I met a fine young woman named Addie. She worked in a different department, but whenever I saw her, I’d flirt with her. Eventually she became my girlfriend. I was a fixture at her mother’s house in the Fruit Town ’hood where Addie lived with her two sons. It was known as Fruit Town because of the names of the streets — Cherry, Peach, Pear — and it was one of the roughest neighborhoods in Compton, home of the Fruit Town Piru gang, one of the original gangs in the confederation known as the Bloods.

headline: A Good Mystery: Why We Read
text: PERHAPS the most fantastical story of the year was not “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,” but “The Uncommon Reader,” a novella by Alan Bennett that imagines the queen of England suddenly becoming a voracious reader late in life.

headline: Glasses White With Foam
text: IF you're in Napa, would you order a Côte du Rhône syrah? In Italy, would you eat microwavable Chef Boyardee? In Belgium, would you buy a Hershey bar?

headline: Toledo, Here He Comes?
text: It is hardly typical of the agent Scott Boras to accept a below-market contract offer. But if Alex Rodriguez, Boras’s marquee client, hammers out the 10-year, $275 million deal he is negotiating with the Yankees, he may be leaving money on the table. Although no other major league team made a formal offer to Rodriguez, he did receive one proposal for $35 million a season from an unlikely suitor: the Toledo Mud Hens, the Class AAA affiliate of the Detroit Tigers.

headline: The Geography of Hate
text: FROM the 1880s to the 1960s, at least 4,700 men and women were lynched in this country. The noose remains a terrifying symbol, and continues to be used by racists to intimidate African-Americans (who made up more than 70 percent of lynching victims).

headline: That’s My Pride Beneath the Love Train
text: BY age 23, I had romanced cigarettes, chocolate soufflé, my pet cat and (through the TV screen) James Franco on “Freaks and Geeks.” But I had yet to experience an actual human romance.

headline: A Soldier’s Tale
text: We’re all familiar with the pictures of American servicemen being dragged through the streets of Mogadishu. We’ve seen the movies and television programs inspired by this tragic event and have read the books and newspaper and magazine articles that analyze how Somalia changed the United States’ attitude toward military intervention, at least in the 1990s. But we haven’t read the fiction inspired by this crucial moment in American military history — because there has been so little.

headline: The Wizard of Whimsy
text: FOR slightly more than a year, a mysterious little periodical has been circulating through the cubicles of New York publishing offices, attracting the kind of cultish attention usually reserved for letters stamped with secret societies’ seals.

headline: In the Majority, Democrats Tighten Control on County Government
text: WHAT a difference a decade makes.

headline: Gender Gap Might Be Wide, but Women Have Their Days
text: For whatever reason, women lag behind men when it comes to chess. The best women rank below the best men (with the exception of Judit Polgar of Hungary, the only woman ever to reach the top 100), but there is no obvious reason why.

headline: The Fish
text: As soon as the elderly waiter  placed before me the fish I had ordered,  it began to stare up at me  with its one flat, iridescent eye.

headline: Most Experience or Enough Experience?
text: IN 1960, Richard Nixon ran for president against John F. Kennedy on a slogan that had powerful resonance for cold war America: “Experience Counts.” Nixon had been vice president for eight years, a senator for two, and a House member for four. Kennedy had been a senator for eight years and a House member for six, and was also a war hero and the scion of a politically powerful family.

headline: When Night Falls at School, Should Darwin Go Home?
text: Northport

headline: Life Lessons Learned
text: KAREN TANG was determined to find an affordable apartment. The target price was just $200,000.

headline: Illusions of Grandeur
text: The 1970s, with their glamour and glitter, are big right now. But ’70s design wasn’t just a look; it was about mixing common sense and theatricality to make the ordinary extraordinary.

headline: New Voting Machines Are Put to the Test
text: HARTFORD

headline: Julie Bierman, Jordan Solomon
text: Julie Lynn Bierman, the daughter of Mara-Lee Bierman and Dr. Fredrick Z. Bierman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening in Pearl River, N.Y., to Jordan Lev Solomon, a son of Susan Solomon Stibel of Marblehead, Mass., and the late Bennett I. Solomon. Daniel Klein, a spiritual leader at Harvard Hillel, officiated at the Hilton Pearl River.

headline: Letter: Questions for Patty Limerick
text: We agree with Patty Limerick’s concern about abandoned Western mines not being a major story source for Hollywood (Deborah Solomon, Nov. 11). But it should be noted that films about such problems have been made.

headline: A Cloud Over Reborn Shelby Mustangs
text: FIVE years ago, amid a sharp rise in prices of vintage muscle cars, Carroll Shelby licensed his name to a Texas company to construct replicas of the 1967 Shelby GT500E used in the 2000 remake of the drive-in classic “Gone in 60 Seconds.”

headline: The Pretenders
text: Guitar Hero

headline: Jessica Sheena, David Cohen
text: Jessica Ann Sheena, a daughter of Rita and Sami S. Sheena of Old Westbury, N.Y., was married last evening to David Bryan Cohen, a son of Sheryl and Lewis J. Cohen of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Katz officiated at the Puck Building in New York, with Cantor Kalman Fliegelman taking part.

headline: Maggie Rivage-Seul, Kerry Reilly
text: Elizabeth Marguerite Rivage-Seul, the daughter of Peggy and Michael Rivage-Seul of Berea, Ky., was married yesterday to Kerry Flannery Reilly, a son of Dr. Maureen A. Flannery of Berea, and the late Peter C. Reilly III. The Rev. Frank Lehnerd, a Roman Catholic priest and a great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Clare Church in Berea.

headline: Running the Ball: Anyone Can Do It?
text: The debate has simmered for a decade, at least since the Denver Broncos began making a habit of turning unsung players into 1,000-yard rushers. Other championship-caliber teams, like the Indianapolis Colts and the New England Patriots, began casting aside top running backs, finding younger and cheaper alternatives with no regrets.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: The Day’s Best
text: MATT RYAN, left, threw for 369 yards and 3 touchdowns as No. 15 Boston College got ready for the Atlantic Coast Conference title game by beating Miami for the first time since 1984.

headline: Persuading Them
text: The announcement this month that Karen Hughes would be stepping down as undersecretary of state for public diplomacy was greeted with a combination of relief and derision. In her first appearance in the Middle East, in 2005, this Bush confidante and fellow Texan avoided substantive issues while reassuring audiences that “my most important title is Mom” and that Americans “greatly value many religious faiths.” The trip was a very public fiasco for the White House; thereafter, Hughes appears to have been largely withdrawn from circulation.

headline: Luxury Lodging for the Eco-Tourist
text: FOR many travelers, Costa Rica has become a destination for eco-tourism — that is, vacations intended to celebrate and preserve the natural environment. And over the years, travelers on such trips have come to expect mostly ascetic accommodations after long days of surfing or hiking, typically not much more than a decent bed in a bug-free room with a semiprivate bathroom.

headline: A Cover Girl Who’s Simply Himself
text: WHAT follows is, in brief (well, not so brief), the curious tale of how a handsome black man who can also look an awful lot like a beautiful black woman, except with better legs than most and a beard, happened to end up on the November cover of French Vogue.

headline: Pasture-ized, Not Pasteurized
text: 5 Spoke Creamery, a new artisanal cheese purveyor based in Port Chester, is giving county residents access to a rare and wonderful taste: small-batch cheeses made with raw milk from grass-fed cows.

headline: Missouri Hands Kansas Its First Loss
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 24 — After No. 3 Missouri’s 36-28 victory against No. 2 Kansas on Saturday night, Tigers fans proudly made the No. 1 sign with their index fingers.

headline: DNA Tests Find Branches but Few Roots
text: HENRY LOUIS GATES JR., whose PBS special “African American Lives” explores the ancestry of famous African-Americans using DNA testing, has done more than anyone to help popularize such tests and companies that offer them. But recently this Harvard professor has become one of the industry’s critics.

headline: The Store Is Jumpin’. The Stock Isn’t.
text: IT’S always been one of the most appealing bits of investor folklore: the retailer you discover after a visit to the mall, or the hip clothing company you hear about from your teenager and whose stocks end up going up through the roof.

headline: Sanctuaries From Trouble, but No One Is There
text: ONE of the more unlikely witnesses to the changing commercial face of the Upper West Side is Annemarie Legendy, a short woman with a soft German accent and a cap of highlighted blond hair.

headline: Suffolk Schools to Say Goodbye to DARE
text: FOR nearly 20 years, Suffolk County police officers have been teaching students in the county’s five western towns about the risks of tobacco, alcohol and other drugs, as well as about peer pressure and safety. But that is changing as the county police department eliminates its DARE program, which will be replaced with a more general health and safety curriculum.

headline: In Broadway Dispute, Questions of Fairness
text: From the day the stagehands’ strike began two weeks ago, the Broadway producers courted public opinion by insisting that the dispute was about one issue: fairness.

headline: Going to Brooklyn for the Views
text: PARK SLOPE. Williamsburg. The Heights. Brownstones. Tree-lined streets. Cute restaurants. With-it galleries. Great museums.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Film

headline: For Riders of a Stepchild Line, Even an ‘F’ Looks Good
text: THE culture of the victimhood designated on subway maps by a green line snaking from Queens to Brooklyn is well established. And so, when it comes to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s rider report card program, which solicits rider evaluations, there is little suspense.

headline: Correction: Producer? So’s Your Old Man
text: An article last Sunday about Jenny Gersten, who has followed in her father’s footsteps as associate producer of the Public Theater, misspelled the given name of her younger sister. She is Jilian Cahan Gersten, not Jillian. The article also misstated the role of Jenny Gersten’s husband, Willie Reale, at the 52nd Street Project. He is the founder, not a co-founder.

headline: Up Front
text: The novelist and poet Jim Harrison, who reviews a new collection of Charles Bukowski’s poems in this issue, has been treated pretty well by critics over the course of his more than 40-year career. Some of Harrison’s early novels, though, were attacked for featuring characters who were perhaps on the far side of macho.

headline: Sir Noël’s Epistles
text: The astute English critic Kenneth Tynan identified Broadway humor as being chiefly of two kinds: Jewish and homosexual. He might have called it kvetch and bitch, perfectly good types, but not really British. Noël Coward, who was only one of those two things, specialized in neither type in his oeuvre. He kept it all for his correspondence.

headline: Years of Thunder for Woman Called Lightning
text: Juanita Epton saw red at her first auto race on a dirt track in Charlotte, N.C., in 1945.

headline: Bitterest Rival of Musharraf Returns Home
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 25 — Nawaz Sharif, the Pakistani opposition leader and former prime minister, arrived home from exile to a tumultuous welcome at Lahore airport on Sunday evening. Hundreds of supporters whistled and cheered, hoisting him and his brother, Shahbaz Sharif on their shoulders through ranks of wary riot police.

headline: The Enabler
text: If there was a single low point in American diplomacy in recent years, it may have been the Bush administration’s handling of the 2006 Lebanese war. For weeks, while Israel responded to Hezbollah’s abduction of two soldiers on July 12 by heavy bombing of Lebanon’s infrastructure and Hezbollah rained rockets on Israel, the United States blocked efforts to arrange a cease-fire. On July 21, asked why she had delayed going to the Middle East, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice explained that the devastation represented “the birth pangs of a new Middle East — and whatever we do we have to be certain that we’re pushing forward to the new Middle East, not going back to the old one.”

headline: Erin Holt, Patrick Sloane
text: Erin Gentry Holt, a daughter of Joyce Gentry Holt and Michael F. Holt of Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday in Healdsburg, Calif., to George Patrick Harvey Ingalls Sloane, a son of Kathleen McNally Sloane and Dr. G. Harvey I. Sloane of New York and Washington. Judge Michael Daly Hawkins of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, for whom the bride was a clerk, officiated at Barndiva, a restaurant.

headline: Food, Drink, and Plenty of Literary Dish
text: WESTCHESTER is a bookish place, especially if you’re a woman. “Spoken Interludes,” a literary event held Nov. 6 at Trinity Bar & Grill in Harrison, was notable for its gender split. Of the 70 or so people there who had paid $30 to eat penne and hear four writers, including Michael Korda and Susan Cheever, fewer than 10 were men — and two of them were behind the lectern.

headline: In a Catalog of Catastrophes, Hurricanes Rule
text: The Count column last Sunday, about insurance losses from catastrophes, misstated the year of Hurricane Katrina, which was responsible for $41.1 billion in losses. It was 2005, not 2002.

headline: In the Back, Not All Cattle Are Equal
text: FLYING in coach doesn’t have to be a horrific experience. Really. You just have to pay more.

headline: More ‘Sex,’ and the City Is Happy About It
text: ONE recent afternoon Bettiann Fishman climbed a ladder in front of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue and brought a bullhorn to her mouth. “Hey, everybody,” she said, addressing crowds gathered on the library steps, on the sidewalk and in the street. “We’re going to roll now, so please don’t shoot.”

headline: Where the Roads Begin
text: A SKY-BLUE smokestack rises above an elevated section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, sending swirling clouds of dissipating steam over the endless traffic. The stack marks the top of the Hamilton Avenue Asphalt Plant, which churns out much of the sticky, smoking substance that will become the surface of the city’s roadways.

headline: Golden Years
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tax for 2 Cents Plain Is Anything but Simple
text: VOTERS in Upper Freehold Township passed a bond question this month that will raise an additional $264,000 annually to preserve farmland in their Monmouth County community.

headline: Fordham Keeps Coming Back Before UMass Pulls Away
text: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 24 — After a 3-8 season last year, the Fordham Rams simply wanted to be respectable this fall. Instead, they found themselves in a postseason game Saturday in front of a national television audience, with an outside chance at a national title.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: Torture as Campaign Issue
text: To the Editor:

headline: More Than a Little Night Music
text: WHEN Uma Dixit, a 44-year-old Indian immigrant, first arrived at her one-bedroom apartment in Inwood two winters ago, she was greatly underwhelmed.

headline: Medical Examiner, Differing on Ground Zero Case, Stands His Ground
text: No New Yorker is privy to as many secrets of the dead as Dr. Charles S. Hirsch. During nearly two decades as New York City’s chief medical examiner, he has quietly overseen autopsies on more than 100,000 people, hoping to learn something more about the way they lived, and why they died.

headline: Caregivers Are Just a Few Clicks Away
text: Let’s say you’re visiting New York and want to go to the Metropolitan Opera. Or you’re in Washington and want to spend the day at the Smithsonian. The only problem: that demanding toddler, teenager, mother-in-law or puppy who has no interest in going with you. Care.com, a new Web site, hopes to provide assistance to travelers in the United States. It provides a city-by-city directory of caregivers for children, pets and the elderly, as well as tutors, who have posted online profiles detailing their availability, experience, abilities and skills and rates. Caregivers may also include photographs and give information about themselves. Interested employers may click on “send a message” if they would like to contact a caregiver or add the caregiver’s profile to a favorites list. Basic membership is free, but there are also premium memberships ($25 to $120), which provide unlimited access to all providers and free background checks.

headline: My Last (Probably Only) Year at Marienbad
text: THE doctor looked at me over his steel-rimmed glasses. “And what is your problem?’” he asked.

headline: Freud Is Widely Taught at Universities, Except in the Psychology Department
text: PSYCHOANALYSIS and its ideas about the unconscious mind have spread to every nook and cranny of the culture from Salinger to “South Park,” from Fellini to foreign policy. Yet if you want to learn about psychoanalysis at the nation’s top universities, one of the last places to look may be the psychology department.

headline: Conventions Throw Doors Open to Bloggers
text: The Democrats are opening the doors of their convention in Denver next year to more bloggers than ever before. The move gives bloggers and the new media a chance to shine, much as they did at the trial of Scooter Libby earlier this year, and to bring a whole new perspective, and competition, to convention coverage. This is, after all, the first convention since the rise of YouTube.

headline: Letters: The Ethicist
text: I quibble with the Ethicist (Oct. 21) on the matter of whether to pay a rabbi who became incapacitated just days before a wedding.

headline: Antipasto in Abundance
text: THE makings of traditional Italian antipasto, the savory snacks served before the meal, are the specialty at Razzano’s Salumeria in Glen Cove.

headline: A Time for Bold Thinking on Housing
text: WE have to consider the possibility that the housing price downturn will eventually be as big as that of the last truly big decline, from 1925 to 1933, when prices fell by a total of 30 percent.

headline: Just Don’t Call It Scotch. Or Irish. Or Tequila.
text: Distilleries? In the Midwest? Why not? Except for a few geographically specific spirits, like tequila and Scotch and Irish whiskeys, anyone can make just about any spirit, anywhere.

headline: Anne Livet and John Langdon
text: Anne Hodge Livet and John E. Langdon were married on Friday at Mr. Langdon’s home in Fort Worth. The Rev. Jan Orr-Harter, a Presbyterian minister, officiated with the Rev. Susan O’Connell, a Zen Buddhist priest, participating.

headline: Ex-Con Back in the ’Hood, Hustling His Novel Now
text: Plainfield

headline: Debating the Degree of Dominance of the Patriots
text: In a season of superlatives, the New England Patriots are also dominating the category of divided opinions. Roughly midway through what often feels like an inexorable march to perfection, the Patriots, 10-0 and heavy favorites to beat the Philadelphia Eagles at home tonight, are already being compared with the greatest teams ever.

headline: Massachusetts Faces a Test on Health Care
text: BOSTON, Nov. 20  As the Democratic presidential candidates debate whether Americans should be forced to obtain health insurance, the people of Massachusetts are living the dilemma in real time.

headline: Amateurs Unravel Russia’s Last Royal Mystery
text: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — On the outskirts of this burly industrial center, off a road like any other, on a nowhere scrap of land — here unfolded the final act of one of the last century’s most momentous events.

headline: In Defense of Lurking
text: For years, I’ve spent hours a day on Web sites devoted variously to television, finance, consumer electronics, celebrity gossip, furniture design, health anomalies and real estate. To the sites’ message boards, which I follow almost as avidly as I did the first seasons of “Damages” and “Mad Men,” I’ve contributed a total of three overwritten comments. I can recall them verbatim. They sank like stones.

headline: Rejwana Haque and Hasan Khondker
text: Rejwana Haque, the daughter of Mursheda Haque and Dr. Mohammad Haque of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married on Friday to Dr. Hasan Karim Khondker, a son of Dr. Sultana Khondker and Sufian A. Khondker of Hollis, Queens. Imam Ghazi Y. Khankan, a Muslim cleric, officiated at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

headline: Letters: Home-Office Politics
text: Matt Bai (Nov. 4) might have mentioned that a large proportion of the “independent” self-employed got there involuntarily. They were laid off from corporate jobs and, for reasons fully examined by Louis Uchitelle, a New York Times reporter, in his book “The Disposable American,” couldn’t find their way back into cubicleland. They need help, above all, with medical-insurance costs.

headline: U.S. Scales Back Political Goals for Iraqi Unity
