text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 — With American military successes outpacing political gains in Iraq, the Bush administration has lowered its expectation of quickly achieving major steps toward unifying the country, including passage of a long-stymied plan to share oil revenues and holding regional elections.

headline: Payload: Taking Aim at Corporate Bribery
text: LATE last month, five jumbo jets from Riyadh touched down at Heathrow Airport in London. They brought with them 13 members of the Saudi royal family, including King Abdullah and his retainers — and controversy. Over the last four years, the British government has been dogged by criticism of its relationship with Saudi Arabia, which is Britain’s biggest trading partner in the Middle East.

headline: Peace Corps Looks for Older Volunteers
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 —The Peace Corps is asking older Americans who might have heard President John F. Kennedy’s call to service more than 40 years ago to heed his request.

headline: The Dead and the Naked
text: Chapter 12: Busy, Busy, Busy

headline: Revised Rule for Employers That Hire Immigrants
text: The Bush administration will suspend its legal defense of a new rule issued in August to punish employers who hire illegal immigrants, conceding a hard-fought opening round in a court battle over a central measure in its strategy to curb illegal immigration, according to government papers filed late Friday in federal court.

headline: Cheesemaking: A Science of Good Taste
text: CHEESEMAKING and Connecticut is not a combo that comes trippingly to the tongue. Yet in recent years the artisanal, or hands-on, method of cheesemaking in small batches from the raw milk of cows, sheep and goats has taken hold in the state. Consumers are increasingly aware of cheese quality and variety. More specialty food stores are stocking artisanal cheeses and more restaurants than ever before are offering high quality cheese plates. Cheese stores, like Darien Cheese & Fine Foods in Darien, are flourishing.

headline: The Case for Illegal Mingling
text: One of the most talked about stories in the Middle East last week came out of Saudi Arabia, where the government affirmed the sentence of 200 lashes for a 19-year-old Shiite girl who was sitting in a car with a male acquaintance last year when they were attacked by seven men who gang-raped both of them.

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption last Sunday with the Evening Hours column misidentified the person in a mask who was shown embracing Elizabeth McCormack at the Asian Cultural Council gala on Nov. 13. He is Dokorda Gde Arsa Artha, a Balinese dancer — not Joseph Polisi.

headline: Jennifer Oppenheimer, Samuel Gutmann
text: Jennifer Lauren Oppenheimer, the daughter of Joan and Robert L. Oppenheimer of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married last evening to Samuel Eric Gutmann, a son of Susan and Ben H. Gutmann of Norwood, N.J. Rabbi Kenneth A. Stern officiated at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in New York.

headline: Forget the Game. Where Can We Eat?
text: NEWARK

headline: So Odd, but Lately in Classic Fashion
text: ON a break from rehearsals for “Cymbeline” at Lincoln Center Martha Plimpton dashed outside for a cigarette and immediately ran into a classmate from her alma mater, the nearby Professional Children’s School. It turned out he too was still performing, as a dancer at the Met. They chatted briefly about work and compared notes about Lincoln Center’s employees-only canteen, which evidently serves excellent chocolate-chip cookies.

headline: Hope for Leaders’ Cooperation, but Little for Results
text: Israeli and Palestinian leaders gather tomorrow under American tutelage, with Arab foreign ministers in attendance amid anxiety about Iran, to try again to negotiate an end to nearly 60 years of conflict.

headline: Kasparov Gets 5 Days in Jail for Marching
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 24 — Garry Kasparov, the former chess champion and opposition leader, was arrested Saturday and sentenced to five days in jail after trying to lead a march to the offices of the federal election authorities.

headline: Correction: Letter
text: Because of an editing error, a letter on Nov. 4 about the Turkish writer Orhan Pamuk and a James Bond film set partly in Istanbul misstated the first word of the movie’s title. It is “From Russia With Love,” not “To.”

headline: Debating the Merits of Energy From Air
text: THE tiny Greek island of Serifos, a popular tourist destination, depends on its postcard views of sandy beaches, Cycladic homes and sunsets that blend sea and sky into a clean wash of color. So when a mining and energy company floated a plan earlier this year to build 87 industrial wind turbines on more than a third of the island, the Serifos mayor, Angeliki Synodinou, called it her “worst nightmare.”

headline: Gotcha!
text: “The gotcha politics will begin,” predicted the TV interviewer Chris Matthews, on MSNBC this summer, “each side trying to catch the other.” I am all too familiar with that adjective, having misidentified Matthews a few weeks ago as being on CNN, which triggered a volley of corrections from his fans, who are presumably snapping up copies of his new book, “Life’s a Campaign.”

headline: Home Economics
text: The housing bubble has burst, the dollar is in free fall and oil prices are at an all-time high. At the same time, unemployment remains down, as does inflation. How do Americans feel about the economy? For the second year in a row, the Op-Ed page asked four writers from around the nation to provide quarterly snapshots of their local economies. Here is their third round of dispatches.

headline: Rock of Ages, Ages of Rock
text: On a muggy afternoon in July, a group of geologists from around the country put on some bug spray and fanned out along one of Ohio’s richest fossil beds. The rock walls were slippery and steep at points, and some people came in their dress shoes straight from the conference that brought them together. But no one seemed daunted; when let loose on the rocks they behaved like children with a piñata, filling their pockets with local specimens and cooing over their treasure. “Ahh, that’s a beautiful brachiopod!” or “A fine trilobite! Let me see that.”

headline: The Office Party, as a Tightrope Walk
text: IMAGINE trying to plan a dinner party for 20 people with different dietary needs. Or think about organizing a wedding reception where both bride and groom have their share of fractious family members, and the new in-laws don’t get along.

headline: He Still Has Fire in His Throat and His Belly
text: WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 18  Gregory Tanis steps into his tuxedo pants, slips on his rhinestone-studded bow tie and piles crates full of props into his 1987 Buick LeSabre. About 70 years after he first entertained at a birthday show for $5 or $10, Mr. Tanis is still performing magic tricks at parties around the state.

headline: Correction: 	Melissa Grigorieff, Jonathan Koomey
text: A report on Nov. 11 about the marriage of Melissa Grigorieff and Jonathan Koomey misspelled the bridegroom’s middle name. It is Garo, not Caro.

headline: Deal if by Air, Steal if by Sea
text: Georges Duboeuf has given Sherry-Lehmann specially blended Beaujolais nouveau for 23 years.

headline: Just Off Insular Senate Floor, Life of the Uninsured Intrudes
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 — When senators debate health care, they usually speak in abstract terms about soaring health costs and the plight of the uninsured.

headline: Immigrant Workers Caught in Net Cast for Gangs
text: GREENPORT, N.Y. — It was still dark the morning of Sept. 27 when armed federal immigration agents, guided by local police officers, swept into this village on the East End of Long Island. Within hours, as the team rousted sleeping families, 11 men were added to a running government tally of arrests made in Operation Community Shield, a two-year-old national program singling out violent gang members for deportation.

headline: California Fire Eases as Winds Subside
text: AGOURA HILLS, Calif., Nov. 25 — Fierce Santa Ana winds that blew a destructive blaze through Malibu on Saturday died down today, allowing firefighters to gain the upper hand in efforts to battle the destructive fire, a month after wildfires destroyed large parts of Southern California.

headline: Letters: Looking for Their Children’s Birth Mothers
text: Looking for Their Children’s Birth Mothers

headline: The Bears Among Us
text: No one can say for sure when things got out of hand — when relations between humans and black bears in the Canadian resort town of Whistler grew untenable for each side — but by the height of last summer’s tourist season, many of the bears that live around the densely developed, Swiss-style village in the mountains of British Columbia had apparently learned some new foraging techniques, and life for the humans took on an aspect of siege: Bears hitting the “bearproof” garbage bins along Highway 99; bears breaking into the loading bays and trash compactors behind the Hilton; bears discovering that snorting, jaw-snapping and bluff-charging golfers on the Whistler greens would cause those golfers to surrender their carts with their hands in the air.

headline: Week 12 in Preview
text: SEAHAWKS

headline: Corrections
text: An article in the Arts & Leisure section last Sunday about the No Music Day campaign in Britain included several incorrect references to Muzak, the company that sells prerecorded background music.

headline: For All the Rock in China
text: BEIJING

headline: Where Mansions Go Begging
text: Grosse Pointe, Mich.

headline: The U.S. Economy: Trying to Guess What Happens Next
text: YOU need not be a Wall Street chieftain to feel the anxiety that has wrapped its arms around the American economy. The stock market seems locked in a downward spiral as one bank after another suffers its day of reckoning with bad mortgages. Companies are sharply cutting profit forecasts as the sense takes hold that American consumers are finally too loaded with debt to buy the next flat-screen television. The dollar has fallen to inglorious depths, turning Manhattan department stores into something like a Tijuana street market for Germans. One unpleasant word hovers large: recession.

headline: Roar of the Engines? It’s an Electric Hum
text: Portland, Ore.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article last Sunday in T: Travel magazine, about three popular musicians in the Brazilian state of Bahia, misspelled the surname of one. She is Ivete Sangalo, not Sangolo.

headline: Small Things in Good Packages
text: TOKYO

headline: Fed’s Forecast Weighs on Stocks
text: Despite a rally during a shortened trading session on Friday, the stock market gave up more ground last week, as the Federal Reserve issued an expanded and rather gloomy report on the economy.

headline: Man Dies in Fire in a Queens Shanty
text: A 68-year-old man died early yesterday in a fire that destroyed a shanty used by homeless people on a vacant lot in Queens, the police and fire officials said.

headline: And That’s the News From Watersmeet
text: THE director Brett Morgen hails from Santa Monica, Calif., lives and works in Rockaway Park, Queens, and has made feature documentaries about young Brooklyn boxers (“On the Ropes”), the idiosyncratic Hollywood producer Robert Evans (“The Kid Stays in the Picture”) and the trial of protesters at the 1968 Democratic National Convention (the forthcoming “Chicago 10”).

headline: Tax Defeat Spells Setback for Land Preservation in Brookhaven
text: AS the Nov. 6 local election fades in the memory, one result stands out — a setback for open-space preservation plans in Brookhaven, Long Island’s fastest-growing and second most populous town, and its largest geographically.

headline: 88, and Still Working His Magic on 88 Keys
text: Uncasville

headline: Year After Year, Giving Thanks (3 Letters)
text: Year After Year, Giving Thanks

headline: Letters: How the Western Was Won
text: I enjoyed A. O. Scott’s article on western movies (Nov. 11). However, he didn’t mention three of the very best: William Wellman’s “Ox-Bow Incident,” Henry King’s “Gunfighter” and Howard Hawks’s “Red River.” If I were teaching a film class, I would assign these three to represent the classic westerns.

headline: Letters: The Evangelical Crackup
text: Praise the Lord! It looks as if evangelicals have finally seen the light (David D. Kirkpatrick, Oct. 28). They’ve been “pimped” by the godless neocons of the G.O.P. Regarding Terry Fox’s comment comparing this country’s religious zealots to a snake “in a hole right now,” it’s not a hole they crawled into; it’s more like crawling back under the rock they came from.

headline: Can a Co-op Board Change Voting Rules?
text: Q I am the president of a co-op in the Bronx. Recently, the board amended the bylaws to prohibit anyone who is in arrears on his or her maintenance or who is in violation of the house rules from voting their shares or running for the board. Can we actually enforce this amendment?

headline: Elizabeth McCarthy, Benjamin Wikler
text: Elizabeth Grant McCarthy, a daughter of Suzanne Grant McCarthy and Dr. Richard E. McCarthy of Little Rock, Ark., was married yesterday to Benjamin McDonald Wikler, the son of Marilyn R. McDonald of London and Dr. Daniel I. Wikler of Cambridge, Mass. Msgr. Francis I. Malone performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Little Rock.

headline: ‘CSI: Vancouver’? Well, Not Exactly
text: VIEWERS disappointed with this fall’s crop of new crime shows — or worried that a lingering writers’ strike will rob them of their favorite old crime shows — can take solace, we’re told, in DVDs. But what if you’ve already watched all 10 seasons of “The Sopranos” and “The Wire,” as well as the 14 Orbach-Noth-Florek-Moriarty episodes of “Law & Order”? What’s left to discover?

headline: Time Runs Out on a Place to See and Be Seen
text: “FOR one brief shining moment that was known as Camelot. ...”

headline: After a Coach’s Scandal, the L.S.U. Women Rebound
text: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 21  When Pokey Chatman resigned last March as the women’s basketball coach at Louisiana State, amid accusations by an assistant that she had improper sexual relationships with former players, many wondered whether the fallout would undermine one of the nation’s top programs.

headline: A Long Road Back After Exoneration, and Justice Is Slow to Make Amends
text: Christopher Ochoa graduated from law school five years out of prison and started his own practice in Madison, Wis. He has a girlfriend and is looking to buy a house.

headline: Tea Leaves Don’t Show a Holiday Lift
text: THIS is the time of year when traders look for share prices to begin rising as holiday cheer engulfs Wall Street. A rally this season may be a tall order, though.

headline: Rediscovering Drawing, the Forgotten Art
text: Drawing is one of the foundations of art. It is probably even fair to say that there would be no art without it. It is also a universal language, speaking to us across time and space. But today many artists no longer know how to draw. Nor do they really need to, for cameras and computers do all the work for them.

headline: Just Married? Now, Get Out of Town
text: ANY couple planning a wedding trip will welcome a gift of luggage. The choices include colorful pieces that will not get lost on an airport carousel in the sea of all-black cases that hip travelers have been carrying for years.

headline: Greatest Hits
text: The rounds in boxing are separated by a 60-second hiatus. But as the Hall of Fame trainer Angelo Dundee observes in his memoir, by the time your man gets back to his corner and sits down, you have only about 45 seconds to work your magic. As this book attests, being a professor of pugilism can be a stressful way to make your daily bread, since there will be contests in which you have to ponder not only strategy but also the health and perhaps life of your fighter.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,275,895.90

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Theater

headline: Showtime
text: This is showdown time for Gov. Jon Corzine. During the next few months, he will have to make good on his promise to put New Jersey on a sounder financial basis.

headline: It May Not Be Double-Digit, but It’s Still a Gain
text: WITH only five weeks left in 2007, and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index down 5.6 percent in what is supposed to be its best quarter of the year, Wall Street is becoming understandably anxious.

headline: An Architect’s Flotilla of West Side Buildings
text: THE New Orleans architect Albert C. Ledner’s three offbeat creations for the National Maritime Union came ashore in New York in the 1960s, their porthole facades impudent in the face of doctrinaire modernism. The union sold off all three buildings within two decades. One of the pair on Ninth Avenue and West 17th Street is now the Maritime Hotel; the other, too, may soon morph into a hotel.

headline: A Room That Simply Beckons You to Sew
text: I FELL under the spell of the sewing room the moment I crossed its threshold 26 years ago. I could sense the decades of solitary endeavor that must have taken place there since the house was built in 1849.

headline: Correction: A Home for a Ballet Academy, and the Vision of Its Namesake
text: An article last Sunday about the Margot Fonteyn Academy of Ballet in Peekskill misquoted its director, Ken Ludden. He said in an interview that Dame Margot “felt that she would have been a better dancer had she had formal training in art, music and drama” — not “art, music and dance.” The article also included outdated information on the location of the academy’s production of “The Nutcracker.” After the article went to press, the production was moved from the Paramount Center for the Arts to the Tarrytown Music Hall, where it will be performed on Dec. 21 at 8 p.m. and Dec. 22 at 3 p.m. and 8 p.m.

headline: Mobile Web: So Close Yet So Far
text: ON the surface, the mobile Web is a happening place. There’s the iPhone in all its glory. More than 30 companies have signed up for the Open Handset Alliance from Google, which aims to bring the wide-open development environment of the Internet to mobile devices. Nokia, which owns nearly 40 percent of the world market for cellphones, is snapping up Web technology companies and has made an eye-popping $8.1 billion bid for Navteq, a digital mapping service. There are also the requisite start-ups chasing the market.

headline: When Campaigning Strays Off Script
text: OBSERVERS of modern presidential campaigns might be allowed some despair over the highly produced, theatrical productions that pass for campaign events these days.

headline: Once Again, Dayne Makes a Late Arrival
text: With the season’s end drawing near, it is once again time for Ron Dayne, a backup running back for the Texans, to stand tall. In the team’s past two games, Dayne, filling in for the injured Ahman Green, has rumbled for 211 yards and a touchdown. Similarly, from Weeks 13 through 16 last season, Dayne amassed 429 yards and 5 touchdowns.

headline: The Nymphet Is a Lethal Weapon
text: FRANK WEDEKIND’S “Lulu” is the modern ur-drama of sex. It’s not an edifying fable about gender roles or sexual politics, or a tragedy of clueless, randy youth (like Wedekind’s earlier “Spring Awakening”), or even at heart a marriage play, though four marriages go bad in it. “Lulu” is a ruthless examination of the terrible destructive potential of a basic human drive, and of that favorite scapegoat for that destruction, the femme fatale.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Steroids and an I.R.S. Agent

headline: Letters
text: Lynn Hirschberg’s article on Daniel Day-Lewis was an unforgettable depiction of a man who is surely a master at his craft (Nov. 11). In her novel-like interview, she drew me into the picture, absorbed by his quest for perfection. “I need to find the right kind of silence or light or noise,” he said, and I believe he has. Indeed, Day-Lewis’s idea of America as a place of infinite possibilities has come to pass for him. Thanks for a great read!

headline: The List Is Stellar, but a Little Dated
text: When Doubledown Media published the first issue of Corporate Leader magazine this month, it included a list of the “100 Best C.E.O.’s.” But if there is a second annual listing, at least four of those chief executives will be missing.

headline: Think Global, Read Local
text: Hillsborough, N.C.

headline: Returning Courts to the People
text: The writers of Connecticut’s Constitution thought judicial secrecy to be so corrosive to the public good that they included five simple but powerful words: “All courts shall be open.”

headline: A Scenic Los Angeles Enclave, Without Glitter
text: “IS this really still Los Angeles?” asked Hélène Rottier, a friend from Tahiti, peering across the Santa Monica Mountains obscured in the Wagnerian carpet of mist rising from the Pacific 2,000 feet below. We had hiked up the four-mile Temescal Canyon Trail, which twists from the village center of Pacific Palisades through thick scrub, sycamores and oaks and past a small waterfall where deer and an occasional cougar pause to drink.

headline: Taking Stock of Your Stuff
text: WHAT is your stuff worth? That is a question the Insurance Information Institute, a Manhattan industry group, thinks everyone who has homeowner’s or renter’s insurance needs to answer.

headline: Natural Detection
text: Diana Abu-Jaber’s second novel, “Crescent,” was a love story involving an Iraqi-American cook and an exiled Iraqi professor, in which Abu-Jaber made pleasing use of the elements of literary romance: a heroine and her nemesis, a talismanic object, delayed revelations. Set in the warmth and light of Southern California and told in tactile and olfactory prose, it was grounded on two subjects she obviously knew well: Arab-American communities and cooking.

headline: Shh! It’s a Secret Kind of Outside Art
text: Los Angeles

headline: Dr. Drug Rep
text: I. Faculty Development

headline: Vindicated by DNA, but a Lost Man on the Outside
text: As a boy, Jeffrey Mark Deskovic could swim the length of a pool underwater without coming up for air. On sultry days at the Elmira state prison, where he spent most of his 16 years behind bars for a rape and murder he did not commit, Mr. Deskovic would close his eyes under a row of outdoor showers and imagine himself swimming.

headline: Bad Bags
text: Plastic bags are nasty little things. Environmentalists — check out a persuasive article by Katharine Mieszkowski in the Web publication Salon in August — argue that plastic bags are the ultimate emblem of a society addicted to consumption, waste and petroleum, the raw material from which most bags are made. It takes millions of barrels of oil to make the 100 billion plastic bags that Americans use every year. About 2 percent of those bags are recycled. The rest are still with us, and will be long after we die, since they do not rot.

headline: The Line Between Homage and Parody
text: “ENCHANTED,” a Walt Disney musical comedy that opened Wednesday, would have been labeled as treason in the Magic Kingdom just a few years ago. The grounds: mocking classic Disney characters.

headline: Rahdi Taylor and David Maynard
text: Rahdi Taylor, a daughter of JoAnn Taylor-Masterson of Loma Linda, Calif., and Clyde R. Taylor of New York, was married yesterday to David Maynard, a son of Nancy H. Maynard of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Robert C. Maynard, who lived in Oakland, Calif. The Rev. Madison T. Shockley II, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Cafe Pinot, a restaurant in Los Angeles.

headline: Datebook
text: CHICAGO

headline: A Serious Side of Fun
text: MY parents, both born in Latvia, emigrated separately to Palestine and met on a kibbutz in 1930. My last name means “son of freedom” in Hebrew. Growing up, I was embarrassed to have such a weird name, but I grew into it and became proud of it.

headline: Wild Wild Lit
text: Readers who like their plots clear and coherent and their prose clean and Hemingwayesque will drop this book in a hurry. Readers with a taste for inspired Joycean wordplay and a tolerance for narrative anarchy will scoop it up in delight.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: CONVERSATIONS WITH WOODY ALLEN: His Films, the Movies, and Moviemaking, by Eric Lax. (Knopf, $30.) In hours of nonconfrontational interviews, Allen ranges freely over his work and reveals a man who hasn’t changed much on a personal level.

headline: Zipcar, a Car-Sharing Service, and a Rival to Merge Fleets
text: Last month, Zipcar, a car-sharing service with hourly and daily rates — popular on both college campuses and in congested cities — announced that it was acquiring Flexcar, a similar car-sharing company.

headline: How ‘What It Takes’ Took Me Off Course
text: MORE than any other book, Richard Ben Cramer’s “What It Takes,” about the 1988 battle for the White House, influenced the way I cover campaigns.

headline: The High Cost of Health Care
text: The relentless, decades-long rise in the cost of health care has left many Americans struggling to pay their medical bills. Workers complain that they cannot afford high premiums for health insurance. Patients forgo recommended care rather than pay the out-of-pocket costs. Employers are cutting back or eliminating health benefits, forcing millions more people into the ranks of the uninsured. And state and federal governments strain to meet the expanding costs of public programs like Medicaid and Medicare.

headline: Correction: The Hollywood Diet
text: The Food column on Nov. 11, about dishes popular in Hollywood, referred imprecisely to the amount of butter used in the cake for peanut-butter cupcakes. While the amount is one and a half sticks, that is the equivalent of three-quarters of a cup, not two-thirds.

headline: Reading Not Required
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: Review of “A Life Decoded”
text: A review on Nov. 11 about “A Life Decoded. My Genome: My Life,” by J. Craig Venter, misidentified the organism that was the first to have its entire genome charted, a feat accomplished by Venter and colleagues at the Institute for Genomic Research. It was a bacterium, Haemophilus influenzae, once thought to cause flu; it was not “the flu virus.”

headline: Jamie Zucker, Jared Sharfman
text: Jamie Lauren Zucker, the daughter of Linda Zucker and Joel Zucker of East Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to Jared David Sharfman, a son of Rita Sharfman-Cristallo of North Bellmore, N.Y., and the late Saul Sharfman. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

headline: Baker’s Million
text: Mort Zachter’s small, wry memoir suggests that with the right sort of talent a man can not only rob and ill-treat his nearest and dearest, but also convince them it’s his just prerogative.

headline: An Unpredictable Path for a Present Imperfect
text: AT this point in the march of modern design, the idea of perfection is so complicated, has been shot so full of holes, that you can’t believe it ever held water. But while many designers prattle on about embracing imperfection, few have developed a whole aesthetic around it.

headline: Other Voices: In the Horse Race, Do the Media Pick the Horse?
text: Re “The Campaign and the Horse Race” (Nov. 18):

headline: When a Mother Country Tells Its Kid, ‘Shut Up’
text: CARACAS, Venezuela

headline: What Price Utopia?
text: As the march of events has lurched in unexpected directions over the past three decades, many a political thinker has been thrown off track and hurled into confusion, if rarely into silence. But not John Gray. He has usually been a little ahead of the zeitgeist, waxing contrarian about whatever consensus is about to form. Gray has been called a chameleon. If so, he belongs to a very peculiar species: one with precognition, able to change colors before landing on whatever patch of landscape lies just around the corner.

headline: Letters
text: The Market for Iraqi Bonds

headline: On an Unloved Lot, a New Source of Friction
text: FOR at least 13 years, neighbors say, the overgrown land behind the ShopRite parking lot in Borough Park, Brooklyn, has been a headache. Among many complaints made to the city, they pointed in 1994 to fire damage to an old warehouse at the site, in 1998 to the danger that the warehouse roof would collapse, and, just this fall, to homeless people slipping into the burned-out shell of the building.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Picture captions last Sunday with an article in T: Travel magazine, about five Baroque churches in the Pelourinho district of Salvador in the Brazilian state of Bahia, appeared out of order. The churches are, from left, the Church of Nosso Senhor do Bonfim, Church of São Francisco, Church of Nossa Senhora do Rosário dos Pretos, Cathedral Basílica and Carmo Church.

headline: Master of Doomed Love and Dark Surprises
text: ANYONE prone to attacks of vertigo should approach the works of Max Ophuls (1902-57) with some caution. Watching an individual Ophuls picture, in which, typically, the camera is in perpetual motion, can be a dizzying enough experience, but attempting to take in the whole of his career — by, say, attending the 12-movie retrospective that begins Friday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Rose Cinemas — could be more disorienting yet, because Ophuls did a fair amount of moving around himself.

headline: A Country Village Caught Up in the Times
text: IN the 40 years that Anthony Occhipinti, the owner of Stop Realty, has been selling homes in the Rockland County village of Pomona, he has witnessed the demise of a bucolic way of life with mixed feelings.

headline: A Comic Genius at Play in the Land of Foible and Folly
text: It would be hard to think of an artist more closely attuned to 20th-century American life than Saul Steinberg, one of our pre-eminent illustrators. His drawings and cartoon sketches for magazines take on almost every subject imaginable, always teasing out a comic dimension. Mr. Steinberg, who died in 1999, at age 84, depicted our follies and foibles for almost 60 years.

headline: Letters: Conductor of the People
text: Arthur Lubow’s article (Oct. 28) on the flowering of classical music in Venezuela has rich implications for American diplomacy with that country. In the spirit of cultural exchange, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, an accomplished pianist, might improve relations with Venezuela by performing a concerto with the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra, under Gustavo Dudamel (when he’s not conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic).

headline: Rust-Free Reality: Creating an All-New Classic
text: IN his 35 years of restoring cars, Mark Miller has seen it all — the good, the bad and the unsightly.

headline: Young Matadors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Underworld
text: To the average tourist, or even the devoted Italophile, the Italy of Roberto Saviano’s “Gomorrah” is an utterly unrecognizable place. There is no Renaissance art, no leisurely lunches or bustling piazzas, no world-class design, no achingly beautiful landscapes. Instead, we find an alien land of doped-up child soldiers, gun-toting clan women, illegal Chinese immigrants, sweatshops, drug smuggling, garbage and cement.

headline: Katherine Van Loon and Jon Steitz
text: AT a bar near Yale, Katherine Van Loon figured out what few Ivy League hitters could: how to make solid contact with Jon Steitz, a highly touted pitching prospect.

headline: The Chicken and Rice Man
text: EVERY weekday, starting as early as 7 in the morning and continuing until 7 at night, weary-looking men dressed in threadbare jackets and worn running shoes gather at the corner of Roosevelt Avenue and 73rd Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, under the gloomy shadow of the el.

headline: Amid Affluence, the Hidden Homeless
text: HEMPSTEAD

headline: Blue Jackets and Their Goalie Turning Corner
text: Fans of the Columbus Blue Jackets have been waiting for the team to become competitive since its inception in the most recent N.H.L. expansion, in 2000 — and particularly for goaltender Pascal Leclaire to fulfill the promise that made him the eighth overall draft pick in 2001.

headline: Just Call Our Band the Model Guests
text: IN her Midtown office, Jennifer Chiara, a travel agent, pulled out one of the standard nine-page riders she faxes to Manhattan hotels on behalf of her clients. In it were the customary requests: organic coffee and snacks, a room in a quiet part of the hotel, smart water and San Pellegrino served at room temperature.

headline: Pakistani Middle Class, Beneficiary of Musharraf, Begins to Question Rule
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  For the last eight years, Tanveer Ahmed, a 40-year-old pharmaceutical company manager, has prospered under the economic reforms put in place by Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Nostalgia That Can’t Miss (but Does)
text: Some moments seem surefire. Take a lovely young woman in a red turn-of-the-century ball gown. Stand her in the middle of a darkened Victorian dining room draped with holiday greenery, a Christmas tree twinkling in the corner. Strike up the orchestra, and turn her and her strong, clear voice loose with some beloved lyrics — say, “Here we are as in olden days/Happy golden days of yore.” And what you’ve got is a certain kind of magic. Normally.

headline: Gay Pastor in the Bronx Could Lose Her Collar
text: In 1994, when the Rev. Katrina D. Foster became pastor of Fordham Evangelical Lutheran Church in the Bronx, she threw herself into ministering to her small, mostly Caribbean-born congregation. She not only preached to them on Sundays but lived in the neighborhood and showed up to support them in everything from surgeries to legal matters.

headline: 36 Hours in Oaxaca, Mexico
text: OAXACA, the southern Mexican city with Zapotec roots and a Spanish colonial gloss, simmers with a passionate spirit. Although it's known as a hotbed for social justice rallies (including a large-scale teachers' strike in 2006), the city's infectious zeal goes far beyond the political, spilling into all its pursuits. You'll feel it in the buzzing markets, see it in the wealth of colorful crafts, and taste it in the culinary specialty: mole. Come during one of Oaxaca's many festivals like Christmas week or the Festival of the Radishes, and you'll experience the city in its full glory. Fetes, however, can be found anytime. ¡Andale!

headline: Japan Hunts the Humpback. Now Comes the Backlash.
text: THE ritual has been the same for nearly 20 years. Japan, while adhering to a 1986 moratorium on commercial whaling, has sent sturdy ships to Antarctic waters and, more recently, parts of the Pacific Ocean to kill hundreds of whales in the name of scientific research.

headline: Home Sweet Dome
text: Home Sweet Dome

headline: Searching for New York’s Hidden Places
text: IMAGINE living on a quiet street lined with postcard-perfect historic houses, a street so secluded that it is unmarred by honking cars and casual pedestrians.

headline: Our Side of the Mountain
text: Missoula, Mont.

headline: An Allowance That’s Measured in Minutes, Not Cents
text: HOWARD AND LIZZIE SHERMAN, ages 15 and 9, know that they need to complete all their homework and chores in order to receive their weekly allowance. The amount may be a little less than usual if they’ve misbehaved, or a bit larger if they have done some extra work around the house.

headline: Legacy of the DeLuca Case
text: Now that Senator Louis C. DeLuca, Republican of Woodbury, has announced he will retire at the end of the month, the Legislature should create a standing ethics committee with set procedures for handling ethics charges against its members. With no such committee in place, the General Assembly was forced to improvise when Mr. DeLuca pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor threat charge in June but refused to resign. The guilty plea came after an F.B.I. investigation revealed that Mr. DeLuca had asked James Galante, a man suspected of having ties to organized crime, to intimidate his granddaughter’s boyfriend.

headline: Letters: Class and Cruising
text: To the Editor: Regarding your Practical Traveler column on cruise ships, “Paying a Premium Not to Mingle at Sea” (Nov. 11): Segregation aboard cruise ships is inevitable, but I hope it doesn’t extend to separate lifeboats for the upper class.

headline: On the Waterfront, With Style
text: OVERSHADOWED by larger, wealthier and more flashy European countries with world-renowned design specialties — Italian lighting, Scandinavian furniture, French fashion — Portugal has long hid on the Continent's margin both geographically and creatively. For years, the best-known cultural contributions from this small seafaring nation were those stewed up in cauldrons from humble materials like squid and cod.

headline: House Demolition? Fire? He’ll Be There, With Camera
text: WESTPORT

headline: Correction
text: A headline last Sunday about a Muslim man and an Orthodox Jewish woman who are partners in two Dunkin’ Donuts stores described their religions incorrectly. The two faiths worship the same God — not different ones.

headline: U.S. Starts First Major Pullout From Iraq, Beginning With Brigade Members
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 24  The first substantive drawdown of American troops in Iraq has begun, as the first members of a brigade in Diyala Province have started to leave, American military officials in Baghdad said Saturday.

headline: From New Mutual Funds, Help in Serving the Nest Egg
text: WALL STREET has repeatedly sounded alarms to spur working Americans to save more for retirement, but it has been less interested in helping convert nest eggs to spendable, post-paycheck income.

headline: So You Want to Be a Nobelist
text: A couple of years ago, I was wandering the stacks of the science and engineering library at my alma mater, the University of New Mexico, when I spotted, naked on the open shelves, ancient bound copies of the British journal Nature. I pulled down a volume stamped 1953 and it fell right open to Page 737: James Watson and Francis Crick’s well-thumbed paper on the structure of DNA.

headline: Buccaneers Face a Test of Their Progress
text: Going by division standings, the game between the Buccaneers and the Redskins today in Tampa, Fla., is a matchup of the first-place team in the National Football Conference South and a team tied for last place in the N.F.C East. But Tampa Bay (6-4) and Washington (5-5) are separated by only one game in the conference standings, and winning this game is vital to each team’s playoff hopes.

headline: Mitchell Report Could Have Impact on Visas
text: Ten days ago, Robert Hill sent a memo to clients and other interested parties. “ALERT,” the memo began in capital letters. “Anticipated December Release of Mitchell Report May Have Unintended Consequences for Foreign Athletes.”

headline: Stalin’s Children
text: For many years, Orlando Figes observes, the memoirs of intellectual dissidents, like Eugenia Ginzburg and Nadezhda Mandelstam, and the work of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, “were widely greeted as the ‘authentic voice’ of ‘the silenced,’” telling us “what it had ‘been like’ to live through the Stalin Terror as an ordinary citizen.” Their books did indeed reflect the experience of people like themselves, who were “strongly committed to ideals of freedom and individualism.” But they did not represent what happened to millions of other people who were not opponents of the regime and did not engage in any kind of substantial dissent, but were still dispatched to labor camps, to exile in remote settlements or to summary execution. As Figes, a leading historian of the Soviet period, concludes in “The Whisperers,” his extraordinary book about the impact of the gulag on “the inner world of ordinary citizens,” a great many victims “silently accepted and internalized the system’s basic values” and “conformed to its public rules.” Behind highly documented episodes of persecution, famine and war lie quieter, desperate stories of individuals and families who did what they could to survive, to find one another and to come to terms with the burden of being physically and psychologically broken. But it was not only repression that tore families apart. The regime’s reliance on “mutual surveillance” complicated their moral burden, instilling feelings of shame and guilt that endured long after years of imprisonment and exile.

text: WASHINGTON

text: To the Editor:

text: Security Patrols

headline: Monte Carlo Off the Track
text: THE powerful Chevrolet Monte Carlo SS stock car is leaving Nascar’s top series and will be replaced next year in all 36 races by Chevy’s version of the Car of Tomorrow, which will have the Impala SS nameplate splashed across its front bumper.

headline: Fire in Southern California Prompts Evacuations
text: AGOURA HILLS, Calif., Nov. 24  Fierce Santa Ana winds blew a destructive blaze through Malibu on Saturday, a month after wildfires destroyed large parts of Southern California.

headline: Correction: The Cloistral Hush Revisited
text: The Day Out column on Nov. 11 about Oxford University misstated the name of a college there. It is Christ Church, not Christ Church College.

headline: It Looks Old but Drives New
text: THE availability of complete reproduction bodies for some classic models raises many questions, including what to call a car built from such a replica shell. Purists would argue that technically it is not a restoration.

headline: Governor Spitzer’s Holiday Cheer
text: After a recent nose dive in the polls, Gov. Eliot Spitzer appears to be trying to sidle back into the public’s good graces. He comes, as many experienced politicians have learned to do, bearing cash. In little more than a week, the governor has announced state money for upstate and down. The showering of good news for schools, the economy and the city’s transportation system has become so noticeable lately that one suspects the governor was saving a lot of these announcements for his rainy days.

headline: In Kids’ Stealth Foods, Similar Strategies Dished
text: Irvington

headline: A Chicken Coop, but No Tigers
text: THE director Ang Lee, whose films have won eight Oscars out of 27 nominations, does not have a screening room in his four-bedroom home in Larchmont, N.Y., and rarely uses a computer or a cellphone. And instead of a fancy swimming pool in his backyard, he has a chicken coop.

headline: Surf’s Up, Hopes Are Too
text: Seattle

headline: Vikings at Giants
text: Vikings’ run offense/defense

headline: Catch a Train, but Look at the Prancing Horses
text: MOUNT ARLINGTON

headline: Talk of Efforts to Fix Matches Rattles Pro Tennis
text: As the venerable Davis Cup finals begin Friday in Oregon, tennis is mired in a widening gambling scandal in which at least a dozen ranked players have said they have been asked to throw matches or have heard of similar approaches to others.

headline: Armchair Traveler
text: “Sacred Sea: A Journey to Lake Baikal,” by the journalist Peter Thomson, is a superb paean to a unique and bizarre ecosystem.

headline: School Renovation as a Learning Experience
text: THE career aspirations of Maxwell Rivas and Gar Yan Yeung, students at a high school in Manhattan, should please a group of New York City architects and designers.

headline: Colombian Metamorphosis
text: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed the recent Explorer column about Tayrona National Park, “In Colombia, a War Zone Reclaims Its Past” (Nov. 11).

headline: Firefighters Found No Gas in House Before It Exploded
text: Firefighters checked a multifamily house in Sunnyside, Queens, shortly before it exploded last week, but found no evidence of a natural gas leak, the Fire Department said yesterday.

headline: Hits and Misses and Hairy Shows
text: Yo Gotti and Pleasure P

headline: Loves the Beach, the Planet and Movies
