headline: What Makes an N.H.L. Goaltender?
text: While I was in Phoenix with the Coyotes last week, I ran into Darren Pang the energetic TV color analyst and former Blackhawks goalie. I asked him about Pascal Leclaire, whom we wrote about on Sunday. Leclaire, the eighth overall pick in 2001, got his sixth shutout on Friday, and with a Ken Hitchcock team in front of him playing hard on every inch of the ice, Leclaire suddenly looks huge in net.

headline: A View of the Penthouse
text:
A 1970s penthouse that’s modest in scale but
big on invention.

headline: The Patriots’ Place Among the Greats
text: It seems the readers of this blog have a lot to say about the Patriots. So here is more food for thought. Judy Battista’s article for Sunday’s Times compares the Patriots to other dominant teams in N.F.L. history. The Patriots are the 18th team to start a season 10-0; only seven of those teams won a championship. In the article, John Madden said that the Patriots have the best offense he had ever seen, but that their defense does not compare with those of the Steelers of the 1970s and the 1985 Bears. Here’s what others had to say:

headline: Out of the Way
text: Houses tucked away in mews and alleys offer refuges from the chaos of New York City. They rarely come up for sale, and they don't come cheap.

headline: Inside the List
text: BURSTING ON THE SCENE: The Virginia-based thriller writer David Baldacci’s new novel, “Stone Cold,” appears at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list this week. The book is about a secretive and feared Washington group called the Camel Club — feared in part, surely, because its fictional leader is named Oliver Stone. Baldacci’s books have a real audience inside the Beltway. (Bill Clinton was spotted buying Baldacci’s “Simple Truth” at a bookstore in 1999.) And like a politician, he is often asked to speak in public. Baldacci’s Web site, helpfully, provides an “introduction text” for him — that is, suggested words for presenting him to a crowd. The first sentence of this text probably startles the librarians who must sometimes need to recite it, with its code-red level of thriller-world bombast: “Internationally acclaimed best-selling author David Baldacci shocked the publishing world when he burst on the literary scene with his incredible first novel, ‘Absolute Power.’ ” The suggested text ends more demurely: “Please help me welcome David Baldacci.”

headline: The Week Ahead: Nov. 25-Dec.1
text: Film

headline: Vikings Defense Has Manning's Number
text: The Vikings defense utterly confused the Giants and Eli Manning, who threw four interceptions, three of them returned for touchdowns, in a loss to Minnesota.

headline: An Angel in Queens
text: Thanksgiving may be the stuff of volunteerism, but for Jorge Munoz it's another night of serving dinners to immigrant day laborers in Queens.

headline: ‘Avoid Boring People’
text: Remembered Lessons from Childhood on Chicago's South Side

headline: ‘A Free Life’
text: Finally Taotao got his passport and visa. For weeks his parents had feared that China, even if not closing the door outright, would restrict the outflow of people. After the Tiananmen massacre on June 4, 1989, all the American airlines except United had canceled their flights to Beijing and Shanghai. At the good news, Pingping burst into tears. She quickly rinsed the colander in which she had drained the shredded turnip for her jellyfish salad, took off her apron, and set out with her husband, Nan Wu, for the town center of Woodland, where the office of Travel International was located.

headline: Methodology
text: To build a comprehensive picture of what happens to wrongly convicted people after they leave prison, The New York Times tried to reach all 206 exonerated prisoners tracked by Aug. 1 by the Innocence Project, based in New York. All were exonerated based on DNA evidence. Although defense lawyers pointed out a few names missing from the Innocence Project’s list, it is widely regarded as the most thorough record of DNA-related exonerations.

headline: ‘Arsenals of Folly’
text: To the Chernobyl Sarcophagus

headline: ‘Dough’
text: REMEMBRANCE 2006

headline: ‘The Confidante’
text: At the Conservatoire Hector Berlioz in Paris, an eager group of sixteen French youngsters were learning to read music when they received a special visitor: a secretary of state on a mission to reshape American diplomacy-and her own image.

headline: Don’t Faze Me, Hermano
text: “Don’t Tase Me, Bro” T-shirts are so yesterday — and so Anglo. The slogan du jour in the Spanish-speaking world is “Why don’t you shut up?” — after the King of Spain’s gentle suggestion to President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela. It’s become an instant hit in ringtones (see below) and apparel (right). And as the Week in Review notes, the episode has become a comic opera illustrating the unendingly complicated relations between Spain and its former colonies.

headline: In Iowa, Clinton Is Pressed on Murdoch
text: FORT DODGE, Iowa – The curious relationship between Hillary Rodham Clinton, presidential candidate, and Rupert Murdoch, media baron, flashed briefly before the eyes of Iowans on Saturday night during a Clinton campaign event.

headline: Did Obama Inhale?
text: AUDUBON, Iowa – In early caucus and primary states, voters play one very important role in the presidential race long before they cast their ballots: They ask questions.

headline: On coming across
text: Why I’m not a proper political journalist:

headline: Red tide rising
text: The fall in the federal deficit since 2003 has been widely used by conservatives — including the Bush administration and all the leading candidates for the GOP presidential nomination — as proof that tax cuts actually increase revenue.

headline: Sunday Kickoff: Missouri Has That Winning Feeling
text: Playing on a neutral field with a crowd split practically down the middle proved that Missouri was simply better than Kansas, writes Tom Keegan of the Lawrence Journal-World. Joe Posnanski of the Kansas City Star writes that quarterback Chase Daniel was the difference for Missouri, and his Star colleague Jason Whitlock says the Tigers left no doubt that they are worthy of the No. 1 ranking.

headline: HIP Times
text: Dreaded Home Information Packs (HIPs) will become mandatory for sellers in the U.K. after Dec. 14. Under the program, sellers must provide a lengthy packet of information to potential buyers, including data on energy usage and local title notices.

headline: Huckchuck
text: With the endorsement of Chuck Norris, Mike Huckabee can tap the large Web sub-genre of Chuck Norris martial arts humor — such as it is. (“Some people wear Superman pajamas. Superman wears Chuck Norris pajamas” — You get the idea). And tap Norris is just what Huckabee does, in this ad in Iowa (but have they thought through the formulation “Huckchuck” and what it can be used to rhyme with?):

headline: Giants and Vikings, Some Running Thoughts
text: Vikings running back Chester Taylor gained more than 1,200 yards last year. Giants running back Reuben Droughns has gained more than 1,200 yards in a season twice, first with the Broncos, then with the Browns.

headline: King of Pain
text: Poetry shouldn’t tell us what we already know, though of course it can revive what we think we know. A durable poet, the rarest of all birds, has a unique point of view and the gift of language to express it. The unique point of view can often come from a mental or physical deformity. Deep within us, but also on the surface, is the wounded ugly boy who has never caught an acceptable angle of himself in the mirror. A poet can have a deep sense of himself as a Quasimodo in a world without bells, or as the fine poet Czeslaw Milosz wrote:

headline: Growing Pains in the Pursuit of Happiness
text: There’s a particularly disturbing line in Peter S. Goodman’s sobering cover story on international economic trends and recession forecasts in Week in Review: “Americans have been buying staggering quantities of goods from overseas using money lent by foreigners.”

headline: Clinton: a Liberal, or a Moderate?
text: PERRY, Iowa – It is a favorite question of voters: Hillary Rodham Clinton, a liberal or a moderate?

headline: Fear creeps in
text: More about the developing liquidity crisis, again from the Financial Times:

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter: Thompson Strikes Back
text: Perhaps Chris Wallace on Fox News Sunday wanted to stir things up a bit ­ — the mission of every good talk-show host, no? — or perhaps Fred Thompson had had enough. Regardless, when Mr. Wallace mentioned “a buzz” that the Thompson campaign was underperforming, a feisty Mr. Thompson lashed back.

headline: Health Care: Round II
text: PERRY, Iowa – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just finished a mid-afternoon news conference with reporters here. No major news, but she whacked Senator Barack Obama again – this time by name – over his health insurance plan and the estimates that it would not cover about 15 million Americans.

headline: Helping the Next Generation
text: “I’m so sick of being asked if I’m adopted,” says Lila, and there are nods of understanding.

headline: Big 12 Trophies Come First for Pinkel
text: While Missouri Coach Gary Pinkel spoke to the news media after Saturday night’s 36-28 victory against No. 2 Kansas, he sat in front of a crystal trophy given to the Big 12 North division champion.

headline: When They Told Me Norman Wrote a Book…
text: I’m mightily impressed by the literacy, enthusiasm and high quality of your comments on my previous column, on Norman Mailer.

headline: Sharif Returns to Pakistan
text: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif arrived home in Pakistan from exile to a tumultuous welcome on Sunday evening.

headline: Week 12 Talking Points
text: It’s Sunday afternoon and I am manning (womaning?) the sports fort at the shiny new New York Times building on Eighth Avenue in New York City. No one else will be here for another four hours, so I thought, it’s time to spend some quality time on The Fifth Down. I’ve got the AP wire at my disposal, and the Giants-Vikings game on one screen, and … nothing on the other (thanks, CBS). I’ll try to keep you posted on today’s big headlines and happenings. If you’re out there, please feel free to join the discussion and tell me what you see (just no profanity, no matter how badly your team — real or fantasy — is playing). Just don’t get used to thiskind of attention. It’s a holiday weekend after all. It’s my gift to you (you may not consider it such a gift when this is over).

headline: Manhattan: Woman Hit by Bus
text: A woman crossing the street was struck yesterday by a charter bus leaving Chinatown for Atlantic City, the police said. The woman, 78, whom the police did not identify, was reportedly in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said. The accident occurred shortly after 11:30 a.m. on the Bowery at Broome Street. The woman was crossing Broome, walking south, when the bus, traveling northbound, turned left on Broome and struck her. A witness, Greg Horowitz, 23, an employee at a Bowery lighting store, said the woman was thrown several feet. No charges were filed against the driver yesterday. A man answering the phone at the bus company, Skyline Travel and Tour Bus, declined to comment.

headline: In a Cycle of Attacks, Giuliani Gives and Receives
text: HAMPTON, N.H., Nov. 25  As the presidential campaigns ratcheted up for the post-Thanksgiving countdown to the first nominating contests, Rudolph W. Giuliani found himself under increasingly fierce attacks on Sunday from two of his rivals.

headline: Queens: Officer Struck by Vehicle
text: A New York City police officer was hit by a vehicle as he was crossing Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst, the police said. The police located the vehicle nearby, but it had been abandoned, said the police, who were searching for its driver. The officer, whose name was not released, was in stable condition in Elmhurst Hospital Center and was expected to recover, the police said.

headline: Virgin Group in Lead for Bank
text: LONDON, Nov. 26 — The Virgin Group appeared as the front-runner today to buy Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, after winning the backing of the Treasury and Bank of England, which is trying to recover billions of pounds in emergency loans that have been made over the last two months.

headline: Redskins’ Taylor Is Seriously Injured in Shooting
text: MIAMI, Nov. 26 — Sean Taylor, a safety with the Washington Redskins, was unconscious and fighting for his life today after being shot by an intruder at his home south of Miami, the authorities and one of his lawyers said.

headline: President Bush and ‘Madame Rice’: A Personal Bond Helps Align Policy
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — Condoleezza Rice and President Bush are often described as opposites, but their closest advisers say they are remarkably alike. Both are products of their own elites — Mr. Bush from the old East Coast establishment, Ms. Rice from Southern black professionals — who are supremely self-confident on the surface but harbor resentments underneath. Ms. Rice, like Mr. Bush, has been underestimated her entire life, as an African-American, as a woman and often as the youngest person in the room.

headline: A Low-Tech Writer With a High-Tech Appetite
text: Alan Flacks has been a consummate Upper West Side gadfly for years and a fixture at meetings of the community board and political clubs, including the Three Parks Independent Democrats, where he is the house nudge.

headline: Menagerie, Not Museum, for Words That Live
text: In his 1755 dictionary Samuel Johnson defined the lexicographer as “a writer of dictionaries; a harmless drudge, that busies himself in tracing the original, and detailing the signification of words.” Unfortunately Johnson was uncharacteristically wrong. A lexicographer, if any good, is hardly a drudge, and if bad, is hardly harmless.

headline: Bush’s Best Hope
text: The Palestinians are the cause of exiting and ex-presidents. There’s no electoral payback in supporting them. Jews and Israel-loving evangelicals dwarf any Arab lobby to the extent it’s not even funny.

headline: Rio Tinto Defends Rejection of Bid
text: SINGAPORE, Nov. 26  Almost three weeks after rejecting a takeover proposal from the rival mining company BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto laid out its case today for why it thinks its shareholders should hold out for a better offer.

headline: Fed Injects Funds to Ease Lending Concerns
text: Seeking to reassure banks amid the ongoing credit crisis, the Federal Reserve said today that it would provide $8 billion in funds to ease concerns over lending during the holiday season.

headline: A Gimmick Becomes a Real Trend
text: TWO years ago, Cyber Monday was a marketing gimmick in search of shoppers. This year, it seems to be a genuine trend that retailers have embraced.

headline: Manhattan: Man Charged in Killing
text: The police have charged a man with murder in the shooting of a man whose body was found on a street corner in Harlem last week. The suspect, Mohamed Musaid, 30, who the police said had no known address, was charged in the fatal shooting of Rafik Alsamet, 39, of Melville Street in the Bronx. The police said the killing was part of a continuing dispute. Mr. Alsamet’s body was found at West 133rd Street and Lenox Avenue on Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Wednesday about Milo Radulovich, an Air Force reserve officer whose firing over suspicion that his relatives had Communist connections prompted an Edward R. Murrow documentary on CBS in 1953, omitted a survivor. She is his sister, Margaret Fishman of Detroit. (Go to Article)

headline: New York Manhole Covers, Forged Barefoot in India
text: NEW DELHI — Eight thousand miles from Manhattan, barefoot, shirtless, whip-thin men rippled with muscle were forging prosaic pieces of the urban jigsaw puzzle: manhole covers.

headline: Thompson Calls for Option of a Simplified Income Tax
text: Fred D. Thompson recommended yesterday that people have the option to pay a simplified tax on their income.

headline: Dueling Guitars in Gameland: MTV and Activision Face Off
text: The holiday season is when all the action takes place in the video game business, and this year has already pitted Microsoft’s Xbox 360 against Sony’s PlayStation 3, and sleek new software against sequels like Halo 3.

headline: New York Public Library Buys Schlesinger Papers
text: In a 1976 letter accompanying seven chapters of his biography of Robert F. Kennedy, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. advises his editor at Houghton Mifflin to prepare for “a very long book and promote it.”

headline: A Piano Pounder Stops by, but Things Remain Orderly
text: Not too long ago, even just 10 years ago, Jerry Lee Lewis treated songs as if they didn’t matter. In concerts at times he sped them up, slowed them down, abandoned them in the middle, acted disdainful of them.

headline: The Child in Balanchine Still Jumps for Joy
text: Why has George Balanchine’s production of “The Nutcracker” remained the gold-standard version of this holiday classic? The New York City Ballet began its annual run of the piece on Friday night at the New York State Theater and worked its usual magic, despite generally run-of-the-mill performing. Part of the charm comes from the timelessly old-fashioned costumes by Karinska and sets by Rouben Ter-Arutunian: like candy but not too sweet and blessedly unchanged in spirit over the 53 years since the premiere. And there are a few choice choreographic set pieces and effects in the second act, which essentially departs from the narrative to spool out a series of traditional divertissements, most of them alluding to holiday treats.

headline: Syria Says It Will Join Conference in Maryland
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Syria announced Sunday that it would attend the Middle East peace meeting beginning here Monday night, joining Saudi Arabia and the rest of the Arab League participants in a turnabout that represented a victory for the Bush administration.

headline: You’re Eating That?
text: A few years ago Americans walked into the grocery store and plucked items from the shelves with a confidence that the world could only envy. Now, according to a survey for the Food Marketing Institute, only 66 percent of consumers in the United States are confident that the food they buy is safe, down from 82 percent last year. With news of killer spinach, tainted hamburger patties and imported seafood that can provide as many toxins as omega-3s, who can blame them?

headline: A Flow of Three Composers With a Flavor of the New
text: It is said that people tend to think of themselves as younger than they really are. This is eminently true of classical music. Randall Hodgkinson’s piano recital at Bargemusic on Friday night would qualify to many as contemporary when it should be labeled classic.

headline: Up Close, Farms Annoy Some Seekers of Rural Life
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Out where the Long Island Expressway and suburban sprawl fall away and the village of Riverhead opens onto the North Fork’s expanse of produce stands, farmhouses and acres of crops, a luxury-home development called the Highlands at Aquebogue has sprouted up on Sound Avenue.

headline: Grandparents Face the Challenges of 2 Households
text: Rosario Bencosme, 64, has two homes, two centers of gravity that she travels between on the No. 1 train: the subsidized one-bedroom apartment in Harlem that she and her husband, Pablo Octavio, got in September, and the rented room in Washington Heights that is the home of her younger son and three of her grandchildren.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 9 in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 25 — A car bomb killed nine people near Baghdad’s medical district on Sunday. It was the second major bomb in the Iraqi capital in three days, after a recent lull in violence.

headline: Misgivings Rise Along With Antarctican Tourism
text: OTTAWA, Nov. 25 — From its beginning until its demise, the Explorer was an Antarctic pioneer. Launched in 1969 under the name Lindblad Explorer, it was the first ship built specifically to ferry tourists to Antarctica. When it disappeared beneath the polar region’s waters last week, it became the first commercial passenger ship to sink there.

headline: Chinese Art Sales
text: A five-day sale of 20th-century and contemporary Asian art at Christie’s International in Hong Kong opened yesterday with two works selling for a total of just over $9 million, Bloomberg News reported. An abstract oil by Zao Wou-Ki, a Chinese painter long based in Paris, sold for $3.3 million, a new record for Mr. Zao, and a piece by Chen Cheng-po, a Taiwanese painter who died in 1947, went for $5.8 million. Among the highlights of this week’s sales — which will also include antiques, jewelry and ceramics — are a set of 14 works in gunpowder on paper by Cai Guo-Qiang, a Chinese artist whose solo show at the Guggenheim opens in February, and a Ming dynasty jar expected to fetch $3.9 million.

headline: Conference Title Game Seen as an Obstacle
text: In a college football season that has rendered predictions and prognosticators nearly useless, there is still the comfort of one certainty: There will be controversy over which two teams play for the national title.

headline: Folk, With an Unusual Bunch of Instruments
text: In the tradition of the American folk singer that he has upheld for the last 40 years, Arlo Guthrie usually performs on his own or with a few sidemen. But for his annual holiday concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening Mr. Guthrie went symphonic, turning up with the University of Kentucky Symphony Orchestra, led by John Nardolillo. Mr. Nardolillo and his ensemble also accompany Mr. Guthrie on his latest album, “In Times Like These” (Rising Son Records), recorded this year.

headline: A Long Shot With the Gift for Resisting
text: Bernie Parrish has been a thorn in many sides.

headline: John Noble, Gulag Survivor, Dies at 84
text: John H. Noble, an American who never knew why the Soviets imprisoned him in their notorious gulag, but not only lived to write books on the grim, decade-long experience but also recovered his family’s company and castle in the former East Germany, died on Nov. 10 in Dresden, Germany. He was 84.

headline: Talks Adjourned in Broadway Strike
text: Talks in the Broadway strike were adjourned at 6:30 a.m. Monday between the league representing the theater owners and producers and the union representing the stagehands.

headline: Short of Funds, G.O.P. Recruits the Rich to Run
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — Confronting an enormous fund-raising gap with Democrats, Republican Party officials are aggressively recruiting wealthy candidates who can spend large sums of their own money to finance their Congressional races, party officials say.

headline: Syria Plans to Attend Meeting on Mideast Peace
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — Syria announced Sunday that it would attend the Middle East peace meeting beginning here on Monday night, joining Saudi Arabia and the rest of the Arab League participants in a turnabout that represented a victory for the Bush administration.

headline: Blocking Shots in N.H.L. Involves Skill and Abandon
text: In a blink of time, a sliver of space opened between Philadelphia forward Joffrey Lupul and the Rangers’ net. It was a tantalizing moment for Lupul, who stood to the left of the crease, seemingly set up for a sure goal. But as soon as Lupul took the shot in that Nov. 15 game, he saw Rangers defenseman Fedor Tyutin sliding into his peripheral vision, hurtling legs-first into Lupul’s treasured open space.

headline: In Miles of Alleys, Chicago Finds Its Next Environmental Frontier
text: CHICAGO, Nov. 25 — If this were any other city, perhaps it would not matter what kind of roadway was underfoot in the back alleys around town. But with nearly 2,000 miles of small service streets bisecting blocks from the North Side to the South Side, Chicago is the alley capital of America. In its alleys, city officials say, it has the paved equivalent of five midsize airports.

headline: Kudos for Spike Lee
text: Spike Lee, below, has been chosen to receive the Wexner Prize, a $50,000 award given by the Wexner Center for the Arts at Ohio State University to a contemporary artist in any field “who has been consistently original, influential and challenging to convention,” the Wexner Center announced. Mr. Lee, 50, is to receive the award in a ceremony at the Wexner in February. Previous recipients include the choreographer Bill T. Jones, the architect Renzo Piano, the director Martin Scorsese and the painter Gerhard Richter.

headline: ‘Enchanted’ Charms Filmgoers
text: “Enchanted,” starring Amy Adams, right,  as a fairy-tale princess exiled to “a place where there are no happily-ever-afters” — that would be present-day New York City — was the top draw at movie theaters over the holiday weekend. The film, directed by Kevin Lima and released by Disney, grossed $35.3 million from Friday through Sunday, with a five-day take of just over $50 million since its release on Wednesday, according to estimates by the box-office tracking firm Media by Numbers. “This Christmas” (Sony/Screen Gems), also released Wednesday but shown on only 1,858 screens in the United States and Canada — half as many as for “Enchanted” — came in second with a five-day gross of $27.1 million ($18.6 million from Friday to Sunday). The semi-animated “Beowulf” (Paramount), No. 1 last weekend, fell two spots with five-day ticket sales of $23.3 million and a three-day take of $16.2 million, bringing its two-week total to $56.3 million. “Hitman” (Fox) opened in fourth place with five-day sales of $21 million ($13 million from Friday to Sunday), and “Bee Movie” (Paramount) pulled in just less than $16 million since Wednesday and $12 million since Friday, for a four-week total of $112 million.

headline: The Vikings’ Defense Belies Its Statistics
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 25  After their decimation of the Giants’ offense on Sunday, the Minnesota Vikings’ defensive players came up with two major reasons.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Albany Bars Rent Rise for Thousands
text: A loophole in New York State’s rent regulations that would have led to sharp rent increases for thousands of tenants was closed last week by housing officials.

headline: Getting Paid to Chew Gum Can Be Sweet, but Also Sour
text: WHIPPANY, N.J. — Sue McNamara is the envy of friends and family alike. For a few hours four mornings a week, she sits in a spotless room in a lab coat and chews gum. Then she tells her boss how it tastes. Then she gets paid.

headline: Totals
text: Previously recorded $2,275,895.90

headline: Reading for Test Scores, and for Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: Polite Entertainment From New York’s House Band
text: Music lovers in this city are lucky to have an orchestra as good as the New York Philharmonic to complain about. It plays skillfully, it makes lovely sounds, and Lorin Maazel has schooled it to new heights of discipline. All this was demonstrated once again in the palindromic program — beginning and ending with short, light pieces that bookended a symphony and a concerto — with which the Philharmonic celebrated the Thanksgiving holiday weekend.

headline: Bush Voices Optimism on Eve of Talks
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 — President Bush today welcomed key participants in the Middle East conference that is getting under way in Annapolis, Md., with an acknowledgment that the United States cannot force peace on the region.

headline: Laugh Lines in the Hollywood Strike
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 — When the 12,000 members of the Writers Guild of America decided on Nov. 4 to strike, Hollywood wondered how hard the white-collar group would fight. The guild addressed the worry before the first pickets hit the streets.

headline: Rite Aid Stores in West Selling a Paternity Test Kit
text: Genetic testing is now available at the drugstore. A company called Sorenson Genomics has started selling a paternity test kit through Rite Aid stores in California, Oregon and Washington. It appears to be the first time a DNA test is being sold through a major pharmacy chain.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, an auction of four-week bills tomorrow, an auction of two-year notes on Wednesday and an auction of five-year notes on Thursday.

headline: Gene Therapy Study to Resume After Woman’s Death
text: Federal regulators have given permission for a company to resume a gene therapy study in which a woman died, the company is expected to announce today.

headline: Bitterest Rival of Musharraf Returns Home
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 25 — Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif arrived home from exile to a tumultuous welcome on Sunday evening, providing a new rallying point for Pakistan’s disillusioned opposition and setting the stage for an overnight shift of the political scene in the country.

headline: Second Day of Protests Against Putin in Russia
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 25 — On a second day of rallies against President Vladimir V. Putin, riot police officers broke up a protest in St. Petersburg on Sunday, detaining numerous marchers, including two prominent politicians.

headline: Security Increased at Giants Stadium Ramps
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 25  The security presence on the two spiral ramps at Gate D of Giants Stadium was overwhelming Sunday during halftime of the Giants’ game against the Minnesota Vikings. More than 25 state troopers and 50 security guards patrolled the multilevel ramps.

headline: Test and Switch
text: Congress hoped that if it required the states to give annual tests in return for federal education aid, state politicians would be encouraged  or at least embarrassed  into improving dismal schools and closing the achievement gap between rich and poor children.

headline: Australia’s Path Bends Away From U.S.
text: LONDON, Nov. 25 — The defeat of John Howard, Australia’s prime minister, in Saturday’s election deprived President Bush of one of his most steadfast allies and will bring changes in Australia’s foreign policy that will be felt in Washington.

headline: Manhattan: Three Men Stabbed
text: Three 28-year-old men were stabbed in a parking garage in Midtown early yesterday after an argument, the police said. The stabbing occurred shortly after 4 a.m. in the garage at 810 Seventh Avenue, near a restaurant and bar, Mars 2112, the police said. One man was stabbed eight times in the torso; he was taken to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, where his condition was upgraded during the day to stable from critical. The other two victims were in stable condition at St. Vincent’s Midtown Hospital, the police said. One of them had been stabbed six times, the other, once. There were no arrests yesterday.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Seeks Votes to Tighten Cable Rules
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — The head of the Federal Communications Commission is struggling to find enough support from a majority of the agency’s commissioners to regulate cable television companies more tightly.

headline: True November
text: A couple of days ago we had what the forecasts call a “wintry mix,” which always sounds to me like something you’d set out in bowls at a cocktail party this time of year. It was, in fact, rain, snow and sleet mixed with sand and salt and the sludge that gets thrown from the treads of tires. One minute snow was falling in clumps, and the next it was raining. The sky was the color of duct tape, and it let about that much light through. What a “wintry mix” does is make you want to stay home  or perhaps go into the world foraging for provisions simply for the pleasure of getting home again.

headline: A Big Book Advance for a ‘Last Lecture’
text: A book based on a heartfelt public talk by an ailing Carnegie Mellon professor is to be published by Hyperion, according to Crain’s New York Business. “The Last Lecture,” written by Randy Pausch, a 47-year-old computer science teacher who has terminal pancreatic cancer, and Jeff Zaslow, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal, will be based on a wide-ranging talk that Professor Pausch gave at Carnegie Mellon, in Pittsburgh, on Sept. 18. With scans of the tumors on his liver in the background, Professor Pausch reviewed his life and career. “Brick walls are there for a reason,” he said in the lecture. “They let us prove how badly we want things.” The lecture became a Web video phenomenon and led to appearances on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” and “Good Morning America.” Citing unnamed sources, Crain’s said that Hyperion offered $6.7 million for the book, beating HarperCollins in a bidding war.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Enchanted’ Charms Filmgoers

headline: Immigrants Pull Weight in Economy, Study Finds
text: Immigrants contribute nearly one-fourth of the economic output of New York State, and outside of New York City, they are overrepresented in some of the most critical occupations, including higher education and health care, according to a study to be released today.

headline: Doorstep Protest: Very Real, Very Virtual
text: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, a varied group of 20 or so protesters — some wearing nose rings, others sensible shoes — gathered on Central Park West on the Upper West Side and started shouting insults like “animal murderer” at the top of their lungs, standing a court-ordered 45 feet away from the apartment of Robert J. McSweeney, a former senior vice president of the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Theater Notes
text: Urban Stages’ holiday show, “The Blue Bird,” written by Stanton Wood and Lori Ann Laster, will run from Dec. 14 to Jan. 13. In the musical, based on the play by Maurice Maeterlinck, a mysterious visitor on Christmas Eve leads a city girl on a fantastical journey in search of the “blue bird of happiness.” Information: urbanstages.org. ... Jonathan Groff, above, of “Spring Awakening,” is one of several strike-bound Broadway stars who lent their voices to a recording of “The Sound of Music” being used for a touring production by the Salzburg Marionette Theater. The show will run at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark (njpac.org) for four performances beginning Friday and at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (metmuseum.org) for four shows beginning Dec. 7. ... The Roundabout Theater will offer a discussion series following performances of “The Ritz” at Studio 54 tomorrow and on Dec. 4. “Sex & the Ritz” will be a candid talk with authors and other participants about the sexual revolution and the emergence of AIDS.

headline: Thomas and Knicks Savor One Victory for All It’s Worth
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 25 — Isiah Thomas blew past Fred Jones for a layup, hit a jumper over Jared Jeffries and made a left-handed runner over Nate Robinson. Thomas chuckled throughout it all, projecting the image of a man who had just had a great burden lifted from his psyche.

headline: Vladimir Kryuchkov, Ex-Chief of K.G.B., Dies at 83
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 25 — Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, who as the K.G.B. chief denounced perestroika as a menace to the Soviet Union and then took matters into his own hands by helping to spearhead a coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1991 that collapsed after only three days, died on Friday. He was 83.

headline: Edwards Offers Heating Plan
text: Former Senator John Edwards outlined a proposal yesterday in New Hampshire to lower the cost of heating oil, increase regulation of oil companies and promote energy efficiency.

headline: Rangers Are Fighting an Inefficient Offense
text: Rangers left wing Brendan Shanahan will celebrate his 39th birthday in January, but he grappled with Dallas Stars forward Steve Ott yesterday and drew a lusty cheer from the crowd at Madison Square Garden after he knocked off Ott’s helmet, then wrestled him to the ice.

headline: Talks Resume Again in Broadway Strike
text: Talks in the Broadway strike resumed yesterday between the league representing the theater owners and producers and the union representing the stagehands.

headline: The Day’s Best
text: Patrick Kerney had three sacks and an interception to lead the Seahawks past the Rams, 24-19. Kerney, a defensive end, also forced a fumble for the second week in a row.

headline: It’s How Much You Think You Have
text: People spend money, in large part, based on how much they think they have; and that perception, it seems, is easily manipulated. A series of experiments reported in The Journal of Consumer Research tested the malleability of people’s understandings of how much money, or other resources, they have on hand, and explored the effects on consumption.

headline: From Vienna, a Killer in a Cowboy Suit
text: In his awkward new book about a particularly unappetizing criminal, John Leake struggles to make a case for the egomaniac he has studied. The killer in question, Jack Unterweger, was Austrian born. He has been unknown to English-language readers except for those who favor serial-killer anthologies with titles like “Vulture,” “The Unknown Darkness” and “The Human Predator.”

headline: Rutgers Gets Physical to Win a Rematch
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 25 — About seven months after Rutgers steamrolled Louisiana State to reach the national championship game, the rematch was immensely more difficult. It was 40 minutes of bump-and-grind basketball and the outcome was not decided until the Lady Tigers missed a last-second shot.

headline: Missouri, No. 1? College Football Surprises Again
text: Imagine Albania playing for the World Cup title in soccer, or an amateur golfer approaching the final hole with the United States Open at stake. Think of Adam Sandler as a nominee for best actor at the Academy Awards.

headline: HSBC Moves to Rescue 2 S.I.V.s
text: LONDON, Nov. 26  Europe’s largest bank, HSBC Holdings, said today that it would bail out its two structured investment vehicles, or S.I.V.s, by taking $45 billion in assets onto its balance sheet.

headline: In the Netherlands, Eat, Drink and Be Monitored
text: WAGENINGEN, the Netherlands — At first sight, nothing betrays the strange happenings at the Restaurant of the Future, a spacious, bright university canteen where scientists and students stop in for food and lunchtime chatter.

headline: Lott to Resign His Senate Seat Before Year’s End
text: PASCAGOULA, Miss. Nov. 26 — Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, who was forced to step down as Republican leader in 2002 after making a remark that seemed to support segregation, announced today that he will resign by the end of the year.

headline: A Magazine Challenges the Big Boys
text: There is a room in our house where time has been stopped. There are no flat-panel TVs, no docking stations for the iPod, and no keyboards save my wife’s accordion. In that room — the quaint description is “living room” — there is a large comfortable chair, a good lamp, and a magazine rack groaning with the fruits of American journalism. Almost every day, I drop a magazine there or a longer newspaper article, with the best intention of getting to it when things slow down a bit.

headline: Monday’s Matchup
text: After a stunning loss to the Jets last week, Pittsburgh is happy to be back at Heinz Field. The Steelers are 5-0 at home, where they have outscored their opponents, 154-54, and outgained their opponents by 1,804-923. Willie Parker was held to 52 rushing yards last week, but Miami entered the weekend with the N.F.L.’s worst run defense, allowing 154.9 yards a game. This will be Miami linebacker Joey Porter’s first game against his former team. Porter went to three Pro Bowls in eight seasons as a Steeler, but was cut in a money-saving move in the off-season. He signed a five-year, $32 million contract with the Dolphins. Porter was certainly a leader on the team, but Pittsburgh has had the No. 1 defense without him.

headline: Patriots Are Unbeaten but Don’t Look Unbeatable
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Nov. 25 — A golden full moon loomed over Gillette Stadium a few hours before kickoff, which should have been all the indication anybody needed that strange things might happen.

headline: A Notorious Main Drag, in Line for Big Changes
text: DENVER, Nov. 21 — Colfax Avenue is often described as one of America’s wickedest streets. Jack Kerouac wrote of its tawdry watering holes in “On The Road.” In the movie “Every Which Way But Loose,” Clint Eastwood’s character and his pet orangutan, Clyde, came here looking for action.

headline: Pressure for Results: The Politics of Tallying the Number of Iraqis Who Return Home
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 25 — At a row of travel agencies near the highway to Syria, the tide of migration has reversed: the buses and GMC Suburban vans filled with people heading to Damascus run infrequently, while those coming from the border appear every day.

headline: If at First You Don’t ... You Know the Rest
text: Surely no publication has struggled to follow its own advice more than Success, the small-business magazine that has failed repeatedly since it was founded in 1891.

headline: Rough Day for Manning and the Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 25 — Eli Manning wore a look of disgust. He had just thrown an interception, and a Vikings defender had run past him on the way to the end zone. Manning looked as if he could not believe what he had done and what he was seeing.

headline: Two Titles in San Francisco
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 — The first national titles at the Fall North American Bridge Championships were decided here Saturday. Bjorn Fallenius and Zia Mahmood of New York won the Bobby Nail Life Master Pairs, just under one board ahead of Michael Prahin of Irvington, N.Y., and Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J. Third were Bobby Levin and Roy Welland of New York.

headline: ABC News and Facebook in Joint Effort to Bring Viewers Closer to Political Coverage
text: Facebook, the popular social networking site, has become a full-fledged platform for communicating, sharing and advertising. ABC News is betting that it will become a platform for political coverage, as well.

headline: This Year’s Models: Searching for Fresh Approaches in Photography
text: Bright letters announce “New Photography 2007” on a wall outside the Museum of Modern Art’s photography galleries. Just inside is a room of vintage-looking black-and-white photographs. Contemporary photographers are showing a strong interest in early photography, so your first thought is that the curator has unearthed someone recycling the ideas and methods of Eadweard Muybridge, Alfred Stieglitz or Clarence White.

headline: Ruminations on Food as Soap, Food for Singles and Henry Miller
text: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, media and popular culture.

headline: A Surprise Gig by Two From U2
text: Bono and the Edge (above, left and right) of U2 made a surprise appearance at a charity concert in a London church on Friday night, The Associated Press reported. Warming up a crowd of about 250 as part of a benefit for Mencap, a British organization that helps people with learning disabilities, they played four songs in a 20-minute acoustic set: “Stay (Faraway, So Close!),” “Desire,” “Angel of Harlem” and “Wave of Sorrow (Birdland),” a rarity that was intended for U2’s 1987 album, “The Joshua Tree,” but not released until the record’s new 20th-anniversary edition. “Don’t tell Larry and Adam we’ve done this,” Bono said, referring to Larry Mullen Jr., the band’s drummer, and Adam Clayton, its bassist. The show was at the Union Chapel, a church that also presents concerts, and Reuters reported that Mr. Clayton was in the audience.

headline: Doling Out Other People’s Money
text: A couple of years ago, Judge Harold Baer Jr. found himself with $6 million of unclaimed money from the settlement of an antitrust class-action lawsuit. The case had involved fashion models, so he decided to give the extra money to charities likely to assist them.

headline: Behind Rice’s Shift on Leading Mideast Peace Efforts
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — At President Bush’s first National Security Council meeting in January 2001, he announced that he did not want to be drawn into the shattered Middle East peace process, people at the meeting recalled, because he believed that former President Bill Clinton had pushed so hard for an Israeli-Palestinian accord that he made the situation worse.

headline: Winter of Our Discontent
text: “Americans’ Economic Pessimism Reaches Record High.” That’s the headline on a recent Gallup report, which shows a nation deeply unhappy with the state of the economy. Right now, “27% of Americans rate current economic conditions as either ‘excellent’ or ‘good,’ while 44% say they are ‘only fair’ and 28% say they are poor.” Moreover, “an extraordinary 78% of Americans now say the economy is getting worse, while a scant 13% say it is getting better.”

headline: Oxford Union Debate Features Holocaust Denier
text: OXFORD, England, Nov. 26 — In the face of angry protests, the Oxford Union debating society went ahead today with plans for an evening debate featuring David Irving, a British author jailed in Austria in 2005 for denying the Holocaust, and Nick Griffin, leader of the far-right British National Party, acquitted by a British court last year of stirring racial hatred.

headline: Faux Fiscal Discipline
text: In the 2000 campaign, Gov. George W. Bush rebutted charges that he was a big spender, noting that on his watch, Texas state spending had been modest “when adjusted for inflation and population.” That answer is utterly reasonable. Spending that is more or less constant in terms of the cost of living and the number of beneficiaries is hardly runaway.

headline: High Empathy (Mostly Women), Low Empathy (Mostly Men) and the Movies
text: Women looking for a movie date and filmmakers looking to increase box-office receipts both know that many men have little interest in melodramatic tearjerkers. New research, however, suggests that producers of emotional films can increase their male audience by emphasizing the films’ disconnection from reality.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC SIGNALS Housing will be a focus for the week. On Wednesday, the National Association of Realtors reports on existing home sales for October. And on Thursday, the Commerce Department reports on new-home sales for October and Freddie Mac reports on mortgage rates.

headline: Antismoking Activist Calls Rolling Stone Insert ‘One Great Big Cigarette Ad’
text: An insert in Rolling Stone magazine sponsored by Camel cigarettes is under fire from antismoking activists because, they say, it blurs the line between advertising and editorial content — and worse yet, features cartoons.

headline: Alternative Journalist’s Web Site Is Scrutinized for Writers’ Strike News
text: When some striking members of the Writers Guild of America created a series of videos depicting speechless actors in support of the writers’ cause, they did not post them on the guild’s Web site or on YouTube. Instead, the videos made their premiere exclusively on Deadline Hollywood Daily, a Web site owned and operated by Nikki Finke, a columnist for the alternative newspaper LA Weekly.

headline: Rice Benefits From a Tight Bond With Bush
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — Condoleezza Rice and President Bush are often described as opposites, but their closest advisers say they are remarkably alike. Both are products of their own elites — Mr. Bush from the old East Coast establishment, Ms. Rice from Southern black professionals — who are supremely self-confident on the surface but harbor resentments underneath. Ms. Rice, like Mr. Bush, has been underestimated her entire life, as an African-American, as a woman and often as the youngest person in the room.

headline: Malibu Fire Is Largely Contained
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 — The fire that burned nearly 5,000 acres and destroyed about 50 homes in Malibu over the weekend was 70 percent contained on Sunday, officials said.

headline: Let Venezuela Ask First
text: To the Editor:

headline: New CDs
text: ‘JORDIN SPARKS’  (19/Jive/Zomba)

headline: Rice’s Turnabout on Mideast Talks
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 — At President Bush’s first National Security Council meeting in January 2001, he announced that he did not want to be drawn into the shattered Middle East peace process, people at the meeting recalled, because he believed that former President Bill Clinton had pushed so hard for an Israeli-Palestinian accord that he made the situation worse.

headline: In West Iowa, Obama’s Man Thinks Locally
text: MISSOURI VALLEY, Iowa, Nov. 24 — Rory Steele had bounced along a gravel road that rides like a washboard to get to the farmstead. He stepped across a few rows of soybeans, climbed up the steps of a red Case combine and squeezed into a seat next to Lyle McIntosh, who was circling a field.

headline: Jaguars Roll Into a Rematch With the Colts
text: Fred Taylor ran for a season-high 104 yards and a touchdown, Josh Scobee kicked five field goals and the Jaguars routed the Bills, 36-14, yesterday.

headline: Couples’s Back, and His Game, Hold Up Fine
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. Nov. 25  Impervious to the whims of style, the ravages of time and even global warming, Fred Couples is still as cool as a fall morning in the desert. This has always been one of golf’s sure things, and it remains unchanged. Only one thing in life can make Couples sweat, and Sunday his often-injured back felt good enough to prevent any beads from popping out on his brow.

headline: Talks Resume Again in Broadway Strike
text: Talks resumed today between the Broadway producers’ league and the striking stagehands’ union as they tried to reach an agreement that would end the walkout that has left most theaters dark for 16 days.

headline: Retail Sales Rise, but Stores Relied on Discounts
text: Black Friday was big — but with a big caveat.

headline: Starting a New Chapter After Foundation Jobs End
text: When Susan V. Berresford steps down as president of the Ford Foundation in January, she hopes to join the LAFF Society. That is, “If they’ll have me,” she said.

headline: Classic, Flashy, Naughty: Which Nutcracker Works for You?
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 — From Baryshnikov to Barbie, anyone who has ever spent time on toes, it sometimes seems, has danced “The Nutcracker.”

headline: Who’ll Pay the Price for Corporate Failure?
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York’s Construction Boom Puts More Women in Hard Hats
text: Olga Aguilar walked through a tunnel of scaffolding at 6:30 a.m. on a recent weekday and into the Brompton, a 20-story condominium building going up at 86th Street and Third Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: Taking Marriage Private
text: Olympia, Wash.

headline: Addiction and Community
text: To the Editor:

headline: Take Tea and See, Again
text: Decades ago, tea makers took out ads that urged coffee-mad consumers to “Take tea and see.” Today, a leader in the booming tea market is asking tea drinkers to take another look at their favorite beverage.

headline: An Indiana Representative Has Terminal Cancer
text: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 25 (AP)  Representative Julia Carson, Democrat of Indiana, has terminal lung cancer, a newspaper reported Sunday.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Franco Bonadio was named chief executive at Identica, London, part of the Cossette Communication Group, effective in early January. He will succeed Michael Peters, the founder of Identica, who will serve as a consultant. Mr. Bonadio is global creative director at the Body Shop retail chain, London, part of L’Oréal.

headline: Tensions Rise for Colombia and Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 25  Venezuela and Colombia moved toward a diplomatic crisis on Sunday after an exchange of insults between President Hugo Chávez and his Colombian counterpart, Álvaro Uribe.

headline: A Touch of Lavender Amid an Embarrassment of Suitors
text: Faced with the challenge of staging a 17th-century play, a director is generally thought to have two options: Stay true to the period or update. With her production of George Farquhar’s “Constant Couple,” written in 1699, at the Pearl Theater Company, Jean Randich has the sense to leave a good play largely alone and the wit to establish small links to the present: bits of anachronistic costuming (a pair of defiantly 21st-century shoes) or speech inflection.

headline: After Cyclone, Bangladesh Faces Political Storm
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Nov. 24 — The political storm that preceded nature’s latest assault on this country still swirls overhead.

headline: British Firms Urge Action on Climate
text: LONDON, Nov. 25 — Britain’s largest companies are pledging to offer greener products and invest in research and technology as part of a wider push to reduce carbon emissions.

headline: William O’Neill, 77, a Connecticut Governor, Is Dead
text: William A. O’Neill, the son of a small-town tavern owner who rose through Connecticut politics to serve as governor for a decade, died Saturday. He was 77.

headline: Anti-Putin Protesters Arrested in Russia
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 25 — On a second day of rallies against President Vladimir V. Putin, riot police officers aggressively broke up a protest in St. Petersburg on Sunday, detaining numerous marchers, including two prominent politicians.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Stocks Plummet; Bond Yields Sag
text: The stock market fell sharply late today and investors rushed to the safety of Treasuries as concerns about mortgage-related losses continued to unsettle the financial market.

headline: Bits
text: What Amazon’s E-Reader Needs

headline: Around the World in One Night
text: The fifth annual GlobalFest, a one-night showcase of top world-music performers, will be held on Jan. 13 at Webster Hall in Manhattan. Connected to a conference of the Association of Performing Arts Presenters, this year’s GlobalFest will feature 13 performers on three stages, including the eccentric Italian songwriter Vinicio Capossela; Fallou Dieng, a rising star of Senegalese mbalax; the Korean drumming group Dulsori; Chango Spasiuk, an accordionist from Argentina; José Manuel Cobles (a k a Puerto Plata), an octogenarian guitarist and singer from the Dominican Republic; Samarabalouf, a French Gypsy jazz band; and Toumast, a guitar group from the deserts of Niger. Tickets: (866) 448-7849 or globalfest-ny.org.

headline: Reader Responses
text: "I just finished reading your article in today's paper. I am a physician and occasionally debate the topic of mistakes, errors, and negligence with legal acquaintances. The plaintiff attorneys equate error with negligence (and therefore payment) without exception. I counter that while certainly not desired, and as you point out when someone's life is in your hands we strive to "avoid mistakes as much as possible", perfection is not humanly possible. Negligence is, or should be, harmful action beyond the range of customary or expected outcome. In my opinion, this is not the same as error free which is an unattainable standard. Yet, try and convince a lay jury in retrospective analysis a decision, diagnosis, judgment was "wrong" but not negligent.

headline: Looking Back at Four ‘Crossroads’
text: Excerpts from recent interviews with some of the Country Music Television series’ alumni.

headline: Suzanne Farrell Ballet
text: Images from the company at the Kennedy Center.

headline: The Stock Isn’t Jumpin’, but the Store Is
text: Starbucks’ stock has been decaffeinated lately, as The Times notes. Maybe Starbucks needs to reconsider a rejected ad jingle:

headline: More of Your Monologue Jokes!
text: Readers continue to prove that even with late-night comedy writers on strike, there’s no shortage of jokes out there (send yours via the comment link below). Here are a few (more than a few, actually) from something of a ringer: Patrick Gorse of Pasadena, Calif., who cranks ’em out daily for radio shows:

headline: Costco Diplomacy
text: A story on our most e-mailed list about the belt-tightening Washington elite notes that the Cheney family, Sally Quinn and foreign embassies all shop at Costco now. But Jimmy Kimmel shows how it’s really done:

headline: Hedge Fund Raises Stake in Northern Rock
text: As bidders continued to circle Northern Rock, SRM Capital, a Monaco-based hedge fund firm, has bumped up its stake in the troubled British lender.

headline: Britain’s Kelda Accepts $6.2 Billion Bid
text: The Kelda Group, a British water utility, said Monday that it had accepted a 3 billion pound ($6.2 billion) takeover approach from a consortium of infrastructure investment firms. Its announcement of the bid on Friday sent its shares almost 15 percent higher.

headline: French Banks Acquire Bond Insurance Company
text: Another crack in the subprime mortgage market appeared to have been patched Thursday as two French banks bought out a bond-insurance company that has exposure to the mortgage crisis.

headline: Wonder Woman
text: Gail Simone has become the first woman to serve as “ongoing writer”  in Wonder Woman's 66-year history.

headline: Four Bidders Said to Consider DundeeWealth Bid
text: At least four of Canada’s biggest financial institutions have signed confidentiality agreements to explore a takeover of DundeeWealth, and potential bidders are expected to decide within days whether to submit offers, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Fund of Hedge Funds Taps Public Markets
text: Gottex Fund Management, the Lausanne- and London-based fund of hedge funds group, this month made its opening on the Swiss Exchange, the latest in a line of alternative asset managers cashing in on a perceived appetite among investors for publicly quoted hedge funds.

headline: China Railway Raises $3 Billion in I.P.O.
text: The China Railway Group, a construction contractor, said it had raised 22.44 billion yuan ($3 billion) in its initial public offering in Shanghai on Friday after generating record interest in its $5.5 billion offer on the Hong Kong and Shanghai markets.

headline: Diller Plans $100 Million Push into China
text: Barry Diller, the chief executive of the Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp, said Friday that the company would invest $100 million to expand in China by creating services for local users.

headline: Hagemeyer and Rexel Finalize $4.6 Billion Deal
text: Dutch electrical wholesaler Hagemeyer threw its full support behind a 3.13 billion euro ($4.6 billion) break-up bid from a French rival, Rexel on Friday.

headline: Philips Hits the Switch on $2.7 Billion Genlyte Deal
text: Philips Electronics has agreed to buy the Genlyte Group, a lighting maker based in Louisville, Ky., for $2.7 billion (1.8 billion euros), making it the top lighting company in North America and sending its shares up to a week-high.

headline: Bain Taps New Chief for Yacht Builder
text: Bain Capital has appointed the former chief operating officer of Arcor, a German fixed-line telecommunications provider to run one of its portfolio companies.

headline: Spanish Bank Boosts Stake in Iberia Airline
text: An unlisted savings bank Caja Madrid has built a stake of more than 23 percent in the Spanish flagship airline Iberia in a move that could disrupt a potential bidding war for the airline, Europe’s fourth-largest carrier.

headline: Banks Also Got a Boost on Black Friday
text: Holiday shoppers weren’t the only ones seeking bargains on Black Friday.

headline: Islamic Banking Enters Mainstream
text: Rising oil wealth is lifting Islamic banking, which adheres to the laws of the Koran and its prohibition against charging interest, into the financial mainstream.

headline: Enron Lawyers Seek $700 Million in Fees
text: Lawyers who recovered about $7.2 billion in settlements for investors who were damaged by the collapse of the energy trader Enron in late 2001 are seeking $700 million for their efforts, the largest fee in history in a securities fraud case.

headline: Britain Plans New Look at Private Equity
text: The British House of Commons Treasury Select Committee plans another inquiry into Britain’s private equity industry, which continues to fend off criticism over its secretive nature and swelling profits.

headline: Cerberus Responds to United Rentals Suit
text: Cerberus Capital Management, in its latest attempt to scuttle its $4 billion purchase of United Rentals, said it had filed a request on Wednesday for declaratory judgment in New York State Supreme Court.

headline: Goldman Boards TPG’s $2 Billion Russian Deal
text: The buyout shop, TPG Capital, is teaming up with Goldman Sachs‘s private equity arm to help finance its acquisition of a Russian supermarket chain, Seventh Continent, as TPG seeks to expand its European network.

headline: Is Murdoch Mulling Deal for LinkedIn?
text: Does Rupert Murdoch have his eye on LinkedIn, the networking site for professionals? TechCrunch reported that it had heard an “unconfirmed rumor” from “a reliable source” that LinkedIn is in talks with the media giant News Corporation over a possible buyout in January.

headline: Google-Backed 23andMe Debuts
text: 23andMe, an online company backed by funds from Google that is selling a personal DNA test for $999, has made its start as a kind of genetics-focused MySpace or Facebook, but with the more serious aim of allowing medicine someday to target Americans’ ills more precisely.

headline: Goldman Said to Seek $6 Billion for New Fund
text: Goldman Sachs is aiming to raise between $4 billion and $6 billion for a new hedge fund as the investment bank tries to rebuild its reputation in the hedge fund business, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Branson Group Chosen for Northern Rock Rescue
text: The British government has chosen a consortium led by Richard Branson’s Virgin Group as the preferred bidder to rescue the troubled lender  Northern Rock. The Virgin group has said it plans to repay 11 billion pounds ($22.6 billion) quickly to the Bank of England.

headline: The List Is Stellar, but a Little Dated
text: When Doubledown Media published the first issue of Corporate Leader magazine this month, it included a list of the “100 Best C.E.O.’s.” But if there is a second annual listing, at least four of those chief executives will be missing.

headline: Rio Tinto Defends Rejection of BHP Billiton
text: The mining giant Rio Tinto promoted its assets and growth prospects Monday as it moved to justify its earlier rejection of a takeover proposal from a rival, BHP Billiton, a multibillion dollar deal that would be among the world’s largest buyouts.

headline: This Week’s Links: The ‘Thumb Generation’ and the Rise of the Writer-Entrepreneur
text: Since last week ended on a Wednesday, I never got around to my Friday links. So now that I’m completely off schedule, I’m treating Monday like Friday and sharing a couple of inspiring reads I consumed these past few days between turkey and television.

headline: Using Genius, Are the Weinsteins Plotting an I.P.O.?
text: Genius Products, whose main business is the home video distribution of The Weinstein Company, is stirring considerable commotion with plans to list on the Nasdaq exchange as soon as next month, Fortune reports.

headline: Does She Get a Raise if She Can She Walk at the Same Time?
text: From Monday’s paper:

headline: Union Backs Tata Bid for Jaguar and Land Rover
text: Ford Motor‘s British union Wednesday endorsed India-based Tata Group‘s bid to buy the Jaguar and Land Rover units.

headline: Spector Keeps Vested Stock in Bear Exit
text: The exit package for Warren Spector, the former president of Bear Stearns, insures that the man charged with the oversight of two internal hedge funds that spectacularly blew up this summer won’t want for money, The New York Post reported.

headline: New York On Track to Outdo London Listings
text: The amount of money raised through initial public offerings in New York is set to surpass London for the first time in three years as companies fuel a surge in I.P.O. volume in spite of the turmoil in capital markets, The Financial Times reported.

headline: For Lawyers, Perks to Fit a Lifestyle
text: The perks for lawyers have burgeoned in recent years as firms pull out the stops to attract top-notch talent. While extras for the partners have always been common, many are now finding their way to associates – young lawyers who have not yet made partner, The New York Times reports.

headline: $300 Billion in Mortgage Write-Offs Is Predicted
text: Losses in the distressed mortgage sector of the United States could reach $300 billion, only a portion of which has so far been accounted for by write-offs at major banks, according to a study released on Thursday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

headline: Citadel Said to Be Up 27% for the Year
text: Despite market volatility, the Citadel Investment Group, a hedge fund based in Chicago, has gained 27 percent year to date in what’s shaping up to be its second straight showing of double-digit returns, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Why hate Huckabee?
text: There are things about Mike Huckabee that make me very nervous — things like this:

headline: HSBC to Restructure 2 SIVs
text: HSBC Holdings said Monday it would consolidate two structured investment vehicles, or SIVs, bringing $45 billion of assets onto the British lender’s balance sheet. The move, which is expected to reduce the worldwide assets in SIVs, comes as United States banks are trying to organize an $80 billion fund to stabilize these kinds of vehicles.

headline: Dubai Buys ‘Substantial’ Stake in Sony
text: Dubai International Capital, a private equity company owned by the ruler of Dubai, said it had made a “substantial investment” in Sony, boosting the shares of the Japanese electronics and entertainment firm.

headline: Unleash Your Wit
text: Arf! Tell us what’s going on in the photo above. It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Oprah Set to Campaign for Obama
text: DES MOINES — Oprah Winfrey is coming to town for Senator Barack Obama, his campaign announced today, scheduling a three-state tour beginning here on Dec. 8.

headline: The 2007 Awards Season Begins
text: Starting today, the Bagger returns for another year of Oscars analysis and more.

headline: The Early Word: Giuliani Revives N.H. Campaign
text: G.O.P. candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani criss-crossed New Hampshire on a bus this weekend, shifting his strategy a bit away from his concentration on the states that vote Feb. 5 and focusing more on his rivals who have long courted the Granite State’s vote.

headline: A Glorious Trainwreck
text: Thankfully, the one thing the Bagger has been allowed to do is see movies, although he has been forced to wear a disguise that involves a fake nose and a rather unfortunate beret. And so far, this season has been like a trip to the magic multi-plex, where the Goobers are free, the popcorn is bottomless and all the clinkers are at some other theater.

headline: Jaunty Is as Jaunty Does
text: Take a good long look at that new logo hanging over the proceedings above us. The Bagger has gone all jaunty. During the off-season, corporate did extensive consumer research and discovered that the rumpled, over-the-hill version of the Bagger was in need of updating. The focus groups have spoken and the hoary use of metaphor in the blog will now be a thing of the past, as will cute asides about stuff that has nothing to do with movies.

headline: Albany Bans Rent Increases for Thousands of Mitchell-Lama Tenants
text: A loophole in New York State’s rent regulations that would have led to sharp rent increases for thousands of tenants was closed last Wednesday by housing officials. The rule allowed landlords withdrawing from government subsidy programs to immediately bring the rent in their apartments up to market rate by claiming that exiting the programs created a “unique and peculiar” circumstance.

headline: BofA Said to Take Lead in Super-SIV Outreach
text: The much-ballyhooed $75 billion fund known as the Super-Siv seems to be moving full-speed ahead, despite ongoing concerns that it will do little to revive the asset-backed securities market.

headline: No Fond Farewells for Lott
text: “Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., the minority whip is in the midst of informing close allies that he plans to resign his senate seat before the end of the year,” reports NBC News.

headline: Finding Perfect Jeans for an Imperfect Body

headline: U.N. Torture Panel Singles Out Tasers
text: All news reports about deaths that follow Taser shocks seem to come with two accompaniments: outrage over police brutality on the one hand, and a lack of definitive proof that the weapon was to blame on the other. A man’s death in Vancouver, B.C., on Saturday was no different. But it happened to come a day after a United Nations panel appeared to take a stand against Tasers.

headline: London’s Savoy: Buy a Piece of Hotel History

Seelye writes about how the Democrats are opening the doors of their convention in Denver next year to more bloggers than ever before. “The move gives bloggers and the new media a chance to shine, much as they did at the trial of Scooter Libby earlier this year, and to bring a whole new perspective, and competition, to convention coverage.”

text: My Thanksgiving was bookended by Iowa: Monday-Wednesday there with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton; Thursday-Friday at my parents’ home in Boston; Saturday-Sunday there with post-holiday Hillary. This meant keeping pace with an atypical load of logistics.

headline: Monday Kickoff: Coaching Carousel Starts Spinning
text: With the regular season over for many teams, there will be plenty of hiring and firing in the next few weeks. Mike Sherman is expected to be named Texas A&M’s new football coach at a news conference today, according to a report by Brian Davis of the Dallas Morning News. Georgia Tech has scheduled a news conference for later today and ESPN.com’s Mark Schlabach is reporting that the university will announce the firing of Coach Chan Gailey. As for Nebraska, it has interviewed Bo Pelini and Turner Gill is expected to be next, according to Brian Christopherson and Steven M. Sipple of the Lincoln Journal Star.

headline: Analysis: Beware Hedge Funds Bearing Advice
text: Hedge funds can inspire terror in boardrooms these days. Whereas directors might once have trashed an angry letter from a hedge-fund manager holding a few million shares of their companies, in this age of investor activism, they are far more apt to listen — and, in many cases, go along with the fund manager’s demands.

By some estimates, two-fifths of the new shares offered in initial public offerings this year will come from private-equity-backed companies.

text: Kazutaka Yamada, known as Kossan, is a rollerblading Buddhist monk who offers prayers to passersby in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: The Case Against a Mideast Fact Box
text: “Here are facts,” The Associated Press wrote in the introduction to a 178-word sidebar to its coverage of the the Middle East peace meeting beginning tonight in Annapolis, Md. But in the Middle East, the facts are rarely so easily summed up, as evidenced by an 886-word rebuttal to the sidebar, posted at Just World News, a blog by Helena Cobban.

headline: On Ships (Not Chips)
text: Hey, gang, I’m back. And darned glad, too. I appreciate your tolerance for my two-week absence from this blog; during that time, I finished a 900-page book (writing, not reading), spoke on a ten-day Geek Cruise to the Panama Canal, got sick and then better, and, of course, had Thanksgiving.

headline: Searching for Names on an Island of Graves
text: New York City has agreed to turn over 1,300 pages of records that could shed light on the identities of some 50,000 people who have been buried over the past several decades at Hart Island, the city’s public burial ground in Long Island Sound.The records are a missing piece of a puzzle that has obsessed Melinda Hunt, a sculptor, writer and filmmaker who lives in the East Village, for more than 16 years.

headline: Who’s Afraid of “Soulless Scientism”?

In some ways, though, the bank seems to have done better than its rivals even without an official top risk manager — for now, at least.

headline: Monday’s Links: Favre Tackles Complacency
text: It is hard to define what makes a great quarterback, but when Brett Favre, quarterback of the 10-1 Packers, comes out and says that he’s concerned about the team’s complacency and rather than celebrate their success is worried about their future, it seems as if that might just be a blueprint. Favre tells Chris Jenkins of The Capital Times “I never thought we’d be 10-1 and be as loose as we are. I worry each week that this complacency and stuff will creep up on us, and it may. I don’t know.”

headline: In Defense of Cable Bundling
text: To consumers who pay dearly for cable television — sometimes more than $100 a month — a la carte pricing sounds like common sense, not to mention a welcome innovation. Why not pay just for the particular channels you watch and not for the ones you don’t?

headline: Planning Panel Approves Columbia Expansion
text: After a tumultuous and bitter meeting replete with persistent heckling, the New York City Planning Commission voted this afternoon to approve Columbia University’s much-debated plan for a 17-acre campus expansion in Harlem. The plan now goes to the City Council, which is expected to modify it before giving final approval.The commission’s decision marks an important step — though not the final one — in the often difficult process known as the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, or Ulurp.

headline: Full Gallop
text: What the Giammetti post reveals to me is that a candid discussion leads to all kinds of other thoughts and information: the real tool of our lives. We cannot have enough sharp tools in our box. I did not see a recent discussion about George Orwell on one of the TV book-chat programs, but I heard the participants discussed how language (and, inevitably, our understanding of events) is increasingly corrupted by feel-good phrases, like “support our troops” — mainly offered by political conservatives and spread by the media to help avoid scrutiny. I mention this because the fashion industry is under extreme pressure from marketing. One of the biggest marketing/PR hoaxes is that grand old Paris fashion houses should be revived. Why on earth do we need Schiaparelli? Ah, because Diego Della Valle can make some money. It’s not complicated. There is no altruistic motive (let’s save a great name!). The fashion world, like the literary and art worlds, is full of great names that only a few people take the time and interest to investigate. But it’s limited, and should be limited. So they are reviving Ossie Clark—to capitalize on the fact that dozens of designers have already dipped into the Ossie well? Too late. Anyway, I’m not interested. I am intrigued by the latest Halston revival, mainly because of the players involved and because I like the challenge of seeing Halston done in a contemporary way. A journalist can examine the details of the current strategy without shoveling the nostalgia.

headline: Free Garry Kasparov
text: Garry Kasparov stopped by The Times recently to talk about his campaign in opposition to Russian President Vladimir Putin. Mr. Kasparov, the former world chess champion, was realistic about the steep odds against his fledgling movement succeeding at the ballot box. The point is not to win elections, he said, but to have elections.

headline: It’s a Sign, Evoking Memories of Lonnie’s in Chinatown
text: Old Chinatown and New Chinatown are united at 21 Mott Street, where a rusty 50-year-old coffee shop sign was uncovered, refurbished and placed on the front wall of a hip new noodle shop — the sort of lost New York tale that draws people who yearn for tangible echoes of their memories.For more than 20 years, starting in 1956, Lonnie’s Coffee Shoppe sat alone among dozens of Chinese restaurants as the solitary Happy Days-style burger joint on Chinatown’s narrow streets. “Lonnie” was Lon Ying Lee, whose family originally hailed — like 80 percent of Chinese American immigrants before 1950 — from the Taishan region of the Guangdong Province, also known as Toisan.

headline: Wash Your Clothes: Elephants Can Smell You a Mile Away
text: It’s a jungle out there — and a desert, an ocean and a savanna, too. So it helps to know your enemies. While many animals can tell friend from foe, relatively few have been shown to be able to distinguish among predator species based on the type of threat they represent. A potentially even more useful ability would be to be able to tell which of several groups of a single predator species are the ones to worry about.

text: The Murphy Oil Corporation bought a stake in an offshore oil project in Australia from the closely held Finder Exploration, its first venture in the country. Murphy, based in El Dorado, Ark., said it had agreed to acquire a 40 percent stake in an exploration permit for an area northwest of Australia and operate the project. Terms were not disclosed. “This acreage acquisition is important as it not only marks our entry into Australia where we see further growth opportunities but complements our existing Southeast Asia position, which is already yielding strong results in Malaysia,” Murphy’s chief executive, Claiborne P. Deming, above, said in a statement.
