text: Henry Blodget has a thoughtful post in which he tries to imagine how a combination of Yahoo and Microsoft’s Internet operations might work. His vision is much the same as the one Microsoft and Time Warner considered a year ago for combining MSN and AOL.

headline: Sipping With a Pro
text: Man, I can’t wait to tell you about all the exciting wines I’ve had in the last week. But I will have to, because I’ve had a few other things on my mind. Like bourbon, which I’ve been obsessed with since a tasting we did several weeks ago. You can read my report on bourbon in the newspaper on Wednesday.

headline: Rewriting the History of New York Preservation
text: A new book challenges the widely held notion that the destruction of the original Pennsylvania Station in 1963-64 — a watershed event in New York’s postwar history — gave birth to the movement to preserve landmarks and save the city’s architectural heritage.

headline: Atlantic Yards Ombudsman Is Named
text: The Empire State Development Corporation named an ombudsman today to serve as a public liaison for the contentious Atlantic Yards development near Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Housing Game, California Style
text: This Blog on housing in Irvine, Calif., which I got to from the calculated risk blog, tells the story very well.

headline: Bracketed
text: On my recent Geek Cruise to the Panama Canal, I took along the Nikon D300 camera, which I’m reviewing. It’s a monster camera (at $1,900, it had better be). But a quirk of one high-end feature almost got me in a heap of trouble.

headline: Head Hunting
text: For all the good things happening with Flyers’ rebuilding this season, which I wrote about early in the season, they keep throwing cold water on their story by sprinkling the N.H.L. with some of the worst hits on opposing players’ heads.

headline: Remembering Sean Taylor
text: It is a sad day in the N.F.L. with the news that Redskins safety Sean Taylor died this morning from wounds he sustained in a shooting at his Miami home yesterday.

headline: Iowa Women Encouraged to Caucus
text: It’s fun to caucus!

headline: Historic Harlem Theater Gets a Developer, at Last
text: After years of delay and political squabbling, state officials have selected Danforth Development Partners to redevelop the long-vacant Victoria Theater on 125th Street, once Harlem’s largest and most elegant theater. Danforth plans to transform the Victoria, which sits a couple of doors east of its more well-known sister, the Apollo Theater, into a cultural center, with two live theaters and space for the Jazz Museum of Harlem, along with a hotel and 91 condominium apartments.

headline: The New York Times Close Up
text: In his weekly program on NY1, Sam Roberts, the Times's urban affairs correspondent, speaks with New York City Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein and Dan Barry of The Times.

headline: Celebrity Face-Off: Streisand vs. Oprah
text: Barbra Streisand is endorsing Hillary Clinton. It’s no great surprise, given her longstanding ties to the Clintons, but she had also given contributions to Barack Obama and John Edwards.

headline: Democrats Supply Video, You Make the Ad
text: Here’s yet another example of how the Internet is changing politics: The Democratic National Committee is putting online all the digital video that its “trackers” are recording of the major Republican candidates.

headline: Gotham Awards: You are There, Sort Of
text: We are just off stage left at the Gothams at Steiner Studios in Brooklyn, an exotic place our driver had apparently not visited. Ever. The Bagger, schnorrer that he is, slipped into the car with Mira Nair, the director of “The Namesake,” one of the nominees for best feature. Mira — the Bagger calls her by her first name because they are pals for the night — is also going to be honored with a tribute tonight for her film work, which began after she attended some seminars put on by the IFP, the sponsor of the Gothams.

headline: Gotham Awards: Running Tributaries
text: There were several tributes at the Gothams, including one to Mayor Michael Bloomberg for his renewed support for film-making in New York. He bragged about his acting career, and said he had recently played a role in “Sex and the City,” the movie. “I was the city,” he deadpanned.

headline: Varied Views on Poverty and Climate
text: The new United Nations Human Development Report is the first of these annual surveys to focus on the intersection of climate change and efforts to improve the human condition.

headline: South Korea and Its Children
text: I was 24 when I first returned to my birth country. Stepping onto the plane that would carry me back to a country I had left 21 years before, I felt dizzy at the convergence of my past and present. Once again I was the 3-year-old girl, traveling halfway around the world to an unknown future in a foreign land — now a woman returning, a foreigner again.

headline: Despite Strike, Carson Daly to Resume Show
text: The NBC talk show “Last Call With Carson Daly” will resume production Wednesday, making it the first late-night program to produce original episodes since the Writers Guild of America went on strike three weeks ago.

headline: Gotham Awards: A ‘Wild’ Ride
text: Well, it’s officially official. “Into the Wild” blew in out of nowhere and won best feature. Ellen Page, cute as bug’s ears and a lot more articulate, picked up the breakthrough actor award for her preggy teen in “Juno.” And there were some kissing cousins in the ensemble award, with “Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead” and “Talk to Me” tying.

headline: Iceland Stomps Norway
text: Using a formula that apparently doesn’t involve the number of available beach palapa bars or recent World Cup finishes, a new United Nations study deems Iceland the world’s most desirable country to live in.

headline: G.O.P. Rivals Trade Jabs in Debate
text: The Republican presidential candidates engaged in a slashing debate tonight over immigration and other issues, confronting each other in testy encounters that reflected the wide-open nature of the race in the final sprint toward the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Iran Casts Shadow on Mideast Talks
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 — The Middle East peace conference here on Tuesday was officially about ending the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. But there was an unspoken goal just below the surface: stopping the rising regional influence of Iran and Islamic radicalism.

headline: Manhattan: Parade Ban Upheld
text: A federal judge upheld a city regulation yesterday that bans new parades on Fifth Avenue, ruling against an antiwar group that had sought to challenge it as a violation of the First Amendment. The challenge to the ban came in a lawsuit filed two years ago in Federal District Court by the International Action Center, an antiwar group that was denied the right to march against the Iraq war on March 19, 2005. The city contended that the ban was a reasonable exercise of power that reduced congestion in Midtown and did not discriminate against applicants because it applied to all parades that had not been granted a permit before July 2001. Jeffrey E. Fogel, a lawyer for the demonstrators, said he would appeal.

headline: Candidates Offer Different Views on Energy Policy
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — As oil prices flirt with record highs, hovering around $95 a barrel on Tuesday, the Democratic and Republican presidential candidates are offering few quick fixes but profoundly different long-term approaches to energy policy.

headline: Dragnet That Ensnares Good Samaritans, Too
text: At first, an epidemic of absent-mindedness seemed to have broken out.

headline: Screenwriters and Producers Set 4th Day of Talks
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 — Striking screenwriters and Hollywood producers agreed to extend their renewed contract talks to a fourth day this evening, signaling at least some progress toward ending a work stoppage that began three and a half weeks ago.

headline: A Slowdown in Jobs Lost, and Created
text: For a few years starting in the late 1990s, Honeywell was one of those companies that couldn’t stop announcing job cuts. It cut jobs in 1999, even as the rest of the economy was booming. It cut more jobs in 2000, when the stock market bubble began to leak. After the 9/11 attacks, the company, which makes cockpit controls and other high-technology equipment, announced its biggest layoff of all: 15,800 jobs.

headline: Cracking the Code of the Zombie
text: THE culinary world seems to inspire a certain kind of dedicated, if slightly obsessive, connoisseurship. Think of Elizabeth Tashjian, who for 30 years ran the Nut Museum out of her house in Old Lyme, Conn., and spent her off hours painting portraits of walnuts. Or, more recently, Steven Kaplan, an American academic whose scholarly energies are principally focused on French bread.

headline: Iran Reopens Investigation Into Killing of Journalist
text: TEHRAN, Nov. 27 — The Iranian Supreme Court has ordered a new investigation into the death of an Iranian-Canadian photojournalist who was killed in Tehran in 2003 while in custody, the judiciary spokesman said Tuesday.

headline: Ex-Commander of NATO Named Mideast Liaison
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 — A day after the Israelis and Palestinians agreed to negotiate a peace treaty, the Bush administration appointed a former NATO commander to act as a liaison between the two sides, an administration official said today.

headline: State Quarters Near End of Popular Run
text: The final five designs in the popular State Quarters series were announced yesterday by the United States Mint.

headline: 35 Are Killed in Iraq, 5 by U.S. Troops
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 27 — American troops in Iraq killed at least five people, including a child, when they fired on vehicles trying to drive through roadblocks in two separate episodes over the past two days, military officials and witnesses said Tuesday.

headline: Recipe: Beachbum’s Own
text: Adapted from Jeff Berry

headline: Broadway Talks Scheduled to Resume After Break
text: Negotiations are scheduled to resume this morning between the stagehands’ union and the league representing Broadway theater owners and producers after a one-day hiatus that was described by a union spokesman as a “rain delay.”

headline: Recipe: Garbage Salad
text: Adapted from Gene & Georgetti, Chicago

headline: History and the Problem of Following the Camera’s Gaze
text: Over the past few days, I’ve looked again and again at recently published images, drawn from two enlarged photographs in the Library of Congress, that very likely show Abraham Lincoln at Gettysburg 144 years ago on the November day, the 19th, when he delivered that famous address. A bearded man in a top hat rises above the crowd (we are looking at him from behind, over his left shoulder) and there’s no real reason to doubt that it’s Lincoln. He appears in a minute portion of two stereoscopic photographs that were meant to be looked at in a special 3-D viewer.

headline: When a Poll Changes the Way People Think About the Race
text: It was inevitable. A poll comes out and it dominates the news and changes the way people are thinking about the campaign. That’s just what happened last week when ABC News and The Washington Post released a poll of Iowa caucusgoers.

headline: Suspect Spent Calm Week After Murders, Police Say
text: Two Sundays ago, the police say, Lamar J. Platt, a Bronx barber, fatally shot his mother and younger brother, cut up their bodies with a machete and a serrated knife, then packed the pieces into several plastic bags.

headline: A Hoax Turned Fatal Draws Anger but No Charges
text: DARDENNE PRAIRIE, Mo., Nov. 21 — Megan Meier died believing that somewhere in this world lived a boy named Josh Evans who hated her. He was 16, owned a pet snake, and she thought he was the cutest boyfriend she ever had.

headline: Astor’s Son Appears in Court and Denies Charges
text: Anthony D. Marshall, 83 years old, the only son of Brooke Astor, leaned forward slightly and gazed down at the table. The only sound in the courtroom yesterday afternoon was the voice of an officer reading a litany of criminal charges against him.

headline: New Method for Making Diesel Fuel Uses Vegetable Oils
text: A Portuguese oil company, Galp Energia, plans to announce today that it is building a 6,500-barrel-a-day plant to make diesel fuel from vegetable oils using a method akin to refining oil.

headline: Fugitive From U.S. Justice Leads Panama’s Assembly
text: PANAMA — The hand that Pedro Miguel González Pinzón extends in greeting — the one that wields the gavel during proceedings of the National Assembly, the one that waves to rural constituents and signs legislative documents — may have blood on it.

headline: Recipe: Spiced Nuts With Sugared Bacon
text: Time: 50 minutes

headline: Theater Awards in London
text: Shakespeare was a big winner at the annual Evening Standard Theater Awards, held at the Savoy Hotel in London, the BBC reported yesterday. The West End production of “Macbeth” won two awards: best actor for Patrick Stewart, left, and best direction for Rupert Goold. Anne-Marie Duff was named best actress for her lead role in “Saint Joan.” “A Disappearing Number” won best play, and “Hairspray” took best musical. Stephen Wight was named outstanding newcomer for his roles in “Dealer’s Choice” and “Don Juan in Soho.” Polly Stenham won for most promising playwright.

headline: Once Again, the Nets Hit the Wall at Home
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 27 — After returning from a four-game western trip, the Nets probably cannot wait to get back on the road again. The unfriendly confines of Izod Center tripped them up again Tuesday night as they lost their fifth straight game at home, falling to the Memphis Grizzlies, 110-103.

headline: Pairings
text: AT the old Trader Vic’s in the Plaza Hotel of yore, my favorite cocktail was an Eastern sour, a whiskey sour made with bourbon. The sweetness, spice and strength of bourbon, when blended with sour and bitter components, can result in a drink that offers a particularly fine balance. At Lucy of Gramercy, Gary Dusek, the beverage director, makes a bourbon manhattan, the Spanish Harlem, with sweet Pedro Ximinez sherry in place of vermouth for a nuttier flavor. He also uses maraschino cherries; bartenders’ superstition decrees you not use an even number. Michael Cecconi, the drink master at Back Forty in the East Village, makes its house cocktail with Tennessee whiskey, though he would allow bourbon in the drink.

headline: For Abu Dhabi and Citi, Credit Crisis Drove Deal
text: A falling dollar, a growing pile of oil revenue and an interest in not being overshadowed by neighboring Dubai’s increasingly high profile spurred Abu Dhabi to break with its low-key investing tradition to purchase a big $7.5 billion stake in Citigroup.

headline: A Violist and His Friends, Assertive and Collaborative
text: Top-drawer soloists are plentiful on most instruments these days. But you have to be a viola fanatic  and how many of those are there?  to be able to list more than a few violists with thriving recital careers. There are Yuri Bashmet and Kim Kashkashian, and once there was William Primrose. Orchestral violists sometimes step out on their own but retain the security of their night jobs. And violinists like Pinchas Zukerman and Janine Jansen occasionally spend quality time with this mezzo-soprano of the violin family.

headline: Fed Official’s Remarks Send Stocks Soaring
text: Stocks soared on Wall Street today after a top Federal Reserve official appeared to open the door for additional interest rate cuts, pledging to follow “flexible and pragmatic policy making” as the central bank decides how to cope with the current financial upheaval.

headline: Caution: Taliban Crossing
text: Albuquerque

headline: Police and Protesters Clash Near Paris
text: VILLIERS-LE-BEL, France, Nov. 27 — Dodging rocks and projectiles, the police lined the streets of this tense suburb Tuesday where angry youths have vowed to seek revenge for the deaths of two teenagers who died in a weekend collision with a police car.

headline: Recipe: Plantation Daze
text: Adapted from Jeff Berry The Coco Palms hotel on Kauai devised this drink with a tropical flavor.

headline: House Cleaning
text: After months of delay, a legislative task force is now expected to recommend the creation of an independent office to goad action and accountability from the House’s ethically challenged ethics committee. In a bipartisan ode to the unrocked boat, the committee sat passively through corruption scandals in the last Congress that put two lawmakers behind bars.

headline: Defense in Teenager’s Death Invokes Memories of Lynch Mobs
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Nov. 27 — The trial of a black man accused of killing a white youth who threatened his son will be as much about race and the echoes of Jim Crow lynch mobs as about the five minutes on a hot August night in 2006 when a white teenager was shot in the face, defense lawyers for the man suggested on Tuesday.

headline: As Rents Go Up, Some Offices Go South
text: When the public radio station WNYC, which was in the City Hall area, set out to find bigger and better space for new offices more than a year ago, it cast an eye to the concrete and steel skyscrapers of Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Musharraf Prepares to Drop Army Role
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 27 — The Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, conducted what the Pakistani military said was a round of farewell calls to the country’s armed forces today, a day before officials say he will relinquish his role of chief of the army.

headline: Dancing to the Top
text: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” drew its largest audience of the season on Monday as 24.7 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for the show’s final round, Nielsen estimated. This helped ABC lead the night’s ratings overall, but the network lost many of those viewers as the night wore on. While ABC’s comedy “Samantha Who?” was about average at 9 (12.6 million), the season premiere of “Notes From the Underbelly” at 9:30 earned just 8.3 million viewers. At 10, the second season of ABC’s “October Road” made its debut with 6 million viewers, good for third place behind NBC’s “Journeyman” (6.2 million). CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (15.5 million) dominated the 10 p.m. hour, helping CBS finish in a tie for first with ABC among adults 18 to 49. NBC ranked third overall as “Heroes” at 9 (11.9 million) delivered its strongest ratings in eight weeks. Fox trailed in fourth for the night.

headline: Recipe: Beachbum Berry’s Zombie
text: Adapted from Jeff Berry This recipe nearly matches the flavor of the 1934 Zombie, but it is simpler.

headline: After 10 Years and 3 Plans, U.N. Renovation Is in Sight
text: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 27 — Cruise ships, barges, islands, tent settlements, a 30-story annex, a Wal-Mart-size building, even Brooklyn.

headline: Grim View of Iraq Dangers in Survey of Journalists
text: In a newly released survey, American journalists in Iraq give harrowing accounts of their work, with the great majority saying that colleagues have been kidnapped or killed and that most parts of Baghdad are too dangerous for them to visit.

headline: Minaya’s Next Move: Finding Elite Starter for Mets
text: Like all the other teams in baseball, the Mets would love to put Johan Santana at the front of their rotation in 2008. But short of agreeing to drive the Twins’ prospective haul to Minneapolis himself  and who knows, stranger things have happened  General Manager Omar Minaya may be unable to put together a package of prospects enticing enough to beat out suitors that have richer farm systems.

headline: Miami’s Williams Back on Sideline
text: Whether it is because of suspension or injury, Dolphins running back Ricky Williams has shown quite a knack for not being on the field in recent seasons.

headline: The Gift Is in the Mail, and on the Web
text: TWENTY-FIVE years after writing my first column on sweet, savory and useful mail-order gifts for the holidays — one filled with imported goodies — I’m amazed by how butchers, bakers and candy makers around this country keep coming up with delectable surprises.

headline: The Burger and the Philosophy Behind It
text: THOUGH it is not a hamburger restaurant, Back Forty has a $10 hamburger that says a lot about the place.

headline: Foreclosure Charges by Lender Investigated
text: The federal agency monitoring the bankruptcy courts has subpoenaed Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender and loan servicer, to determine whether the company’s conduct in two foreclosures in southern Florida represented abuses of the bankruptcy system.

headline: Economic Development Corporation Is Seeking New Heliport Manager
text: After 47 years of operating the Downtown Manhattan Heliport, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is getting out of the helicopter business.

headline: Venezuela Recalls Colombia Envoy
text: Venezuela called home its ambassador to Colombia for consultations after an exchange of insults over the weekend between President Hugo Chávez and the Colombian president, Álvaro Uribe. Colombia opted not to reciprocate. The presidents’ spat erupted after Mr. Uribe withdrew his support for Mr. Chávez’s mediating role with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, Latin America’s largest rebel group. Mr. Chávez had been attempting to win the release of about 45 hostages believed held by the group, including three Americans. Concern persists for the dispute’s potential impact on trade between the countries, valued at more than $4 billion.

headline: Purification That Comes in a Bottle: Water Takes on New Responsibilities
text: AT a tiny table for two in the back of her cafe in Chappaqua, N.Y., on a recent Saturday evening, Diane Felicissimo was expounding on the virtues of a mineral water from an ancient French spring called Wattwiller. “They say it’s so old it has a soul,” she said.

headline: Congress Called Near Compromise on Fuel Economy Bill
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — Congressional negotiators are nearing agreement on a measure to set significantly higher fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks, according to aides and lobbyists following the talks.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report on Thursday in the Men’s College Basketball Preview about the outlook for Georgetown misstated the stage of last season’s N.C.A.A. tournament at which the Hoyas lost. It was the national semifinals, a Final Four matchup against Ohio State, not the title game. (Florida defeated Ohio State for the championship.) (Go to Article)

headline: Stuck on a Family Hamster Wheel, Mile After Mile, Year After Year
text: The hands that rock the cradle sometimes tip it over. Watching “The Savages,” Tamara Jenkins’s beautifully nuanced tragicomedy about two floundering souls, you have to wonder if those hands didn’t also knock that cradle clear across the nursery, sending both Savage children into perpetual free-fall.

headline: Bidding Adieu to a Treasured American Heirloom
text: He is a French aristocrat who created a stir in America as a precocious teenager, and then returned decades later to the United States to be celebrated in New York, Philadelphia, Washington and Boston.

headline: Back to ‘Don’t Look Back,’ This Time With Dylan’s Songs in the Spotlight
text: The great relief of D. A. Pennebaker’s “65 Revisited” — which pulls together never-released footage shot for his documentary “Don’t Look Back” — is that this time you can hear the songs in their entirety. Because Mr. Pennebaker wanted “Don’t Look Back” to be about Bob Dylan, not his 1965 British concert tour, he made the somewhat maddening decision to cut down the songs in that first film to tantalizing bits and pieces. The problem of course being that the songs were as much a part of this youthquaking sensation as his pipe-cleaner-skinny legs, his fuzzy ’fro, bobbing head, sly smile, riffs, rants, puns and playful, otherworldly genius.

headline: Making Old Hardware Play New Tunes
text: Jeremiah Johnson, 27, is a chiptune composer: His instrument is not the guitar or the piano or even the latest music software, but old-school video hardware like the Nintendo GameBoy. Working with screwdrivers and soldering irons, he painstakingly reprograms the rudimentary sound chips in the game machines to create songs that play right from the console. The sound is less Super Mario Brothers and more post-punk, New Wave electronica (albeit with that familiar, bleepy timbre).

headline: Verizon Plans Wider Options for Cellphone Users
text: In a major shift for the mobile phone industry, Verizon Wireless said yesterday that it planned to give customers far more choice in what phones they could use on its network and how they use them.

headline: J. Robert Cade, the Inventor of Gatorade, Dies at 80
text: J. Robert Cade, a nephrologist who mixed water, sugar, salt and cunning dashes of whatever to invent Gatorade, of which 12 million bottles are guzzled daily by electrolyte-depleted athletes, post-operative patients and the simply thirsty, died yesterday in Gainesville, Fla. He was 80.

headline: Recipe: Back Forty
text: Adapted from Back Forty

headline: Longtime Mentor Thrives With a Sense of Wonder
text: When I was 14, I was caught fishing illegally in a drinking-water reservoir by a game warden named Joe Haines. Instead of giving me a ticket, he took me under his wing.

headline: Mbeki’s Support Erodes in Party Vote in South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 27  With a national conference looming in mid-December to choose the next leader of South Africa’s ruling party  and by extension, the nation’s probable next president  President Thabo Mbeki’s control of the party has shifted to his former vice president and bitter rival, the populist politician Jacob Zuma.

headline: Recipe: Hot Pot
text: Time: 30 minutes

headline: Group Urges Immediate Action to Reduce Size of Classes
text: City school officials could begin reducing class sizes immediately in more than 150 of New York’s lowest performing schools, according to a report released yesterday by the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the advocacy group that successfully sued the state for more money for the public school system.

headline: Manhattan: Movement in Theater Redevelopment
text: After years of delay and political squabbling, state officials have selected Danforth Development Partners to redevelop the long-vacant Victoria Theater on 125th Street, once Harlem’s largest and most elegant theater. Danforth plans to transform the Victoria into a cultural center, with two live theaters, space for the Jazz Museum of Harlem, a 200-room hotel and 91 condominiums. The theaters would be used primarily by the Classical Theater of Harlem and the Harlem Arts Alliance. Danforth, a Harlem-based developer, said it would restore the Victoria’s Ionic columns, terra cotta rosettes and other historic elements.

headline: In French Suburbs, Same Rage, but New Tactics
text: PARIS, Nov. 27 — Two years after France’s immigrant suburbs exploded in rage, the rituals and acts of resentment have reappeared with an eerie sameness: roving gangs clashing with riot police forces, the government appealing for calm, residents complaining that they are ignored.

headline: Footnotes
text: “In Bruges,” a first-time feature written and directed by the playwright Martin McDonagh, below, will open next year’s Sundance Film Festival. The film stars Ralph Fiennes, Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, and is about of two London hit men ordered to take a forced vacation in Bruges, Belgium. The festival runs from Jan. 17 to 27 in Park City, Salt Lake City, Ogden and Sundance, all in Utah. ... Constantin Costa-Gavras, the Greek-born director of “Z” and “Missing,” will head the jury at the annual Berlin Film Festival in February, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The Italian director Francesco Rosi will receive the festival’s Golden Bear award for lifetime achievement. ... The Manhattan Theater Club has announced that Mary Catherine Garrison, Elizabeth Marvel, Martha Plimpton and Marisa Tomei will star in the Broadway premiere of Caryl Churchill’s “Top Girls” at the Biltmore Theatre. Previews begin on April 15; the official opening is May 7. ... The Public Theater has announced the lineup for its annual Under the Radar Festival for new theater, running Jan. 9 to 20; for schedule and ticketing information: publictheater.org. ... “Good Boys and True,” by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa, which forces a mother to confront the truth about her son, will be the third production of the season at Second Stage Theater. The play, about a scandal at a boys’ prep school, will begin previews in late April and open in mid-May.

headline: Oil Producers See the World and Buy It Up
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — Flush with petrodollars, oil-producing countries have embarked on a global shopping spree.

headline: In New Hampshire, Some Fret About Too Little, Too Early
text: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 27 — At the Merrimack Restaurant on Elm Street, where a mural of past presidential candidates adorns the red brick facade, Maria Saitas is worried. Not only will New Hampshire’s primary be over earlier than ever next year, but the window between the Iowa and New Hampshire contests — a mere five days in early January — will be wincingly brief.

headline: Top Prospects Merely a Down Payment on Santana
text: When Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins thinks about the seven-year, $126 million contract that Barry Zito signed with the San Francisco Giants 11 months ago, it would be natural for him to smile. And when general managers ponder that bloated contract, it would be just as natural for them to cringe.

headline: Blurring the Line Between a College Application and a Slick Sales Pitch
text: The language is pure Madison Avenue, but it is richly in vogue among paid counselors who advise students on how to make strong impressions with top-flight colleges. Package yourself, they say. Brand yourself.

headline: A Star Is Bailed
text: The Bollywood star Sanjay Dutt, above,  was granted bail yesterday and is expected to be released by today, after serving 19 months of a six-year sentence for illegal weapons possession, The Associated Press reported. The Supreme Court in New Delhi agreed to free Mr. Dutt pending its decision on an appeal of his sentence, his attorney said. The actor was sentenced in July for possessing three automatic rifles and a pistol that had been supplied to him by men subsequently convicted in the 1993 Mumbai bombings, which killed 257 people. He was originally arrested on suspicion of involvement in the bombings, but was acquitted of terrorism and conspiracy charges.

headline: Bourbon’s Shot at the Big Time
text: IN the recent history of whiskey, bourbon would seem to have had a lot going for it. It’s homegrown, for one thing. Grass-roots acceptance counts for a lot when you are battling for shelf space. Bourbon has always been right up there with college football, Nascar and canned beer — the sort of whiskey that anyone can order without fear of being labeled effete or snobbish.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Nov. 20 about the role of denial in nourishing close relationships misstated the title of a book. It is “Predictably Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions,” not “Hidden Forced.”

headline: Supreme Court Is Referee in Delaware River Fight
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — If litigation is war by other means, then the Supreme Court case of New Jersey v. Delaware is nothing less than civil war — the latest battle in a dispute over the two states’ Delaware River boundary, which has flared up periodically for well over a century.

headline: Recipe: Spanish Harlem
text: Adapted from Lucy of Gramercy

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report on Thursday in the Men’s College Basketball Preview about the outlook for Georgetown misstated the stage of last season’s N.C.A.A. tournament at which the Hoyas lost. It was the national semifinals, a Final Four matchup against Ohio State, not the title game. (Florida defeated Ohio State for the championship.)

headline: Israel and Palestinians Set Goal of a Treaty in 2008
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 — The Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves on Tuesday to negotiate a peace treaty by the end of 2008, setting a deadline for ending a conflict that has endured for six decades.

headline: In an Ever-Changing Galaxy, the Action’s Starting to Get Intriguing
text: One of the strengths of an online computer game is that what you see when it first appears is not necessarily what you get if you pick it up years later.

headline: Bill Hartack, 74, Champion Jockey, Dies
text: Bill Hartack, a Hall of Fame jockey who was a five-time winner of the Kentucky Derby, died Monday night in Texas while on a hunting vacation. He was 74.

headline: A Switch for Exhibition on Black Migration
text: A traveling exhibition of panels from Jacob Lawrence’s seminal “Migration” series — scheduled to appear at the Studio Museum in Harlem — has opened instead at the Whitney Museum of American Art because of last-minute problems with the Studio Museum’s space, officials from both museums said. The 30 paintings, 17 of which are owned by the Phillips Collection in Washington, depict the flight of African-Americans from the rural South to the industrial cities of the North. Thelma Golden, the Studio Museum’s director and chief curator, said that as she was preparing to install the works, instruments showed that one wall in the exhibition space was undergoing temperature fluctuations that could have threatened the paintings. “For me it was very important that the show be in New York,” she said, “and with the help of the Whitney it is.” The show will remain at the Whitney through Jan. 6, then travel to the Mississippi Museum of Art in Jackson before returning to the Phillips.

headline: Oasis or Mirage?
text: Annapolis, Md.

headline: A Shift in Applications as Early Admission Is Cut
text: When Harvard, Princeton and the University of Virginia announced that they would eliminate early admission starting this fall, many educators wondered whether the decision would alter the strategies of thousands of students seeking a spot at the nation’s most selective colleges and universities.

headline: Red Cross Fires Its President, Citing Relationship
text: The American Red Cross dismissed its president and chief executive, Mark W. Everson, yesterday, citing his “personal relationship with a subordinate employee.” He had been in office for only six months.

headline: With an Eye on Olympics, Lochte Is a Fish, in and Out of Water
text: Does Ryan Lochte’s sketch pad contain the blueprint for beating Michael Phelps? Lochte’s drawings are as vivid as hallucinations, full of raindrops falling up and fish swimming in the sky.

headline: Spitzer, Hat in Hand, Asks Fellow Democrats in the Assembly for a Second Chance
text: At first, Gov. Eliot Spitzer told a packed room of Assembly Democrats yesterday, his wife didn’t like him much either.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $2,404,555.37

headline: Elaine Lorillard, 93, a Founder of the Newport Jazz Festival, Is Dead
text: Elaine Lorillard, a socialite who with her husband, Louis, lured jazz greats to their hometown in Rhode Island for a two-day concert series in the summer of 1954, starting the Newport Jazz Festival and creating the model for what became a worldwide circuit of outdoor jazz festivals, died on Monday near her home in Newport. She was 93.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening this Week

headline: Health Care: A National Conversation
text: To the Editor:

headline: China’s Denial of Port Calls by U.S. Ships Worries Navy
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  Two senior American admirals expressed concern on Tuesday over decisions this month by China to refuse access to the port of Hong Kong for three American warships, including two seeking fuel and sheltered waters ahead of a major storm.

headline: Broadway Stagehands in Tentative Agreement
text: The 19-day strike by stagehands that had closed most Broadway theaters ended late tonight as a tentative agreement was struck.

headline: West Orange: Two Shot Behind Apartments
text: Two men were shot, one fatally, early yesterday behind an apartment complex, the police said. Each man had been shot in the head at point-blank range, the police said. The dead man was identified as Devon Rodriguez, 20. The other man, a 19-year-old, was not identified; he was in critical condition yesterday at University Hospital in Newark. Witnesses reported hearing four shots from behind the complex, the Hutton Arms, before hearing a car speeding away. The shooting took place about four blocks from the home of the State Senate president, Richard J. Codey.

headline: Black and Hispanic Firefighter Applicants Have Doubled
text: The Fire Department’s pool of black and Hispanic job candidates has more than doubled since 2002, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday, raising hopes that efforts to hire more minority firefighters might be yielding results.

headline: Brooklyn: Apartment Building Stairway Collapses
text: Up to 50 residents of an apartment building were displaced from their homes after stairs in an apartment building collapsed last night, officials with the police and the Fire Department said. No one was hurt in the collapse, which occurred about 8 p.m. at 1568 Sterling Place, in the Weeksville neighborhood, the authorities said. The cause of the collapse was under investigation. City agencies helped find temporary housing for the tenants.

headline: Greek Court Dismisses Case Against Ex-Curator
text: ATHENS, Nov. 27 — An appeals court here dismissed a criminal case on Tuesday against Marion True, a former curator for the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles who had been accused of conspiring to acquire an ancient gold wreath that Greece says was looted from its soil.

headline: Bracing for Home Loan Losses, Wells Fargo to Take Big Charge
text: Wells Fargo & Company, the nation’s second-largest mortgage lender, after Countrywide Financial, said yesterday that it would take a $1.4 billion fourth-quarter charge for losses it anticipated in connection with home loans.

headline: Challenging Tradition, Young Jews Worship on Their Terms
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  There are no pews at Tikkun Leil Shabbat, no rabbis, no one with children or gray hair.

headline: Herb McKenley, 85, Top Jamaican Runner, Is Dead
text: Herb McKenley, the world’s fastest 400-meter runner more than half a century ago and later the driving force in Jamaica’s climb to track and field glory, died Monday in Kingston, Jamaica, where he lived. He was 85.

headline: To the Things That Remain
text: YOU always remember your first time, but what about your last?

headline: Survivor of Connecticut Home Invasion Urges Stricter Laws
text: HARTFORD, Nov. 27  The man whose wife and two daughters were killed during a night of terror in their Cheshire home appealed to Connecticut legislators on Tuesday to address “glaring defects” in the criminal justice system that may have opened the door to the accused men last summer.

headline: Recipe: Hot Coffee Grog
text: Adapted from Jeff Berry This warm, spicy after-dinner drink is suitable for parties or quiet winter nights.

headline: Manhattan: Environmental Tests Downtown
text: Initial tests at 53 apartments and in the common areas of nine buildings within 1,500 feet of ground zero found three dust samples that were contaminated with asbestos above safe levels and 71 samples that were laced with lead that exceeded federal standards, environmental officials said yesterday. The spaces were tested under a controversial program of the Environmental Protection Agency. Since the testing began this year, most of the 5,600 samples the agency has analyzed have fallen below federal benchmarks for exposure. Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the agency, said that 272 apartments and 25 buildings below Canal Street will be tested within the next year, and any contamination will be cleaned. Complete test results can be seen at www.epa.gov /wtc/testandclean.

headline: Nose on the Prize, but Which Oscar to Sniff?
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 — Eddie Valiant, the hard-nosed private eye played by Bob Hoskins in “Who Framed Roger Rabbit,” wasn’t about to fiddle with animation. “Forget it,” he said. “I don’t work Toontown.”

headline: How the Job Churn Numbers Are Counted
text: The numbers on job churning compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics are based on a quarterly canvass of work sites across the country. The survey includes all of the roughly seven million private-sector work sites that are part of the unemployment-insurance system. These work sites account for 112 million workers.

headline: South Korean Leader Allows Inquiry Into Samsung Bribes
text: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 27 — President Roh Moo-hyun of South Korea agreed on Tuesday to an independent investigation into a slush fund and bribery scandal at the Samsung Group, including accusations that he and his aides may have accepted bribes from the conglomerate.

headline: Pro Bono Efforts Follow Targets to the Web
text: A NONPROFIT organization founded when “The Pride of the Yankees” meant a movie about Lou Gehrig, rather than the feelings of a departing manager, is taking a more contemporary tack in selecting the media in which its campaigns appear.

headline: Home Prices Post Big Drop in Survey
text: Housing prices fell the most in almost 20 years this summer, and consumers remain deeply skeptical about the economy, according to reports released yesterday.

headline: Despite Strike, Carson Daly to Resume Show
text: The NBC talk show “Last Call With Carson Daly” will resume production today, making it the first late-night program to produce original episodes since the Writers Guild of America went on strike three weeks ago.

headline: China Says Three Gorges Dam Is Not Responsible for Landslides
text: BEIJING, Nov. 27 — Chinese officials overseeing the Three Gorges Dam defended the project’s environmental record on Tuesday and asserted that pressure from rising waters in the dam’s reservoir was not to blame for any major geological problems or disasters in the region.

headline: Defending Rights, He Said He Was Marked to Die
text: The assassin’s name was Panther. He had a stocky 5-foot 8-inch frame. Though he was only 26, a look of hatred was encrusted on his face.

headline: A Battle-Scarred Edwards, Emerging a Fighter
text: MILFORD, N.H. — He has beat his Diet Coke addiction — “too much caffeine.” He no longer shrinks from foreign policy talk and salts his speeches with lines like, “I saw a piece recently in the Guardian newspaper, a British newspaper.” And where he once meandered from topic to topic, the John Edwards of today tries to keep it concise.

headline: Palestinian Is Killed in Hebron as Police Disperse Protest Over Mideast Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 27  A Palestinian man was killed Tuesday in Hebron on the West Bank as Palestinian Authority police officers loyal to President Mahmoud Abbas fired weapons to disperse protests against the Middle East peace conference taking place in Annapolis, Md.

headline: For a Communal Meal, One Pot, Many Cultures
text: THERE is no more communal dish than hot pot, which goes by various names, like horhog (Mongolia), huoguo (China) and shabu shabu (Japan). You cut up some meat and vegetables, set a heated pot in the center of the table, fill it with seasoned water or stock and let your guests take over.

headline: One-Year Term for Oilman Convicted in Iraq Kickbacks
text: Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., the self-made Texas oilman who pleaded guilty in October to violating the rules of the United Nations oil-for-food program, was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison, half the maximum penalty he faced under federal sentencing guidelines.

headline: Jump on the Peace Train
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Best of Bad Sex
text: Norman Mailer won The Literary Review’s Bad Sex in Fiction Award, becoming the first posthumously honored author, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. The judges paid tribute to a notable coupling in “The Castle in the Forest,” Mailer’s novel about Hitler. “We are sure that he would have taken the prize in good humor,” the judges said of Mailer, who died this month at age 84. Among this year’s eight finalists were a lusty automaton in Jeanette Winterson’s “Stone Gods,” a Russian oligarch in Gary Shteyngart’s “Absurdistan” and a breathless Shakespeare in Christopher Rush’s “Will.” Other finalists included Clare Clark, for “The Nature of Monsters,” Richard Milward for “Apples” and David Thewlis’s “Late Hector Kipling,” about an artist who dabbles in S & M.

headline: Recipe: Zombie Punch
text: Adapted from Jeff Berry Mr. Berry believes that this recipe, found in a waiter’s notebook, is the original Zombie introduced at Don the Beachcomber’s in 1934.

headline: Rewritten, in a Language of Its Own
text: MORE than a few chefs have spent more than a little time trying to turn carpaccio into an intricate production that reflects and trumpets their ingenuity.

headline: Some Big Bets That the Funky Bowery Can Be Luxe
text: The Bowery might sound like the last place in Manhattan where you would go to pick out a new designer suit, dine at a chic restaurant or stay in a $1,200 hotel suite. But much of the old Bowery is being swept away faster than you can say “skid row,” and new high-end offerings are on the horizon.

headline: Wedding a Blur? Here’s the Recipe
text: AT my wedding I had weightier matters to focus on than sampling every hors d’oeuvre. But then I heard that the sugared bacon my friend Shawn Kelley had brought was devoured before the ceremony. After listening to wistful descriptions of the caramelized porky strips that stood tall in a glass until they crunched in the mouth, I felt deprived — until I asked Shawn for the recipe.

headline: Antarctic Voyage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Google’s Next Frontier: Renewable Energy
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 — Google, the Internet company with a seemingly limitless source of revenue, plans to get into the business of finding limitless sources of energy.

headline: Car Bomb Attack Kills 2 in Afghan Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 27 — A huge car bomb exploded in a residential district of Kabul that is used by foreign diplomats and international organizations, killing two civilians and wounding four others, the police said. Two vehicles in a United States military convoy were damaged, but no servicemen were killed or wounded, said a military spokesman, Col. David Johnson.

headline: Nixon Papers Recall Concerns on Israel’s Weapons
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 — In July 1969, while the world was spellbound by the Apollo 11 mission to the moon, President Richard M. Nixon and his close advisers were quietly fretting about a possible nuclear arms race in the Middle East. Their main worry was not a potential enemy of the United States, but one of America’s closest friends.

headline: Patriots Lose Colvin to Foot Injury for Rest of Season
text: The New England Patriots, whose undefeated start has been largely free of serious injuries, absorbed their first big jolt yesterday, when the starting outside linebacker Rosevelt Colvin was placed on injured reserve with a foot injury.

headline: Recipe: Hong Kong Spare Ribs
text: Adapted from “Bruce Aidells’s Complete Book of Pork,” by Bruce Aidells with Lisa Weiss (HarperCollins, 2004)

headline: Indexes Up Sharply on Some Good News
text: Stock markets snapped back yesterday as promising news on credit and oil emerged from the Middle East, offering investors some reassurance about two recent trouble spots.

headline: To Muslim Girls, Scouts Offer a Chance to Fit In
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Sometimes when Asma Haidara, a 12-year-old Somali immigrant, wants to shop at Target or ride the Minneapolis light-rail system, she puts her Girl Scout sash over her everyday clothes, which usually include a long skirt worn over pants as well as a swirling head scarf.

headline: O.J. Simpson Pleads Not Guilty
text: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 28 — O.J. Simpson pleaded not guilty today to a dozen charges, including kidnapping and armed robbery, stemming from a confrontation in a hotel room here on Sept. 13.

headline: A Cultural Critic’s Restless Last Night
text: “If one views the growing work as a blazing pyre, its commentator can be likened to the chemist, its critic to an alchemist,” Walter Benjamin once wrote. “While the former is left with wood and ashes as the sole objects of his analysis, the latter is concerned only with the enigma of the flame itself.”

headline: Stocks Rebound on Citigroup Deal and Oil News
text: Stock markets snapped back today after promising news emerged from the Middle East.

headline: U.N. Official Criticizes Sudan for Resisting Peace Force in Darfur
text: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 27 — The United Nations’ top peacekeeping official said Tuesday that obstacles created by the Sudanese government were jeopardizing the deployment of the joint African Union-United Nations force in Darfur.

headline: Cable Industry Wins Compromise on F.C.C. Plans
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — In the face of a lobbying blitzkrieg by the cable television industry, the Federal Communications Commission drastically scaled back Tuesday evening a proposal by the agency’s chairman to more tightly regulate the industry.

headline: China Rejects Europe’s Call for Currency to Rise Faster
text: BEIJING, Nov. 27  China signaled Tuesday that it would resist European demands for rapid appreciation of the yuan and would instead continue gradual progress toward a more flexible exchange rate.

headline: Authorities Search for Killer of Redskins’ Taylor
text: MIAMI, Nov. 27 — The authorities searched Tuesday for the killer of Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor, who died early in the morning after he was shot by an intruder at his home south of the city.

headline: Mugabe Says He Will Attend Meeting With Europeans
text: BRUSSELS, Nov. 27  President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe said Tuesday that he would attend a summit meeting of European and African leaders next week, a move guaranteed to provoke divisions over human rights and a boycott by Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain.

headline: Data Seen as Favorable for Abbott’s Proposed Heart Stent
text: The data continues to be favorable for Abbott Laboratories’ new drug-coated heart stent, Xience V, which the company is hoping will win federal approval.

headline: Iran: New Long-Range Missile
text: The defense minister, Mostafa Mohammad Najjar, said Iran had built a new long-range missile. In comments reported by the Fars news agency, he said the missile had range of 1,200 miles. He did not say how the missile, called Ashoura, differed from the Shahab-3, also with a range of 1,200 miles, or if it had been test fired.

headline: Starting From Annapolis
text: The American-led Annapolis peace conference achieved the minimum — a pledge by Israel and the Palestinians to begin immediate negotiations with a goal of reaching a peace treaty by the end of 2008.

headline: Details of Shifting Story Emerge in 5th Ave. Death
text: At first, according to court documents released yesterday, Natavia S. Lowery told investigators that her last day with her boss, Linda Stein, had been a normal one. She did Ms. Stein’s makeup and hair, laid out her clothes and helped with her work, she told detectives on Nov. 8, nine days after Ms. Stein, a prominent real estate broker, was found bludgeoned to death in the living room of her Fifth Avenue apartment.

headline: Nascar Driver Taking Antidrug Message on the Road
text: CINCINNATI, Nov. 27 (AP)  The Nascar driver Aaron Fike understands where he was headed when he was arrested while shooting heroin in an amusement park parking lot this summer.

headline: A Loss for Privacy Rights
text: The Constitution protects individuals against unreasonable searches, but for this protection to have practical meaning, the courts must enforce it. This week, the Supreme Court let stand a disturbing ruling out of California that allows law enforcement to barge into people’s homes without a warrant. The case has not prompted much outrage, perhaps because the people whose privacy is being invaded are welfare recipients, but it is a serious setback for the privacy rights of all Americans.

headline: Marbury Hasn’t Won Since His Breakup With Garnett
text: Stephon Marbury was all smiles as he left the Knicks’ locker room, shuffled down a dim hallway and ducked through double doors to meet a crowd of friends and family late Monday night. There was no wrecking Marbury’s mood at this moment.

headline: Mitchell’s Report Due Before End of Year
text: George J. Mitchell’s report on the use of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball will be issued before the end of the year, a spokesman for Mitchell said yesterday, confirming speculation about the timing of the report.

headline: On the Way to the Common Good, Delegates Found Words That Still Apply
text: For those of us interested in the promise of the American Constitution and also in its imperfections, it is a happy coincidence that these two volumes have appeared at the same time, for they nicely complement each other.

headline: Elevating Show Tunes Into American Art Songs
text: You can take the girl out of Texas, but you can’t take Texas out of the girl. For the singer and actress Victoria Clark, that is a good thing. Although fortified by a fancy music-theater education that carried her to Austria to study opera, fundamental true grit that smacks of her hometown, Dallas, seeps through her impeccable musical training.

headline: U.N. Warns of Climate-Related Setbacks
text: A new United Nations report warns that progress toward prosperity in the world’s poorest regions will be reversed unless rich countries promptly begin curbing emissions linked to global warming while also helping poorer ones leapfrog to energy sources that pollute less than coal and oil.

headline: Brooklyn: Ex-Prosecutor Charged With Leaks
text: A former assistant district attorney in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with providing information about prosecution witnesses to a defense lawyer who is now her husband, prosecutors said. The former prosecutor, Sandra Fernandez, 35, of Queens, was charged with official misconduct and with offering a false instrument for filing, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, who acted as a special prosecutor in the matter. Mr. Brown said in a statement that Ms. Fernandez, who worked in the office for more than five years until she was fired in February, obtained confidential criminal histories on two prosecution witnesses in cases in which the defense lawyer was her then-fiancé.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Film Garlands From the Gothams

headline: Oral Roberts U. and President Part Ways
text: DALLAS, Nov. 27 — Oral Roberts University’s regents announced Tuesday that they would legally and financially separate the university from the ministry headed by Richard Roberts, the television evangelist accused last month in a lawsuit of tapping university and ministry money to finance a lavish lifestyle .

headline: Musharraf Quits Pakistani Army Post
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 28 — President Pervez Musharraf resigned his military post as chief of army staff today, handing over the baton of command to his successor in a ceremony at Pakistan’s army headquarters and ending his eight years of military rule. He remains president and will be sworn in to a new five-year term in the capital on Thursday, but as a civilian president his grip on power is expected to loosen in coming months.

headline: Calendar
text: The Dogs of Winter

headline: Panel Rebukes Judge, Citing ‘Lunacy’ in Court
text: The next time you pass through the city court system in Niagara Falls, N.Y., remember to turn your cellphone off.

headline: Porsche to Wait Until Holidays End to Take Over Volkswagen
text: STUTTGART, Germany, Nov. 27 — Porsche is bestowing an early Christmas present on the workers at Volkswagen: a pledge not to take over their company, at least before the holidays.

headline: In Iowa, Mormon Issue Is Benefiting Huckabee
text: The religious divide over Mitt Romney’s Mormon faith that his supporters had long feared would occur is emerging in Iowa as he is being challenged in state polls by Mike Huckabee, a former Baptist pastor who has played up his faith in his bid for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Senate Race That Fizzled Honed Skills for ’08
text: By the time Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York stepped before a wall of television crews in the Public Hearing Room at City Hall on May 19, 2000, there were no surprises left.

headline: Cycling’s Drug Problem Leads T-Mobile to End Sponsorship
text: T-Mobile, the professional cycling team that began this year with the sport’s largest budget and an ambitious plan to reform the sport’s drug problem, lost its sponsor yesterday because of continuing doping controversies.

headline: Bill Clinton Flatly Asserts He Opposed War at Start
text: During a campaign swing for his wife, former President Bill Clinton said flatly yesterday that he opposed the war in Iraq “from the beginning” — a statement that is more absolute than his comments before the invasion in March 2003.

headline: The Solar Wawas: Not a Happy Family
text: Our judges need your help in the Solar-Twin Naming Contest. They’ve been sorting the many nominations for the name and accompanying myth for the Sun-like star in the constellation Draco. Now Jorge Melendez, one of the two Peruvian astronomers who discovered this twin, has submitted a myth to go with the Quechua name, Intipa Awachan, suggested by his collaborator, Ivan Ramirez.

headline: ‘The Genius of America’
text: THE MORE FATAL PROBLEM LIES AMONG THE PEOPLE THEMSELVES

headline: Dow Jones Considers Selling 23 Papers
text: Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said Tuesday that it was considering the sale of the rest of the Ottaway community newspaper group.

headline: Porsche to Wait Until Holidays End to Take Over Volkswagen
text: Porsche is bestowing an early Christmas present on the workers at Volkswagen: a pledge not to take over their company, at least before the holidays.

headline: Japan’s Astellas to Buy Agensys
text: In what might be the hottest sector of the drug industry, another biotech firm is now off the table. Japan’s second-largest drugmaker, Astellas Pharma, said Tuesday that it would buy Agensys of Santa Monica, Calif., to add biologic drugs to its pipeline.

headline: Qwaq Suits Up With $7 Million Round
text: Much like Second Life, Qwaq Forums uses animated avatars representing users to populate 3-D office spaces, complete with rotating fans and potted plants. Only instead of being a time killer, Qwaq Forums aims to actually increase productivity by allowing clients to skip those long flights and stuffy conference rooms and let their avatars take the meeting for them.

headline: Private Equity Firm Cressy Nabs Frist as Partner
text: Cressey & Company, a recently formed private equity firm focused on the health care industry, said the former Senate Majority Leader, Bill Frist, a doctor by training, has agreed to join the Chicago-based firm as a partner.

headline: Wheeling-Pitt Investors Approve Esmark Deal
text: Steelmaker Wheeling-Pittsburgh and steel distributor Esmark said their shareholders approved the merger of the two companies.

headline: Xiotech Adds $40 Million to Its Coffers
text: Xiotech, a data-storage provider, announced Tuesday that it had secured $40 million in mostly equity financing from a group led by Steve Luczo, the chairman of Seagate Technology, who is joining the board of Eden Prairie, Minn.-based Xiotech.

headline: More Headaches for Zell as Tribune Reports Drop in Revenue
text: Tribune, which is in the process of going private through a deal with the real-estate magnate Samuel Zell, reported a 9.3 percent decline in revenue during October on Tuesday as advertising continued to slump at its broadcast and publishing segments.

headline: Google’s Next Frontier: Renewable Energy
text: Google, the Internet company with a seemingly limitless source of revenue, plans to get into the business of finding limitless sources of energy.

headline: France’s Thales Puts Merger Plans on Hold
text: Proposals for a merger between Thales, the French defense electronics group, and security and aerospace equipment conglomerate Safran have been shelved, according to the chairman of Thales.

headline: PPR Mulls Swap for Clarins Stake, Report Says
text: Shareholders in Clarins might need to reach for the company’s famous creams to smooth out some recently acquired worry lines.

headline: With Merger Talk in Vogue, UAL’s Tilton Feels Vindication
text: The head of United Airlines’ parent company said Tuesday he no longer feels like a voice in the wilderness in arguing that airlines must consider consolidation to withstand competitive challenges, including rising fuel costs.

headline: The Naked and the Awful
text: Norman Mailer won The Literary Review’s Bad Sex in Fiction Award, becoming the first posthumously honored author. The judges paid tribute to a notable coupling (discretion advised) in “The Castle in the Forest,” Mailer’s novel about Hitler. “We are sure that he would have taken the prize in good humor,” the judges said of Mailer, who died this month at 84. Read more on the awards (fifth item).

headline: UBS Shares Rise on Speculation of Stake Sale
text: Shares in UBS powered higher on Wednesday on speculation that Asian or Gulf-based investors might target European banks whose stock has weakened in the wake of the subprime crisis. The speculation was prompted by Citigroup‘s $7.5 billion stake sale to Abu Dhabi’s sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Absolute Capital Hires Outsider for Review
text: Absolute Capital, an Australian hedge fund that suspended withdrawals because of the turmoil in credit markets, has appointed an outside administrator to review the business, the company said Tuesday.

headline: British Hedge Fund Hires Lawyer for Litigation Investments
text: A British hedge fund has hired a former litigator to invest $100 million in European legal disputes, in what The Times of London says is believed to be the first formal arrangement of its kind.

headline: Gotham Awards: Indier Than Thou
text: The Gothams last night had significant virtues. “Into the Wild,” and “Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead,” two of the evening’s big winners, represent both the cantankerousness of the indie genre and its enduring value. And there was something sort of remarkable about holding the whole shindig at Steiner Studios. Yeah, it was a schlep and the Bagger commuted home in a car full of Manhattanites who all had strong opinions about how to get out of Brooklyn even though none of them any idea of what they were talking about.

headline: 2 Small Hedge Funds Merge
text: Two small hedge funds have merged in a rare deal as tiny investment pools, watching giants such as the Citadel Investment Group prepare  to post returns of up to 27 percent for the year, huddle together looking for better returns.

headline: Wells Fargo to Take Big Charge on Loan Losses
text: Wells Fargo & Company, the nation’s second-largest mortgage lender, said Tuesday that it would take a $1.4 billion fourth-quarter charge for losses it anticipated in connection with home loans.

headline: Mideast Funds Go on Global Shopping Spree
text: Flush with petrodollars, oil-producing countries are buying up assets all over the world. The Abu Dhabi Investment Authority‘s $7.5 billion investment in Citigroup is just the latest example, and it’s not likely to be the last.

headline: Citi Said to Reject Proposal for BofA Merger
text: Was Bank of America, known for its acquisitive streak, considering swallowing rival behemoth Citigroup?

headline: While We’re Talking About Branding
text: A savvy reader pointed out that on the same day that I linked to a smart post by Pamela Slim, an entrepreneur/blogger/consultant, she blogged about how successful branding needs to have a clear and focused message. What does that mean for all those “slashes” (the consultant/cartoonist, the lawyer/filmmakers) I write about, asked the savvy reader?

headline: Carlyle Raises First Infrastructure Fund
text: The Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, has raised its first infrastructure fund, which is focused on North America, where the company believes public-private partnerships will increase. Common in Europe, these arrangements involve private companies that deliver and run public assets such as roads, schools and hospitals.

headline: NYSE Euronext Expects More Secondary Listings
text: The transatlantic exchange NYSE Euronext expects United States companies with New York Stock Exchange listings to seek secondary listings in Amsterdam, a Dutch newspaper quoted a NYSE Euronext board member as saying on Wednesday.

headline: The Early Word: G.O.P.’s Turn for CNN/YouTube Forum
text: “Sanctuary cities” – referring to towns that harbor illegal aliens – likely will be a hot topic tonight at the CNN/YouTube debate between G.O.P. candidates, who are looking to paint their opponents as soft conservatives, writes Brian C. Mooney of the Boston Globe.

headline: Gotham Awards: Getting Dude-ed at the Gothams
text: As Juno, Canadian actress Ellen Page described her character’s ill-timed pregnancy as an affliction, a kind of slow-moving body snatch. The awards season, too, will make the business of daily living seem a bit like a kidnapping. Ms. Page, who will be spending the next several months on carpets hither and yon answering the same inane questions about inhabiting a pregnant teen character, is more skate punk than Valley Girl, and is always cracking wise.

headline: A ‘Helluva Lot’ for a LinkedIn Sale?
text: Tongues were wagging earlier this week on speculation that the News Corporation would buy LinkedIn, the professionals-oriented social network, early next year. (Never mind that the rumors were thinly sourced.)

headline: Mr. Picasso Head
text: An interactive cubist time-waster diversion.

headline: Only at "T": The New Museum
text: Exclusive tour of New York's New Museum of Contemporary Art.

headline: It's All About...Hiroshi Sugimoto
text: The acclaimed photographer discusses his work, including his first-ever fashion commission for T.

headline: All the 'T' in China
text: Fendi and Karl Lagerfeld turn the Great Wall of China into the world's largest catwalk.

headline: S.E.C. Expected to Limit Proxy Access
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to adopt a proposal Wednesday that allows companies to bar shareholders from access to ballots for board elections. Some major pension funds and governance advocates said the move could make corporations less responsive to investors.

headline: The Republican Debate
text: Following is a transcript of the Republican Presidential debate in St. Petersburg, Fla., as provided by the Federal News Service.

headline: In Court, Astor’s Son Denies Charges
text: The top local story in today’s newspapers is the court appearance of Anthony D. Marshall, who pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to charges of stealing millions of dollars and valuable property from his mother, Brooke Astor, the philanthropist and socialite, after she was found to have Alzheimer’s disease. Among the charges against Mr. Marshall, who had been his mother’s salaried financial adviser: scheme to defraud, grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property and falsifying business records.

headline: Advice for Meeting-Weary Mideast Peace Talkers
text: Tuesday’s kickoff of the Mideast peace conference in Annapolis, Md., raised hopes for a final settlement, but now the real work will begin, in countless meeting rooms and on conference calls, not to mention frequent visits by American mediators.

headline: May the force be with them
text: Or at least a little Kingfisher beer. I know it’s a corny headline and that it will be used again and again and again in stories relating to Force India. But today’s announcement by that team does call for something like that headline.

headline: Bill Clinton’s War Dance
text: “During a campaign swing for his wife, former President Bill Clinton said flatly yesterday that he opposed the war in Iraq ‘from the beginning’ — a statement that is more absolute than his comments before the invasion in March 2003,” reports The Times’s Patrick Healy.

headline: Wildfire Danger in Southern California Today
text: The National Weather Service’s red flags are flying again in Southern California, and they are being whipped by the Santa Ana winds that were merciless during late October’s blazes. A severe warning of fire risk is in effect until 10 p.m. Eastern time for much of the region.

headline: Wednesday Kickoff: The B.C.S. vs. Playoff Argument
text: We open today with an age-old argument: What would be better, the B.C.S. or a playoff system? The Tennessean’s Joe Biddle is clearly on the side of the playoffs. Meanwhile, David Whitley of the Orlando Sentinel writes that people should simply sit back and enjoy the B.C.S. madness.

headline: Rome’s stray cats
text: By Elisabetta Povoledo

headline: The Social Security obsession, again
text: By any reasonable standard, Social Security is at most a second-tier policy issue.

headline: A Message in Volatility
text: The stock market is up today. Assuming that holds, we will end the rotation of big days at four. (Up 1 percent one day, down 1 percent the next, and so on.)

headline: Food Stuff
text: If It's Frozen and Comes in a Box, Is It Really a Latke?

headline: Blankfein Tops Buffett in Fortune’s Power List
text: Goldman Sachs‘ Lloyd C. Blankfein has lapped his rivals at other investment banks this year. But who knew he would outshine Warren E. Buffett, the legendary investor, and the three guys behind the Internet giant Google?

headline: Google Doesn’t Know Where You Are (But It Has a Good Guess)
text: UPDATE: See comment from Google at the end.

headline: How Badly Do the Yankees Want Santana?
text: As they prepare for the winter meetings in Nashville next week, the paramount question for the Yankees is how badly do they want Johan Santana?

headline: Wall Street Research, Made in India
text: Wall Street firms are cutting costs and tightening belts these days — just try ordering a new BlackBerry at Bank of America. This could accelerate a cost-cutting trend that was already gaining momentum: The outsourcing of junior research and investment banking activities to India, where analysis and pitchbooks come far more cheaply than in the United States.

headline: Please Please Me, Like I Please You
text: Enough crying about the schedule already. The N.H.L.’s board of governors, which will meet Thursday in Pebble Beach, Calif., will attempt to fix it and be done with the whole subject for a while. But it will not be soon enough to quiet Canadian fans, who blame N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman for the lockout, low scoring, no team in Hamilton, a team in Nashville, Versus and the schedule (And if the loonie heads south while Bettman is in office, count on the commissioner taking a bit of a hit for that one, too.

headline: The Strike: Almost Over, Or Just Begun?
text: For three weeks, Writers Guild of America members circled the picket lines while union leaders and the studio heads stood on the sidelines.

headline: Giving and Receiving
text: A couple of trends are clear in today’s list of holiday gifts in the Dining section.

headline: SEC vs. the Other Conferences: A Look at the Evidence
text: I saw the comments made by the analyst and oddsmaker Danny Sheridan in the Times about the Southeastern Conference and the alleged imbalance among the other B.C.S. conferences, which he said handicapped the SEC in the national championship race.

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Stephen Elliott
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

headline: Fat Boys and Dreamliners, but No Mustangs?
text: ROME — Airbus, the giant Europe-based aircraft maker, complained this week that its American archrival, Boeing, is “killing us.”

headline: Disturbing the Peace?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Log-rolling in Our Time
text: After live-blogging the Gothams last night to mixed effect — he got the name of the winning movie, “Into the Wild” wrong for a few minutes — the Bagger was sort of played out. Perhaps it was the final stop of the evening, at the Tick Tock diner on Route 3 in New Jersey, where he flyspecked the copy he had put up and finally ate something. If there is a place psychically more distant from the glamour of the Gothams than the Tick Tock, the Bagger has never been there. It is the kind of joint where third-string mafiosi go to profile, being careful not to park in that one spot where Uncle Vinny was probably buried under the asphalt some time ago. The food, though, is wonderful and if its good enough for the real-life Sopranos, it is good enough for the Bagger.

headline: More ‘Late Night’ Jokes From Readers
text: Send your jokes via the comment link below:

headline: When the 6-Year-Old Artists Came to Sotheby’s
text: When a Harlem school official sat down with a Sotheby’s executive in May to plan an exhibit of her first graders’ art at the famed auction house, one of the issues he brought up was insurance.

headline: Does Bloch Feel Rove’s Pain?
text: Foxes and henhouses, etc. “The head of the federal agency investigating Karl Rove’s White House political operation is facing allegations that he improperly deleted computer files during another probe, using a private computer-help company, Geeks on Call,” reports The Wall Street Journal’s John R. Wilke.“Scott Bloch runs the Office of Special Counsel, an agency charged with protecting government whistleblowers and enforcing a ban on federal employees engaging in partisan political activity. Mr. Bloch’s agency is looking into whether Mr. Rove and other White House officials used government agencies to help re-elect Republicans in 2006. At the same time, Mr. Bloch has himself been under investigation since 2005. At the direction of the White House, the federal Office of Personnel Management’s inspector general is looking into claims hat Mr. Bloch improperly retaliated against employees and dismissed whistleblower cases without adequate examination.”

headline: Q & A: Approval Ratings, Pessimism and Annapolis
text: As the Middle East peace process restarts down in Annapolis, Md., The Lede asked one of The New York Times’s resident experts to answer a few questions. Ethan Bronner is deputy foreign editor until next year, when he will move back to Jerusalem as bureau chief. Mr. Bronner was the Jerusalem correspondent for The Boston Globe from 1991 to 1997 and for Reuters from 1983 to 1985.

headline: When a Poll Changes the Way People Think About the Race
text: In her Web column today, Janet Elder writes about last week’s ABC News/Washington Post Poll of Iowa caucus goers.

headline: It’s a Plan!
text: Late last week, our architect Laura Gee e-mailed us a revised set of house plans, but with the rush of Thanksgiving preparations, Paul and I didn’t have a chance to give them more than a passing glance. Over the weekend, we sat down at the kitchen table to take a closer look.

headline: It’s Lonely at the Coliseum
text: Announced attendance for the Islanders-Stars game Monday night: 8,161.

headline: Rangers Lose Avery Again
text: Rangers forward and prime agitator Sean Avery will undergo arthroscopic surgery to his left wrist Thursday afternoon, he said after practice Wednesday at the Rangers’ practice facility in Greenburgh. Neither Avery nor team officials had any timetable for how long he would be out of action. “Hopefully it will only be a week or two,” Avery said.

headline: In Real Estate, Even Smart Money Got Burned
text: If you are nursing losses on real estate deals, here’s a small piece of consolation: Some of Wall Street’s hotshot investors seem to have made similar mistakes.

headline: If White House Walls Could Talk …
text: On Monday, I put out a call asking if anyone overheard what President Bush and former Vice President Al Gore discussed after the White House photo op honoring American Nobel Prize winners. Mr. Gore told The Times that the

headline: When Surgeons Cut the Wrong Body Part
text: It sounds like something out of a horror movie, but wrong-sided surgery happens more often than you think.

headline: Can New York Be Too Successful?
text: Has New York City’s remarkable economic expansion of the past decade been too much of a good thing? A panel of developers took up this question on Tuesday night in a panel discussion organized by the Municipal Art Society, with the title “The Oversuccessful City, Part 1: Developers’ Realities.”Not surprisingly, no one really argued that the city could be too successful. Instead, the often spirited discussion — which at times seemed dominated by angry members of the audience — focused on the dilemmas of affordable housing and out-of-scale development. Projects like Atlantic Yards and the redevelopment of the Far West Side came up. Charles V. Bagli, who covers economic development for The Times, moderated the discussion.

headline: A Casualty in the Atlantic Yards Battle
text: The Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, has named a local community board chairwoman to the City Planning Commission, following the political downfall of his previous appointee, Dolly Williams, a self-inflicted casualty of the Atlantic Yards battle. Ms. Williams agreed last month to a $4,000 fine from the city Conflicts of Interest Board, the board announced Tuesday, settling a complaint over a crucial zoning vote that paved the way for the Brooklyn mega-project in 2004. The planning commission is a 13-member body whose part-time commissioners are paid $48,000 per year to oversee zoning and urban renewal, subject to approval of the City Council.

headline: Cocktails of the South Pacific
text: You may laugh at drinks with umbrellas in them but Jeff “Beachbum” Berry doesn’t. While you slowly sink beneath the tiki bar, he’s working to elevate the Zombie and the Mai Tai into the cultural pantheon, as the

headline: ‘Well, Can I Use My Cell in My Cell?’
text: An upstate New York judge who detained 46 people in his courtroom when a cell phone call interrupted proceedings was removed from the bench Tuesday. The phone rang while Niagara Falls City Court Judge Robert Restaino was hearing domestic violence cases. ”Everyone is going to jail,” Restaino said. ”Every single person is going to jail in this courtroom unless I get that instrument now.” Read more.

headline: Hip-Hop D.J., Fired for Threats, Returns to Airwaves
text: Updated, 3:54 p.m. | Don Imus is not the only shock jock to make a comeback from disgrace.

headline: Bear Stearns to Cut 650 Jobs
text: Bear Stearns, the investment bank, is eliminating 650 jobs, or 4 percent of its workforce, as it seeks to lower costs after losing bets on risky subprime mortgages.
