Bloomberg News said a majority of the cuts would be in the firm’s fixed-income business; the Associated Press said cuts would likely come from the operations side, which includes information technology and legal departments.

headline: Ashcroft Takes Waterboarding Bait — To No Avail
text: On Tuesday night, former Attorney General John D. Ashcroft became the latest backer of waterboarding to face a stirring moral appeal that came from the Bible, and may be written into our genes: “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.”

headline: The Top 10
text: Look here for a list of the Book Review’s Top 10 Books of 2007.

headline: Blue Crush
text: I’m spectacularly late to this sublime surfing video from YouTube. But it’s the first video from that site that has me fantasizing about setting it up in my living room, on some Bravia plasma screen, at obnoxious Anselm Kiefer size.

headline: Answers From the Urban Rodentologist
text: Following is a first set of answers from Robert M. Corrigan, a well-known urban rodentologist and research scientist for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene who is taking questions on the City Room blog this week. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment link below.

headline: Almost 25 Million Watch The ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Conclusion
text: Nearly 25 million viewers tuned in for final results of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” on Tuesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, the largest audience for the series this season but less than the fall finale a year ago. The two-hour show, which followed a rebroadcast of the Charlie Brown Christmas special at 8 p.m. (which drew 13.6 million viewers), helped put ABC on top of the night’s ratings overall.

headline: Media-Coaching Mr. Schwarzman
text: Nearly five months after the Blackstone Group went public, Stephen A. Schwarzman finally spoke out in defense of his firm and the private equity industry. But at least a few observers thought that the speech was a little too defensive and more than a little too late.

headline: Report: Giuliani Billed City Agencies for Trips
text: The Politico’s Ben Smith takes a look at previously undisclosed records that indicate Rudolph W. Giuliani billed “obscure city agencies” — including agencies responsible for regulating loft apartments, aiding the disabled and providing lawyers for indigent defendants — “for tens of thousands of dollars in security expenses amassed during the time when he was beginning an extramarital relationship with future wife Judith Nathan in the Hamptons.”

headline: Bertuzzi Returns and Leaves Quietly
text: While you were sleeping on Tuesday night, Todd Bertuzzi came back to Vancouver for the first time since 2006, when he was traded to Florida for Roberto Luongo. And while reports indicate that he said all the right things, he left town as a minus player in Anaheim’s 4-0 loss to the Canucks.

headline: Pledge of Allegiance
text: Open primaries ­ in which voters don’t have to be a member of a party to vote for its candidates ­ have long been a thorn in the sides of national Democrats and Republicans. Now, according to the Associated Press, Virginia’s G.O.P. is going to do something about it: “If you’re planning to vote in Virginia’s February Republican presidential primary, be prepared to sign an oath swearing your Republican loyalty. The State Board of Elections on Monday approved a state Republican Party request to require all who apply for a G.O.P. primary ballot first vow in writing that they’ll vote for the party’s presidential nominee next fall.”

headline: What It Takes to Make a Sandwich
text: It is becoming easier for those of us who are conscientious diners to figure out where and how ingredients were grown. But learning the social provenance of food, or, in this case, of a sandwich, is often more challenging.

headline: Lolcats on ’24’
text: Writers’ strike? Hah! With funny cats and other free, high-quality Internet content filling in the plot and character gaps, it’s no problemo:

headline: The Multi-Purpose Room
text: If you have read this blog for even 12 seconds, you know my co-author is very, very smart. She proved it again yesterday, by solving a problem that has been (vaguely) bothering me from the beginning.

headline: Chairman Ben and Chairman Mao
text: Chairman Mao once led a campaign called “Let a Hundred Flowers Bloom,” which encouraged dissent. Is Chairman Ben running a similar operation?

headline: City Moves to Put Parking Regulations Online
text: Updated, 6:18 p.m. | The City Council today passed a bill that would require the Transportation Department to create a searchable Web site with detailed, block-by-block parking regulations around the city, an attempt to mitigate the confusion that often arises from parking signs that are unclear or seem to be inconsistent.

headline: Holding an Open House? Hiding Valuables May Not Be Enough
text: Even before two women were charged on Monday with wearing disguises, sneaking into open houses and looting expensive apartments in some of the city’s most elegant buildings on the Upper East Side, real estate agents had gone on the alert.

headline: It’s Still Pork Time In Washington — Time to Fund the First Lady Museum
text: When Democrats took control of Congress, they pledged to reduce the use of earmarks — budget allocations inserted by individual Congress members that often end up as pork.

headline: Is Nuclear Fusion an Answer to Climate Change?
text: My last posting was on a technology (carbon capture and sequestration) that seems to promise more than it can deliver within a time period that could help the planet avoid some of the worst ravages of climate change.

text: Two campaign commercials for the United Russia party.

headline: Hawaii's Colt Brennan
text: Hawaii Quarterback Colt Brennan sustains a concusion against Fresno State on November 10th, 2007.

text: Stanford quarterback Tavita Pritchard sustained a concussion against Notre Dame on Nov. 24. (Courtesy: ESPN)

headline: Sundance Rolls Out Its Picks
text: Sundance has unveiled its 2008 schedule, and David M. Halbfinger, the Bagger’s colleague, is reporting in — from Beverly Hills, no less — with a nifty run-down on the doings in Redford-land. The piece will be in the paper tomorrow, but readers are invited to place their fingers on the festival’s pulse now.

headline: How About Those Knicks?

headline: NY’ers Prepared for the ‘Dance
text: In search of that elusive New York angle for Sundance? The Reeler found plenty in today’s announcement of the slate for this year’s festival that redounds to the benefit of the New York film community.

headline: Pathway to Less Polarized Politics?
text: Party polarization “is the historical norm, not the exception,” said Pietro Nivola, vice president of the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank.

headline: Survey Sees Rise in Children’s Asthma From 9/11 Dust
text: A survey of post-9/11 effects on children released today found that children exposed to the dust cloud following the collapse of the twin towers were twice as likely to be diagnosed with asthma as those not caught in the dust cloud.In general, children under 5 years old had an elevated likelihood of being diagnosed with asthma in the two to three years after the event, though not as sharp an increase as the rescue workers (who were 12 times as likely to be diagnosed as the general population). The survey did not reveal evidence of elevated levels of post-traumatic stress in children.

headline: The Late Show Dilemma
text: Come Monday, will Carson Daly be the only late-night talk show host back on television?

headline: Democrats Cancel CBS Debate
text: “The Democratic National Committee, finding itself in the middle of labor disputes between television writers and CBS, announced this evening that it was canceling the debate among Democratic presidential candidates that had been scheduled to be broadcast on some of the network’s stations on Dec. 10,” Bill Carter reports.

headline: Shorting Bond Insurers for Charity
text: William Ackman has never lacked for confidence in his bets on companies like Target and McDonald’s. Now, he seems so assured of his bet against bond insurers that he says he will donate the more than $500 million he expects to earn from those short positions to charity.

headline: Zombie ideas about income mobility
text: Many politically charged topics are overrun with zombie ideas — false stories that refuse to die, and just keep coming back. Another one has just resurfaced — the idea that America’s rich are just kings for a day, and that pretty soon they’ll be replaced by another lucky group.

headline: G.O.P. Pro-Choice Group Releases Anti-Romney Ads
text: A Republican abortion-rights group is set to begin an advertising offensive against Mitt Romney on Sunday in Iowa and New Hampshire, attacking him as a flip-flopper on the issue.

headline: CBS Cancels Democratic Debate
text: It looks like the Dec. 10 Democratic debate on CBS is off now because of the writers’ strike. The leading Democratic candidates have said they won’t cross the picket line of the striking writers in Los Angeles, and the Democratic National Committee has said it will not try to find an alternative venue.

headline: The New Zunes
text: David Pogue on Microsoft's Zune, which is taking on Apple's iPod.

text:
Journalists David Corn of Mother Jones, left, and James Pinkerton of Newsday ponder the Bush administration's erratic attitude toward Mideast peacemaking.
