headline: Scent Notes | Elle by YSL
text: On the Richter scale of disasters, some are more inexplicable than others. Consider one of the latter. But first, some background: The Yves Saint Laurent scent collection is among the strongest on the market. It contains an effectively perfect perfume, Paris, the paradigmatic rose created by the legendary perfumer Sophia Grojsman; Baby Doll, the brilliantly executed scent of a young girl’s sweet laughter and the world standard in the sweet helium/chic kitsch category; Opium, the still-great reference oriental; and Rive Gauche, now a retro masterpiece. YSL’s revolutionary Nu stumbled commercially but it too is an excellent perfume. Finally, In Love Again is yet another standard-setter of its type (post-modern fruit neon). And now Yves Saint Laurent is rolling out Elle.

headline: Out of Left Field
text: “Well, at least the candidates were probably all Republicans. As for the questioners, that’s a different story,” writes Rick Moran at Rightwing Nuthouse, pretty much summing up the outrage among conservatives that “at least 4 of the questioners from last night’s CNN/YouTube Debate were Democratic party supporters and activists including one gay general who worked for John Kerry’s campaign and is on Hillary Clinton’s LGBT Steering Committee.”

headline: We’re From Citadel, and We’re Here to Help

headline: TPG to Acquire Axcan Pharma for $1.3 Billion
text: Axcan Pharma, a Canadian pharmaceutical company specializing in treatments of gastrointestinal disorders, said Thursday that it will be acquired by TPG Capital for about $1.3 billion in cash. It is the latest in a string of smaller buyouts, since the summer’s credit market squeeze halted the mega-deals from earlier this year.

headline: Helping the ‘Chicken and Rice Man’ of Queens
text: Many readers have written to The City section and the City Room blog, asking how they can help support the work of Jorge Muñoz, the “chicken and rice man” profiled on the cover of the weekly Sunday print section and in this video.Mr. Muñoz, a 43-year-old former illegal immigrant from Colombia, is called an angel by the dozens of day laborers — many hungry, homeless and without work — who congregate at the corner of Roosevelt Avenue and 73rd Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, looking for odd jobs. He shows up at 9:30 every night driving a white pickup truck laden with enough home-cooked fare to feed them all at no charge.

headline: Christmas Trees Go Green
text: The greenest tree in N.Y.C. (Credit: James Estrin/The New York Times)  Over the last several years, several big-city mayors, led by Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Richard M. Daley of Chicago, have made pronouncements that amount to a race to see which metropolis is the “greenest” in the country. They’re retrofitting old city buildings to cut energy waste and greenhouse gases, trying to curtail traffic, putting up solar panels. (For two independent analyses of green cities, go to the Green Guide and Yahoo.)  In the latest move, New York City’s Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, illuminated last night, shines not with old-style incandescent bulbs but with 30,000 electricity-sipping light-emitting diodes, or L.E.D.'s, powered in part with solar panels. (And the tree was even cut with a hand saw, the city says.)  There are some signs of spreading green tree envy.   A recent article in The Minneapolis Star Tribune questioned the cost and carbon dioxide emissions from lighting St. Paul’s giant, and incandescent-lit, Christmas tree. The headline asked: “A bright and shining energy waste?”  The reporter, Karen Youso, wrote that the city’s tree-lighting practices, with 60,000 incandescent bulbs burning around the clock for five and a half weeks, costs about $1,300 and results in 18.7 tons of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping emission from human activities.  She asked state energy officials to calculate the financial and environmental cost if St. Paul erected the tree and bulbs now blazing in Rockefeller Center. The answer was $136.80 and one-tenth as much carbon dioxide.   It’ll be interesting to see what St. Paul and the corporate partners that pay for the display do next year.   What are other cities doing about the kilowatt-hours and carbon dioxide that come with holiday decor?

headline: In Ontario, They Learn Hockey When They’re Young
text: Hockey is a red-blooded, manly endeavor, and with that in mind have a look at Agence France Presse’s report on the bench-clearing brawl between two teams of 8-year-olds that took place in Guelph on Friday. Ontario hockey authorities are tut-tutting the sordid episode — clearly players shouldn’t fight until they’re 15. To start earlier would be, why, obscene.

headline: Shanghai’s Skate Showdown

headline: What Price is Right?
text: Johan Santana, the star pitcher of the Minnesota Twins, is at the center of trade talks between the Twins and a number of clubs. He won’t come cheaply. The team that lands him would likely have to give up multiple top prospects and sign Santana to a long-term contract. How far should a team go to get Santana?

headline: What Gives?
text: It is a little early in the season for the Bagger to mount his hobby horse, but how come “Lars and the Real Girl” and “Once” are getting so little love? “Lars,” a touching story of romance between Ryan Gosling’s character and a blow-up doll, got bubkes at the Gothams and ditto from the Spirit nominations. “Once” got a foreign film nod from the Spirits, but that’s it. Both films would seem to embody indie excellence and ambition, but don’t seem to be gaining the kind of traction they deserve.

headline: Sweeney Todd, a Battleship About to Dock?
text: One of the games we play out here in the land of much portent and little impact is The Big One That is Still Coming. So far, with “Charlie Wilson’s War” getting a wan initial reception, that would be “Sweeney Todd.”

headline: At the Center of the Vortex

headline: No Quarter for Ending of “No Country”
text: Anne Thompson, writing in Variety, said that the refusal of the Coen Brothers to let good triumph over evil in “No Country for Old Men” is a subject of discussion that is showing up everywhere, including her book club. The ending hews closely to the book and the Bagger found it in keeping with a film that constructed its own moral universe. Others, though, aren’t so sure. Nora Ephron gets a laugh out of the debate in the New Yorker, while Alec Baldwin uses it as a soapbox for a short speech. “Go see No Country for Old Men. It’s a metaphor for Iraq and the post 9/11 world,”he concludes.

headline: A Milestone Approaches for Commissioner Kelly
text: At year’s end, Raymond W. Kelly will have logged the longest continuous period as police commissioner of anyone who has held that post since 1945. That’s not including his first of term of service in the Dinkins administration.

headline: PopularityDialer Goes Offline
text: Over a decade ago, I remember seeing a "Saturday Night Live" skit that still stays with me. It was a talk show where all of the guests had one thing in common: they were all jerks or psychopaths whose one-time actions had created lifelong inconvenience for the rest of society. There was that guy who put poison into a bottle of Tylenol, initiating the era of the childproof (and adult-proof) package. There was the hijacker, whose actions led to the nationwide construction of airport X-ray machines. And so on.

headline: After Giving Thanks, Satisfaction

headline: Boots on the Ground in Brooklyn, Plastic Pigeon in Hand
text: In between the remarks about crime-fighting, terrorism and any future role he has in city government, Police Commissioner Raymond W. The commissioner, who is approaching a modern-day record of sorts for continuous service in his post, presented the figurine, along with a certificate of appreciation from the police commissioner’s office, to City Councilman Simcha Felder for “taking on a real serious quality-of-life issue.”

headline: Clinton Polls Best Among Gays, Lesbians
