Kennedy Jr. endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president today, and headed out to campaign for her in Iowa — a state where he once told residents, “large-scale hog producers are a greater threat to the United States and U.S. democracy than Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network.”

headline: CNN/YouTube Debate Breaks Ratings Record
text: CNN’s Republican YouTube debate last night attracted 4.4 million viewers, making it the most-watched debate of this presidential primary season and breaking all records for any primary debate on cable television in cable history.

headline: Wipe That Brilliant Idea Off Your Face
text: Just asking, but doesn’t this miss the point of spontaneous, back-of-the-napkin creativity? Maybe someone doodled the idea on a Post-It note. More here.

headline: I’m a Blackhawk and She’s Joan Cusack
text: The Chicago Blackhawks are making progress, and moving out of obscurity.

headline: Senators Press Japan on Whale-Hunting Plan
text: A group of eight senators sent a letter of protest today to Ryozo Kato, the Japanese ambassador to the United States, over Japan’s impending whale-hunting operation near Antarctica. The operation is billed as scientific research but has been widely criticized by other countries, many environmental groups and marine biologists as a slaughter conducted for relatively unpopular meat and national pride.

headline: S.E.C.’s Lead WorldCom Lawyer to Join Simpson Thacher
text: Peter H. Bresnan, the man who led the Securities and Exchange Commission’s landmark accounting fraud lawsuit against WorldCom, is trading his enforcement duties for private practice.

headline: Say No to Computerized Voting Machines
text: The 2008 presidential election is fast approaching and some states are still using unreliable paperless computerized voting machines.

headline: Bacardi
text: A TV commercial promoting Bacardi rums for the holidays.

headline: Bacardi
text: A TV commercial from Bacardi asking consumers to drink responsibly.

headline: Annoying Things To Do on an Elevator
Will That Be Virtually All?
text: How should we feel about outsourcing “virtual personal assistants”?

headline: Profits Head Down
text: The government’s estimate of corporate profits for the third quarter is out today, and while everyone should understand the early figure is little more than an educated guess, it is interesting. (The figures will eventually be adjusted using tax return data.)

headline: Joy of Failure
text: Do you think financiers should be embarrassed and repentant as the financial system erodes? Or do you see an opportunity for a party?

headline: Do We Need Another El Camino?
text: Autoweek recently reported that General Motors is on the verge of approving an El Camino-like vehicle to slot into the new Pontiac G8 model lineup (based on vehicles sold by G.M.’s Australian subsidiary, Holden).

headline: Bubbe Says You Don’t Have to Squeeze the Latkes
text: What we are reading elsewhere…

headline: A Trifecta of Excuses
text: Sears fell to its lowest level since the KMart-Sears merger today, although it did somehow eek out a profit of a penny per share.

headline: New Year’s in Des Moines
text: It pains me that several of you feel that I dissed the farmers in Iowa and South Dakota in my Nov. 29 column. After spending years working with Verlyn Klinkenborg on the editorial board here, I’ve become a fan of all things farm related, give or take a few subsidies.

headline: Dig This: Red Bull Park, the New Design
text: Promises, promises. Soccer fans in the New York metropolitan area have heard them before.

headline: Road Trip, Part 11: The End Is Near
text: The dynamic CSTV.com duo of Matt Meyers and Mike Ogle are nearing their end of the season-long odyssey known as Going Big. Along the way they’ve seen a little bit of everything, but nothing as jaw-dropping as Missouri assuming the No. 1 ranking. They also managed to solve the season-long mystery of why a flag from Washington State has been in the background for 61 consecutive broadcasts of ESPN’s “College Gameday.” So make sure the gas tank is full. It’s time to hit the road.

headline: Quips Fly as Council Ponders Recycling Plastic Bags
text: Plastic bags, according to the lobby group reusablebags.com, are responsible for the deaths of hundreds of sea turtles, whales and other marine life that accidentally ingest them.

headline: Intensifying the Hunt Against Somali Pirates
text: Pirates operating off the coast of Somalia haven’t caused so much havoc by simply being ruthless. Their innovative tactics have enabled them to launch attacks farther out on the high seas than small skiffs should be able to go, and then they evade pursuers by floating closer to the shore, where international patrols can’t follow without permission from Somalia’s embattled government.

headline: Blogtalk: CNN Debate Under Fire
text: Whew. CNN had barely been confronted by the disclosure last night that one of the video questioners — (the gay retired general) — served on two of Hillary Clinton’s committees before computer keyboards from one coast to another began sounding off heatedly.

headline: A How-To Guide for Sovereign Wealth Funds
text: Sovereign wealth funds based in Asia and the Middle East are on the move. In recent months, these huge government-backed investment firms have taken stakes in Bear Stearns, the Carlyle Group, Advanced Micro Devices, and perhaps most notably, Citigroup.

headline: Cruz Is Out at Morgan Stanley
text: Morgan Stanley said Thursday that Zoe Cruz, a co-president and one of the highest-ranking women on Wall Street, would leave the investment bank in the latest management shakeup since the summer’s credit turmoil.

headline: Could Home Sales Be Better Than Reported?
text: The home sales numbers are dismal, but they may not be as bad as some think.

headline: Broadway Goes Back to Work
text: After 19 dark days, Broadway theaters reopen for business.

headline: Facebook Executive Discusses Beacon Brouhaha
text: Update: The interview below took place hours before Facebook announced a major change in its Beacon system, one that requires users to explicitly approve the sending of information to their friends’ News Feeds. See our article for details.

headline: Jozy Altidore: Next Stop China
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his latest post, Altidore discusses a coming trip to China with the United States men’s Olympic team for games on Dec. 13 in Changsha and Dec. 16 in Guangzhou, and his brief off-season.

headline: The Banjo Santa
text: Meet Warren McKnight of Riverhead, N.Y., on Long Island.

headline: Broadway Goes Back to Work
text: After 19 dark days, Broadway theaters reopen for business.

headline: Verizon’s Real Move to Openness
text: Verizon Wireless got a lot of attention Tuesday for its vague announcement about offering open access to its network. But a much geekier announcement today may well be more important.

headline: Cowboys-Packers Pregame: Who Knows?
text: Pregame warm-ups aren’t necessarily an accurate barometer for things to come. Maybe with field-goal kickers clanking a few off the goal posts or hooking a few balls into the parking lot. But this moment stuck out like Jerry Jones ringing a bell in a Santa Claus outfit:

headline: The New York Times Close Up
text: The guests on Sam Roberts's weekly NY1 program include Ira Berkow, a sports columnist for The Times.

headline: Ouch … Packers Starters Out
text: I know a lot of folks can’t watch the game because they don’t have the NFL Network, so I’ll try to post a few updates from Texas Stadium.

headline: Garry Kasparov on Russian Media
text: An excerpt from an interview with The New York Times conducted last month.

headline: One More Beacon Amendment From Facebook
text: Bowing a bit more to the recent angry sentiment from privacy advocates and some users, Facebook just made yet another change to its controversial Beacon program. No longer will the social network publish a user’s Internet activities to his or her friends on the service without getting explicit approval.

headline: Reality Check
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani's tenure as mayor is a central part of his stump speech, but the statistics he cites are sometimes exaggerated or wrong. (Video: NBC News)

headline: The Back of Henry Blodget’s Envelope
text: In a cross-blog dialog, I challenged Henry Blodget of Silicon Alley Insider to estimate what the MSN division is worth if Microsoft traded it to take a partial stake in Yahoo. (This was Mr. Blodget’s sensible proposed alternative to an outright purchase of Yahoo.)

headline: Facebook Bows to Privacy Protest
text: We told you last week about the outcry — spearheaded by MoveOn.org — over a new feature on Facebook that broadcasts users’ purchases and other activity on some external websites to their friends and in their profiles on the social networking site.

headline: This Might Be a Blowout
text: Somebody has to give in on this NFL Network issue, because 74 million or so of you are missing a shootout that the Cowboys are threatening to turn into a rout.

headline: Favre is Out With Elbow Injury
text: Brett Favre has been knocked out of the game for at least one series with a right elbow injury. His return has been announced as questionable. Aaron Rodgers replaced him, and the Packers promptly went three-and-out.

headline: Helicopter Parenting Turns Deadly
text: Megan Meier, a 13-year-old from Dardenne Prairie, Missouri, killed herself last year after an online relationship she believed she was having with a cute 16-year-old boy named Josh went very sour. What she didn’t know – what her parents would learn six weeks after her death – was that “Josh” was the fictitious creation of Lori Drew, a then-47-year-old neighbor and the mother of one of Megan’s friends.

headline: 'Promise' From Rudolph W. Giuliani
text: First aired on Nov. 29, 2007.

headline: The Evolution of Facebook’s Beacon
text: Facebook keeps tweaking its new Beacon advertising program, which tracks users’ actions on sites other than Facebook. The program ignited a petition from MoveOn.org Civic Action that has won the support of 50,000 Facebook users. Facebook introduced a new version of the Beacon alert box on Thursday that still lacks an easy way to avoid participating.

headline: Favre Looks Done …
text: Favre received treatment and had an X-ray at halftime. No word yet on the extent of the injury to his right elbow. He came out a few minutes into the third quarter and put a Packers cap on his head. Going by his body language, he’s not coming back in, and now the Cowboys are teeing off on Aaron Rodgers. Just sacked him.

headline: Home but Not Home
text: Iraqi officials handed out cash to returning refugees during an event at a Baghdad hotel.

headline: Coach Rod’s First Quarterback
text: Jed Drenning was the first quarterback in Rich Rodriguez’s spread offense. Drenning started for Glenville State in 1991, when Rodriguez was the coach. Now that the coach has West Virginia in the hunt for a national title, Drenning has fond memories of the spread’s early days and he was nice enough to share them with us here at The Quad.

headline: A YOO Conversation
text: One New York newspaper described YOO co-founders John Hitchcox and Philippe Starck as the odd couple of the building industry. In the framework of YOO, the “design-focused” development company with apartment tower projects around the world, Hitchcox is the businessman, the operator, the numbers guy; Starck is the flamboyant designer, able to speak for hours about the shape of a chair.

headline: Cowboys 37, Packers 27, Final
text: Postgame: The Cowboys improve to 11-1 and cement their reputation as the N.F.C.’s favorite to be the Patriots’ whipping ‘boys in the Super Bowl. (New England has already beaten Dallas, 48-27, this season).

headline: That Aloha Feeling
text: One of the inherent joys of college sports is the surreal feeling of discovery when a team or programs reaches the peak for the first time. This obviously happens more in basketball than football, as small schools often ambush their major-conference brethren in the N.C.A.A. tournament, which is almost tailor-made for such moments.

headline: The New York Times Close Up
text: This week, Sam Roberts's guests include the Metro reporters Leslie Kaufman and Ben Weiser and the film critic A.O. Scott.

headline: Police Say Olmert Inquiry Should Be Closed
text: JERUSALEM, Nov. 29 — The Israeli authorities, who were investigating whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert acted criminally in the 2005 sale of a bank, recommended on Thursday that the case be closed, citing a lack of evidence.

headline: U.S. Leans on Subprime Lenders to Freeze Rates
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Treasury Department is leaning on the nation’s biggest subprime mortgage lenders to help at least some of their borrowers avoid foreclosure, but the biggest obstacle is not the lenders themselves.

headline: Manhattan: Job Numbers Continue to Rise
text: New York City has replaced nearly all of the jobs lost since employment in the city peaked before the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, according to federal data released yesterday. The number of jobs in the city, adjusted for seasonal hiring trends, rose to 3.742 million in October, from 3.738 million in September, figures from the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics showed. That was the highest level of employment in the city since January 2001, when there were 3.748 million jobs. Employment in the city has risen steadily all year, outpacing the rate of job growth in the nation, the Labor Department said, but some economists expect that trend to be disrupted soon by various labor strikes and layoffs at big financial firms.

headline: Bombs Found Near Home of Politician in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 29  Two car bombs were found near the house of a senior Sunni political leader on Thursday, and seven of his bodyguards were arrested, an Iraqi military spokesman said.

headline: Latino Immigrants’ Children Found Grasping English
text: Most children of Hispanic immigrants in the United States learn to speak English well by the time they are adults, even though three-quarters of their parents speak mainly Spanish and do not have a command of English, according to a report released yesterday by the Pew Hispanic Center in Washington.

headline: New Look for the New Museum
text: New York is in the cultural doldrums. The city is bursting with gorgeous art exhibitions, but where is the raw energy? Where is the new blood, intent on upending the establishment? Today, once-rebellious talents often seem to be wandering lost in the constellation of celebrity, where they soon settle into complacency.

headline: Bush Renews Call for Congress to Pass Iraq Financing Bill With No Strings
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  President Bush on Thursday began a new offensive against Congressional Democrats over money for the Iraq war, calling on the lawmakers to give American troops “what they need to succeed in their missions” and pass a bill without strings attached.

headline: A Landscaper Is Mauled, and an Outpouring of Sympathy Goes to the Dog
text: PRINCETON, N.J.

headline: Mexico: Governor Off the Hook in Press Case
text: The Supreme Court ruled that Gov. Mario Marin of Puebla State did not violate the rights of a journalist, Lydia Cacho, when he had her briefly jailed on slander charges that were later dropped. She had accused a well-connected Puebla businessman of having links to a pedophilia ring. The case had been closely followed in Mexico as a test of press freedom.

headline: Plans for Annex to Governor’s Mansion Draw Critics
text: NASHVILLE, Nov. 29 — A low-key Democrat, Gov. Phil Bredesen is often praised for his level head and business sense. He was easily re-elected to a second term last fall, sweeping every county in Tennessee.

headline: Turkey Takes Publisher to Task Over Book Questioning God
text: ISTANBUL, Nov. 29  Turkish prosecutors on Thursday questioned the Turkish publisher of the book “The God Delusion,” by a British author, Richard Dawkins, after a young reader complained that it was offensive, the publisher said.

headline: Spas and Stars, but Ojai Tries to Stay Grounded
text: FINDING the ideal small-town retreat is getting tougher these days, at least for urban escapees whose checklist for perfection includes some potentially contradictory traits.

headline: Medicare’s ‘Doughnut Hole’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Queens: Shots Fired at Police Officers
text: A 33-year-old man was arrested yesterday after he fired at police officers who were trying to arrest him after they saw him toss aside a different gun. The officers, none of whom were hurt, arrested the man without returning fire, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. “It showed tremendous restraint on the part of the officers,” Mr. Kelly said. He said that a police sergeant and two officers saw the man, identified as Nnamdi Clarke, toss the gun shortly before 1 a.m. near 97th Place and 57th Avenue. They chased him, and Mr. Clarke, of Horace Harding Expressway, fired one shot before his weapon jammed, the police said. They said that Mr. Clarke had not yet been charged yesterday evening. The police commissioner said that the suspect had two guns, a .25-caliber automatic and a .32-caliber automatic, as well as several bags of marijuana.

headline: The Kid’s Got Energy. Now Watch Him Conduct.
text: AND now, the real debut.

headline: British Teacher Found Guilty in Sudan
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 29 — The British teacher in Sudan who let her 7-year-old pupils name a class teddy bear Muhammad was found guilty on Thursday of insulting Islam and sentenced to 15 days in jail and deportation.

headline: For Both Sides in Broadway Strike, the Message Was: Take Me Seriously
text: After a two-and-a-half week strike that sapped the city of nearly $40 million, wiped away millions of dollars of potential ticket sales and left hundreds of actors, musicians and stagehands without paychecks, the payoff finally arrived. And anyone not intimately familiar with the business of Broadway could be forgiven for asking: Is that it?

headline: Rangers Win Game According to Plan
text: When Rangers center Brandon Dubinsky scored to put the final touch on the Rangers’ 4-2 victory against the Islanders, his exuberance included raucously slamming against the boards with his linemates, Martin Straka and Jaromir Jagr.

headline: Strings and Things: Classical’s Best and Brightest
text: The talk of doom and gloom for the classical recording industry, or at least its CD wing, proceeds apace. Yet recordings continue to stream out from new sources as well as from major labels in retrenchment or recovery. And many of them are truly excellent. The classical music critics of The New York Times here offer a guide to the some of this year’s most notable.

headline: TV Host to Pay Some of His Staff
text: Conan O’Brien, the host of NBC’s “Late Night” show, has agreed to pay nonwriting staff members on his show their regular salaries starting on Monday if the strike by scriptwriters against networks and studios is not resolved.

headline: Rebel Officers Surrender in Manila
text: MANILA, Nov. 29 — Philippine SWAT teams stormed a five-star hotel commandeered by dissident army officers today, arresting a senator, a former vice president, a Catholic bishop and several journalists after a seven-hour standoff.

headline: China Agrees to Remove Certain Export Subsidies
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 — Bowing to American pressure on the eve of high-level talks to reduce economic tensions, China agreed Thursday to terminate a dozen different subsidies and tax rebates that promote its own exports and discourage imports of steel, wood products, information technology and other goods.

headline: In a House of Connection, Isolated Still
text: Gina Gibney’s distinctive choreographic voice has made her one of the most intellectually stimulating of New York dance artists. There is nothing particularly brainy about her dances. She does not play mind games. Instead, quietly, she deals in abstractions, making them do the work of expression for her.

headline: A Payoff for Syrians: Seats at the Table, at Least
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  For almost three years, Syria has been in the diplomatic doghouse, shunned by the United States, disrespected by France, bombed by Israel and even scolded by its fellow Arab governments for cozying up to Iran.

headline: Musharraf Sets Date for End of Emergency Rule
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 29 — Hours after being sworn in to a second term, President Pervez Musharraf announced Thursday that he would lift his state of emergency on Dec. 16, leaving barely three weeks for election campaigning and setting the stage for further confrontation with his opposition.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some editions yesterday about the Republican presidential debate misstated the response of former Senator Fred D. Thompson in a passage about high points for many candidates. During the debate, he offered a spirited defense of gun rights, not gun control.

headline: The Davis Cup and the Greatest Generation
text: Their moment to collectively shine did not simply materialize. The opportunity to define their comparatively under-credentialed generation of American men’s tennis did not present itself like some slick marketing campaign.

headline: Knicks Are a Flop in Prime Time
text: BOSTON, Nov. 29 — Fifty-two points separated the Boston Celtics from the Knicks late Thursday night, and it was hard to say whether the biggest gap was on the scoreboard, or between Coach Isiah Thomas and his players.

headline: Slumping Motorola Replaces Its Chief
text: Motorola said today that its chief executive was stepping down, a move Wall Street had long expected as the company struggled to revive its troubled mobile division.

headline: Fed Chief Offers New Hint on a Rate Cut
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 — Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, acknowledged on Thursday that a “fresh wave of investor concern” had led to tougher credit conditions that posed new risks to the economy, reinforcing the view that the Fed is likely to cut interest rates again, when it meets on Dec. 11.

headline: Court Orders Police to Return Marijuana
text: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 — A California appeals court has ordered the police in Garden Grove to return marijuana that was seized from a man during a routine traffic stop, ruling that enforcement of federal drug laws did not supersede the state’s allowance of marijuana for medicinal purposes.

headline: 3 Held in Killing of Sean Taylor
text: The police have detained three men for questioning in death of Washington Redskins safety Sean Taylor, according to two law enforcement officials in Lee County, Fla.

headline: Broadway’s Delayed Curtain
text: The just-ended strike by stagehands that shut down most Broadway theaters went on an agonizingly long 19 days. Besides disappointing anyone holding tickets, the strike was particularly unnerving for the thousands of people whose livelihoods depend on the money that theatergoers spend in and around the district.

headline: Bobby Van, Saloonkeeper and Pianist in the Hamptons, Dies at 64
text: Bobby Van, a pianist and restaurateur who for nearly two decades presided over the Bridgehampton saloon that bore his name, an upscale oasis frequented by literary royalty like Truman Capote, Kurt Vonnegut and Joseph Heller, died on Tuesday in Nassau County. He was 64.

headline: Google to Join Spectrum Auction
text: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 — True to its promise earlier this year, Google said today that it was preparing to take part in the federal government’s auction of radio frequencies that could be used to deliver the next generation of Internet and mobile phone services to consumers.

headline: Henry J. Hyde, a Power in the House of Representatives, Dies at 83
text: Former Representative Henry J. Hyde, the powerful Illinois Republican who won battles to prohibit federal financing of abortions and to impeach President Clinton but who failed to persuade the Senate to convict and remove him from office, died yesterday in Chicago. He was 83.

headline: Putting on Weight for Football Glory
text: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 29 — When the Desire Street Academy football team plays in a Louisiana state semifinal playoff game Friday night, the Lions will feature three starting linemen who weigh at least 300 pounds and two others who weigh 270 and 280 pounds, reflecting a trend in which high school players are increasingly reaching a size once seen almost exclusively among linemen in college and the N.F.L.

headline: Brief but Pointed Journeys in the Wilderness Within
text: The poor guy slumps before a cluster of microphones, sweating defeat and helplessness. “This should all come as no surprise,” he says. “The phrase, of course, you are familiar with. It was a ‘building year,’ this last year was. We suffered some losses, yes, we suffered some last season, and we had to start out all over.”

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Polishing Sets and Lines, Broadway Comes Back
text: At “Chicago,” the cast had to do a run-through because the new leading man and two other stars joining the show — Vincent Pastore and Aida Turturro, of “The Sopranos” — had never rehearsed together.

headline: Familiar With Emo, Intimate With Upbeat
text: Around 10:30 on Wednesday night, Paramore’s short and generally sharp set ended, and a few thousand people started filing out of the Roseland Ballroom. Outside on West 52nd Street, there was a barricade and, behind it, a row of eager faces.

headline: Giuliani Defends Spending on His Mayoral Security
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani last night called a Web site’s account of his spending a “political hit job” as his campaign struggled to explain why hundreds of thousands of dollars in travel expenses for his mayoral security detail were billed to obscure city offices instead of the Police Department.

headline: Closing Arguments Begin in Trial of Men Charged in Plot to Destroy the Sears Tower
text: MIAMI, Nov. 29  A group of Miami men led by an impoverished construction worker tried to form an alliance with Al Qaeda and start a homegrown religious insurrection against the American government that would include spectacular attacks “just as good or greater than 9/11,” a federal prosecutor said Thursday in closing arguments in the trial of the group.

headline: Sprint Is Said to Reject Offer by Investors and SK Telecom
text: Sprint Nextel has rejected an offer from Providence Equity Partners and SK Telecom of South Korea to replace management and invest $5 billion in the company, according to people apprised of the situation.

headline: Countering Schizophrenia by Finding Solace in Art
text: Rodney Smith sat and shuffled and reshuffled a small stack of business cards he held in his large, gentle hands.

headline: Bush Urges Congress to Increase AIDS Money
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 — Marking the 20th anniversary of World AIDS day, President Bush urged Congress today to make more money available to fight the disease, and he announced that that he and his wife, Laura, will visit sub-Saharan Africa early in 2008.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article in some editions yesterday about the Republican presidential debate misstated the response of former Senator Fred D. Thompson in a passage about high points for many candidates. During the debate, he offered a spirited defense of gun rights, not gun control. (Go to Article)

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Nov. 20 about performances by the singer and songwriter Natalie Merchant at Club Hiro in New York starting on Jan. 4 misstated her recent performing history. The Club Hiro dates will be her first full concerts in four years, not her first live appearances in four years.

headline: Wounds of the Revolution
text: BEIJING

headline: Food and Fun
text: A cloying blend of Bollywood sentiment and “Amélie” whimsy, “Nina’s Heavenly Delights” is a lesbian-foodie fairy tale that keeps its appetites well under control. The title may hint at naughty pleasures, but the director, Pratibha Parmar, is more interested in pappadams than passion.

headline: Romo, T.O. Stand Tall as Injuries Fell Favre
text: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 29 — The Dallas Cowboys stamped their claim to N.F.C. supremacy with a 37-27 victory against the Green Bay Packers on Thursday night when the duel between Tony Romo and Brett Favre never materialized.

headline: Ecuador Congress Is Dissolved in Vote
text: Members of an elected assembly convened to rewrite Ecuador's Constitution voted last night to dissolve Congress, a move expected to strengthen President Rafael Correa. The decision gives the assembly the legislative powers of Congress while it debates a new Constitution over the next six months. Mr. Correa has been seeking to strengthen the office of the president after a long bout of political instability; he is the eighth president in 10 years. The assembly is controlled by Mr. Correa's movement.

headline: Pushing for Livability Amid Downtown’s Chaos
text: Sure, urban lobbyists are made, not born. But if the force field emanating from Elizabeth H. Berger, the excitable, fancifully attired (she swears by quirky designer finds from her neighbor, the Century 21 store) new president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, is a reliable signifier, once a lobbyist, always a lobbyist.

headline: On Lake Michigan, a Port of Call for Art
text: THE building at 328 Main Street in Racine, Wis., started life as a dry goods store in 1854. A newspaper named The Times-Call took it over at the turn of the 20th century. In the 1930s, it became a high-end fur shop, with a facade reflecting its elegance, and later it did a stint as a church.

headline: Giuliani on Taxes, Democrats and Record as Mayor
text: The campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani began running its fourth advertisement yesterday in New Hampshire.

headline: A Seascape Dotted by Chaotic Bursts
text: Some theatrical pieces inspire a vague and intermittent boredom as they are performed, yet feel worthwhile by the time you emerge, blinking, into the theater lobby. Such was “Ship in a View,” a work performed by the Japanese dance-theater company Pappa Tarahumara, which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night as part of the Next Wave Festival.

headline: Study Details How U.S. Could Cut 28% of Greenhouse Gases
text: The United States could shave as much as 28 percent off the amount of greenhouse gases it emits at fairly modest cost and with only small technology innovations, according to a new report.

headline: Hedge Fund to Nominate Four for Brink’s Board
text: Millbrook Capital, the activist hedge fund seeking a breakup or sale of the Brink’s Company, is expected to announce its four nominees today for directors of the security company.

headline: Some Essential Hardware (Even Away From the Street)
text: For almost every lawyer, accountant, Wall Street executive or deal maker, the briefcase and the BlackBerry can be a lifeline to the office, particularly for those on the road for business or commuting from the suburbs. Executives these days can’t go anywhere without the cellphone or the BlackBerry, but there are other gadgets and high-tech devices that are also catching on — some for work, but many for relaxation.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: The Economic Effect

headline: Atlanta Police Tied to Child Pornography Case
text: ATLANTA, Nov. 29 — The husband of a city police sergeant was arrested on a child pornography charge on Thursday, and federal investigators said police officers had apparently withheld and destroyed evidence in the case.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Chiefs Lineman Tries to Spark Generosity
text: Kansas City Chiefs lineman Kyle Turley wants his contribution to be the first of millions of dollars donated by today’s players to the pioneers of the N.F.L. He said he hoped that his announced donation would prompt other active players to turn over their game paychecks on Dec. 23, a day being called Gridiron Guardian Sunday.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Body Unwilling, a Mind Takes Flight
text: Julian Schnabel has made three feature films: “Basquiat,” “Before Night Falls” and now “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” All are biographical, examining the lives of real people, and in each case the protagonist struggles with a condition of literal or metaphorical imprisonment. Jean-Michel Basquiat, Mr. Schnabel’s younger colleague in the New York art scene of the 1980s, is trapped by addiction and by his outsider status. Reinaldo Arenas, the gay Cuban poet whose memoir was the basis of “Before Night Falls,” is censored, harassed and locked up by successive dictatorships.

headline: States Take Up Immigration Issue
text: State lawmakers, stepping into a vacuum left by the defeat of immigration legislation in Washington, have considered more than 1,560 bills related to immigration this year and enacted 244 of them in 46 states, according to a report by the National Conference of State Legislatures. The number of measures enacted nearly tripled from the 84 in 2006, creating a legal patchwork for immigrants across the country. A large number of measures determined whether states would give drivers’ and other licenses to illegal immigrants, and established penalties for employers hiring those immigrants.

headline: Dell Raises Earnings and Sales; Shares Fall
text: Dell, undergoing a transformation to reach consumers worldwide and a broader base of business customers, reported improved financial results that nevertheless disappointed Wall Street.

headline: Russia: Berezovsky Sentenced in Absentia
text: A Moscow court convicted the Russian oligarch Boris Berezovsky in absentia of embezzling millions of dollars from the national airline, Aeroflot. Mr. Berezovsky, one of President Vladimir V. Putin’s most vocal critics, received a prison sentence of six years. He lives in Britain and did not contest the charges, saying they were trumped up. Britain will not extradite him.

headline: Panel Rebuffs White House Privilege Claim
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 — The Senate Judiciary Committee inched forward Thursday in its struggle with the White House over subpoenas demanding information from current and former Bush administration officials about the firing of several United States attorneys last year.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $2,417,341.86

headline: Beautiful Manhole Covers, but at What Price?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about Ryan Lochte, an elite American swimmer, misstated the distance of a long-course race in which he has posted three of the 10 fastest times. It is the 200-meter individual medley, not the 400. As the article noted, Lochte also swims in the short-course 200-yard individual medley. (Long-course events take place in a 50-meter pool, and short-course races are in a 25-yard pool.)

headline: A Hero of Hockey
text: “You’re the Babe Ruth of hockey.” That’s what Dick Irvin (Stephen McHattie), coach of the Montreal Canadiens, says to Maurice Richard (Roy Dupuis), the team’s great star of the 1940s and ’50s. “The Rocket,” Charles Binamé’s 2005 film (which starts a brief theatrical run in Manhattan today), certainly gives him the kind of adoring biopic treatment sports heroes used to enjoy routinely. Mr. Binamé and the movie’s screenwriter, Ken Scott, present a Richard who has, off the ice, little in common with the boisterous Babe. He’s a faithful husband and a strong, silent hunk of blue-collar stoicism, as well as a fighter against discrimination and injustice — a combination of Jackie Robinson and the Gary Cooper version of Lou Gehrig, if you insist on a baseball analogy.

headline: Capital Is King Once Again
text: When you take big risks, you expect big rewards if all goes well. Right?

headline: Stocks Surge, Then Give Up Early Gains
text: Stocks soared early today, but gradually gave up much of their gains as investors weighed the bad news with the good.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article yesterday about high-technology toys misidentified one item shown. It was the ClickStart, My First Computer, by LeapFrog, not the Easy Link Internet Launch Pad by Fisher-Price.

headline: A Cosmopolitan Voice Wedded to a Smoky Sax
text: A peripatetic jet-set couple shuttling between London and Paris with extended visits to Rio de Janiero and Tokyo: that is the glamorous picture that the pop-jazz singer Stacey Kent and her husband, the saxophonist Jim Tomlinson, conjured on Wednesday evening at Birdland.

headline: Stormy Outlook in Vienna: Atonal, Serial and Cryptic
text: There were two ways to approach the concert that Tactus, an exemplary young contemporary-classical ensemble from the Manhattan School of Music, presented in the school’s Ades Performance Space on Wednesday night. On the program were Schoenberg’s “Pierrot Lunaire” and Berg’s Chamber Concerto for Violin, Piano and 13 Winds. (A third work previously announced, Jorg Herchet’s Piece for Solo Flute, was omitted without comment.)

headline: Giants’ Struggles Go Beyond Manning
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 29  Little has gone right for the Giants’ offense in the last three games. Take the rushing attack. During the first eight games of the season, the Giants averaged 138 yards on the ground. In the three since then, two of them losses, they averaged 84 yards.

headline: Broadway, Restaged
text: SO: the curtains are up, the marquees are glowing, the Playbills are once again stacked in their neat little piles. Now what?

headline: Miami Art Museum to Unveil Design for New Building
text: Although revisions are usually inevitable, museums planning a new building typically present the design as a done deal, with every detail resolved and the architects ready to break ground.

headline: Corzine Is Set to Revamp School Aid Formula
text: After more than a year of review, Gov. Jon S. Corzine will propose a new school financing formula as early as next week that would give at least $400 million in new state money to poor and disadvantaged children who live outside traditional inner-city school districts, according to officials familiar with the plan.

headline: Missing Top Players, Jets Look to Tight End for a Boost
text: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 29 — Laveranues Coles, one of the Jets’ starting wide receivers, has missed two of the last three games. Jerricho Cotchery, the other starting wideout, hurt his right index finger in Monday’s practice.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The On Education column on Nov. 28, about private firms that use branding techniques to coach high school students who apply to college, misstated the educational credentials of Chioma Isiadinso, founder of a small New York coaching firm, Expartus. She has a master’s in education from the University of Pittsburgh, not an M.B.A. from Harvard.

headline: Ralph Beard, Kentucky Star Involved in Point-Shaving Scandal, Is Dead at 79
text: Ralph Beard, who propelled the University of Kentucky to two consecutive N.C.A.A. basketball championships in the late 1940s, and starred in the N.B.A. before his career was shattered by involvement in a widespread collegiate point-shaving scandal, died yesterday in Louisville, Ky. He was 79.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A headline and picture caption with an article in some editions on Wednesday about a search for a new operator of the heliport in downtown New York misidentified the agency that is conducting the search. It is the city’s Economic Development Corporation, not the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. (The Port Authority, the current operator, did not renew its lease.)

headline: Lottery Numbers
Prosecutor Seeks to Pull Kerik Lawyer
text: A judge should consider removing the defense lawyer representing Bernard B. Kerik, the city’s former police commissioner, because the lawyer might be called as a witness, federal prosecutors said yesterday in a request they sent to a court.

headline: Former Rep. Henry Hyde Is Dead at 83
text: Former Representative Henry J. Hyde, who won battles to prohibit federal funding of abortions and to impeach President Clinton but failed to persuade the Senate to convict and remove him from office, died yesterday.

headline: Lebanese Opposition Leader Backs Army Chief for President
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 29  The political logjam over Lebanon’s vacant presidency was broken Thursday when a leader of the Syrian-backed opposition announced his support for the compromise candidate accepted by the pro-Western alliance. The deal follows Syria’s participation in the American-sponsored Middle East peace conference.

headline: Musharraf Defends Actions After Taking Oath
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 29 — President Pervez Musharraf was sworn in to a second five-year presidential term today, a day after stepping down as military chief. He warned foreign diplomats assembled for the ceremony not to force democracy and human rights on developing countries, but to let them evolve in their own time.

headline: 1,000 Police Enforce Uneasy Peace in Paris Suburb
text: VILLIERS-LE-BEL, France, Nov. 29 — The first thing everyone mentions is the helicopters: the relentless throbbing of blades cutting through the skies above the housing projects and the probing searchlights that have kept the residents of this heavily immigrant suburb of Paris awake over the last four nights.

headline: Reveling in the Stillness, Puzzling Over the Self
text: There is something distinctly female about the quiet, controlled worlds that Beth Gill creates. They conjure the still interiors of an Anita Brookner novel, or the sensual gradations in an Agnes Martin painting. Disruptions are subsonic.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article yesterday about John Tavares, a promising 17-year-old hockey player for the Oshawa Generals in Ontario, misspelled the surname of the former National Hockey League defenseman who coaches the team. He is Brad Selwood, not Sellwood.

headline: Yankees and Red Sox Competing for Santana
text: The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox have been competing on and off the field for more than a century. So it is not surprising that the teams are now feverishly competing to acquire Johan Santana, the elite left-handed pitcher from the Minnesota Twins.

headline: Appeals Court Voids Agreement to Pay Freelancers for Work Published on the Web
text: A federal appeals court yesterday threw out a hard-fought agreement between publishers and freelance writers to pay the writers for electronic reproduction of their work.

headline: Reading Fun Before Frosty Melts Away, and After
text: Will there be another white Christmas? The polar bears, dressed for snow, nervously await the answer. Given current climate trends, future generations will no doubt marvel at folk memories of snowball fights, ice skating and arguments about how anyone can possibly know that no two snowflakes are alike. Yes, Virginia, we used to have winter, and Santa traveled with a herd of reindeer, not camels.

headline: A Soccer Player’s Ordeal in an Argentine Prison
text: From an early scene in which a gang of thugs kicks and yells at the frail, cowering mother of a man whose whereabouts they demand to know, Israel Adrián Caetano’s film “Chronicle of an Escape” makes your stomach knot in anticipation that worse is to come. Minutes later, as the object of their search, a soccer player named Claudio M. Tamburrini (Rodrigo de la Serna), makes his way home after a game, he is blindfolded and dragged into a car. Taken to a sinister mansion in suburban Buenos Aires, he is thrown into a room with other prisoners who have been rounded up for interrogation.

headline: Chávez Proposals Would Make Finances Opaque
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 29 — As petrodollars stream into oil-producing countries, Western officials have begun to demand greater accountability for how they are spent. Some countries known for corruption, like Nigeria and Azerbaijan, have heeded the call, increasing their financial transparency, or at least paying lip service to it. But Venezuela under the leadership of President Hugo Chávez appears headed in the opposite direction.

headline: Army Official Resigning
text: The Army’s top procurement official, Gen. Claude M. Bolton Jr., is resigning, Army officials said. General Bolton’s resignation comes one month after an independent panel criticized how the Army oversees $4 billion a year in contracts for food, water, shelter and other supplies to sustain American forces in Iraq, Kuwait and Afghanistan. General Bolton, a retired two-star Air Force general, plans to leave on Jan. 2, after exactly six years in his current job. He is scheduled to testify before a Senate subcommittee next week on the review panel’s conclusion that the Army failed to train enough experienced contracting officers to operate in combat zones.

headline: Former Governor’s Daughter Seeks a Congressional Seat in New Jersey
text: TRENTON, Nov. 29 — Another aspiring politician hopes to go into the family business in New Jersey.

headline: In Chávez Territory, Signs of Dissent
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 29 — Three days before a referendum that would vastly expand the powers of President Hugo Chávez, this city’s streets were packed on Thursday with tens of thousands of opponents to the change. The protests signaled that Venezuelans may be balking at placing so much authority in the hands of one man.

headline: New York TV Station Takes Chance on Liquor Ads
text: ALMOST six years after NBC ended an experiment to bring the first liquor commercials onto national broadcast network television, the flagship station it owns, WNBC-TV in New York, has started running such spots.

headline: Citadel Throws E*Trade a $2.55 Billion Lifeline
text: When shares of E*Trade Financial began tumbling this month amid speculation that its faltering mortgage investments were jeopardizing its health, the company began casting about for a solution.

headline: Haunted History
text: The documentary “Oswald’s Ghost” initially plays as yet another primer on the assassination of John F. Kennedy, the vilification of Lee Harvey Oswald, the normalization of conspiracy theory and the collective aftershocks of a murder many Americans still consider unsolved.

headline: Cyclocross: Mud, Sweat and Gears
text: ABOVE the pool of filth, but still within the shadow of the ditch, my bike skidded sideways in muck. “Heads up!” yelled a fellow racer, elbow out, body a blur.

headline: Kasparov Warns of ‘Chaos’ in Russia
text: MOSCOW, Nov. 29 — Released from jail after serving a five-day sentence for leading an opposition march, Garry Kasparov, the former chess champion, warned today that Russia was heading toward chaos under President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Gay Question Puts CNN on Defensive
text: The president of CNN said yesterday that the cable channel would redouble its efforts to vet the campaign affiliations of questioners at open-forum debates, after a retired brigadier general was permitted Wednesday to ask the Republican presidential candidates about gay men and lesbians in the military without CNN’s knowing that he was listed on an advisory committee of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Here Comes the Bride With Chewing Gum
text: Anyone too busy during the last couple of decades to make it to the Off Broadway production that inspired “Tony N’ Tina’s Wedding” can relax: the film version is now being granted a limited release. Exactly how limited will depend on your tolerance for tasteless behavior, extravagant overacting and a decibel level to rival the unveiling of Oprah’s Favorite Things.

headline: Art in Review
text: CHARLES RAY

headline: Sharing (for a Price)
text: PART of the joy of owning a second home is sharing it with others. And all the better if those others are willing to pay for the privilege. If that’s one of the reasons you’re thinking of buying a ski condo — or renting out one you already own — then you need to consider a few big questions.

headline: A New Push to Roll Back ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 — Marking the 14th anniversary of legislation that allowed gay men and lesbians to serve in the military but only if they kept their orientation secret, 28 retired generals and admirals plan to release a letter on Friday urging Congress to repeal the law.

headline: Resurrecting a ‘Firebird’ and Transcending a Choreographer in a Single Bound
text: For those of us who attend too many galas, Wednesday’s opening night of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater season at City Center was a happy model of how these things should be done. The onstage speeches projected good humor; a sense of pride in work and in colleagues; and belief in the work, the cause and indeed the whole art form of dance. Especially in the personality of the company’s artistic director, Judith Jamison, they built a showbiz sense of anticipation before each dance.

headline: Central Rome Streets Blocked by Taxi Drivers
text: ROME, Nov. 29 — If the question ever arises again, Romans now know how long it takes to paralyze the entire city center: 20 minutes.

headline: Oxygen Suppliers Fight to Keep a Medicare Boon
text: Millions of people with respiratory diseases have relied on oxygen equipment, delivered to their homes, to help them breathe. A basic setup, including three years of deliveries of small oxygen tanks, can be bought from pharmacies and other retailers for as little as $3,500, or about $100 a month.

headline: Rivalry With Celtics Stirs Thomas’s Passion
text: BOSTON, Nov. 29 — Isiah Thomas started his day with talk of rivalries and hatred and the sort of fierce competition that drives a team deep into the spring. The references were all in the past tense, however; his current team is not ready for such weighty emotions.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article yesterday about the Bush administration’s effort to provide impetus for peace efforts on the day after Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves to negotiating a peace treaty reversed the position of the leaders shown walking with President Bush. Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel was on the left and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, was on the right.

headline: British Muslim Leaders Propose ‘Code of Conduct’
text: LONDON, Nov. 29 — Moderate British Muslim leaders on Thursday proposed guidelines that aim to root out extremism, promote a culture of “civic responsibility” and foster women’s rights in the country’s mosques, Islamic centers and Muslim schools.

headline: By the Beach, a Town Where Winter Also Has Its Fans
text: ON the drive south from Neahkahnie Mountain toward Manzanita on the north coast of Oregon, the view is startling: broad cobalt skies above shaving-cream waves that ghost toward shore, all complemented by low, purple mountains that bulk in the distance.

headline: On the Golden Eagle Jump, It’s Form Against Fear
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Nov. 29  One of the most fearsome jumps in downhill ski racing is on the second half of the Birds of Prey course at Beaver Creek, the only stop the men’s World Cup circuit makes in the United States.

headline: Mandates and Mudslinging
text: From the beginning, advocates of universal health care were troubled by the incompleteness of Barack Obama’s plan, which unlike those of his Democratic rivals wouldn’t cover everyone. But they were willing to cut Mr. Obama slack on the issue, assuming that in the end he would do the right thing.

headline: Facebook Retreats on Online Tracking
text: Faced with its second mass protest by members in its short life span, Facebook, the enormously popular social networking Web site, is reining in some aspects of a controversial new advertising program.

headline: Hokulia and Seclusion Bay
text: Hokulia

headline: Suspect Is Arrested in Clinton Office Standoff
text: A tense standoff at a presidential campaign office of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Rochester, N.H., ended shortly after 6 p.m. this evening when a man later identified as Leeland Eisenberg was taken into police custody after holding at least four people hostage. There were no apparent injuries.

headline: A War Hero’s Terror, Tragedy and Rescue
text: “Badland,” a melodrama by the writer and director Francesco Lucente, stands apart from the recent throng of post-9/11 dramas by posing a burning question we haven’t heard yet: Can a mentally ill Iraq war veteran who murdered his pregnant wife and two of his children learn how to love again?

headline: Drop in Sales of a Drug Leads to a Write-Down
text: Johnson & Johnson said last night that it would record a $440 million write-down to account for declining revenue from its heart-failure infusion treatment, Natrecor.

headline: Lott the Latest in Unusual Retirement Trend
text: There used to be a saying about the Senate that the only way someone left was by the ballot box or feet first. Except for the occasional run for the White House or governor, hardly anyone voluntarily relinquished such a rarefied position, with its attendant aura of power and dignified public service.

headline: Keeping the Focus on AIDS
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Evolution of a Broken Play
text: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 27 — In the fall of 1991, Glenville State quarterback Jed Drenning left the field with a few fractured fingers and numerous body bruises. He had been sacked 20 times by West Virginia State, and no one was more embarrassed than his coach, Rich Rodriguez.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day last Friday about a deal between Gazprom, the Russian energy giant, and Eni, the Italian energy group, referred imprecisely to its scope. It was a contract to conduct a feasibility study on a pipeline linking Russia to Europe via the Black Sea; it was not a contract to build the pipeline. (A memorandum of agreement between Gazprom and Eni signed in June detailed the companies’ plans to design, finance and manage the construction of the pipeline.)

headline: Mexican Court Finds No Violation of Rights in Jailing of Journalist
text: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29 — In a setback for journalistic freedom in Mexico, the Supreme Court ruled Thursday that the governor of Puebla did not violate the rights of a journalist when he had her jailed on defamation charges.

headline: Europeans Endorse Stricter Gun Control
text: The European Parliament overwhelmingly backed a set of stricter gun-control rules that would limit gun ownership across the 27-member European Union. Under the rules, which must be approved by national governments, minors under 18 would be allowed to possess a firearm only for hunting or target shooting under the guidance of an adult, and anyone over 18 who has been convicted of a violent crime would be banned from buying a gun.

headline: In Slovakia, Three Are Held in a Uranium Smuggling Case
text: BRUSSELS, Nov. 29  Two Hungarians and a Ukrainian were arrested Wednesday after trying to sell highly enriched uranium, Slovak diplomats and police authorities said Thursday. The quantity, however, was far too small to make a crude warhead.

headline: No Longer a Secret, Paterno’s Base Coaching Salary Is $512,664
text: Joe Paterno’s salary as Penn State’s coach is $512,664, which is relatively modest among his peers for a man of his accomplishments and tenure.

headline: Florida Freezes Its Fund as Governments Pull Out
text: Seeking to stem a multibillion-dollar run on an investment pool for local governments, top Florida officials voted yesterday to suspend withdrawals from the fund, leaving some towns and school districts worrying about how they would pay their bills.

headline: Books to Make Spirits Bright
text: Here is information about the books included in William Grimes's 2007 Holiday Gift Guide:

headline: Sears Profit Plunges; Cost Cuts Get Blame
text: Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire financier and chairman of Sears Holdings, is fond of saying that a company must be regularly “pruned,” like a tree or a wardrobe. But “you can’t cut your way to success,” he warned investors in his annual letter this year.

headline: M.T.A. Savings Proposal May Mean Service Cuts
text: Straphangers could be forgiven if they see something Grinchlike about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority this holiday season.

headline: It’s Not About Money in Pettitte Wait
text: Seven weeks after Andy Pettitte’s season ended with the Yankees, he is no closer to deciding if he will return and pitch for them again next season. Tom Pettitte, Andy’s father, said yesterday that Pettitte has not determined if he will retire or rejoin the Yankees for his 14th major league season.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,869 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Nov. 21 about a RAND Corporation study on street stops by the New York Police Department referred incorrectly at some points to an overall figure and misstated the number of individual officers who were found to be disproportionately more likely to stop whites. There were 508,540 street stops in 2006  not 508,540 people stopped  and 13 officers, not 9, tended to stop whites more often. The article also misstated the finding of a racial disparity in the handing out of summonses. Whites are more likely  not less  to receive them.

headline: Business and Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Galleries, a Nervy Opening Volley
text: Nothing raises expectations or dashes hopes like a new building. When the New Museum of Contemporary Art opens tomorrow in its first built-from-scratch home, it will represent hope fulfilled and be a much more visible element in the always interesting New York museum landscape. Its new building is a stack of neutral, elegantly off-register, no-frills white cubes not only inside, but outside too. It’s great truth in advertising, and achieves the bracing spareness of the best Swiss-German museums.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Economics, Immigrants and Lou Dobbs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about efforts by the Advertising Council to devote more attention to online media, included a foundation erroneously in a coming campaign to discourage violence among teenagers. The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation is not involved in the campaign.

headline: How the Littlest Nazi Turned Out to Be a Jew
text: A little boy running from the people who killed his mother, brother and sister is lost for months in a dark forest in Eastern Europe. He survives on wild berries and ties himself to trees to escape the howling wolves. Frozen and starving, he happens upon a hut that holds out the promise of food and warmth, but as with the hut in “Hansel and Gretel,” the promise is cruelly deceptive, and again he narrowly escapes death. Eventually he is rescued by soldiers. But they are dangerous, too, and he must hide from them the truth about himself. It is a truth so frightening that as time passes he gradually forgets who he is, to the point that he cannot even remember his name.

headline: Injuries Reported in Train Crash
text: CHICAGO, Nov. 30  An Amtrak train slammed into a freight train at a Chicago South Side rail yard today, the impact forcing some passenger seats off their bracing and leaving dozens of people injured, authorities said.

headline: Sanctuary Was a Lovely Word. Then the G.O.P. Got Hold of It.
text: When they finally got down to business, after being serenaded by a guitarist on YouTube, it took the Republican presidential candidates 11 ½ minutes Wednesday night for one of them to acknowledge that illegal immigrants are human beings.

headline: Obama’s Color Line
text: BARACK OBAMA is running an astonishing campaign. Not only is he doing far better in the polls than any black presidential candidate in American history, but he has also raised more money than any of the candidates in either party except Hillary Clinton.

headline: Russia Decides to Keep Davydenko in Reserve
text: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 29  Nikolay Davydenko, eager for this tumultuous season to be over, will get the chance Friday to take an early break.

headline: Iraq Lacks Plan on the Return of Refugees, Military Says
text: BAGHDAD, Nov. 29 — As Iraqi refugees begin to stream back to Baghdad, American military officials say the Iraqi government has yet to develop a plan to absorb the influx and prevent it from setting off a new round of sectarian violence.

headline: Minaya Rules Out Trading Reyes
text: Omar Minaya understands what it is like to be forced to trade a top pitcher. As the general manager of the Montreal Expos, Minaya was ordered to slash payroll after the 2002 season. So off went Bartolo Colón, whom Minaya had acquired only six months earlier.

headline: Adult but Not Old
text: WHO Sheldon Cherapp, 66, a consultant and retired accountant, and his wife, Elaine, 65, of Rockville, Md. WHAT 4-bedroom house WHERE Lake Worth, Fla.

headline: New in New Orleans
text: WHILE New Orleans continues to struggle to repopulate many residential neighborhoods after Hurricane Katrina pummeled the region in late August 2005, the bulk of the city’s popular cultural assets, which generally suffered little damage, are pulling in tens of thousands of out-of-town visitors. And not only are those old venues still big draws — breakfast at Brennan’s, a stroll past street artists on Jackson Square, a visit to Preservation Hall to hear traditional jazz — an entirely new selection of cultural and culinary sites has emerged.

headline: Theater Listings
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: On Nuclear Seesaw, the Balance Seems to Shift to Iran
text: PARIS, Nov. 29  Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, is known for overheated, boastful pronouncements. So it was hardly a surprise earlier this month when he declared that despite demands from the United States and other countries that Iran stop enriching uranium, Tehran was pressing ahead and negotiations were out of the question.

headline: Problematic Medical Scans
text: CT scans have long been cited as a prime example of how the overuse of fancy medical technologies can drive up the cost of health care. Now there are newly voiced concerns that computed tomography, or CT, may be a health risk as well.

headline: Everything's Popping Up Showbiz
text: Like a Disney show itself, “How Does the Show Go On?,” a whiz-bang introduction to the inner workings of the commercial theater from Disney Editions, is gorgeously produced and cunningly designed to appeal to the largest possible audience. Kindergarten concepts (what is a ticket?) are explained alongside complicated issues that longtime theatergoers will have wondered about. In easily digestible, winking prose, Thomas Schumacher, who runs Disney’s theatrical unit, and Jeff Kurtti, a Disney historian, define dummy lyrics, fight calls and house heads, and parse which union member is in charge of a candle.

headline: Producer of Poisonous Toy Beads Issues Apology
text: HONG KONG, Nov. 29 — The Hong Kong company that manufactured millions of poisonous toy beads in mainland China issued a public apology on Thursday, with the chairman saying that it had not occurred to anyone to check whether an inexpensive glue ingredient in the beads would be dangerous for children to eat.

headline: Morgan Stanley Executive Ousted After Trading Loss
text: Morgan Stanley, its reputation battered over a recent $3.7 billion subprime trading loss, has become the latest Wall Street firm to force the retirement of a senior banking executive.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with the Shifting Careers column in Business Day yesterday reversed the identifications of two of the three men shown. Richard Jepsen, a partner in OSCS Sailing School in San Francisco, was in the middle, not Larry Ledgerwood, a consultant, who was at the left.

headline: Tower Planned Atop Port Authority Bus Terminal in New Wave of Development
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has revived plans to build a sleek 40-story office tower over the north wing of the West Side bus terminal at the suddenly hot intersection of Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street.

headline: Obama Takes His Campaign to Harlem
text: Senator Barack Obama held a fund-raiser in Harlem last night, his first event in the historic seat of black cultural and political power since he announced his Democratic presidential candidacy and a place where Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton enjoys wide popularity.

headline: Citing Statistics, Giuliani Misses Time and Again
text: In almost every appearance as he campaigns for the Republican presidential nomination, Rudolph W. Giuliani cites a fusillade of statistics and facts to make his arguments about his successes in running New York City and the merits of his views.

headline: The Capitol’s Rich Afterlife
text: Senator Trent Lott’s sudden decision to retire from public office has Washington’s lobbying industry salivating at the prospect that the Mississippi lawmaker may join the millionaire’s row on K Street. That’s where more and more Congressional alumni have been hanging their backslapper’s shingle to lobby old buddies. Mr. Lott’s planned departure  conveniently ahead of the new two-year wait before a retired senator can lobby  is shedding light on Capitol Hill’s quasi-aristocracy of ex-incumbents who never return home and stay close by to work politics from its more lucrative shadow world.

headline: Sometimes a Big Gun Takes Time to Unlimber
text: On “Surprise,” her recent debut recording for Deutsche Grammophon, the Canadian soprano Measha Brueggergosman sings amusing works by Schoenberg, Satie and William Bolcom with such presence, power and humor that she almost seems to fly out of the speakers. So it was odd to hear her give comparatively pale performances of the same songs (along with Britten, Poulenc and Rorem works) at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening.

headline: China Explains Decision to Block U.S. Ships
text: BEIJING, Nov. 29 — China denied permission for a United States aircraft carrier battle group and other American warships to visit Hong Kong last week because of the Bush administration’s proposal to sell upgrades to Patriot antimissile batteries to Taiwan, Chinese state media said today.

headline: Still No Way Out
text: There has been so much horrible news out of Iraq for so long that it is natural to want to celebrate better news. Sending another 30,000 American troops into Iraq has made life better: attacks are down, as are the number of American and Iraqi casualties. Some refugees are even venturing home. The news has cheered Americans and dampened Democrats’ enthusiasm for keeping up the pressure on Iraq policy. Unfortunately, it is just as important to look at what has not happened since President Bush announced his surge: Iraq’s leaders are no closer to making the political deals that are the only hope for building a self-sustaining peace.

headline: Food Banks, in a Squeeze, Tighten Belts
text: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 26 — Food banks around the country are reporting critical shortages that have forced them to ration supplies, distribute staples usually reserved for disaster relief and in some instances close.

headline: Men Behaving Extremely, With True Believers’ Passion
text: The four men who relate their life stories in “Protagonist,” Jessica Yu’s enthralling documentary exploration of people with obsessive needs for control and self-mastery, are all disillusioned (and extremely articulate) true believers. When they were younger, they were certain they had found the Answer. One embraced terrorism, another crime, a third martial arts and the fourth missionary Christianity as ways of transcending painful, oppressive childhoods that left them with feelings of inadequacy and shame.

headline: Splitting Up a Collection
text: SPLITTING UP

headline: California: City Votes to Restrict Jets
text: The Santa Monica City Council has challenged the Federal Aviation Administration by voting unanimously to ban the fastest jets now flying into the city’s single-runway airport. The new challenge comes in response to concerns among residents and local officials about the potential for aircraft to overrun Santa Monica’s runway. Homes sit as close as 250 feet to landing and departing aircraft. The F.A.A., which signed an agreement with the city in 1984 to prevent Santa Monica from regulating jet traffic, has vowed to fight the ordinance.

headline: From City to City, 20th-Century Art and Furniture
text: December promises to be a big month for 20th-century furniture and decorative arts at fairs, auctions, exhibitions and events around the country. There is even a floating art gallery involved.

headline: China: U.S. Navy Snub Not a ‘Misunderstanding’
text: The Foreign Ministry said China withdrew permission for the United States aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk to visit Hong Kong last week because of the Bush administration’s proposal to sell antimissile upgrades to Taiwan, and not as a result of a “misunderstanding,” as the White House characterized it earlier. The ministry’s spokesman, Liu Jianchao, also said that President Bush’s meeting with the Dalai Lama last month had also damaged ties between the countries.

headline: Nobody’s Home, and the Old House Is Ours Again
text: MAYBE it’s because we crave good apple pie. Or maybe it’s a desire for a bit of peace and quiet. Or maybe we thirst for nature. But whatever it is, once every couple of years, my mother, my father, my brother and I pile into one of our cars and drive east on Long Island on I-495 until we reach the last exit: the North Fork.

headline: Fighting Off Darkness in a New Land of Oz
text: Nearly from the first glimpse, DG, a woman-child with pigtails and a soul-squelching job as a waitress in a rural nowhere, seems like someone who would be happier almost anywhere else. She has a sketch pad and some vague artistic ambition, slouchy trousers and a voice so flat you could lay a lounge chair on it. “This town, that job, taking other people’s orders,” DG tells her parents like an emo-style Stella Dallas, “that’s just passing time.”

headline: Queens: Man Resentenced in Wendy’s Killings
text: A man whose death sentence in the fatal shooting of five people at a Wendy’s restaurant in Flushing was set aside last month by the state’s highest court was resentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole, prosecutors said. The man, John B. Taylor, had been convicted of shooting seven employees at the restaurant on May 24, 2000, after forcing them to kneel at gunpoint inside a basement refrigerator. Prosecutors said Mr. Taylor shot the people to eliminate witnesses of a robbery; two survived. The Court of Appeals had vacated his death sentence in a divided opinion that found the state death penalty statute to be unconstitutional. Yesterday, Mr. Taylor was resentenced in State Supreme Court. His co-defendant, Craig Godineaux, had already been sentenced to life without parole. “Neither will ever again see the light of day,” Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said in a statement.

text: Postgame, it was revealed that Brett Favre also has a separated left shoulder, along with the injury to his right elbow (a sprain that injured a nerve in his funny bone).

headline: Is Romo the Next Favre, or Is Rodgers?
text: At 11-1, the Cowboys are riding high and Tony Romo has stepped into the role of the next Brett Favre. Call it a passing of the torch, of sorts, made even more poignant by the fact that the 38-year-old Favre was banged up by Dallas.

text: Should African women be allowed to engage in the practice sometimes called female circumcision? Are critics of this practice, who call it female genital mutilation, justified in trying to outlaw it, or are they guilty of ignorance and cultural imperialism?

text: While investors cheered AMR‘s decision Wednesday to spin off American Eagle, Reuters said that the parent of American Airlines may have trouble actually completing the deal.

headline: Candover Convinces Opponents to Deliver Stork
text: Candover Partners  announced Wednesday that it had sewn up a 76 percent stake in Dutch industrial group Stork, after enlisting former opponents of its bid to join an improved 1.5 billion euro ($2.2 billion) offer.

headline: Navteq Takes a Hit on EU Scrutiny of Rival’s Deal
text: Shares of digital mapping company Navteq nosedived Wednesday after the European Commission served notice that it would conduct an in-depth, stage-two investigation of the takeover of Navteq’s biggest competitor, Tele Atlas of the Netherlands.

headline: Alliance Data Denies That Blackstone Wants to Rejigger Deal
text: Alliance Data Systems, which manages credit cards for retailers, said it hasn’t been approached by Blackstone Group to renegotiate the terms of its takeover.

headline: Newmont Sell $1.3 Billion of Assets to Franco-Nevada
text: As Newmont Mining prepares to spin off Franco-Nevada in an initial public offering, the world’s No. 2 gold producer on Friday said it agreed to sell its royalty assets and other non-core investments to its subsidiary, in a deal worth about $1.3 billion.

headline: Six Sins of Greenwashing — a Primer
text: Just a quick note. I found an excellent overview of what to look for in a product or service if you’re concerned that its environmental attributes are being oversold.

headline: America loses the wireless race — again
text: I have a T-Mobile cell phone, which uses GSM technology; it works all over the world — and in parts of New Jersey. One of the parts of New Jersey where it doesn’t work happens to be my own home.

headline: Millbrook Capital to Nominate Four for Brink’s Board
text: Millbrook Capital, the activist hedge fund seeking a breakup or sale of the Brink’s Company, is expected to announce its four nominees Friday for directors of the security company, The New York Times reported.

headline: Clean Tech Investments Soar
text: Clean-technology investments by U.S. venture capital firms reached $2.6 billion in the first three quarters of 2007, the highest dollar volume ever by U.S. firms and a 46 percent increase over clean tech investments for all of 2006.

headline: Florida Freezes Its Fund as Governments Pull Out
text: Seeking to stem a multibillion-dollar run on an investment pool for local governments, top Florida officials voted Thursday to suspend withdrawals from the fund, leaving some towns and school districts worrying about how they would pay their bills.

headline: VCs Sample Gilt Groupe
text: Fashionistas jonesing for a high-end designer fix now have a discount online dealer-if they can score an invitation.

headline: China Railway Said to Raise $2.5 Billion in Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: Hot on the heels of its $3 billion initial public offering in Shanghai last week, China Railway Group, the world’s third-largest construction company, raised more than 19.22 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.5 billion), pricing a Hong Kong share sale at the top end, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: 2 Hedge Funds Flail, Even Without Subprime
text: A pair of hedge funds that are getting battered by the choppy markets of the past few months are serving as a stark reminder that the pain inflicted on the once white-hot hedge-fund sector isn’t only confined to those with subprime-bond exposure, the New York Post noted.

headline: Friday’s Links: Thoughts on Creativity
text: When I’m stuck for ideas, I usually hit one of my two standbys — the shower or the streets. They say that standing under running water does something to stimulate creative thought. And a good walk, or any kind of exercise, often does the same thing. But these are pretty vanilla methods, and keeping in touch with creativity is far more complex. Here’s two resources to get you thinking:

text: Before E*Trade Financial agreed to a deal with the Citadel Investment Group, the hedge fund run by Kenneth C. Griffith, a parade of almost 40 other suitors had come calling.

headline: Fortis Plans $3.7 Billion Bond Sale to Fund ABN Deal
text: Fortis, part of the group that bought ABN Amro in Europe’s biggest-ever banking takeover, is raising 2.5 billion euros ($3.7 billion) by selling bonds convertible into shares to help pay for the purchase.

headline: Has Lampert Cut Too Much at Sears?
text: Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire financier and chairman of Sears Holdings, is fond of saying that a company must be regularly “pruned,” like a tree or a wardrobe. But “you can’t cut your way to success,” he warned investors in his annual letter this year.

headline: Snubbed in Scotland: Trump’s Golf Megaresort
text: Hmm. Are we sure Bill Forsyth didn’t script this news? It plays a lot like “Local Hero“: A flamboyant American billionaire accustomed to getting his own way cooks up a grandiose development scheme for a pristine stretch of the Scottish coast, and though the locals are sorley tempted by the money, they decide to preserve what they have and thwart the developer in the last reel.

headline: Deal Value Falls 71 Percent Fall in November, Report Finds
text: The value of announced U.S. mergers and acquisitions fell 71 percent in November to $58.1 billion when compared to the same month last year, Reuters reported, quoting a report by Dealogic, the research firm.

headline: Whither ‘Lars’?
text: Before the showing of “Sweeney” at the Lincoln Square Loews, the Bagger met up with David Poland for some food at Ollie’s. It’s a perfect pre-movie spot because they feed you in much the same way that geese are engorged in order to produce foie gras. A funnel is inserted and you are filled to the brim within a matter of minutes. Poland and the Bagger thought about doing a “Lunch with David” meets Carpetbagger video , but that seemed a little too meta, so we just ate and talked movies instead.

The Bagger has not had the pleasure and has kept his eyes crossed while reading the reviews because he has heard the movie is full of surprises and wants to keep it that way.

headline: The Early Word: Don’t Take Giuliani’s Word

But a presidential candidate who throws statistics around as much as Mr. Giuliani does might want to make sure that those figures are accurate, writes Michael Cooper of the New York Times.

From where the Bagger sat, which was very close to the front, it seemed as if it had been filmed entirely on location in the Red Sea, but then he faints when a knee scab comes loose.
