headline: Future Remains Bright for Oregon’s Dixon
text: One of the most gut-wrenching storylines of this college football season has been the downfall of Oregon quarterback Dennis Dixon. With one twist of a knee, he went from being a favorite for the Heisman Trophy and having his team on track for the national title to being out for the season with an uncertain football future. The reality is especially tough because Dixon risked further injury by playing with a torn anterior cruciate ligament.

text: While Hawaii’s games are usually last-call fodder for folks on the East Coast, they’re really evening games in Honolulu. That gives the Hawaii team all day on Saturday to digest and analyze games around the country as they await kickoff.

headline: Meet Coach Rod
text: MORGANTOWN, W. Va. — College football fans across the United States about to get to know West Virginia Coach Rich Rodriguez a lot better. And boy, are they going to like him. Rodriguez could win a charm-off with just about any coach in America this side of Bobby Bowden. (If Ohio State goes to the national title game, Jim Tressel would be a six-touchdown underdog to win any of the news conferences.) Coach Rod, as he’s know in these parts, has a folksy twang, uses the word “ain’t” liberally and isn’t afraid to make a joke or two.

headline: Obama and Bloomberg’s Breakfast Date
text: Just as developments in the real presidential race threaten to overshadow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s status as the $1 billion question mark hovering over the contest, comes this: a showy breakfast meeting with Senator Barack Obama at a midtown coffee shop earlier today.

headline: Page Two
text: The Baguette also caught up with Ellen Page, the diminutive star of “Juno” who won the award for breakthrough actor at the Gothams. We thought it might be good to check in on a girl we will be seeing a lot of in the next few months.

headline: Indie Redux
text: There was a lot of debate at the Gothams the other night about the definition and application of the word “independent,” so the Baguette asked Sidney Lumet, the director of “Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead” and winner in the ensemble category, what he thinks qualifies. “I don’t think anything’s truly independent anymore,” he said.

headline: 50 Sense
text: Ever wonder who the smartest 50 people in Hollywood are? The Bagger hasn’t either, but he still read EW’s list with a quickness. Judd Apatow topped the list, and it’s hard to argue with somebody who has cracked the code on making good movies that people actually pay money to see. But the Bagger visited Mr. Apatow a while back in his nothing-special Santa Monica office and he can say with certainty that Mr. Apatow is a little on the normal side to be on the top of any list of big cigars.

headline: A Cameo Interview
text: The Reeler talks with Max von Sydow, who makes a brief appearance in “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly” as the father of Jean-Dominique Bauby, the Elle magazine editor who became locked in his own body and built a route back to the world. Mr. von Sydow said the reason he doesn’t work much anymore is not his age — 78 — but because a lot of the scripts that come his way, um, suck.

headline: When Stem Cell Research Gets Personal
text: The report last week that scientists had turned human skin cells into embryonic stem cells without having to make or destroy an embryo has a couple of heavy-hitter pundits with strong personal interests in such issues to square off. “Even a scientist who cares not a whit about the morality of embryo destruction will adopt this technique because it is so simple and powerful,” writes Charles Krauthammer, who has been confined to a wheelchair by a spinal cord injury for most of his adult life, in The Washington Post.

headline: Clinton Campaign Calls Obama Health Care Ad Misleading
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign, which is now attacking Senator Barack Obama on a daily basis, this morning called on the Obama campaign to stop running a campaign television commercial in New Hampshire that asserts that his health insurance plan will cover all Americans.

headline: Luxe In Translation | Hindi
text: T presents a series of “essential” foreign phrases. The first lesson is for weary travelers who find themselves in New Delhi, where the herbal oils used in even five-star ayurvedic massages can sometimes pack a wallop to rival a vindaloo.

headline: Facebook: What Would Google Do?
text: From its spare white layout to its audacious growth plans, a lot of Facebook’s moves seem copied from Google’s playbook. But as I look at the spurt of Facebook news this week, it leaves me wondering how Google would have handled the same situations.

headline: An Air of Expectation
text: Tim Burton was jittery when the Baguette interviewed him recently but who could blame him? He’s got both a movie — “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street,” and a baby — with Helena Bonham Carter — making an appearance in the world about the same time. “I’m a bit nervous about both I guess,” Mr. Burton said.Ms. Carter co-stars in “Sweeney” as Mrs. Lovett, and Sacha Baron Cohen plays looney rival barber Signor Adolfo Pirelli. The Baguette asked Mr. Burton about casting non-singers in the title roles of the film.“It gives the film, I think an extra layer of something that you don’t necessarily get from the stage,” which led the Baguette to ask about the casting of Mr. Cohen, who inhabited a similarly over-the-top persona as Borat.“Sacha, he’s great! I’ll never forget it, he came in to audition and he had the book for ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ and basically did pretty much the whole song book,” Mr. Burton said. “I knew he could do it. He has no fear.”Mr. Burton’s most palpable fears involved Stephen Sondheim’s reaction to his film. “I was so nervous. I think I was more nervous showing it to him than anybody.”Before they showed the movie to Mr. Sondheim he told the producers, “You show him the movie. I’ll be down at the pub down the street.” Mr. Burton said he was relieved that Mr. Sondheim liked the film. “He was extremely positive.”As the Bagger mentioned, the movie has a rather crimson palette.“We tried to use a bright color red, you know, because it’s Christmas.”

headline: Stealthy Virtues
text: Could it be that the best way to campaign for an Oscar is not to campaign? The Hollywood Reporter suggests that Focus Features has decided the best way to make sure “Atonement” gets a fair shake is to keep its pie-hole closed.

headline: To Save the Polar Bears, Ride a Cub
text: Beyond being the quickest way to telegraph to fellow highway travelers that you enjoy macrobiotic salads and care about the environment, the Toyota Prius gets pretty good gas mileage. But it’s still not as good as the E.P.A. would have you believe.

headline: Through Two Rounds of the World Cup, a Big Upset and a Heartbreaking Loss
Please Explain
text: Paul and I are planning our next trip to Anna Maria. We’re going to be there for an entire week, from Dec. 8 to 15, to make another round of decisions that can only really be done on site. For this trip we’ve rented a house. Also, some of our family — my brother and his wife, and my father and stepmother — will be joining us.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: The Conference Title Games
text: So it comes down to this. Pete and Thayer are locked in a fierce competition to see who will end the season with the best record. Meanwhile, I’m trailing far behind, sort of like Vanderbilt in the SEC. Oh well, I can always redeem myself during the bowl season. Or not. Still, this weekend promises to be another entertaining one, with plenty of games with national implications. Disagree with any of the picks? Feel free to let us know.

headline: East to Meet West
text: Sidney Crosby’s Penguins will play Joe Thornton’s Sharks next season. Guaranteed. The N.H.L. Board of Governors made that happen, voting Thursday to scale back the eight games of in-division contests to six, and ensuring that every team plays every other team in the league at least once.

headline: Is the Exaflood Coming?
text: YouTube and its bit-hungry brethren of video, music and social-networking Web sites are surely consuming more of the Internet’s bandwidth. But are we facing a capacity crunch that will soon clog the global network, as it is overwhelmed by what some warn is a coming “exaflood” of demand?

headline: Weekly Matchups: The Final Saturday
text: The last Saturday of the college football season is always filled with intrigue and this one is no different. Allow me to break this down for you and let you know what you’re in for. Let’s see, depending on how hard-core you are, you could peek in at the MAC Championship game at 11, but I imagine most of you will start with a look in at Army-Navy at noon. That one segues nicely into the A.C.C. title game at 1, which is about when you should be starting to hit your college football-viewing stride.

headline: Ratings: Reruns Return and Reality Emerges
text: With the November “sweeps” period over, the reruns have returned, and along with them, ratings for the leading networks on Thursday, ABC and CBS, plummeted accordingly. NBC and Fox, meanwhile, failed to make up much of any ground.

headline: Euro 2008 Draw Live on ESPN

text: In his Web column today, Carl Hulse writes that Senator Trent Lott’s decision to retire before the end of his term is unusual in Senate history, but the “draw of the dollar on K Street is strong.” Go to column

headline: The Style Equation | Stella bag
text: Be it a work of fashion, art or home design, in an era of hyper-vigilant P.R., a designer’s “inspirations” aren’t nearly as fun — or accurate — as guessing at them. Here, in The Moment’s The Style Equation column, we use a rudimentary calculation to reduce a new design object to the sum of its parts. First up, the new Stella McCartney ruck sack.

headline: Mets Trade Milledge to Nationals
text: The news: Omar Minaya & Co. pulled off an interesting trade today, acquiring catcher Brian Schneider and outfielder Ryan Church from Washington in exchange for Lastings Milledge. Minaya is familiar with both players from his days as the Expos’ GM, trading for Church in 2004.

headline: E*Trade’s Deal Fails to Impress
text: Despite E*Trade Financial‘s proclamation that its $2.55 billion deal with Citadel Investment Group should ease fears about its financial health, it appears few are listening.

headline: Answers From the Urban Rodentologist, Part 3
text: Following is a third and final set of answers from Robert M. Corrigan, a well-known urban rodentologist and research scientist for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene who took questions on the City Room blog from Nov. 26-30. Previous sets of answers from Dr. Corrigan were posted on Wednesday and Thursday.

headline: First Impressions: dell’Anima
text: You can pack a lot of trends into a little space, and dell’Anima is proof of it.

headline: Coke Is Holding Off on Sipping Facebook’s Beacon
text: At Facebook’s Nov. 6 extravaganza to introduce its new social advertising features, I asked the first question after the speech of Mark Zuckerberg, the company’s 23-year-old chief executive. I asked why he thought lots of users would want to have information about their purchases sent to their Facebook friends through the company’s new system called Beacon.

headline: Romney Demurs on Giuliani Expense Issue
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Maybe they are pals after all.

headline: D.N.C. Fall Meeting Ends on Difficult Note
text: VIENNA, Va. — Worry and disappointment weighed heavy in the ballroom of the Sheraton Premiere hotel during the afternoon session of the Democratic National Committee fall meeting after Chairman Howard Dean announced that Hillary Rodham Clinton had cancelled her speech because of the hostage situation at her campaign office in Rochester, N.H.

headline: Clinton Office Standoff Ends
text: 6:53 p.m. Less than an hour after the standoff ended, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton emerged from her home in Washington to make a statement and answer a few questions about the situation.

headline: Where’s the Party?
Q & A: David Downton
text: I first met David Downton maybe five years ago at a showing of his drawings in Paris. His subject was Erin O’Connor. You might say David, who is English, has an obsession with Erin’s long neck and lines. Well, she was meant for charcoal. Shortly after that meeting, I asked him to sketch a Dior couture dress in the studio, for a story about the making of a collection. Our link then and now was our admiration for the work of Joe Eula, and a fascination with the man. I got to know Joe well and in the last years of his life we worked together on a number of illustrated articles for the Times, including one about the denizens of the back track at Belmont. This past January, at the Dior show, David told me he was planning to bring out a magazine of fashion illustration and asked if I’d write something about Joe. Issue #1 of Pourquoi Pas? has drawings by Rene Gruau, Eula, Richard Gray, Jason Brooks, with illustrations by David of Amanda Harlech, Jade Parfitt, and Carmen Dell’ Orefice. Among the writers contributing are Sarah Mower, Tony Glenville and Tim Blanks. The 72-page magazine is on heavy stock, costs about $40, and is available at pqpmagazine.com. David and I chatted by phone a few days ago.

headline: For Fund, a New Focus on Corporate Bond Trouble
text: John Paulson has made billions of dollars betting against subprime mortgages. Now the short-selling hedge fund manager is training his sights on corporate bonds as he expects a recession.

headline: A Jackpot for Unions?: Organizing Indian Casinos
text: With unions in a prolonged decline, there has not been a lot of good news lately for the labor movement. But there was some last month in Connecticut — a modest jackpot, so to speak.

headline: Kefi on the Move
text: The casual Greek restaurant Kefi, a big hit on West 79th Street, won’t stay there too long. In a telephone conversation I had today with its chef-owner, Michael Psilakis, he told me that he is definitely — no question about it — moving the restaurant into a much bigger space next year. He guessed that this would happen sometime around the middle of the year.

headline: Trying Times for Wall Street’s Top Women
text: When Zoe Cruz, who headed Morgan Stanley‘s trading and risk operations, was forced into early retirement Thursday, an era quietly closed.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 30
text: Here is a slide show of 12 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include shopping on Black Friday, the end of the stagehands’ strike on Broadway and the indictment of Brooke Astor’s son, Anthony.

headline: The Case of the Vanishing Jobs
text: The most important economic statistic this week is one that appears to be months old. It is the revision of the government’s estimate of wage and salary income in the second quarter.

text: The first annual JAM Awards welcomed Snoop Dogg, LL Cool J and DMC to the Hammerstein Ballroom. Melena Ryzik of The Times reports.
